edition.title: 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i rgyud
edition.author: bcom ldan 'das

f.d: @##/ /rgya gar skad du/ Ar+ya many+dzu shrI mU la tan+t+ra/ bod skad du/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i rgyud/

d.crumb: The Root Manual of the Rites of Mañjuśrī

f.d: The Root Manual of the Rites of Mañjuśrī
sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Oṁ, homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas!
'dus pa'i le'u
Chapter 1

'di skad bdag gis thos pa dus gcig na/ bcom ldan 'das gnas gtsang ma'i steng gi nam mkha'i dkyil na/ byang chub sems dpa' 'dus pa'i 'khor gyi tshogs so so tha dad pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa ngo mtshar rmad du byung ba/ so sor rab tu gnas pa dang thabs cig tu bzhugs te/ de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu rnams la bka' stsal pa/

Thus did I hear at one time. Lord Śākyamuni dwelt above the Pure Abode, in an inconceivable, wondrous pavilion, circular in shape, with a congregation of bodhisattvas[9] distributed all around, located in the canopy of the sky. There the Lord addressed the gods of the Pure Abode:

lha'i bu dag khyed cag nyon cig / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i cho 'phrul gyi spyod pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa ngo mtshar rmad du byung ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi bye brag dang / rdzu 'phrul dang / rnam par thar pa'i dkyil 'khor byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par 'phrul pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi nye bar 'tsho ba/ tshe dang nad med pa dang dbang phyug dang / yid la bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par byed pa'i sngags kyi gzhi dag sems can rnams la phan pa'i phyir bshad par bya ste/ de shin du legs par nyon la yid la zung shig dang / ngas bshad par bya'o/ /

“Honored gods! Listen as I tell of the inconceivable, wondrous miracles of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, bodhisattva, and great being‍—listen as I tell of his conduct, different types of samādhi, and magical power; his liberation, maṇḍala, and his miraculous bodhisattva manifestations; and how he is the sustenance for all beings and brings them life, health, and sovereignty! I will explain, for the benefit of all beings, the mantra subjects that completely fulfill one’s wishes. Listen well and duly reflect upon it‍—I will now tell you about him.”

de nas gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu de dag gis thal mo sbyar ba btud nas/ bcom ldan 'das la legs so zhes gsol te/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi spyod pa ting nge 'dzin gyi khyad par dang / sa chen po thob par bya ba dang / rdo rje'i gdan gnon pa dang / bdud gdul ba dang / chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba dang / nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad kyi nges par 'byung ba dang / lha rnams dang mi rnams su skye bar bya ba dang / sdug bsngal dang / dbul ba dang / nad thams cad zhi bar byed pa/ longs spyod kyis phyug pa 'dren par byed pa/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags kyi spyod pas phongs par mi byed pa/ re ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi gsung 'bras bu med par byed pa ma yin pa/ bcom ldan 'das kyis byams pa'i thugs dang / phan pa'i thugs dang bdag dang sems can thams cad la thugs brtse ba nye bar bzung nas bcom ldan 'das de bshad du gsol/

Thereupon the gods of the Pure Abode, folding their hands, said:[10] “Then tell us, Lord, about the conduct of the bodhisattvas; their different samādhis and their attainment of the bodhisattva levels; their sitting upon the vajra throne, overpowering of Māra, and turning of the wheel of Dharma; their liberating of all śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas; their ensuring for all beings rebirth as a god or a human and the pacification of all suffering; their removal of diseases of the poor, sick, and wealthy alike; their invulnerability to the use of all mundane and supramundane mantras; and their fulfilling of all wishes that thus makes the speech of all the tathāgatas fruitful.[11] Lord, speak with a mind full of love and concern for our welfare, and out of pity for all sentient beings.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor rnams dang gnas gtsang ma'i gnas la sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis gzigs nas/ dag pa'i yul la 'od rnam par spros te/ yul rnam par 'jigs pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ / bcom ldan 'das snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu mdzod spu nas me tog kun tu skyes pa zhes bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' yang dag par bskul ba zhes bya ba'i 'od phyung ste/ 'od bye ba khrag khrig phrag brgya stong du ma'i 'khor gyis bcom ldan 'das la lan gsum bskor ba byas nas/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams su song nas/ byang shar gyi phyogs su brgya stong gi gang gA'i klung gi 'jig rten gyi khams 'das nas/ me tog dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i 'jig rten gyi khams su rjes su zhugs te/ gang na me tog kun du skyes pa'i rgyal po'i dbang po zhes bya ba'i de bzhin gshegs pa bzhugs par ro/ /

Then Lord Śākyamuni, casting a glance with his buddha eye over the entire realm of the Pure Abode, entered the samādhi called the spreading and diffusing of the light of the pure sphere.[12] As soon as the Lord entered this samādhi, out of his ūrṇā came an array of light rays called arouser of the bodhisattva Saṃkusumita;[13] he was surrounded by many hundreds of thousands of millions of rays. The light circumambulated the Buddha three times and, having passed through billions of trichiliocosms and crossed as many worlds in the northeastern direction as there are grains of sand in one hundred thousand Gaṅgā rivers, it came to the world sphere called Kusumāvatī, where the tathāgata Saṃkusumita Rājendra was staying.

der yang 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa sngon gyi smon lam gyi dbang gis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po'i spyod pa dang ldan pa rnams dang lhan cig gnas par gyur to/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas 'od zer gyi snang ba de mthong nas/ bzhin cung zad 'dzum pa dang ldan par gyur nas byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs de dag la smras pa/ rgyal ba'i sras dag 'od 'di ni nga la yang dag par bskul ba'i phyir 'ongs pa yin gyis/ khyed cag g.yeng ba med par gyis shig ces smras so/ /

Due to the power of his previous aspirations, Mañjuśrī was also staying there together with other bodhisattvas, great beings engaged in bodhisattva activity. Seeing this effulgence of light, he gently smiled and addressed the multitude of bodhisattvas: “This arousing ray of light, O sons of the victorious ones, has come here to wake me up. Do pay attention!”

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa mig mi 'dzums shing kha bye bas/ 'od gang na ba de logs su mngon du bltas nas 'dug go/ / de nas bskul ba'i 'od des me tog dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i 'jig rten gyi khams snang ba chen pos snang bar byas te/ me tog kun du skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pa la lan gsum bskor ba byas te/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i spyi bor nub par gyur to/ /

Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, the bodhisattva, the great being, with his eyes wide and unblinking, sat facing the radiance of the ray. And this arousing ray, illuminating the Kusumāvatī world sphere with great radiance, circumambulated the thus-gone lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra clockwise three times and dissolved into the head of the great being, the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī.

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa stan las langs te/ bcom ldan 'das me tog kun du yang dag par skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pa la lan gsum bskor ba byas te/ spyi bos phyag 'tshal nas/ pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs te/ bcom ldan 'das me tog kun du skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po la 'di skad ces gsol to/ /

The divine youth Mañjuśrī then got up from his seat and circumambulated the thus-gone lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra three times. Then, bowing his head and placing his right knee on the ground, he spoke to Lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra:

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa zhes bya ba de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyis bdag la dgongs te/ bcom ldan 'das bdag ni bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la blta ba dang phyag bya ba dang bsnyen bkur bya ba dang / sngags thams cad kyi spyod pa dang / sgrub thabs dang / dkyil 'khor dang / cho ga dang / gsang ba dang / cho ga zhib mo dang / cho ga'i ngo bo dang / de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi thugs dang / gsang ba dang / phyag rgya dang / dbang bskur ba bstan pa dang / sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir/ mi mjed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams 'di nas mchi bar 'tshal lo/ /

“May Lord Śākyamuni, the tathāgata, the arhat, the completely awakened one, think of me. Let me go, O lord, from here to the Sahā world sphere to see Lord Śākyamuni, to honor him and serve him. Let me go so that he may instruct me in the mantra practice, the sādhana practice, and the procedure of constructing the right maṇḍala; the secrets of the ritual and the procedure of drawing the picture; and the secret mudrā empowerment into the heart of all the tathāgatas, so that all the wishes of all beings are fulfilled.” [14]

de skad ces bcom ldan 'das me tog kun du skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pa la gsol pa dang / … …'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa ting nge 'dzin gang la snyoms par zhugs pa na/ … …'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ /
Being so addressed, … … … … …the thus-gone lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth:

'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa de'i dus la bab par shes na song shig / 'on kyang nga'i bkas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la gnod pa nyung ngam/ nyam nga ba chung ngam/ bskyod pa yang ngam/ bde ba la reg par gnas sam zhes zhu bar bya'o/ /

“You may go, divine youth Mañjuśrī, if you think that this is the right time. And please ask Lord Śākyamuni, on my behalf, if he is without pain and without worry, if his efforts come easily to him, and if his life is comfortable.”
de nas bcom ldan 'das me tog yang dag par skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ /
Then, the thus-gone lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra [15] further said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth:

gzhan yang gzhon nu gang gA'i klung brgya stong gi bye ma snyed kyi de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyis khyod kyi sngags kyi spyod pa dang / dkyil 'khor dang cho ga zhib mo dang gsang ba dang / dbang bskur ba dang phyag rgya'i tshogs dang cho ga dang sbyin sreg dang / bzlas pa dang brtul zhugs bsam pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa sems can thams cad dga' bar byed pa/ 'od rin po che'i tshogs kyis rab 'byam 'das pa dang da ltar byung ba dang ma 'ongs pa'i shes pa rgyal po'i dbang phyug lung ston par byed pa/ sngags bzla ba yul gyi mthar 'gro bar byed pa mi snang bar byed pa dang / dus dang dam tshig rab 'byam gyi tshogs thams cad dang / 'jig rten pa ma lus pa dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sangs rgyas dang / byang chub sems dpa' dang 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi nges par 'byung ba'i spyod pa mthar thug pa gsungs pa dang / gsung ba dang / gsung bar 'gyur ba yin te/ de ltar rjes su yi rang ba nyid de/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa de'i dus la bab par shes na song shig / shAkya thub pa'i spyan sngar mngon sum du chos kyi rnam grangs 'di thos par 'gyur te/ khyod kyang ston par 'gyur ro/ / 'dir yang gsungs pa/

“Also, O divine youth, the tathāgatas, the arhats, the completely awakened ones, numerous as grains of sand in one hundred thousand Gaṅgā rivers, have taught and will teach again of your proficiency in mantra practice, maṇḍala ritual, the secret empowerment, the mudrās, the picture drawing procedure, the homa rite, the mantra recitation, and the regular observations, all of which fulfill every wish and bring joy to every being. They will teach of your proficiency in the vast fields of astrology and gemology; of your knowledge of the past, present, and future; and of your ability to govern and make predictions. They will teach of your mantra repetition, your ability to travel to the ends of the earth and to become invisible, and your vast knowledge of the right time and occasion for anything. They will teach how to traverse all the stages of the buddhas, bodhisattvas, śrāvakas, and pratyekabuddhas, and all the mundane and supramundane stages without exception. They will teach the way in which you are established in the practice of all of these. So that I too may rejoice, please go Mañjuśrī, O divine youth, if you think that the time is right. You will hear these teachings in the presence of Śākyamuni, face to face with him, and you will later give them yourself. The mantra for this is as follows:
na maHsarba ta thA ga tA nAM/ a tsin t+ya a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ oM sma ra sma ra a pra ti ha ta shA sa na ku mA ra rU pa ha ri Na/ oM hU~M hU~M phaT phaT swA hA/
“Homage to all the tathāgatas whose instructions are inconceivable and perfect! “Oṁ, ra ra! Do remember! O perfect teacher possessing the form of a divine youth! Hūṁ hūṁ! Phaṭ phaṭ! Svāhā![16]

'di ni 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i rtsa ba'i sngags so/ / de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi snying po ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis gsungs la/ gsung zhing gsung bar 'gyur la/ khyod kyang mi mjed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams su song nas/ dbye ba dang rnam par dbye ba rgya cher ston par 'gyur te/ de bzhin gshegs pa shAkya thub pa zhes bya bas kyang las thams cad byed pa 'di rjes su gnang bar 'gyur ro/ / 'dir snying po mchog tu gyur pa ni/

“This was, O divine youth Mañjuśrī, the root mantra. It is the heart essence of all the tathāgatas, and it was and will be[17] recited by them. You will also now recite this, the all-accomplishing mantra, together with all its parts, having arrived in the Sahā world. This has been sanctioned by Śākyamuni. Here, the ultimate heart mantra is:
oM bA kye daM na maH/
“Oṁ, this [mantra] is [my] homage to speech![18]
'dir nye ba'i snying po ni
“The subsidiary heart mantra in this set is:
bA kye hUM/
“Speech, hūṁ!”[19]

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa bcom ldan 'das me tog yang dag par skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pas gnang nas/ bkod pa thams cad kyi rgyan byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dang rgyu mthun pa/ byang chub kyi snying po thob pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ /

Lord Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, being thus granted leave by Saṃkusumita Rājendra, the tathāgata, entered the samādhi called the ornament of all supernal manifestations that brings the attainment of the essence of awakening which is a product of the conduct of a bodhisattva.
As soon as Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, entered this samādhi,
phyogs bzhi mtha' yas mu med pa steng dang 'og dang thad ka thams cad dang ldan pa'i phyogs sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis yang dag par gang bar gyur to/ /
the world sphere with all its directions‍—above, below, and across‍—up to its farthest reaches, became filled with lord buddhas.
Saṃkusumita Rājendra then said:

'jig rten gyi khams de dang bcom ldan 'das dang bcas pas/ rgyal ba'i sras legs so legs so/ / 'di lta bu'i ting nge 'dzin gyi khyad par la snyoms par zhugs pa ni/ nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad kyis kyang mi nus/ byang chub sems dpa' spyod pa la zhugs pa dang / sa bcu la gnas pa dag gis kyang snyoms par zhugs par mi nus so/ /

“Good, good it is, O son of the Victorious One, that you have entered this particular samādhi! No śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, or bodhisattvas who are established in the perfect conduct, not even those on the tenth bodhisattva level, are able to enter this samādhi.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das me tog kun du yang dag par skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de rnams dang lhan cig tu yang dag par bgros te/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa 'di'i snying po mchog tu gsang ba/ don thams cad sgrub pa'i snying po gsungs pa ni yi ge gcig pa zhes bya ba mchog tu gsang ba/ sems can thams cad kyi las thams cad byed pa sngags kyi spyod pa khyad par can bzang po yang sgrub par byed pa'o/ /

Then Saṃkusumita Rājendra, having conferred with the lord buddhas, the tathāgatas, taught the following mantra of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth‍—his ultimately secret, innermost heart essence that accomplishes all purposes. This most secret, divine mantra, called One Syllable,[20] which serves the interests of all beings, is also fit to accomplish the special mantra practice.[21]

de nas bcom ldan 'das me tog yang dag par skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pa yud tsam zhig cang mi gsung bar gyur te/ thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'jig rten thams cad la sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis gzigs te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag la yang yang dag par dgongs nas/ byams pa'i thugs kyis sngags gsungs so/ /

Lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra, the tathāgata, became quiet for a moment. Looking with his buddha eye over all the world spheres, he considered all the lord buddhas dwelling there, and with a mind filled with love, pronounced the mantra:[22]
na maHsarba bud+d+hA nAM aM maM/
“Homage to all the buddhas! “Oṁ maṁ!”[23]
'di ni 'jam dpal gyi snying po mchog yin te las thams cad byed pa'o/ /
“This mantra is the ultimate heart essence of Mañjuśrī, which accomplishes all endeavors.”

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa ting nge 'dzin de las langs nas/ dper na skyes bu stobs dang ldan pa lag pa bskum pa las brkyang ba dang / brkyang ba las bskum pa'am sel gol gtogs pa tsam mam/ mig 'byed 'dzums tsam la rdzu 'phrul gyi stobs kyi shugs blo ting nge 'dzin ces bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi khyad par rnam par 'phrul pa zhes bya ba la snyoms par zhugs te/ mi mjed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams su chas te slar 'khod nas/ steng gi nam mkha'i dkyil na nor bu rin po che rab tu gnas pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha rnams gnas su 'dug ste/ gnas gtsang ma'i gnas de thams cad 'od chen po'i snang bas gsal bar byas te/ 'od kyi rin po ches rab tu brgyan cing gsal ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ /

Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, arose from the aforementioned samādhi and performed, in the time that it takes a strong person to bend or to extend their arm, or to snap their fingers, or to close and open their eyes, the miraculous, special samādhi called the intellect with the force of magical power, and went to the Sahā world. Having arrived there, he established himself in the palace of the gods of the Pure Abode founded upon fine jewels and gems in the canopy of the sky. Illuminating this entire realm of the Pure Abode with powerful rays of light, he entered the samādhi called the illuminator adorned with brilliant jewels.

'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu … rin po che rnam pa tha dad pa du ma'i khang pa brtsegs pa dang / rin po che'i gdugs dang dpag tshad brgya stong phrag du ma rgya che ba'i lha'i gos dang / dar mang po'i tshogs kyis nye bar mdzes par byas pa'i… bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la mchod pa bya ba'i phyir… lha'i me tog rnam par bkod pa dang / rgyal mtshan dang ba dan dang phreng ba'i tshogs dang / rin po che'i dril bu'i dra bas 'brel pa snyan pa'i sgra sgrogs pa/ phyir mi ldog pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i sa thob par byed pa/ lha'i dri dang byug pa dang phreng ba dang phye ma'i char 'bab par mngon par sprul to/ /

As soon as Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, entered this samādhi, he manifested through the power of bodhisattva transformation, for the worship of Lord Śākyamuni, a divinely created palace sumptuously studded with many gems and adorned with jeweled parasols spanning many hundred of thousands of leagues; bedecked with divinely beautiful great bundles of silk streamers; decorated with celestial flowers, banners, flags, garlands, and jewels; and pleasant with the sweet sound of draperies of latticed wind-chimes. Also, in the act of worshiping Lord Śākyamuni, he manifested a copious rain of perfume, garlands, ointments, wreaths, and scented powders.

de nas gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu rnams kyis byang chub sems dpa'i ngo mtshar rmad du byung ba'i cho 'phrul gyi rnam par 'phrul pa mthong nas/ ba spu ldang zhing gnas g.yo ba mthong nas snying 'dar zhing dngangs te/ ci bdag cag gi 'byor pa nyams par ma gyur tam zhes phan tshun du rings par 'gro zhing skad mthon pos smra ba rtsom par byed de/ 'di skad du bcom ldan 'das yongs su bskyab tu gsol/ / shAkya thub pa yongs su bskyab tu gsol zhes gsol to/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i 'khor rnams la bka' stsal pa/ grogs po dag ma 'jigs shig ma 'jigs shig / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa 'di ni me tog yang dag par skyes pa'i rgyal po de bzhin gshegs pa de'i spyan snga nas nga la blta ba dang / phyag bya ba dang bsnyen bkur bya ba dang / don chen po'i spyod pa dang sngags kyi tshig dang / rgya che zhing rmad du byung ba'i chos kyi tshig ston pa'i phyir 'ongs pa yin no/ / de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la lan gsum bskor ba byas te/ mig mi 'dzums par bcom ldan 'das la blta zhing zhabs gnyis la btud de/ tshig 'bru 'di dag gis bcom ldan 'das la bstod pa/ /

Seeing this extraordinary and marvelous display‍—a miracle of a bodhisattva‍—the hair of the gods of the Pure Abode stood on end in excitement. When, however, they saw their abodes trembling, their hearts became tormented and pained. They immediately began to wail loudly, with a sense of great urgency, “Oh, what can this be? Could it be that we are being deprived of our divine powers?” And they implored, “Please protect us, Lord! Please protect us, Śākyamuni!” Lord Śākyamuni then addressed the entire assembly of the gods of the Pure Abode: “Do not be afraid, friends! Do not be afraid! Mañjuśrī, the divine youth present here, the bodhisattva, the great being, has come here from the presence of the tathāgata Saṃkusumita Rājendra in the buddhafield Saṃkusumita, in order to see, worship, and serve me. He has come to teach the conduct of great purpose, the mantra subjects, and the vast and amazing Dharma subjects.” The divine youth Mañjuśrī, in turn, circumambulated Lord Śākyamuni three times and, looking at him with unblinking eyes, bowed down to his feet and praised him with these succinct words:
skyes bu bskyed pa khyod phyag 'tshal/ / skyes mchog khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / skyes bu gtso bo khyod phyag 'tshal/ / spyod pa thams cad don sgrub pa/ /
“Homage to you, the liberated one not subject to birth! Homage to you, the best among men! Homage to you, the elder of men, Who accomplishes all purposes of [mantra][24] conduct!
skyes bu seng ge khyod phyag 'tshal/ / phung khrol thams cad zlog byed pa/ / dpa' bo chen po khyod phyag 'tshal/ / ngan 'gro thams cad 'jig byed pa/ /
“Homage to you, O lion of a man, Who prevents anything undesirable from occurring! Homage to you, the great hero Who eliminates all evil destinies!
skyes bu pad dkar khyod phyag 'tshal/ / kun nas bsod nams dri ldan pa/ / skyes bu pad+ma khyod phyag 'tshal/ / srid gsum 'dam ni rnam dag byed/ /
“Homage to you, white lotus of a man, Who is fragrant with the scent of merit! Homage to you, O lotus of a man, Who purifies the mire of the three types of existence!
rnam grol khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sdug bsngal ma lus rnam grol byed/ / zhi gyur khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / thams cad ldan pa legs 'dul byed/ /
“Homage to you, O liberated one, Who delivers from all pain! Homage to you, the tranquil one Who perfectly tames all the untamed ones!
thams cad grub pa khyod phyag 'tshal/ / sngags kyi spyod pa'i don sgrub byed/ / bkra shis khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / bkra shis kun gyi bkra shis pa/ /
“Homage to you, the accomplished one Who fulfills the purpose of all mantra practice! Homage to you, the auspicious one, The most auspicious among all auspicious!
sangs rgyas kun la khyod phyag 'tshal/ / chos kun rnam par rtogs mdzad pa/ /
“Homage to you, the awakened one Who awakens others to the complete truth of the Dharma!
chos thams cad kyi de bzhin nyid spros pa med pa'i ngo bo la yang dag par rjes su zhugs shing ston par byed pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to you, the tathāgata, The one who abides in and teaches The suchness of all phenomena, Which is devoid of conceptual elaboration!

shes pa dang shes bya'i dngos po thams cad dang / 'dus byas dang 'dus ma byas dang / theg pa gsum gyi lam dang / mya ngan las 'das pa'i lam la 'jog par byed pa dang / gnas par byed pa thams cad mkhyen pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo zhes tshig 'bru 'di dag brjod pa'i bstod pa'i tshig gis bcom ldan 'das la mngon sum du bstod nas 'di skad ces gsol to/ /

“Homage to the omniscient one who is established, and is establishing others, in nirvāṇa and in the path of the three vehicles that encompasses all consciousnesses and all knowable objects, both conditioned and unconditioned!” Having praised Lord Śākyamuni in his presence with these words, Mañjuśrī said:

bcom ldan 'das 'di nas gang gA'i klung brgya phrag stong gi bye ma snyed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams 'das nas/ byang shar gyi phyogs mtshams na me tog yang dag par skyes pa zhes bya ba'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing mchis te/ de na me tog dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i 'jig rten gyi khams na gang du bcom ldan 'das me tog yang dag par skyes pa dbang po'i rgyal po de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa bde bar gshegs pa 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa de chos ston te/ thog mar dge ba/ bar du dge ba/ tha mar dge ba/ don bzang po tshig 'bru bzang po/ / ma 'dres pa yongs su rdzogs pa/ yongs su dag pa/ yongs su dkar ba tshangs par spyod pa yang dag par ston to/ / de da ltar bzhugs te 'tsho zhing gzhes la chos kyang ston to/ / sngags kyi spyod pa dang byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod dang / lam gsum gyi spyod pa'i lam sgrub par byed pa/ skyob pa dang gnas dang skyabs dang dpung gnyen dang / bde ba dang shin tu mthar thug pa dang shin tu yongs su mthar phyin par byed pa sems can rnams la ston te/ bcom ldan 'das de nyid kyis rjes su gnang nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs drung 'dir mchis so/ / bcom ldan 'das me tog yang dag par skyes pa rgyal po'i dbang po de yang / bcom ldan 'das la gnod pa nyung ngam/ bskyod pa yang ngam/ bde ba la reg par gnas sam zhes 'dri'o/ / 'di skad kyang gsung ste/

“There is, O lord, in the eastern direction beyond world spheres as numerous as the grains of sand in one hundred thousand Gaṅgā rivers, a buddhafield called Saṃkusumita. There is a world sphere there called Kusumāvatī where the tathāgata Lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra dwells. An arhat, one perfectly awakened, perfected in wisdom and conduct, the bliss-gone one, the supreme knower of the world, the guide of people who need to be tamed, the preceptor of gods and men, he expounds the Dharma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end. He presented an account of the buddha activity[25] that is profoundly meaningful, full of beautiful figures of speech, original, complete, perfectly pure, and highly polished. He is presently living and teaching all sentient beings the Dharma, the bodhisattva basket[26] that pertains to the mantra practice, the path that conforms to the practice of the threefold path, the protection, the place of rest, the refuge, the highest aim, the well-being, and the ultimate and final cessation. It is by his command that I have arrived here in your presence, to be at your feet. Lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra, the tathāgata, asks if you are without pain and without worry, if your efforts come easily to you, and if your life is comfortable. He also said this:

gang du 'di lta bu'i snyigs ma lnga'i dus su sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa 'byung ba ni ngo mtshar to zhes so/ / de yang lam gsum dang byang grol dang mir skye ba thob pa nyid kyi chos ston par byed do/ / gang du'ang sems can gyi ris skal ba med pa dang / srid pa gsum yang dag 'joms par byed pa'i lam dang gtan tu grub pa dang bde ba dang / mthun pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa la sems can rnams dgod par byed pa'i bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i brtson 'grus ni ngo mtshar to/ / bcom ldan 'das bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi thugs ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis mkhyen par 'gyur gyi/ bdag gis ci zhig 'tshal ba rngo thogs/ dbang phyug gis rnam par 'phrul pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ rmad du byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa shes par ram/ 'tshal bar ram/ thugs kyi spyad pa spyod pa'i rjes su 'jug pa'i sgrub pa dang / spyod pa 'tshal bar ram mdor na bskal pa bye ba khri phrag brgya stong gi bar du'ang bstan par mi nus so/ / gang yang de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i mdzad pa bsdus pa'am/ tha dad ma lus pa'i ngo bo 'di ni chos 'dus ma byas su blta bar bya ste/ mthong bas spang bar bya ba la brten pa'am/ yon tan ni bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa kho nas mkhyen pa yin gyi bdag gis ni ma lags so/ /

“ ‘It is indeed wonderful that in this time of the five degenerations Lord Śākyamuni, the awakened one, has appeared and is giving complete Dharma teachings with nothing missing[27]‍—the Dharma that consists of the threefold path and that brings about rebirth as a god or a human and final emancipation. Wonderful indeed is Lord Śākyamuni’s courage, that in this world of helpless beings he establishes them on the path that leads to escape from the three realms, and he also establishes them in the state of nirvāṇa, which is complete with boundless spiritual accomplishment and happiness.[28] Is it not true that only the awakened ones can know the minds of the lord buddhas? How could I know how to perform the magical feats[29] of the lord buddhas, whose miracles stem from an inconceivable, wondrous, superhuman power? How could I know of their engagement in the mental and physical conduct that constitutes their potential for the accomplishment of tasks?[30] Would I be able to even summarize these things in hundreds of thousands of millions of eons? The accomplishments of the tathāgatas, and all their forms without exception, whether separate and distinct or altogether, should be seen in terms of unconditioned dharmas. Only you, O Lord, the tathāgata, can explain the conduct and the qualities related to the elimination of traits eliminable through the path of seeing.[31] I cannot do that.’ ”

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas rang gi rdzu 'phrul gyi rnam par 'phrul pas rin po che'i pad+ma sprul pa la bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la blta zhing 'dug go/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la de bzhin gshegs pa dang rjes su mthun pa'i gtam rnam pa sna tshogs sngon du 'gro ba mdzad nas chos bstan pa dang rjes su mthun pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa sgrub pa dang rjes su mthun pas tshangs pa'i dbyangs dang / ka la ping ka'i skad dang 'brug sgra dang / rnga bo che'i sgra skad kyi gsung gi dbyangs kyis 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/

Seated on a great jeweled lotus miraculously created through his own magical power, Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, watched Lord Śākyamuni with anticipation. The latter, following the usual practice of a tathāgata, first gave by way of introduction the customary manifold preamble preceded by questions from the audience, and then he spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, the bodhisattva, the great being, with a voice as sweet as Brahmā’s, a voice that resembled the call of a cuckoo or the resounding of thunder or a drum, a voice that is fitting to a Dharma discourse and causes the bodhisattva to be accomplished:

'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa khyod legs par 'ongs sam/ / sems dpa' chen po'i spyod pa sangs rgyas thams cad kyis byin gyis brlabs pa bsgrub pas byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi don thob par byed pa/ sngags thams cad kyi tshig dang gsang ba dang bcas pa dang / dbang bskur ba dang phyag rgya dang / dkyil 'khor dang cho ga dang / dbang bskur ba dang tshe dang nad med pa dang / dbang phyug dang bsam pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ sgrub pa'i thabs thams cad dang ldan pa rgyud shes pa dang / shes bya dang dus dang mi snang ba dang / rgyal po'i zhing du gyur pa 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar byung ba shes par byed pa mdor na sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ rang gi yon tan dang mthun pa'i sngags kyi spyod pa rjes su 'jug pa/ sems can gzhan dga' bar byed pa mi snang bar 'gro ba/ nam mkha' la 'gro ba/ chu la mi nub par 'gro ba/ yid gzhungs par byed pa/ 'gugs par byed pa/ sa 'og tu 'jug pa/ mngon du spyod par byed pa/ 'dod pa thams cad thob par byed pa/ gnod sbyin dang / gnod sbyin mo thams cad dang / mngag gzhug pa dang sha za dang 'byung po thams cad 'gugs par byed pa/ byis pa dang / rgan po dang gzhon nu gnas ci lta ba bzhin 'jog par byed pa/

“Welcome to you, Mañjuśrī! The extensive tract of this great manual will now be explained; it has been approved by me and taught by all the buddhas. It is the manual that effects the accomplishment of the conduct of great beings; that is blessed by the buddhas; that achieves the aims of bodhisattvas; that contains the mantra topics together with the secret empowerments, mudrās, maṇḍalas, and empowerment rituals; that brings about long life, lack of illness, and dominion and fulfills all wishes; that contains all the tantras on sādhana rites; that causes one to know all minds and mental objects, the occurrences in all times, all hidden phenomena, and the kingdoms and realms in the past, present, and future‍—in short, the fulfillment of all the wishes of all beings. This is a mantra practice that facilitates the generation of good qualities and is the cause of the joy of beings. This manual contains instructions on becoming invisible; traveling through space; fast walking; increasing intelligence; the magic of summoning; the ability to visit subterranean paradises; the rites of assault; the obtainment of every sensual pleasure; the power to summon the multitudes of yakṣas and yakṣiṇīs, kiṃkaras, piśācas, and bhūtas; and the power to become a child, an old person, or a youth, as required by circumstances.

mdor na las thams cad byed pa ste/ yid la re ba thams cad rdzogs par byed pa/ mngon spyod dang rgyas pa dang / zhi ba'i las dag rab tu byed pa ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che/ bskal pa chen po'i rin po che'i le'u rab 'byam 'di ngas kyang rjes su gnang zhing sangs rgyas thams cad kyis kyang gsungs te/ sems can dag pa'i rang gi sngags spyod pa'i don gyi chos kyi mdzod/ skye bo mang po la phan pa dang / skye bo mang po la bde ba dang / lha dang mi rnams dang / sems can thams cad kyi don du bstan pa'i phyir ro/ /

“In short, this teaching has the power to perform all actions; it fulfills the heart’s every wish, magically manifesting itself in the magic of assault, of enriching, and of pacifying. It will be accomplished exactly according to how it is applied. Please teach now this ornament of the bodhisattva basket, this great, jewel-like, extensive manual, this treasury of teachings on the mantra practice of pure beings that was sanctioned by me and taught by all the buddhas. Teach it for the benefit and happiness of many beings, gods and humans, with all sentient beings in mind.”

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis byin gyis brlabs pa'i 'od kyi snang ba bkod pa'i rgyan yang dag par bskul ba zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu dag pa'i sems can gyi 'od kyi snang bas gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed du ma'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing / 'og min gyi gnas kyi bar dang / mnar med pa'i dmyal ba chen po'i bar du khyab par byas te/ sems can gang su dag shin tu sdug bsngal ba de dag thams cad kyi sdug bsngal rab tu zhi bar gyur to/ / nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' dang / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams yang dag par bskul nas/ 'od de yang 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i spyi bo'i gtsug tu nub par gyur to/ / 'dir gang dag shar phyogs na rnam par gnas pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing der 'od zer rlung gi dkyil 'khor gyi reg pa'i bya bas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams yang dag par bskul te/

Upon hearing this, Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, entered the bodhisattva samādhi called arousing with an array of light rays the blessing power of all the buddhas.[32] As soon as he, the pure being, entered this samādhi, the light primarily illuminated the world spheres that were as numerous as the grains of sand in many Gaṅgā rivers, as well as all the buddhafields from the Akaniṣṭha heaven to the Avīci hell. Any beings that were experiencing pain attained a peaceful state with their suffering pacified. Having aroused all the śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and lord buddhas, the light again disappeared into the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī’s forehead. Immediately, all the lord buddhas who inhabited the buddhafields in the eastern direction were impelled by the display of the light sphere illuminating everything around. These buddhas were:

de bzhin gshegs pa 'od zer gyi zla ba dri snang ba'i dpal zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa sman gyi lha bai DUr+ya'i 'od dang / de bzhin gshegs pa dpal kun tu snang ba zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rgyal po yang dag par 'phags pa zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa sA la'i dbang po'i rgyal po zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa 'jig rten gyi dbang po'i rgyal po zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa tshe dpag tu med pa ye shes rnam par nges pa'i rgyal po zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa snang ba mtha' yas dbang po'i rgyal po zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa snang ba'i 'od kyi rgyal po zhes bya ba dang /

The tathāgata Jyotissaumyagandhāvabhāsaśrī, the tathāgata Bhaiṣajyaguruvaiḍūryaprabharāja, the tathāgata Samantāvabhāsaśrī, the tathāgata Samudgatarāja, the tathāgata Śālendrarāja, the tathāgata Lokendrarāja, the tathāgata Amitāyurjñānaviniścayarāja, the tathāgata Anantāvabhāsarājendra, and the tathāgata Jyotiraśmirājendra.

de dag la sogs pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs kyis yongs su bskor ba/ mtha' yas mu med pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams dag nas de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'dus pa dag la mi mjed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams kyi gnas gtsang ma'i khang bzangs na/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas shAkya thub pa dang / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa lhan cig tu byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa ston pa dang / sngags kyi tshig gi don gyi le'u rab 'byam ston te/

The lord buddhas headed by those just mentioned, surrounded by multitudes of bodhisattvas and residing in numberless and infinite world spheres‍—the tathāgatas, the arhats, the fully awakened ones‍—all congregated in the Sahā world in the realm of the Pure Abode where Śākyamuni, the tathāgata, the arhat, the fully awakened one, was staying together with Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, and expounding the vast topic of mantras and bodhisattva conduct.

de bzhin du lho dang / nub dang byang gi phyogs dang phyogs mtshams dang steng dang 'og dang thad ka thams cad dang ldan pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing snang bar byas te/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad du bdud kyi gnas thams cad spa gong bar byas nas byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs thams cad kyis yongs su bskor cing / nyan thos kyi dge 'dun dang bcas pas mdun gyis bltas te/ gnas gtsang ma'i gnas su sangs rgyas kyi 'phrul pa dang byang chub sems dpa'i bdag nyid chen po blta bar 'dod pa dang / sngags kyi spyod pa bsgrub pa dang / ting nge 'dzin gyi khyad par dang / le'u'i tshogs dang de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa thogs pa med pa/ gsal bar 'dod pas chas pa ni 'di lta ste/

So it was also in the southern, western, and northern directions, and in the intermediate directions. The light illuminated there all the buddhafields that lie above, below, and across, and it obscured all the abodes of the māras. All the tathāgatas who were surrounded by multitudes of bodhisattvas and accompanied by congregations of śrāvakas, desiring to see the Pure Abode, the miraculous power of the buddhas, and the greatness of bodhisattvas, and desiring to make the instructions of the tathāgatas‍—the vast topics of the different types of samādhi produced by the mantra practice‍—shine unimpeded throughout the world, took their places. They were:

lag bzang dang / rin chen bzang po dang / brtul zhugs bzang po dang / spyan mdzes dang / bzang dga' dang / chos bzang dang / don thams cad grub pa dang / thams cad du 'phags pa dang / chos 'phags dang / rin chen 'phags dang / rin chen dpal dang / lhun po'i dpal dang / bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i dpal dang / 'od byed dpal dang / 'od dpal dang / don thams cad kyi dpal dang / thams cad phyag na rin po che dang / phyag na gtsug gi rin po che dang / phyag na lhun po'i rgyal mtshan dang / rnam par snang mdzad snying po dang / rin chen snying po dang / ye shes snying po dang / bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i don gyi snying po dang / chos 'phags kyi snying po dang / rgyal mtshan gyi tog dang / tog bzang dang / mtha' yas tog dang / dri ma med pa'i tog dang / mtha' dag gi tog dang / nam mkha'i tog dang / rin po che'i tog dang / 'brug sgra dang rnga bo che'i skad kyi rgyal po dang / mtha' yas par snang ba'i ye shes kyi rgyal po dang / mun pa mun nag thams cad 'joms pa'i rgyal po dang /

Subāhu, Suratna, Suvrata, Sunetra, Surata, Sudharma, Sarvārthasiddhi, Sarvodgata, Dharmodgata, Ratnodgata, Ratnaśrī, Meruśrī, Acintyaśrī, Prabhākaraśrī, Prabhaśrī, Jyotiśrī,[33] Sarvārthaśrī, Sarvaratnapāṇi, Cūḍāmaṇi,[34] Merudhvajapāṇi, Vairocanagarbha, Ratnagarbha, Jñānagarbha, Sacintyārthagarbha,[35] Acintyārthagarbha, Dharmodgatagarbha, Dhvajaketu, Suketu, Anantaketu, Raśmiketu, Vimalaketu, Aśeṣaketu, Gaganaketu, Ratnaketu, Garjitaghoṣadundubhisvararāja, Anantāvabhāsajñānarāja, Sarvatamāndhakāravidhamanarāja,

gnod pa thams cad rnam par 'jig pa'i rgyal po dang / spyod pa thams cad kyi yul shes pa'i rgyal po dang / 'jig rten gyi dbang po'i rgyal po dang / mngon par rtogs pa'i dbang po'i rgyal po dang / rnam par 'joms par byed pa'i rgyal po dang / nges par g.yo bar byed pa'i rgyal po dang / nyi ma'i rgyal po dang / dngos po med pa yang dag par 'phags pa'i rgyal po dang / dngos po med pa'i ngo bo nyid yang dag par 'phags pa'i rgyal po dang / mi mthun pa'i phyogs med pa'i rgyal po dang / rang bzhin gyi 'od dang / bsod nams 'od dang / 'jig rten 'od dang / dpag med 'od dang / mtha' yas 'od dang / spyan bzang 'od dang / 'byung med 'od dang / don gyi 'od dang / mi tshugs pa dang / bzod par dka' ba dang / las med dang / 'og min dang / dri med dang / me dang / 'od dang / blo dang / rtogs pa dang / bde ba dang / bde ba'i mu khyud dang / mu khyud tog dang / 'dod pa'i lha dang /

Lord Śākyamuni dwelt with these and other bodhisattvas in the realm of the Pure Abode. There were also other bodhisattva great beings. Some, with female forms, fulfill the purpose of bodhisattva conduct throughout the infinite universe.[66] Some embody the inconceivable magical formulae of mantras and dhāraṇīs with the power to establish the minds of all beings on the path of no return. Some take on the forms of medicinal herbs. Some emulate the ways of different types of beings, entering flocks of birds, yakṣas, rākṣasas, or entities not designated as sentient beings (asattvasaṁkhyāta), such as jewels, mantras, or wish-fulfilling kings of gems. They act in a manner suitable for taming beings according to their individual capacities and take on the forms most suited to this purpose. The Lord dwelt there with uṣṇīṣa kings who[67] grant proficiency in the Dharma based on perfect realization in accordance with the instructions pertaining to vidyārāja.[68] They cause beings to enter the Tathāgata, Lotus, and Vajra families and all the worldly and supramundane families. They prevent beings from breaking their samaya vows, establish them on the path of the teachings, and keep the lineages of the Three Jewels from breaking up. They were:

Lord Śākyamuni dwelt with these and other uṣṇīṣa kings, who abide in the sphere of phenomena fulfilling the heart aspirations of beings and pursuing the heart essence of all the victorious ones, in the realm of the Pure Abode. It would be impossible to list all of these uṣṇīṣa kings[71] down to the last one, or to describe their greatness, with their inconceivable might and powers, even in hundreds of thousands of millions of eons. Therefore, they are described here only briefly in an abbreviated form. The gathering of vidyārājñīs will now be enumerated:

Lord Śākyamuni dwelt with these and with other beings‍—the vidyārājas and vidyārājñīs, the ceṭas and ceṭīs, the dūtas and dūtīs, the yakṣas and yakṣiṇīs, and other sentient and non-sentient beings‍—uttering tathāgata mantras, created out of the Cloud of Dharma, and distinguishable by their adornments. They also dwelt in the realm of the Pure Abode. Among the vidyārājas belonging to the Lotus family, there were:

These and other dhāraṇī goddesses, surrounded by retinues of many hundreds of thousands of millions of such dhāraṇīs, all gathered in this great assembly. Through the infinite blessing of the buddhas, and the great blessing of the samādhi of the bodhisattvas, there assembled in this great gathering also venerable pratyekabuddhas from other buddhafields where there are no tathāgatas[122] present. Among them were both the solitary, rhinoceros-like ones and those who move among people, working for the benefit of beings. They demonstrate the way of the Dharma that involves habituation to silence. However, as their mindstreams are devoid of great compassion, they circle in saṃsāra with their minds ever weary. Their minds brim over with habitual thought patterns, and thus their previously generated bodhicitta is also tainted by habitual thinking. Their minds thus stall in progress when they reach the first, second, third . . . or any bodhisattva level up to the eighth, and they are fearful of saṃsāra, with minds ever weary. They were:

Lord Śākyamuni dwelt with these and many other śrāvakas who knew the taste of infinite freedom in the sphere of phenomena. Out of the collection of the three vehicles, they had reached the lesser one. Fleeing saṃsāra,[163] they had immersed themselves in the contemplation of the triple liberation. They were endowed with the deportment of the four immeasurable thoughts. They focused single-mindedly, became properly ordained, and followed the correct conduct. Having adopted the right system (sunaya),[164] they attained the state of nirvāṇa with its mental tranquility and freedom from mental elaboration. They too were seated in this great assembly along with Lord Śākyamuni and the others, established on the tenth level, who constitute the Three Jewels.

Together with them there were many female śrāvakas. Relying on the path of the unconditioned, they abided in the state of nirvāṇa‍—the attainment of śrāvakas. Pure and free from desire, they developed halos of light. They were all objects worthy of veneration, being repositories of good qualities who facilitate purification. The best among the multitude of beings, they were the foremost leaders of the world. They were objects of worship of gods and humans and were their fields of merit. They were the supreme leaders of two-legged, four-legged, multi-legged, and legless beings. They were:

These and other of the most senior of the great female śrāvakas approached in order to salute the Lord’s feet. Desiring to swell the ranks[175] of this great gathering, which was a great miraculous feat of the bodhisattvas, they congregated and took their seats. They were eager to hear the Lord’s teaching and to become a shining example to demonstrate the accomplishment of mantra practice.

Lord Śākyamuni then looked at this entire gathering and, knowing with his pure heart that the realm of beings[176] extends beyond the three times and is sky-like in nature, without independent existence, he addressed Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, as follows: “Please focus your attention, Mañjuśrī, on the acts that serve the interests of beings! Enter now the bodhisattva samādhi that will delight them according to their wishes, that is accompanied by faith in karmic results, and that will fulfill the purpose of their mantra practice; the samādhi that is the seat of the Dharma, the seat of right action, and the seat of tranquility and liberation; the samādhi that accomplishes ritual procedures and brings a state of equipoise free of all conceptuality; the bodhisattva samādhi that is endowed with the complete power of the ten powers of the tathāgatas and overwhelms the power of Māra.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal ma thag tu 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa snyoms par zhugs par gyur to/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu/ de nas stong gsum gyi stong chen po 'di dang 'jig rten gyi khams brgya phrag stong du ma'i rdul phra rab kyi rdul dang mnyam pa'i stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams yang dag par rab tu g.yos te/ snang ba chen pos gsal bar yang byas nas/ rang gi rdzu 'phrul gyi stobs skyed pa ston te/ rang gi sngags kyi tshig kyang ston pa la/

Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, then entered the samādhi that was just described by the Lord. As soon as he entered it, he illuminated with a great light and caused to shake great trichiliocosms equal in number to the minute dust particles in many hundreds of thousands of world spheres, similar to this trichiliocosm of ours. He also displayed the use of magical powers, and then pronounced the words of his own mantra:

namaHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a b+hA ba swa b+hA ba mung+ga tA nAM/ namaHpra t+ye ka bud d+hA nAM Ar+ya shra ba kA nAM/ na mo bo d+hi sa twA nAM/ da sha b+hU mi pra tiSh+Thi te shwa rA nAM/ bo d+hi sa twA nAM/ ma hA sa twA nAM/ tad+ya thA/

“Homage to all the buddhas who arise out of the nature of nonexistence of individual entities! Homage to the pratyekabuddhas and the noble śrāvakas! Homage to the bodhisattvas, the lords established on the ten levels, the great beings! This is the mantra proper:

oM kha kha khA hi khA hi/ duSh+Ta sa twa da ma ka a si mu sa la par+shu pA sha hasta/ tsa tur+b+hu dza/ tsa turmu kha/ Sha Ta tsa ra Na/ gats+tsha gats+tsha/ sarba big+h+na big+h+nAn+te ka / bi krI tA nan/ sarba b+hU ta b+ha yaM kar/ aT+TAT+Ta hA sa ni nA di ne/ bya g+h+ra tsarma ni bA sa na/ ku ru ku ru/ sarba d+harmA na/ ts+tshin+da ts+tshin+da/ sarba man+t+rAn/ b+hin+d+ha b+hin+d+ha/ pa ra mu drAn/ A kar+Sha ya/ A kar+Sha ya/ sarba b+hU tAn/ nirma tha nirma tha/ sarba duSh+Ta na/ pra be sha ya pra be sha ya/ maN+Da la ma d+h+ye/ bai ba swa ta dzI bi tAn+ta ka ra/ ku ru ku ru ma ma sarba kAr+yam/ da ha da ha/ pa tsa pa tsa/ mA bi lam+ba/ mA bi lam+ba/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ hUM hUM phaT/ s+pho Ta ya s+pho Ta ya/ sarba A sha pa ri pU ra ka/ he b+ha ga bAn kiny+tsi rA ya si ma ma sarbAmar+thaM sA d+ha ya swA hA/

“Oṁ, kha kha! Devour, devour! O tamer of evil beings, with a sword, a club, an axe, and a noose in your hands! One with four arms, four faces, and six feet, go, go! O great destroyer of obstacles with contorted face, inspiring fear in all nonhuman beings! One who roars with wild laughter and wears a tiger skin, perform, perform all tasks![177] Cut, cut all the mantras [of non-believers]! Break, break all the mudrās of non-believers! Draw here, draw here all nonhuman beings! Grind, grind all the wicked ones! Cause them to enter into the center of the maṇḍala! O terminator of the life of Vaivasvata, perform, perform tasks for me! Burn, burn! Cook, cook! Do not delay, do not delay! Remember your samaya pledge! Hūṁ hūṁ! Phaṭ phaṭ! Split, split! Fulfiller of all wishes! Hey, hey, blessed one! Why do you tarry? Accomplish all my aims! Svāhā![178]

'di ni bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i khro bo chen po gshin rje'i gshed ces bya ba yin te/ gshin rje'i rgyal po yang 'joms pa dang / 'gugs par byed pa yin na/ sems can gzhan lta smos kyang ci dgos/ / khro bo'i rgyal po chen pos gzungs sngags 'di smras ma thag tu sems can thams cad bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar lhags par gyur te/ 'jigs pa dang nyam thag pa dang / dngangs pa dang yid skyo ba dang snying 'gas par 'gyur te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa ma gtogs par skyabs gzhan med skyob pa gzhan med dpung gnyen gzhan med par gyur to/ /

This mantra of Lord Mañjuśrī, called Yamāntaka, Great Lord of Wrath, will crush or summon even the king Yama, not to mention ordinary beings. As soon as the Great Lord of Wrath is pronounced, all beings will come into Lord Mañjuśrī’s presence, unhappy, frightened, and terrified, their minds disturbed and their spirits broken, without any other refuge, no other protection or recourse apart from Lord Buddha and the divine youth Mañjuśrī.

de nas gang su dag sa la gnas pa dang chu la gnas pa dang / nam mkha' la gnas pa dang / brtan par gnas pa dang / mi brtan par gnas pa dang / mngal nas skyes pa dang / sgo nga las skyes pa dang / drod gsher las skyes pa dang rdzus te skyes pa'i sems can gyi grangs su gtogs pa/ 'jig rten gyi khams mtha' yas pa dag na rnam par gnas pa steng dang / 'og dang thad ka dang phyogs dang phyogs mtshams dag tu skad cig de dang yud tsam de la gab cing gnas pa dag skad cig de nyid la/ khro bo'i rgyal po chen pos 'di nyid du bkug par gyur to/ / khro bo'i rgyal po'i sngags 'di ni 'dod chags dang ma bral ba rnams kyi mdun du brjod par mi bya ste/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de yang 'chi bar 'gyur ba'am/ skam par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / dam tshig la dmigs par byas nas sangs rgyas kyi sku gzugs sam sku gdung dang bcas pa'i mchod rten nam/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i sku gzugs kyi spyan sngar bzlas par bya'o/ / yang na las gzhan gyi ched du brjod par bya ste/ gang de dang de dag tu ni brjod par mi bya ste/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ ltas ngan chen po dang / mya ngan chen po dang / bdag nyid 'jigs pa chen por 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

Any beings that live on dry land, or in water, or fly in the sky, the mobile and the immobile, those enumerated as born from a womb, from an egg, from moisture, or as born spontaneously, those that are situated in the infinite world spheres up to their farthest reaches, and those that are hidden in the cardinal and intermediate directions, above, across, and below will be removed at that very moment from those places by the Great Lord of Wrath himself and brought into the presence of Mañjuśrī. The Lord of Wrath must not be pronounced in the presence of those whose desires have not been extinguished, for they also would wither and die. It should be recited by those who keep their samaya pledges, in front of a buddha image, or a caitya containing relics, or a book containing a genuine Dharma teaching, or in front of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth. It must not be recited for the sake of performing other acts in just any place, otherwise terrible omens and great ruin will come to the reciter.

For the lord buddhas are indeed filled with utmost compassion, and the bodhisattvas, the great beings, exclusively strive to establish beings in the practice of the insight of omniscient knowledge; enthralling all beings, they establish them in the way of the Dharma. They deliver into nirvāṇa the entire realm of sentient beings; they give instructions and establish beings on the triple path; they prevent breaks in the lineages of the Three Jewels; they illuminate the mantra practice. With minds born of the power of great compassion, they obliterate the power of Māra. They destroy obstacle makers and keep the lords of evil in check. They increase[179] their own power and hold back the power of opponents. They perform the acts of paralyzing, killing, destroying, chastising, burning, and gratifying. They teach the practice of their own mantra. They cause the lifespan, health, and power of beings to increase. They swiftly accomplish all tasks. They readily assume the modes of[180] great love, great compassion, great equanimity, and great sympathetic joy. That is why the Yamāntaka mantra was now recited with a mind free from all doubt and deliberation. Summoned by the mantra were:

tha skar dang / bra nye dang / smin drug dang / snar ma dang / mgo dang / lag dang / na ba so dang / rgyal dang / skag dang / mchu dang / gre dang / dbo dang / me bzhi dang / nag pa dang / sa ri dang / sa ga dang / lha mtshams dang / snron dang / snrubs dang / chu stod dang / chu smad dang / gro bzhin dang / mon gru dang / mon gre dang / khrums stod dang / khrums smad dang / nam gru dang / lha mo 'dra dang / byi bzhin dang pu na rna ba dang / 'od dang / ang gi ra si dang / rgyu skar dang nye ba'i gre dang / gre ldan dang / 'jig rten rab mchog dang / rab mchog ldan dang / dpal ldan dang / 'jig rten mgon po dang / chang ldan dang / rgyal byed dang / nor ldan dang lha don te/

de ltar rgyu skar gyi rgyal po de dag kyang de'i tshe gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang du rgyu skar brgya stong phrag du ma'i 'khor dang ldan pa/ sangs rgyas kyi byin gyis brlabs kyis 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po der 'dus te 'khod par gyur to/ / khyim sum cu rtsa drug la 'di lta ste/

lug dang / glang dang / sbyor ba dang / sbal pa dang / seng ge dang / bu mo dang / srang dang / sdig pa dang / gzhu dang / chu srin dang / bum pa dang / nya dang / mi'u thung dang / nye ba'i bum pa dang / b+h+ring ga ra dang / ral gri dang / glang po che dang / ma he dang / lha dang / mi dang / dge ltas dang / dri za dang / 'jig rten dang / g.yung drung rgyal dang / drag po'i gzi brjid dang / zla ba'i 'od dang / sa dang / mun pa dang / rdul dang / nye ba'i rdul dang / sdug bsngal dang / bde ba dang / byang chub dang / so so gcig dang / nyan thos dang / dmyal ba'i rig pa 'dzin pa dang / gzi brjid chen po dang / gzi brjid chen po ldan dang / dud 'gro dang / yi dgas dang / lha ma yin dang / sha ldan dang / sha za dang / /gnod sbyin srin po dang / 'byung po thams cad pa dang / 'byung ba pa dang / phyogs kyi glang po dang / steng 'gro dang / thad kar 'gro dang / kha bye ba dang / bsam gtan 'gro dang / rnal 'byor 'gro dang / rab tu gnas dang / mchog dang / bar ma dang tha ma ste/

Meṣa, Vṛṣabha, Mithuna, Karkaṭaka, Siṃha, Kanyā, Tula, Vṛścika, Dhanus, Makara, Kumbha, Mīna, Vānara,[241] Upakumbha, Bhṛṅgāra, Khaḍga, Kuñjara, Mahiṣa, Deva, Manuṣya, Śakuna, Gandharva, Loka, Sarvajita,[242] Ugratejas, Jyotsna, Chāya,[243] Pṛthivī, Tama, Raja, Uparaja, Duḥkha, Sukha, Mokṣa,[244] Bodhi,[245] Pratyeka, Śrāvaka, Naraka, Vidyādhara,[246] Mahoja, Mahojaska, Tiryak, Preta, Asura, Piśita, Piśāca, Yakṣa, Rākṣasa, Sarvabhūtika, Bhūtika, Nimnaga,[247] Ūrdhvaga, Tiryaga, Vikasita, Dhyānaga, Yogapratiṣṭha,[248] Uttama, Madhyama, and Adhama.

khyim chen po de dag kyang khyim brgya stong phrag du ma'i 'khor dang ldan pa gang na gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang gang na bar 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po der lhags shing phyin te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la btud nas rang rang gi gnas su 'khod par gyur to/ / gang yang gnod sbyin mo dag gnod sbyin mo brgya stong phrag du ma'i 'khor dang bcas pa la 'di lta ste/

They were:

mig bzang ma dang / smin bzang ma dang / skra bzang ma dang / skad snyan ma dang / blo bzang ma dang / dge ldan ma dang / sna tshogs mig ldan ma dang / rdzogs byed ma dang / gsang ba ma dang / bzang po ma dang / ska rags bzang po ma dang / pad+ma ltar smra ba dang / 'jigs byed ma dang / mi 'jigs sbyin ma dang / rgyal ma dang / rnam par rgyal ma dang / nam gru ma dang / sgra gcan ma dang / sgra mthar byed ma dang / rlung ma dang / yid 'phrog ma dang / yid ldan ma dang / me tog ldan ma dang / me tog gi grong khyer la gnas ma dang / ser skya ma dang / 'phrog ma dang / dpal ldan ma dang / dpa' mo dang / dpa' bzang mo dang / shin tu mi bzad ma dang / mi bzad ldan ma dang / lha mdzes ma dang / ro bzang ma dang / gsang ba dam pa ma dang / shing la mu la gnas ma dang / mya ngan med ma dang / mun par mdzes ma dang / snang bar mdzes ma dang / 'od ldan ma dang / lhag par ldan ma dang / gzugs mdzes ma dang / dkar med ma dang / zhi ba ma dang / phyogs mtshams ma dang / stug ma dang / dga' byed ma dang / nye ba'i dga' byed ma dang / 'jig rten las 'das ma ste/

Sulocanā, Subhrū, Sukeśā, Susvarā, Sumatī, Vasumatī, Citrākṣī, Pūrāṃśā, Guhyakā, Suguhyakā,[249] Mekhalā,[250] Sumekhalā, Padmoccā, Abhayā,[251] Abhayadā, Jayā, Vijayā, Revatikā, Keśinī, Keśāntā, Anilā, Manoharā, Manovatī, Kusumā,[252] Kusumāvatī, Kusumapuravāsinī, Piṅgalā, Hārītī, Vīramatī, Vīrā, Suvīrā, Sughorā, Ghoravatī, Surasundarī, Surasā, Guhyottarī, Vaṭavāsinī, Aśokā, Andhārasundarī, Ālokasundarī, Prabhāvatī, Atiśayavatī, Rūpavatī, Surūpā, Asitā, Saumyā, Kāṇā,[253] Menā,[254] Nandinī, Upanandinī, and Lokottarā.

gnod sbyin mo chen mo 'di dag gnod sbyin mo brgya stong phrag du ma'i 'khor dang ldan pa 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po der rgyang ring po nyid nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la phyag 'tshal zhing 'khod par gyur to/ / gang yang sha za mo dag sha za mo brgya stong phrag du ma'i 'khor dang ldan pa/ 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po der rgyang ring po nyid nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la phyag 'tshal zhing 'khod par gyur pa la 'di lta ste/

These great yakṣiṇīs, with retinues of many hundreds of thousands of yakṣiṇīs, bowing to Lord Śākyamuni from a distance, were present in this great gathering. Also the great piśācīs, with retinues of many hundreds of thousands of piśācīs, joined in, paying respects to Lord Śākyamuni. They were:

sdud ma dang phyag dar khrod kyi sha za mo dang / sha za mo drag mo dang sha za mo skar mda' ma dang sha za mo 'bar ma dang thal ba za ma dang sha za ma dang / dug ma dang bung ba ma dang rmongs byed ma dang sdigs mdzub ma dang / dmar ldan ma dang glang dmar ma dang 'jig rten nye gnas ma dang thal bar nye gnas ma dang shing pi lu dang ldan ma dang / mang ldan ma dang mang ma dang gdul dka' ma dang / e la ma dang mtshon byed ma dang du ba la gnas ma dang du ba ma ste/

Maṇḍitikā, Pāṃsupiśācī, Raudrapiśācī, Ulkāpiśācī, Jvālāpiśācī, Bhasmodgirā, Piśitāśinī, Durdharā, Bhrāmarī, Mohanī, Tarjanī, Rohiṇikā, Govāhiṇikā, Lokāntikā, Bhasmāntikā, Pīluvatī, Bahulavatī, Bahulā, Durdāntā, Elā, Cihnitikā, Dhūmāntikā,[255] Dhūmā, and Sudhūmā.[256]

sha za mo chen mo 'di dag sha za mo'i 'khor bye ba brgya stong phrag du ma dang bcas pa de dag kyang 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po der 'dus shing rab tu zhugs par gyur to/ / gang yang ma mo dang ma mo chen mo dag 'jig rten gyi rjes su rnam par spyod cing / sems can rnams la 'tshe bar byed cing / gtor ma dang / me tog dman ma la spyod par byed pa dag la 'di lta ste/

These great piśācīs, with retinues of many hundreds of thousands of piśācīs, also entered this great gathering. Also, the mātṛs and the great mātṛs, who wander throughout the world harming living beings and seizing oblatory offerings of food and garlands, joined in. They were:

tshangs pa ma dang / dbang phyug chen mo ma dang / khyab 'jug ma dang / gzhon nu ma dang / rgan byad ma dang / phag mo dang / dbang mo dang / gshin rje mo dang / me phyogs ma dang / nyi ma'i bu mo dang / 'jig rten mthar byed ma dang / chu lha ma dang / dbang ldan ma dang / rlung phyogs ma dang / gzhan gyi srog 'phrog ma dang / mgo bregs ma dang / bya ma dang / bya ma chen mo dang / srul mo dang / lus srul mo dang / skem byed ma ste/

Brahmāṇī, Māheśvarī, Vaiṣṇavī, Kaumārī, Cāmuṇḍā, Vārāhī, Aindrī, Yāmyā, Āgneyā, Vaivasvatī, Lokāntakarī, Vāruṇī, Aiśānī, Vāyavyā, Paraprāṇaharā, Mukhamaṇḍitikā, Śakunī, Mahāśakunī, Pūtanā, Kaṭapūtanā, and Skandā.

ma mo chen mo de dag kyang ma mo'i 'khor bye ba khri phrag brgya stong du ma dang bcas pa de dag kyang 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po der sangs rgyas la phyag 'tshal lo zhes bya ba'i tshig 'don cing 'khod par gyur to/ /
These great mātṛs, with retinues of many hundreds of thousands of mātṛs, were present in this great assembly, calling out, “Homage to the Buddha!”

de bzhin du mi dang mi ma yin pa bye ba khri phrag brgya stong du ma dang / sems can dang sems can ma yin pa nas dmyal ba chen po mnar med pa nas srid pa'i rtse mo'i bar du thams cad kyang skabs 'dir nam mkha'i dkyil du snang bar gyur to/ / sems can gyi ris na srog chags su la yang phan tshun mi mthun pa med par gyur to/ / sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs dang byang chub sems dpa'i cho 'phrul gyi rgyan gyis sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa sems can thams cad kyi spyi bo'i gtsug na bzhugs par mthong bar gyur to/ /

Similarly, the entire expanse of space with its many hundreds of thousands of beings, both human and nonhuman, sentient and non-sentient, from the great hell of Avīci to the pinnacle of saṃsāra, became open and accessible to sight. Within the totality of beings there was not a single one who would be in disharmony with another. By the blessing of the Buddha enriched with the magical power of the bodhisattvas, all these beings then saw Lord Buddha and the divine youth Mañjuśrī seated on the crowns of their heads.

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams su sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis rnam par gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ dag pa'i sems dpa' sngags kyi spyod pa'i don rnam par gtan la dbab pa dang ting nge 'dzin gyi le'u rab 'byam byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod gang 'di bshad pa'i dus la bab par sems na shod cig /

Now, Lord Śākyamuni, having looked over this entire assembly with his buddha eye, said to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, “Please speak, O pure being! Give a full presentation of the section on samādhi that explains the meaning of mantra practice. Present this basket of bodhisattva teachings if you think that the moment is right.”

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas rjes su gnang bar mdzad pa na/ nam mkha'i ngo bo dang 'dra ba'i rdo rje mthug cing sra ba'i rgyud bkod pa'i rgyan zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs te/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa de snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang de dpag tshad brgya stong du ma rgya che ba'i rdo rje'i rang bzhin du lhag par gnas par gyur to/ / gang du gnod sbyin dang srin po dang dri za dang rlung lha dang sha za de dag dang / mdor na sems can gyi khams thams cad byang chub sems dpa'i byin gyi rlabs kyis gzhal med khang de dag rdo rje'i nor bu rin po che lta bur gyur te/ der rab tu zhugs nas 'khod par gyur kyang phan tshun rnam par 'tshe bar byed pa med do/ /

Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, with the approval of Lord Śākyamuni, entered the samādhi called the ornament of a contiguous formation solid as fused vajras, adorned with miraculous displays[257] of the space-like nature. As soon as Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, entered this samādhi, he blessed the realm of the Pure Abode, which extended over many hundreds of thousands of leagues, so that it became made of vajras. All the many yakṣas, rākṣasas, gandharvas, mārutas, and piśācas‍—in short, the entire universe inhabited by living beings‍—became situated by the blessing of the bodhisattvas in this great palace that resembled diamond jewels and gems, and there took their seats together, without any mutual enmity.

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po de 'dus par gyur par shes nas khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje'i gshed la smras pa/ kye khro bo chen po sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi rjes su nges par 'byung bar byed pa/ 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po 'dus pa 'di'i sems can thams cad la srungs shig srungs shig / dbang du gyis shig ma rungs pa gdul bar gyis shig sems can zhi ba dag sad par gyis shig / sems can thams cad dad par gyis shig / ci srid du nga'i rang gi sngags kyi spyod pa rjes su sgrub pa/ byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod rgya che ba dag las sngags spyod pa'i dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga 'chad par byed pa de srid kyi bar du 'di dag gi phyi rol du song la srung ba gyis shig /

Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, seeing that this great assembly had gathered, said to Yamāntaka, the Lord of Wrath, “Ho, ho, Great Lord of Wrath, who emanates from all the buddhas and bodhisattvas! Please protect this great gathering! Protect and enthrall it! Tame the wicked ones! Awaken the gentle ones into realization! Placate the implacable ones! As long as I am teaching this bodhisattva basket that accords with my own mantra practice and contains the extensive instructions on mantra practice and the maṇḍala, please go outside and guard this gathering.”

de skad ces smras pa dang / khro bo'i rgyal po chen pos bka' mnyan nas/ khro bo chen po'i gzugs kyis sems can thams cad rjes su bsrung ba dang rjes su bstan pa'i phyir 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad du khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed khro bo'i 'khor brgya stong phrag du ma phyogs bzhi kun dang steng dang 'og dang thad ka dag tu shin tu mi bzad pa'i sgra rab tu 'don cing gnas par gyur to/ / de nas sems can de dag zhi ba dang yid dang sems bzang po dang ldan par gyur te bka' las mi 'da' bar byed par gyur to/ / 'di lta bu'i sgra yang thos par gyur te/ gang dam tshig 'di las 'da' bar byed pa de dag ni a rdza ka'i dog pa bzhin du mgo tshal pa brgyar 'gas par 'gyur te/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i byin gyi rlabs kyang de yin no/ /

Thus addressed, the Great Lord of Wrath, of extremely ugly, misshapen appearance,[258] acknowledged the command and went outside in order to protect all the beings and to train the assembled audience in every respect. Letting out a terrible roar into the four directions, above, below, and across, he took up his position in the form of Yamāntaka Lord of Wrath, with a retinue of many hundreds of thousands of wrathful deities. Thus all beings, having become peaceful and content, did not transgress his orders. They also heard these words: “Those who would disobey this injunction, their heads will split into one hundred parts like a garland made of basil plants. For such is the power of the bodhisattvic blessing.
de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas rang gi sngags kyi spyod pa'i don du chos kyi tshig smras pa/
Mañjuśrī then gave a Dharma teaching on the practice of his mantra.

chos gcig la yang dag par bsams na byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po'i sngags 'grub par 'gyur te/ gcig po gang zhe na 'di lta ste/ chos thams cad spros pa med pa'i rnam par rjes su mthong ba'o/ /

“When a bodhisattva, a great being, possesses a single quality, his mantras become effective. What is this single quality? It is the mind that beholds all phenomena without mentally elaborating upon them.

byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos gnyis la rab tu gnas na sngags 'grub par 'gyur te/ gnyis po gang zhe na byang chub kyi sems mi gtong ba nyid dang / sems can thams cad la sems mnyam pa'o/ /

“When a bodhisattva, a great being, possesses two qualities, his mantras become effective. What are these two? They are (1) never abandoning bodhicitta, and (2) having equanimity toward all sentient beings.

chos gsum dang ldan na sngags kyi spyod pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur te/ gsum po gang zhe na/ sems can thams cad yongs su mi gtong ba nyid dang / byang chub sems dpa'i tshul khrims kyi sdom pa srung ba dang / rang gi sngags yongs su mi gtong ba nyid do/ /

“With three qualities, his exposition of the meaning of mantra practice will be perfect. What are these three? They are (1) never abandoning any sentient being, (2) guarding the vows of the bodhisattva’s discipline, and (3) never abandoning his mantra.

chos bzhi dang yang dag par ldan na dang po sems bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i sngags 'grub par 'gyur te/ bzhi po gang zhe na/ rang gi sngags yongs su mi gtong ba nyid dang / gzhan gyi sngags rjes su spyod pa med pa nyid dang / sems can thams cad la byams pas gnas pa nyid dang / snying rje chen pos yongs su bsgos pa'i sems pa nyid do/ / chos bzhi po 'di dag dang ldan na dang po sems bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i sngags 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“When a bodhisattva, who has made the initial resolution of a bodhisattva, possesses four qualities, his mantras become effective. What are these four? They are (1) never abandoning his mantra, (2) not neutralizing the mantras of others,[259] (3) generating loving kindness for all sentient beings, and (4) suffusing his mindstream with compassion. The mantras of a bodhisattva who has made an initial resolution and possesses these four qualities become effective.

chos lnga dang ldan na byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod la 'jug cing sngags kyi spyod pa sgrub pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur te/ lnga po gang zhe na/ rnam par dben pa'i phyogs yang dag par bsten pa nyid dang / / bas mtha' dgon pa sten par byed pa nyid dang / sems can gzhan la zhe sdang med pa nyid dang / 'jig rten pa'i sngags la mi lta ba nyid dang / tshul khrims dang thos pa dang spyod pa la gnas par byed pa nyid de chos lnga po 'di dag dang ldan na sngags spyod pa'i don 'grub cing yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro/ /

“Five qualities will bring the bodhisattva’s mastery of his mantra practice and his engagement in the basket of teachings to perfection. What are these five? They are (1) frequenting solitary places, (2) frequenting remote, peaceful places, (3) not hating others, (4) not considering employing mundane mantras, and (5) establishing others in discipline, learning, and good character. These five qualities will completely fulfill the purpose of his mantra practice.

chos drug dang ldan na sngags kyi spyod pa 'grub cing yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur te/ drug po gang zhe na/ dkon mchog gsum la dad pa rjes su mi gcod pa nyid dang / byang chub sems dpa' la dang ba rjes su mi gcod pa nyid dang / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags la kun du dga' ba nyid dang / chos kyi dbyings spros pa med pa la lta ba nyid dang / theg pa chen po'i mdo sde zab mo'i tshig gi don mi spong zhing skyo ba med pa'i sems nyid dang / sngags kyi spyod pa yongs su btsal ba dang / dge ba'i phyogs yongs su mi gtong ba nyid de/ chos drug po 'di dag dang ldan na rig pa'i spyod pa dang sngags 'grub cing yang dag par sgrub pa nyid du 'gyur ro/ /

“Six qualities will completely fulfill the purpose of mantra practice. What are these six? They are (1) not giving up faith in the Three Jewels, (2) not giving up faith in the bodhisattvas, (3) praising both mundane and supramundane mantras, (4) perceiving the sphere of phenomena that is free of elaboration, (5) not rejecting the sūtras of the Great Vehicle that contain profound words and meaning, (6) never losing heart, (7) pursuing the mantra practice, and (8) not letting virtue decline.[260] These six qualities will bring complete success in the practice of mantra and the knowledge of vidyās.

chos bdun dang ldan na rig pa sgrub pa'i dus kyi thabs thob par 'gyur zhing / sngags kyi spyod pa la rjes su spyod pa nyid du 'gyur te/ bdun po gang zhe na/ theg pa zab mo shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa nyid sgom pa dang / klog pa dang / ston pa dang / 'don du 'jug pa dang / 'dri ba dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la mos pa nyid dang / dus dang / phyogs dang / nges par sdom pa dang / bzlas pa dang / sbyin sreg dang / mi smra ba dang / dka' thub la gzhol ba nyid dang / rtogs pa dang / blo dang / dran pa dang / shes rab dang / bstan pa la bsnyen pa nyid dang / byang chub kyi tshogs dang / theg pa chen po dang zab pa'i chos kyi tshul la yang dag par rab tu zhugs pa nyid dang rang dga'i sngags dgug pa'i bya ba la mkhas pa nyid dang / snying rje chen po dang / byams pa chen po dang / btang snyoms chen po dang / dga' ba chen po nyid yongs su bsgom pa nyid dang spros pa med pa'i sems can gyi khams kyi chos kyi dbyings kyi de bzhin nyid la 'jug pa gnyis su med pa'i ngo bo'i thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes yongs su tshol ba nyid dang / sems can thams cad yongs su mi gtong ba nyid dang theg pa dman pa la dga' ba med pa nyid de/ chos bdun po de dag gis ni rig pa dang sngags 'grub cing yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro/ /

“There are seven qualities that lead to the taking up of mantra practice that are helpful at the time of the actual application of magical vidyās. What are these seven? They are (1) taking up the profound path by cultivating the perfection of wisdom; (2) resolving upon the bodhisattva conduct that consists in reciting, teaching, studying, and writing; (3) taking up the right demeanor, thoughts, recollections, and the holding on to insight, without being impeded by time, place, ritual injunctions, mantra recitation, homa offerings, vows of silence, or the practice of austerities;[261] (4) entering the way of the deep teachings of the Great Vehicle through the two accumulations of a bodhisattva; (5) skill in the procedures of summoning the mantra deities of one’s own lineage[262] or in effecting protection;[263] (6) cultivating great compassion, great loving kindness, great equanimity, and great sympathetic joy, as well as the six perfections;[264] (7) pursuing the two types of omniscient wisdom by bringing together the sphere of sentient beings, the sphere of phenomena, and ‘suchness’ through nonconceptuality; (8) never abandoning any sentient being; and (9) not seeking the Lesser Vehicle.[265] These seven qualities lead to the perfect mastery of mantras and magical knowledge.

chos brgyad dang ldan na rig pa dang sngags kyi spyod pa'i don 'grub cing lam du 'gro bar 'gyur te/ brgyad po gang zhe na/ mthong ba dang ma mthong ba'i 'bras bu dag la blta ba dang sems par 'dod pa nyid dang / byang chub sems dpa'i 'bras bu dang bcas pa'i rdzu 'phrul dang rnam par 'phrul pa nyid la the tshom med cing dang ba nyid dang / phyin ci ma log pa'i sngags gzung ba dang bla ma la gus pa nyid dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' nyid kyi sngags dang / rgyud dang spyod pa bstan pa mi slu ba bzung zhing bdog pa thams cad yongs su gtong ba nyid dang / sangs rgyas kyi zhing gnas dang gnas ma yin pa rmi lam na mthong ba rab tu ston pa la mkhas pa nyid dang / ser sna dang gnyid dang rmugs pa mtha' dag dang bral bar byed cing rtag tu brtson 'grus rtsom la/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' la bdag nyid 'bul bar byed pa nyid dang / mdor bsdu na dge ba'i rtsa bas chog mi shes shing go cha chen po bgos pa dang / bgegs thams cad rab tu sel bar 'dod pa nyid dang / byang chub kyi snying po gnon pa dang longs spyod chen po dang / dbang che bar grags par bdag nyid 'dod pa nyid dang dbang che bar grags pa'i gang zag la bsnyen pa dang dge ba'i bshes gnyen dang mi 'bral bar bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la nye bar gnas pa nyid de/ chos brgyad po 'di dag dang ldan na sngags spyad pa'i don 'grub pa'i yang dag pa'i lam du 'gyur ro/ /

“Eight qualities will completely fulfill the purpose of the practice of mantra and magical vidyās.[266] What are these eight? They are (1) faith in karmic results, both seen and unseen; (2) refraining from investigating anything out of mere curiosity or the desire to know;[267] (3) displaying magical powers made effective through the grace of a bodhisattva;[268] (4) out of respect for the teacher, learning from him the undistorted mantras;[269] (5) taking to heart the master’s instructions on the buddhas and bodhisattvas’ own mantra system; (6) keeping one’s word;[270] (7) renouncing all of one’s possessions; (8) being able to skillfully explain the signs received in one’s sleep about suitable and unsuitable places for gaining accomplishment;[271] (9) freeing oneself from all stains of stinginess, sleepiness, and dullness, and constantly practicing diligence; and (11) always offering oneself to the buddhas and bodhisattvas.[272] In short, never being complacent about accumulating the roots of virtue, donning great armor, or desiring to remove all obstacles, one will ascend the seat of awakening and experience great bliss as anticipated. One will be known as a great being and will also fall in with other great beings. One will never be separated from a spiritual friend and will be accompanied by Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, the bodhisattva. The aforementioned eight qualities will completely fulfill the purpose of mantra practice.
