grogs po dag mdor na byang chub kyi sems dang mi 'bral ba dang / dkon mchog gsum la dad pa dang mchog tu sdug bsngal zhing tshul khrims nyams pa la yang mi skyo ba'i yid kyis rtag tu mngon par brtson pa la/ nga'i sngags kyi le'u rab 'byam mtha' yas shing rmad du byung ba/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa'i rgyu mthun pa'i yid las byung ba 'grub par 'gyur te de las gzhan du shes par bya ba ma yin no/ / rnam par rtog pa med pa'i yid du byas nas nyam sad pa'i phyir yang bsgrub par bya ba yin no/ /

“Friends! To sum up, a person who is not separated from bodhicitta, who is devoted to the Three Jewels, who continually exerts himself with unwearied mind even if he were of extremely bad disposition, will succeed in the infinite and marvelous mantra practice of a bodhisattva as taught in the detailed chapter on my mantra, and will develop the mind that arises from this practice. It should not be known to be otherwise. Once someone has become free from dualistic thinking, he will succeed even if his original motive was mere curiosity.”
de nas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang rang sangs rgyas dang 'phags pa nyan thos rnams kyis byin gyis brlabs pa dag gis 'di skad du tshig rjod par byed de
Then, the entire gathering, graced with the presence of buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, and venerable śrāvakas, said these words:

kye rgyal ba'i sras legs so legs so/ / sngags kyi spyod pa'i don rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i bya ba chos kyi tshul la rjes su 'jug pa dang mthun zhing chos bstan pa legs par bstan pa ni sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir ro/ / de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas chos rnam pa sna tshogs bstan pa dang rjes su mthun zhing sngags kyi spyod pa dang rjes su mthun pa legs par bstan pa nyid do/ / rgyal po chen po gang la la zhig 'dus pa'i le'u 'di klog par 'gyur ba dang / 'dzin par 'gyur ba dang / yid la byed par 'gyur ba'am/ g.yul gyi thog mar glang po che'i steng du bzhag pa dang / me tog dang / bdug pa dang / dri dang / phreng ba dang / byug pa rnam pa sna tshogs kyis mchod par byed na/ de la bdag cag byin gyis rlob par byed cing phyir rgol ba dang / dgra bo dag kyang dbang du 'gyur la gzhan gyi dmag gi dpung yang gzhig par bgyi'o/ / glegs bam la bris pa byas te rang gi khyim tu bzhag na de la rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo'am rgyal po'am rgyal po chen po'am rgyal mo'am rgyal mo chen mo'am/ dge slong ngam dge slong ma'am/ dge bsnyen nam dge bsnyen ma dag la srung ba chen po dang longs spyod chen po dang ldan pa dang / tshe ring ba nyid dang / nad med pa nyid dang / longs spyod rtag tu mngon par 'phel ba nyid kyang bgyi'o/ /

“Good! It is good, O son of the victorious ones! This Dharma discourse, which leads beings to enter an illustrious Dharma path whose special purpose is mantra practice, has been well presented for the benefit of all beings. O divine youth Mañjuśrī, this talk that is in accord with mantra practice and complies with the requirements of a fine Dharma discourse has been eloquently presented. If any king has this chapter, which records the coming together of the audience, retold, or causes it to be memorized or reflected upon, or if, before a battle, he has it mounted on an elephant and worshiped with various flowers, incense, scents, and ointments, there we will also be present. We will bring his opponents and enemies under control, and we will destroy the armies that oppose him. Or, if anyone keeps it in their house written in the form of a book, we will grant to that son or daughter of the Buddha family‍—be they a king or a queen, a monk or a nun, or a male or female lay practitioner‍—protection, prosperity, long life, life free from disease, and the continuous increase of good fortune.”
de skad ces smras nas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor cang mi smra bar gyur to/ /
Having said this, the great assembly fell silent.

theg pa chen po sngags kyi spyod pa bstan pa'i cho ga zhib mo chen po las/ byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i rnam par 'phrul pa'i le'u rab 'byam rtsa ba'i cho ga zhib mo las 'dus pa'i le'u ste dang po'o// //

This concludes the first chapter, describing the coming together of the audience, from this great root manual containing an exposition of the mantra practices of the Great Vehicle, an extensive textbook that is a miraculous bodhisattva display of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth.
dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga bstan pa
Chapter 2

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor la bltas nas/ / sems can thams cad kyi dam tshig la rjes su 'jug cing kun du lta ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa snyoms par zhug ma thag tu lte ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi phyogs nas 'od zer bye ba brgya stong du ma'i 'khor dang ldan pa'i 'od zer phyung ste/ sems can gyi khams thams cad kun du snang bar byas nas slar log ste/ gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang snang bar byas nas 'khod par gyur to/ /

Now Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, gazing at this entire assembly, entered the samādhi called the gaze that causes all sentient beings to take up the samaya pledge. As soon as Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, entered this samādhi, a ray of light issued from his navel. Along with many hundreds of thousands of millions of other rays, it entirely illuminated all the realms of sentient beings and, reflecting back onto the realm of the Pure Abode, suffused it with light.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po phyag na rdo rjes 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la smras pa/
Then the bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi, the great being, addressed Mañjuśrī, the divine youth:

sems can thams cad kyi dam tshig la rjes su zhugs pa zhes bya ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi le'u rab 'byam gyi spyod pa sgrub pa/ sems can thams cad kyi thun mong du gyur pa/ khyod kyi sngags kyi tshogs gang du sems can yang dag par zhugs na 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi sngags 'grub pa yang dag par thob par 'gyur bas/ sems dpa' chen po khyod smros shig smros shig / de skad ces smras pa dang / gsang ba pa'i bdag po gnod sbyin gyi bdag po la 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas mchog tu gsang ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi rgyud smras so/ / rig pa thams cad yang dag par bskul ba zhes bya ba'i rdzu 'phrul gyi rnam par 'phrul pa ston par yang byed do/ / lag pa g.yas pa bteg nas sor mo'i rtse mos 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor la ston par byed de/ sor mo'i rtse mo de las rig pa'i rgyal po bye ba khri phrag brgya stong du ma byung ste/ byung nas kyang gnas gtsang ma'i gnas kyi gzhal med khang thams cad snang ba chen pos gnas par gyur to/ /

“Please teach, O son of the victorious ones,[273] the full chapter on the maṇḍala called Establishing All Beings in the Samaya, which concerns the accomplishment of the practice that is common to all beings. Having taken up this practice, beings will accomplish your collection of mantras, in addition to accomplishing all mundane and supramundane mantras.” Being thus requested by the lord of guhyakas and yakṣas, Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, taught the most secret system of the maṇḍala. He displayed the magical feat called impelling all the vidyā beings. Raising his right hand, he drew the attention of the assembled congregation by using the tip of his finger, from which emerged many hundreds of thousands of millions of vidyādhara kings.[274] Upon emerging, they illuminated the entire realm of the Pure Abode with great light and remained there.

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed kyi snying po las thams cad byed pa dang / dpa' bo gcig pa spyan drang ba dang gshegs su gsol ba dang / zhi ba dang rgyas pa dang / mngon spyod dang mi snang ba dang / nam mkha' la 'gro ba dang / sa 'og tu 'jug pa dang / chu la mi nub par 'gro ba dang dgug pa dang / rnam par dbye ba dang dbang du byed pa dang / / dri thams cad dang phreng ba dang / mar me dag kyang rang gi rgyud kyi sngags kyis sbyin par byed de/ mdor na ji lta ji ltar sbyar ba de lta de ltar sgrub par byed pa ni yi ge gsum zhes bya ba/ stobs chen po don thams cad sgrub par byed pa/ khro bo'i rgyal po'i sngags smras pa de gang zhe na/

Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, then pronounced the heart mantra of Yamāntaka, the Lord of Wrath, a sole hero suitable for all activities. This mantra effects summoning, dismissing, pacifying, enriching,[275] and assaulting. It bestows the ability to become invisible, travel through space, enter subterranean paradises, and walk with great speed.[276] It can be used for the activities of bringing beings into one’s presence, sowing enmity among them or enthralling them, and obtaining all kinds of perfume, garlands, ointments, and lamps. Being the chief mantra in its own tradition, it can accomplish, in short, anything that it is employed for. It is called Three Syllables. It is a great hero that accomplishes all purposes; it is the Great Lord of Wrath himself.[277] And what is it?
o~M AHhU~M/
“Oṁ āḥ hrūṃ!”

'di ni khro bo chen po de'i snying po ste las thams cad byed pa dkyil 'khor thams cad dang sngags thams cad kyi spyod pa la sems dpa' chen po 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis smras te/ bgegs thams cad 'jigs par byed pa'o/ /
This is the all-accomplishing heart mantra of the Great Lord of Wrath, prescribed by the great being Mañjughoṣa for all maṇḍalas and all types of mantra practice. It will destroy all obstacles.

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas lag pa g.yas pa bteg ste/ khro bo'i spyi bor gzhag pa byas so/ / 'di skad du yang smras te/ sangs rgyas thams cad la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams dgongs su gsol/ gang su dag phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams na rnam par gnas shing mtha' yas mu med pa'i rdzu 'phrul dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams dam tshig la lhag par gnas par gyis shig /

Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, then raised his right hand and, placing it next to the head of Lord of Wrath, said, “Homage to all the buddhas! May the lord buddhas, established in the infinite world spheres throughout the ten directions, pay heed! May the bodhisattvas with great magical powers, present throughout the limitless universe, empower this pledge!”

de skad ces smras nas/ khro bo'i rgyal po la lag pa bskor nas btang bar gyur to/ / khro bo'i rgyal po chen po btang ma thag tu thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams dag tu song nas/ skad cig tsam gyis gang dag sdang ba'i bsam pa dang ldan pa'i sems can rdzu 'phrul che ba dag tshar bcad cing der bkug par gyur nas/ 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang der yang dag par bcug ste/ gnas ji lta ba bzhin du gnas par byas nas sems can ma rungs pa dag la yang kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng ba'i tshogs su byas shing / spyi bo la yang dag par gnas par byas so/ /

Having said this, he turned the Lord of Wrath around and dispatched him. As soon as he was dispatched, the Great Lord of Wrath went to every world sphere and, in an instant, subjugated all ill-willed beings possessed of great magical powers and brought them into the great assembly in the realm of the Pure Abode. Having thus established them there, he assumed a form surrounded by a blaze of light and placed himself atop the heads of the evil beings.

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor de la yang bltas nas/ sems can khyed cag thams cad nyon cig / gang yang dam tshig 'di las 'das par gyur na de la khro bo'i rgyal po 'dis chad pa gcod par 'gyur te gang gi phyir zhe na/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi dam tshig ni 'da' bar bya ba ma yin te/ sngags kyi don gyi tshig gsang ba byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul chen po dang ldan pa rnams kyi mdor bstan pa brjod par bya yis/ de legs par rab tu nyon la yid la zung shig dang bshad par bya'o/ /

Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, looking at the gathering, said, “Please listen, all you respectable beings! Anyone who would transgress my samaya will here be brought into submission by the Lord of Wrath. For that reason the words of the lord buddhas and the bodhisattvas who possess great magical powers‍—the words that convey the meaning of the samaya pledges and the secret mantra‍—should not be disobeyed. Please listen well and keep in your minds what I will tell you.
na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/
“Homage to all the buddhas!
a~M ra ra smra ra a pra ti ha ta shA sa na/ ku mA ra rU pa d+hA ri Ne hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/
“Oṁ, ra ra! Do remember! O perfect teacher possessing the form of a divine youth! Hūṁ hūṁ! Phaṭ phaṭ! Svāhā![278]
grogs po dag 'di ni rtsa ba'i sngags yin te 'phags pa 'jam dpal zhes bya ba yin no/ / phyag rgya ni gtsug phud lnga pa zhes grags te de la rab tu sbyar bar bya'o/ /
“This, friends, is my root mantra. It is called Noble Mañjuśrī. The mudrā that should be employed with this root mantra is the so-called great five-crested mudrā.
rtsa ba'i sngags 'di ni las thams cad pa zhes bya'o/ / snying po'i sngags 'di ni las thams cad byed cing shes pa yin te/
“Next is the all-accomplishing heart mantra. I will now pronounce this auspicious mantra that is suitable for all actions:
oM bA kye daM na maH/
“Oṁ, this [mantra] is [my] homage to speech![279]
'dir phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni gtsug phud gsum zhes bya ba yin te/ longs spyod thams cad mngon par 'phel bar byed pa'o/ /
“The mudrā that belongs with this mantra is the one called three-crested. It increases all pleasure and good fortune.
'dir nye ba'i snying por 'gyur ba ni/
“There is, in this set, also the subsidiary heart mantra:
bAkye hU~M/
“Speech, hūṁ![280]
'dir phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni gtsug phud gsum pa zhes grags pa yin te/ sems can thams cad 'gugs par byed pa yin no/ /
“The mudrā that belongs with this mantra is also the one called three-crested. It will magically summon any being.
'dir snying po mchog tu 'gyur ba ni
“There is, in this set, also the ultimate, one-syllable heart mantra:
maM/
'dir phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni rma bya'i gdan zhes bya bar bstan pa yin te/ sems can thams cad dbang du byed pa'o/ /
“The mudrā that belongs with this mantra is the one called peacock seat. It enthralls all beings and captivates the hearts of all buddhas.[282]

gzhan yang phyag rgya thams cad kyi snying po dpa' bo chen po zhes bya ba yi ge brgyad yod de/ dpal mchog tu byed pa/ dag byed chen po srid pa gsum gyi chos nye bar gcod par byed pa/ ngan 'gro thams cad zlog par byed pa/ zhi ba thams cad byed pa/ las thams cad byed pa/ mya ngan las 'das pa'i bde ba thob par byed pa/ sangs rgyas mngon sum du mthong ba bzhin du nye bar gnas pa/ byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa nyid bzhin du nye bar gnas pa/ sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir/ mchog tu gsang ba'i ngo bos nye bar gnas pa re ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ gang du dran pa tsam gyis mtshams med pa lnga yang yongs su sbyong bar byed na bzlas pas lta smos kyang ci dgos/ de yang gang zhe na/

“There is another mantra, of eight syllables,[283] most propitious, with great purificatory power, which is called Great Hero. It severs the path of the threefold existence,[284] it prevents all unhappy rebirths, it pacifies everything, it performs all activities, it brings forbearance,[285] and it leads to nirvāṇa. It is like meeting the Buddha directly. I myself, the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī,[286] have assumed the form of this most secret mantra[287] for the benefit of beings. It fulfills all wishes and, merely by being called to mind, purifies the five acts of immediate retribution. Is there a need to say more? So, what is this mantra?
oM A bI ra hU~M/ khe tsa ra/
“Oṁ, āḥ! O wise one,[288] hūṁ! You, the sky traveler![289]

grogs po dag 'di ni yi ge brgyad po dpa' bo chen po zhes bya ba/ gsang ba'i snying po'i bdag nyid yin te/ sangs rgyas nyid bzhin du rab tu nye bar gnas pa yin no/ / mdor na bya ba thams cad la yon tan gyi mtha' rgya chen po brjod par ni bskal pa bye ba khri phrag brgya stong du mar yang mi nus te/ 'dir phyag rgya yang stobs po che zhes par rnam par grags pa/ re ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs pa'o/ /

“Friends, this mantra is my very self in the form of the eight syllables. It is a great hero, the ultimately secret heart mantra that is like buddhahood itself.[290] It can, in short, help with any task. The extent of its qualities cannot be described in full even in many hundreds of thousands of millions of eons. There is also a mudrā that belongs with it‍—it is called great fortitude, and it fulfills all aspirations.
spyan drang ba'i sngags ni/
“There is also, in this set of mantras, a summoning mantra:

oM he he ku mA ra bi shwa rU pi NI/ sarba bA la b+hA Shi ta pra bo d+ha ne/ e h+ye hi b+ha ga bAn/ e h+ye hi ku mA ra/ krI Da nut+pa la d+hA ri Ne maN+Da la ma d+h+ye tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM hUM/ mA bi laM ba ku ru phaT swA hA/

“Oṁ, he he! O divine youth! You [assume] every form to awaken childish beings through speech. Please come, O lord, come! You, who playfully hold the blue lotus of the divine youth,[291] please remain in the center of the maṇḍala, please do! Please remember your samaya pledge! You are a perfect teacher, hūṁ! Do not delay! Act! Phaṭ, svāhā![292]

'di ni bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal gyi spyan drang ba'i sngags so/ / sangs rgyas thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang / lha dang / klu dang / gnod sbyin dang / dri za dang / lha ma yin dang / nam mkha' lding dang / mi'am ci dang / lto 'phye chen po dang / sha za dang / srin po dang / 'byung po thams cad kyi'ang yin no/ /

“This mantra calls upon Lord Mañjuśrī and also summons all beings‍—all bodhisattvas, all pratyekabuddhas, venerable śrāvakas, gods, nāgas, yakṣas, gandharvas, garuḍas, kinnaras, mahoragas, piśācas, rākṣasas, and all spirits.

tsan+dan gyi chur byas te/ lan bdun bsngags nas/ phyogs bzhi dang / steng dang / 'og dang / thams cad du gtor na sangs rgyas dang / byang chub sems dpa' dang / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa rang nyid 'khor dang bcas pa thams cad dang / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad dang / sngags dang de bzhin du 'byung po'i tshogs dang sems can thams cad 'gugs par 'gyur ro/ /

“Should one incant sandalwood water seven times and throw it upward, downward, across, and all around in the four directions, all the buddhas and bodhisattvas will come, along with Mañjuśrī himself with his retinue, all the mundane and supramundane mantra deities,[293] the entire host of spirits, and all beings.
na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ oM d+hu d+hu ra d+hu ra d+hu ma bA si ni/ d+hu ma ra tsi shi hUM tiSh+Tha sa ma ya ma nu sma ra swA hA/ bdug pa'i sngags so/

The incense mantra is as follows: “Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! [The mantra is:] “Oṁ, dhu, be steady, be steady! Remain within the fragrant flame of incense, hūṁ! Remember your samaya! Svāhā![294]

tsan+dan dang / ga pur dang / gur gum gcig tu byas te/ bdug pas bdugs na de bzhin gshegs pa rnams dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / sems can thams cad bdug pas tshim zhing dgyes nas bzhugs par 'gyur ro/ / 'dir yang phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni/ / pad+ma'i phreng ba zhes grags pa/ / thams cad 'gugs byed zhi ba yin/ / spyan drang ba yi sngags la yang / / pad+ma'i phreng ba bzang po zhes/ / bya ba'i phyag rgya 'di nyid do/ /

“Having blended together sandalwood, camphor, and saffron, one should offer it as incense to the tathāgatas, all the bodhisattvas, and all beings. Their minds gratified by the incense, they will all be drawn[295] to it. The mudrā that belongs with this mantra is called garland of lotuses. This auspicious mudrā attracts all sentient beings. This is the mudrā of ritual activity,[296] called garland of lotuses.

sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / sems can thams cad byon pa la mchod yon dbul bar bya ste/ ga bur dang tsan+dan dang gur gum chu dang sbyar nas/ me tog ku su dang ma li ka dang / dbyar gyi me tog dang me tog pun nA ga dang me tog ba ku la dang / me tog paN+DI ta ga ru 'di dag gang yang rung ba'i me tog gam/ dus ci lta ba'i me tog dri zhim po bcug ste/ sngags 'dis mchod yon dbul bar bya'o/

“When all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, and also all sentient beings, have arrived, one should prepare a welcome offering. Having infused water with camphor, sandalwood, and saffron, one should mix into it the flowers of royal jasmine, sacred jasmine, or Arabian jasmine; the blossoms of the pannay tree, cobra’s saffron tree, bulletwood tree, and the flowers of crepe jasmine; or any other fragrant flowers that may be in season. One should present the welcome offering while saying the following mantra:

na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ he he ma hA kA ru Ni ka bi shwa rU pa d+hA ra ni/ ar+g+haM pra tIts+tsha pa ya/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha/ maN+Da la ma d+h+ye pra be sha ya pra be sha ya/ sarba b+hu tA nu kaM pa ka grih+na grih+na hUM/ aM ba ra bi tsA ri Ne swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! The mantra is: “He, he, O greatly compassionate one who assumes all forms! Please accept the welcome offering and let [the others] accept it. Remember your samaya pledge! Endure, endure! Enter into the center of the maṇḍala and let [the others] enter! You who have compassion for all beings, please take, take [this offering], hūṁ! Svāhā to the one who abides in space![297]
'dir yang phyag rgya ni gang ba zhes bya bar grags pa sems can thams cad dang rjes su mthun zhing brtan pa'o/ / 'dir yang dri'i sngags su 'gyur ba ni/
“The mudrā that belongs with this mantra is called the complete; it is steadfast and suitable for all beings. There is also, in this set, the mantra of perfume:

na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ na maHsa man+ta gan+d+hA ba b+hA sa shri ye/ ta thA ga tA ya/ tad+ya thA/ gan+d+he gan+d+he gan ng+h+yA de/ gan+d+ha ma no ra the/ pra tIts+tsha pra tIts+tsha maM/ gan+d+haM sa ma tA nu tsA ri Ni swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas! Homage to the tathāgata Glorious with Surrounding Fragrance and Light! The mantra is: “Gandhā, Gandhā! Rich in fragrance! You who gratify with fragrance! Take this perfume, take![298] Svāhā to the one who abides in equanimity![299]
'dir phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni lo ma zhes bya ba re ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa'o/ / 'dir me tog gi sngags su 'gyur ba ni/
“In this set there is also the mudrā that fulfills all hopes called blossom, and a mantra of flowers, which is as follows:

na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ na maHsaM ku su mi ta rA dza s+ya/ ta thA ga ta s+ya/ tad+ya thA/ ku su me ku su me ku su mA d+h+ye/ ku su ma pU ra bA si ni/ ku su ma ba ti swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! Homage to the tathāgata Saṃkusumita Rājendra! The mantra is: “Kusumā, Kusumā! Rich in flowers! Dwelling in the flower palace with an abundance of flowers! Svāhā![300]

bdug pa'i sngags 'di nyid dang gong du bstan pa'i bdug pas bdug par bya'o/ / sku ni rmad byung bsam mi khyab/ / sangs rgyas thams cad phyag 'tshal te/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis gsungs pa yi/ / gtor ma'i sngags ni bshad par bya/

“One should burn incense while saying the mantra of incense given above. “Paying homage to all the buddhas, Inconceivable and marvelous in form, I will now proclaim the bali mantra, As taught by the completely awakened ones.

na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ he he b+ha ga bAn/ ma ha sa twa sarba lo ki te i maM ba li gr-ih+NA pa ya gr-ih+NA pa ya hUM hUM/ sarba bi shwa ra ra Ta Ta s+pha Ta swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, the perfect teachers! The mantra is: “He, he! O venerable great being with the gaze of the Buddha! Do not delay! Please take this bali and let [the others] take it! Hūṁ, hūṁ! You with all [forms]! Ra ra, ṭa ṭa! Phaṭ! Svāhā![301]
'dis ni bshos dbul bar bya ste/ 'byung po thams cad kyi gtor ma yang bya'o/ / 'dir yang phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni/ / mdung zhes bya ba ma rungs pa/ / thams cad zlog par byed pa'o/ /

“One should offer, with the above mantra, bali of food that satisfies all the senses. In this set there also is a mudrā called spear, which wards off all evildoers. Here belongs also the mantra of lamps:

na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ sarba ta mo \u0f85n+d+ha kA ra bid+hAn sa nAM/ na maHsa man+ta dz+yo ti gan d+hA ba b+hA sa shri ye/ ta thA ga tA ya/ tad+ya thA/ he he b+ha ga bAn/ dz+yo ti ra smi sha ta sa ha sra pra ti maN+Di ta sha rI ra bi kurba bi kurba ma ha bo d+hi sa twA sa man+ta dz+wa lod d+yo ti ta mUr ti khurda khurda/ a ba lo ka ya/ a ba lo ka ya mAn/ baM sarba/ sa twA nAM tsa swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers who remove the darkness of ignorance! Homage to the tathāgata Splendid with Light and Fragrance All Around! The mantra is: “He, he! O venerable lord with a body adorned with hundreds of thousands of rays of light! Please manifest [yourself] magically, please do! O great bodhisattva with a body illuminated by radiating light! Please frolic and play! Behold [with compassion] the totality of beings, behold! Svāhā![302]
mar me'i sngags te 'dis mar me dbul bar bya'o/ / kha bye ba zhes bya ba'i phyag rgya ni/ / sems can kun gyis mthong ba'o/ /
“This is the mantra of lamps; with it, one should offer butter lamps. The mudrā that belongs with it is called beholder of all beings. In this set belongs also the mantra that produces fire:
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ dz+wa la dz+wa la/ dz+wa lA ya dz+wa lA ya/ hUM bi b+ho da ka ha ri kr-iSh+Na ping+ga la swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! The mantra is: “Burn, burn! Set ablaze, set ablaze! Huṁ! [303]

me'i bya ba byed pa'i sngags so/ / 'dir yang phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni/ / sems can kun la 'od gsal byed/ / kha sbyar zhes byar 'jig rten grags/ / byang chub sems dpa' blo ldan gyir/ / thub pa mchog gis sngon bshad pa'o/ /

“This is the mantra that produces fire. The mudrā that belongs with this mantra is called the hollow space. It is famed throughout the world and illuminates all beings with light. It has been taught before by the best among sages to the bodhisattva Dhīmat.”[304]

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas byang chub sems dpa' phyag na rdo rje la smras pa gsang ba pa'i bdag po sngags kyi tshig 'di ni gsang ba dang bcas shing mchog tu gsang bar bya ba yin te/ khyod bu 'jig rten rnams grags pa'i/ / mi bzad pa ni gang yin pa/ / sngags rnams dag ni thams cad kyis/ / mkhas pa rnams kyis bsgrubs pa ste/ / spyi bo'i gdu bu zhes grags pa/ / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs kyang yin/ / de ni rnam par gzhig bya'i phyir/ / rig pa 'di ni yang dag brjod/ /

Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, said this to the bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi: “These mantric formulae, O lord of guhyakas, are most esoteric and require secrecy. “There is, known to belong to your buddha family,[305] A wrathful and terrifying son, Whose every mantra, without exception, Yields results for the wise. “His name is Mūrdhaṭaka and he belongs To both the Vajra and the Lotus families. The following formula is now taught For the sake of invoking his power to expel.

na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ oM ka ra ka ra/ ku ru ku ru/ ma ma kAr+yaM b+hany+dza b+hany+dza/ sarba big+h+na da ha da ha sarba badzra bi nA ya kaM mUr+N+ha ga TaM dzri bi tAn+ta ka ra ma hA bi kr-i ta rU pa d+hA ri Ni/ pa tsa pa tsa sarba duSh+TA na/ ma hA ga na pa ti dzI bi tAn+ta ka ra ban d+ha ban d+ha sarba gra hAn/ ShaT mu kha ShaT b+hu dza/ ShaT tsa ra Na ru dra mA na ya/ biSh+Nu mA na ya bra h+mA d+ya de ba mA na ya mA bi laM ba/ la hu la hu maN+Da la ma d+h+ye pra be sha ya/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra hU~M hU~M hU~M hU~M hU~M hU~M s+pha Ta s+pha Ta swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, the perfect teachers! “Oṁ, act, act! Please carry out my task! Break all the troublemakers, break! Burn all the vajravināyakas,[306] burn! Mūrdhaṭaka, you who bring death! One with misshapen form! Cook, cook all miscreants! Bringer of the death of Mahāgaṇapati! Bind, bind all the spirits who cause possession! O six-faced, six-armed, six-footed one! Please summon Rudra! Summon Viṣṇu! Summon the gods, Brahmā and so forth! Do not delay, do not delay! Protect, protect! Enter into the center of the maṇḍala! Remember your samaya pledge! Hūṁ hūṁ! Phaṭ phaṭ! Svāhā![307]

gsang ba pa'i bdag po 'di ni 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i mchog tu gsang ba'i sngags chen po gdong drug pa zhes bya ba yin te/ khro bo'i rgyal po bgegs thams cad 'jig par byed pa ste/ 'di brjod pa tsam gyis sa bcu'i dbang phyug la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yang 'jigs par byed pa yin na/ bgegs ma rungs pa lta smos kyang ci dgos 'di brjod pa tsam nyid kyis srung ba chen po byas par 'gyur ro/ / 'dir yang phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni/ / nag po chen po zhes bya ba'i/ / bgegs rnams thams cad 'jig byed pa'o/ / 'di nyid kyi khro bo'i rgyal po'i snying po ni/

“This mantra, O supreme lord of guhyakas, which is supremely secret, is called Six-Faced Mañjuśrī of Great Courage.[308] He is the Great Lord of Wrath himself, the destroyer of all obstacle makers. As soon as it is recited, even the bodhisattvas established on the tenth bodhisattva level will flee, not to mention wicked trouble makers. As soon as it is recited, great protection is effected. The mudrā that belongs with it is called great spear;[309] it destroys all obstacles. The following is the heart mantra of this Lord of Wrath:
oM hrIHSh+TIHbi kr-i tA na na hU~M sarba sha trUM nA sha ya staM b+ha ya phaT phaT swA hA/
“Oṁ, hrīṁḥ, jñīḥ! You with contorted face, huṁ! Destroy all the enemies! Paralyze them! Phaṭ phaṭ! Svāhā![310]

sngags 'di brjod pas dgra thams cad zug gzer chen po dang / nad chen po dang nyin bzhi pa'i rims kyis thebs par 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu dga' ba med pa dang / byams pa med pa dang / snying rje'i sems thob par mi 'gyur te/ bzlas pa zin gyi bar du grol bar mi 'gyur zhing 'chi bar 'gyur ro/ / dkon mchog gsum la gnod pa byed pa dag la bya'i/ zhi ba'i sems yod pa gzhan dag la ni ma yin no/ / phyag rgya ni rtse gsum chen po zhes bya ba sbyar bar bya'o/ / 'dir nye ba'i snying por 'gyur ba ni/

“With this mantra one can afflict all enemies with severe pain or quartan fever.[311] But if one keeps reciting for as long as one likes, or until loving kindness or compassion arise,[312] the target will not be freed at the end of the recitation and will die.[313] Thus, this should only be performed on enemies of the Three Jewels and not on others with peaceful minds. “One should also employ the mudrā great spear.[314] In this set there is also a subsidiary heart mantra:
oM tri kA la rU pa hU~M khaM swA hA/
“Oṁ, hrīṁḥ! O Kālarūpa! Huṁ, khaṁ! Svāhā![315]

phyag rgya ni rtse gsum chen po zhes bya ba nyid sbyar bar bya'o/ / ma rungs pa thams cad la gang 'dod pa de byed par 'gyur ro/ / snying po'i mchog sangs rgyas thams cad kyis byin gyis brlabs pa'i yi ge gcig pa zhes bya'o/ /

“Only the great spear mudrā should be employed. One will be able to deal with any wicked being that one wants to. There is also a supreme heart mantra, rich in the blessing of all the buddhas, consisting of just one syllable:
hU~M/
“Hūṁ!

'di ni las thams cad byed pa'o/ / phyag rgya yang rtse gsum chen po zhes bya bar sbyar bar bya'o/ / phung khrol thams cad zlog par byed pa/ 'byung po thams cad dbang du byed pa ste/ mdor na khro bo'i rgyal po 'di ni las thams cad la sbyar bar bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor gyi dbus su bzlas pa byas na grub pa'i dus su khyad par du 'phags par 'gyur ro/ / 'dir gshegs su gsol ba'i sngags su 'gyur ba ni/

“This mantra accomplishes all ritual activities. With this mantra, too, only the great spear mudrā should be employed. It will put an end to all misfortune, and will enthrall all beings. In short, this mantra, the Lord of Wrath, can be employed in all ritual activities. It should be recited, especially at the time of the accomplishment, at the center of the maṇḍala. “The following are the mantras of dismissing:

na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ dza ya dza ya su dza ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni ka bi shwa rU pi Ni gats+tsha sarba bud d+hAsh+tsa/ bi sar+dz+dza ya sa pa rI bA raM swa b+hA ba nAM tsa pra be sha ya sa ma ya ma nu sma ra sarbAr+thAsh+tsa me sid d+h+yan+tu man+t+ra pa da ma no ra thany+tsa/ me pa ri pU ra yan+tu swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! The mantras are: “Win a victory, an auspicious victory, O most compassionate [lord] whose nature is everything! Go, go to your own abode and dismiss [also] all the buddhas with their retinues. Cause them to return to their respective dwellings. Remember the pledge. May the words of [these] mantras fulfill my every purpose. Make my wishes come true, svāhā![316]

'di ni gshegs su gsol ba'i sngags te/ las thams cad la sbyar bar bya'o/ / phyag rgya ni bzang po'i gdan zhes bya ba yin te/ 'dis gdan la yang sbyar bar bya'o/ / yid kyis bzlas pa bdun byas te gshegs su gsol lo/ /

“The above mantra of dismissing can be employed in all ritual activities. The accompanying mudrā is called auspicious seat. With this mudrā one should provide the seat.[317] The dismissal is effected after mentally reciting the above mantra seven times.

'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi dkyil 'khor dang sngags dang sngags grub pa dag dang / dam tshig dang / bzlas pa dang / dus dang nges par sdom pa dag la yang sbyar bar bya'o/ / de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la yang bltas te/ 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po dang / rang gi rig pa'i tshogs kyi sngags kyi le'u rab 'byam smras so/ /

“Mastery of this mantra is useful for all mundane and supramundane maṇḍalas and mantras. It is to be applied to the observances at the time of samaya recitation.”[318] Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, again directed his gaze at the Pure Abode and the great assembly gathered there, and taught in full the section on the mantras of the host of vidyās from his own great retinue-circle:
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta gA trA NAM/ oM ri Ti ni swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! “Oṁ riṭi svāhā!
'di ni 'jam dpal gyi rjes su 'brang ba skra can ma zhes bya ba'i rig pa/ las thams cad byed pa/ phyag rgya chen po gtsug phud lnga zhes bya ba dug gi las thams cad la sbyar bar bya'o/ /
“This vidyā, Keśinī by name, is an attendant of Mañjuśrī and may be employed in all rites. When combined with the great five-crested mudrā, she may be employed in all rites involving poison.
na maHsarba bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ oM ni ti Ti/
“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! “Oṁ niṭi!
'di ni nye ba'i skra can ma zhes bya ba'i rig pa yin te las thams cad byed pa'o/ / phyag rgya ni kha bye ba zhes bya ba gza' thams cad kyi las la sbyar bar bya'o/ /
“This vidyā, Upakeśinī by name, may be employed in all rites. When combined with the mudrā budding blossom, she may be employed in all rites involving demonic possession.[319]
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta ga tI nAM/ laM ni/
“Homage to all the buddhas, whose conduct is impeccable! “Oṁ niḥ![320]
rig pa 'di ni pad+ma can zhes bya ste/ las thams cad byed cing dge ba'o/ / phyag rgya bzang po'i gdan zhes bya ba dang ldan pas gnod sbyin mo nges par dgug par bya'o/ /
“This vidyā, Nalinī by name, Is useful in all ritual activities. When combined with the mudrā auspicious seat, She will certainly summon yakṣiṇīs.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a tsin t+yAd b+hu ta rU pI NAM/ oM Sh+Tai Sh+Tai swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, Whose forms are inconceivable. “Oṁ jñaiḥ svāhā![321]

phyag rgya mdung ni bsdam pa yis/ mkha' 'gro ma rnams 'joms par byed/ / sangs rgyas dag ni thams cad kyis/ / thams cad gzugs can rab bsngags pa/ / rig pa thod can zhes bya ba/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis bshad pa yin/ /
“When combined with the mudrā spear, This vidyā will kill all the ḍākinīs. “This vidyā, Kapālinī by name, Was taught by Mañjughoṣa. The buddhas perpetually praise Her divine form.[322]
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta tsa rI NAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM ba ra de swA hA/ /
“Homage to all the buddhas, the followers of impeccable paths! The vidyā of Varadā is: “Oṁ, Varadā! Svāhā![323]
phyag rgya gtsug phud gsum nyid ni/ / dpal sbyin byed pas sbyar bar bya/ / gzugs mnga' 'chang ba lha mo ni/ / myur du longs spyod sgrub byed pa'o/ /
“With a propitious attitude, One should combine this vidyā with the mudrā three-crested. This vidyā goddess assumes many forms And swiftly bestows good fortune.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a tsin t+yAd b+hu ta rU pI NAM/ oM b+hu ru swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! “Oṁ bhūri svāhā![324]
phyag rgya mdung rtse yang dag sbyar/ / rims nad thams cad rnam 'jig yin/ /
“When combined with the mudrā spear, This vidyā will remove all fever.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA NAM/ a tsin t+yAd b+hu ta rU pI NAM/ oM tA re swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! “Oṁ ture svāhā!
rig pa phug ron zhes bya ba/ / las rnams kun la rab tu bsngags/ / phyag rgya mdung dang ldan pa yis/ / bgegs ni 'joms par byed pa yin/ /
“This vidyā, Tārāvatī[325] by name, Is proclaimed to be effective in all rites. When combined with the mudrā wand of power, It will destroy obstacles.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a tsin t+yAd b+hu ta rU pI NAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM bi lo ki ni swA hA/ /
“Homage to all the buddhas, Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! The next vidyā is: “Oṁ, Vilokinī! Svāhā![326]
rig pa snang ldan zhes bya ba/ / 'jig rten thams cad dbang du byed/ / bde ba thams cad sbyin byed pa/ / gdong gi phyag rgya sbyar bar bya/ /
“This vidyā, Lokavatī by name, Can enthrall the entire world. When combined with the mudrā the mouth, It will grant every type of enjoyment.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a tsin t+yAd b+hu ta rU pI NAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM bi shwe bi shwe saM b+hA be bi shwa rU pI Ni ka ha ka ha a be shwa be sha sa ma ya ma nu sma ra ru ru tiSh+Tha swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! The next vidyā is: “Oṁ, you are the totality [of things], the source of everything, possessed of all forms! Summon, summon! Enter [them], enter! Remember your pledge! Ru ru! Please remain! Svāhā![327]

rig pa chen po stobs chen 'di/ / 'jig rten 'dren pas bstan pa ste/ / mche ba'i phyag rgya ldan byas na/ / sems can thams cad 'bebs shing dge/ / 'byung po kun la mchog sbyin pa/ / thams cad ces ni yang dag bsgrags/ /

“This vidyā, Mahāvīryā, Was taught by guides of the world. When combined with the fangs mudrā, She, the auspicious, enters all weapons.[328] She is a granter of boons, And proclaimed as the totality of all beings.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a tsin t+yAd b+hu ta rU pI nAM/ oM shwe te shrI ba su swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! The next vidyā is: “Oṁ, you with the white, splendorous body! Svāhā![329]

rma bya'i gdan gyi phyag rgya yis/ / rnam dgod las ni thams cad byed/ / dkar mo chen mo zhes bya ba/ / rmad byung bsam med gzugs can te/ / 'jig rten rnams kyi skal ldan byed/ / skyes pa bud med dbang du 'gyur/ /

“When combined with the mudrā peacock seat, This vidyā may be employed in all rites. She is called Mahāśvetā, the brilliantly white one. With her wondrous, inconceivable form, She brings prosperity and happiness to the world, Enthralling both men and women.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a tsin t+yAd b+hu ta rU pI NAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM khi khi ri khi ri b+hang gu ri sarba sha truM staM b+ha ya dzam b+ha ya mo ha ya ba sha mA na ya swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! The next vidyā is: “Oṁ, khi khiri khi riri! The wrinkled one! Paralyze, smash, stupefy, and enthrall all enemies! Svāhā![330]
rig pa 'di ni rig chen po/ / rnal 'byor ma zhes rab tu bstan/ / phyag rgya gdong gsum sbyar byas na/ / ma rungs sems can 'dul bar byed/ /
“This vidyā, Mahāvidyā, Is said to be a yoginī. When used in combination with the mudrā the mouth,[331] She can tame wicked beings.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shAk+ti pra tsa rI NAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM shrIH/
“Homage to all the buddhas, The followers of impeccable paths. The next vidyā is: “Oṁ, Śrī![332]
rig pa 'di ni dpal chen mo/ / 'jig rten mgon gyis bstan pa ste/ / phyag rgya kha sbyar sbyar byas na/ / rgyal srid chen po sbyin byed pa'o/ /
“This vidyā, Mahālakṣmī, Was taught by the protectors of the world. When combined with the mudrā hollow space, She will grant the rank of a great king.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ sarba satwA b+ha ya pra da yi nAM/ oM a dzi te ku mA ra rU pI NI e h+ye hi A gats+tsha ma ma kAr+yaM ku ru swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, The givers of fearlessness to all beings. The next vidyā is: “Oṁ, Ajitā! One with a youthful form! Come, come! Help me with my affairs! Svāhā![333]
rgyal byed ma zhes rnam grags pa/ / gzhon nu bdud rtsi las byung ba/ / rdzogs pa'i phyag rgya ldan pa yis/ / dgra rnams thams cad zlog par byed/ /
“Her name is Ajitā, and she is A girl of royal bearing arisen from ambrosia! When combined with the mudrā complete, She will restrain all one’s enemies.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a tsin t+yAd b+hu ta rU pI NAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM dza ye swA hA/ bi dza ye swA hA/ a dzi te swA hA/ a pa rA dzi te swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! The vidyā of the four sisters is: “Oṁ, Jayā, svāhā! Vijayā, svāhā! Ajitā, svāhā! Aparājitā, svāhā![334]

sring mo bzhi zhes rnam grags pa/ / byang chub sems dpa'i rjes 'gro ba/ / sa rnams thams cad kun 'gro zhing / / kun la rjes su 'dzin byed pa'o/ / ming po gtum bu ru zhes grags/ / 'di dag gi ni rjes su 'brang / / gru yi bzhon pa la zhon nas/ / rgya mtsho la ni gnas pa yin/ / khu tshur phyag rgya bcings pa yis/ / bsam pa thams cad yongs rdzogs byed/ /

“These attendants upon bodhisattvas Are referred to as the four sisters. They wander the breadth of the earth, Showing favor to living beings. “They are accompanied by their brother, Who is referred to by the name Tumburu. They travel in boats, Dwelling on the water. When this vidyā is combined with the mudrā the fist,[335] It will completely fulfill all wishes.

na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ lo kA grA d+hi pa tI nAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM ku mA ra ma hA ku mA ra kri Da kri Da/ shaM mu kha bo d+hi satwA nu dz+nyA ta/ ma yU rA sa na/ shak+to d+ya ta pA Ne/ rak+tAM ga rak+ta gan d+hA nu le pa na pri ya/ kha kha khA hi khA hi hUM nr-i t+ya nr-i t+ya/ rak+ta puSh+pA rtsi ta mUrti sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ b+h+ra ma b+h+ra ma/ b+h+rA ma ya b+h+rA ma ya/ lA hu lA hu mA bi lam+ba sarba kA Ni me ku ru ku ru/ bi tsi tra rU pa d+hA ri NAM/ tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha hU~M sarba bud d+hA nu dz+nyA ta swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, The supreme masters of the world! The mantra of Mañjuśrī-Kārttikeya[336] is: “Oṁ, divine youth! Great prince, play, play! O six-faced one, authorized by the bodhisattvas! Mounted on a peacock seat and raising your hand with a spear in it! Your color is red and you are fond of red fragrances and unguents. Kha kha! Eat, eat, eat! Huṁ! Dance, dance! Your images are worshiped with red flowers. Please remember your samaya! Move about, move! Stir them up, do, do! Quick, quick! Don’t delay! Carry out all my tasks, do! You with a bright and colorful form, remain, remain, huṁ! You have the authorization from all of the buddhas, svāhā!”[337]

skyob pa byang chub sems dpa' ni/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis bshad pa na/ / sa rnams ma lus rnam drug tu/ / kun nas yongs su rab tu g.yos/ / sems can kun gyi don phyir dang / / ma rungs sems can zlog pa'i phyir/ / mi bzad dbang phyug bu'i gzugs su/ / gdul ba'i don du 'dir ston te/ / skem byed dang ni mig dmar gyi/ / phyag mtshan gyis ni mtshon pa ste/ / snying rjes thugs ni brlan pa yis/ / 'jam pa'i ngag gis gsungs pa yin/ / sems dpa'i nang na bdag nyid che/ / byis pa rnams la phan byed gang / / sems can spyod phyir brtson pa ni/ / 'gro ba kun la rnam par spyod/ / phyag rgya mdung dang ldan pa yis/ / bdag nyid chen pos sbyar na ni/ / tshangs pa sogs pa'ang 'gugs byed na/ / mi rnams la ni smos ci dgos/ / gzhon nu'i sems su mtha' dag ni/ / bsdus nas yongs su bshad par bya/ / smin drug bu dang 'jam dpal gyi/ / sngags su 'di ni yang dag bstan/ / sems can rjes su gzung ba'i phyir/ / byang chub sems dpar 'di ston to/ / yig gsum zhes bya'i snying po ni/ / 'di yi sngags su brjod pa yin/ / sems can kun la phan pa'i phyir/ / longs spyod 'dren pa'i mchog de yin/ / phyag rgya mdung dang ldan pa yis/ / bkod na las kun byed pa yin/ /

The bodhisattva Mañjughoṣa, the protector, Spoke these words And the entire earth shook all around In six different ways. At that moment, this terrifying son of Maheśvara Arrived in this world for the benefit of all beings, To restrain every wicked being, And for the sake of those to be trained. “The[338] mantra of Skanda, who is marked with The distinguishing marks of the planet Mars, Should be recited in a soft voice And with the mind filled with compassion. “He is a magnanimous bodhisattva, Acting for the benefit of naive beings. Since he is engaged in virtuous conduct, He wanders everywhere throughout the world. “When his mantra is combined with the mudrā shaft of a spear, This magnanimous being can bring forth Even the state of Brahmā, and so forth, Let alone the state of a human being. “In short, all deafness and dumbness Can be destroyed by this divine youth,[339] For his mantra, when pronounced, Is Mañjuśrī-Kārttikeya himself. “This bodhisattva has arrived in this world With the desire to show kindness to beings. The mantra called Three Syllables Has been taught as his heart mantra. “He is completely dedicated to bringing enjoyments In order to benefit all beings. Combined with the mudrā shaft of a spear, This three-syllable mantra may be used in all rites.
oM hUM dz+dzaH/
“Oṁ hūṁ jaḥ.
sngags 'di mdo ru bsdu byas na/ / mi rnams kyi ni don byed do/ /
“The above mantra, in short, Will bring about birth as a human.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ sa man+ta d+yo ti ta mU rtI nAM/ oM bi kr-i ta gra ha hUM phaT swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, With their forms all radiant! The auxiliary heart mantra of Kārttikeya is: “Oṁ, you disfigured graha! Huṁ phaṭ, svāhā![340]

'di yang nye ba'i snying po ste/ / de bzhin phyag rgya mdung ldan pas/ / 'byung po thams cad 'gugs byed cing / / de bzhin gza' dang ma mor bcas/ / phyag rgya kun gyis phyag rgya la/ / bkod na 'bras bur bcas par 'gyur/ / 'byung po rnams ni dngangs byed cing / / ma rungs 'jug pa zlog par byed/ /

“When this subsidiary heart mantra is combined, Optionally, with the mudrā spear, It will ward off spirits, including grahas, As well as the mātṛs. “This mantra will produce results When combined with any of the above mudrās; It will frighten away evil beings And release beings from their possession.

'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa 'di'i gdong drug gi bu zhes bya ba'i 'jam dpal gzhon nu'i rjes su 'brang ba ste/ las thams cad byed pa ste/ bzlas pa tsam kho nas las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / 'byung po thams cad dngangs par byed pa dang / skrag par byed pa dang / 'gugs par byed pa dang / dbang du byed pa dang skem par byed pa dang / 'jig par byed pa dang rig pa 'dzin pa ji ltar 'dod pa de thams cad sgrub par byed pa'o/ /

“This divine youth called Mañjuśrī-Kārttikeya is an attendant of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth. He may be employed in all rites. By merely reciting him, he will accomplish all tasks‍—frighten any being away,[341] summon it, enthrall it, cause it to wither, or smash it; or, he will bring whatever the practitioner who has mastered his mantra may desire.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM bra h+ma bra h+ma bar tsa sa shAn+tiM ku ru swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! The mantra of Brahmā is: “Oṁ, Brahmā, good Brahmā! You with infinite energy and splendor! Bring peace, svāhā![342]

sngags 'di tshangs pa chen po ste/ / byang chub sems dpas bshad pa yin/ / 'byung pos zhi gyur rab tu thob/ / skad cig nyid la bsil bar gyur/ / phyag rgya gtsug phud lnga sbyar na/ / myur du dge legs thob par 'gyur/ / mngon spyod dag ni thams cad la/ / srid srung gi ni rig byed 'dod/ / 'di ni mdor bsdu bstan pa ste/ / 'di yi cho ga bsdus pa yin/ /

“This mantra is the great Brahmā; He has been taught by the bodhisattva [Mañjuśrī]. Living beings can attain soothing calm The very moment they recite it. “If, in addition, the five-crested mudrā is employed, Good fortune will soon follow. It is taught in all rites of assault On the authority of the Atharva Veda. This procedure has been concisely taught here In its abridged form.
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM ga ru Da bA ha na tsa kra pA Ni/ tsa tur b+hu dza hUM hUM sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ b+ho d+hi satwa A dz+nyA pa ya ti swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! The mantra of Viṣṇu is: “Oṁ, you with a garuḍa for a mount! Holding a discus in your hand! The four-armed one! Hūṁ hūṁ! Remember your samaya! Bodhisattva [Mañjuśrī] is commanding you, svāhā![343]

'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis bka' stsal pa/ / zhi ba'i don ni myur byed yin/ / 'byung po rnams ni rnam 'jig cing / / khyab 'jug gzugs kyi lus can yin/ / phyag rgya gtsug phud gsum sbyar na/ / las rnams kun byed brtan pa yin/ / gang dag khyab 'jug rgyud la ni/ / bya ba rgya cher bstan pa dag / thabs kyis gdul bya'i sems can la/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis bshad pa yin/ /

“Commanded by Mañjughoṣa, He, the peaceful one, will promptly accomplish the assigned task.[344] In his form of Viṣṇu, he will expel spirits From the bodies of living beings.[345] “When employed in conjunction with the mudrā three-crested, He will promptly and resolutely carry out his tasks. Whatever elaborate rites Were expounded in Vaiṣṇava tantras Had been taught by Mañjughoṣa As the means to guide sentient beings.

na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nAM nAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM ma hA ma he shwa ra b+hU tA d+hI pa ti br-i Sha b+ha d+h+wa dza pra laM ba dza Ta dza Ta mu ku Ta d+hA ri Ne/ si ta b+hasma d+hu sa ri ta mUrti hUM hUM phaT phaT bo d+hi sa twa A dz+nyA pa ya ti swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! The mantra of Śiva is: “Oṁ, great Maheśvara, lord of living beings! Having a bull for an emblem! With your matted hair hanging down from a topknot, and your form ash-colored with [the dusting of] white ashes! Hūṁ, phaṭ phaṭ! Bodhisattva [Mañjuśrī] is commanding you, svāhā![346]

sems can rnams la phan 'dod pas/ / sngags 'di bdag gis smras pa ste/ / phyag rgya mdung rtse gsum sbyar na/ / 'byung po thams cad rnam 'jig pa'o/ / bdag gis sngon ni gang bstan pa/ / 'di yi cho ga sngon byung ba/ / sems can sa steng gnas pa la/ / zhi ba pa zhes brjod pa ste/ / yon tan sna tshogs rgya che ba/ / zhi ba'i rgyud las nga yis bstan/ /

“This mantra has been proclaimed by me, Wishing to benefit living beings. Used in combination with the mudrā spear,[347] It will destroy all evil spirits. “The old rites of [Śiva], Which I formerly taught, Are described, by beings who dwell On the surface of this earth, as Śaivite. Different rites of great value, taught by me, Can be found in the Śaiva tantras.

na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM shA ku na ma hA shA ku na/ pad+ma bi dA ta pa k+Sha sarba pan+nA ga na shA ga kha kha khA hi khA hi sa ma ya ma nu sma ra ha tiSh+Tha bo d+hi sa twa A dz+nyA pa ya ti swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! The mantra of Vainateya is: “Oṁ, bird, great bird! With your wings spread like lotuses! Destroyer of all serpents! Kha kha! Devour, devour! Remember your samaya, hūṁ! Remain! Bodhisattva Mañjuśrī is commanding you, svāhā![348]

sngags 'di'i mthu ni chen po ste/ / nam mkha' lding zhes rnam par grags/ / gdul dka' 'dul byed rnams kyi mchog / gdengs ka can gyi dug rnams 'joms/ / phyag rgya che dang sbyar byas na/ / phung khrol shin tu mi bzad 'joms/ / gnas dang 'gro ba'i dug dag ni/ / gso bar byed la the tshom med/ / sems can gdul bya'i thabs su ni/ / byang chub sems dpa'i yang dag bka'/ / nam mkha' lding gzugs sa la spyod/ / 'dab chags dbang po 'od chen ldan/ / ci srid nam mkha' lding rgyud du/ / cho ga rgya cher bstan de dag / sems can rnams la phan pa'i phyir/ / thams cad nga yis bstan pa ste/ / byang chub sems dpa' nam mkha' lding / / dul ba'i don du 'di bstan to/ / gdengs can dug ni gzhom bya'i phyir/ / 'dab chags tshul gyis rnam par rgyu/ / 'jig rten sngags ni ji srid pa/ / cho ga 'di ni bstan pa na/ / sems can gdul bya'i don du ni/ / de lta de ltar rnam par rgyu/ / gang yang de bzhin gshegs sngags dang / / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs dag kyang / / nga yis cho ga rab 'byam dang / / mdo dag kyang ni bstan pa yin/ / ji ltar ma mo mang po ni/ / 'bad pas byis pa rnams srung ba/ / de bzhin byis pa'i blo can la/ / sngags kyi tshul gyis nga yis bshad/ / sngon ni stobs bcu ldan pas bstan/ / da ni nga yis bstan pa yin/ / sngags rgyud don ni ma lus pa/ / 'od chen gzhon nus bstan pa yin/ / rgyal ba mchog gis gang gsungs dang / / stobs bcu ldan pa'i sras gsungs dang / / rmad byung bsam mi khyab tshul gyis/ / 'jam dbyangs kyis gsungs de dag go/ /

“This mantra is intensely potent; It is known by the name Vainateya. It is the supreme tamer of those who are difficult to tame And the destroyer of the poison of snakes. “Used in combination with the great mudrā,[349] It kills the evil and the cruel ones. It will cure poison without a doubt, Whether it is of animate or inanimate origin. “Commanded by the bodhisattva [Mañjuśrī], This king of birds, great in splendor, Travels to different places in the form of a garuḍa To train sentient beings by skillful means. “Whatever elaborate rites Were expounded in the Garuḍa tantras Were all taught by me alone For the good of sentient beings. “That garuḍa bird is a bodhisattva Who has arrived in this world in order to guide[350] beings. He wanders around in a bird’s form To destroy the poison of serpents. “Whatever worldly mantras there are, They have been taught in this manual of rites. I apply them in whatever way is necessary In order to guide sentient beings. “As for the mantras of the tathāgatas Of both the Vajra or the Lotus families, They have been taught In this extensive manual and also before.[351] “Just as a mother enthusiastically plays[352] With her child in various ways, In the same way I assume[353] different mantra forms For the sake of naive beings. “What was previously taught by those of the ten powers[354] I have now taught. The entire subject matter of the mantra system Has also been explained by the divine youth of great splendor. “The verses sung by the supreme victors, And those sung by the sons of those of the ten powers, Have also been sung by Mañjughoṣa In many wondrous and inconceivable forms.”

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang dang / 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po la gzigs nas/ dam tshig thams cad yang dag par bskul ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ / gang du ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs pa na sems can mtha' dag gi sgrub pa'i spyod pa sems la rab tu zhugs par gyur to/ /

Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, gazing at the realm of the Pure Abode and the great gathering that had assembled there, entered the samādhi called the one that animates all samayas. When this samādhi is entered, every being develops the intention to engage in conduct to liberate all sentient beings.[355]

'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang nor bu rin po che sna tshogs pa'i rgyan bkod pa'i dkyil 'khor du gyur te/ bsam gyis mi khyab cing rmad du byung ba'i byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par 'phrul pa rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang / byang chub sems dpa' spyod pa la zhugs pa dang / sa bcu'i dbang phyug la gnas pa dag gis kyang dkyil 'khor de bri ba'am 'drir gzhug par mi nus na so so'i skye bor gyur pa'i sems can gyis lta smos kyang ci dgos/

As soon as Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, entered this samādhi, the entire realm of the Pure Abode changed, by way of a wondrous and inconceivable transformation through his bodhisattva power, into a beautiful maṇḍala adorned with ornaments of jewels and gems of many colors. None of those who have undertaken the conduct of pratyekabuddhas or venerable śrāvakas, nor any of the bodhisattvas, these mighty lords established on the tenth level, would be able to paint or supervise the painting of such a maṇḍala, so what need is there to mention ordinary people?

'phags pa'i dkyil 'khor bzang po de grub pa'i gnas skabs la gnas pa 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas gzigs nas/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' sa bcu la rab tu gnas pa/ rgyal tshab tu dbang bskur ba thams cad dang / spyod pa la zhugs pa thams cad dang / zag pa dang bcas pa dang / zag pa med pa thams cad 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i byin gyis brlabs kyis sangs rgyas dang / byang chub sems dpa'i mdzad pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i rgyu mthun pa dang ting nge 'dzin gyi khyad par gyi thugs las byung ba'i dkyil 'khor la zhugs par bdag nyid kyis yang dag par shes par gyur to/ / sems can so so'i skye bo'i yid kyis kyang de dmigs par mi nus na bri ba'am 'drir 'jug pa lta smos kyang ci dgos/

When they beheld Mañjuśrī, the princely youth, established in the state of accomplishment of the samaya of this divine, noble maṇḍala,[356] all the blessed buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, venerable śrāvakas, bodhisattvas established on the tenth level, crown princes consecrated to kingship, and all those who undertook their respective conduct including beings that are free from or subject to karmic influences perceived themselves, through the blessing of the divine youth Mañjuśrī, as being part of this inconceivable maṇḍala arisen as the consequence of buddha or bodhisattva activity through the mental power of his special samādhi. It is not possible for ordinary people even to visualize this maṇḍala in their minds, let alone paint it or supervise a painting of it.

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas dkyil 'khor chen po bzang po de la rab tu zhugs pa'i sems can de dag la smras pa/ grogs po dag nyon cig 'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa rnams dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis 'da' bar bya ba ma yin na/ sems can gzhan 'phags pa dang / 'phags pa ma yin pa rnams kyis lta smos kyang ci dgos/

Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, addressed the beings who were about to enter the samaya[357] of the maṇḍala of this great assembly as follows: “Listen, friends! This samaya[358] must not be violated even by the tathāgatas and the bodhisattvas, let alone by other beings, be they noble or not.”

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas gas gsang ba pa'i bdag po phyag na rdo rje la smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras mi las 'das pa'i dkyil 'khor dam pa/ yid las byung ba ni bstan to/ / mi rnams kyi dkyil 'khor bstan par bya ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams yongs su mya ngan las 'das na'ang / sems can rnams gang du yang dag par zhugs na/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags thams cad 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de nas gsang ba pa'i bdag po lag na rdo rjes 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la smras pa/ rgyal ba'i sras gang de dus la bab par shes na gsungs shig gsungs shig /

Then Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, spoke to Vajrapāṇi, the general of the guhyakas: “Mentally generated samayas[359] beyond the scope of humans have been taught before, O son of the victorious ones. But I will now teach the samaya[360] of the completely liberated tathāgatas, suitable for humans, whereby beings, once they have entered it, will attain the accomplishment of all worldly and transcendent mantras.”[361] Vajrapāṇi, the general of the guhyakas, replied to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, “Speak, speak, O son of the victorious ones, if the time seems right to you!

shAkya seng ge mgon po ni/ / yongs su mya ngan 'das 'og na/ / sems can rnams kyi sangs rgyas nyid/ / sa steng khyod kyi dkyil 'khor byed/ / mthong ba tsam gyis 'jig rten na/ / sngags ni rab tu 'grub par 'gyur/ / mi shes cho ga nyams pa'am/ / dam tshig bdag por ma gyur na/ / bdag nyid chen po tshangs pa yang / / sngags rnams 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / sngags la dad pa med pas ni/ / 'bad pa du ma byas gyur kyang / / sngags rnams 'grub par mi 'gyur bas/ / ma rungs dam tshig mi bstan to/ / dam tshig sbyor ba nyams pa ni/ / rab 'byam brgya byin yin na yang / / sngags rnams 'grub par mi 'gyur na/ / mi rnams smos kyang ci zhig dgos/ / dam tshig bstan bcos de nyid shes/ / las kyi spyod pa sgrub pa la/ / 'jig rten 'jig rten 'das pa yi/ / sngags rnams thams cad 'grub par 'gyur/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyi dkyil 'khor ni/ / las kun byed la rab zhugs na/ / bstan pa la ni gzhon nu bzhin/ / sngags rnams 'grub par 'gyur ba yin/ /

“Once the protector of the world,[362] The Lion of the Śākyas, had entered into perfect nirvāṇa, You created[363] a maṇḍala here on earth That is, for beings, like awakening itself. “For, when this maṇḍala is merely seen, One will attain, in this world, the accomplishment of mantra. But if the rite is corrupted out of ignorance, Or if one does not master the samaya, “One will not accomplish the mantras, Even though one may be as great as Brahmā. If one does not apply oneself to this tantra[364] And does not meet with its teaching on the samaya,[365] “One will not accomplish the mantras, Even if one exerts oneself again and again.[366] If one’s application of the samaya is corrupt, Then even if one has the perseverance[367] of Śakra, “One will not accomplish the mantras; How then could the humans on earth?[368] However, when one knows the true teaching on the samaya And performs the activities pertaining to conduct, The mantras will be accomplished as soon as they are recited, Be they worldly or noble. “One who has entered the maṇḍala of Mañjughoṣa Will be able to accomplish all activities. One will definitely attain the accomplishment of mantra Just as in the teachings of the divine youth.”
de nas gsang ba pa'i bdag po lag na rdo rjes sems dpa' chen po de la gsol ba btab pa/ kye sems can chen po sems can gyi don gyi phyir mdor bsdus pa'i dkyil 'khor gsungs shig ces so/ /
At that moment, Vajrapāṇi, the general of the guhyakas, supplicated the great being Mañjuśrī: “Ho, ho, great bodhisattva! Please teach concisely the maṇḍala procedure for the benefit of all beings.”
gsang ba pa'i bdag pos de skad ces smras pa dang / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur bas sems can gyi don gyi phyir/ dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga smras pa/
Being thus requested by the general of the guhyakas, Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, commenced teaching the maṇḍala procedure for the benefit of all beings.

re zhig dang po cho 'phrul gyi zla phyed dam dpyid zla 'bring po'am dpyid zla tha chungs sam zla ba yar ngo 'am/ nyin zhag dge ba dang gza' bzang po bltas te/ rgyu skar bzang po dang ldan pa yar ngo'i tshes gcig dang / zla ba nya ba'am dus gzhan la dbyar gyi dus spangs la/ snga dro sa byin gyis brlab par bya ste/

“To start, on a bright fortnight of the month of Caitra or Vaiśākha, which is a ‘fortnight of miracles,’ on an auspicious day, after ascertaining the favorable positions of the planets and when the moon is in the right constellation, either on the first day of the bright fortnight or during the full moon, or at some other time, other than the rainy months, one[369] should consecrate the ground in the morning.

gang du grong khyer chen po la brten pa'am/ dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon rang nyid 'dug par bya'o/ / rgya mtsho chen por 'jug pa'i gnas sam/ rgya mtsho'i ngogs dang nye ba'i grong khyer chen po'i byang shar gyi phyogs su ha cang yang mi ring ha cang yang mi nye bar dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon song ste lo ma'i spyil bu byas pa la zhag bdun nam zla ba phyed kyi bar du gcig pu rab tu gnas par bya ste/

“One should take one’s quarters in a city, or where oneself or the maṇḍala master lives, or by a river that flows into the ocean, or near an ocean shore that is to the northeast of the city,[370] neither too near nor too far from where the maṇḍala master lives. One should build there a hut of leaves and stay there alone for a period of a week or two.

gang gnas de dag tu'ang gtsang ma'i sa phyogs rdo ba med pa/ gyo mo dang thal ba dang sol ba dang / /phub ma dang rus pa spangs pa shin tu gtsang ba shin tu yongs su sbyangs pa'i sa phyogs su srog chags med pa'i chu la ba'i rnam lnga'am/ tsan+dan dang ga pur dang / gur gum gyi chus bsres pa khro bo gshin rje gshed kyi sngags stong rtsa brgyad bzlas te/ gtsug phud lnga'i phyag rgya chen po dang ldan pas sa phyogs der phyogs bzhi dang steng dang / 'og dang thad ka dang phyogs mtshams thams cad du bsang gtor bya'o/ /

“There, one should choose a place on the ground that is clean, covers a square area measuring sixteen or twelve cubits across,[371] and is free from stones, gravel, ash, coals, chaff, eggshells,[372] and bones. Having cleaned and prepared this place well, one should sprinkle it using water that is free of living organisms and mixed with the five products of the cow,[373] or water mixed with sandalwood, camphor, and saffron. This water should be incanted one thousand and eight times with Yamāntaka, the Lord of Wrath, recited while forming the great five-crested mudrā. One should throw the water in the four cardinal and four intermediate directions, upward, downward, horizontally, and all around the area.

de nas phyogs der kun nas gru bzhir khru bcu drug gam khru bcu gnyis sam khru brgyad pa bya ste/ de la chen po ni khru bcu drug pa'o/ / 'bring ni khru bcu gnyis pa'o/ / chung ngu ni khru brgyad pa'o/ / dkyil 'khor 'di ni rnam pa gsum/ / thams cad gzigs pas gsungs pa yin/ / rgyal po 'dod pas chen po ste/ / 'bring ni longs spyod 'phel byed pa/ / chung ngu'i dam tshig yang dag srung / / las rnams kun byed zhi ba yin/ /

“This square area on the ground with four equal sides may be sixteen, twelve, or eight cubits across‍—sixteen cubits is the largest size, twelve the medium size, and eight cubits is the smallest. Such a maṇḍala has been proclaimed by the all-knowing ones to be of three kinds: the largest is for those who desire kingship, the medium serves for bringing enjoyments, and the smallest, which merely safeguards[374] the samaya, can be used in all activities as it is auspicious.

de dag las yid la gang 'dod pa'i dkyil 'khor bri ba ni de la sa phyogs der khru do tsam brkos la/ der rdo ba dang sol ba dang thal ba dang rus pa dang skra la sogs pa dang / srog chags kyi rigs rnam pa sna tshogs gal te mthong na/ sa'i phyogs gzhan du brko ba byas na gnod pa med pa dang 'tshe ba med par 'gyur ro/ / ri bo'i rtse mo dang chu bo'i ngogs dang rgya mtsho'i 'gram dang chu bo chen po'i ngogs su bye ma'i phung po chen po rnams 'bad pas/ shin tu so sor brtags te/ shin tu gtsang ba dang srog chags med par byas la bri bar bya'o/ /

“One should thus draw the maṇḍala in the size that one desires, and excavate its area to the depth of two cubits. If one sees stones, coals, ashes, bones, hairs, or any other products of living beings, one should dig at another location. It ought to be a place where one will not be obstructed or disturbed. If such a place is difficult to find, one should go to a mountaintop, or dig the layers of sand, or other soil, on the beach of an estuary, the sea, or a large river. After examining the place with great care, cleaning it, and removing all living creatures, one should draw the outline.

sa phyogs de yang srog chags med pa'i chu la ba'i rnam lnga bsres te/ chu bo'i klung gis gtsang ma'am/ grog mkhar gyi sa gang du srog chags med pa'i sa des dgang bar bya'o/ / bkang nas kyang legs par brdungs te kun nas mnyam par byas la dkyil 'khor rnam pa gsum gang 'dod par bya'o/ / seng ldeng gi phur ba bzhi la khro bo'i rgyal po'i sngags lan bdun bzla zhing phyogs bzhir gdab bo/ / tshon sna lnga'i skud pa la khro bo'i snying po lan bdun bzlas pa byas te/ dkyil 'khor phyogs bzhi kun nas bskor bar bya'o/ /

“One should further smear this entire area with the five products of the cow mixed with water uncontaminated by living organisms and fill it with unpolluted clay from a riverbank or an anthill, making sure that the clay does not contain living creatures. Once the area has been filled and well beaten, with an even surface, one should create the threefold maṇḍala as required,[375] with a well-beaten and even surface all over. In its four corners one should plant four stakes made of cutch wood, incanting them seven times with the Lord of Wrath.[376] Then, having likewise incanted a five-colored thread seven times with the heart mantra of the Lord of Wrath, one should completely enclose with it the maṇḍala, tracing its four-sided shape.

de bzhin du dbus kyi gnas su nang du yang zur bzhir bya'o/ / dbus na gnas pa'i dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis rang gi rig pa rtsa ba'i sngags stong rtsa brgyad bzla bar bya'o/ / gtsug phud lnga'i phyag rgya chen po bcings nas rtsa ba'i sngags kyis grogs po dang / bdag nyid bsrung bar byas la/ sngags zlo bzhin du dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol tu byung ste/ dkyil 'khor de la g.yas su bskor ba byas nas kha shar phyogs su bltas te/ ku sha'i stan la 'dug par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad yid la byas te/ dkyil 'khor de'i gru bzhi kun du ku shas bskor zhing dgram par bya'o/ / de nyid kyi phyi rol du yang ba rnams zhag gcig gnas pas bsnyal zhing dbyung bar bya'o/ /

“One should trace in the same way a four-sided shape delimiting the intermediate area and another one delimiting the inner area.[377] The maṇḍala master, standing in the intermediate area, should recite the root mantra of his own vidyā[378] one thousand and eight times. By forming the great five-crested mudrā while reciting the root mantra the master will afford protection for his assistants and himself. After reciting, he should step outside and circumambulate the maṇḍala clockwise. Then, facing east, he should sit on a bundle of kuśa grass and contemplate all the buddhas and bodhisattvas.[379] Then, he should completely surround the maṇḍala with kuśa grass,[380] tracing its quadrangular shape. On the outside of it, he should keep two cows for one night without food and then have them led away.[381]

de la dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis sngon du bya ba rnams byas nas rang gi rgyud kyi sngags la mkhas pa dang / sems can gyi don gyi thabs kyi phyir theg pa chen po la mos pa dang / zhag gcig smyung bar byas pa dang grogs bzang po dang ldan pa dang / bstan bcos sna tshogs kyi las mthong bas/ tshon sna lnga'i phye ma zhib mo shin tu gsal zhing legs par sbyar bar byas la/ yi ge drug pa'i snying po mngon par bzlas pa'i phye ma dkyil 'khor gyi dbus su gzhag par bya'o/ / phyi rol du yang rgyal mtshan dang ba dan bsgreng ba dang rta babs bzhis brgyan pa chu shing 'bras bu'i tshogs kyis g.yur za ba dang rnga bo che dang rdza rnga brdung ba dang dung gi sgra dang dga' ba dang / bkra shis pa'i sgra sgrogs pa dag bya'o/ / zur bzhi nas chos mnyan pa dag la bshad par bya'o/ / phyogs bzhir theg pa chen po'i mdo sde bklag par bya ba la 'di lta ste/ bcom ldan 'das yum shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa lho phyogs su bklag par bya'o/ / 'phags pa zla ba'i sgron ma'i ting nge 'dzin nub phyogs su bklag par bya'o/ / 'phags pa sdong pos brgyan pa byang phyogs su bklag par bya'o/ / 'phags pa gser 'od dam pa'i mdo sde shar phyogs su bklag par bya'o/ / glegs bam dag med na mdo sde bzhi po shes pa'i gang zag chos 'chad pa po la chos mnyan pa'i phyir bskul bar bya'o/ / de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon langs nas tsan+dan dang ga pur dang gur gum bsres pa'i me tog dri zhim pa dkar po la rtsa ba'i sngags bzlas te/ dkyil 'khor de thams cad du chal par dgram par bya'o/ / mngon par bkram pa byas nas phyi rol tu byung ste/ zhag bdun gyi bar du 'dod pa'i kha zas bsten pa'i ri mo mkhan gnyis sam gsum byang chub tu sems bskyed pa gso sbyong nye bar bsten pa mkhas pa dag bcug ste/ rtsa ba'i sngags kyis gtsug phud bcing ba byas la/ de nas gser dang dngul dang zangs dang rin po che rnam pa sna tshogs las tshon sna lnga shin tu mdzes pa yid du 'ong ba'i phye ma zhib mo rab tu blangs te longs spyod chen po dang ldan pa dang chos dang ldan pa'i rgyal po dag 'drir gzhug pa byas na/ dkyil 'khor mthong ba tsam gyis nges par byang chub 'thob pa yin na/ / sngags sgrub par byed pa lta smos kyang ci dgos/

“The maṇḍala master, who has completed the preparatory rites, is skilled in the art of mantra in his tantric tradition, is fully intent on the Mahāyāna goal of benefiting sentient beings through skillful means, and has fasted for one night, should prepare, with help from his able assistants and following the prescribed procedure as gleaned from scientific treatises (śāstra), five-colored powder, finely ground, sparkling, and well refined. Having incanted it with the six-syllable heart mantra,[382] he should place it in the center of the maṇḍala.[383] “On the outside, he should adorn the area with raised banners and flags and four gateways. Upon supports of plantain posts he should hang clusters of fruits and have the area resound with kettledrums, tambourines, and the sounds of conchs and lutes. He should have others recite texts of the Mahāyāna sūtras, with their exalted words, containing Dharma teachings suitable for the fourfold assembly. They should be recited in the four quarters[384] as follows: “The blessed Prajñāpāramitā should be read in the south, the noble Candrapradīpasamādhi[385] in the west, the noble Gaṇḍavyūha[386] in the north, and the noble Suvarṇaprabhāsottamasūtra in the eastern direction. If the texts are not available, the master should instruct four Dharma reciters, learned in these four sūtras, to recite them accordingly. Then the maṇḍala master, rising up in order to listen to the Dharma,[387] should strew white flowers of nice fragrance mixed with sandalwood, camphor, and saffron all over the maṇḍala while reciting the root mantra. Having thus bestrewn it, he should exit the maṇḍala. “After seven days, he should bring in two or three highly skilled painters of sacred images‍—ones who rely on sacrificial food, give rise to bodhicitta, and follow the prescribed observances and fasts. The master should tie their hair into topknots while reciting the root mantra. Then, after obtaining nice and finely ground powder in five vivid colors and made from gold, silver,[388] and various shining jewels, the master should request some great kings who follow the Dharma, very wealthy and pure, to commission the painters to do the main drawing,[389] one which has awakening for its goal and invariably leads to such.[390] “One attains this goal of awakening through merely seeing the maṇḍala‍— What need is there then to speak of its bringing about the accomplishment of the mantra?

shAkya'i skyes mchog 'das gyur nas/ / sems can bsod nams chung ba la/ / 'di 'dra'i longs spyod ga la yod/ / de bas cho ga 'di bstan bya/ / 'jam dbyangs 'od chen ldan pa yis/ / skye bo phongs par gzigs nas ni/ / nyung zhing dkyil bsdus dkyil 'khor ni/ / mdor bsdus nas ni bstan pa yin/ /

After the best of the Śākyas has reached nirvāṇa, And at a time when beings have but little merit, How could such a boon be found? But yet this rite is now being taught. “Seeing the misery of poor humanity, Mañjughoṣa, great in splendor, Will now briefly teach the maṇḍala With a summary of its ritual.[391]
'bras sA lu dang thug po che'i phye ma shin tu zhib pa'i tshon sna lnga bzang po/ dkar ba dang ser ba dang dmar ba dang nag po dang ljang gu dag gis bsgyur te/
“One should color the maṇḍala Using finely ground rice grains, Brightly dyed in five colors‍— White, yellow, red, dark blue, and green.[392]

sngar bzhag pa'i tshon gyi phye ma slob dpon rang gis blangs nas/ gtsug phud lnga'i phyag rgya chen po bcings te/ rtsa ba'i sngags kyi bzlas pa byas nas phye ma de la phyag rgya bcing ngo / / sgrub pa'i grogs mchog gi slob dpon gyis dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol shar lho mtshams kyi phyogs su cho ga mthong ba'i las kyis thab khung bya ste/ rgyar khru do la zabs su khru gang ba kun nas 'khor bar pad+ma'i ze ba 'dra ba/

“The maṇḍala master should take up the previously prepared powder, form the great five-crested mudrā, and seal[393] the powder with it while reciting the root mantra. He should have the second officiating master dig a fire pit outside of the maṇḍala to the southeast, following the prescribed ritual. The pit should be two cubits across and one cubit deep, its rim with anthers like a lotus flower.[394]

phyi rol yang pad+ma'i ze ba 'dra ba shing pa la sha'i yam shing gis me sbar bar bya/ shing bil ba'i yam shing mtho gang tsam rlon pa la zho dang sbrang rtsi dang / mar la btags pa la rtsa ba'i sngags 'bru drug pa'am snying pos khu tshur gyi phyag rgya bcings te me lha spyan drang bar bya'o/ / spyan drangs nas sngar bstan pa nyid kyi rtsa ba'i sngags yi ge gcig pa'i snying pos phyir yang brgya rtsa brgyad sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis cod pan dang 'tshog chas byas nas bdag nyid dang ri mo mkhan yang rtse gcig par byas nas sbyin sreg byed du gzhug go/ /

“A fire should be lit outside using sticks of the bilva tree for firewood and sticks of the dhak tree, as thin as the anthers of a lotus flower, for kindling. The former should be nine inches[395] long, moist with sap, and smeared with curds, honey, and ghee. The officiant should summon the fire deity[396] by reciting the root mantra or the six-syllable heart mantra[397] while forming the mudrā the fist. Having summoned it, he should use the previously explained single-syllable root mantra or the heart mantra[398] to once again perform one hundred and eight oblations.

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams yid la byas te/ sngar bstan pa'i bdug pas bdugs nas thal mo sbyar te byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la rab tu btud nas/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la yang phyag byas te/ tshon gyi phye ma blangs nas sku'i gzugs kyis bcad pa la/ ri mo mkhan gyis yongs su rdzogs par bya'o/ / cho ga 'di dag gis dang por sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa nyid rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa/ seng ge'i khri la bzhugs pa gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang na chos ston cing bzhugs pa bri bar bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon ri mo 'dri ba na 'dir sgrub pa'i grogs mchog gis slob dpon bdag nyid bsrung ba'i phyir/ rtsa ba'i sngags kyis 'byung po thams cad pa'i gtor ma gtang bar bya ste/ phyi rol gyi phyogs bzhi dang steng dang 'og dag tu gtor bar bya'o/ /

“Then the master of the maṇḍala, having tied on a turban and prepared the implements, should himself guide the skilled painters in their work.[399] Thinking of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, he should light incense while saying the same incense mantra[400] as previously specified. Folding his cupped palms together, he should bow to all the buddhas[401] and bodhisattvas, and to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth. Having thus paid homage, he should fetch the colored powders and let the painters do their work. They should fill in with the powders each shape as outlined.[402] Employing this procedure, the maṇḍala master should first supervise the painting of the blessed lord, Buddha Śākyamuni endowed with all the supreme features, sitting on a bejeweled lion throne in the realm of the Pure Abode and teaching the Dharma. When the image has been created, the assistant to the maṇḍala master should perform self-protection by reciting the root mantra and then offer bali that satisfies all spirits. He should throw it into the four directions outside of the maṇḍala and also upward and downward.

de nas khrus byas te thab khung du nye bar song nas gos gtsang ma bgos te/ gtsang sbra dang srung ba'i cho ga byas nas gur gum dang bsres pa'i mar gyi sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad bya'o/ / de nas ku sha'i khres la 'dug nas bzlas pa bya ste/ de nyid du gnas par bya'o/ /

“After bathing, ritually pure and wearing clean clothes, he should go to the fire pit and perform the rite of protection and offer one thousand and eight oblations of ghee mixed with saffron while reciting the root mantra. Subsequently, he should sit down on a bundle of kuśa grass and remain there, reciting.
