yungs kar la khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed kyi sngags brgya rtsa brgyad kyis mngon par bsngags la kham phor kha sbyar gyi nang du gzhag par bya'o/ / bgegs kyi rnam pa 'jigs su rung ba'i gzugs can mi bzad pa'i sgra rnam pa du ma rlung dang char dang yul ngan gzhan dang gzhan gang gi yang rung ba mthong na/ khros pas yungs kar kham phor nas phyung la chang par bcangs te lan bdun sbyin sreg byas pa des ni bgegs rab tu 'joms par 'gyur ro/ / mi'i bgegs la ni lan lnga chang pa nas sbyin sreg byas na skyes bu de rengs par 'gyur ba'am/ nus pa med par 'gyur ba'am/ 'chi bar 'gyur ba'am/ skad cig de nyid la mi ma yin pas zin par 'gyur ba la nams kyang the tshom med de/ brgya byin yang 'chi bar byed na ma rungs ba'i sems dang ldan pa'i mi'am/ bgegs tha mal pa lta smos kyang ci dgos/ khro bo gshin rje gshed kyi 'jigs pas bgegs rnams phan tshun du 'bros shing mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ /

“He should incant white mustard seeds one hundred and eight times with Yamāntaka, the Lord of Wrath, and place them between two earthenware bowls.[403] If an obstacle maker is perceived in any form, be it a misshapen figure, a terrible sound, wind, rain, bad weather, or any other form, the assistant should, in a wrathful state of mind, offer seven mustard seed oblations.[404] The obstacles will then vanish. If the obstacle makers are human, he should offer five oblations.[405] They will become paralyzed, lose their strength, and die or will immediately be seized by nonhuman beings. There is no doubt about this. Even Śakra would die swiftly, let alone human beings with wicked minds or other obstacle makers.[406] Seized by the fear of Yamāntaka, the Lord of Wrath, they will disappear, fleeing in all directions.

de nas sgrub pa'i grogs mchog gis de nyid du ku sha'i khres la gnas nas khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed kyi bzlas pa byed cing gnas par bya'o/ / de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i sku gzugs kyi g.yas ngos su/ rang sangs rgyas nyid pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs par bya'o/ / de gnyis kyi 'og tu nyan thos chen po gnyis chos nyan par bya'o/ /

“The assistant should remain seated at the same place, on a bundle of kuśa grass, and keep reciting Yamāntaka, the Lord of Wrath. The master of the maṇḍala should then let the painters execute the painting of two pratyekabuddhas, sitting in a cross-legged posture on lotus seats to the right of the painting of Lord Śākyamuni. Below the pratyekabuddhas, two great śrāvakas listening to the Dharma discourse should be painted.

de dag gi yang g.yas su bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ ston ka'i 'dam bu'i mdog ltar dkar ba/ pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa/ phyag g.yon pa na pad+ma bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas pa na mchog sbyin pa/ de'i yang g.yas na bcom ldan 'das ma yum gos dkar mo phyag g.yon pa na pad+ma bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas pas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la phyag 'tshal ba pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa gser gyi cod pan 'chang ba dar la dkar po'i na bza' mnabs pa/ thal ba nag pos thig le gsum byas pa de bzhin du sgrol ma dang / khro gnyer can yang rang rang gi gnas su spyod lam dag gis gnas par bya'o/ / de dag gi steng du ni bcom ldan 'das yum shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyan dang gtsug tor gyi rgyal mo rnams bya'o/ /

“To the right of them, there should be the blessed lord, the noble Avalokiteśvara, adorned with every ornament, white as the autumn moon,[407] sitting on a lotus seat, holding a lotus with his left hand and making a boon-granting gesture with his right. To the right of him, again, there should be the blessed Pāṇḍaravāsinī, holding a lotus with her left hand and saluting Lord Śākyamuni with her right, sitting on a lotus seat, and wearing a diadem on her hair tied in a topknot,[408] a turban of white silk,[409] white garments, and a tightly fitting silken bodice.[410] She should be painted with three dots made of black ash.[411] Tārā and Bhṛkuṭī should be depicted in a similar way, sitting on their respective seats and displaying their specific postures. Above them are the blessed Prajñāpāramitā, Tathāgatalocanā, and Uṣṇīṣarājñī.[412]

de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' bcu drug bya ba la 'di lta ste/ kun tu bzang po dang / sa'i snying po dang / nam mkha' mdzod dang / sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sel ba dang / ngan song rnam par sbyong ba dang / byams pa rnga yab lag na thogs shing sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la blta ba dang / dri ma med par 'gro ba dang / dri ma med pa'i tog dang / nor bzang dang / zla ba'i 'od dang / dri ma med par grags pa dang / nad thams cad gso bar byed pa dang / chos thams cad kyi dbang phyug gi rgyal po dang / 'jig rten 'gro ba dang / blo chen po dang / blo bzang po ste/ sems dpa' chen po 'di dag ni lus shin tu zhi ba dang rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“The sixteen bodhisattvas should also be included: Samantabhadra; Kṣitigarbha; Gaganagañja; Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin; Apāyajaha; Maitreya with yak-tail whisk in his hand and looking at the Blessed Buddha; Vimalamati; Vimalaketu; Sudhana;[413] Candraprabha; Vimalakīrti; Bhaiṣajyarāja; Sarvadharmīśvararāja; Lokagati; Mahāmati; and Patidhara.[414] Each of these sixteen great bodhisattvas should be depicted in a peaceful form adorned with all types of jewelry.

rig pa'i rgyal po'i gtso bo dang / rig pa'i rgyal mo dang pad+ma'i rigs gzugs dang phyag rgya lung ci lta ba bzhin du gnas ci lta ba ma lus pa dag tu bri bar bya'o/ / mtha'i gru bzhi'i gnas dag tu ni gnas rnams gzhag par bya'o/ / pad+ma'i me tog legs par byas pa dang rig pa'i lha gang dran pa yang de dag tu gzhag par bya'o/ /

“The chief vidyārājas and vidyārājñīs should all be painted in the forms and postures of the Lotus family as passed down by the tradition[415] or described in scriptures and arranged in their respective places. On the periphery, a four-sided area should be designated and strewn with lotus flowers; in this should be included whatever other vidyā deities one can think of.

de bzhin du lho phyogs su bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa dang rang sangs rgyas gnyis ni/ ri spos kyi ngad ldang ba la bzhugs pa bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du dkyil 'khor kyi shar du bdag nyid blta ba dang / thams cad la yang 'jug pa'i sgo rnams bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i g.yon gyi phyogs su rang sangs rgyas gzhan gnyis te/ tsan+dan dang grub pa zhes bya ba gnyis bri bar bya'o/ / de gnyis kyi 'og tu nyan thos gnyis ni 'od srung chen po dang kA t+yA ya na chen po bri bar bya'o/ /

“The two pratyekabuddhas on the right side of Lord Śākyamuni, as mentioned above, are Gandhamādana and Upāriṣṭa.[416] The maṇḍala, facing east, should have entry gates painted on all sides. On the left side of Lord Śākyamuni should be the other two pratyekabuddhas, Candana and Siddha. Below them should be the two great śrāvakas, Mahākāśyapa and Mahākātyāyana.

de dag gi'ang g.yon du 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje ut+pa la ltar mdog sngo bsangs gzugs shin tu mdzes pa rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ lag pa g.yas pa na rnga yab thogs pa/ g.yon pa khro bo'i lus kyis gnas pa rdo rje khu tshur ma rdo rje lcags kyu ma rdo rje lu gu rgyud ma dpung bzang ma rdo rje sde ma cha byad ci lta ba bzhin du bgegs kyi gdan la gnas pa/ rig pa'i rgyal po thams cad dang rig pa'i rgyal mo 'khor dang bcas pa bzlas pa dang / phyag rgya dang ldan pa ji ltar shes pa bzhin bri bar bya'o/ / de dag gi yang g.yon du zur bzhir sna tshogs rdo rje'i phyag rgya bri bar bya ste/ bris nas kyang gnas gang du rig pa'i tshogs ma dran pa'i gnas de dag kyang 'dir bzhugs shig ces brjod par bya'o/ /

“To their left is the noble Vajrapāṇi in his peaceful form, dark blue like a water lily, adorned with all types of jewelry. He holds a fly-whisk in his right hand; his left is clenched into a vajra fist in an expression of wrath. Vajrāṅkuśī, Vajraśṛṅkhalā, Subāhu, and Vajrasenā should all be painted in their respective locations, wearing their specific apparel and emblems and surrounded by retinues of vidyārājas and vidyārājñīs. Their forms,[417] postures, and so forth should be drawn according to the tradition. To their left, a symbol of the double vajra should be painted in the shape of a square. Once painted, the following should be said: ‘In this place, where vidyā beings have not been known to assemble, may they now come to reside.’[418]

de'i steng du pha rol tu phyin pa drug dang / bcom ldan 'das yum mA ma kI bri bar bya ste rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gzugs shin tu mdzes par bya'o/ / de dag gi steng du gtsug tor gyi rgyal po brgyad kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng ba'i phyag rgya bcings nas rang rang dag gi 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po chen po'i gzugs su bri bar bya ste/ gser gyi mdog can dbang po shin tu dul la rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa la zur gyis blta ba dag la/ 'di lta ste/ gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba dang / gtsug tor mngon par 'phags pa dang / gtsug tor gdugs dkar po dang / rgyal ba'i gtsug tor dang / pad+ma'i gtsug tor dang / rnam par rgyal ba'i gtsug tor dang / gzi brjid phung po'i gtsug tor dang / gtsug tor mthon po ste/

“Above them should be painted the six pāramitā goddesses and the blessed Māmakī,[419] all of them with serene forms adorned with all types of jewelry. Above them are the eight uṣṇīṣa kings, each surrounded by a halo of blazing light. Having first formed the appropriate mudrā, the respective forms of these great cakravartin kings should be painted, golden in color, with pacified senses and adorned with all types of jewelry. Their gaze is cast slightly in the direction of the image[420] of the Tathāgata (Śākyamuni). These eight are Cakravartyuṣṇīṣa,[421] Abhyudgatoṣṇīṣa, Sitātapatra, Jayoṣṇīṣa, Kamaloṣṇīṣa, Vijayoṣṇīṣa, Tejorāśi, and Unnatoṣṇīṣa.

brgyad po 'di dag ni gtsug tor gyi rgyal po rnams so/ / g.yon du bri ba ni rang sangs rgyas rnams so/ / 'jug pa'i phyogs kyi sgor ni byang chub sems dpa' gnyis bya ste/ g.yas phyogs su ni 'jig rten las 'das par 'gro ba zhes bya ba ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ lus zhi ba lag pa g.yas pa mchog sbyin pas phreng ba 'dzin pa/ lag pa g.yon pas spyi blugs 'dzin cing sgo la mngon du phyogs pa bzhin cung zad khro gnyer dang bcas pa bri bar bya'o/ 'jug pa'i sgo'i g.yon phyogs su ni byang chub sems dpa' chen po ma rgyal ba las rgyal ba zhes bya ba bri bar bya ste/ lus rab tu zhi ba ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ lag pa g.yon pa na dbyig pa dang spyi blugs 'dzin pa/ lag pa g.yas pa na mchog sbyin pa phreng ba 'dzin pa bzhin cung zad khro gnyer dang ldan pa sgo la mngon du phyogs pa bri'o/ /

“These eight uṣṇīṣa kings should be painted to the left of the pratyekabuddhas. At the gate should be two bodhisattvas: to the right of the entrance, one called Lokātikrāntagāmin, and to the left, the great bodhisattva called Ajitañjaya. The first should be depicted as having a peaceful form, wearing a diadem on his topknotted hair,[422] holding a rosary in his right hand and a water jar in his left, facing the gate, and with a slight frown on his face. The other has a peaceful form, wears a diadem on his topknotted hair and carries a staff and a water jar in his left hand, and in his right hand, which displays a boon-granting gesture, he carries a rosary. He should be painted facing the gate, with a slight frown on his face.

seng ge'i khri'i 'og tu chos kyi 'khor lo kun tu 'bar bas khyab pa/ de'i 'og tu rin po che'i gzhal med khang de la gnas pa bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa/ gzhon nu'i gzugs can sku mdog dmar skya zhi ba'i gzugs dang / mdzes pa'i gzugs can cung zad zhal 'dzum pa/ phyag g.yon pa na ut+pa la sngon po bsnams pa phyag g.yas pa na bil ba bsnams pa/

“Below the lion throne should be painted a Dharma wheel surrounded by a halo of blazing light. Below that should be painted a jeweled palace within which is Lord Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, the great bodhisattva, with a youthful body of pale saffron color. He has a peaceful form of beautiful appearance and a gentle smile on his face. In his left hand he holds a blue lotus; with his right he displays a boon-granting gesture and holds a wood-apple fruit.

byis pa'i rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gtsug phud lngas nye bar mdzes par gyur pa mu tig gi phreng bas mchod phyir thogs pa dar la'i stod g.yogs mnabs pa dar gyi na bzas smad g.yogs mdzad pa 'od kun nas 'phro ba 'bar ba'i phreng bas kun nas khyab pa pad+ma'i gdan la nye bar bzhugs pa khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed la gzigs pa dkyil 'khor du 'jug pa'i sgo la mngon du phyogs pa blta na sdug pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“He is adorned with all the ornaments of youth and is decorated with five locks of hair.[423] He wears a string of pearls, a sacred cord, a silken bodice, and garments of silk. Shining in all directions, he is surrounded by a halo of blazing light. He sits on a lotus seat facing the entrance gate of the maṇḍala and looks toward Yamāntaka, Lord of Wrath. He should be painted as being beautiful to behold in every respect.

de'i g.yas phyogs kyi ngos kyi pad+ma'i 'og tu khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed bri bar bya ste/ mi sdug pa chen po'i gzugs can kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas khyab pa/ bka' len cing 'dzin pa/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po'i phyogs su lta ba'o g.yon phyogs kyi pad+ma'i 'og tu gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu'i gzugs can/ byang chub sems dpa' lnga bri bar bya ba la 'di lta ste/ shin tu dri med dang shin tu dul ba dang dag pa dang mun sel dang kun tu snang ba'o/ / de dag thams cad kyang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang na 'dug pa/ rin po che du ma 'bar ba'i rdo'i steng dang 'dra ba kun nas 'bar ba me tog sna tshogs kyis gcal bkram pa shin tu mdzes pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“On his right side, below the lotus,[424] should be painted Yamāntaka, Lord of Wrath, in his ugly misshapen form, completely surrounded by blazing light. Awaiting a command, he looks at the great bodhisattva Mañjuśrī. He should be painted complete in every detail. On the left side of Mañjuśrī, below the lotus, should be painted five bodhisattvas in the form of gods of the realm of the Pure Abode. These five are Sunirmala, Sudānta, Suśuddha, Tamodghātana, and Samantāvaloka. All of them should be depicted as residing in the realm of the Pure Abode, their beautiful forms covered with flowers and bright all around with multicolored light like multifaceted gemstones.

phyi rol 'khor yug tu zur bzhi'i rnam par byas te/ rta babs bzhi dang ldan pa phyogs bzhi nas rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i tshon sna lnga gsal bas ri mo shin tu drang ba dang ldan pa nang gi dkyil 'khor bri bar bya'o/ / shar gyi bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i steng du ri mo'i dbus su me tog kun nas skyes pa'i rgyal po'i dbang po pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gzugs cung zad chung bar bya'o/ / 'od kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas khyab pa/ mchog sbyin gyi phyag rgya dang ldan pa/ skyil mo krung gis bzhugs pa/

“The inner maṇḍala has an outer perimeter in the shape of a square. It has four archways and shines in the four cardinal directions with a vivid light of five colors.[425] It should be demarcated with nicely colored cord stretched in straight lines. In the eastern quarter, above Lord Śākyamuni, is Saṃkusumita Rājendra. He should be drawn in the center within the cord-lined area, sitting on a lotus, with the body of a tathāgata but small in size, and surrounded by a halo of blazing light. His right hand displays the boon-granting gesture, and he sits in the cross-legged posture.

de'i g.yas su gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba'i phyag rgya bri bar bya'o/ / g.yon du ni gzi brjid phung po'i phyag rgya bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyan gyi steng du ni shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i phyag rgya bri bar bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi steng dang / shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma'i phyag rgya'i g.yas su bcom ldan 'das 'od dpag tu med pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i gzugs can bya ste/ phyag mchog sbyin pa/ pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa kun nas 'od 'bar ba'i phreng bas khyab pa/ de'i yang g.yas phyogs su ni lhung bzed dang chos gos kyi phyag rgya bya'o/ / de bzhin du mthar gyis 'jug pa'i gnas la ni pad+ma'i phyag rgya bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das me tog yang dag par skyes pa'i rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pa'i g.yon phyogs su gtsug tor gzi brjid phung po'i phyag rgya bri ste kun nas 'od 'bar ba'i phreng bas khyab pa/ de'i g.yon phyogs su de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen tog bya ste/ rin po che'i ri bo'i steng du chos ston cing bzhugs pa/ bai DUr+ya sngon po dang margad dang pad+ma rA ga rnam pa sna tshogs 'bar ba'i 'od 'phro ba'i kun nas 'od dang ldan pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“To the right and left of Saṃkusumita Rājendra should be drawn, respectively, the mudrās of the uṣṇīṣa [kings] Cakravartin and Tejorāśi. The mudrā of Prajñāpāramitā should be drawn above Tathāgatalocanā. Above the noble Avalokiteśvara and to the right of the mudrā of Prajñāpāramitā should be drawn Lord Amitābha with the body of a tathāgata. With his right hand Amitābha displays the boon-granting gesture; he sits on a lotus seat and is surrounded by a halo of blazing light. “To Amitābha’s right the mudrās of the alms bowl and the monk’s robe should be drawn. Following the sequence, the lotus mudrā should be drawn at the entrance. To the left of Lord Saṃkusumita Rājendra, the mudrā of the uṣṇīṣa king Tejorāśi should be drawn surrounded by a halo of blazing light. To his left the thus-gone Ratnaketu should be drawn sitting upon a jewel mountain and expounding the Dharma. He should be depicted as surrounded by light emanating all around from a multicolored blaze of sapphires, beryls, emeralds, and rubies.

de'i yang g.yon phyogs su rgyal ba'i gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas khyab pa bri'o/ / de'i yang g.yon phyogs su chos kyi 'khor lo'i phyag rgya kun nas 'bar ba dang ldan pa bri'o/ / de'i yang g.yon phyogs su 'khar gsil dang / spyi blugs dang phreng ba dang bzang po'i gdan gyi phyag rgya bri'o/ / mthar gyis sgo'i gnas su rdo rje rtse gsum pa gnyis ka la yang kun nas 'bar ba bri'o/ / bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i 'og tu phyag rgya chen po gtsug phud lnga zhes bya ba dang / ut+pa la'i phyag rgya kun nas 'bar ba 'di gnyis phan tshun 'brel ba bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor kun nas sgo bri bar bya'o/ / sgo dag ni rgyab kyis lta ba dang / 'jug pa na ni mdun gyis blta bar bya'o/ / phyi rol gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad du 'gyur ba yang kha dog lnga'i tshon shin tu gsal ba sna tshogs blta na sdug pa/ zur bzhis rnam par 'byes pa/ rta babs bzhi'i rnam pa phyogs bzhir khru gnyis tsam nang gi dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol gyi shar phyogs su tshangs pa chen po bri bar bya ste/ gdong bzhi pa gos dkar po bgos pa la stod g.yogs gos dkar po dang / tshangs skud dkar po thogs pa/ kha dog gser 'dra ba/ ral pa'i cod can 'dzin pa/ lag na dbyug pa dang / spyi blugs 'dzin pa/ de'i g.yas phyogs su 'od gsal gyi lha'i bu bya ste/ mdog gser 'dra ba bsam gtan khyad par can gyi gzugs can/ dar la'i gos bgos pa dar la'i stod g.yogs byas pa/ bzhin shin tu gsal ba ral ba'i cod can 'dzin pa mchod phyir thogs dkar po can/ skyil mo krung gis 'dug pa lag g.yas pas mchog sbyin pa/

“To the left of Ratnaketu should be painted the mudrā of Jayoṣṇīṣa, surrounded by a halo of blazing light. To its left is the mudrā of the Dharma wheel, with light blazing all around it. To its left are the mudrās of a mendicant’s staff, water jar, rosary, and the auspicious throne. Next in sequence, at the gate of the maṇḍala, should be painted an earth vajra[426] with three prongs at either end, radiating blazing light. The great five-crested mudrā and the utpala[427] mudrā, both radiating blazing light and connected to one another, should be painted below Lord Mañjuśrī. “Then the surrounding maṇḍala should be drawn. It should be made so that one enters it via the western gate, and it should be facing to the east.[428] This outer maṇḍala should be painted in all its aspects the same as the inner one‍—it radiates five-colored light, is beautiful to behold in its vividness, and it has four gateways in the four cardinal directions. It should extend two cubits beyond the inner maṇḍala. “In the eastern quarter should be painted the Great Brahmā with four faces, wearing white apparel including a white shirt and a white sacred thread. He is of golden color, wears a diadem on his topknotted hair, and carries a water jar and a walking stick in his left hand. To his right there is a god from the Ābhāsvara realm‍—golden in color, distinguished in appearance due to his meditation, wearing silken garments and a silken shirt, and with a serene expression on his face. He wears a diadem on his topknotted hair and a white sacred thread. He sits in the cross-legged posture with his right hand displaying the boon-granting gesture.

de'i g.yas phyogs su 'og min gyi lha'i bu bya ste/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ lus rab tu zhi ba bsam gtan gyi rnam pa'i cha byad can/ dar la'i gos bgos pa dar la'i gos kyis stod g.yogs byas pa/ skyil mo krung gis 'dug pa lag pa g.yas pas mchog sbyin pa/ mchod phyir thogs dkar pos byas pa/ de'i rim gyis dga' ldan dang / 'phrul dga' dang / gzhan 'phrul dbang byed dang / 'thab bral dang / brgya byin la sogs pa'i lha'i bu bri bar bya ste/ go rims ji lta ba dang cha byad dang dbyibs ci lta ba bzhin du'o/ / brgya byin gyi 'og tu rgyal po chen po bzhi'i ris la rtag tu myos dang / phreng thogs dang / lag na gzhong thogs dang / pi bang gnyis pa dang sa bla'i lha'i bu dag go rims ji lta ba dang / cha byad ji lta ba bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du lho phyogs su mi che ba dang / mi gdung ba dang shin tu mthong ba dang gya nom snang dang / dge chung dang bsod nams skyes la sogs pa'i lha'i bu cha byad dang dbyibs ci lta ba bzhin bri bar bya'o/ / nub phyogs dang byang phyogs su yang de bzhin te/ de dag ni rim pa 'og ma gnyis la brten te bri bar bya'o/ /

“To his right should be painted a god from the Akaniṣṭha realm, adorned with all types of jewelry. With his mind steeped in meditation, he is of peaceful appearance. He is wearing silk garments and a silk shirt, sits in the cross-legged posture, and displays with his right hand the boon-granting gesture. He is invested with a white sacred thread. The gods from the Tuṣita, Sunirmita, and Paranirmita realms should be painted following the same sequence, and they are headed by Suyāma and Śakra, each at his assigned location, and following the right order. Below Śakra should be painted gods from the realm of the four great kings, as well as the sadāmattas, mālādhārins, karoṭapāṇis, and vīṇādvītiyakas. The gods of the earth should likewise be painted sequentially arranged, with all their respective attributes. “Similarly, in the southern quarter, the gods starting with those from the Avṛha, Atapas, Sudṛśa, Sudarśana, Parīttābha, and Puṇyaprasava realms should be drawn, all in their respective places and wearing their individual ornaments. The same should be done for the western and northern quarters. More are drawn below the ones just mentioned, arranged in two rows.

dkyil 'khor gnyis kyi phyi rol du dkyil 'khor gsum par 'gyur ba la/ mthar gyis phyogs bzhir rgyal po chen po bzhi ste/ byang phyogs nas 'jug pa'i g.yas ngos su gter nye bar gnas pa la/ nor sbyin rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gtsug phud cung zad 'dud pa gnod sbyin gyi gzugs can/ de'i g.yas su nor bu bzang po dang gang ba bzang po gnod sbyin gyi bdag po gnyis bri'o/ / de bzhin du mthar gyis gnod sbyin ma chen mo 'phrog ma yang bri'o/ / de bzhin du mthar gyis nub phyogs su chu lha lag na zhags pa thogs pa dang / klu dga' bo dang / nye dga' bo dang / 'jog po dang / nor rgyas la sogs pa klu'i rgyal po chen po brgyad po bri'o/ / de bzhin du rim pa gnyis la gnas pa'i mthar gyis gnod sbyin dang / srin po dang / mi'am ci dang / lto 'phye chen po dang / drang srong dang / grub pa dang / yi dgas dang / sha za dang / nam mkha' lding dang mi dang mi ma yin pa la sogs pa dang / sman dang nor bu rin po che'i bye brag dang ri dang chu bo dang gling dang mthar gyis gtso bo thams cad bri bar bya'o/ /

“Outside of the second circle there is the third circle in which the four great kings are drawn sequentially in the four quarters. To the right of the entrance gate in the northern direction should be painted Dhanada in the form of a yakṣa standing next to a treasure trove. He is adorned with all types of jewelry and wears a slightly curved[429] diadem. To his right are the two yakṣa generals, Maṇibhadra and Pūrṇabhadra. “Next, following the proper order, should be drawn the great yakṣiṇī Hārītī with an amiable boy sitting in her lap who is looking at the maṇḍala, as well as Pañcika, Piṅgala, and Vibhīṣaṇa, with the emblems (mudrā) of the yakṣas near them.[430] “Following next, in the west, should be drawn Varuṇa with a noose in his hand, followed by the two nāgas Nanda and Upananda and the eight great nāga kings, starting with Takṣaka and Vāsuki. “In this way should be painted two sequentially arrayed rows of yakṣas, rākṣasas, gandharvas, kinnaras, mahoragas, ṛṣis, siddhas, pretas, piśācas, garuḍas, and other human and nonhuman beings, as well as medicinal herbs, gems and jewels in all their variety, mountains, rivers, and islands‍—with the chief and most important among them at the head.

lho phyogs su ni gshin rje ma mo bdun gyi 'khor dang bcas pa bri bar bya'o/ / shar lho mtshams su me kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas khyab pa/ dbyug pa dang spyi blugs dang phreng ba lag na thogs pa/ ral pa'i cod pan 'dzin pa/ gos dkar po bgos pa/ dar la'i stod g.yogs byas pa/ mchod phyir thogs dkar po thogs pa/ mdog gser 'dra ba thal ba'i thig le gsum byas pa/ de bzhin du rgyan dang mtshon cha dang cha byad dang dbyibs dang kha dog rnam pa sna tshogs pa rim pa gnyis pa la brten te bri bar bya'o/ / thams cad kyi dkyil 'khor du 'jug pa'i sgo'i phyi rol du dka' zlog gi bdag po khyu mchog la zhon pa/ lag na mdung rtse gsum thogs pa lha mo dka' zlog ma kha dog sna tshogs pa rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ smin drug gi bu rma bya'i stan la 'dug pa mdung thogs pa/ gzhon nu'i gzugs can gdong drug pa lus dmar por snang ba/ gos ser po bgos pa/ gos ser po'i stod g.yogs can lag pa g.yon pa na dril bu dang ba dan dmar po thogs pa/ mthar gyis b+h+ring gi ri ti shin tu rid pa 'dra ba dang / tshogs kyi bdag po chen po dang / dga' byed dbang phyug dang nag po chen po dang / ma mo bdun po rgyan dang mtshon cha dang kha dog dang dbyibs ci lta ba bzhin bri bar bya'o/ /

“In the southern quarter should be painted Yama along with his retinue, which includes the seven mothers. In the southeastern quarter is Agni, depicted as surrounded by a halo of flames; holding a staff, a water jar, and a rosary in his hands; wearing a diadem atop his matted hair; and dressed in white garments including a shirt of fine silk. He is of golden color, wearing a white sacred thread, and has a triple line drawn with ash on his forehead. They are all painted arranged in two rows, with their various respective adornments, weapons, attire, body postures, and colors. “All around the area outside this triple maṇḍala are distributed the following deities: Umā’s husband, riding a bull, with a trident in his hand; the goddess Umā herself, of golden color,[431] adorned with all kinds of jewelry; and Kārttikeya, in his form of a divine youth with six faces and a red body, sitting on a peacock, raising a javelin in his hand, wearing yellow garments and a yellow shirt, and holding in his left hand a bell and a red banner. Next in sequence are Bhṛṅgiriṭi, extremely emaciated, Mahāgaṇapati, Nandikeśvara, Mahākāla, and the seven mothers. They should be painted with their respective adornments, weapons, attire, and body postures.

nor lha brgyad dang drang srong bdun dang khyab 'jug lag pa bzhi na 'khor lo dang dung dang ga dA dang ral gri thogs pa/ gdan nam mkha' lding rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gza' brgyad dang rgyu skar nyi shu rtsa bdun dang / gang yang nye ba'i gza' brgyad sa steng gi dkyil 'khor na rab tu rgyu ba yang bri bar bya'o/ / mthar gyis tshes grangs bcwa lnga dang yar ngo dang mar ngo'i phyogs dang / khyim bcu gnyis dang dus drug dang zla ba bcu gnyis dang lo tshigs dang / sring mo bzhi gru la zhon pa dang ming po lnga gru la zhon zhing chu la gnas pa ste/ mdor na phyag rgyar gzhag par bya ba yang yin no/ / lha mo de dag mthar gyis rim pa gnyis pa la brten te bya ba yin no/ / slob dpon bdag nyid phyi rol tu byung nas dkyil 'khor de la g.yas phyogs su bskor ba byas te/

“Next to be painted are the eight vasus and seven ṛṣis. Viṣṇu[432] should be painted with four arms, holding a discus, a mace, a conch, and a sword. He rides a garuḍa and is adorned with all types of jewelry. Next are the eight grahas, the twenty-seven constellations, and the eight upagraha deities who roam the expanse of the earth. Following next are the personifications of the fifteen lunar days of the bright fortnight and the fifteen of the dark fortnight, the twelve signs of the zodiac, the six seasons, the twelve months, and of the year. Next are the four sisters, riding in boats, and the five brothers who live in water. For conciseness these[433] deities can be represented by their respective mudrās and arranged sequentially in two rows.
mdor na dkyil 'khor gsum yang dkyil 'khor la brten cing bri bar bya ste/ dkyil 'khor gsum char yang gru bzhir rnam par gnas par bya ba yin no/ /
“In[434] short, as regards the three maṇḍalas, one should draw them also as the three dwelling places (āśraya), each with the four corners, with the distribution [of the deities] as follows:[435]

mdor na 'di ltar sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das sems can rnams kyi mgon po ni nges par bri bar bya'o/ / pad+ma'i rigs 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug kyang nges par bri bar bya'o/ / rdo rje'i rigs 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje'ang nges par bri bar bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi gtso bo 'phags pa kun du bzang po'ang nges par bri bar bya'o/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'ang nges par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma rnams ni ji ltar rnam par bzhag pa bzhin phyag rgya bri bar bya'o/ / 'di ni nang gi dkyil 'khor ro/ /

“In short, Lord Buddha must be painted at the head of all beings. Representing the Lotus family, Noble Avalokiteśvara must be painted to Śākyamuni’s right.[436] Representing the Vajra family, Noble Vajrapāṇi must be painted to Śākyamuni’s left.[437] Samantabhadra must be painted at the head of all bodhisattvas, and likewise the divine youth, Mañjuśrī, should also be included. The remaining ones should each be represented by his or her mudrā in their respective places. This is how the inner maṇḍala should be painted.

dkyil 'khor bar ma la yang shar phyogs su ni mi mjed kyi bdag po tshangs pa bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du 'od gsal ba ni lho phyogs su'o/ / 'og min gyi gzugs can rnams lha'i dkyil 'khor gyi rnam par ro/ / 'du shes med 'du shes med min gyi skye mched kyi bar ni brjod par mi bya'o/ / byang phyogs su brgya byin lha'i rgyal po dang / rab 'thab bral dang / yongs su dga' ldan dang / rab 'phrul dga' dang / gzhan 'phrul dbang byed dang / 'od chung la sogs pa'i lha'i bu rnams nges par lha'i rgyal po re re bya'o/ / lhag ma rnams ni phyag rgyar gnas par bya'o/ /

“In the middle maṇḍala, Brahmā Sahāmpati must be painted in the eastern quarter. Similarly, in the southern quarter are the Ābhāsvara and Akaniṣṭha gods, the form gods, and the gods from the realm of neither consciousness nor unconsciousness who do not appear in the maṇḍala in any particular form. In the northern quarter are the king of gods Śakra and the gods starting with those from the realms of Suyāma, Tuṣita, Sunirmita, Paranirmita, and Parīttābha. Each king of the gods’ realms must be painted individually. The rest should be represented by their respective mudrās.

de bzhin du dkyil 'khor gsum par yang byang phyogs su 'byung po'i bdag po dbang ldan dka' thub zlog ma dang bcas pa nges par bri'o/ / 'jam dpal gyi sgo gnyis pa'i sgo'i drung du ni smin drug gi bu rma bya'i stan yod pa lag na mdung thogs pa/ lus kyi kha dog dmar ba/ gos ser pos stod g.yogs dang gos byas pa lag pa g.yas pa na dril bu dang ba dan thogs pa/ gzhon nu'i gzugs can gyi 'khor la lta ba'o/ / shar phyogs su ni nam mkha' lding 'dab chags kyi gzugs can dang / drang srong gi nang nas mar ka Na Da nges par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma ni ji ltar gnas pa bzhin phyag rgyar bri bar bya'o/ /

“Similarly, in the third maṇḍala, Īśāna the Lord of Beings must be painted in the northern quarter together with Umā. Kārttikeya-Mañjuśrī should be painted near the second gate,[438] riding on a peacock and holding a javelin in his hand. His body is of red color and he is dressed in a yellow upper shirt and other garments. In his right hand he holds a bell and a red banner. He possesses the beauty of a youth and looks upon the maṇḍala. Vainateya, who has the form of a bird, should always be painted in the eastern quarter, along with the sage Mārkaṇḍa. The rest should be represented by their respective mudrās.

shar lhor ni gzhon nu ma bzhi dang / ming po gzhon nu dang bcas pa/ gru'i bzhon pa la gnas pa/ rgya mtsho chen po la rnam par rgyu ba dang / me lha'i rgyal po yang nges par bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du lho phyogs su ni srin po'i bdag po las ni grong khyer lang ka'i bdag po bi b+hi sha na shing pi tsu marda la gnas pa dang / dzam b+ha la chu dbang zhes bya ba gnod sbyin gyi gzugs can byang chub sems dpa' nges par bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du mthar gyis gshin rje'i rgyal po yi dgas rdzu 'phrul chen po nges par bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du sha za'i rgyal po rnam par g.yengs byed ces bya ba nges par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma ni ji ltar gnas pa bzhin phyag rgyar bri bar bya'o/ /

“In the southeastern division should be the four girls of royal bearing together with their brothers, the divine youths. They are aboard boats, traveling around the great ocean. Also Agni, the lord of gods, should always be painted in the same area of the maṇḍala. Also in the southern quarter should be painted Vibhīṣaṇa, the king of rākṣasas, in the country of Laṅkā. Also located there, dwelling in a neem tree, is the bodhisattva named Jambhala, the Lord of Waters, who has the form of a yakṣa.[439] Painted next in the same sequence should be the king Yama, a preta of great power. So too the king of piśācas named Vikarāla. The remaining ones should be represented by their respective mudrās.

de bzhin du lho nub kyi mtshams su ni klu'i gtso bo dga' bo dang / nye dga' bo nges par bri bar bya'o/ / gza'i gtso bo nyi ma bri bar bya'o/ / nub phyogs su ni drang srong thub pa'i mchog gcer bu pa mu stegs kyi mchog gcer bu'i gzugs bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma ni ci ltar gnas pa bzhin phyag rgyar bri bar bya'o/ /

“Similary, the two chief nāgas, Nanda and Upananda, and also Āditya, the chief among celestial bodies, must be painted in the southwestern division. The best of ṛṣis, the sage named Kapila, should be in the western quarter. The preeminent one among non-Buddhists, he should have the form of a naked mendicant. The remaining ones should be represented by their respective mudrās, arranged in a proper order.[440]

nub byang mtshams su ni gnod sbyin gyi rgyal po mchog sbyin dang / dri za'i rgyal po gtsug phud lnga pa dang / mi'am ci'i rgyal po ljon pa nges par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma ni gnas ji lta ba dang / dbyibs ci lta ba bzhin du phyag rgyar bri bar bya'o/ /

“In the northwestern division should be the king of yakṣas Dhanada, the king of gandharvas Pañcaśikha, and the king of kinnaras Druma. These three must always be included in the painting. The remaining ones should be represented by their respective mudrās and arranged in sequence according to their respective places.

dkyil 'khor bzhi po phyi rol du ri mo lngar bkod de/ phyag rgya'i phreng bas nye bar mdzes par byas pa/ zur bzhi nas rta babs bzhi dang rgyal po chen po bzhis brgyan pa ci ltar gnas pa la 'di lta ste/ phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni sgor 'jug pa la ut+pal sngon po bri'o/ / g.yas dang g.yon gyi phyogs su ni pad+ma rdo rje dgra sta/ ral gri mdung dang mdung rtse gsum pa dang / ga dA dang 'khor lo dang swa sti ka dang / bum pa dang / nya dang / dung dang / gdub kor dang / spyi blugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan dang / zhags pa dang / dril bu dang / chu gri dang / gzhu dang / tho ba dang / 'di dag rnam pa 'di dag 'dra ba'i mtshon cha'i mchog gi phyag rgyas dkyil 'khor gyi phyogs su kun nas khyab par bya'o/ / de nas phyi rol gyi phyogs bzhir rgya mtsho chen po gzhag par bya ste/ byang phyogs su ni dkyil 'khor gru bzhir bya ste/ sna tshogs rdo rje rtse gsum yod pa kun nas 'bar ba bya'o/ / shar phyogs su ni dkyil 'khor gzhu'i dbyibs can byas te bzhag la kun nas 'bar ba'i pad+ma'i phyag rgyas mtshan pa'o/ / lho phyogs su ni dkyil 'khor zur gsum pa byas te kun nas 'bar ba'i lhung bzed kyis mtshan pa'o/ / nub phyogs su ni dkyil 'khor kun nas zlum por byas te/ ut+pa la sngon po sdong bu dang 'dab ma dang bcas pa kun nas 'bar bas mtshan pa'o/ /

“Outside the third maṇḍala there should be a fourth, comprised of five concentric zones and adorned with rows of mudrās. It has four sides, each including a gateway graced with [one of] the four great kings. The emblems are arranged in the following order: “At the entrance gate in the east should be painted a blue lotus. From right to left,[441] there should be a lotus, vajra, axe, sword, trident, mace, discus, swastika, water jar, fish, conch, earring,[442] banner, flag, noose, bell, dagger, bow, arrow, and hammer. All four of the maṇḍala’s sides should be filled with rows of symbols[443] (mudrā) [representing] these various weapons and implements. Outside all of this, in the four directions, should be placed the four great oceans. “In the northern direction should be drawn a small four-sided maṇḍala,[444] within which is placed a three-pronged double vajra that radiates blazing light. In the eastern direction should be drawn a small triangular maṇḍala, within which is placed a lotus that radiates blazing light. In the southern direction should be drawn a small bow-shaped maṇḍala, within which is placed a bowl that radiates blazing light.[445] In the western direction should be drawn a small maṇḍala entirely made of light,[446] within which is placed a blue lotus complete with a stalk and leaves and radiating blazing light.

phyogs mtshams bzhir yang phyag rgya bri bar bya ste/ nub byang gi phyogs su ni dkyil 'khor zlum po bya ste/ zhags pa kun nas 'bar bas mtshan pa'o/ / lho nub mtshams su ni dkyil 'khor gzhu 'dra ba bya ste dbyug pa kun nas 'bar bas mtshan pa'o/ / shar lho mtshams su ni dkyil 'khor gru gsum pa bya ste/ dgra sta 'od zer kun nas 'bar bas mtshan pa'o/ / byang shar gyi mtshams su ni ral gri 'od kun nas 'bar ba gzhag par bya'o/ / de ltar thams cad bris nas steng dang 'og dang thad kar phyag rgya gsum dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol sgo dang nye bar phye ma dang bri bar bya la 'di lta ste/ na bza' dang rnga yab dang lham 'od zer kun nas 'bar ba bri bar bya'o/ /

“In the four intermediate directions should be the following four mudrās, each of them blazing with light all around: A noose should be placed in the northwestern direction, within a round maṇḍala. A staff should be placed in the southwestern direction, within an elongated maṇḍala.[447] An axe should be placed in the southeastern direction, within a triangular maṇḍala. A sword should be placed in the northeastern direction. “When all this has been drawn, three mudrās should be traced with colored powders outside the gate of the main maṇḍala: one above, one below, and one at the same level. The three mudrās to be painted are clothes, a fly-whisk, and a pair of shoes, each surrounded by blazing light.”
'jam pa'i dbyangs ni blo can gyis/ / sems can rnams la phan bzhed nas/ / dkyil 'khor gyi ni cho ga rnams/ / 'dir ni mdor bsdus bstan pa yin/ /
This maṇḍala procedure Has been taught here in brief By the wise Mañjughoṣa, Out of his desire to benefit beings.

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis dang po nyid du slob ma gzung bar bya bya ba la/ dbang po ma tshang ba med pa dang yan lag thams cad mdzes pa dang / bram ze dang rgyal rigs dang rje'u rigs dang dmangs rigs dang / byang chub tu sems bskyed pa dang / theg pa chen por zhugs pa'i rang bzhin can dang theg pa dman pa mi 'dod pa'i ngang tshul can dang / sems dpa' chen po dang dad pa dang ldan pa dang / dge ba'i chos can dang rgyal po chen po mngon par 'dod pa dang longs spyod chung ba la smod pa dang / longs spyod chen po mngon par 'dod pa dang ldan pa dang / bzang ba dag dang dul ba dang ldan pa dang / tshul khrims dang ldan pa'i dge slong dang dge slong ma dang / dge bsnyen dang dge bsnyen ma rnams yang dag par sdom pa la nges par gnas pa dang / gso sbyong la nye bar gnas shing sdom pa la gnas pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' chen po la zhe mi sdang ba dang / phyogs chen po dang rigs mthon po dang rang bzhin nyid kyis chos spyod pa dang

“Then, the maṇḍala master should first of all select the right disciples. They should have unimpaired faculties and bodies beautiful in every limb; should belong to the brahmin, kṣatriya, vaiśya, or śūdra castes; should have developed bodhicitta; should be followers of the Great Vehicle; should possess discipline that is not related to other vehicles; should be great beings (bodhisattvas); should have faith and follow the auspicious Dharma; should wish for the great kingship;[448] should shun trivial enjoyments but delight in the great ones; should be gracious, well mannered, and disciplined;[449] should be monks or nuns, or male or female lay practitioners; should observe their particular rules, fasts, and ritual observances; should abide by their vows of conduct; should not harbor hatred for great bodhisattvas; should belong to a spiritual family of many adherents; and should have a natural inclination to practice Dharma.

zhag gcig smyung ba byas pa dang / gos gtsang ma bgos pa dang skra dri zhim pa dang / dus gsum du khrus byed pa dang / de'i nyin zhag la ga pur dang gur gum dang li shi la wang ga'i dri zhim pos dri zhim par byas pa/ rtag tu nye reg dang ldan pa dang / ku sha'i khres la 'dug pa dang srung ba'i cho ga byas pa dang / tshangs par spyod pa dang bden pa dang ldan pa dang dus mtshams las rgyal ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol de nyid du ha cang yang mi nye ha cang mi ring bar gzhag par bya'o/ / shin tu gtsang ba dang shin tu gtsang sbra dang ldan pa gcig nas brgyad kyi bar te de las gzhan ma yin pa de dag kyang phan tshun gnyen du 'brel ba/ rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bo nas dbang bskur ba'i rgyal po chen po dag gi bu gzhon nu ma'am gzhon nu ma grong gi chos mi shes pa'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das gzhon nu'i gzugs can byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal ni byis pa'i skye bo dga' bar byed pa/ gzhon nu'i rol pa la dgyes pa

“They will have fasted for one day and one night, put on clean clothes, nicely scented their hair, bathed three times, and observed silence. On the day of the empowerment, they should perfume their mouths with the fragrances of camphor, saffron, and cloves,[450] and, after the regular performance of ritual besprinkling, they should sit on bundles of kuśa grass and have the protection ceremony performed for them. Celibate and committed to truth, they should be placed outside the maṇḍala Victorious over the Divisions of Time, not too far from it and not too near to it.[451] Clean and ritually purified, they should number no more than between one and eight and be close associates of one another. They will include kṣatriyas who are closely associated with one another and great kings who have had their heads anointed, as well as their offspring‍—the princes and princesses who have not yet experienced sex. This is because Lord Mañjuśrī, the great bodhisattva in a youthful form, loves to engage in youthful play, awakening foolish people to realization.

des na dang po nyid du gzhon nu nang du gzhug par bya'o/ / rgyal po chen po mngon par 'phel ba dang tshe dang nad med pa dang / dbang phyug dang skal ba chen po mngon par 'phel ba yin te/ khyad par du byis pa rnams la nges par sngags grub pas grub pa gnas pa yin te/

“Consequently, it is the princely youths who should be ushered in first. This will elevate their regal status and promote long life, health, power, and the ability to savor sensual enjoyments. In particular, this will stabilize the accomplishment of mantra for them, the inexperienced.

de dag sngar bzhag pa byas nas/ grogs po bag yod pa bzang po dang ldan pas/ dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis ga pur gyi bdug pas bdugs te/ rgyab kyis phyogs pa ma yin pas phyi rol du byung bar bya ste/ byung nas dus dang ci ltar mthun pa'i chu legs par gtsang sbra byas pa dang / srog chags med pa la rtsa ba'i sngags brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bzlas te/ gtsug phud lnga'i phyag rgya chen pos phyag rgyar byas pa'i chus khrus byas la nye reg byas nas/ gos gtsang ma bgos pa'i gtsang bas me thab kyi drung du song ste/

“Once they are positioned in front, assigned an assistant, and attentive, the maṇḍala master should exit backward[452] while burning incense of camphor. After exiting, he should bathe and besprinkle himself, as convenient for the season, with water[453] that has been incanted one hundred and eight times with the root mantra and sealed with the great mudrā called five-crested. Dressed in clean white clothes, he should then approach the sacrificial fire pit, and,
ku sha'i khres la 'dug nas byang shar gyi phyogs su mngon par bltas te/ mar gyi sbyin sreg ga pur dang gur gum dang / tsan+dan dang bsres pas stong rtsa brgyad bya'o/ /
“Seated on the bundles of kuśa grass and facing northeast, He should offer into the fire One thousand and eight oblations consisting of Camphor, saffron, and sandalwood mixed together.[454]

sngar bshad pa'i cho gas spyan drang ba dang gshegs su gsol ba byas te/ yang dkyil 'khor du 'jug par bya'o/ / nges par yang bum pa gang ba brgyad ras gtsang ma'i gos dang ldan pa/ shing a mra'i lo ma dang 'bras bu dang ldan pa gser dang / dngul dang rin po che dang / 'bras dang 'bru nang du bcug pa gcig bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la dbul lo/ / gnyis pa ni sangs rgyas thams cad la'o/ / gsum pa ni rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang 'phags pa nyan thos la'o/ / bzhi pa ni byang chub sems dpa' chen po thams cad la'o/ / lnga pa ni byang chub sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa 'jam dpal la'o/ / drug pa ni lha thams cad la'o/ / bdun pa dang brgyad pa ni dkyil 'khor gnyis pa'i sgo khang la gzhag par bya ste/ / gcig ni 'byung po thams cad la'o/ / gcig ni sems can thams cad kyi thun mong du gyur par bsngos nas gzhag par bya'o/ /

“Having summoned and then dismissed the deities according to the previously described procedure, he should again enter the maṇḍala. After entering he should prepare eight full vases draped in clean cloth, adorned with mango blossoms, and containing gold, silver, gems, grain, and rice. He should allocate the first to Lord Śākyamuni, the second to all the buddhas, the third to all the pratyekabuddhas and the noble congregation of the śrāvakas, the fourth to all the great bodhisattvas, the fifth to the great bodhisattva Mañjuśrī, and the sixth to all the gods. The seventh and the eighth should be placed in the niches by the gate of the second maṇḍala. They should be draped in clean white cloth. One of them should be assigned to all the spirits, and the second should be dedicated to all beings equally.

de bas na sngar bshad pa'i cho gas spyan drang bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du me tog dang bdug pa dang dri dang / mar me dang lha bshos kyang sngar bstan pa nyid kyi las kyis dbul bar bya ste/ thams cad kyi thams cad du go rims bzhin du bya'o/ / mar me 'dzin pas mar gyi mar me gzung bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa dang 'phags pa ma yin pa thams cad la lha bshos zhes smos pa ni/ 'bras sA lu'i chan zho dang bcas pa dang sbrang rtsi dang ldan pa'i 'o thug khyad par can gyis nye bar sbyar ba'i mar la btsos pa'i snum khur gyi 'breng bu la sogs pa dang / khaN+Da la sogs pa'i bza' ba thams cad ni de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la dbul bar bya'o/ / mar gyis gang ba dang tsan+dan gyi thang chu sbrang rtsi'i snying po dang 'o mar btsos pa'i bza' ba ni rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang byang chub sems dpa' chen po dang 'phags pa'i lha thams cad la dbul bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du gar+b+hod u lo pi ka ri ka dang / khyad par du snum khur gyi yo byad 'byung po thams cad dang / sems can thams cad la sngags dang ldan pa'i cho gas sbyin par bya'o/ /

“Then, following the previously described procedure, the maṇḍala master should burn incense and, forming the great five-crested mudrā, should do the summoning again. Following the procedure as before, he should summon all the buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, noble śrāvakas, great bodhisattvas, spirits, and beings, as well as Mañjuśrī, the divine youth.[455] “Similarly, he should offer, in a ritual as previously described, flowers, incense, fragrances, light, and foodstuffs; he should offer all this to all the recipients, thoroughly and in the right order. For the offering of light, he should offer butter lamps. When offering food to all the noble recipients and others, he should offer rice pudding with curds. “To all the tathāgatas he should offer cakes rich particularly in honey and milk and fried in butter, as well as pastry-rolls (vartī), candies (khaṇḍa), and other delicacies.[456] To all the pratyekabuddhas, noble śrāvakas, great bodhisattvas, and the noble deities he should offer dishes prepared with honey and cooked in milk, rich in butter, and flavored with chir pine resin.[457] Similarly, to all the gods[458] and hosts of spirits, and all beings in general, he should offer cake products, particularly sweetmeats,[459] incanted with the mantra according to procedure.

de bzhin du me tog dri zhim pa sna ma'i me tog dang rgya spos dang / klu'i me tog dang me tog pun nA ga la sogs pa sngar bstan pa sangs rgyas dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang 'phags pa nyan thos dang / byang chub sems dpa' chen po dang 'phags pa dang 'phags pa ma yin pa'i lha thams cad la dbul bar bya'o/ / khyad par du ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs la ni sna ma'i me tog dang / pad+ma'i rigs la ni me tog pad+ma dang / de bzhin du rdo rje'i rigs la ni me tog ut+pal dang / lha gzhan dag la ni gzhan gang yang rung bas dbul bar bya'o/ /

“Similarly, to all the buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, noble śrāvakas, and great bodhisattvas as well as all noble and ordinary beings[460] he should offer fragrant flowers as described before, starting with royal jasmine, crepe jasmine, champak, and the blossom of the pannay tree. Royal jasmine flowers are particularly suitable for the Tathāgata family, lotuses for the Lotus family, and water lilies for the family of Vajrapāṇi. For other mantra deities[461] other flowers may be suitable.

ga pur gyi bdug pa ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs la'o/ / tsan+dan ni pad+ma'i rigs la'o/ / de bzhin du gu gul ni gsang ba'i bdag po phyag na rdo rje la shes par bya'o/ / lha gzhan thams cad ni bdug pa tha mal pas bya'o/ / mar gyi mar me 'phags pa rnams/ / thams cad la ni dbul bar bya/ / 'phags min lha ni thams cad la/ / dri zhim 'bru mar dbul bar bya/ / cho ga ji bzhin rim pas ni/ / bdug pa mthong ba'i rgyu yis so/ / de ltar gsungs pa de bzhin dri/ / sngags rnams kun la rtag tu bya/ / spyan ras gzigs la gang gsungs dang / / gang gsungs phyag na rdo rje la/ / rang rang gi ni sngags dag gis/ / sngags spyod don du bsgrub pa'o/ / cho ga gcig pu blta bya ste/ / rtag tu rjes su mthun par bya/ /

“Camphor incense is suitable for the Tathāgata family, sandalwood for the Lotus family, and bdellium for the family of Vajrapāṇi, the lord of guhyakas. For all other mantra deities[462] the master should offer a different incense. Butter lamps should be offered to all the noble ones, and scented oil lamps to all the ordinary mantra deities.[463] “As for the successive procedures That function as previously described, These procedures are the same as the one taught for perfume And are required in the case of all mantra deities.[464] “Whatever has been taught by Avalokiteśvara Or taught by Vajrapāṇi, In their respective tantras, On accomplishing the aims of mantra practice, That also can be learned from this manual And applied in every respect.[465]

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis sngar mthong ba'i cho gas spyan drang ba dang / mchod pa dang bdug pa la sogs pa byas nas/ gtsor mthun pa'i bya ba byas te de'i 'og tu sgrub pa'i grogs mchog gis mkhas pa dang / myur bas 'byung po thams cad pa'i gtor ma sha med pa/ kun nas rnga pa Ta ha dang dung gi sgra dga' ba'i sgra sgrogs pa la sogs pa des bdug pa dang spos dang me tog dang phreng bas brgyan pa'i phyogs bzhi mtshams brgyad steng dang 'og dang thad ka thams cad du dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol du bskor ba bya zhing / 'byung po thams cad pa'i gtor ma rgya cher gtong bar bya'o/ / de nas khrus byas te yang zho dang sbrang rtsi dang / mar gyis bsgos pa'i sA lu dang / 'bras thug po che'i sbyin sreg rtsa ba'i sngags yi ge drug pa dang snying pos stong rtsa brgyad bya'o/ / sbyin sreg byas nas dkyil 'khor la rjes su bcug cing sngar bzhag pa'i sems dpa' chen po la srung ba byas nas/ dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyi slob ma nyid du khas blangs pa/ byang chub tu sems bskyed pa gso sbyong byas pa/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' la bdag nyid kyi lus phul ba/ dngos grub kyi phyir sems can thams cad kyi nye bar longs spyod pa dang yongs su longs spyod pa thun mong du gyur pa dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba bla na med pa'i byang chub kyi snying po gnon par bya ba dang / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi sangs rgyas thob par bya ba la dkyil 'khor bstan par bya'o/ / bstan pa tsam nyid kyis sdig pa'i rnyog pa thams cad las grol bar 'gyur te/ mtshams med pa lnga byed pa'i skye bo yang de ma thag tu grol bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The maṇḍala master then, following the previously described procedure, should perform the ritual acts of summoning, making offerings, burning incense, and the rest, and he should offer food and service as well.[466] Having done this, he should have his skillful assistants promptly prepare the meatless bali for all the spirits. He should have them beat the kettledrums, blow the conchs, and utter cries of joy in every direction. The bali should include incense, flowers, lamps, and garlands. “Circling then the maṇḍala to the right, the master should scatter the extensive bali that satisfies all spirits,[467] upward, downward, and horizontally, into each of the four cardinal and four intermediate directions and everywhere outside the maṇḍala. After bathing, he should offer into the fire one thousand and eight oblations consisting of rice grains smeared with curds, honey, and ghee. As the master offers the oblations while reciting the heart mantra and the six-syllable root mantra, the great beings who have entered the maṇḍala and now stand before him; who have had the protection rite performed for them and have been accepted as disciples by the maṇḍala master; who have developed bodhicitta, observed the ritual fast, and offered their own bodies to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas; who for the sake of spiritual accomplishments[468] share in the experiences of ordinary beings; who are fit to ascend to the seat of unsurpassable awakening;[469] and who desire omniscient awakening will become liberated from all their vices through merely beholding the maṇḍala. Even those people who have committed the five deeds of immediate retribution are immediately liberated.

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis ras ma nyams pa thag mas btags ma thag pa skra med pa la/ rtsa ba'i sngags kyis lan gsum bzlas te/ dri zhim po'i tsan+dan dang gur gum gyis bsgos pa'i ras kyis gdong g.yogs par bya'o/ / dang por byis pa lo gsum nas lo bcu drug pa'i bar zur phud lngas nye bar mdzes pa'am/ gtsug phud gcig gis nye bar mdzes pa'am/ gtsug phud gsum gyis nye bar mdzes pa skra dang ldan pa/ rgyal po'i bu spyi bo nas dbang bskur ba'am/ rgyal rigs kyi bu'am gzhan bdag nyid chen po rgyal po chen po 'dod pa dkyil 'khor du gzhug par bya'o/ /

“The maṇḍala master then should cover the faces of the initiands[470] who wish to enter the maṇḍala[471] with a veil fashioned from a newly made, unbleached cloth from which the loose[472] threads have been pulled out and hairs removed,[473] that has been incanted with the root mantra seven times,[474] and that has been anointed with fragrant ointments, sandalwood, and saffron. First, boys should be brought into the maṇḍala starting from the sixteen- and finishing with the three-year-olds.[475] They may be embellished with either five decorative locks of hair or just one,[476] and they may wear a topknot of hair or not.[477] They should be princes whose crowns have been anointed, sons of kṣatriyas, or others of great endeavor who desire sovereignty.

dkyil 'khor gnyis pa la phyin pa na gdong g.yogs par bya ste/ ut+pa la'i phyag rgya bcings nas/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i rtsa ba'i sngags lan cig brjod du gzhug ste/ me tog dri zhim po tsan+dan dang gur gum dang bsres pa shin tu gtsang bar byas pa/ lag pa gnyis su byin la me tog 'dor du gzhug go/ / gang du de'i me tog babs pa der de'i sngags sbyin par bya ste/ sngags 'di ni de'i yin par bstan te/ skye ba brgyud pa nas de dang rjes su 'brel pa yin te/ de nyid dge ba'i bshes gnyen byang chub kyi snying po la gnon pa/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes yongs su rdzogs pa'i don du mngon par sgrub par byed pa/ longs spyod chen po dang rgyal po chen po dang grags pa chen po dang / gang zag rtse gcig par mngon par sgrub pa yin no/ / tshe 'di nyid la yang chos thams cad la yang the tshom med par bsgrub par bya ba 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“When the initiand stands in the second maṇḍala with a veiled face, the master should form the utpala[478] mudrā and have him recite the root mantra of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, once. Guiding his actions, he should give him a flower of nice fragrance and have him throw it onto the maṇḍala with both hands that have been purified with the mixture of sandalwood and saffron. The master should give him the mantra corresponding to the spot where the flower falls. “That is said to be his personal mantra and will stay with him through the succession of his future births. This mantra is like his spiritual guide; it will bring about his ascension to the seat of awakening and the complete unfolding of the omniscient knowledge of great bodhisattvas. He should master this mantra, which will bring great enjoyments, the status of a king, and the company of eminent people. That which is to be accomplished will be accomplished in this very life without doubt, including all the activities.

de bzhin du mthar gyis dngos grub 'dod pas brgya rnyed kyi bar du bya ste gzhan la ni ma yin no/ / gzhan dag la ci ltar sdig pa spang ba'i phyir dam tshig tsam sbyin par bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis dbang bskur na/ dang por re zhig dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol ha cang yang mi nye ha cang yang mi ring bar byang shar gyi phyogs su rtsa ba'i sngags kyis dag par byas pas byin gyis brlab par bya'o/ / rgyal po dbang bskur ba bzhin du bdag nyid sems pa dang gcig tu sangs rgyas dang chos dang dge 'dun la dad cing dad pa dang / spro ba chen po dang ldan pa dang / byang chub kyi sems dang ma bral ba dang / theg pa chen po la zhugs pa dang / dkon mchog gsum la phan par byed pa dang / dbang po ma tshang ba med pa dang ma smad pa dang / tshe 'di nyid la sngags grub par 'dod pa dang / bsam pa bzang po dang sngags kyi spyod pa la spro ba dang / blta bar 'dod pa'i rang bzhin can dang sad par 'dod pa'i phyir yang sngags kyi don la rnam par rtog pa med pa dang / der gtad pa'i yid dang gcig la sogs pa nas lnga'i bar du dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / lhag ma ni spang bar bya'o/ / shes rab can dang spyod pa la rmongs pa med pa'i khyad par dang ldan pa la dbang bskur bar bya'i/ gzhan dag ni ma yin no/ / de nas rgyal po thams cad dbang bskur ba bzhin du yo byad thams cad bsogs te/ slob dpon mkhan po mnyes na/ de nas bla re chen po bres te/ rgyal mtshan dang ba dan mthon po bsgreng zhing gdugs dkar po dbu la 'dzin pa dang / rnga yab dkar pos g.yob pa dang / bkur sti chen pos dung dang / rnga bo che'i dga' ba'i sgra sgrogs shing rgyal ba'i sgra dang / bkra shis kyi tshigs su bcad pa dang bde legs dang rab tu bsngags pa'i tshigs su bcad pa/ rgyal bas gsungs pas mngon par bstod pa dang / dkyil 'khor de la bskor ba byas te/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag byas nas/ 'di skad du slob dpon bdag ni sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa'i sngags kyi spyod pa sgrub pa la yang dag par 'jug pa dang / 'jig rten pa thams cad las yang dag par 'das pa'i gsang ba'i rnam par thar pa'i dkyil 'khor la yang dag par 'jug pa dang / chos kyi rgyal srid thams cad kyi sangs rgyas nyid rtogs par 'dod pa dang / mdor na sangs rgyas nyid du 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir ro zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

“Thus, in due course, those who desire magical accomplishments will obtain each one of them until all eight are obtained, but no other accomplishments. If one desires other accomplishments, such as the removal of sins, only the samaya may be given. For this purpose, the maṇḍala master who bestows the empowerment should first consecrate an area outside the maṇḍala toward the northeast, neither too far nor too near, by purifying it with the root mantra. Just as in the case of the royal empowerment, he should admit disciples whom he regards as single-mindedly devoted to the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha; who have faith and great energy; who are never separated from bodhicitta and follow the Great Vehicle; and who serve the Three Jewels. They should have unimpaired faculties, be irreproachable, and wish to accomplish the mantras in this very life. Their hearts may be kind and their minds resolved upon mantra practice, or they may be merely interested in the nonconceptual meaning of the mantra out of curiosity and a desire to know. They should be granted the first through the fifth empowerments; the remaining ones should be omitted.[479] Only those with the special qualities of insight and full understanding of the conduct should be initiated; others should not be. “The master should then collect the requisites as in every royal empowerment, or any that he finds pleasing. A canopy should be spread above him, banners and flags raised, and a white parasol should be held above his head. He should be fanned with a white yak-tail whisk with great care, and praised with well-wishing, auspicious, and excellent verses as spoken by the buddhas themselves, accompanied by cries of joy, the sounds of conchs, kettledrums and tambourines, and cries of victory. After circumambulating the maṇḍala clockwise, the disciples should bow to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, bow their heads to the master,[480] and say the following: “ ‘O master![481] I will exert myself in order to engage in carrying out the mantra activities of all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, in order to enter the secret maṇḍala of liberation that surpasses all that is mundane, and to realize the state of buddhahood that affords sovereignty over all phenomena. In short, I will become a buddha.’

de nas ku sha'i khres la 'dug ste/ shar gyi phyogs su phyogs te dkyil 'khor la blta zhing / dang por re zhig rig pa'i dbang bskur ba byin te phyag rgya chen po gtsug phud lnga 'ching du gzhug par bya'o/ / de nas rang 'dod pa'i sngags gang dang gang la dga' ba gro ga'i 'dab ma la gi wang gis bri bar bya ste/ bris nas kyang tsan+dan dang gur gum gyi chus lag pa dang kham phor kha sbyar bkrus la/ de nas gro ga'i 'dab ma de kham phor kha sbyar ba'i nang du gzhag par byas pa dkyil 'khor gyi nang du byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyi zhabs drung du gzhag par bya'o/ /

“Then, the initiand should sit on a bundle of kuśa grass, facing east and looking at the maṇḍala. He will first be given the knowledge (vidyā) empowerment and then made to[482] form the mudrā called five-crested. Then, whatever mantra he desires should be written on a leaf of birchbark with bovine bezoar. Having written it, he should smear both his hands and the interior of an earthenware vessel with sandalwood and saffron and place the birchbark leaf between two earthenware bowls.[483] He should then place the leaf, enclosed between the two bowls, inside the maṇḍala[484] at the soles of the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī’s feet.

de nas ku sha de la gnas nas rig pa'i rtsa ba'i sngags brgya rtsa brgyad snga ma nyid du bzla bar bya'o/ / de nas ku sha'i khres la 'dug pa la dbang bskur bar bya ste/ phyi rol gyi dkyil 'khor la gang sems can thams cad dang thun mong du gyur pa'i bum pa gang ba sgo dang nye bar sngar bzhag pa blangs te/ slob dpon gyis rtsa ba'i sngags brjod pas spyi bo nas dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / gzhan dag la ni ci ltar 'dod pa'i chus so/ / de nas kham phor kha sbyar de de la sbyin par bya ste mar me la klog tu gzhug par bya'o/ / gal te de nyid yin na ni rim gyis 'bad pas 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / yang na ci ste gzhan na ni sngags bzlas pa kho nas 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / yang na yi ge'i yan lag nyams pa'am/ lhag pa byin ni dang po sgrub pa kho na la 'grub par the tshom med do/ / de ltar slob dpon gyis sngar bris pa'i sgrub pa gsum gyis nges par 'grub par the tshom med do/ / de bzhin du dang pos ni rig pa'i dbang bskur ba sbyin par bya'o/ /

“Next, the disciple sitting there should first be made to recite the root vidyā mantra one hundred and eight times and then should be consecrated while still sitting on the bundle of kuśa grass. The master should take the full vase that had been allocated to all beings in common from outside the inner[485] maṇḍala where it was earlier placed near the gate and, while reciting the root mantra, anoint[486] the disciple’s head. For the remaining empowerments, he should use whatever water is appropriate. “The earthenware container should then be handed to him, and, while a butter lamp is burning, he should be made to recite the mantra. If it is the same mantra,[487] the disciple will succeed through merely reciting it. If it is a different one, he will succeed gradually, after applying effort.[488] It is said that even if the mantra given to him lacks or has extra syllables, he can still succeed, without a doubt, at the first sādhana session, for this mantra was written earlier by the master himself. If he keeps practicing, he will arrive, within three sādhana sessions, at the stage where success comes without effort. In this way, the master should first give the knowledge empowerment.

dkyil 'khor gnyis pa la dbang bskur ba ni gnyis pa'i dkyil 'khor du lha thams cad la bstabs pa'i sngar gyi bum pa des dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / spyi bo la sngar gyi cho ga ci lta ba de nyid kyis byas na sdig pa'i rnyog pa thams cad las grol bar 'gyur te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das thams cad kyis gnang zhing / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi dam tshig dang / dkyil 'khor dang sngags dang phyag rgya thams cad sgrub pa la byin gyis brlabs par 'gyur zhing / slob dpon du dbang bskur ba sbyin no/ / dkyil 'khor gsum pa la ni rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / nyan thos thams cad la phul ba'i bum pa gang ba de nyid kyi cho gas spyi bo nas dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul chen po dang ldan pa thams cad kyis 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi sngags rgyud dag 'don pa dang / dkyil 'khor bri ba dang ston pa dang phyag rgya dang spyod pa ston pa dang rang nyid spyod cing ston par khyod la rjes su gnang zhing brjod par bya ba yang tshe 'di nyid la yin la/ phyi nas skye ba brgyud pa dag la ni sangs rgyas nyid thob par 'gyur ba yin no/ / de bzhin du rgyal ba dang rnam par rgyal ba'i dbang bskur ba yang sngar bstan pa'i cho gas/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la sngar phul ba'i bum pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' la phul ba'i bum pa gang bas kyang de bzhin du dbang bskur ro/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' chen po dang / nyan thos rnams kyis kyang de bzhin du brjod par bya zhing khyod la rjes su gnang ba yin no/ /

“As for the empowerment in the second maṇḍala, he should take the full vase that had been allocated to all the gods in this maṇḍala and anoint the disciple’s head with it. As before, this procedure will free him from all his vices. He is then authorized by all the buddhas to enter samayas for any worldly or transcendent maṇḍala, as well as the practice of any mantra or mudrā. He will be blessed by all the bodhisattvas.[489] Consequently, the master may now give him the ācārya empowerment.[490] “The ācārya empowerment is given in the third maṇḍala. The master should take the full vase that had been allocated to all the śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas and, following the same procedure, anoint the disciple’s head with it. The master should say, ‘All the buddhas and bodhisattvas of great power have authorized you to write and recite all worldly and transcendent mantras, to use the instructions on the maṇḍala, and to give to others, as well as apply yourself, the instructions on the practice of the mantra methods, including the mudrās. In this very life, and in the lives to come until the final one, you will definitely obtain the state of awakening.’[491] “Similarly, in the empowerment of victory and the empowerment of conquest, the master should perform the sprinkling following the previously described procedure, using, respectively, the full vase that had been allocated to the blessed buddhas and the one allocated to the bodhisattvas. He should say, ‘You are authorized by all the blessed buddhas, the great bodhisattvas, and the śrāvakas,

'byung po thams cad kyis rab tu thub par dka' zhing lus can thams cad kyis mi pham pa dang sngags pa thams cad las khyod rgyal ba dang ci ltar 'dod pa sgrubs shig pa'o/ / de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis re re la yang ci ltar 'dod pa bzhin du dbang bskur ba lnga sbyin par bya'o/ / sems can rnams la yang lnga po nyid kyis bya'o/ /

“ ‘Unassailable by any spirits, And unconquerable by any embodied beings; May you find victory through all the mantras And accomplish whatever you desire.’[492] “The maṇḍala master should, According to each of their wishes, Grant to all the disciples The five empowerments, but only the five.

de dag mthar gyis dkyil 'khor la bcug ste/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la bdag nyid phul nas dkyil 'khor la bskor ba lan gsum byas te slar gtang bar bya'o/ / de las gzhan pa'i nyin zhag la mthar gyis sngags kyi spyod pa la bslab par bya zhing sbyar bar bya'o/ / skad cig de nyid la bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la sngar phul ba'i bum pa gang ba blangs nas dkyil 'khor du zhugs pa de dag la chu khyor ba gsum shar du mngon par blta bar byas la blud par bya'o/ / 'di skad du brjod par bya ste/ kye byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i gsang ba'i dam tshig las 'das par gyur na bsod nams ma yin pa mang po skye bar ma byed cig / sngags thams cad kyang 'dor bar ma byed cig / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dag kyang slu bar ma byed cig / bla ma mnyes par gyis shig / gzhan du dam tshig las 'das par gyur na sngags 'grub par mi 'gyur zhing / bsod nams ma yin pa mang por 'gyur ro/ /zhes de ltar smras la gtang bar bya'o/ /

“The master should then usher them, one by one, into the maṇḍala, present them to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, have them circumambulate the maṇḍala clockwise three times, and dismiss them. At a later time they should be gradually instructed in and enjoined to practice the mantra. On the present occasion, however, the master should take the full vase that had earlier been allocated to the great bodhisattva Mañjuśrī and make those disciples who have entered the maṇḍala drink three handfuls of water while facing east. He should say to them: “ ‘Do not generate a great amount of nonvirtue by transgressing the secret samaya of the divine youth, the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī. You must not discard any of the mantras. You must be loyal to all the buddhas or bodhisattvas and must please the master. Otherwise you will break your samaya, your mantras will not be successful, and there will be much nonvirtue.’ Having said this, he should dismiss them.

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis kyang zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis btags pa'i sA lu dang 'bras thug po che'i sreg blugs kyis yi ge brgyad pa'i snying po dang sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas langs nas dkyil 'khor gyi dbus su zhugs te/ sngar bstan pa'i me tog gis/ sngar bstan pa'i cho gas lha thams cad yid la byas te mchod yon dbul lo/ / bdug pas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas dang 'phags pa nyan thos thams cad dang / lha dang / klu dang / gnod sbyin dang / nam mkha' lding dang / dri za dang / mi'am ci dang / lto 'phye chen po dang / srin po dang / sha za dang / 'byung po dang / rnal 'byor pa dang grub pa dang / drang srong rnams dang sems can thams cad yang dag par bdug nas me tog gtor te/ tsan+dan dang gur gum gyis bsangs la sngar bstan pa'i cho gas slar gshegs su gsol bar bya ste/ sems kyis thams cad btang ba yin no/ /

“The maṇḍala master should, in addition, offer oblations of rice grains smeared with curds, honey, and ghee, while reciting the eight-syllable heart mantra. Getting up, he should then enter into the middle of the maṇḍala and make a welcome offering to all the visualized recipients[493] using the previously mentioned flowers and following the procedure as previously described. Using the previously specified incense, he should make an incense offering to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas and noble śrāvakas, and all the gods, nāgas, yakṣas, garuḍas, gandharvas, kinnaras, mahoragas,[494] rākṣasas, piśācas, and bhūtas, as well as the divine yogins, siddhas, and ṛṣis and all beings. He should strew flowers over them, sprinkle them with water scented with sandalwood and saffron, and then dismiss them following the previously described procedure. He should imagine that all of them become liberated.[495]

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis bshos dang gtor ma dang / sa tshon thams cad chu bor dor bar bya ba'am/ srog chags sdug bsngal ba rnams la sbyin par bya'o/ / sa phyogs de legs par byugs shing 'jam par byas te/ legs par phyag pa byas nas ba lang gi lci bas byug tu gzhug pa'am/ chus byug par bya ba'am/ shin tu gtsang ba'i sas byug pa'am/ bye mas gtor bar byas la/ de nas ci ltar 'dod par 'gro bar bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor la zhugs pa des bdag nyid 'o ma dang / 'bras chan gyi zas sam/ lha la dbul ba'i kha zas bza' bar bya'o/ /

“The maṇḍala master should then take the food, bali,[496] and aromatic powder and let all these articles float[497] upon a river. Alternatively, he should give them to suffering beings. He should select an area on the ground, sweep and clean it well, adorn it, and smear it with cow dung.[498] Optionally, he may wash it with water, smear it with well-purified clay, or cover it with sand. He should do this himself and may proceed as he desires. Those who have entered the maṇḍala should themselves partake of the milk porridge[499] or sacrificial food.”

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod cho ga zhib mo'i rgyal po'i dbang po las/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i rnam par 'phrul pa byang chub sems dpa'i le'u rab 'byam las/ dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga bstan pa ste le'u gnyis pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the second chapter, that of the instructions on the maṇḍala procedure, from this great king of manuals that forms a garland-like[500] basket of bodhisattva teachings, an extensive bodhisattva textbook that is a miraculous display of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth.
dkyil 'khor
Chapter 3

de nas gzhan yang 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang gi 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po 'dus pa la gzigs nas/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag 'tshal te/ yi ge gcig pa mchog tu gsang ba dug thams cad 'joms par byed pa/ las thams cad byed pa sngags dang dkyil 'khor chung ngu sgrub pa'i thabs dang / las phran tshegs thams cad la nye bar sbyar bar bya ba smras so/ / de yang gang zhe na/

Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, again looked at the realm of the Pure Abode and, bowing to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas gathered together in that great assembly, pronounced the most secret single-syllable mantra, which removes all poisons and can be employed in all rites the mantra that is effective in the practices of his maṇḍala and which can also be used in all minor ritual activities. What is that mantra?
na maHsa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM dza/
“Homage to all the buddhas! This mantra is: “jaḥ.[501]
grogs po dag 'di ni 'byung po thams cad nyon cig / sngags 'di nyid ni yi ge gcig gi dkyil 'khor gnyis pa'i cho ga thams cad du dgos pa/
“This very mantra, friends and all hosts of spirits, the one syllable, is to be used, in short, in the second maṇḍala procedure.[502]

khru brgyad dam khru bzhi sa'i phyogs yang dag par byas la tshon sna lnga'i phye mas rang nyid kyis bri bar bya ste/ gzhan gyis ni ma yin te/ gang de dang de dag tu yang 'dir ni nges pa med do/ / dkyil 'khor gru bzhi mnyam pos nye bar mdzes pa/ gtsug phud lnga'i phyag rgya chen po dang por re zhig bri'o/ / bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i ut+pa la'i phyag rgya dang / mche ba'i phyag rgya dang zhal gyi phyag rgya dang dbyug pa'i phyag rgya ste/ phyag rgya 'di dag dkyil 'khor gyi nang du shar gyi char bri bar bya'o/ /

“After cleaning an area on the ground either eight or four cubits in size, it should be delimited using five-colored powder by oneself, not by anyone else. No matter where this is done, there is no fault. The area should be four sided, with sides of equal length, and should include the triple maṇḍala.[503] First one should draw the great five-crested mudrā, the utpala[504] mudrā of Lord Mañjuśrī, and the mudrās the fangs, the mouth, and the stick. These mudrās should be drawn in the eastern quarter of the inner maṇḍala.

de nas pad+ma dang rdo rje dang ut+pal dang phyag mtshan dang ba dan dang gdugs dang rta babs dang / shing rta dang glang po che dang rta dang glang dang ma he dang / swa sti ka dang rma bya dang ra dang lug dang / skyes bu gzhon nu'i gzugs can phyi rol gyi sgo'i rtsa bar bri bar bya ste/ mthar gyis rim pa la brten nas bris te/ dkyil 'khor gsum la brten nas de ltar bri bar bya'o/ /

“Next, outside the door base[505] should be drawn a red lotus, a vajra, a blue lotus, a banner, a flag, a parasol, a doorway, a chariot, an elephant, a horse, a bull, a buffalo, a swastika, a peacock, a goat, a ram, and a man of youthful appearance. They should be arranged in successive rows fitting in with the threefold maṇḍala.

de nas yi ge gcig pa'i sngags nyid kyis shar lho'i phyogs kyi char me'i las bya ste/ shing a pa marga'i yam shing zho dang sbrang rtsi dang / mar la btags pas stong rtsa brgyad sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas me tog gi mchod yon dbul lo/ / yi ge gcig pa'i sngags kyis ci ltar 'dod par gtor ma dang lha bshos dang mar me dang bdug pa dang spyan drang ba dang gshegs su gsol ba rnams bya'o/ /

“Then, in the southeastern direction, one should perform the fire kindling ritual using the one-syllable mantra and offer one hundred and eight[506] oblations with sticks of the devil’s horsewhip plant smeared with curds, honey, and ghee. Then a welcome offering of flowers should be presented. Using the one-syllable mantra, one may also offer, whenever desired, a bali,[507] sacrificial food, lamps, or incense or perform the summoning and the dismissing.[508] “One should usher the supplicant into the maṇḍala.[509]
