de nas rgyal srid 'dod pas ni grong khyer gyi dbus su bri bar bya'o/ / longs spyod 'dod pas ni shing a mra'i drung du'o/ / bu 'dod pas ni bo de tse'i shing gi drung du'o/ / chung ma dang glang po che dang rta 'dod pas ni glang po che'i bres skyu'am/ rta'i bres skyur ro/ / chu 'dod pas ni mtsho chen po'am klu'i gnas su'o/ / nyin bzhi pa'i rims sam/ rtag pa'i rims sam/ rims thams cad la rtag gcig pa'am/ grong gi g.yas phyogs su'o/ / srin pos zin pa ni dur khrod dam khang pa stong par bya'o/ / yang srin pos zin pa la ni ba ru ra'i shing gi drung ngam/ e raN+Da'i shing gi drung du bya'o/ / ma mo thams cad kyis zin pa la ni bzhi mdo'am shi ba'i khyim dang bu btsas pa'i khyim du nye bar bya'o/ / tshangs pa'am srin pos zin pa la ni ta la'i shing drung du'o/ / sbyar ba'i dug 'byin pa la ni yi ge gcig pa'i sngags kyis chu la lan gsum bsngags pa byas te/ dkyil 'khor de nyid du blud pa byas na grol bar 'gyur ro/ /

If he wants royal power, the maṇḍala should be drawn in the middle of a city; if he wishes for enjoyments, then near a banyan tree;[510] if he wants a son, then near a lucky bean tree. If he desires a wife,[511] horses, or elephants, then inside an elephant stable or a horse stable; if he has been bitten [by a snake],[512] then at a pond or a place where nāgas live; if he is afflicted with a quartan, chronic, or any other fever, then near a solitary liṅga or to the south of a village; if he is possessed by rākṣasas, then in a cemetery or in an empty house; if he is possessed by piśācas,[513] then near a beleric myrobalan tree or a castor oil plant; if he is possessed by any of the mātṛs, then at a crossroad or near a house where a male offspring has died; if he is possessed by brahmarākṣasas,[514] then under a palm tree or a large sebesten tree. If he was fed poison, he should be given water incanted seven times[515] with the one-syllable mantra and made to lie down in the middle of the maṇḍala‍—he will be released from the effects of the poison.

de bzhin du bud med dam skyes pa grags pa 'dod pa la ni bzhi mdo'am bram ze gnas par bri bar bya'o/ / bu shi ba la ni shing 'bras bu can nam 'o ma can gyi shing drung du'o/ / 'bras sA lu smin pa'i sa dang zhing gi dbus su ni bu med pa la bri bar bya'o/ / nad rnam pa gsum bdag gir byas pa dang gzhan gyis nyams pa la ni 'jug ngogs la sogs pa la'o/ / nad chen pos btab pa la ni dkyil 'khor chu bo'i ngogs dang 'gram du bya'o/ / nad thams cad kyis thams cad du btab pa la ni ri'i rtse mor bri bar bya'o/ / mkha' 'gro mas byas pa la yang bram ze'i ldum ra'am/ khang pa stong pa'am/ gnas dben par gzhol ba'i sa phyogs su bya'o/ /

“Similarly, in the case of a woman or a man who seeks fame, one should draw the maṇḍala at a crossroad or on brahmins’ land.[516] If it is a woman whose child has died, then it should be drawn near a fruit-bearing tree or a sap-filled tree. In the case of a childless woman, it should be drawn in the middle of a field of rice ready to harvest. For those who have contracted the three diseases[517] or have been afflicted by others, it should be drawn at a crossing point[518] or a similar place. In the case of severe illness, a maṇḍala that destroys rākṣasas[519] should be drawn on a river island or a riverbank. Drawn on a mountaintop, the maṇḍala counters all diseases, in whatever form they may be.[520] For the diseases caused by ḍākinīs, it should be drawn in a brahmin’s garden,[521] an empty house, a lonely spot, or a depression in the terrain.

de bzhin du las thams cad la nam phyed dam dus thams cad du mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / yi ge gcig pa de nyid kyi sngags kyis me tog gi mchod yon phul te gshegs su gsol lo/ / dkyil 'khor la chus gtor ba byas na nad thams cad bsrung ba chen po byas par 'gyur te

“In all rituals such as these, the maṇḍala should be drawn at midnight, or midday,[522] or otherwise at any time. Employing this very one-syllable mantra, one should present a welcome offering of flowers to the deity and then dismiss him. Having done so, one should inundate the maṇḍala with water. This will provide strong protection to all those who are weary.

nad thams cad las grol bar yang 'gyur ro/ / bu med pas ni bu rnyed cing / / skal med rnams kyang skal ldan 'gyur/ / dbul po rnams kyis nor 'thob pa/ / dkyil 'khor mthong ba tsam gyis so/ / skyes pa'am yang na bud med kyang / / thos nas the tshom med byas na/ / ci 'dod rnam pa sna tshogs ni/ / thob 'gyur rtag tu phun sum tshogs/ /

“They will be freed from all illnesses[523] And will attain their desired goals.[524] One without a son will obtain a son, And the unfortunate will meet with good fortune. “The destitute will obtain wealth Through merely seeing the maṇḍala. Anyone with faith in the ritual, Whether it is a woman or a man, Will meet, every time, With whatever kind of good fortune they wish for.”[525]
byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod kyi cho ga rab 'byam las/ /'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i rtsa ba las kyi dkyil 'khor gsum pa'i le'u ste gsum pa rdzogs so// //
This concludes the chapter on the maṇḍala procedure, the third in “The Root Manual of the Divine Youth Mañjuśrī,” an extensive bodhisattva textbook.
ras ris chen mo dang po'i cho ga'i le'u
Chapter 4
Homage to the Buddha and all buddhas and bodhisattvas![526]

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma la gzigs nas/ gzhan yang 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po der 'dus pa la yang gzigs te/ bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i zhabs gnyis la btud nas zhal 'dzum pa dang ldan pas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ /

Mañjuśrī then looked at the entire realm of the Pure Abode and again directed his gaze at the great assembly gathered there. Prostrating at the feet of Śākyamuni, he smiled and said this to the Blessed One:

bcom ldan 'das sems can thams cad la phan pa'i phyir sngags kyi spyod pa'i cho ga'i sgrub pa'i rgyu mthun pa/ chos kyi char ci ltar 'dod pa'i 'bras bu sgrub pa'i cho ga rab 'byam las ras kyi ri mo'i cho ga bsod nams bla na med pa skyed pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi sa bon mngon par sgrub par byed pa/

“It is good fortune, O Blessed One, that there is a painting procedure, intended for the benefit of all beings, from the extensive chapters that produce a rain of desired results falling down from the Cloud of Dharma that arises from the accomplishment of sādhana methods of mantra practice. This procedure generates a vast amount of merit and creates the seed of perfect awakening; it also brings complete omniscience.[527]

mdor na bsam pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa sngags thams cad kyi 'bras bu la rab tu sbyor zhing 'bras bu dang bcas par byed pa/ don med pa ma yin pa grub cing sgrub par byed pa/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi spyod pa yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po'i go cha bgos pa/ bdud thams cad kyi stobs zil gyis mnan cing rgyab kyis phyogs par byed pa bdag dang sems can thams cad la thugs brtse ba'i phyir de legs par bshad du gsol/

“In short, it completely fulfills all wishes; it grants the complete acquisition of the fruits of all mantras; it brings about accomplishments that are fruitful and effective, as well as the complete fulfillment of bodhisattva conduct; it equips one with the armor of a great bodhisattva; and it overpowers and puts to flight the entire army of Māra. Please take pity on us, O Blessed One, and on all beings, and teach us this procedure.”
'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas de skad ces gsol pa dang / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ /
Being thus addressed by the divine youth Mañjuśrī, Lord Śākyamuni said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth:

'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa khyod skye bo mang po la phan pa'i phyir zhugs pa dang / 'jig rten la snying brtse ba'i phyir gang khyod de bzhin gshegs pa la don 'di 'dri bar sems pa ni legs so legs so/ / de shin du legs par nyon la yid la zung shig dang / ngas bshad par bya'o/ / khyod kyi ras ris kyi cho ga rab 'byam sngags thams cad sgrub par byed pa la rab tu 'jug pa mthar gyis ngas bshad par bya'o/ / sngon yang de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis bstan te da ltar yang ngas bshad par bya'o/ /

“Good, Mañjuśrī! It is good that you, acting for the benefit of many people, with compassion for the world, deem this topic to be worthy of asking the Tathāgata. Listen well and reflect upon it thoroughly. I will teach your painting procedure to you in full‍—the procedure that is the means for all sentient beings to accomplish their practice.[528] I will teach it just as it was previously taught by all the tathāgatas, introducing and expounding it in the right order. I will teach it now.

dang por re zhig sa'i phyogs gtsang ba rdul med pa las ras bal yang dag par blangs la/ dam tshig la zhugs pa'i sems can rnams kyis ras bal de yang dag par byas te/ yang sngags 'dis dkyil 'khor gyis brgya rtsa brgyad tu bsngags par bya'o/ /

“To start, the maṇḍala master should bring cotton to a patch of ground free of impurities and have it cleaned by people who have taken up the samaya vows. When it has been cleaned, the maṇḍala master[529] should incant it with the mantra, as given next, one hundred and eight times.

na maH sa man+ta bud d+hA nAM/ bo d+hi sa twa a pra ti ha ta ga ti ma ti pra tsA ri NAM/ na maHsaM shod+ha na duHkha pra sha ma nen+d+ra rA dzA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya ar+ha te samyak+saM bud d+hA ya/ tad+ya thA/ oM sho d+ha ya saM sho d+ha ya/ sarba big+h+naM g+ha ta ka ma hA kA ru Ni ka ku mA ra rU pa d+hA ri Ni/ bi kurba bi kurba/ sa ma yam nu sma ra tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha hUM hUM phaT phaT swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas whose intentions are impeccable and who practice impeccable conduct. Homage to the sovereign king of kings who purifies and pacifies suffering, the tathāgata, the worthy one, the perfectly awakened one. The mantra is as follows: “Oṁ, purify purify! You are the destroyer of all obstacle makers, one of great compassion, possessed of the form of divine youth! Transform, transform! Remember your samaya! Remain, remain! Huṁ huṁ, phaṭ phaṭ, svāhā![530]

de nas grong gi chos mi shes pa'i gzhon nu ma/ bram ze'i rigs dang rgyal rigs su skyes pa dang / rje'u'i rigs su skyes pa dang rigs ngan pa'i skyes gnas yongs su spangs pa/ / dbang po ma tshang ba med pa/ yan lag thams cad mdzes pa pha dang mas rjes su gnang ba/ gso sbyong byas pa/ byang chub tu sems bskyed pa/ snying rje dang ldan pa/ bzhin dkar ba/ kha dog gzhan rnam par spangs pa/ mdor na bud med kyi mtshan nyid rab tu zhi ba'i mtshan nyid kyis mtshan pa/ shin tu nyin zhag shis pa dang / zla ba yar ngo dang gza' bzang po bltas te/ du ba dang khug rna med cing sprin dang bral ba rlung med cing gtsang ba'i sa phyogs su sngar bstan pa'i gzhon nu ma khrus byas shing gos gtsang ma bgos te/ gos kyis legs par bkab pa byas pa la sngags 'di phyag rgya chen po dang ldan pas bsrung bar bya ste/ tsan+dan dkar po dang / gur gum srog chags med pa'i chu dang sbyar bas ras bal de dang bu mo de sngags de nyid kyis yang dag par sbyangs te gtor la/ tsan+dan dkar po dang / gur gum gyi chus steng dang 'og dang phyogs bzhir yang gtor bar bya'o/ /

“Then the maṇḍala master should procure a young girl, who has not yet had a sexual experience, born into a brahmin, kṣatriya, or vaiśya family. Those of a low-caste origin should be avoided.[531] She should be physically unimpaired[532] and beautiful in every limb. She should have obtained permission to take part in the ritual from her mother and father and should be observing the ritual fast. She should have developed bodhicitta and be compassionate. She should have a clear, light complexion without any discoloration. In short, she must have all the auspicious marks of a woman. On an auspicious day of the bright fortnight, having ascertained that the planets are astrologically auspicious and bright, in a clean, windless place that is free from smoke, fog, and clouds,[533] having bathed the previously described girl, the maṇḍala master should dress her nicely in clean clothes and perform the protection ritual employing the mantra as given next along with the great mudrā.[534] He should mix some white sandalwood and saffron with water that is free of living organisms and, while the girl is drinking it, he should sprinkle her with this water,[535] purified with the same mantra.
tsan+dan dkar po dang gur gum dang ga bur gcig tu byas pa'i bdug pas bdug par bya ste/ rang nyid kyis sbyin pa'am/ sgrub pa'i grogs mchog gi slob dpon gyis sbyin par bya'o/ /

“He should throw white sandalwood and saffron-scented water in the four cardinal directions, upward, downward, and in the four intermediate directions.[536] Having blended white sandalwood, saffron, and camphor together,[537] the master should offer it himself or have the practitioner do this.[538]
sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang sa bcu'i dbang phyug la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams/ ras kyi dog pa 'di la lhag par gnas par mdzod cig ces lan gsum brjod par bya'o/ /
The following should be spoken three times: “ ‘May the blessed buddhas and the great bodhisattvas established on the tenth bodhisattva level bless the thread for making this cloth.’ ”

de nas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams dgongs su gsol zhes byas nas/ bdug pas bdug pa de'i dus su rma bya dang / khrung khrung dang ngang pa dang bzhad dang ngur pa rnam pa sna tshogs bya dge ba thang la gnas pa'am/ chu la spyod pa rnams nam mkha' la 'gro bar 'gyur ba'am/ dge ba'i skad 'don na las 'di ni 'bras bu dang bcas pa yin no zhes sgrub pa pos shes par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams kyis bdag gi ras skud 'di la byin gyis brlabs te/ bdag gi skye ba dam pa ni legs par 'tsho ba yin te/ bdag gi sngags sgrub pa 'bras bu med par mi 'gyur ro/ /

“The blessed buddhas and the great bodhisattvas will subsequently give their attention to the ritual. While the master burns incense, at that time peacocks, curlews, wild geese, cranes, and ruddy geese‍—many beautiful birds who live on water or on land‍—will fly up into the air and utter their auspicious cries. The practitioner should then know, ‘My rite will bear fruit. The holy buddhas and the great bodhisattvas have blessed my canvas thread for me. My present life will be a happy one, and my mantra accomplishment will not be in vain.’

rnga pa Ta ha dang rnga bo che dang rdza rnga dang dung dang pi bang dang gling bu dang khar rnga dang rdza rnga chen po'i sgra thos pa'am/ bud med dang khye'u'am/ bu mo'am skyes pa rnams bcos ma'am bcos ma ma yin pa de'i dus su blo bur du 'di skad ces/ rgyal ba dang grub pa dang sbyin pa dang byin pa dang khyer cig ces pa dang / dpal dang 'bras bu dang / 'bras bu yod pa dang / cho ga dang brgya byin dang / mang po dang de dag la sogs pa'i sgra gzhan rab tu dge ba 'don pa'am dril bu'i sgra dang dga' ba'i sgra thos na/ des na rig pa 'dzin pas shes par bya ba ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams kyis byin gyis brlabs pa ni 'di yin te/ don yod pa'i grub pa ni 'di yin zhing gzhan du ma yin no zhes so/ /

“The sounds of drums‍—big, medium, and small‍—conchs, lutes, flutes, cymbals, and tambourines will be heard. Women, boys, girls, and men‍—both real and imagined[539]‍—will at that time spontaneously say the following: “ ‘Victory is accomplished! Take the offering that has been offered! This is glorious and fruitful, with an opulence matching that of Śakra!’[540] “They, and others too, will say similar words. Sounds of a bell or sounds of rejoicing may also be heard. Only then will the knowledge holder[541] know that the thread has been blessed by the holy buddhas and the great bodhisattvas, not in any other way. The accomplishment will not be futile.

ci ste de'i dus su ma rungs pa'i tshig 'don pa khyer cig zo shig zung shig / nyams pa rnam par nyams pa/ kyi hud ring ba shin tu ring ba med pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa'i sgra 'don pa'am/ spre'u dang ma he dang ce spyang dang bong bu dang byi la dang / ba lang dang dud 'gro smad pa rkang gnyis sam rkang bzhi pa'i sgra 'don par gyur na/ des ni sgrub pa pos bdag gi dngos grub ni med pa yin no zhes shes par bya ste/ skabs der brtul bar bya zhing yang snga ma bzhin du yang brtsam par bya'o/ / de bzhin du lan bdun gyi bar du byas la/ bdun pa'i las kyi bya ba la ni mtshams med pa lnga byas pa yang 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de nas sgrub pa pos gzhon nu ma de bsrung ba byas la ku sha'i khres la gzhag par bya ste/ shar ram byang phyogs su phyogs par bzhag la bdag nyid srung ba dang lha la dbul ba'i kha zas zas su sbyin no/ / sngar sbyang ba byas pa'i ku sha'i khres de nyid kyi cho gas ras bal la yang bya'o/ /

“But, on that occasion, they may also say harsh words, such as: “ ‘Seize, devour, and cause others to devour! It is lost, lost completely. Alas! It is far, very far! It is gone!’ “They could say words such as these. Also, the monkeys, buffaloes, jackals, donkeys, cats, and other detestable humans and animals might utter their cries. The practitioner will then realize that he has not succeeded, and that his present life will be short.[542] As an option, he can do the preliminary practice and repeat the procedure from the beginning up to seven times. After the seven performances of the ritual, even someone who has committed the five acts of immediate retribution will succeed. “The practitioner should then perform the protection ritual for the previously selected girl and have her sit on a bundle of kuśa grass. He should place her facing the east or north, get his sacrificial food, and feed it to her.[543] Following this procedure, he should have her spin the cotton upon the bundle of kuśa grass that was prepared beforehand.

dog pa de 'jam pa dang legs par bsgrims pa dang sngar bslabs pa'i bu mos yang dag par blangs te/ gcig dang gsum dang lnga dang brgyad la sogs pa nas bcu drug gi bar ram/ kar sha'i grangs legs par bgrangs pa dang ldan pas bya'o/ / de la rab ni bcu drug bya/ / de bzhin brgyad ni bar ma ste/ / phran tshegs las la sgrub pa ni/ / gcig dang lnga ni tha ma'o/ / las rnams kun la sngags rig pas/ / ci ltar nus pa bzhin du bya/ /

“The thread, well spun and white, should be twisted together by a girl who has previously been trained. It should be well measured into units of one, three, five, eight, or up to sixteen palas or karṣas.[544][545]The best would be of sixteen units.[546] The middling would be of eight units. The next in rank would be of five units. In rites where the target is of minor significance, the thread should be of one unit.[547] A mantra adept should use this scheme in all rites according to his ability.[548]

de nas brtsams te gang cung zad/ / sdig pa sngar ni byas pa dag / dog par sems kyis dmigs pa na/ / de yi mod la 'jig par 'gyur/ / dog pa 'di dag yang dag blangs/ / gtsang ma'i snod du gzhug par bya/ / de nas bzhag pa byas nas de/ / ga bur gyi ni bdug pas bdug / srog chags yan lag byung ba'am/ / gur gum tsan+dan la sogs dang / / me tog ma le tsam pa ka / dri zhim sogs pas yongs su bsgo/ / bsrung ba'i cho ga byas nas ni/ / gtsang ma'i phyogs su yang dag bzhag / sngags rig las kun shes pa yis/ / shin du mnyam gzhag bzlas pa bya/ / de nas tha ga par song nas/ / ci 'dod pa yi rin sbyin no/ / rang dbang yan lag ma nyams dang / / dkar po'i chos la rtag tu dad/ / rgan min nad kyis gdungs pa min/ / lud pa dbugs mi bde ba spangs/ / ma ning smad pa ma yin dang / / 'phye bo ma yin skra dkar spangs/ / kun gyis bkur ba'i mtshan nyid ldan/ / rab bsngags blta na sdug pa dang / / blo dang yang dag spyod pa dge/ / 'jig rten pa yi tshul la brten/ / dngos grub 'dod pas de la ni/ / ras bzang btags pa'i ched du bskul/ / grogs po rigs bzang rab bsngags shing / / blo ldan bzo ni mkhas pa dang / / shin tu khyad par mchog gyur pa'i/ / ras thag bzang la bskul bar bya/ / rab ni rab tu bsgrub par bya/ / 'bring ni 'bring la bsgrub par bya/ / tha mal phran tshegs las la ni/ / dman pa nyid ni thams cad la/ / bzo bo ci ltar smra ba bzhin/ / rin ni de ltar sbyin par bya/ / dang po'i tshig ni yang dag 'byung / / bzo bo la ni sngags rigs pas/ / de nas myur du rin byin pa/ / dpa' bo'i tshong zhes de la brjod/ / don du gnyer med de la ni/ / rin du smra byed sgrub pa po/ / 'di ni myur du 'grub byed pa'i/ / ras ni bzang po bla na med/ / las kun byed cing mchod pa ste/ / lha dang mi yi bde ba sbyin/ / 'byung po kun gyi dpal 'gyur zhes/ / yang dag rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis gsungs/ /

“From then onward, Whatever bad karma one has previously committed Will be destroyed in an instant, As his mind focuses on the thread.[549] “He should take this thread And place it in a clean container. Having placed it there,[550] He should cense it with an incense of camphor “Or other substances not derived from the bodies of living beings,[551] Such as saffron, sandalwood,[552] and so forth. He should worship[553] it with fragrant flowers Such as jasmine, champak, and others. “The mantra adept, familiar with all the rites, Having recited the mantra as required, well focused, Should place the thread in a clean place For which the protection rite has been performed. “He should then go to a weaver And pay him a fee of his choice. The weaver should not be lacking any limbs, Not be emaciated, and always delight in the pure Dharma. “He should not be afflicted with illnesses, not be too old, And be free from coughing and asthma. He should not be impotent, And should be of a blameless origin.[554] “He should be faultless, Have no hump, and not be lame.[555] He must have all the auspicious marks[556] And be praiseworthy and good looking. “He should be pure in mind, virtuous in conduct, And depend for his livelihood on a profession approved by the world. The practitioner who seeks accomplishment in this ritual Should request him to weave the best of cloths. “His assistants[557] should be praiseworthy, of good caste, Intelligent, and well trained In weaving the best cloth Of the highest quality.[558] “For the highest rite, the mantra adept should follow the highest routine; For the medium, he should follow the medium. He should follow other routines Whenever the deeds are low or insignificant, “Paying whatever price The craftsman specifies. At the first utterance of the craftsman The mantra adept should “Promptly make the payment‍— This is called the ‘heroes’ transaction,’ Since the mantra reciter pays After a mere request, without bargaining. “This supreme and best of cloths Swiftly produces accomplishment, Fulfills all rites, is venerable, And bestows divine and human happiness. The perfectly awakened buddhas taught That this was auspicious for all beings.

de nas rig pa 'dzin pas tha ga pa la rgyu skar bzang po'am/ cho 'phrul gyi zla ba phyed dam nyin zhag dge ba'am gza' dge ba bltas te gso sbyong sbyin/ yang na dus kyi mchog dpyid kyi dus kyi zla ba yar gyi ngo la shing a mra'i me tog skyes shing shing gi mchog rnams kyi yal ga dang me tog rgyas pa de'i dus mtshams su/ snga dro nyi ma 'char ba la sngar bstan pa'i tha ga pa lha la dbul bar 'os pa'i kha zas bsten cing / gos gtsang ma bgos la mgo la cod pan bcings nas khrus legs par byas te/ tsan+dan dkar po dang gur gum gang yang rung bas lus byugs nas ga pur gyi dris kha la bsgos te yid dga' ba dang bkres pa dang skom pa med par byas te/ thags kyi lag cha tha ga pa la sogs pa'i yo byad thams cad kyang sar pa la sa dang ba lang gi lci bas bkrus te/ yang ba'i rnam lngas bkru bar bya'o/ /

“Then the knowledge holder should prescribe to the weaver the observance of a fast and, during an auspicious lunar asterism, on a bright day during the ‘fortnight of miracles’ when the planets have been ascertained as auspicious, or during another bright fortnight, in the spring, that best of seasons when mango trees are garlanded with blossoms and the best of trees are fully in bloom, in the morning when the sun has risen, he should give sacrificial food to the weaver who fits the previously described characteristics. He should dress him in clean clothes, tie a turban on his head, bathe and anoint him well, and smear his body with white sandalwood and saffron or some other such fragrance. He should perfume the weaver’s mouth with camphor, cheer him up, and make sure that he is neither hungry nor thirsty. The knowledge holder should then thoroughly clean the weaving implements, the rope, and other tools, using clay and cow dung. Placing them in front, he should rinse them with the five products of a cow again and again.

de nas srog chags med pa'i chus kyang bkru bar bya'o/ / tsan+dan dkar po dang gur gum gyi chus kyang gtor bar bya'o/ / gtsang ma'i sa phyogs su ca co med cing skye bo dang bral ba dben pa'i gnas su bkab pa dang gsang bar me tog gis mchod do/ / de nas sgrub pa pos yang dag par dag par byed pa'i sngags kyis brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags pa'i yungs kar gyis phyogs bzhi steng 'og phyogs mtshams su gtor bar bya'o/ / de nas tha ga pa la yungs kar gyis gtor bar bya zhing / phyag rgya chen po gtsug phud lnga bcings te/ gtsug phud bcing ba byas na srung ba chen po byas par 'gyur ro/ /

“Then, having rinsed them with water free of living organisms, he should ritually besprinkle them with white sandalwood and saffron. Having chosen a clean spot on the ground in a place free from noise and people, the practitioner should sit on a seat that is secluded, peaceful, and adorned with flowers. He should then throw white mustard seeds incanted one hundred and eight times with the purification mantra in the four cardinal directions, upward, downward, and in the four intermediate directions. Then, having cast mustard seeds at the weaver, he should form the great five-crested mudrā and tie his hair into a topknot. This will afford powerful protection.

gal te ras ris rab yin na ni/ zur bzhir zheng du khru bzhi chur khru brgyad de/ tha ga pas de tsam la yongs su goms par bya'o/ / 'bring ni zheng du khru do chur khru lnga pa'o/ / tha ma ni zheng du bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho gang chur ni khru brgyad kyi phyed do/ / de la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi mtho gang la ni yul dbus kyi skyes bu tshad dang ldan pa'i khru gcig ste/ 'di la bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho zhes bsgrags te/ tshad 'dis tshad du bstan pa yin no/ /

“If the cloth is going to be of the superior kind, it should be four cubits wide and eight cubits long;[559] he should supply the weaver with enough material for these measurements. If the cloth is going to be of the medium kind, it should be two cubits wide and five cubits long. If it is to be of the smallest kind, it should have the width equal to the thumb-to-index-finger measurement of the Sugata, and the length of one cubit.[560] Regarding these particular measurements, the thumb-to-index-finger measurement of Lord Buddha corresponds to the length of the forearm of a man from the central region[561]‍—this is what is known as the Buddha’s thumb-to-index-finger measurement as a unit of length. The cloth is said to be of the authentic size when these measurements are used.
ras ni rab kyis dngos grub mchog / 'jig rten gang zag mchog gis gsungs/ / thub pa mya ngan 'das 'og tu/ / rgyal srid 'dod la bar ma yin/ /

“When the cloth is of the superior kind, The superior accomplishment will arise, as taught by the most eminent of men. The medium cloth is for those desiring royal status After the sage has disappeared.[562]

longs spyod che 'dod skyes bu dang / / lha mi lha min gdengs can ni/ / tha ma la ni grub par bshad/ / 'bring gis 'bring ni grub pa'o/ / las rnams phran tshegs dag la ni/ / ras ni tha mas rtag tu 'grub/ / rdzas rnams kun la rtag tu ni/ / las rnams thams cad 'grub par 'gyur/ / ras gsum gyis kyang bstan pa ni/ / skal 'dod mi la 'grub pa yin/ / brgya byin bde sogs bdag po la'ang / / cho ga nyams na 'grub mi 'gyur/ / cho ga yang dag ldan na ni/ / mi yi skye ba tha ma la'ang / / las rnams thams cad 'bad med par/ / myur ba nyid du 'grub par byed/ / rgyal ba rgya mtsho sras dag gis/ / lam 'di dag ni yang dag bstan/ / phongs pa mgon med sdug bsngal ba'i/ / sems can kun la legs sbyin pa'o/ / byang chub lam ni ma lus kyang / / de nyid gzigs pas bstan pa ste/ / byang chub rgyu yi chos 'di ni/ / sngags kyi lam gyis bstan pa yin/ /

“When the cloth is of the lowest quality, the accomplishment is said To belong to the seekers of great prosperity Who will attain the comforts of the three classes of gods and the asuras. When middling, the accomplishment will be middling. “The cloth of the lowest quality should always be used To accomplish the least important activities. Any activity will be accomplished And all substances always obtained. “What is taught in the cloth ritual will bring accomplishment For people seeking good fortune. Those who stray from the right procedure‍— Even Śakra, the husband of Śacī‍—will not succeed. “Those, however, who follow the right procedure, Even those of lowly birth, Will swiftly succeed In all rituals without effort. “This path has been taught By the victorious ones and their foremost sons To improve the lot of all beings Suffering from poverty and lacking a protector. “The complete path to awakening Has been explained by those who know the truth. This path, the cause of awakening, Is presented by means of the Mantra Vehicle.

'jig rten dkyil 'khor ma lus dang / / 'jig rten 'das pa'ang 'grub 'gyur te/ / dkyil 'khor gang dag bstan pa yis/ / 'bad pa med par sngags rnams 'grub/ / gang zhig byang chub rgyu 'dod pas/ / de la rtag tu dngos grub 'gyur/ / 'gro la phan sems rtag med pa/ / gzhan la 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / bdag nyid chen po 'jam dpal ni/ / gzhon nur gyur pas khyad par du/ / byang chub 'jug pa'i khyad sems la/ / ras ris 'grub par gsungs pa yin/ /

“Mantras will be accomplished without effort, As will all mundane maṇḍalas. The supramundane ones that have been taught Will also be accomplished. “Those whose minds are set on awakening Will always gain accomplishment. As for those who are always hostile to the world, Their accomplishment will not be taught in this manual. “The great being Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, Always taught this accomplishment[563] In particular for those beings Who set out in pursuit of awakening.

bya ba myur du 'grub pa'i phyir/ / thams cad 'dir ni thob pa yin/ / de nas mthar gyis bzo bos ni/ / ras ni 'bad pas btags par bya/ / nyin zhag lnga dang brgyad dang ni/ / bcu drug gnyis dang bzhi dang ni/ / nyin zhag gcig gis myur du ni/ / myur bar ras kyi tha ga bya/ /

“One can swiftly obtain this accomplishment in full For the sake of fulfilling that which needs to be done. The craftsman should therefore Weave the cloth diligently, step by step, “Working in two sessions of four time units each day, It will take him five or eight days of sixteen time units. Working all day and all night, The weaving will be completed quickly.[564]

grub pa mchog ni 'dod pa yis/ / nyin zhag gcig pa dge ba yin/ / gtsang sbra'i spyod pa phun sum tshogs/ / bzo bo rtag tu byin brlabs ldan/ / gnas nas thag ring song nas ni/ / bshang dang gci ba yongs su dor/ / de nas gos bcas khrus byas te/ / gos gzhan dag kyang bgo bya zhing / / gos dkar phreng ba ldan par 'chang / / yang dang yang du nye reg bya/ / lus ni tsan+dan dkar pos byugs/ / bzo bos lag pa gnyis kyang byugs/ / legs 'jam rtag tu dri med par/ / 'bad pas kyang ni tha ga bya/ / de la sogs pa'i sbyor ba 'am/ / gzhan ni rgyal bas gsungs pa dang / / rnam dpyad rang bzhin 'bad pa yis/ / ras ni ma lus tha ga bya/ / ras kyi tha ga zin pa dang / / sngar gsungs las kyis legs byas pa/ / tshad ldan nyams pa med pa ni/ / nyin zhag bzang la bltab ste bzhag / yar ngo'i shin tu bzang po la/ / de la sngags ni gzhug par bya/ /

“In the case of those who desire the accomplishment of the highest order The cloth should be completed within a single day and night. The craftsman should be continually supervised To check whether he observes his purification practices. “He should walk away from his dwelling the required distance To evacuate his bowels and bladder. He should then bathe and wash his clothes, Changing into the new ones. “Wearing white garments and a garland, He should rinse his mouth repeatedly, Anoint his body with white sandalwood, And wipe his hands clean. “He should weave on with diligence, Making a fine and blemish-free cloth. Using the previously mentioned methods Or other methods as taught by the victorious ones, “When the thoughtful and disciplined weaver Who weaves the entire cloth Creates it through the preceding rites And completes it as described, “The practitioner should ensure, on an auspicious day, That it is not too small but of the right size and even. Then, during an auspicious bright fortnight, He should invest it with a mantra.[565]

ras ni yongs su gsal byas pa/ / kha tshar mthar ni mdud mdzes bya/ / 'od ma'i shing la btags nas ni/ / de nas ras ni blangs te 'gro/ / bzo bo bde legs byas nas ni/ / nor mang pos ni bgo bsha' bya/ / brtul zhugs bzang po legs spyod pa'i/ / sngags pa ci ltar 'dod song nas/ / me tog dri zhim gyis mchod de/ / gtsang ba'i phyogs su gzhag par bya/ / 'di nyid kyi ni sngags kyis su/ / srung ba'i cho ga rab tu bya/ / sngon ni ras bal gang de yis/ / lan mang du ni yongs sbyangs la/ / bdag nyid dang ni ras dag la/ / de nyid kyis ni bsrung bar bya/ / dpa' bo chen po 'jam dpal gyis/ / sngags kyi bzlas pa gsungs pa dang / / 'das pa'i sangs rgyas mang po dang / / ngas kyang da ltar gsungs pa yin/ /

“Having spread out the cloth, Adorned with knotted tassels, He should fasten it onto bamboo sticks, Then take it and go. “He should congratulate the craftsman at length, Rewarding him with a substantial honorarium. He should then go wherever he wishes, Sticking by his rules of conduct and ritual observances. “He should worship the cloth with fragrant flowers Then place it in a clean place And perform the protection rite Using the mantra. “To perform the protection rite He should use the same mantra With which he had earlier purified the cotton repeatedly. The protection should be both for himself and the cloth. “Mañjuśrī, he of great valor, Has been expressed in the form of mantra In the past by many mantras And by me as well again and again.[566]

de nyid sngags ni thams cad kyi/ / sngags kyi ngo bos rnam par spyod/ / brtson 'grus che zhing gzi brjid che/ / sngags kyi don kun sgrub byed pa/ / cha byad rnam pa sna tshogs byed/ / skyob pa rnam pa sna tshogs rgyu/ / 'dzam gling gnas pa'i sems can rnams/ / rmongs pa spyod cing sems pa med/ / ma dad phyin ci log par byed/ / log spyod shin tu brkam chags kyis/ / rdzas rnams ma lus pa dag dang / / sngags rnams kyis kyang 'grub mi byed/ / 'khor ba'i mun pa'i btson rar ni/ / de nyid kyis ni 'khor bar 'gyur/ / gang yang rtag tu yi dag cing / / dad ldan bkra shis dag la dga'/ / sngags rnams kun la spro ba dang / / rtag tu 'dzin dang 'chang ba dang / / bdag nyid chen po dngos grub 'dod/ / spro ba che zhing gzi brjid che/ / rgyal bas gsungs pa'i sngags dag ni/ / 'bad pa med par 'grub par 'gyur/ / dad pa med pa'i skye bo la/ / dkar po'i chos rnams mi skye ste/ /

“He, the very nature of mantra, Pervades all mantras; With great valor and efficacy, He fulfills the aims of all mantras. “He takes a great diversity of forms And serves as the cause for all manner of protection. Foolish are the minds and behavior Of beings living in Jambūdvīpa. “They are devoid of faith and perverted; They follow mistaken conduct and are very greedy. They are unable to accomplish the mantras, Nor can they obtain any substances. “And so they wander In the dark prison of saṃsāra. However, if one has a pure mind, Constant faith, and keen interest in the auspicious; “If one is constantly eager To grasp and maintain all the mantras; And if such a great being desires accomplishment And has great perseverance and energy, “The mantras taught by the victorious ones Will bring him results without effort. But among those without faith, The virtuous Dharma will not grow.

sa bon tshwa sgor btab pa la/ / myu gu skye ba med pa bzhin/ / dad pa'i rtsa ba rtag tu chos/ / chos don gzigs pas gsungs pa ste/ / chos don spyod pa de dag la/ / sngags rnams rtag tu 'grub par gsungs/ /

“It is like a seed sown in salty soil, Whose sprout will not bear fruit. Faith is always the root of Dharma, As has been taught by all those who show the true goal. The accomplishment of mantra, as has always been taught, Belongs to those disciplined for the sake of the Dharma.

de nas sgrub pa pos bzo bo legs par bslab pa'i ri mo mkhan nam/ bdag nyid 'dri ba la mkhas pas/ tshon ma 'dres shing kha dog gsal ba dang ldan pa'i tshon rtsi rnams blangs te/ sngar tha ga pa la byas pa'i cho ga ci lta ba de nyid kyi mtshan nyid dang ldan pas/ ri mo mkhan la snga ma bzhin sbyar bar bya ste/ sngar ci ltar tha ga pa la byas pa de nyid kyis ras la ri mo 'drir gzhug go/ / yang na bdag nyid kyis bri bar bya'o/ / ga pur dang tsan+dan dang gur gum la sogs pa'i dris tshon rtsi la bsgo bar bya zhing bdug spos bsregs te/ de nyid kyi sngags kyis lan brgya rtsa brgyad 'khor dang bcas pa la yang bzla ste/ me tog nA ga ge sar dang pun nA ga dang ba ku la dang tsam pa ka dang dbyar gyi me tog dang d+hA nush+ka ri dang mA la ti'i me tog la sogs pas ras de gcal bkram pa byas la/ shar du mngon par phyogs pas ku sha'i khres la 'dug ste blo legs par gnas pa dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' la dmigs pa'i sems kyis pir phra mo lag par blangs nas/ 'khrug pa med pa'i sems kyis ras de la bri bar bya'o/ /

“Therefore, only a well-trained painter skilled in sādhana,[567] or oneself if able to, should do the painting using uncontaminated paints. The painter, having undergone the ritual procedure as previously described for preparing the weaver, and endowed with the auspicious marks and so forth should choose any bright paints of strong colors and execute the painting in detail. The painting may be commissioned or done by oneself adhering to the same procedure as before in the case of the weaver. “One should infuse the paints with camphor, saffron, sandalwood, and so forth, and then, burning incense, incant them with the very same mantra one hundred and eight times.[568] One should bestrew the cloth with the blossoms of the ironwood tree, pannay tree, bulletwood tree, and the flowers of champak, Arabian jasmine, dhānuṣkārika jasmine, and royal jasmine. Then, sitting on a bundle of kuśa grass and facing east, with a settled mind and thoughts directed to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, one should take hold of a fine-tipped brush and, with a relaxed mind, commence the painting.

dang por re zhig bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa bri bar bya ste/ rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa skyes bu chen po'i mtshan sum cu rtsa gnyis kyis mtshan pa/ sku dpe byad bzang po brgyad cus nye bar mdzes pa rin po che'i pad+ma la bzhugs pa kun nas 'od 'bar ba/ sku 'od 'dom gang gis nye bar mdzes pa chos 'chad bzhin pa/ sku dang zhing rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa/ dbus na gnas pa'i pad+ma bai DUr+ya'i sdong bu can 'og na ni klu'i rgyal po gnyis kyi gdan chen po'i pad+ma'i sdong bu la 'dzin cing / de bzhin gshegs pa la blta ba/ lag pa g.yas pas phyag 'tshal ba/ mdog dkar po rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa mi dang 'dra ba/ phyed sbrul gyi gzugs can dga' bo dang nye dga' bri bar bya'o/ / kun nas pad+ma'i mtsho pad+ma'i 'dab ma dang me tog cung zad kha bye ba dang / rnam par kha bye ba dang chu las skyes pa'i srog chags rnams dang / bya dang nya la sogs pas khyab pa yangs shing mdzes par skyes pa bri bar bya'o/ / gang bcom ldan 'das kyi rtsa ba'i pad+ma'i sdong bu de las 'phros pa'i yal ga las pad+ma'i me tog du ma mthar gyis mtho ba bya'o/ / g.yon gyi phyogs su pad+ma'i me tog brgyad byas te/ pad+ma de dag la byang chub sems dpa' chen po brgyad kyi gzugs bzhugs pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“First one should paint the Tathāgata Śākyamuni, endowed with all of his excellent forms, his body marked with the thirty-two marks of a perfect man and adorned with the eighty minor characteristics. He sits on a jeweled lotus, his form surrounded by a halo of light to the distance of one fathom all around. He teaches the Dharma with a serene expression. “Beneath the great throne in the center, which consists of a lotus with a strong beryl stalk, are two nāga kings‍—Nanda and Upananda‍—who support the stalk. They should be painted in half-human, half-serpent form, looking at the Tathāgata and greeting him with their right hands. A lotus pond should be painted surrounding them that is filled with lotus leaves and flowers with opening buds and teeming with aquatic creatures such as birds, fish, and so forth. All the figures throughout it should be of exquisite form. “At the base of the stem of the Blessed One’s lotus spring several other lotus flowers, all growing progressively higher. To his left, eight lotuses should be drawn with the figures of the eight great bodhisattvas seated upon them.

dang po la re zhig 'phags pa 'jam dpal cung zad kha dog pad+ma'i ge sar bzhin du ser skya'am gur gum mam gser gyi mdog 'dra ba gzhon nu'i cha byad byis pa dang / khye'u'i gzugs can skra zur phud lnga dang ldan pa/ gzhon nu'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa/ lag pa g.yon pa na ut+pal sngon po bsnams pa/ lag pa g.yas pas de bzhin gshegs pa la phyag byed pa/ sku mdzes pa zhi ba'i cha byad kyis de bzhin gshegs pa la blta ba/ bzhin cung zad rgod pa 'od 'bar ba dang ldan pas dkyil 'khor kun du khyab pa bri'o/ / pad+ma gnyis pa la 'phags pa zla ba'i 'od shin tu gzhon sha can de bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / gsum pa la ni nor bzang ngo / / bzhi pa la ni sgrib pa rnam par sel ba'o/ / lnga pa la ni nam mkha' mdzod do/ / drug pa la ni sa'i snying po'o/ / bdun pa la ni sdig med do/ / brgyad pa la ni spyan bzang yin te/ de dag thams cad kyang gzhon nu khye'u'i cha byad can/ gzhon nu'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“On the first lotus is Noble Mañjuśrī. His color is either whitish like the filaments of a lotus[569] or golden like saffron. His form is that of a divine youth with the features of a young male child. On his head are five decorative locks of hair, and he is ornamented with all the adornments of a divine youth. In his left hand he holds a blue lotus, and with his right he salutes the Tathāgata, at whom he is directing his gaze. His bodily form is charming and peaceful, with a slightly laughing countenance, and a halo of blazing light encircling him. “The noble Candraprabha should be painted on the second lotus, also in the form of a divine youth. On the third should be Sudhana; on the fourth, Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin; on the fifth, Gaganagañja; on the sixth, Kṣitigarbha; on the seventh, Anagha; and on the eighth, Sulocana. All of them should be painted as divine youths ornamented with the corresponding adornments.

bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yas phyogs su ni/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po brgyad byams pa ma gtogs pa rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ 'phags pa byams pa ni bcom ldan 'das dang nye bar bri bar bya ste/ tshangs par spyod pa'i cha byad 'dzin pa/ mgo ral pa'i cod pan bcings pa/ mdog gser 'dra ba/ ga sha dmar po gyon pa/ dar la dmar po'i stod g.yogs byas pa/ thal ba'i thig le gsum gyis mtshan pa/ gzugs mdzes pa dang ldan pa dbyig pa dang spyi blugs 'dzin pa kriSh+Na sa ra'i pags pa thal gong g.yon par bgos pa/ lag pa g.yon pas phreng ba 'dzin cing de bzhin gshegs pa la phyag byed pa/ der gtod pa'i lta ba sems kyi spyod pa bsam gtan la dmigs pa'i rnam pa can no/ /

“To the right of the Blessed One there are another eight great bodhisattvas, all of them, except Maitreya, adorned with all types of jewelry. The noble Maitreya, who is next to the Blessed One, wears the attire of one who is celibate and has a topknot held up with a crown. His body is golden colored and his robes red ocher. His silken upper garment is red. His elegant form is marked with the triple line[570] of an ascetic. Inside his left arm he carries a staff with a water jar suspended from it, and he has a black antelope skin thrown over his left shoulder. With his right hand he holds a rosary and greets the Tathāgata at whom he directs his gaze. His mental activity has its basis in mental absorption.

pad+ma gnyis pa la 'phags pa kun du bzang po mdog me tog pri yang ku ltar sngo sangs/ lus rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ lag pa g.yon pa na nor bu rin po che thogs pa/ lag pa g.yas pa na bil ba thogs shing mchog sbyin pa/ gzugs mdzes pa dang ldan pa de bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / gsum pa la ni 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'dam bu'i mdog 'dra ba/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ mchod phyir thogs dkar pos byas pa/ 'phags pa 'od dpag med gzugs mdzes shing yid du 'ong ba/ stobs bcu dang ldan pa/ ral pa'i mthar skyil mo krung gis bzhugs shing cod pan du byas pa/ lag pa g.yon na pad+ma bsnams pa/ lag pa g.yas pa mchog sbyin pa/ sems kyi spyod pa bsam gtan la dmigs pa'i rnam pa can/ lus kun nas 'od kyis gsal bar byas pa'o/ /

“On the second lotus is Samantabhadra, his body the dark color of the beautyberry flower and adorned with all types of jewelry. In his left hand he holds a wish-fulfilling gem and in his right a bel fruit, which he holds out in the boon-granting gesture. He should also be painted with a charming form. “On the third lotus is the noble Avalokiteśvara, white as the autumn moon[571] and adorned with all types of jewelry. He wears a topknot and a crown and is invested with a white sacred thread. On his head is the noble omniscient Amitābha, sitting nestled in the ends of his matted hair‍—wondrous and beautiful in form and possessed of the ten powers. He should be painted holding a lotus in his left hand[572] and displaying the boon-granting gesture with his right. His mental activity is grounded in mental absorption, and his body is surrounded by light.

bzhi pa la ni 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje lag pa g.yon na rdo rje 'dzin pa/ lag pa g.yas na bil ba thogs pas mchog sbyin pa mdog gser 'dra ba/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gzugs mdzes pa/ zhi ba'i lta ba dang ldan pa dang / dra ba dang dra ba phyed pas lus nye bar dkris pa mu tig gi phreng bas mchod phyir thogs byas pa/ cod pan rin po che 'bar bas rnam par 'phro ba gos g.yo ba dang ldan pa bgos pa dar la dkar po'i stod g.yogs byas pa'o/ / 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug dang kun du bzang po'i na bza' stod g.yogs kyang 'di bzhin du bya'o/ / cha byad ni ci ltar sngar bstan pa bzhin bya'o/ /

“On the fourth lotus is the noble Vajrapāṇi, with a vajra in his left hand. Golden in color, he is adorned with all kinds of jewelry. His right hand is clasped around a fruit and displays a boon-granting gesture. His charming form is of gentle aspect. His body is adorned with long and short pearl necklaces, and a pearl necklace serves as his sacred thread. He wears a crown studded with sparkling jewels, short trousers[573] of fine cloth, and an upper garment of white silk. Just like the noble Avalokiteśvara and Samantabhadra, he wears a cloak used for visiting holy bathing places, and his appearance[574] is as previously described.

de bzhin du pad+ma lnga pa la ni 'phags pa blo gros chen po/ drug pa la ni blo gros zhi ba/ bdun pa la ni rnam par snang mdzad snying po/ / brgyad pa la ni ngan song spong ba ste/ byang chub sems dpa' 'di dag bri bar bya ste/ bil ba'i 'bras bu dang glegs bam lag na thogs pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis shin tu mdzes pa/ dar las stod g.yogs byas pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ g.yo ba dang ldan pa'i gos bgos pa'o/ / de dag gi steng du'ang rang sangs rgyas brgyad bri bar bya ste/ dge slong gi cha byad 'dzin pa lus skyes bu chen po'i mtshan dang ldan pa/ chos gos dmar po gyon pa/ skyil mo krung gis nye bar gnas pa/ rin po che'i ut+pal la 'dug pa cha byad zhi ba'i bdag nyid kun nas 'od 'phro ba'i phreng bas khyab pa/ me tog dri zhim pos gcal bkram pa la 'di lta ste/ me tog mA li ta dang dbyar gyi me tog dang / d+hA nuSh+ka ri ka dang pun nA ga dang nA ga ge sar la sogs pa'i me tog gis ras ris kun nas gcal bkram par bri bar bya'o/ /

“On the fifth lotus is the noble Mahāmati; on the sixth, Śāntamati; on the seventh, Vairocanagarbha; and on the eighth, Apāyajaha‍—these bodhisattvas, too, should be depicted. They hold in their hands fruits and books, are adorned with all types of jewelry, and wear an upper garment and short trousers of fine silk. “Above them should be painted the eight pratyekabuddhas, attired in monks’ garb. Their robes are red ocher and their bodies possess the marks of a great being. They sit cross-legged on seats of jeweled lotuses in serene absorption,[575] surrounded by halos of blazing light. While painting the picture, one should strew the cloth with fragrant flowers such as royal jasmine, Arabian jasmine, dhānuṣkārikā jasmine, blossoms of the pannay tree and ironwood tree, and so forth.

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i g.yon phyogs su 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi steng du rin po che du mas nye bar spras pa/ shin tu yangs pa'i gzhal med khang gi dkyil 'khor brag gi tshogs kyis shin tu nye bar mdzes par byas pa/ rin po che'i ut+pa las shin tu bkab pa ri'i rnam pa lta bu bri bar bya'o/ / gnas der sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das brgyad bri bar bya ste/ 'di lta ste rin chen gtsug tor can rin po che bai DUr+ya'i 'od rnam par 'phro ba/ kun nas 'od 'dom gang ba/ rin po che pad+ma rA ga dang in+d+ra nI la dang / margad la sogs pa dang / bai DUr+ya dang asma gar b+ha la sogs pa nor bu rin po che chen po'i bye brag kun nas 'od 'phro ba dang ldan pa nyi ma 'char ka'i mdog 'dra ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku lhung bzed dang chos gos dang bla gos dang ldan pa/ skyil krung gis bzhugs shing chos 'chad pa/ na bza' ser po mnabs pa/ skyes bu chen po'i mtshan gyis sku la khyab pa/ dpe byad bzang po brgyad cus sku nye bar mdzes pa/ zhi ba'i gzigs pa dang ldan pa/ rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen gtsug tor can bri bar bya'o/ /

“To the left of Lord Śākyamuni and above Noble Mañjuśrī one should paint a lofty palatial maṇḍala, decorated with many gems and adorned with the king of mountains.[576] It has the shape of a mountain entirely covered with precious stones.[577] There one should paint the eight blessed buddhas, as listed below. “The first, Ratnaśikhin, should be painted adorned with jewels the color of beryl and with an aura of light extending one fathom all around him. He shines in all directions with the glow of many exquisite jewels, such as rubies, sapphires, emeralds, beryls, and so forth. His body of a tathāgata has the soft color of the rising sun. He wears the yellow robes and upper garment of a monk, sits in the cross-legged posture, and expounds the Dharma. His outer garment is yellow. His body is armored with the thirty-two marks of a great being and is also adorned with the eighty minor marks. He is of peaceful appearance and in all aspects excellent. Thus should Tathāgata Ratnaśikhin be depicted.

gnyis pa de bzhin gshegs pa me tog yang dag par skyes pa'i dbang po'i rgyal po kha dog gser 'dra ba bri bar bya'o/ / gsum pa pad+ma'i gtsug tor pad+ma'i ge sar dang 'dra ba chos 'chad pa bri bar bya'o/ / bzhi pa spyan bzang po yang bri bar bya'o/ / lnga pa bsnyen par dka' ba dang / drug pa rgyal ba rnam par snang mdzad dang / bdun pa sman gyi bla bai DUr+ya'i 'od kyi rgyal po dang / brgyad pa de bzhin gshegs pa sdug bsngal thams cad zhi bar byed pa'i spyan gyi rgyal po bri bar bya'o/ / 'di dag thams cad kyang gser gyi mdog can de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku'i gzugs su bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pa de dag gi steng gi phyogs su g.yas g.yon nas sprin gyi gseb nas gnas gtsang ma'i lha'i bu gnyis lus mi snang bar me tog gi char 'bebs pa bri bar bya ste/ bar snang la gnas nas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas dang 'phags pa nyan thos rnams la phyag 'tshal ba bri bar bya'o/ / rang sangs rgyas thams cad kyi 'og tu nyan thos chen po brgyad byang chub sems dpa'i mgo la 'dug pa spangs te bri bar bya ba la 'di lta ste/ gnas brtan shA ri'i bu dang maud gal gyi bu chen po dang 'od srung chen po dang / rab 'byor dang sgra gcan 'dzin dang / dga' bo dang bzang ldan dang / ka pi na'o/ / rang sangs rgyas dag kyang 'di lta ste/ spos kyi ngad ldang dang dman pa dang nye ba'i 'chi ltas dang / dkar po dang dkar po'i tog dang / mu khyud dang mu khyud bzang po'o/ / 'di dag thams cad kyang shin tu mdzes pa/ zhi ba'i cha byad kyi bdag nyid can shin tu dul ba'i cha byad can no/ / nyan thos chen po dag kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la lta ba'o/ /

“The second, Tathāgata Saṃkusumitarājendra, should be painted in golden color and richly bestrewn with flowers, such as the blossoms of the ironwood tree, bulletwood tree, and so forth. His gaze is directed at Noble Mañjuśrī. He is surrounded with light that forms a halo sparkling with the colors of precious jewels.[578] “Tathāgata Śālendrarāja[579] should be painted as the third. He is of the color of lotus filaments and is expounding the Dharma. The fourth to be painted is Tathāgata Sunetra; the fifth is Duḥprasaha; the sixth is Vairocana, the Victorious One; the seventh, Bhaiṣajyavaidūryarāja; and the eighth, Tathāgata Rājendra, the pacifier of all suffering.[580] All of them should be depicted endowed with tathāgata forms of golden color, displaying the hand gesture of granting fearlessness. “Two gods from the realm of the Pure Abode should be painted among the clouds above the tathāgatas, each in an upper corner of the canvas. They should be depicted releasing a rain of flowers. Standing in the midst of space, they salute all the buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, and the noble śrāvakas. “Beneath[581] the pratyekabuddhas should be painted the eight great śrāvakas, seated separately near the bodhisattvas’ heads. They are Elder Śāriputra, Mahāmaudgalyāyana, Mahākāśyapa, Subhūti, Rāhula, Nanda, Bhadrika, and Kaphiṇa. “The eight pratyekabuddhas are Gandhamādana, Candana,[582] Upariṣṭa, Śveta, Sita, Ketu,[583] Nemi, and Sunemi. All of them are beautiful, serene, and self-controlled. They and the great śrāvakas fold their hands in reverence, looking at the blessed Buddha Śākyamuni.

steng du gnas gtsang ma'i lha'i bu gzhan gnyis nye bar kun nas gos kyi bla re chu zhing yangs pa shin tu mdzes pa 'dzin cing sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas dang 'phags pa nyan thos rnams kyi steng du lha'i gos dang phreng ba 'dzin pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“Above them should be painted two more gods, near to the other two gods of the Pure Abode. They hold a long, elegant canopy of fine cloth, spreading it above all the buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, and noble śrāvakas. They should be depicted wearing celestial garlands and clothes.

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i steng dbu'i steng du mu tig gi phreng ba dang / thag gu dmar po pad+ma rA ga dang / in+d+ra nI la la sogs pa'i mdud pa byas pa rin po che'i thag gu'i tshogs bya'o/ / de la yang gos kyi bla re shin tu legs par kun nas bkod pa dang / mu tig gi phreng ba 'phyang bas mdzes pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“Above the head of Lord Śākyamuni one should paint a bundle of jeweled threads, including strings of pearls, gems, rubies, sapphires, and so forth. On this bundle, there should be a well-arrayed canopy of silk, decorated all around with hanging strings of pearls.

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi 'og tu ni pad+ma'i mtsho las 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi zhabs drung dang nye ba na/ klu'i rgyal po nye dga'i phyogs su rin po che chen po'i ri bo pad+ma'i mtsho las mngon par 'thon pa rin po che'i myu gu dang phug dang ri sul dang byi ru'i yal ga dang rin po che'i shing gis yongs su bskor ba/ drang srong chen po'i gnas dang grub pa dag gis de la brten pa/ ri'i rtse mo'i steng du khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed shin tu mi bzad pa'i gzugs can/ lag pa g.yas pa na zhags pa thogs pa/ lag pa g.yon pa na gzhu thogs pa/ bzhin khro gnyer dang ldan pa/ bka' nyan cing 'phags pa 'jam dpal la phyogs te lta ba gsus pa 'phyang ba/ skra gyen du brdzes pa/ mig sman nag po dang sprin nag po dang 'dra ba/ kha spu ser ba sen mo ring ba mig dmar ba/ mgul ba'i phyogs sbrul gyis brgyan pa/ stag gi pags pa mnabs pa bgegs thams cad rnam par 'joms par byed pa rab tu mi bzad pa chen po khro bo'i rgyal po chen po kun nas 'bar ba khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje'i gshed bri bar bya'o/ /

“Below the lotus seat of Lord Śākyamuni, near the base of Noble Mañjuśrī’s feet and to the side of Upananda, the king of nāgas, one should paint a great jewel mountain, rising up from a lotus lake. The mountain is overgrown with jeweled sprouts, vines of coral, and jeweled trees; it abounds in gorges and hidden caves and is frequented by great sages and siddhas. “On the mountain’s summit one should paint Yamāntaka, Lord of Wrath, most terrible in form, holding a noose in his right hand and a staff[584] in his left. He knits his brow and looks at Noble Mañjuśrī, awaiting orders. He has a ‘wolf’s belly’[585] and upwardly flowing hair. His body color is that of collyrium or a dark cloud. He has a reddish beard, prominent fangs, long nails, and red eyes.[586] He is adorned with snakes coiling around his neck and clothed in tiger skin. Extremely fierce, he destroys all obstacles. One should thus paint Yamāntaka, Lord of Great Wrath, with flames blazing all around him.

ri de'i 'og tu rdo'i steng na 'dug pa/ lus sa la btud de spos kyi snod lag na thogs pa/ cha byad dang dbyibs ci lta ba bzhin rtags 'dzin pa/ ji ltar rjes su mthun pa'i spyod pa dang / 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rjes su lta ba'i sgrub pa po bri bar bya'o/ /

“Below this mountain, one should paint the practitioner sitting on a slab of stone, with his knees touching the ground, and with an incense censer in his hand. He holds the emblems consistent with his dress and form and acts in the attitude of obedience. He should be depicted with his gaze directed at Noble Mañjuśrī.

klu'i rgyal po dga' bo dang nye bar bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i 'og de'i g.yas ngos su pad+ma'i mtsho las mngon par byung ba'i rin po che'i ri'i rgyal po/ ji ltar sngar ri'i rgyal por bstan pa de bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje'i gshed med pa lha'i me tog gis khyab pa bri bar bya'o/ / ri de yang 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi 'og tu bri'o/ / ri de yang shin tu mtho ba rin po che pad+ma rA ga'i them skas 'dra ba/ bai DUr+ya'i rang bzhin rtse mo myu gu 'dra ba bri bar bya'o/ / de la brten pa'i lha mo 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi thugs rje'i ngo bo 'phags ma sgrol ma rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ dar la dmar pos stod g.yogs byas pa kha dog rnam pa sna tshogs dang ldan pa'i gos can/ bud med kyi rgyan thams cad kyis lus brgyan pa/ lag pa g.yon pa na ut+pa la thogs pa/ gser gyi kha dog can rked pa phra ba ha cang yang mi skem ha cang yang mi sbom ha cang yang mi rgan/ sems bsam gtan la zhugs pa/ bka' nyan cing 'dug pa/ lag pa g.yas pa mchog sbyin pa/ cung zad gdong dang lus 'dud pa/ skyil krung gis 'dug pa/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la cung zad lta zhing 'dug pa/ kun nas 'bar ba'i 'od kyi phreng bas yongs su bskor ba/ der yang bai DUr+ya rin po che'i rtse mo la shing pun+n+nA ga'i yal gas kun nas bskor ba/ yal ga dag la yang me tog 'phel zhing kha bye bas legs par rgyas pas bcom ldan 'das ma sgrol ma mngon par bkab pa/ yal ga mngon par 'dud pa de nyid kyang shin tu kha dog sna tshogs pa byi ru'i myu gu'i 'brel ba rnam pa sna tshogs kyi ngo bo'i tshon 'bar ba na/ lha mo sgrol ma mngon du phyogs shing lta ba bri bar bya'o/ /

“Near Nanda, the king of nāgas, and off to the right below Lord Śākyamuni, one should paint the great jewel king of mountains[587] rising from a lotus lake, as previously described.[588] This time one should paint it without Yamāntaka, Lord of Wrath; also it should be bestrewn with celestial flowers and located below the noble Avalokiteśvara.[589] This tall and lofty mountain should be painted as made of ruby, with a single summit made of beryl in the shape of a sprout.[590] “Resting there should be painted the goddess who is the compassion of the noble Avalokiteśvara embodied‍—the noble Tārā. She is adorned with all types of jewelry and wears a red bodice and brightly colored silken garments. Her whole body is adorned with feminine adornments. In her left hand she holds a blue lotus. Her body color is golden and her waist slim, but not overly so. She is neither too young nor too old.[591] Her mind is absorbed in meditation, and she is awaiting an order. Her body is slightly bent forward with her right hand displaying the boon-granting gesture, and so forth. She sits in a cross-legged posture, turning her gaze slightly toward[592] Avalokiteśvara. She is surrounded by a halo of blazing light. “There, on the jeweled peak made of beryl, completely enclosed and shaded by a pannay tree whose branches are all covered in flowers with buds fully open, is the blessed Tārā. The tree’s overspread branches are bent down with fresh sprouts, in a variety of shapes, bright and colorful. The goddess Tārā should be painted looking ahead.

lha mo bgegs rnams ma lus 'joms/ / 'jigs pa sel bar byed pa'i mchog / sgrub pa po ni srung don du/ / des ni dam pa sbyin zhing dge/ / stobs bcu ldan sras thugs rje ni/ / bud med gzugs 'chang lha mo yin/ / 'byung po kun gyi dpal don dang / / mchog sbyin byed pa bri bar bya/ /

“The goddess removes all obstacles And is the ultimate destroyer of fear. For the protection of the practitioner, She should be painted as the virtuous granter of boons. “The goddess takes the female form And arises, along with her ten powers, from compassion. She should be painted granting the boon Of good fortune to all beings.

'jam pa'i dbyangs can 'od chen ni/ / gzhon nu'ang lha mo 'di la dgyes/ / bgegs rnams thams cad bsal ba'i phyir/ / sgrub pa pos kyang yang dag bkur/ / mi yi bdag po srung don dang / / dpal sgrub phyir yang ri mo bri/ /

“The goddess is the mother of the divine youth‍— Mañjughoṣa of great splendor. In order to completely remove The practitioner’s every obstacle,[593] “To ensure protection by the rulers of men, And to bring prosperity, she should be installed on the canvas.[594]

khro bo'i rgyal po gang yin te/ / ri yi rtse mor gzhag bris pa/ / bgegs rnams thams cad gzhig pa'i phyir/ / rgyal ba mchog dang sras kyis gsungs/ / mi bzad chen po 'khyil ba che/ / gtum chen 'od chen ldan pa po/ / ma rungs sems can tshar gcad phyir/ / sgrub pa la ni rab tu brtags/ / sgrub pa po ni srung ba dang / / bgegs rnams thams cad sel bar byed/ / mi bzad khro bo'i ngang tshul can/ / sngags kyi lha dag 'gugs par byed/ /

The supreme Lord of Wrath, Situated at the top of his mountain,[595] “Has been taught by the most excellent Victor and his sons For the sake of destroying all obstacles. Very terrifying, most venerable,[596] Very fierce, and of great splendor, “He is primed for restraining beings Who are hostile to the teachings. For the practitioner, however, He is a remover of all obstacles. “Violent and of a wrathful disposition, He is the mantra deity to be summoned.[597]

shin tu mi bzad drag po'i gzugs/ / brtse ba med pa thams cad 'dul/ / sdig dang drag por spyod pa rnams/ / dbang du mi 'gyur dbang du byed/ / mkha' spyod sa la spyod pa dang / / sa 'og spyod pa thams cad kyi/ / thub pa'i bstan la 'gal byed gang / / ma rungs thams cad 'dul bar byed/ / ras ni kun nas gru bzhi dang / / zur bzhi dag tu bri ba yin/ / ras kyi 'og tu tha mar ni/ / chu bo rgya che'i gnas bya ste/ / klu yi gdengs ka yan lag can/ / gcig ni kun du bya ba yin/ / yan lag bzang po dkar po dang / / lus phyed mi yi rnam par skyes/ / byang du mgo ni gzhag bya ste/ / rtag tu thal mo sbyar byed pa/ /

Most terrible and frightening, He wards off all who are cruel. “He brings under control the unsubmissive Who commit evil and violent acts, Whether they dwell in the sky, on earth, In subterranean realms, or anywhere else. “He destroys all evildoers Who oppose the teachings of the Sage. Thus one should paint the cloth Four sided, with four corners. “At the bottom edge of the cloth, There is an area with rivers. Throughout it one should paint nāgas, one by one, With their distinctive hoods expanded. “Their pure, white bodies Are half human in form. Raising up their torsos, Their hands are folded in constant reverence.

stobs chen gdengs ka bdun dang ldan/ / mtha' yas zhes ni bya ba yin/ / de bzhin gshegs la nges par lta/ / nor bu rin chen gyis mdzes pa/ / legs par mdzes dang gzugs mdzes dang / / rin chen rgyan gyis yongs brgyan pa'i/ / 'bar ba'i phreng can bri ba ni/ / klu rgyal chen por rnam par grags/ / 'jig rten kun la phan par brtson/ / sangs rgyas bstan la rab tu zhugs/ / bgegs rnams thams cad rnam gzhig phyir/ / chu bo la brten bri bar bya/ / ras kyi cho ga dam pa 'di/ / rgyal ba rnams kyis gsungs pa yin/ / de bzhin gshegs pas sngon gsungs pa/ / rgyas bstan ngas ni mdor bsdus yin/ / mkhas pa gang zhig 'dri byed pa/ / de yi bsod nams mtha' yas 'gyur/ /

“One with seven hoods, of great valor, Ananta by name, is referred to as ‘great lord.’[598] Adorned with jewels and gems, He directs his gaze at Tathāgata Śākyamuni. “Of very beautiful and charming form, He is adorned with jewel ornaments. Known as the great king of nāgas, He should be painted with a garland of blazing light. “He exerts himself for the good of the entire world, Fully engaged in applying the teachings of the Sage In order to remove all obstacles. One should paint him as dwelling in a river. “This is the supreme painting procedure That was taught by the victorious ones. It has been taught before in brief and at length By the tathāgatas. “Any wise person who paints it Will gain infinite merit.

bskal pa bye bar byas pa yi/ / sdig pa shin tu mi bzad pa/ / sa steng ri mo mthong ba tsam/ / de yi mod la 'byang bar byed/ / mtshams med lnga po byed pa dang / / tshul khrims nyams dang smad pa dang / / sdig pa kun la 'jug pa dang / / 'khor ba'i mun par spyod pa dang / / 'gro ba'i skye gnas ngan pa dag / der ni ras ris gzhag mi bya/ / ras ris mthong ba'ang don ldan zhes/ / thub pa'i dbang pos gsungs pa yin/ / mthong ba tsam gyis dag 'gyur te/ / de bas skad cig de tsam gyis/ / yid dag lus ni dag 'jug dang / / rjes su bzlas pa byed pa dang / / sngags rten nyid la rtag brtson pa'i/ / mi rnams grub 'dod smos ci dgos/ /

The bad and dreaded karma Accumulated over millions of eons “Will be annihilated the very moment One beholds this painting here on earth. Therefore, one must not withhold this painting[599] From those who have committed the five acts of immediate retribution “Or who are undisciplined or detestable, Who commit all kinds of evil acts While lost in the darkness of saṃsāra And dragged from birth to birth. “Simply beholding the painting will bear fruit for them‍— So it was taught by the lords of sages. As soon as they see it, that very moment They will be freed from their evil. “What need then to speak of those who maintain purity In their body and in their speech, Who perform their recitations And are diligent in relying on mantra?[600]

bskal pa bye bar sangs rgyas la/ / mchod pa'i bsod nams gang yin pa/ / sa steng ras ris 'dri ba yi/ / sngags pas bsod nams de 'thob 'gyur/ / gang gA yi ni bye ma dag / tshad du bstan pa gang yin pa/ / de dang mnyam pa'i sangs rgyas dang / / rang rgyal dang ni byang chub sems/ / bse ru nyan thos 'jig rten na/ / lan mang dag tu mchod ston byas/ / ras ris mthong ba tsam gyis ni/ / mi yis de bzhin bsod nams 'thob/ / cho ga klog pa tsam dang ni/ / mchod dang rjes su yi rang ba/ / cho ga thams cad rab brtags pa/ / de la sngags kyi dngos grub des/ / 'jig rten sngags rnams ci snyed pa/ / gang dag rgyal ba skyes mchog dang / / de'i slob bse ru byang chub sems/ / bdag nyid chen pos gang gsungs pa/ / ri mo 'di ni mdun bzhag na/ / sngags rnams ma lus grub par 'gyur/ /

“The merit that has been accumulated by the totality of beings Through religious worship over a million eons[601] Will be obtained by a practitioner of mantra Who does this painting here on earth. “Buddhas‍—including the pratyekabuddhas And the foremost sons of the victorious ones‍— Will come in numbers equal to the grains of sand in the Gaṅgā, Whatever their number is said to be. “Merely upon seeing this painting A person will gain the same merit As those pratyekabuddhas and śrāvakas of the world Who make large numbers of offerings. “Whoever simply describes it, Makes offerings to it, or rejoices in it Will certainly accomplish the mantras That are employed in every rite. “Whatever worldly mantras have been taught By the victorious ones, the most excellent of men, Or their pupils, the śrāvakas, or the pratyekabuddhas, Or the divine bodhisattvas, the great beings, All these mantras will be accomplished In front of this foremost of all paintings.”
