Chapter 5
de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor la gzigs nas/
Now, Lord Śākyamuni, looking at the entire assembly, spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth:
'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ gzhan yang khyod kyi 'bring gi ras kyi cho ga de ngas bshad par bya yis/ legs par rab tu nyon la yid la zung shig /
“There is, Mañjuśrī, yet another procedure from your ritual of cloth painting‍—the medium one. I will teach it now, so listen well and duly reflect upon it.

dang por re zhig sngar bstan pa'i dog pa dang / sngar bstan pa'i cho ga dang / sngar bstan pa'i bzo bo dang sngar gyi tshad bar ma dang ldan pa/ ras shin tu bzang ba dang 'jam pa dang shin tu bkrus pa kha tshar dang bcas pa dang / tshon ma 'dres pa dang skra la sogs pa med par byas la/ tshad ma gtogs pa dang po ci lta ba de bzhin du byas pa'i ras de la phyi nas bri bar bya ste/ dang por re zhig gnas gtsang ma kun nas mdzes pa/ rin po che shel gyi rang bzhin lta bu mu tig dkar pos brgyan pa/ de'i dbus su bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa bri bar bya ste/ rin po che'i seng ge'i khri la rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa chos 'chad cing bzhugs pa'o/ /

“First, to produce the medium painting, thread should be used as previously described, following the same procedure as before. The work should be done by craftsmen who have been trained beforehand, applying the same measurements as the previous cloth. Just as before, the cloth should be of excellent quality, white, tightly woven, and thoroughly clean[602] and have fringe tassels.[603] The painting should then be executed using uncontaminated paints free of hairs, dust, or other debris, with everything done just as before, except for the sizes and forms of the painted figures. “First one should paint the realm of the Pure Abode, its form beautiful in every respect, abounding in things made of jewels, and adorned with garlands of white pearls. Portrayed in the middle should be Lord Śākyamuni, sitting on the lion throne expounding the Dharma and excellent in every aspect.

g.yas phyogs na 'phags pa 'jam dpal pad+ma'i ge sar ram/ gur gum mam/ nyi ma'i mdog 'dra ba g.yon pa'i dpung pa'i phyogs su ut+pal bsnams shing thal mo sbyar bas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la blta ba/ bzhin cung zad rgod pa gzhon nu'i gzugs can/ zur phud lngas mgo mdzes par byas pa/ byis pa gzhon nu'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa/ pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga dang mgo 'dud pa'o/ /

“To his right is Noble Mañjuśrī, the color of lotus filaments, saffron, or the sun, with a blue lotus near his left shoulder. With the palms of his hands folded in reverence, he looks toward Lord Śākyamuni. He has the form of a divine youth, with a gentle smile on his face, and his head is adorned with a crown of five decorative locks of hair. He is ornamented with the adornments of a young boy and inclines his head toward his right knee.

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i g.yon logs su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug ston ka'i zla ba'i mdog ltar dkar ba/ snga ma ci lta ba de bzhin du bri bar bya ste/ 'on kyang bcom ldan 'das la rnga yab g.yob par bya'o/ / de'i phyogs su 'phags pa byams pa dang / kun du bzang po dang phyag na rdo rje dang / blo gros chen po dang zhi bar gshegs pa dang nam mkha' mdzod dang / sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sel ba ste/ 'di dag kyang snga ma bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / dang po ci lta ba de bzhin du rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan par bri bar bya'o/ / 'di dag gi steng du sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das brgyad bri bar bya ste/ bzhengs pa dang lag pa g.yas pas mchog sbyin pa dang / sku la na bza' ser pos stod g.yogs byas pa/ lag pa g.yon pas chos gos kyi dkyil nas 'dzin pa/ chos gos kyi kha dog cung zad dmar ba mnabs pa/ kun nas 'od dang ldan pa rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa la 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa me tog yang dag par skyes pa'i rgyal po'i dbang po dang / rin chen gtsug tor dang / gtsug tor can dang / thams cad skyob dang / log par dad sel dang / gser thub dang / 'od srung dang / spyan bzang ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag bri bar bya'o/ /

“To the left of Lord Śākyamuni is the noble Avalokiteśvara, white as the autumn moon and painted just as he was described before, but this time fanning the Blessed One with a yak-tail whisk. To his left, arranged one next to the other, are the noble Maitreya, Vajrapāṇi, Mahāmati, Śāntamati, Gaganagañja, and Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin. They should be painted as before and adorned with all kinds of jewelry. “Situated above them the eight blessed buddhas should be painted in a standing position, displaying the boon-granting gesture with their right hands, their bodies covered in the yellow robes of a monk and an upper cloak. With their left hands they hold the corner of their robes. The well-fitting robes are yellowish with a slightly red hue. They are surrounded with halos of light and are excellent in every aspect. The blessed buddhas that should be portrayed are the tathāgatas Saṃkusumitarājendra, Ratnaśikhin, Śikhin, Viśvabhuk, Krakucchanda, Bakagrīvin, Kāśyapa, and Sunetra.

bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yas phyogs su 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi mdun du 'khor chen po'i dkyil 'khor bri bar bya ste/ nyan thos chen po brgyad dang / rang sangs rgyas brgyad snga ma ci lta ba de bzhin du bri ste/ 'on kyang 'phags pa maud gal gyi bu chen po dang / shA ri'i bu ni bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la rnga yab kyis g.yob pa 'greng bag tu bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu bri bar bya'o/ / lha rnams kyi dbang po brgya byin dang 'thab bral dang dga' ldan dang 'phrul dga' dang dag pa dang / dri ma med pa dang 'jam pa dang mi gdung ba dang 'od gsal dang / tshangs pa mi mjed kyi bdag po dang 'og min dang de la sogs pa'i lha'i bu gzugs na spyod pa dang / 'dod pa na spyod pa'i lha'i bu dag mthar gyis bri bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal dang nye bar 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor legs par dgod par bya ste/ rang rang gi gzugs dang cha byad du bri bar bya'o/ /

“To the right of the Blessed One and near Noble Mañjuśrī should be depicted the great assembly. The eight great śrāvakas and eight pratyekabuddhas should be painted exactly as before, except that the noble Mahāmaudgalyāyana and Śāriputra are standing up and fanning Lord Śākyamuni with a yak-tail whisk. “The gods from the realm of the Pure Abode, Śakra, the lord of gods, and Suyāma, as well as the gods from the heavens of Tuṣita, Sunirmita, Śuddha, Vimala, Sudṛśa, Atapas, and Ābhāsvara should also be included. In addition, Brahmā Sahāmpati and the gods from the Akaniṣṭha heaven should be included. These and other gods who dwell in the realm of form and the realm of desire should be painted arranged in sequence, near to Noble Mañjuśrī. They should be painted arranged in tiers above the assembly with their respective features and dress.

bcom ldan 'das kyi seng ge'i khri'i 'og tu ni/ rgya mtsho chen po las mngon par byung ba'i kun nas rin po che'i ri bo ras kyi mtha' mar bri bar bya'o/ / ras ris kyi phyogs gcig gi mtha' la sgrub pa po cha byad dang dbyibs ci lta bu'i rnam pa pus mo'i lha nga dang mgo btud pa/ spos snod lag na thogs pa bri bar bya'o/ / rin po che'i ri bo de'i steng 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi 'og tu khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje'i gshed ci ltar bstan pa de ltar bri bar bya'o/ /

“Below the lion throne of the Blessed One, a great mountain should be painted rising from a great ocean and extending up to the edges of the canvas. In one corner of the canvas should be depicted the practitioner in the same form and dress as in real life. He should be depicted with his head inclined toward his knees and holding an incense holder in his hand. On the same jewel mountain, below Noble Mañjuśrī, is Yamāntaka, Lord of Wrath. He should be painted as previously described.

bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yon phyogs seng ge'i khri'i 'og tu 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi zhabs drung dang nye ba der/ rin po che'i ri bo'i steng du lha mo sgrol ma sngar ci ltar bstan pa de bzhin du bri bar bya ste/ ras ris de'i kho ra khor yug tu me tog gtor ba bri bar byas la gcal bkram par bya ba la me tog tsam pa ka dang nI lod pa la pad+ma dang dri mchog dang mA la ti dang / bAr shi ka dang d+hA nu Sh+kA ri ka dang pun nA ga dang / nA ga ge sar la sogs pa'i me tog gis ras ris de la kho ra khor yug tu gtor bar bya'o/ / ras ris kyi steng gi mtha'i zur gnyis su lha'i bu gnyis me tog gi tshogs 'thor ba/ gzugs rnam par bkra ba bar snang la gnas pa/ char 'byin pa'i sprin gyi nang nas mgo tsam 'thon pa lding bzhin pa/ kha dog dkar po bri bar bya'o/ /

“To the left of the Blessed One, below his lion throne, and near to the soles of the noble Avalokiteśvara’s feet, the Goddess Tārā should be painted sitting on that jewel mountain. She should be depicted exactly as previously described. The canvas should be strewn all over with flowers, such as champak, fragrant blue lotus, royal jasmine, Arabian jasmine, dhānuṣkārīka jasmine, and blossoms of the pannay tree, ironwood tree, and so forth. “And above, in the upper two corners, two gods should be painted releasing a great flood of flowers. They each have variegated, bright forms and rest within rain clouds in the midst of space. They should be depicted as white and flying.

ras ris 'bring du gsungs pa 'di/ / dpal don gnyer la yang dag 'byung / / sa yi steng gi mi rnams la/ / grub pa 'bring ni 'di la brten/ / 'khor bar sngon chad 'khor ba na/ / sdig pa cung zad gang byas pa/ / 'dir ni ras ris mthong tsam gyis/ / de yi mod la rnam par 'jig / 'gro ba lngar ni 'khor ba na/ / sems can rmongs pas mi shes te/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyi ras ris ni/ / 'bring po mthong bar mi byed pa'o/ / mtshams med lnga po byed pa dang / / sdig pa'i rnyog pa byed gyur pa/ / sngags rnams sna tshogs gsungs gyur pas/ / tshul khrims nyams pa'ang 'grub par 'gyur/ / myur du rtogs pa'ang 'grub pa ni/ / bzlas pas thob par byed pa yin/ / ras ris 'bring po mthong bas ni/ / nad pa dag kyang nad las thar/ / dbul po dag kyang nor thob byed/ / bud med rnams kyang bu 'thob 'gyur/ / de tshe mthong ba tsam gyis ni/ / bsod nams rgya chen thob par 'gyur/ / nges par lha dang mi rnams kyi/ / bde ba mi yis bsten par 'gyur/ / skye ba gzhan du nges par ni/ / sangs rgyas nyid ni nges thob 'gyur/ / klog dang 'dri ba nyid dang ni/ / de bzhin mchod dang phyag 'tshal dang / / mthong dang reg pa tsam gyis ni/ / sdig pa'i rnyog pa kun las grol/ / ras ris 'di ni mthu chen la/ / don du gnyer dang bskul bas ni/ / myur du skye ba don yod 'thob/ / rjes su yi rang de bzhin no/ / ras ris mthong ba'i skye bo yi/ / bsod nams thob pa don yod pa/ / bskal pa bye ba rnams su yang / / brjod par yang ni mi nus so/ /

“This painting, which is called ‘medium,’ Is produced for the sake of good fortune. For people here on earth It brings middling accomplishments. “Any bad karma previously accumulated By one wandering in saṃsāra Will be destroyed instantly Through merely seeing this painting in this life. “Circling throughout the five destinies, Deluded people do not know this. Those, however, who have seen This painting of Mañjughoṣa in its medium version,[604] “Even if they commit offenses Such as the five acts of immediate retribution, Even if they lack morality, they will succeed At the various mantras that have been taught. “Having done their recitation They will swiftly gain accomplishment.[605] The sick will be freed from their illness, The poor will obtain wealth, The childless will obtain sons[606] When they behold the medium painting. “As soon as they see it, They will obtain merit great and vast. Such a person will certainly come to partake In the happiness of gods and humans And will definitely attain buddhahood At the end of this birth.[607] “Through merely drawing or describing it, Likewise through worshiping it, making copies of it,[608] Viewing it, or touching it, One will be freed from all negativity. “So also, through requesting this painting of great splendor, Or requesting the instructions thereof, One will obtain a fruitful life And swiftly win happiness. “It is not possible to express in words, Not even in millions of infinite eons, The merit and its results one would obtain Through merely seeing this painting.”

ras ris chung ngu gsum pa'i cho ga
Chapter 6

de nas gzhan yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa gzhan yang khyod kyis ras ris gsum pa'i cho ga rab tu gsungs pa zhes bya ba yod de/ gang sems can rnams la 'bad pa med par 'grub par 'gyur ba sngar bstan pa'i bzo bo dang / cho ga dang bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho gang tsam thad kar de bzhin du kun nas zur bzhi snga ma bzhin du ras la ri mo bya'o/ /

Now, Lord Śākyamuni again addressed Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “There is, Mañjuśrī, yet another secret[609] cloth-painting procedure,[610] a third type, referred to as ‘smallest,’[611] by the means of which all beings can effortlessly win accomplishment. “Following the procedures as previously described, skilled craftsmen should prepare a cloth one width of the Buddha’s hand across that is in the same four-sided shape as before. The painting should then be done with the paints as previously described.

sngar bstan pa'i tshon gyis dang por re zhig 'phags pa 'jam dpal seng ge'i khri la bzhugs pa snga ma bzhin du byis pa khye'u'i gzugs mdzes pa'i gzugs can 'od zer 'phro ba dang ldan pa chos 'chad pa bri bar bya'o/ / g.yon gyi phyogs su 'phags pa kun du bzang po rin po che'i ri la gnas pa/ rnga yab lag na thogs pa lag pa g.yon pa na nor bu rin po che thogs pa/ me tog pri yang ku ltar sngo sangs snga ma bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi g.yas phyogs su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug snga ma bzhin rin po che'i ri la gnas pa/ rnga yab lag na thogs pa lag pa g.yon pa na pad+ma 'dzin pa/ lus kun nas 'od dang ldan pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“First one should paint Noble Mañjuśrī, sitting on a lion throne with the form, as before, of a young boy expounding the Dharma. He should be painted as having a charming form that radiates light. To his left, the noble Samantabhadra stands on a dais of precious stone, with his right hand extended forth holding a yak-tail whisk and his left hand holding a wish-fulfilling gem. As before, he should be painted in the dark blue color of the beautyberry flower. To the right of Noble Mañjuśrī stands the noble Avalokiteśvara on a dais of precious stone.[612] As before, he has a yak-tail whisk in his [right] hand and a lotus[613] in his left. He should be drawn with his form haloed in blazing light.

seng ge'i khri'i 'og tu rin po che'i ras ris kyi mtha'i bar du bri bar bya'o/ / ras kyi mtha' ma dang nye ba'i zur du 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi seng ge'i khri'i 'og g.yas phyogs su khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed snga ma bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / de'i 'og tu sgrub pa po snga ma bzhin du bri bar bya ste/ spos snod lag na thogs pa thams cad kyang snga ma ji lta ba bzhin du bya'o/ /

“Below Mañjuśrī’s lion throne should be painted a golden-colored mountain, extending down to the edge of the canvas. In the corner at the edge of the canvas, below the lion throne of Noble Mañjuśrī and to his right, Yamāntaka, the Lord of Wrath, should be painted with the same details as before. The practitioner should be painted[614] as before, holding an incense holder.

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi steng du de bzhin gshegs pa me tog yang dag par skyes pa'i dbang po'i rgyal po bri bar bya ste/ rin po che'i ri'i phug sor bcu drug gi tshad tsam gyi nang na bzhugs pa/ ri'i stod kyi cha khang pa brtsegs pa 'dra ba bri bar bya'o/ / ras ris kyi kho ra khor yug tu ri'i rnam pas yongs su 'khor ba bri bar bya'o/ / steng gi ras kyi mtha' gnyis la gnas pa'i ri'i stod kyi cha la lding ba bzhin du me tog gi tshogs 'thor ba'i gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu dag pa dang rnam par dag pa zhes bya ba gnyis snga ma bzhin du bri bar bya zhing / / ras la me tog rnam pa sna tshogs kyi gcal bkram pa yang bri bar bya'o/ /

“Above Noble Mañjuśrī should be painted Tathāgata Saṃkusumitarājendra, sixteen fingers tall, sheltering in a cave on a jeweled mountain. Its ten peaks should be drawn to resemble palaces.[615] Around the perimeter of the cloth one should draw a ring of mountains.[616] Above, perched on the front slopes of the mountains located in the two upper corners of the cloth, are two divine sons from the realm of the Pure Abode, named Śuddha and Viśuddha, who scatter heaps of flowers that float in arrays. They should be painted [with the same details] as before.[617] The painting should be drawn with various flowers placed all around it.

rnam gsum ras ris mtshan nyid ni/ / thams cad 'dir ni bstan pa las/ / 'di ni tha ma zhes bya ste/ / phran tshegs las rnams dag la shes/ / bskal pa bye bar mi bzad las/ / ras ris mthong ba tsam gyis grol/ / ras ris mthong ba tsam gyis ni/ / skad cig de la grol bar 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas bye ba stong phrag ni/ / mthong ba tsam gyis grol 'gyur te/ / ras ris mthong ba tsam gyis kyang / / de yi mod la grol bar 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas bye ba stong phrag la/ / blo dang ldan pas bsnyen bkur bas/ / ras ris tha ma mthong ba ni/ / bcu drug char yang mi phod do/ / sangs rgyas skyob pa kun la ni/ / mchod byas bsod nams gang yin pa/ / mkhas pas bsod nams gang thob de/ / ras ris mtha' ma mthong ba'i yin/ / dge ba dag gi las rnams la/ / longs spyod phyir yang 'dir spyad do/ / sngags rnams gang dag ci yod pa/ / tshangs dbang drang srong gis bshad dang / / nam mkha' lding gis gang bshad dang / / chu lha nyi ma lus ngan dang / / nor sbyin sogs dang srin po dang / / lha min dbang po lto 'phye dang / / zla ba rlung dang gshin rje sogs/ / khyab 'jug lha chen sogs bshad pa/ / sngags rnams 'dir ni bkug pa dag / ras ris mdun du dngos grub 'gyur/ / 'dir ni zhi ba bya ba ste/ / de bzhin du ni rgyas pa bya/ / 'dir ni mngon spyod spang bya ste/ / thub pa mchog gis smad pa yin/ /

“The entire threefold description Has now been given. The painting called ‘smallest’[618] Is the best for minor rites. “Whatever evil has been committed or caused to be committed, All this terrible karma, Accumulated over thousands of eons, Will be purified through merely seeing this painting.[619] “As soon as this painting is seen, At that very moment the karma will be purified. A wise person who paid respects To thousands of millions of buddhas[620] “Will not obtain even one sixteenth of the merit Obtained through merely seeing this smallest painting. “A wise man will obtain the same merit By merely looking at this smallest painting As he would obtain by worshiping All the protector buddhas. In this life he will thus perform Meritorious acts leading to good fortune. “However many mantras Have been taught by the sages Brahmā and Indra; By Vainateya, Varuṇa, Āditya, or Kubera; “By all the rākṣasas, Dhanada and so forth; By the lordly dānavas or mahoragas; By Soma, Vāyu, Yama, and so forth‍— Any that have been taught by Viṣṇu or Śiva‍— All these mantras brought here before this painting Would be accomplished. “One should always perform pacifying And enriching rites in this way. Violent acts ought to be shunned, As they have been condemned by the best of victors.”

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po'i mdo sde shin tu rgyas pa las/ 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga zhib mo le'u drug pa'i cho ga rab 'byam las/ ras ris chung ngu gsum pa'i cho ga rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed sixth chapter in “The Root Manual of Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings. This chapter contains the third procedure, that of the “smallest” painting.
ras ris kyi cho ga bzhi pa
Chapter 7

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa stan las langs te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs la phyag 'tshal nas/ bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la lan gsum bskor ba byas te/ bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyis chos kyi rnam grangs 'di bshad pa ni legs so legs so/ / rig pa thams cad kyi brtul zhugs spyad pa'i don dang / phan pa dang bde ba dang 'jig rten la snying brtse ba'i phyir dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi thabs la mkhas pa ston pa/ phung po lhag ma dang bcas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'i grong khyer du 'gro bar byed pa/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rgyud nges par byang chub sgrub par byed pa/ sngags kyi spyod pa thams cad kyi don sgrub par byed pa/ bdag gi gsang sngags 'di skye bo thams cad la rgyas par byed par 'gyur ro/ /

Now Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, rose from his seat, circumambulated Lord Śākyamuni three times clockwise and, having prostrated at his feet, said this to the Blessed One: “Good! It is good that you, the blessed one, the tathāgata, the worthy one, the perfectly awakened one, gave this Dharma discourse in such a clear way for the benefit, the welfare, and the happiness of all who observe their vidyā vows and in order to show your compassion for the world. You exemplified the bodhisattvas’ skill in means with this particular method that takes them higher than nirvāṇa[621] and, with their continuous dedication to the goal of awakening,[622] accomplishes their conduct consistent with all the goals of the mantras. This will promote the spread of this[623] secret mantra among all people.

ma 'ongs pa'i dus na 'jig rten gyi bla ma 'das pa na/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i nyi ma'i rigs nub pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad spangs pa dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas rnams kyis mun par gyur pa dang / snod kyi 'jig rten rnam par 'jig pa dang 'phags pa'i lam dang / rig pa thams cad dang sngags dang sman dang / nor bu rin po che med pa dang / skye bo dam pa rnams kyis 'jig rten na yongs su ma zin pa dang / sems can gyi khams thams cad 'byung bar 'gyur te/ le lo can dang dran pa nyams pa dang / ma dad pa dang mi srun pa dang mi dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis yongs su zin pa dang g.yo sgyu dang ldan pa dang / slu ba spyod pa de dag chos kyi rnam grangs 'di thos nas skrag par 'gyur te/ le lo la mngon par 'dod cing dad par mi 'gyur la/ 'dod pa tshol zhing yid ches par mi 'gyur ro/ / log pa'i lta ba skye zhing bsod nams ma yin pa 'phel bar 'gyur ro/ / mtshams med par gzhol zhing shin tu mi bzad pa'i yang shin tu mi bzad pa 'thob pa sdug bsngal ba de dag gi don dang dbang med pa la dbang du bya ba'i don dang / dbang du gyur pa la mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa'i phyir dang / thabs mkhas pas bsdu ba'i sbyor ba/ sngags kyi ras kyi ri mo'i cho ga gang de'i dus la bab par mkhyen na bcom ldan 'das kyis bshad du gsol/

“In the future, when the teachers of the world have entered nirvāṇa and the sun of the tathāgatas has set‍—when their lineages have ended and all the buddhafields are empty of all the buddhas, bodhisattvas, noble śrāvakas, and pratyekabuddhas; when the inhabitants of the world have become blind with ignorance; when the noble eightfold path has been cut and the medicine of all the vidyā mantras that are like precious gems is lost; when the world spheres have gone dark, devoid of good people[624]‍—at that time, beings will be lazy because of lack of interest;[625] they will lack faith, will be willfully destructive,[626] and will not rely on spiritual friends. They will be deceitful and treacherous, and they will act like rogues. “Such people, when hearing this Dharma discourse, will become frightened. Indulging in idleness and apathy, they will lack faith. Seeking sensual enjoyments, they will lack conviction. Delighting in wrong views,[627] they will generate a lot of negativity. Rejecting the true Dharma, they will move from one terrible state to one even worse, bound for Avīci Hell.[628] For the sake of those suffering like this, to enthrall the unsubmissive and, once they are enthralled, to grant them fearlessness, please muster your skill in means, O Blessed One, and teach them the procedure of painting involving mantras if you think that the time is right.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la legs so zhes bya ba byin te/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa de bzhin gshegs pa la don 'di 'dri bar sems pa legs so legs so/ / 'jam dpal khyod kyi mchog tu gsang ba rig pa'i brtul zhugs spyod pa'i le'u ras ris kyi cho ga rab 'byam yod de/ snying po mchog rnams kyi don mchog tu gsang ba dam pa don chen po sngags thams cad kyi cho gar gyur pa drug po 'di dag yi ge drug gi snying po'i mchog / the tshom med pa de'i tshe 'grub par 'gyur te/ sems can de dag gdul ba'i phyir dang / thabs la mkhas pa la yang dag par rab tu zhugs pa'i phyir dang / nges par yang dag pa'i byang chub thob pa'i phyir/ sangs rgyas bye ba phrag bdun cu rtsa drug gis sngar gsungs shing da ltar yang ngas bshad de/ ma 'ongs pa'i skye bo'i tshogs la phan pa'i phyir legs par nyon la yid la zung shig dang / ngas bshad par bya'o/ / de gang zhe na/

Then Lord Śākyamuni applauded Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “Good, Mañjuśrī! It is good that you ask the Tathāgata about this matter. There is, Mañjuśrī, your most secret and detailed teaching on another procedure of cloth painting, with its associated conduct and practice of the vidyā observances. It includes the supreme and most secret meaning of the mantras of the ultimate essence‍—the great meaning that is the foundation of all mantras. “These six six-syllable mantras of the ultimate essence will, at that time, lead to an accomplishment without a doubt. I too will now teach what was previously taught by seven hundred and sixty million buddhas in order to tame such beings, to help them develop the skill in means, to cause them to take up the practice of the mantra, and to invariably bring them to perfect awakening. Focusing on the people of the future, listen well and reflect on the meaning thoroughly. I will now tell you, so what are they?”
de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas sngags gsungs pa/
Lord Śākyamuni then pronounced the mantras:
oM bAkye \u0f85r+tha dza ya/ oM bAkye she sha swA/ oM bAkye baM dza ya/ oM bAkye ni Sh+the ya/ oM bAkye ya na maH/ oM bAkye daM na maH/
“Oṁ vākyārthe jaya.[629] “Oṁ vākyaśeṣe sva.[630] “Oṁ vākyeyanayaḥ.[631] “Oṁ vākyaniṣṭheyaḥ.[632] “Oṁ vākyeya namaḥ. “Oṁ vākyeda namaḥ.[633]

de ltar 'di dag 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa khyod kyi sngags drug dang yi ge drug pa mthu chen po dang stobs mnyam pa/ snying po dam pa mchog tu grub pa/ sangs rgyas bzhin du 'byung ba sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis rab tu gsungs pa/ dam tshig nyams pa dang dam tshig g.yos pa rnams kyi las thams cad byed pa/ byang chub kyi lam rjes su ston pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs la sngags kyi mchog tu gyur pa/ mchog dang 'bring dang tha ma gsum la rab tu sbyor ba/ legs par sbyangs pa'i las kyi 'bras bu'i rnam par smin pa sbyin pa/ bstan pa nub pa'i dus su yang dngos grub thob par 'gyur ro/ / las kyi tshul dang bcas pa la yang dag par gzhol ba la/ skad cig gis don bsgrub par 'gyur ba de dag myur du shin tu myur bar de'i tshe dang de'i dus su 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / nyam sad pa'i phyir yang snying po dam pa 'di dag bsgrub par bya ste/ mdor na ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / des na ras ris kyi cho ga 'di bya ba yin te/ de'i tshe de'i dus na 'jigs pa chen po dang / snyigs ma la sems can bsod nams chung ba 'byung bar 'gyur te/ grags pa chung ba dang / tshe thung ba dang longs spyod chung ba dang / chos spyod pa chung bas shin tu rgya che ba'i ras ris kyi cho ga'i sgrub pa la sogs pa rtsom par mi nus te/ de dag gi phyir shin tu mdor bstan par bya'o/ /

“These six mantras of yours, Mañjuśrī, each numbering six syllables, are of great power and equal in their great potency. They are the supreme heart mantras that bring the highest accomplishment, as if they originated from the Buddha himself. They have been proclaimed by every buddha for the benefit of all beings. They involve and activate the samaya[634] and are suitable for all types of activity. They are signposts for the road to awakening and are the most important mantras of the Tathāgata family. They can be employed in all three levels of ritual, the highest, the medium, and the lowest. They bring the ripening of the fruit of virtuous karma. They will lead to accomplishment at the time when the Buddha’s teaching has disappeared. “For those who will have succeeded in finding, for the sake of protection, a true Dharma guide, these mantras will, even through only basic application, accomplish the goals of kingship, good fortune, and great powers.[635] They will swiftly lead them to accomplishment at that time and juncture. Therefore, these supreme heart mantras should be accomplished even if it were only out of curiosity. In short, in whatever way they are employed, they will lead to corresponding accomplishments. The painting procedure involving these mantras will now be presented in brief.[636] “At that time, during the terrible period of five degenerations, beings will have very little merit. They will be petty,[637] with short lifespans and little happiness. Being weak in diligence,[638] they will not even be able to begin the very elaborate rites for the painting procedures. It is for their benefit that I will teach a very short procedure.

dang por re shig dpa' bo'i tshong gis dog pa srang gcig gam srang phyed kyis nyos la chur khru gang / zheng du khru phyed tsam gyi ras kha tshar dang bcas pa thag pa la 'thag tu gzhug go/ / yang na skra med pa'i ras kyi dum bu sar pa gzhan steng dang 'og tu ci ltar 'dod pa khru gnyis dang bzhi dang drug dang lnga dang bcu dang brgyad pa'i ras blangs te/ ci ltar 'dod pa'i ri mo bas ri mo bri bar bya'o/ / tshon ma 'dres pa dang tsan+dan dang ga pur dang / gur gum gyis bsgos te/ ras kyang tsan+dan dang ga pur dang / gur gum gcig tu byas pa srog chags med pa'i chu rdul med pa dang bsres te/ snod sar pa'i nang du bkrus la zhag gsum gyi bar du legs par bkab ste/ bzhag nas gtsang ba'i phyogs su srung ba byas shing bdag nyid kyang gtsang bar byas te/ zla ba yar ngo'i tshes bcwa lnga la ras snod kyi mdun du shar du mngon par phyogs te/ ku sha'i khres la 'dug nas/ sngags kyi tshig lan brgya rtsa brgyad brjod par bya ba la 'di lta ste/

“First, one should purchase thread with due care, one pala or half a pala in weight, and commission a weaver to make a cloth one cubit long and half a cubit across, together with a fringe.[639] Alternatively, one should obtain a different, new piece of cloth that is free from hairs,[640] measuring‍—as one prefers‍—two, four, six, five, ten, or eight cubits from top to bottom,[641] and very white,[642] and one should have the painter do the painting according to one’s wish. “It should be painted using uncontaminated paints infused with sandalwood, camphor, and saffron. First one should mix together sandalwood, camphor, and saffron into a homogenous substance and blend this with water free of living organisms and impurities. One should soak the cloth in a vessel with this mixture, cover it well with a lid, and leave it for three days. Then, having performed the protection rite, in a clean place, having ritually purified oneself, during the bright fortnight, on the full moon day,[643] one should sit on a bundle of kuśa grass in front of the vessel with the cloth in it and, facing the east, recite the words of the following mantra one hundred and eight times:

oM he he b+ha ga bAn ba hu rU ba d+hA ra di bya tsak+Shu She/ a ba lo ka ya/ a ba lo ka ya/ mAM sa ma ya ma nu sma ra ku mA ra rU pa d+hA ri Ne/ ma hA bo d+hi sa twa kiny+tsi rA ya si hUM s+pha Te s+pha Te swA hA/

“Oṁ he he! O blessed one with many forms and the divine eye, look after me, look! Remember your samaya! O great bodhisattva with the form of a divine youth, why do you delay? Hūṁ hūṁ phaṭ phaṭ svāhā![644]

sngags 'di bzlas pa byas la de nyid du nyal bar bya'o/ / gnyid log pa'i rmi lam du 'grub pa 'am mi 'grub pa ston par 'gyur ro/ / de nas langs nas rmi lam du grub pa'i mtshan ma mthong na ring po mi thogs par ras ris bri bar bya'o/ / gal te grub pa'i mtshan ma rmi lam du ma mthong na/ ras de snod de las phyung la nyi ma la bskams nas yang snod sar pa gzhan du bcug la/ shin tu dben par legs par bsrung ba byas la bzhag go/ / de nas yang snying po'i mchog de dag las gang yang rung ba'i sngags blangs la/ gang 'dod pa'i yi ge drug pa yang yi ge 'bum bzla bar bya'o/ / des na ras mi dge ba yang 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / dang por re zhig ras de blangs la cho 'phrul gyi zla phyed dam/ yar ngo'i nyin zhag la rgyu skar bzang po dang ldan pa'i grangs bzang po la/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal byis pa khye'u yi gzugs can mgo zur phud lnga dang ldan pa/ byis pa'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa mdog gser 'dra ba/ na bza' sngon po g.yo bzhin pa mnabs pa/ na bza' dar la sngon pos stod g.yogs byas pa/ chos 'chad pa seng ge'i khri la skyil mo krung phyed pas bzhugs la/ zhabs g.yas pas rin po che'i zhabs rten la bzhag pa/ g.yon pa seng ge'i gdan la bzhugs pa/ rgyan thams cad dang ldan pa bzhin cung zad 'dzum pa dang bcas pa/ sgrub pa po la lta ba bri bar bya'o/ /

“Having recited this mantra, one should go to sleep right then. While asleep, one will receive a sign whether the procedure will be successful or not. Upon awakening, one should commission the painting without delay if one’s dreams indicated success. If the dreams conveyed no sign of success, one should take the cloth out of the vessel and dry it in the sun. When dry, one should again place it in a different new vessel. One should keep it well hidden, and also do the protection rite over it. Then, choosing whichever among the six-syllable heart mantras given previously one wishes, recite its syllables one hundred thousand times. One will then be able to swiftly[645] accomplish the cloth-painting procedure. “To begin, one should take this cloth, and, during the prātihāra fortnight, or any day during the bright fortnight when the stars are auspicious, and during an auspicious lunar asterism, on a night augured as favorable by the cries of auspicious birds, at midnight, one should have the painter do the painting. This should be done in a clean place, by a painter who is observing the ritual fast and burning an incense of camphor.[646] “The painter should first[647] paint Noble Mañjuśrī with the form of a young boy, his hair in five locks, and dressed with all the adornments of a boy. Golden in color, he wears short trousers and a shirt of blue silk. He expounds the Dharma while sitting on a lion throne in the cross-legged posture with his right foot placed on a jeweled footstool and his left[648] on the seat of the lion throne. Adorned with all types of jewelry, he is of charming appearance.[649] Smiling slightly, he is directing his gaze at the practitioner.

g.yas phyogs su 'phags pa kun du bzang po rnga ma dkar po g.yob pa/ pri yang ku'i mdog ltar sngo bsangs lag pa g.yon pa na nor bu rin po che thogs pa/ yan lag thams cad mdzes pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ na bza' sngon po g.yo ba mnabs pa/ mu tig gi phreng bas mchod phyir thogs pa/ pad+ma dkar po'i gdan la 'dug pa bri bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi g.yon phyogs su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug ston ka'i zla rgyu'i mdog ltar dkar ba/ na bza' sngon po g.yo ba mnabs pa/ yan lag thams cad mdzes pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ mu tig gi phreng bas mchod phyir thogs byas pa/ lag pa g.yon pa na pad+ma dkar po 'dzin pa/ lag pa g.yas pa na rnga yab gser gyi yu ba can dkar po thogs pa/ zhi ba'i cha byad can 'phags pa 'jam dpal la lta ba/ de bzhin du 'phags pa kun du bzang po pad+ma dkar po la gnas pa/ gnyi ga yang de ltar bri bar bya'o/ /

“On his right side should be painted the noble Samantabhadra, waving a white yak-tail whisk. He is of the dark blue color of the beautyberry flower. In his left hand he holds a wish-fulfilling gem. He is beautiful in every limb and adorned with all types of jewelry. He wears short trousers of blue silk and is invested with the sacred thread made of a garland of pearls. He should be painted standing on a white lotus. “The noble Avalokiteśvara, white as the autumn moon and wearing short trousers of blue silk, should be painted to left side of Noble Mañjuśrī. Beautiful in his every limb and adorned with all types of jewelry, he is invested with the sacred thread made of a garland of pearls. He holds a white lotus in his left hand, and with his right he holds a white yak-tail whisk with a golden handle, which he waves. Peaceful in form, he, just like the noble Samantabhadra, directs his gaze at Noble Mañjuśrī. Both of them should be painted standing on white lotuses.[650]

de nas sdong bu gcig las skyes pa'i pad+ma gsum la dbus kyi rtsa ba'i pad+ma'i ge sar la ni 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi seng ge'i khri dang rin po che'i zhabs rten no/ / gnyis pa'i pad+ma la ni 'phags pa kun du bzang po'o/ / gsum pa'i pad+ma la ni spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug go/ / pad+ma'i sdong bu mdzes pa rin po che margad 'dra ba/ pad+ma'i me tog du ma kha ma bye ba dang / phyed tsam bye ba dang kha bye ba dang ldan pa/ mtsho chen po ma dros pa las skyes pa klu'i rgyal po dga' bo dang nye dga' gnyis pad+ma'i sdong bu la 'dzin pa/ klu'i rgyal po de dag gi kha dog dkar ba/ gdengs ka bdun gyis nye bar brgyan pa/ lus rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ lus kyi stod mi la sbrul gyi gdengs kas mtshan pa/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal la lta ba/ lus phyed chu'i nang du nub pa nor bu rin po che dang gos kyis nye bar mdzes pa bri bar bya'o/ /

“Next, three lotuses spring from a single stalk. On the pericarp of the middle, primary lotus is the lion throne of Noble Mañjuśrī and his jeweled footstool. On the second lotus the noble Samantabhadra stands on a white[651] lotus seat. On the third lotus is the noble Avalokiteśvara. The beautiful, emerald-like stalk rises from Anavatapta Lake, which is covered in lotus buds with leaves, half-opened lotuses, and lotuses in full bloom. This lotus stalk is supported by two nāga kings, Nanda and Upananda. “These two nāga kings should be painted as white, each of them adorned with seven hoods. Their bodies, adorned with all types of jewelry, are half human, and the other half is distinguished by the coils of a snake. With their [lower] bodies submerged in water, they direct their gaze at Noble Mañjuśrī. They are shaded with parasols decorated with jewels.

mtsho chen po kun gyi 'og tu sgrub pa po ras ris kyi g.yas phyogs kyi mtha'i zur du 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi zhal gyi dkyil 'khor la lta ba/ spos snod lag na thogs pa mgo dang pus mo'i lha nga 'dud pa/ cha byad dang kha dog snga ma ci lta ba bzhin bri bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi steng ras kyi zur gnyis su lha'i bu me tog gi phreng ba 'dzin pa/ nam mkha' la lding ba/ sprin gyi nang nas byung ba/ me tog gi tshogs chen po 'thor ba shin tu mdzes pa bri bar bya'o/ / ras ris kyi 'khor yug tu me tog nA ga ge sar la sogs pas rab tu gtor bar bri bar bya'o/ /

“In the right corner of the cloth, on the margins below the great lake, the practitioner should be painted looking at the orb of Noble Mañjuśrī’s face. He holds an incense holder in his hand and inclines his head toward his knee. He should be depicted with all the respective details of dress and colors.[652] “Above Noble Mañjuśrī, in the two corners at the edge of the cloth, two divine sons wearing garlands[653] and holding garlands of flowers should be painted. They float nestled within clouds and release a great flood of flowers. Both are very beautiful. Blossoms of the ironwood tree and so forth should be painted strewn all around the cloth. One may create this painting, presided over by the three forms,[654] however one desires.[655]

ci ltar 'dod pa'i gzugs de bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal chos 'chad pa dang / 'phags pa kun du bzang po dang 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs lag na rnga yab g.yob pa bri bar bya'o/ / yang na sgrub pa po ci ltar 'dod pa bzhin du ras ris kyi gzugs nges par bri bar bya ste/ ci ltar 'dod pa'i cha byad dam/ ci ltar 'dod pa'i dbyibs sam/ sgrub pa po ci lta ci ltar 'dod pa de lta de ltar bri bar bya'o/ /

“They may be painted as the practitioner pleases, but these three figures must be included‍—the noble Mañjuśrī expounding the Dharma and the noble Samantabhadra and Avalokiteśvara, both of whom are painted with yak-tail whisks in their hands. Optionally, other forms may be added as desired, arranged according to their respective places. Whatever forms the practitioner finds agreeable, these forms may be painted.

dbus su 'phags pa 'jam dpal g.yas g.yon du 'phags pa 'jig rten dbang phyug dang / kun du bzang po ci ltar 'dod par nges par bri bar bya'o/ / yang na ci rnyed pa'i ras kyi dum bu mtho gang ngam/ khru gang la bdag nyid dam gzhan gyis sam/ ri mo mkhan gso sbyong byas pa'am gso sbyong ma byas pa dad pa'am ma dad pa'am/ gtsang ba 'am mi gtsang ba 'am/ tshul khrims dang ldan pa 'am tshul khrims 'chal pa'i ri mo mkhan gyis kyang bri bar bya'o/ / bdag nyid dam sgrub pa pos nges par sngon du bsnyen pa byas pa dang / dad pa dang byang chub tu sems bskyed pa ni nges par bya'o/ /

“Noble Mañjuśrī should always be painted in the middle, with the noble Avalokiteśvara and Samantabhadra on either side. The other forms, however, can be painted as preferred.[656] One can also use any piece of cloth as available, which could be one vitasti or one cubit in size and either do the painting oneself or have it done by any painter whether he observes the fast or not, has faith or not, is pure or impure, or of good or bad morals. If, however, the practitioner does the painting himself, he must certainly first complete the preparatory rites, have faith, and have given rise to bodhicitta.

de ltar byas na sngags 'grub par 'gyur gyi gzhan du sdig pa'i las can gyis ni mi 'gyur te/ de ltar dad pa dang de ltar gyur pas bsgrub par bya'o/ / sngags kyi rgyal po dang sngags kyi lha dag 'dir dad pa dang ldan pas 'grub par 'gyur gyi gzhan dag gis ni ma yin no/ / gang phyir dad pa theg pa mchog / gang gis rnam par 'dren pa mchog / dad pa med pa'i mi la ni/ / dkar po'i chos rnams mi skye ste/ / sa bon tshig par gyur pa las/ / myu gu sngon po ci bzhin no/ / dad dang ldan pa'i mi dag la/ / sangs rgyas las ni 'grub 'gyur te/ / sngags rnams thams cad khyad par du/ / dad pa med la mi 'grub bo/ / gang yang 'jig rten lha dag dang / / de bzhin 'jig rten 'das pa dag / dad ldan kun la 'grub 'gyur te/ / sdig pa dag dang bral phyir ro/ / byang chub der song yid kyis ni/ / de dag myur du nges 'grub ste/ / gzhan la 'grub par mi 'gyur zhing / / bstan pa 'di la rnam par bzlog / ras ni chung dang chen po dang / / 'bring du nye bar bsgrags pa yin/ / las rnams kun la sgrub pa ni/ / da ni rab tu bstan par bya/ /

“In this way the mantras will be accomplished, But not for those who commit evil. Accordingly, once faith has been developed, The mantra deities[657] will be accomplished.[658] “The mantra kings will be accomplished through this ritual Only by those who have faith, not otherwise,[659] Because faith is the supreme vehicle Traveled in by the spiritual guides themselves. “For a person without faith The white Dharma will not grow, Just like green shoots From seeds burnt by fire. “But if an ordinary person is confirmed in faith And has begun working toward awakening, He will accomplish the deities. If he has no faith, he will not. In particular, he will not Accomplish any mantras.[660] “Whatever worldly deities there are, And whatever are beyond this world, All of them, free from stain, Will be accomplished by those with faith.[661] “Swiftly will they gain accomplishment, And their awakening is certain, if they direct their minds to it. No attainment is said to arise for the others Who have turned from this teaching. “The painting procedures‍—the small, the special, And the middle‍—have now been taught. Presently, I will teach the practice That accomplishes all activities.”

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga bdun pa'i le'u rab 'byam las/ ras ris kyi cho ga bzhi pa'i le'u rab 'byam rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed seventh chapter, which is the detailed fourth chapter on the cloth-painting procedure, from “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a basket of bodhisattva teachings.
'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga zhib mo rab 'byam sgrub pa'i thabs mchog gi las
Chapter 8
de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/
Now Lord Śākyamuni addressed Mañjuśrī, the divine youth:

'jam dpal gzhon nu gang khyod kyis bstan pa'i sems can de dag gi phyir/ le'u'i cho ga rab 'byam 'di thabs sla bas 'grub par 'gyur ba ngas kyang bstan te/ de dag gi don gyi phyir yon tan rgya che ba'i bye brag gi dbye ba/ las rnam par 'byed pa sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir yang dag par bshad par bya yis/ de legs par shin tu rab tu nyon cig dang bshad par bya'o/ /

“The full topic of the cloth-painting procedure, Mañjuśrī, has now been taught by me for the benefit of those beings you foretold. They will succeed even with little skillful means.[662] For their benefit I will now teach a sādhana method classified according to the type of activity, describing at length its different virtues. Listen to it well, and reflect upon it thoroughly. I will speak for the benefit of all beings.”[663]

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas/ bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bdag gi tshig gi nus pa gsal bar mdzad cing / sngags kyi spyod pa'i yon tan grub par mdzad pa ni legs so legs so zhes gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das de'i dus la bab par mkhyen na bdag la thugs brtse ba'i slad du de bshad du gsol/

The divine youth Mañjuśrī, in turn, said to the Blessed One, “Good! It is good, O Blessed One, that you will give this eloquent exposition that illuminates our incisive meditation and causes the qualities of mantra practice to fully manifest.[664] So do teach this method, Blessed One, if you think that the time is right. Do so out of compassion for us.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor la gzigs te 'dzum pa mdzad do/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i zhal gyi sgo nas 'od zer sngon po dang / ser po dang ljang gu dang shel gyi kha dog lta bu byung ste/ 'od zer de byung ma thag tu thams cad dang ldan pa'i dkyil 'khor snang bar byas nas stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi bdud thams cad zil gyis mnan nas/ rgyu skar gyi 'od dang ri bo'i tshogs thams cad kyi 'od dang / gang 'di zla ba dang nyi ma rdzu 'phrul che zhing mthu che ba de dag gi 'od kyang zil gyis mnan te/ mi gsal zhing 'od med par 'gyur ba dang / rnam par mdzes par mi 'gyur zhing gsal bar mi 'gyur ro/ / nor bu thams cad dang / sngags dang sman dang / rin po che'i 'od thams cad 'od med par byas nas slar log ste/ bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i zhal gyi sgor nub par gyur to/ /

Lord Śākyamuni looked then at the entire assembly and smiled. At that moment rays of blue, yellow, and translucent crystalline light[665] issued from the mouth of Lord Śākyamuni. As soon as these rays issued forth, they illuminated the entire assembly and dimmed the worldly realm of the great trichiliocosm, including the abodes of all the māras. This included the light of the entire multitude of stars, celestial bodies, mountain ranges, and the moon and the sun, those two luminaries of great power and might, which were also dimmed by the light of Śākyamuni’s rays. They lost their radiance and did not illuminate the worlds. They did not shine and appeared dark. The rays dimmed also the jewel light of all gems, mantras, and medicines and then disappeared back into Lord Śākyamuni’s mouth.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po phyag na rdo rje 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor de nyid du 'dus shing 'khod par gyur pa de stan las langs nas/ rings pa'i tshul gyis bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la btud de/ bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das ni rgyu ma mchis rkyen ma mchis par 'dzum pa mi mdzad na/ bcom ldan 'das 'dzum pa mdzad pa'i rgyu gang lags/ rkyen gang lags/ de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis byang chub sems dpa' phyag na rdo rje la bka' stsal pa/ phyag na rdo rje de de bzhin no/ / de de bzhin te/ ci skad smras pa de bzhin no/ / bcom ldan 'das ni rgyu med pa dang / rkyen med par 'dzum pa mi mdzad de/ rgyu yod rkyen yod do/ / gang zhig mdo sde'i dbang po'i rgyal po 'di 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga rig pa'i spyod pa rjes su sgrub pa las sgrub pa'i thabs la yang dag par gzhol ba/ chos kyi sprin la rten pa la yang dag par 'jug cing rjes su 'brang bar byed pa dang / 'dzin par 'gyur ba dang / klog par 'gyur ba dang / dad par 'gyur ba dang / glegs bam la 'dri ba byas nas mchod par 'gyur ba dang / tsan+dan gyi phye ma dang byug pa dang / bdug pa dang / phreng ba dang / gdugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan rnam pa sna tshogs pa'am/ tshig gi bye brag gis sam/ sil snyan rnam pa sna tshogs dang / pheg rdob pa dag gam tha na rjes su yi rang ba dang ldan pa'i sems rgyud la thob pa 'am/ ba spu ldang bar byed pa 'am/ rig pa'i mthu thos nas dga' ba skyes pa 'am/ rjes su yi rang bar 'gyur ba 'am/ spyod pa thob par 'gyur ba de dag ni ngas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das su 'gyur bar lung bstan te/ des na rgyal ba de ltar 'dzum pa mdzad kyi gzhan du ni ma yin no/ /

Bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi, the great being, was present at that time in the midst of this great gathering. Seated, he rose from his seat in his beautiful form pleasing to beings,[666] prostrated at the Blessed One’s feet, and said this to him: “It is not without a cause or a reason that the blessed[667] buddhas smile. What is the cause, Blessed One, what is the reason for your smile?” Being thus asked, the Blessed One said to Bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi, “It is so, Vajrapāṇi, it is so. It is exactly as you say. The smile of the tathāgatas does not happen without a cause or a reason.[668] There is a cause, there is a reason: future beings will take up and follow this king of the lords of sūtras, this root manual of Mañjuśrī, which arose out of the tenth bodhisattva level, Cloud of Dharma‍—a collection of skillful methods such as ritual practices that involve knowledge-vidyās and practicing the right conduct. Future beings will study this manual in full, memorize it, spread it by word of mouth, and put their faith in it. “Having written it down in the form of a book, they will worship it with sandalwood powder, ointments, incense, flower garlands, parasols, flags and banners, or other different means, in particular with the music[669] of various instruments and cymbals. Through that they will attain a continuous mental state of inner rejoicing that makes their bodily hair bristle with joy. Learning about the power and efficacy of vidyās, they will be thrilled, rejoice, and will take up the right conduct. I predict that all of them will become blessed buddhas, established in supreme, perfect awakening. It is for this and no other reason that the victorious ones smile.

'dir dang por re zhig cho ga'i rgyal po 'di la dam tshig mthong ba sngon du bya ba rnams byas pa dang dbang bskur ba thob pa/ rtsa ba'i sngags sam snying po 'am nye ba'i snying po 'am/ sngags gang yang rung ba bzung nas yi ge gcig pa 'am/ gang 'dod pa dgon pa chen por song ste 'bum phrag gsum bzla bar bya'o/ / 'bras bu dang chus 'tsho ba 'am/ rtsa ba dang / lo ma'i bza' ba byas na/ sngon du bya ba byas par 'gyur ro/ / de nas ri'i rtse mor 'dzegs nas ras ris chen po'i tshad nub phyogs su mngon du lta ba bzhag pa byas la bdag nyid shar du bltas te/ ku sha'i khres la 'dug nas/ pad+ma dkar po la tsan+dan dang gur gum gyis btags te/ bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas dang nyan thos dag la 'bum phrag gcig ri mo'i ras ris kyi 'og tu dbul bar bya'o/ / ga pur gyi bdug pa yang ci 'byor pas bdug go/ / lha'i bu dang klu rnams la yang ci rnyed pa'i me tog gis mchod par bya'o/ / de nas mtshan phyed kyi dus su cho 'phrul gyi zla phyed kyi zla ba nya ba la/ ras ris kyi mdun du pad+ma'i rnam pa lta bu'i me thab byas pa la/ tsan+dan dkar po'i shing gis me sbar nas/ gur gum dang ga pur bsres pas sreg blugs ci 'byor pas stong rtsa brgyad sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas bsrung ba bya'o/ /

“To start, one who observes his samaya of, who has completed the preparatory rites for, and who has been ritually initiated into this king of manuals should choose either the root mantra, heart mantra, subsidiary heart mantra, or another mantra, whether of one syllable or another one as desired and go to a large forest. There one should recite the mantra three million times, living on fruits, water, roots, or leaves. This constitutes the preliminary practice. “One should then climb to the top of a mountain and position the superior[670] painting so that it faces the west. Then, sitting on a bundle of kuśa grass and facing east, one should offer, below the painting, one hundred thousand white lotuses smeared with white sandalwood[671] and saffron to Lord Śākyamuni and all the buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, and noble śrāvakas. One should burn camphor incense according to one’s means[672] and make offerings to the gods and nāgas of whatever flowers are available. “Then, at the midnight hour, on a bright full moon night, the completely full moon of the prātihāra fortnight, one should dig, in front of the painting, a fire pit in the shape of a lotus and kindle the fire using white sandalwood sticks. One should blend together saffron and camphor and offer it into the fire one thousand and eight times, [or as many times] as one can. [In this way] one becomes ritually protected.

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa las 'od zer byung ste/ ras kyi ri mo'i 'khor yug nas gcig tu 'bar bar 'gyur te/ sgrub pa pos gur gum dang / tsan+dan gyis btags pa'i tsan+dan dkar po'i me tog gis mchod yon dbul lo/ / de nas sgrub pa pos rings pa'i tshul gyis ras ris la lan gsum bskor ba byas te/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang 'phags pa nyan thos rnams la phyag byas nas/ sgrub pa pos bris pa'i ras ris kyi mtha' ma'i phyogs nas 'jigs pa med pas ras ris gzung bar bya'o/ / de nas bzung ba tsam gyis 'phur te/ se gol gtogs pa tsam gyis tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du phyin par 'gyur te/ me tog can gyi 'jig rten gyi khams su rab tu gnas par 'gyur te/ gang du bcom ldan 'das me tog yang dag par skyes pa'i rgyal po'i dbang po de bzhin gshegs pa de bzhugs te/ 'tsho zhing gzhes la chos kyang ston to/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal yang mngon du mthong ngo / / chos kyang thos so/ / byang chub sems dpa' du ma dag kyang mthong zhing / de dag la bsnyen bkur yang byed de bskal pa chen po stong du rga ba dang 'chi ba med cing gnas par 'gyur ro/ /

“Then rays of light emanate from Lord Śākyamuni, encircle the painting, and envelop it with blazing light. The practitioner,[673] in a form pleasing to beings,[674] should then circumambulate the painting three times clockwise, bow to all the buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, and noble śrāvakas, and take the painting into his hands.[675] “As soon as one grasps the end of the cloth where the practitioner had been painted earlier, one will fly upward.[676] In the snap of a finger, one will ascend to the realm of Brahmā. One will reach the world sphere called Kusumāvatī, where dwells Tathāgata Saṃkusumita Rājendra. There he upholds, maintains, and expounds the Dharma. One will see there Noble Mañjuśrī in person and will hear his Dharma discourse. One will also see many hundreds of thousands[677] of bodhisattvas and attend upon them. One will live for one thousand great eons, enjoying[678] freedom from old age and death.

ras ris kyang de na gnas par 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis byin gyis brlabs par 'gyur ro/ / de dag gis byin gyis brlabs par yang yang dag par shes so/ / sangs rgyas kyi zhing stong yang 'da' bar byed do/ / lus stong yang ston par byed do/ / rdzu 'phrul gyi mthu du ma yang 'byin par byed do/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal yang dge ba'i bshes gnyen du 'gyur ro/ / nges par byang chub la gzhol bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The painting also remains there and is blessed by all the buddhas and bodhisattvas; one can clearly feel the blessing. One will be able to visit hundreds of thousands of buddhafields, display hundreds of thousands of bodies, and develop many magical powers. Noble Mañjuśrī will become one’s spiritual friend, and one will be destined to attain awakening.”

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po rgya che ba'i mdo las/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga zhib mo rab 'byam sgrub pa'i thabs mchog gi las kyi le'u brgyad pa las dang po rdzogs so// //

This concludes the eighth chapter of this extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings. This chapter constitutes the detailed first chapter on the ritual involving the supreme sādhana method.
gnyis pa sgrub pa'i thabs dam pa'i las
Chapter 9

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor gyi lha 'dus pa rnams la bka' stsal pa/ grogs po dag khyed cag nyon cig / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i spyod pa'i dkyil 'khor sngags sgrub pa'i thabs kyi las byed pa/ sgrub pa po bsrung ba'i phyir/ mchog tu gsang ba dam pa snying po dam pa de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis gsungs pa rig pa'i rgyal po chen po bzlas pa gang gis sngags thams cad bzlas par 'gyur te/ kye lha'i tshogs dag 'di ni 'da' bar bya ba ma yin te/ rig pa'i rgyal po 'di ni 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa yang rig pa'i rgyal po 'dis 'gugs shing dbang du byed la/ 'byor pa med par byed na byang chub sems dpa' gzhan lta smos kyang ci dgos/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags thams cad dang / bgegs thams cad kyang 'jig par byed de/ 'di ni stobs che ba dang mthu che ba dang dpa' bo gcig pa dang sngags thams cad kyi mchog gcig tu bstan pa dang / yi ge gcig pa rnams kyi nang na gcig par bstan pa dang / yi ge gcig gis don thams cad sgrub par byed pa/ bya ba thams cad byed pa/ sngags thams cad gcod par byed pa/ ma rungs pa'i las rnams kyi sdig pa thams cad rab tu 'jig par byed pa/ sngags thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ dge bar byed pa dang / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags rnams kyi gong nas gong du 'dug pa/ thogs pa med pa de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi snying po bsam pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa de gang zhe na/ oM n+thI grogs po dag 'di nyid ni mchog tu gsang ba dam pa las thams cad byed pa/ yi ge gcig pa zhes bya ba rig pa'i rgyal po 'da' bar bya ba ma yin pa/ sems can thams cad kyis thub par dka' ba 'byung po thams cad kyi bkra shis pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad sgrub par byed pa/ sngags thams cad kyi mnga' bdag 'jig rten thams cad kyi dbang phyug / rnam par sdang ba rnams la byams pa'i bdag nyid dang skye bo thams cad la snying brtse bar byed pa/ bgegs thams cad 'jig par byed pa ste/ mdor na ci lta ci ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar las byed de/ bsgrubs pa med kyang las 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

Now Lord Śākyamuni addressed the hosts of gods who were sitting among the entire assembly: “Esteemed friends! Please listen to my discourse about the method for accomplishing the conduct, maṇḍala, and mantra of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth. Hear this great vidyārāja‍—the supremely secret and sublime heart mantra that was taught by all the tathāgatas for the sake of protecting the practitioner‍—by the uttering of which all mantras are uttered. “This vidyārāja, O hosts of gods, is inviolable. With this vidyārāja even Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, can be summoned, enthralled, and made to comply. Why say more? There are, O bodhisattvas, other mantras, both worldly and transcendental, but this unique mantra of great valor and power is said to be the best of all mantras‍—it can destroy all obstacles.[679] Among all one-syllable mantras, only this one is called the syllable.[680] “This single syllable fulfills all purposes and accomplishes every task; it nullifies all the mantras of evildoers and removes all sins;[681] it makes all the other mantras effective; it brings that which is virtuous. It surpasses all other worldly and transcendental mantras. It is the impeccable essence of all the tathāgatas that fulfills all wishes. Which mantra is this? It is kḷlhīṁ.[682] “Friends, this most secret vidyārāja called One Syllable can be employed in all rites. No being may transgress it; it cannot be assailed by any spirit; it constitutes the auspiciousness of all the buddhas; it makes all mantras effective; it is the master of the worlds; it is the lord of all the lords of wealth;[683] it is the love for all those who hate; it awakens the compassion of all beings; and it is the remover of all obstacles. In short, whatever it is employed in, that very thing it will accomplish. It can perform tasks even when it is not fully mastered.

sngags 'di bzlas la reg pas de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / gos la bsngags nas gyon na skal ba bzang por 'gyur ro/ / so shing la bsngags na so nad nye bar zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / ka ra bI ra dkar po'i so shing la/ lan bdun bsngags te zos na don du ma gnyer bar yang kha zas 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / mig gi nad la rgyam tshwa btags te lan bdun mngon par bsngags la mig bkang na mig gi nad sel to/ / rna ba'i nad la 'brug sgrogs pa las skyes pa'i rtswa tsha tri ka zhes bya ba/ glang po che'i rgyab tu reg par byas la/ rang gi lo ma'i nang du btums nas me chung ba la bsregs te shin tu 'jam par byas la/ rgyam tshwa'i phye ma chu dro 'jam tsam dang sprus te lan bdun bsngags pas rna ba bkang ba dang / skad cig de nyid la rna ba na ba nye bar zhi bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Whomever one touches while reciting this mantra[684] will become enthralled. If one wears incanted clothes, one will obtain good fortune. If one bites an incanted tooth stick, one will get rid of a toothache. If one bites an incanted tooth stick from the white oleander tree,[685] food will be found without one’s having to ask for it. “If one has eye pain, one should grind sea salt, incant it seven times, and apply it to the eye. This will remove the pain. If one has an earache, one should take a mushroom[686] that has grown in elephant dung while it thundered, wrap it in a leaf of kedhuka, and cook it over a low fire until it is well cooked. Having then added a lukewarm solution of sea salt, one should incant the decoction seven times and pour it into the ear.[687] The pain will be assuaged at that moment.

bud med bu 'byung ba'i dus su mngal nas mthon te/ na zhing nyam thag pa la ni shing A DA ru sha ka'i rtsa ba srog chags med pa'i chu la btags te lte ba'i phyogs su bskus na nye bar zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / mtshon nang du lus pa'i skyes bu la ni mar rnying pa la lan brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags te/ btung ba'am byugs na phyogs de nas de'i skad cig la zug rngu med par 'gyur ro/ / ma zhu ba dang gsud pa dang / 'khru ba'i nad la ni lan tshwa nag po 'am rgyam tshwa 'am tshwa gzhan gang yang rung ba la lan bdun bsngags te zos na nad de las grol bar 'gyur te/ de nyid kyi nyin par bde legs su 'gyur ro/ / ldan pa'i nad kyi tshad pas 'khru ba 'am/ 'khru ba la ni ma du lung ga'i rtsa ba btags te/ lan gcig gam gnyis bzlas pa byas nas srog chags med pa'i chu dang 'thungs na gnod pa med par de las grol bar 'gyur ro/ /

“If, at the time of giving birth, a woman is having a difficult delivery and is overcome with pain, one should grind the root of Malabar nut with water that is free of living organisms and smear it over the navel area.[688] She will give birth with ease. If a person with a splinter in his flesh[689] drinks old ghee incanted one hundred and eight times, or smears it over the affected area, the splinter will come out. “In the case of indigestion with vomiting and dysentery,[690] one should incant seven times some sochal salt, sea salt, or other type of salt, and eat it. One will be free from this disease the same day and will become well. In the case of the twofold dysentery or a sudden dysentery,[691] one should mash the fruits[692] of citron[693] with water that is free of living organisms and has been incanted once or more.[694] By this method one will be freed from the unpleasant symptoms.

bud med mo sham bu mi skye ba skye bar 'dod na/ a shwa gan d+ha'i rtsa ba mar bzang po dang lhan cig bskol la/ ba'i 'o ma dang lhan cig bskol te ba'i 'o ma dang bsres la lan nyi shu rtsa lngar bzlas la zla mtshan gyi dus su blud la khrus byas pa'i 'og tu khyim bdag gzhan gyi chung ma spangs shing 'dod pas log par g.yem pa spangs pas/ rang gi chung ma la mngon par song na rang gi khyo dang 'dra ba'i bu skye bar 'gyur ro/ / lo gsum mam lo lnga'i bar du bu btsa' ba'i dus su khrag 'byung ba 'am/ lo du ma'i bar du bu ma chags pa 'am/ gzhan gyi sngags rgyud dang sman dang gzhan gyi phyag rgyas bcings pa dang / gzhan gyis ma rungs par byas pa'am/ bu zla ba ma tshang bar byung ba 'am/ nad las yang dag par byung ba 'am/ gzhan gyi sbyor bas yang dag par byung ba 'am/ gzhan gang yang rung ba cung zad gzhan gyis byas pa'i nad dang / gnas pa dang 'gro ba dang bcos ma dang / bcos ma ma yin pa'i dbyig dug la sogs pa byin pa 'am rtsa ba dang sman dang sngags thams cad dang / mdza' ba dang mi mdza' bas sbyor ba byas pa la lan nyi shu rtsa bdun bsngags te/ mar rnying pa la rma bya'i sgro zla ba 'dra ba dang bsres te btags la de nas shin tu zhib par byas la sha kha ra dang lhan cig sbyar te/ a ru ra tsam bza' bar bya'o/ / zhag bdun gyi bar du kha ra dang ldan pa'i bskol ba btung bar bya ste/ yang dang yang du sngags kyang bzla bar bya'o/ / mgo bo'i nad la ni khwa'i gshog pa la lan bdun bsngags te byabs na bde legs su 'gyur ro/ / bud med la spyad drags pa la sogs pa'i nad ni shing a la ma bu sa'i rtsa ba'i lo ma dang lhan cig btags nas/ sman ni li ka'i rtsa ba dang ldan pa la brgya rtsa brgyad bsngags te 'o ma de dang bsres la btung bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du rims nyin gcig pa dang nyin gnyis pa dang nyin gsum pa dang nyin bzhi pa dang / ther zug pa'i rims dang / rtag pa'i rims dang rims mi bzad pa la sogs pa la 'o thug mar dang ldan pa la brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags te blud pa byas na bde bar gnas par 'gyur ro/ /

“In the case of a barren woman, or a woman who wants but is unable to conceive, one should cook the root of winter cherry with ghee,[695] blend it with cow’s milk, and dilute it with more milk. One should incant it twenty-five times and give it to such a woman to drink during her period, after bathing. The householder-husband, staying away from the wives of others and avoiding inappropriate sexual conduct, should then approach her sexually, or she him. She will then conceive a son. “If she experiences bleeding within the next three to five years when she is with child; if she does not conceive a child for many years;[696] if she is harmed by the mantra magic, medicines, or mudrās of others;[697] if she suffers a miscarriage; if she falls ill; if there is any other disorder caused by others; or if she is poisoned by animate or inanimate, or natural or artificial means‍—if any of this was effected by the friendly or hostile use of any root or medicine mantras, one should chant the mantra twenty-seven times and then grind old ghee with the moon-like eye of a peacock feather, making it homogenous. When it is finely ground, one should mix it with sugar and eat an amount the size of myrobalan fruit every day over seven days. “The patient should be made to drink milk cooked with sugar, having incanted it again and again. If one has a headache, one should wipe the head with a crow’s pinion incanted seven times. One will become well. “For female disease such as hypermenorrhea, one should grind the root of nīlikā[698] together with milk,[699] add to it some root of the indigo plant, and incant this one hundred and eight times. One should then blend it with milk and give it to the patient to drink. Similarly, in the case of a fever, be it a quartan, one-day, two-day, three-day, chronic, constant, or recurrent one, one should have the patient drink milk with ghee, incanted one hundred and eight times. The patient will become well.

de bzhin du mkha' 'gro ma'i gdon gyis zin pa dag la ni/ bdag nyid kyi gdong la lan brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags te nad pa la bltas na bde bar gnas par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du ma mo dang byis pa dang lus srul po dang ro langs dang gzhon nu'i gdon la sogs pa mi ma yin pa'i mi bzad pa'i gdon thams cad kyis zin pa la ni/ bdag nyid kyilag pa la lan brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags pa byas nas gdon gyis zin pa'i mgo la reg par byas na bde bar gnas par 'gyur ro/ /

“Similarly, if someone is seized by a ḍākinī or a graha,[700] one should incant one’s own face one hundred and eight times and face the affected person; they will become well. Similarly, if someone is seized by any terrible and evil nonhuman being, such as a mātṛkā, a pūtanā that attacks children, a vetāla, or a graha that seizes children, one should incant one’s own hand one hundred and eight times and touch the affected person on the head. They will become well.

lan cig bzlas pas bdag nyid bsrung bar 'gyur ro/ / lan gnyis bzlas pas grogs po bsrung bar 'gyur ro/ / lan gsum bzlas pas khyim bsrung bar 'gyur ro/ / lan bzhi bzlas pas ni grong bsrung bar 'gyur ro/ / lan lnga bzlas pas ni grong gi spyod yul gyi 'gro ba bsrung bar 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du lan stong gi bar du bzlas na dmag gi tshogs bsrung ba byas par yang 'gyur ro/ / de dag dang gzhan yang ma bsgrubs par las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / ci ste sgrub par 'dod na ni las phran tshegs rnams bya ba ma yin te/ gcig pu dben pa'i gnas su song nas rgya mtshor 'bab pa'i chu bo 'byung ba'i gnas dang / rgya mtsho'i ngogs dang chu bo gang gA'i ngogs dang / gzhan gang yang rung ba'i chu bo chen po'i ngogs la brten nas/ gtsang ma'i gnas su lo ma'i spyil po byas te/ khrus lan gsum bya zhing gos lan gsum brjes la/ thub par gnas shing slong mo'i kha zas bza' ba'am tshod rngad dam/ khyor gang tsam mam 'o ma 'am/ 'bras bu za zhing bzlas pa sum 'bum byas te/ grub pa'i mtshan ma mthong na de nas sgrub pa brtsam par bya'o/ /

“A single repetition of the mantra will protect oneself; a double repetition, one’s friends; a triple one, one’s house; a fourfold one, one’s village; a fivefold one, everybody within the greater village area; up until, with one thousand repetitions, one may protect an army. One may perform these and all the other similar minor acts, even if one has not fully mastered the mantra. “One who desires accomplishment should not engage in trivial activities.[701] One should go alone to a secluded place at the source of a river that flows into the ocean or on the ocean shore, on the bank of the Gaṅgā, or on the bank of any big river. There, in a clean spot, one should build a hut.[702] One should perform the threefold ablutions, wear the three garments, observe silence, and live on food obtained by begging or on the practitioner’s diet of milk, barley, and fruit. Living thus, one should recite the mantra three million times. Then, once the sign has been observed, one should commence the sādhana practice.

phyogs de nyid du ras ris chen po bzhag la/ ras ris la mchod pa chen po byas te/ mar me'i snod gser ram dngul lam zangs sam sa'i rang bzhin la/ shing du ru ska'i 'bru mar gyis bkang ba'am dri zhim po'i 'bru mar gyis bkang ba 'am ba'i mar gyis yongs su bkang ba'i mar me ras kyi dum bu sar pa'i snying po byas te ras ris kyi mdun du 'bum phrag gcig gi mar me dbul bar bya'o/ / kho ra khor yug tu mar me'i phreng ba phul ma thag tu ras ris las 'od 'byung ste/ 'od byung ma thag tu ras ris kyi kho ra khor yug tu 'od 'bar ba'i phreng bas kun nas khyab par 'gyur ro/ / steng gi nam mkha' bar snang las rnga bo che'i sgra sgrogs shing legs so zhes bya ba'i sgra yang thos te/ de nas rig pa 'dzin pas rings pa'i tshul gyis sgrub pa pos ras ris kyi mtha' la sngar bris pa'i ras ris kyi mtha' nas mchod yon gsol/ lan gsum bskor ba byas te sangs rgyas thams cad la phyag 'tshal nas gzung bar bya'o/ / de nas de bzung ba tsam gyis mar me thams cad 'dzin pa'i sems can rnams gcig gis lhag pa'i gzhal med khang 'bum dang lhan cig 'phur bar 'gyur ro/ / lha'i sil snyan dang yang dag par ldan pa dang / glu snyan pa'i sgra la sogs pa dang ldan pa dang / gar dang ldan pa'i rig pa 'dzin ma 'khor yug tu khyab pa dag gis mar me thogs pa dang lhan cig sgrub pa po rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal por dbang skur bar byed do/ / rga ba dang 'chi ba med pas rol par 'gyur zhing / bskal pa chen por gnas shing nyi ma dang 'dra ba dang / lha'i yan lag lta bur mdzes pa dang / gos rnam pa sna tshogs kyis brgyan pa dang / 'khor de dag dang yang 'di lhan cig tu spyad par 'gyur ro/ /

“On that location, in the same place, one should install the superior[703] painting and offer a big pūjā with lamps of gold and silver, or of copper and clay, filled with olibanum oil or ghee,[704] with wicks made of high-quality fabric. One should prepare one hundred thousand[705] such lamps and offer all of them before the painting. “With the lighted lamps evenly arranged in contiguous rows, light will radiate from the painting. The moment the light shines, the painting will be haloed with a blazing ring of light that pervades everywhere. In the sky above drums will sound and congratulatory cheers will be heard. “At that point, a vidyādhara, in a form that delights sentient beings, will emerge from the corner where the practitioner is depicted on the previously painted cloth. One should give him a welcome offering, circumambulate him, bow to all the buddhas, and seize him. As soon as one has seized him, one will fly up together with all the beings holding lamps and, perhaps, ascend to 100,001[706] palaces. Surrounded by vidyādharīs playing divine instruments, singing songs in sweet voices, and dancing, one will be consecrated by them to kingship as a vidyādhara-cakravartin. Together with the holders of the lamps, one will revel in freedom from old age and death, endure for a great eon, have the luster of the rising sun and divinely beautiful limbs, and be adorned with a diverse array of garments.[707]

rig pa 'dzin pa thams cad kyang 'di'i bran bzhin du nye bar gnas par 'gyur te/ rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ / ring du 'tsho ba dang grub pa thams cad kyis mi tshugs par 'gyur ro/ / rig pa 'dzin pa rnams kyi bu mo rnams la mchog tu yid du 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / rdzas thams cad la dbang du 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams rgyal mtshan gyi rtse mo la bzhugs par 'gyur ro/ / skad cig gis tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du 'gro zhing brgya byin la yang bgrang ba med na/ rig pa 'dzin pa gzhan lta ci smos/ 'di ni mthar yang sangs rgyas nyid du 'gyur zhing / 'phags pa 'jam dpal yang 'di'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen du 'gyur ro/ /

“The vidyādharas, for their part, will become one’s servants.[708] Together with them, one will travel around as the king of all of them,[709] and they will attend upon one as servants. One will become a monarch of vidyādharas. One will live long, be unassailable by all siddhas, be supremely attractive to vidyādhara girls, and will master all substances. One will worship the buddhas and bodhisattvas and will be placed on the pinnacle of their victory banners.[710] One will be able to ascend even to the world of Brahmā in an instant. One will not even need to consider Śakra, let alone other vidyādharas. In the end, one will attain the state of awakening. Noble Mañjuśrī will become one’s spiritual friend.[711]

gzhan yang las kyi sgrub pa po yod de/ de nas shin tu brtson pas gcig pu dben pa/ skye bo med la 'dres pa med cing 'dres pa dang bral bas dgon pa chen por zhugs te/ gnas gang du pad+ma chen po yod pa'i mtsho dang ldan pa'i ri'i rtse mo gcig tu brten nas/ ri'i rtse mo de'i steng du 'dzegs te/ rig pa'i rgyal po yi ge gcig pa 'jam dpal gyi cho ga las bshad pa'am/ de bzhin gshegs pa'am/ gzhan byang chub sems dpas bshad pa'am/ gang yang rung ba'i sngags 'dod pa de dag bzung ste/ pad+ma'i rtsa ba'am 'o ma'i kha zas kyis 'tsho zhing / rig pa 'bum phrag sum cu rtsa drug bzlas la/ bzlas pa'i mthar cho ga de nyid kyis sngar bstan pa'i ras ris kyi ri mo chen po rab tu bzhag ste/ me tog pad+ma la tsan+dan dkar po dang / gur gum gyis btags la seng ldeng gi shing gi me sbar te/ sngar yongs su btags pa'i me tog gis stong phrag drug cu rtsa drug gi sbyin sreg bya'o/ /

“There are, however, those practitioners whose[712] sādhana practice is more intense. In such a case, one should go alone to a secluded place free from the distractions of attachment. One should retreat to a big forest and find a place where there is a lotus pond adjacent to a lonely mountain and fed by a stream.[713] One should climb to the top of the mountain and, having chosen either the single-syllable vidyārāja taught in the Mañjuśrī’s manual of rites, one taught by the Tathāgata or another bodhisattva, or any other one prefers, one should live on lotus roots and milk products, recite the vidyāmantra three million six hundred thousand times. At the end of the recitation, one should install, following the same procedure as previously taught, the superior one of the previously taught types of painting and prepare the lotus flowers smeared with white sandalwood and saffron paste. Having lit a fire of cutch tree sticks, one should offer into the fire the already-prepared lotuses thirty-six thousand times.

de nas sbyin sreg gi mthar bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i ras ris las 'od zer 'byung ngo / / de nas sgrub pa po snang bar byas te/ spyi bor zhugs par 'gyur la des reg ma thag tu sgrub pa pos mngon par shes pa lnga thob par 'gyur ro/ / byang chub sems dpa'i sa thob par 'gyur/ lha'i lus kyis ci ltar 'dod pa bzhin du 'gro bar 'gyur/ bskal pa sum cu rtsa drug gi bar du 'tsho bar 'gyur/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing sum cu rtsa drug gnon par 'gyur/ de dag gi mthu yang dag par rjes su mthong bar 'gyur/ sangs rgyas sum cu rtsa drug gi gsung rab 'dzin par 'gyur/ de la mchod cing bsnyen bkur ba la mngon par dga' bar 'gyur/ mthar yang byang chub la gzhol bar 'gyur/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyis byang chub kyi mthar thug pa/ mya ngan las 'das kyi bar du dge ba'i bshes gnyen du yongs su 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /

“Then, at the conclusion of the homa rite, rays of light will issue forth from the painting of Lord Śākyamuni. Having illumined the practitioner, they will dissolve into his head. As soon as one is touched by these rays, one will attain the five superknowledges. Having attained the levels of a bodhisattva, one will go about as one pleases in the form of a god. One will live thirty-six eons and will traverse thirty-six buddhafields, beholding all their might. One will memorize the teachings of the thirty-six buddhas and will delight in worshiping and serving them. In the end, dedicated to the attainment of awakening, one will be wholly taken care of by the spiritual friend, Noble Mañjuśrī, right until the ultimate state of awakening, the final nirvāṇa.”

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo sde 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga dgu pa'i le'u rab 'byam las/ gnyis pa sgrub pa'i thabs dam pa'i las kyi le'u rab 'byam rdzogs so// //

This concludes the ninth chapter of “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings. This chapter constitutes the detailed second[714] chapter on the ritual involving the supreme sādhana method.
ras ris chen po'i cho ga'i le'u
Chapter 10
