de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas sgrub pa'i las dam pa gzhan yang gsungs te/ cho ga'i rgyal po 'di las gang yang rung ba'i sngags bzung nas/ gang gA'i klung chen por zhugs te/ dkyil du gru'i bzhon pa la 'dug ste/ 'o ma dang sbyar ba'i 'bras chan za zhing ci ltar 'dod pa'i nyi ma la bzlas pa sum 'bum bya'o/ / de nas bzlas pa'i tha ma la klu thams cad mthong ste/ de nas bsgrub pa brtsam par bya'o/ / gru'i steng de nyid kyi nang du me thab pad+ma'i rnam pa 'dra ba byas nas/ me tog nA ga ge sar dag gis ras ris la mchod pa chen po byas te/ ras ris chen po nub du bstan pas bzhag la/ bdag nyid shar du bltas nas ku sha'i khres la 'dug ste/ me tog nA ga ge sar re re la yang lan bdun bdun bsngags pa byas nas/ shing seng ldeng gis me sbar ba la sbyin sreg bya ste/ tsan+dan dkar po dang gur gum dang bsres pa'i me tog nA ga ge sar gyis lan stong phrag sum cu rtsa drug gi bar du bya ste/ gzhan gyis ni ma yin no/ / klu rnams mthong ba yang don yod pa yin te/ grub pa'i rdzas rnams la rab tu chags pas blang bar mi bya ste/ grub pa'i rdzas rnams la chags pas len par mi byed na/ des na sbyin sreg rdzogs pa dang gru'i bzhon pa dang bcas par 'phur bar 'gyur te/ rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur la/ klu'i rgyal po'i dbang po thams cad kyang su 'brang zhing bran bzhin du gnas par 'gyur ro/ / bar gyi bskal pa sum cur 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / 'di rang dbang du'ang spyod par 'gyur ro/ / 'gro ba la thogs pa med par 'gyur ro/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal mngon sum du mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / spyi bo la phyag gis reg par mdzad de/ reg pa tsam gyis mngon par shes pa lnga thob par 'gyur ro/ / nges par sangs rgyas nyid kyang 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /

At that time Lord Śākyamuni taught yet another supreme ritual practice: “Having chosen another mantra from this king of manuals, one should go down to [the bank of] the great river Gaṅgā. Staying in a boat in the middle of the river, one should incant rice gruel mixed with milk three million times on the days of one’s choice. Subsequently, at the end of recitation, one will perceive all the nāgas. One should then start the main practice. For that, one should prepare, in the middle of the boat, a fire pit in the shape of a lotus. One should prepare a big offering of ironwood blossoms to the painting. The painting of the superior type should be positioned facing west, with oneself sitting on a bundle of kuśa grass facing east. One should incant each of the ironwood blossoms seven times and offer it into the blazing fire of cutch tree sticks. One should do this until one has offered thirty thousand such blossoms, each smeared with white sandalwood and saffron paste. One should use nothing else. One should wait for the nāgas to appear.[715] They will be enticed by the power substances, but will not take them. “Then, at the conclusion of the homa ritual, one will fly up together with the boat. One will become a vidyādhara-cakravartin, and all the nāga kings will become one’s followers, acting as servants. One will live thirty intermediate eons and will be able to act as one pleases. One’s activities will be unimpeded. One will be able to perceive Noble Mañjuśrī face to face. He will touch one on the head, and as soon as he has done so, one will obtain the five superknowledges. One will be certain to attain buddhahood.

las kyi mchog gzhan yang bstan pa ni bil ba'i shing gcig gi rang bzhin las gru'i bzhon pa shin du brtan pa dang / legs par byas te de la zhon nas gang gA'i klung chen por zhugs te/ bil ba'i shing las rlung yor byas te/ de nyid kyis gru de rlung yor 'dzin pa mkhas pa gsal ba des phyag par bya'o/ / gang gA'i klung chen po mi dor bar yongs su thad ka'am/ chur phyag par bya'o/ / de nas gzhan gang yang rung ba'i sngags rtsa ba'i sngags sam/ 'bru drug pa'am/ 'bru gsum pa'am/ 'bru brgyad pa'am 'bru gcig pa'am/ khro bo'am pho nya'am/ 'khor gyi sngags bzung nas/ dang por ras ris chen po de nyid nub tu bltas pas bzhag la/ sgrub pa po shar du blta bar bya'o/ / de nas ci ltar 'dod pa'i 'o ma dang / nas chan khyor gang ngam 'bras bu'i kha zas sam/ chu dang rtsa ba dang / 'bras bu'i kha zas kyis 'tsho la mi smra ba'i dka' thub dang / dus gsum du khrus bya zhing gos lan gsum brjes nas dge ba'i las bzang po yang dag par spyod pa dang / blo dge ba bzang po dang ldan pa'o/ / dang por re zhig ras ris kyi mdun du sngar ci ltar bstan pa'i sngar bshad pa'i cho gas rig pa 'bum phrag drug cu bzla'o/ / bzlas pa zin pa na gru de rgya mtsho chen por 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ /

“There is another supreme ritual practice. One should descend to the bank of the great river Gaṅgā and construct a boat from a single block of wood from the bilva tree. It ought to be well made and attractive. One should board it,[716] bringing an oar of bilva wood. With this, one should propel the boat, employing a genuinely skilled assistant. One should have him row the boat, without leaving the great river Gaṅgā, in circles, across, or lengthwise.[717] One should choose either the six-syllable root mantra, the eight-syllable mantra, the single-syllable one, or another, such as those of the wrathful deities, dūtas, or dūtīs, or yet another mantra.[718] One should then install the painting of the superior type facing west, with the practitioner facing east. From this point onward one can conduct the ritual as one wishes. One should use either a dish of milk, barley, and fruit, or one of water, radishes, and fruit. One should observe silence, ritually bathe three times a day, and possess three changes of clothing. One should practice pure conduct, with a very pure mind. First, one should recite the mantra,[719] in front of the painting, six million times, following the previously described procedure. Then, at the end of the recitation, the boat will be fit to sail across a big ocean.

sgrub pa po'i yo byad yang dag par blangs te sngar gyi gnas su gzhag par bya'o/ / de nas gru'i bzhon pa rgya mtsho chen por 'gro ba na 'jigs par mi bya ste bzlog par yang mi bya'o/ / sgrub pa po ma gtogs pas zlog par nus pa yang ma yin no/ / de nas dpag tshad stong du gnas pa'i rgya mtsho chen por yang yud tsam gyis 'jug par 'gyur na/ lam thung ngu lta smos kyang ci dgos/ rgya mtsho chen po der phyin pa na sgrub pa pos bsgrub pa'i las brtsam par bya'o/ / de nas seng ldeng gi shing gi me sbar la/ sngar byas pa'i me thab bam/ rdza mkhan gyis byas pa'i sa'i snod la/ me tog nA ga ge sar tsan+dan dkar po dang ga pur gyis bsres pa'i sreg blugs kyis shin tu nyung ba'am rab tu mang ba yang rung 'bum phrag drug cu sbyin sreg bya'o/ / sbyin sreg byed pa na yang lang ka'i grong khyer na gnas pa'i srin po gzugs dang cha byad mang po 'dzin pa ha ha zhes bya ba'i sgra sgrogs pa dang / klu'i grong khyer gdengs ka dang ldan pa na gnas pa'i rgyal po rnams langs par 'gyur te/ cha byad rnam pa sna tshogs 'dzin pa rab tu drag pa dang / rab tu zhi ba'i klu de rnams dang / srin po de rnams 'di skad du khyed bzhengs shig bzhengs shig / bdag cag gi bdag po mdzad du gsol zhes brjod do/ / de bzhin du lha ma yin dang gnod sbyin dang / lha dang lto 'phye chen po dang grub pa dang mi ma yin pa thams cad kyang rab tu chags par byed na ldang bar mi bya/ 'jigs par mi bya'o/ /

“For that reason, the practitioner should collect the things that he will need and put them in the boat in advance. He should not be afraid when sailing across the great ocean. The boat will not be obstructed. It cannot be forced to turn back, except through the practitioner’s own will. He will thus be able to enter the big ocean in an instant even if this ocean is a thousand leagues away, so what need is there even to mention short distances? “Having entered it, this home of all rivers, one should start one’s practice.[720] Having lit a fire of cutch tree sticks in a previously constructed pit or a clay basin made by a potter, one should offer into the fire six million oblations of stamens of ironwood blossoms mixed with white sandalwood and camphor. These individual oblations could be either small or big. “While one is offering the oblations, the rākṣasas who dwell in Laṅkā and assume many forms will cry, ‘Ha, ha!’ The nāga kings who dwell in Bhogavatī, a city of the nāgas, will emerge from the water in their different forms, ranging from exceedingly fierce to very peaceful. These nāgas and rākṣasas will say, ‘Get up, sir, get up! Become our master!’ In this way, the asuras, the yakṣas, the gods, the mahoragas, the celestial siddhas, and all the humans will try to entice the practitioner. One should neither get up, nor be afraid.

de nas rig pa 'dzin pas sngags zlo zhing / lag pa g.yon pa'i mdzub mos sdigs mdzub byas na/ de nas phan tshun du 'gro ba dang 'byor ba dang 'bros par byed do/ / de nas sbyin sreg zin pa na gru de sgrub pa po des blangs na skad cig gis 'og min du 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / 'jig rten gyi khams gzhan du yang 'gro ba dang 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / byang chub sems dpa'i sems dang mthu mnyam par 'gyur/ mngon par shes pa lnga dang rdzu 'phrul chen po dang mthu chen po dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / 'dis 'phags pa 'jam dpal yang rtag tu mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang / rang sangs rgyas dang 'phags pa nyan thos ma gtogs pa/ klu'i rgyal po thams cad dang srin po thams cad dang gnod sbyin thams cad dang / lha thams cad dang lha ma yin thams cad dang / sems can thams cad kyang 'di'i bka' bzhin byed cing dbang du 'gyur ro/ / 'di'i sngags grub pa de dag la yang byams pa'i bdag nyid du 'gyur zhing rjes su dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / sems can thams cad kyis kyang mi thub pa'i bar du 'gyur ro/ /

“At that time, the adept of vidyās should, while reciting the mantra, threaten them with the index finger of the left hand. They will then disperse, running hither and thither, and be gone.[721] Then, at the conclusion of the homa ritual, they will seize the boat together with the practitioner and, in an instant, take it to the realm of Akaniṣṭha. One can thus go to and return from other world spheres. One will become equal in mental power to a bodhisattva,[722] possessing the five superknowledges, great magical abilities, and great power. One will be able to see Noble Mañjuśrī at all times. All the nāgas, rākṣasas, gods, asuras, and every other being will come under one’s control, having been appointed to carry out one’s orders by all the buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, noble śrāvakas, and those who have accomplished the mantra. They will be lovingly disposed toward the practitioner and act in his interest, so that he cannot be harmed by any being.[723]

gzhan yang las sgrub pa'i thabs dam pa yod de/ shing bil ba chen po las gru'i bzhon pa byas la yang shing gcig gi shing gi tshogs las gnas chen po byas te/ gang gA'i dbus kyi gling der gru'i bzhon pa'i gnas byas la/ der yang gru'i bzhon pa la zhon pa'i skyes bu brgya nyi shu rnams mar me lag na thogs pa/ gos dkar po bgos pa srung ba byas pa/ cho ga snga mas yang dag par bzhag pa'i ras ris mdun du gzhag par bya ste/ de nas ras ris la mchod pa chen po byas nas/ nA ga ge sar gyi phye ma tsan+dan dkar po dang gur gum dang ga pur gyis bsres pa'i sreg blugs kyis seng ldeng gi me la stong phrag sum cu rtsa drug sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas sbyin sreg zin pa na/ skad cig gis tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du 'gro ba dang 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / ci ltar 'dod pa bzhin du rnam par rgyu bar byed do/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa mngon sum du mthong bar 'gyur te/ mthong ba tsam gyis sa thob par yang 'gyur ro/ / mngon par shes pa lnga 'thob pa dang yun ring du 'tsho zhing bskal pa chen por gnas par yang 'gyur ro/ / rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar yang 'gyur ro/ / mar me 'dzin pa de dag kyang rig pa 'dzin pa 'di'i grogs por 'gyur te/ de dag dang lhan cig ci ltar 'dod pa bzhin du rgyu zhing rang dbang du 'gro bar yang 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams la mchod pa dang bsnyen bkur byed par mngon par dga' bar 'gyur zhing / 'phral yang sangs rgyas nyid du nges par 'gyur ro/ /

“There is another supreme ritual practice. One should commission the construction of a boat from a big log of bilva wood, or perhaps from the pieces of a single block of wood. One should construct a big wharf on an island in the middle of the Gaṅgā. One should build a boat docked at that place. In that boat, there should be one hundred and twenty passengers‍—each holding a flower and a lamp‍—who have performed the protection rite and are wearing white clothes. One should have them place the flowers and the lamps in front of the superior of the different types of painting, installed according to the previously described procedure.[724] One should then perform a large pūjā in front of the painting and offer into the cutch-wood fire thirty-six thousand oblations of powdered ironwood blossoms mixed with saffron, white sandalwood, and camphor. “Subsequently, at the conclusion of the homa ritual, the boat will ascend to the world of Brahmā in an instant. When one arrives there, one will be able to move around at will. One will perceive Noble Mañjuśrī face to face. As soon as one beholds him, one will attain the bodhisattva levels and the five superknowledges. One will live for a long time, enduring for one great eon. One will become the great monarch of the vidyādharas, who, holding lamps in their hands, will become one’s helpers. Together with them one will be able to wander as one pleases; one will be able to go wherever one wants to. One will delight in worshiping the blessed buddhas.[725] In the end, one will be certain to attain buddhahood.
gzhan yang sgrub pa'i thabs kyi las dam pa yod de/ chu klung rgya mtsho'i 'gram dag gam/ / de bzhin ri bo kha ba can/ / ri yi rgyal po 'bigs byed la/ / las kyi mchog ni bsgrub par bya/ /
“There is yet another supreme ritual practice. One will accomplish the supreme ritual On a riverbank or an ocean shore, Or also on the snowy mountain‍— The king of the Vindhya range.
ma la ya ri sa ha dang / / spos kyi ngad ldang ar bu dang / / ri yi rgyal po sum brtsegs la/ / las kyi mchog ni bsgrub par bya/ /
“One will accomplish the supreme ritual In the Sahya mountain range, In Arbuda, or on Gandhamādana Mountain‍— This three-peaked king of mountains‍—
de bzhin rgya mtsho chen po dang / / ri ni shing ldan me tog yod/ / 'di dag gi ni phyogs dag tu/ / sngags grub par ni rgyal bas gsungs/ /
“Or similarly, by the great ocean, Or on a mountain rich in trees and flowers. It is in these places that the mantras Taught by the victorious ones can be accomplished.
gtsang zhing bas mtha' dben phyogs su/ / grong gi chos ni rnam par spangs/ / de bzhin ri yi tshang tshing du/ / sngags kyi rgyal po thams cad 'grub/ /
“In a secluded place in the wilderness, Free from the vulgar pursuits of lust, Will the kings of mantras be accomplished‍— In particular, in inaccessible mountain caves.
bas mtha'i gnas mal nyams dga' dang / / rgyal bas de bzhin bsngags pa dang / / ma rungs sems can thams cad la/ / sngags kyi rgyal po thams cad 'grub/ /
“The kings of mantras will be accomplished In pleasant places of retreat, The ones particularly recommended by the victorious ones, Free from wicked beings.

chos ldan rgyal po yod pa dang / / gtsang sbra spyod pa'i skye bo yod/ / pha dang ma la gus pa dang / / bram ze'i rigs ni yod pa yi/ / gnas der lha rnams 'grub 'gyur te/ / gzhan du 'grub pa ma yin no/ /

“Places where the king is righteous And people follow pure conduct, Where mothers and fathers are revered, And which are not without the twice born[726]‍— In such places and no others Will the deities grant an accomplishment.
chu bo gang gA'i 'gram dang ni/ / de bzhin legs mdzes ya mu na/ / sin+du nar ma dA nang dang / / zla ba'i cha ni gtsang ngogs dang / /
“On the pleasant bank of the Bhāgīrāthī,[727] Or the bank of the Yamunā, so beautiful, Or the Indus, the Narmadā, the Oxus,[728] Or the clean bank of the Candrabhāgā,
de bzhin kA ba'i sa ra swad/ / chu bo chen po sI ta rnams/ / 'di dag grub pa'i zhing du ni/ / stobs bcu ldan sras rnams kyis bshad/ /

“And also the rivers Kāverī, Sarasvatī, Or the Sitā,[729] this great river of the gods‍— All these have been declared by the sons[730] of those who possess the ten powers To be places of accomplishment.
stobs bcu ldan pas bshad pa'i zhing / / byang phyogs yod pa'i ri dag dang / / kha che dang ni rgya yul dang / / bal po de bzhin mang yul dang / /
“Among the places recommended by the those with the ten powers[731] Are the mountain ranges of the north, Including in Kaśmīra, Tibet, Nepāla, and Kāviśa,

rgya yul che dang li yul dag / de dag ma lus grub pa'i zhing / / byang phyogs la ni gnas pa dang / / nas dang gro la spyod pa dang / / ri dang chu bo dag la yang / / bsod nams yul du bstan pa yin/ / sems can snying rje ldan gang gnas/ / de dag la ni nges 'grub 'gyur/ /

“And also all the places in China[732] That bring various accomplishments, And the mountains and streams That are located in northern countries. “Countries where people consume wheat and barley Have been declared to be meritorious. Where the inhabitants are compassionate, The accomplishments will certainly be attained.

dpal gyi ri bo'i ri chen ni/ / lho yi phyogs na yang dag gnas/ / dpal ldan 'bras phung mchod rten ni/ / rgyal ba'i ring bsrel gnas pa'i sa/ / thams cad don gyi gnas dag la/ / der ni sngags rnams myur du 'grub/ / mchod rten chen po rdo rje gdan/ / chos kyi 'khor lo rab bskor dang / / thub mchog zhi bar rab gshegs pa/ / der yang grub par rab tu snang / / lha las babs pa'i mchod rten dang / / nai ka sha dang cho 'phrul bstan/ / grong mchog ser skya zhes bya dang / / nags tshal lum bi nir 'khrungs la/ / sngags kyi rgyal po 'grub 'gyur zhes/ / rgyal bas rab bsngags brjod pa yin/ / bya rgod phung po'i ri dang ni/ / de bzhin sa steng bsil ba'i tshal/ / grong mchog me tog ces bya dang / / rtag tu de bzhin ga sha dang / / bcom brlag ka n+ya kub dza dang / / sa steng grong ni 'phags rgyal dang / / de bzhin yangs pa can mchod rten/ / mi thi la yi grong khyer sa/ / grong dang grong khyer mchog dag ni/ / gang gzhan skye bo yang dag 'byung / / rab bsngags bsod nams yul dag ni/ / de dag la ni bsgrub pa bya/ / de dang gzhan yang yul dag dang / / grong dang ljongs dang ri bor dang / / gnas dang grong mchog gtso bo ni/ / bsod nams gnas la rab brten nas/ / der ni slong mos rjes 'tsho zhing / / bzlas dang sbyin sreg dga' ba dang / / gnas khang bla gab med pa dang / / rtag tu khyim ni stong pa la/ / sngags rnams las ni thams cad la/ / thog ma nyid du bya ba yin/ / sngags pas rtag tu yul dbus su/ / sngags bzlas mngon par 'dod pas bya/ / bzlas la rab zhugs rtag tu brtson/ / sngags rig gtong ba dag la goms/ / tshul khrims spyod cing shin tu dben/ / 'byung po kun la phan par dga'/ / sngags spyod pa la dga' ba yi/ / sdom brtson gyis ni sngags bzlas bya/ / gtsang zhing gtsang sbra yod phyogs dang / / kla klo rkun ma rnam par spangs/ /

“The great mountain, Śrīparvata, Renowned in the Deccan, And the temple in the glorious country of Dhānyakaṭaka, Where the relics of the Victorious One are kept here on earth‍— “There the mantras can be swiftly accomplished For the sake of all ritual purposes. In the great temple of the Vajra Seat, Where the splendid wheel of Dharma has been turned, “The supreme sage attained tranquility; There, also, can the accomplishment be seen. In the great temple where the Sage descended from the gods’ realm; In the country of Saṃkaśya,[733] the place of great miracles; “In the great city called Kapilavastu; in the best of the forests, Lumbini, Where the most eminent of people [was born]‍— There the kings of mantras bring accomplishment, In the places praised by the Victorious One. “So, too, on Vulture Peak Mountain, Or the place called Śītavana; In the great, pleasant city called Kusuma, And always in Vārāṇasī; “In Mathurā, Kanyakubja, Or the city called Ujjain; By the stūpa of Vaiśālī, Or in the place called Mithilā‍— “Whatever cities and towns there are, Or other places with human population, If they are praised as places of merit, Accomplishments will be attained in them. “Living in these and other places‍— Villages, hamlets, and market towns, Fine cities, the best of capitals, Cities located on rivers, rich in merit‍— “And subsisting there on alms, one should joyfully engage In mantra recitation and homa ritual, Always occupying a place With an open space or empty area. “One should do the preliminary practice Before commencing any mantra rites. The mantra practitioner, always in the center, Should recite the mantra with great yearning.[734] “Always engaged in recitation, The mantra adept should practice renunciation, Comport himself in a disciplined way, be truthful,[735] And delight in doing good for all beings. “First engendering faith in the mantra practice[736] And keeping one’s observances, one should recite In a clean place at a good location, Free from barbarians and thieves‍—

sems can sdig sbrul la sogs pa/ / spangs pa'i sa phyogs 'dod pa yis/ / 'bras bu me tog yang dag ldan/ / dri med rab bsngags chu yod par/ / sngags rigs sngags ni brten byas na/ / sbyor ba thams cad rab tu 'grub/ /

“A place where there is no harm From any creeping animals,[737] A place abounding in fruits and flowers, Praiseworthy, and supplied with pure water. “A mantra adept is praised [if he recites] All the mantras in no other places than these.[738]

The recommended sites are a temple, A cemetery, or a lonely mountain. “A mantra adept also recites all mantras By a solitary lingam, or in a wilderness. One should perform the protection ritual For oneself and one’s friends, and do the preparatory rites. “The reciter, always engaged in recitation, Should always practice the supreme mantra In a great forest with big trees, Rich in blossoms and bearing fruits. “ . . .[739] On a mountaintop, in a valley, Or in a nice place with clean water, Such as the bank of a big river. “The mantra adept should practice the mantra In places . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[740] In the eastern country by the Brahmaputra, The great and beautiful river. “Also in the country of Kāmarūpa, With its thriving and splendid cities, Or where the best of rivers[741] flows, Full of merits, winding on the valley floor‍— “In such a place should the reciter Do his devotion, remaining pure.[742] He should do the preliminary practice Intended for all the rites. “And definitely at the mouth of the Gaṅgā, Where the river empties into the ocean, Should he also recite his mantra, remaining pure And keeping the observances enjoined for whatever methods.

gzhan yang dur khrod chen po ni/ / der ni bzlas pa rtag tu bya/ / dri med chu dang 'bab chu ni/ / srog chags dag kyang rnam par spangs/ / der ni de nyid bzla bya ste/ / mnyam par bzhag pas sngags bzlas bya/ / 'jig rten spyod pa'i bsod nams min/ / der ni cung zad mi mthong ste/ /

“The great cemeteries, too, Are where the reciter should always recite, Or rivers with pure waters, Free of worm-like creatures. “So, the reciter should always recite the mantra In those places with a focused mind, Because no merit shall be seen By one engaged in the affairs of the world.

'on kyang sngags ni bstan pa yis/ / cung zad dus ni bstan pa'o/ / dam tshig tshogs pa'i rgyu ldan na/ / de las gzhan du'ang 'gro bya ste/ / der ni dam tshig thob bsten pa/ / cung zad dus te gzhan du min/ / de nas gzhan du'ang myur du ni/ / sngags rig pas ni ci nus 'gro/ /

“However, for the sake of mantra instructions, One may remain[743] in the world for some time; Otherwise, one should go elsewhere, Departing at the time of a lunar eclipse.[744] “Having obtained the samaya, one may remain In the world for a short time, not otherwise. Later the adept of mantras should, without delay, Go elsewhere, wherever he is able to.

bde gshegs mchod rten bzhugs pa yi/ / sa steng dag la rtag tu bsten/ / 'jig rten mu stegs thams cad ni/ / lta ba log par ltung ba dang / / gzhan yang stegs su gyur pa rnams/ / sngags rig pas ni rtag tu spang / / rgyu ngan 'gro ba ngan yod par/ / sngags rig pas ni der mi bsten/ / gang du rgyal ba mchog bzhugs dang / / sa steng bse ru rang rgyal dang / / byang chub sems dpa' skal ba che/ / nyan thos rgyal ba'i sras dag ni/ / de dag gnas pa'i phyogs dag tu/ / zlos pa sngags rig ldan pas bsten/ / 'bad pas snga ma nyid du ni/ / gnas de la ni rtag tu spyod/ /

“He should always dwell in places where there are The dazzling white reliquaries of the tathāgatas, And also all the holy sites in this world Where wrong doctrines are absent‍— “The mantra adept should always avoid Other holy sites.[745] An expert in mantras should not dwell in them, As they constitute the cause of bad rebirth. “Instead, he should dwell in those places on earth That have been visited by the best of victors, The rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddhas, the great bodhisattva beings, The śrāvakas, or the sons of the victorious ones. “The mantra adept, reciting his mantra, Should frequent all these places. In such places he should always practice With great effort as previously explained.

sngags shes cho ga mthong ba yis/ / yang dang yang du sngags zlos bya/ / lus can sdig pa ma lus dag / bzlas dang sbyin sreg dag gis sel/ / de bas 'bad pa kun gyis ni/ / mnyam bzhag sngags ni bzla bar bya/ /

“Knowing the right procedure, the mantra adept Should recite the mantra ever more, For through the recitation and the homa ritual He will remove all the evil of embodied beings. He should therefore recite the mantra With all his diligence and a focused mind.

las thams cad la gnas 'di dag gsungs pa las sgrub pa mchog gi las kyi thabs sgrub pa la gnas 'di dag ma rnyed na/ gang yang rung ba'i gnas de dag tu gtsang sbra byas te sngon du bsnyen pa byas la/ dad cing mos pas sgrub pa'i thabs kyi lam dam pa brtsam par bya ste/ dang por re zhig ras ris chen po nub tu bltas pas bzhag ste/ bdag nyid shar du bltas la/ grog mkhar gyi sa'am/ gang gA'i klung gi ngogs na yod pa'i sa blangs te/ rtswa u shi ra dang tsan+dan dkar po dang gur gum dang ga pur la sogs pas bsre ba bya ste/ rma bya'i gzugs byas la ras ris de'i mdun du bzhag go/ / ku sha'i rtse mo ma nyams pas phyogs gtsang mar skyes pa 'khor lo'i gzugs su byas te/ ras ris kyi mdun du lag pa g.yas pas bzung zhing / lag pa g.yon pas rma bya bzung la/ yar ngo'i zla ba nya ba'i mtshan mor ras ris la mchod pa chen po byas te/ ga pur dang tsan+dan gyi dud pa bsregs la/ nam langs kyi bar du bzlas pa byas na/

“If one does not find, among those places that were taught for all rites, places for the practice of the rites that bring supreme accomplishment, one should perform the preliminary practices in any clean place anywhere. With faith and resolve, one should commence the supreme rites employing the sādhana method.[746] “To start, one should install the painting of the superior[747] type facing west, with oneself facing east. One should take some clay, either from a fine anthill or from the bank of the Gaṅgā, and, optionally, [the root of] khaskhas grass, white sandalwood, and saffron. One should mix this very well with camphor and fashion from this an effigy of a peacock. One should place it in front of the painting and fashion with kuśa grass that has grown in a clean place, with the tips of the grass blades untrimmed, the shape of a ring. Holding this ring with one’s right hand in front of the painting, and the peacock[748] with one’s left, one should, on the night of the full moon, offer to the painting a large pūjā, burning an incense of camphor.[749] One should recite the mantra until daybreak.

de nas nyi ma shar ba'i dus su lha'i rang bzhin gyi rma bya ni rma bya chen po'i rgyal mor 'gyur ro/ / 'khor lo ni kun du 'bar bar 'gyur zhing / bdag nyid kyang lha'i lus su 'gyur ro/ / de nas lha'i phreng ba dang gos dang rgyan gyis brgyan par 'gyur ro/ / nyi ma shar ba dang 'dra ba'i 'dod pa'i gzugs mdzes par 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' la phyag byas nas/ ras ris la g.yas phyogs su bskor ba byas la/ ras ris blangs te rma bya'i stan de la 'dug na yud tsam gyis tshangs pa'i 'jig rten gnon par 'gyur ro/ / rig pa 'dzin pa bye ba khri phrag brgya stong gi 'khor du ma dang ldan pa'i rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ / bar gyi bskal pa drug cur 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / ci ltar 'dod par 'gro zhing spyod par 'gyur ro/ / 'gro ba la thogs pa med pa dang lha'i phun sum tshogs pa dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal yang mngon sum du 'gyur zhing / de nyid 'di'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen du 'gyur ro/ mthar yang sangs rgyas nyid thob par 'gyur ro/ /

“Then, at sunrise, this clay peacock will become the great king of peacocks,[750] and the ring of grass will blaze with light. Oneself will become possessed of a divine body, adorned with divine garlands, clothes, and ornaments. One will be graced with a desirable form that resembles the rising sun. One should bow to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, circumambulate the painting clockwise, take the painting into one’s hands, and sit upon the peacock as one’s mount. In an instant one will ascend to the realm of Brahmā. One will become the great emperor of vidyādharas, surrounded by many hundreds of thousands of millions of them. One will live for sixty eons of Manu.[751] One will be able to go wherever one wants, and one’s movement will not be impeded. One will be endowed with divine good fortune and be able to see Noble Mañjuśrī face to face. Mañjuśrī will become one’s spiritual friend and, in the end, one will attain buddhahood.

de bzhin du dbyug pa dang / spyi blugs dang tshangs skud dang ldong ros dang gi wang dang ral gri dang / lcags mda' dang mtshon rtse gcig pa dang dgra sta dang / mtshon rnam pa sna tshogs kyi khyad par sa'i rang bzhin nam/ rkang gnyis dang rkang bzhi dang bya dang bzhon pa'i bye brag seng ge dang stag dang dom la sogs pa'am/ grog mkhar gyi sa'i rang bzhin la dri zhim po'i dris bsres pa las/ gdan dang bzhon pa dang gnas mal dang / gdugs dkar po dang cod pan dang rgyan gyi bye brag thams cad dang rin po che'i bye brag thams cad dang / rab tu byung ba'i yo byad kyi bye brag phreng ba dang lham dang shing lham dang / lhung bzed dang chos gos dang khar gsil dang khab dang / gri la sogs pa lcags khyad par can gyi rang bzhin nam/ gzhan yang gang cung zad sems can gyi yo byad snod la sogs pa/ lcags bzang po'i rang bzhin nam/ grog mkhar gyi sa'am/ chu bo'i ngogs kyi sa las byas pa de dag thams cad pa'i rnam lngas bkrus pa'am/ chus gtor ba tsam byas la snga ma bzhin du yongs su dag par byed pa'i sngags sam/ yi ge gcig pa'i sngags sam/ gzhan gang yang rung ba'i sngags cho ga'i rgyal po sgrub pa'i thabs kyi sngags ma gtogs pas lan brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags pa byas te/ ci ltar 'dod par bdag nyid bsrung ba byas pa dang grogs po yang yongs su bskyab pa byas pa dang shin tu gsang ba'i sngags dang rgyud shes pa sngar bstan pa'i gnas dag tu ras ris nub tu bltas pas gzhag la/ bdag nyid snga ma bzhin du byas te/ ras ris la mchod pa chen po byas nas ras ris chen po la ga pur gyi bdug pas bdugs te/ sngar bstan pa'i mtshon dang yo byad dang sems can gyi khyad par sngar bstan pa'i bcos mar byas pa la/ yar ngo'i zla ba nya ba'i mtshan mo gong ma'i rdzas gang yang rung ba de dag blangs te/ mtshan mo nyi ma shar ba'i dus kyi bar du bzla bar bya'o/ /

“Similarly, one should procure a mendicant’s staff, a water pitcher, a sacred cord, red arsenic and bovine orpiment, a sword, an arrow, a javelin, an axe, and [other] different kinds of weapons and also, made of clay, humans and animals, different types of birds for riding, lions, tigers, hyenas, and so forth, fashioning them from clay from an anthill or clay from a riverbank[752] richly scented with pleasant scents. Likewise, one should procure conveyances provided with a chair or a bed, white parasols, various types of head ornaments, all types of jewels, and all the different requisites of one who has gone forth, including a rosary of rudrākṣa beads,[753] sandals, wooden clogs, an alms bowl, an ascetic’s robes and staff, a needle, and a knife and any other implements made of ‘flower-metal,’[754] starting with a bowl. One should fashion them from flower-metal, clay from an anthill, or clay from the riverbank, and smear or sprinkle all of them with the five products of a cow.[755] One should incant them one hundred and eight times with the purificatory mantra, one-syllable mantra, or any other mantra taught in this king of manuals, with the exception of the mantras employed in subsidiary practices.[756] Having performed, as appropriate, the desired protection ritual for oneself and one’s friends, one who is well acquainted with the knowledge of the mantra system should secretly install, in any of the previously described places, the painting of the superior type facing west, with oneself facing east, and offer to it a large pūjā. Burning incense of camphor, one should grasp any one of the previously mentioned individual weapons and implements,[757] fashioned as specified, and recite over it the mantra on a bright night of the full moon until sunrise.

bar 'dir 'od chen po'i phreng ba ras ris la yang dag par mthong la/ gal te bzhon pa'i khyad par sgrub pa pos gzung bar gyur na ni/ de la zhon nas ci ltar 'dod par 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te rgyan gyi khyad par ram tshon gyi khyad par de blangs pas de bcangs na/ rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor lo 'dzin par 'gyur te/ ci ltar 'dod par 'gro zhing lha'i gzugs dang ldan pa dang / nyi ma shar ba dang 'dra bar 'gyur ba dang 'od kyi phreng ba chen po dang ldan pa dang / lus shin tu gsal bar 'gyur ba dang rig pa 'dzin pa thams cad kyi mnga' bdag tu 'gyur ro/ / ring du 'tsho zhing bskal pa chen por gnas pa dang rig pa 'dzin pa bye ba khri phrag brgya stong gi 'khor du ma dang ldan pa dang / lha'i nor bu rin po che'i gzhal med khang la spyod pa dang bzhon pa gang sngar yongs su brtags pa sa'i rang bzhin grub na/ de nyid 'dir mthu chen po dang ldan par 'gyur te bzhon pa de nyid 'di'i grogs por 'gyur ba dang gzhan gyi sngags 'gugs par byed pa grub pa rnams kyi brten pa'i gnas su gyur pa/ bdag gi sngags kyi grub pa la yang dag par sbyor bar byed pa/ byams pa'i bdag nyid dang phan par 'dod pas rab tu 'brel ba gang 'di nyid kyi mtshon dang rgyan dang rin po che'i khyad par dang / stan dang gnas mal dang sems can la sogs pa nyid 'di la srung ba chen po nyid dang sba ba dang sbed pa la rtag tu 'brang bar 'gyur ro mthu chen po dang brtson 'grus chen po dang lus chen po dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa mngon sum du mthong bar 'gyur zhing legs so zhes bya ba yang sbyin par mdzad la/ spyi bo la reg par mdzad cing byang chub kyi snying po thob kyi bar du dge ba'i bshes gnyen du sgrub par mdzad do/ / stobs bcu nyid kyang nges par thob par mdzad cing / sems can thams cad zil gyis gnon cing mchod par yang 'gyur ro/ / 'byung po thams cad kyis mi tshugs par 'gyur ro/ / yang dag pa'i rgyud kyi mtha' gcod pa med par 'gyur ba dang sa thob par 'gyur ba dang stobs bcu dang / byang chub sems dpa'i sa nges par thob par 'gyur te/ mdor na las dam pa thams cad gnas dam pa dag tu gnas nas/ ras ris dam pa dag gi mdun du mchod pa dam pa la mngon par dga' bas las dam pa gzhan dag kho na bya'o/ /

“Immediately, the painting will appear enveloped in a great halo of light. If it was a mode of conveyance that was grasped by the practitioner, he will be able, after boarding it, to go wherever he pleases. If, on the other hand, it was an ornament or a weapon item, he will become, when holding it, a venerable[758] vidyādhara-cakravartin. He will be able to go wherever he pleases, possessed of divine form, effulgent as the rising sun, enveloped in a halo of great light, with the body as bright as lightning.[759] He will be the master of all vidyādharas, will live for one great eon, have a retinue of many hundreds of thousands of millions of vidyādharas, and live in a divine palace made of precious jewels and gems.[760] [The ability] that was perceived in the previously crafted conveyance, whatever [that being] was good at, will now become its great power.[761] This being will become one’s conveyance for riding and a companion. Thwarting the minute powers of others’ mantras[762] and employing the powers of one’s own, it will become compassionate at heart, desiring to benefit others, and always devoted [to the practitioner]. And whatever items of weaponry, ornaments, jewels, and so forth one took up, starting with the beings who serve as seat and bed conveyances, they will always follow the practitioner to give him good protection, cover, and shelter. “One will obtain great power, energy, and a superb physical body. One will behold Noble Mañjuśrī face to face and be applauded by him. When touched by him on the head, one will receive the boon of spiritual friendship until one has reached the essence of awakening. One will definitely obtain the ten powers. One will be venerated by all beings[763] and will never be assailed or defeated by spirits. One will not be separated from the lineage of the final goal and will attain the bodhisattva levels. One will follow the obligations of a bodhisattva consistent with the ten powers.[764] In short, all the supreme rites should be performed in these supreme places, and one who delights in the supreme worship in front of the superior painting should only perform the supreme rites.[765]

rig pa 'dzin pa nyid du nam mkha' la 'gro ba dang / byang chub sems dpa'i rjes su zhugs pa dang mngon par shes pa lnga nyid dang sa dang sngags thob pa nyid dang lus 'di nyid kyis 'jig rten gyi khams dag tu 'gro ba nyid dang stobs bcu'i rgyud yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir dang / 'phags pa 'jam dpal mngon sum du mthong ba nyid kyi phyir dang 'bras bu yod par mthong ba'i chos ston pa mnyan pa'i phyir dang / sangs rgyas kyi gdung rgyun mi gcad pa'i phyir dang / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes mthar gyis rjes su thob pa nyid kyi phyir dang / chos kyi sprin las byung ba'i sngags bzang po la 'jug pa nyid kyi phyir dang / nyon mongs pa bskam pa dang bdud rtsi'i char gyis nyon mongs pa zhi bar bya ba'i phyir dang / 'jig rten rjes su gzung ba la rab tu 'jug par rjes su sgrub pa nyid kyi phyir dang / de bzhin du chos kyi tshul gzung ba'i phyir dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung don yod par bya ba'i phyir dang / sngags kyi thabs kyi sgrub pa'i cho ga rab tu gsang ba nyid kyi phyir dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang rang sangs rgyas dang 'phags pa nyan thos kyi bdag nyid chen po 'byung ba nyid kyi phyir/ cho ga'i rgyal po rab 'byam sngags kyi mthu dang rab tu rnam par ldan pa 'di ras ris chen po'i mdun du nye bar gnas la bsgrub par bya ste/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags kyi cho ga dang / sngags rgyud thams cad kyi cho ga'i lam gyi ste/ mdor na 'dir cho ga gzhan du gsungs pa'i las kyis kyang cho ga'i rgyal po 'di bsgrub par bya ste/ myur du de dag gi sngags rnams 'grub par 'gyur te/ gang ngas bstan pa de dag nges par 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“One should become a sky-traveling vidyādhara‍—a bodhisattva endowed with the five superknowledges, established on the bodhisattva levels, and able to traverse the world spheres in this very body‍—in order to swell the lineage of the buddhas possessed of the ten powers, to be able to see Noble Mañjuśrī face to face, to give Dharma discourses that will bear fruit, to encourage others to listen to Dharma teachings, to prevent the lineage of the buddhas from dying out, to gradually attain omniscience, to reach the tenth bodhisattva level called The Cloud of Dharma,[766] to dry up and pacify the afflictions with the rain of ambrosia, to continually confer benefits on the people of the world, to guard the Dharma eye of the Tathāgata, to make the doctrine of the Tathāgata bear fruit, to manifest the power of the sādhana methods that involve the mantra practice,[767] and to propagate the teaching of the greatness of all the buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, and noble śrāvakas.[768] For all this, one needs to accomplish the complete teachings in this king of manuals. “This ritual of the king of paintings should be accomplished following the procedure taught in all the tantras and manuals of worldly and supramundane mantras that are to be recited by the practitioner in front of the superior type of painting. Briefly speaking, it can be accomplished through the rites taught in this and also other manuals. These mantras will quickly bring on the accomplishment. Whatever I have taught here will definitely bring accomplishment.”
byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga bcu pa ras ris chen po'i cho ga'i le'u rab 'byam rdzogs so// //

This concludes the tenth chapter of “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings. This chapter constitutes the detailed chapter on the procedure involving the superior painting.
las thams cad kyi cho ga sgrub pa'i le'u
Chapter 11

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal khyod kyi ras ris bar ma'i cho ga gzhan sgrub pa'i thabs kyi cho ga yod de/ mdor bsdus nas bshad kyis de legs par rab tu nyon la yid la zung shig dang bshad do/ / de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ /

Now Lord Śākyamuni looked again at the realm of the Pure Abode, and said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “There is, Mañjuśrī, in your ritual, a painting procedure of the medium type, a practice procedure serving as the means for accomplishing middling rites. I will teach it in brief, so please listen carefully and reflect upon it well. I will teach it now.” Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, for his part, said this to the Blessed One:

bcom ldan 'das 'jig rten la thugs brtse ba dang ston pa sems can thams cad la phan par dgyes pa dang / bdag cag la thugs brtse ba'i phyir dang / ma 'ongs pa'i skye bo rnams la gzigs nas/ de'i dus la bab par mkhyen na de bshad du gsol/ de skad ces gsol pa dang / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ /

“May the Blessed One, the teacher, full of compassion for the world and delighting in benefiting all beings, speak! Please speak, if you think that the time is right, out of compassion for us and regard for future generations.” Having been thus addressed by Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, the Blessed One said this:

'jam dpal nyon cig dang por re zhig tshul khrims dang brtul zhugs dang / gtsang sbra'i spyod pa dang nges par sdom pa dang bzlas pa dang / sbyin sreg dang bsam gtan dang cho ga gang du legs par rab tu gnas pa la sngags thams cad kyi spyod pa sgrub pa'i las 'bras bu dang bcas shing don yod par 'gyur te/ sngags thams cad kyi sbyor ba 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / ngas bshad pa de gang zhe na/ gzhon nu nyon cig /

“Listen, Mañjuśrī. All the rites involved in the practice of the mantra conduct will bear fruit and not be futile for those who, first of all, are firmly established in discipline, ritual observances, purificatory acts, ritual obligations, mantra recitations, homa ritual, and the meditation methods.[769] Then, the application of all the mantras will swiftly[770] lead to success. Why is this so? I will explain that. Listen, O divine youth!

dang por re zhig rig pa dang brtul zhugs dang / tshul khrims kyi yi dam dang po nyid du blang bar byas la/ dang po re zhig dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis bstan pa'i dam tshig khyod kyi cho ga'i rgyal por bstan cing sngar bshad pa la rjes su 'jug par bya'o/ / blo gsal ba yid gzhungs pa dang ldan pa/ slob dpon du dbang bskur ba khyod kyis bstan pa'i cho ga shes pa/ dge ba gsal ba'i chos dang ldan pa/ bden par smra ba spro ba chen po dang ldan pa byas pa gzo ba/ yid gzhungs pa dang ldan pa/ 'dris brten pa ha cang mi rgan ha cang mi gzhon pa rnyed pa dang / bkur sti la chags pa med pa tshangs par spyod pa/ snying rje dang ldan pa rnyed pa tsam mam/ longs spyod kyi rgyu tsam mam/ rjes su chags pa'i rgyur yang rdzun mi smra na cung zad tsam mam/ chags pa'am rmongs pa tsam gyis rnam par lta smos kyang ci dgos/ dam bcas pa brtan pa dang sems can thams cad la sems mnyam pa dang / snying rje dang ldan pa dang tshul khrims dang ldan pa dang / sngon du spyad pa byas pa dang khyod kyi gsang ba'i sngags rjes su zlos pa dang snga ma nyid du rig pa goms par byas pa dang / khyod kyi dkyil 'khor la mthar gyis yang dag par zhugs pa dang / 'jig rten shes pa dang cho ga shes pa dang yang dag par rjes su 'dzin par byed pa dang / 'bras bu dang ldan zhing mkhas pa dang legs pa la rab tu zhugs pa dang gzugs mdzes pa dang 'dod pa med pa dang / chags pa med pa dang dpa' ba dang brtson 'grus brtan pa dang nad med pa ste/ nad gang gis las mi nus pa'i ngang tshul can gyi nad med pa dang rigs mthon por skye ba'o/ / yon tan de dag dang ldan na ni dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon du 'gyur la/ sgrub pa po yang de dang mnyam pa ste/ yan lag lhag pa'am ma tshang ba cung zad kyang med pa'o/ / de lta bu'i dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon la mchod pa byas shing don du gnyer bar byas te/ slob dpon dang lhan cig byang chub sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i dam tshig la rjes su 'jug par 'tshal na/ slob dpon gyis bdag la thugs brtse ba'i slad du/ phan pa'i thugs dang brtse ba'i thugs kyis de bshad du gsol/

“To start, one should assume the disciplined conduct and observances pertaining to the practice of vidyās. First, one should take the samaya pledge according to the instructions[771] of the maṇḍala master as clearly taught in your king of manuals. One should acquire a learned master who has received the ‘master empowerment’ (ācāryābhiṣeka) and has the acumen of a spiritual instructor.[772] Such a master should possess the Dharma that is virtuous and clear and be truthful, diligent, grateful, steadfast,[773] good natured, not too old and not too young, free from desire with regard to all gain and favors, and celibate. He should be compassionate, but not merely on account of desire or based on sensual pleasure or emotional attachment. He should not speak untruth out of strong delusion and greed, let alone due to trivial reasons. He should keep his promises and be equanimous toward all beings, have compassion for them, and practice generosity.[774] He should have completed the preparatory rites and the preliminary practice that involves the recitation of your secret mantra and have gained [therefrom the requisite] knowledge.[775] He should have entered your maṇḍala according to the right order of succession. He must understand the ways of the world and also know the ritual procedure. He should be kind, industrious, and wise. He must practice goodness and be fearless, free from hesitation or vacillation,[776] stable, and diligent. He should not be afflicted by any disease that would render him inactive, and he should be disciplined.[777] He should come from a great and illustrious family. These are the qualities that the maṇḍala master should be endowed with. “The practitioner, for his part, should be either the same as him or lacking in some attributes.[778] After worshiping such a maṇḍala master, he should supplicate him as follows: “ ‘I would like to enter the samaya with you, master, who are identical with the great bodhisattva, the divine youth Mañjuśrī.[779] Out of the master’s[780] kindness, please instruct me with a benevolent and kind mind.’

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon des sngar bstan pa'i cho gas slob ma la snga ma ci lta bu bzhin du brtags nas rab tu gzhug par bya ste/ sngar ci ltar dbang bskur ba bzhin du phyis kyang sbyin par bya'o/ / go rims ci lta ba bzhin du dam tshig bstan te/ gsang ba'i phyag rgya dang rgyud dang sngags dang las kyang dus ring po nyid nas nges par brtags te/ bsam pa shes nas bstan par bya ste/ sngags la sogs pa'i las rnams kyang thams cad du gzhan du ma yin no zhes cho ga 'di ltar bstan pa yin no/ /

“The maṇḍala master then, following the same procedure as previously explained, should examine the disciples as before and usher them in. He should give the empowerment as before and give them the mantra.[781] He should then explain the stages of samaya and the secret tantra, mudrā, and rites. After examining them for a long time and determining their character, he teaches them the rites for all tantras, mantras, and so forth. He should not teach this to anyone else.[782] This is the accepted procedure.
de nas slob mas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon la ci nus pas/ gang gis slob dpon dgyes pa bdag dang longs spyod rab tu dbul bar bya'o/ /
“The disciple, for his part, should gratify the maṇḍala master with anything that may be pleasing to him, and offer himself and the enjoyments.
de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon des bu'i 'du shes nye bar gzhag par bya ste/ bu bzhin du bsgrub par bya zhing ma bzhin du yang longs spyod kyis nye bar bsdu bar bya'o/ /
“The maṇḍala master should then regard the disciple as his son, and treat him as such. Like a mother, he should offer him comforts and enjoyments.

de nas sgrub pa po des sngags gang yang rung ba bzung ste/ gcig pu dben par song nas sngar bstan pa gong ma bzhin du rgya cher sbyar te/ de dag nyid kyis sngags dag gis ni spyan drang ba dang gshegs su gsol ba dang / mar me dang dri dang bdug pa dang gtor ma dang lha bshos dkyil 'khor la gsungs pa nyid kyi cho gas rgya cher bya ste/ spyan drangs nas gdan dang mchod yon phul la/ dus mtshams gsum du khrus lan gsum bya zhing / gos lan gsum brje zhing nyin re bzhin du bzlas pa bya'o/ / de la dus gsum zhes bya ba ni mtshan mo'i mtha' nas brtsams pa yin te/ zung tsam nas nyi ma 'char ba'i bar 'dir dang po'i dus su brjod do/ / nyi ma gung ni nyi ma gnyi ga'i gung tsam gyi tshad du nam mkha' la gnas pa'i nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor la ni nyi ma gung gi dus zhes brjod do/ / nyi ma nub pa'i dus su lhag ma zung tsam lus pa'i dus gsum pa zhes brjod do/ /

“The disciple then, having obtained a particular mantra, should retire to a secluded area, to a place as previously described in more detail, and, in short, employ this mantra for the summoning, dismissing, and offering to the deities a bali consisting of lamps, perfume, and incense, following the elaborate procedure that has been taught as part of the maṇḍala instructions. He should thus summon the deity and present it with a welcome offering and a seat at the three junctions of the day. He should perform ritual ablutions three times a day, wear the three-piece apparel of an ascetic, and recite the mantra every day. Regarding the junctions of the day, the first junction is said to be from the end of the night until the sun is four angular cubits[783] above the horizon. The second junction is said to be at midday, for as long as the center of the sun disk traverses in the sky the distance of four cubits. The third junction is said to be at sunset, for as long as it takes the sun to move the full distance of four cubits.

tshul khrims brtul zhugs yang dag ldan/ / slob dpon mkhas pa chen po dang / / mthon po'i rigs su skyes pa dang / / rnam pa kun du brtson 'grus brtan/ / sngags rgyud dag la mngon brtson dang / / bya ba kun la blo gros dge/ / zhib cing mkhas la chog shes dang / / chos kyi dbyings ni rtag tu 'dzin/ / spro ba che zhing gzi brjid che/ / 'jig rten chos la ltos pa med/ / thub mchog chos la dad pa dang / / 'jig rten na ni yongs su bsngags/ / dben pa shes shing bzlas pa byed/ / sngon du bsnyen pas rjes bsnyen byed/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyi sngags shes shing / / mthong bas nges 'dzin de mchog byed/ / sangs rgyas gsungs pa'i sngags rnams la/ / 'jig rten pa yi sbyor ba shes/ / srung byed mthu ni brtan pa dang / / rtag tu gtsang sbra'i spyod la dga'/ / sangs rgyas bstan pa'i lam la ni/ / thams cad du ni 'jug par byed/ / rab bsngags rgyal bas bstod pa yi/ / sngags zlos pa la brtson par byed/ / las 'bras dag la rtag yid ches/ / 'jig rten pha rol de bzhin no/ / sdig pa kun la 'jigs byed pa/ / shin tu phra ba'ang de bzhin no/ / gtsang zhing grims dang le lo med/ / yid gzhungs blta na sdug pa dang / / stobs bcu ldan pas sngags bshad dang / / de bzhin rgyal ba'i sras dang ni/ / gang dag 'jig rten sngags dag dang / / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs dag gis/ / de la rtag tu brtson byed dang / / gzhung dang bstan bcos don klog pa/ / nad med pa dang stobs ldan dang / / rgan dang gzhon pa rnam par spangs/ / sngags grub de bzhin shes nyen can/ / kun nas myur du byed pa dang / / las mtha' mi ring nga rgyal chung / / zur tsam gyis go khyad par can/ / tshangs par spyod cing shes rab che/ / gcig pu 'dre bar mi byed dang / / 'jam dpal gyis gsungs rgyud dag la/ / dbang bskur thob cing dpa' ba dang / / bzlas pa'i mthar byas ldan pa dang / / de bzhin rig pa goms byas dang / / sems dpa' che zhing 'jig rten shes/ / 'gro ba'i de nyid rjes sems dang / / legs pa'i lam nyid rab sbyar byed/ / sbyin byed 'byung po phan la dga'/ / khyad par can de'i slob dpon la/ / rtag tu don du gnyer bar bya/ / dkyil 'khor de ni bris pa la/ / sngags rnams grub pa ster bar 'gyur/ /

“One should approach a master who is learned and skilled And has taken up the vow of disciplined [conduct], One born in a great and illustrious family, Steadfast and diligent in every respect. “He must be actively engaged in the art of mantras And be skilled and judicious in all tasks. He should be subtle, have expert knowledge of mantras,[784] And always uphold the domain of Dharma. “He should have great perseverance and ardor And be unconcerned about worldly affairs. He must have faith in the teachings of the Sage And shun the teachings of worldly masters.[785] “He must have performed the required mantra recitations, Have discernment, and have done the preliminary practice. He should understand the mantra of Mañjughoṣa And have complete confidence in it. “He should also know the worldly magical rites That employ mantras taught by the Buddha. He should have performed the protection ritual, Have unwavering strength, and always delight in pure conduct. “He must follow, in all respects, The path shown by the Buddha. He should be engaged in the recitation of the mantra taught here, Described by the Victorious One as perfect. “Seeing that the fruits of one’s actions Come without fail, even in the afterlife, He would be wary of any evil, Even as small as a tiny particle. He should be pure, adroit, not lazy, Intelligent, and pleasant to behold. “Whatever mantras have been taught by those with the ten powers And by the sons of the same, the victorious ones, And whatever worldly mantras there are, And also those in the Vajra and Lotus families, He should always exert himself in their study, Absorbing the meaning from the written treatises. “He should not be diseased or disabled, Neither too old nor too young. He should have accomplished the mantra and be protected by it.[786] He should operate efficiently in every respect. “He must not procrastinate, be free of haughtiness, And specifically understand bodily expressions.[787] Celibate and with great insight, He should be solitary and not mingle. “He, the hero, must have obtained an initiation Into this tantra, taught by Mañjuśrī. He should have reached the end of his recitations[788] And have gained the understanding. “He should have great dignity, understand the ways of the world, And reflect upon the reality of the different states of rebirth. He should apply himself diligently to the practice of virtue, Be generous, and delight in benefiting beings. “A master distinguished in this way Should always be supplicated, As the maṇḍala containing mantras written by him Will lead to accomplishment.

de nyid kyis ni dbang bskur na/ / 'bras bu chen po ster bar 'gyur/ / grub pa 'dod pa'i slob mas kyang / / thub mchog de ni rtag tu mchod/ / de yi bka' ni mi 'gom par/ / slob mas 'bad nas bya ba yin/ / ci ltar 'byor pa yod pa bzhin/ / longs spyod de la sbyin par bya/ / nyung ba'ang yang na mang ba'ang rung / / gang gis dga' ba thob 'gyur ba/ / lus dang srog gi don phyir ni/ / nor ni ci ltar sbyin pa bzhin/ / slob ma chos rig de bzhin du/ / slob dpon phyir ni nor sbyin na/ / tshe dang nad med de bzhin du/ / grags pa thob par 'gyur ba yin/ / slob mas bla ma de mchod na/ / dag pa'i 'gro ba thob par 'gyur/ / lam ni sna tshogs nyer bstan pas/ / de la sngags ni 'grub par 'gyur/ /

“An empowerment bestowed by him Will bear great fruits. Such a master should always be venerated as a sage By the disciples who desire accomplishment. “His instructions must not be disobeyed But should be followed by the disciples with diligence. He should be given objects of enjoyment, Whatever are available, according to one’s means‍— “A gift big or small, Or any gift that will please the master. Just as the father’s body and mind Constitute the cause for the existence of one’s own body,[789] “In the same way will the disciple who knows the Dharma Obtain renown, accomplishments, Long life, and good health, If only he offers his wealth to the master. “A disciple who reveres his master Will make excellent progress. His mantras will bring accomplishments Once the path of ritual procedures has been explained.

de la bsten dang bsnyen bkur byas/ / ri mo byas dang mchod pas ni/ / sangs rgyas rnams dang de bzhin du/ / rgyal ba'i sras rnams mnyes par 'gyur/ / bla ma rtag tu bsnyen bkur na/ / lha rnams thams cad dga' bar 'gyur/ / bla ma sngags rnams mthong ba yis/ / de ltar thams cad bstan pa yin/ / sgrub pa pos ni dang por yang / / dam tshig la ni 'jug par bya/ / dma' ba'am de dang mnyam pa'ang rung / / gal te khyad par gyur na yang / / rmongs pa'am lhag pa yin yang rung / / rtag tu bla ma brnyas mi bya/ /

“All the buddhas rejoice, And so do the foremost sons of the victorious ones, When the teachers are served, adored, And worshiped respectfully.[790] “All the gods are pleased With any kind act done to a teacher. All this pertains to teachers Who impart the knowledge of mantras. “If he has not done this already, The practitioner should first enter into the samaya bond, Regardless of whether he is a person of equal Or superior position to the teacher. “Neither an ignorant nor a brilliant disciple Should ever disrespect the master.[791]
He should instead apply himself to the tantra In which he has been instructed.[792]

ci ltar de nyid rjes mthong la/ / sngags 'grub pa la bya ba yin/ / sngar bstan pa yi slob ma yis/ / de la phrag dog bya ba min/ / lus can brtse ba 'phel byed pa'i/ / mig ni gang la yod gyur pa/ / de ni slob ma nyid bya ste/ / slob dpon rgyur yang bya ba yin/ / gang du phan tshun rgyud la ni/ / brtse ba'i phreng ba yod pa dang / / brtse ba'i rgyud ni 'dzin pa la/ / de la sngags ni sbyin par bya/ / slob dpon la ni slob ma 'am/ / bla mas slob ma mthong ba'ang rung / / rtag tu spro bar 'gyur ba la/ / gnyi ga la ni grub pa gnas/ / de dag la ni rtag tu yang / / sngags spyod lam ni bstan par bya/ / gnyi gas pha dang bur shes la/ / sngags ni 'bras bcas gnas pa yin/ / slob ma bla mas rtag tu ni/ / brtan dang dga' ba de bzhin thob/ / bu ni chos dang rjes mthun la/ / 'bad pas rtag tu bsrung bar bya/ / de dag la ni sangs rgyas chos/ / rtag tu rgyun mi chad par 'gyur/ /

He should engage, for the sake of accomplishment, In the practice of the mantra that he was instructed in. “A previously trained disciple Should harbor no jealousy toward the master, But instead should have an eye That is the embodiment of growing love. “The master is himself the cause For the development of the disciple; A bond of love should stretch Between their two minds. “While maintaining a loving mind He should offer the mantra to the disciple; Whenever the disciple sees the master, Or the master sees the disciple, “They should always be joyful, Remain practicing together, And at all times focused On the path of mantric conduct. “Both of them, the father and the son, Knowing the mantra, will reap the results. Both the disciple and the teacher Will find stability and joy. “The son‍—the dear Dharma child‍— Should always be diligently protected. The uninterrupted condition of the buddhas Is present also in them.[793]

gal te de med mgon bral la/ / sngags rnams ci skad gsungs pa bzhin/ / sems can dbul po rnams la ni/ / khyad par du yang sngags byin na/ / sems can kun la'ang sbyin pa bas/ / sngags kyi spyod pa khyad par 'phags/ / mchog dang bar ma tha ma ni/ / dus rnams kun du bya ba ste/ / rtag tu sems can kun la ni/ / rjes su gzung ba'i phyir bya'o/ / 'gro ba'am skye gnas rnam brtags nas/ / 'dod pa dag la sbyin par bya/ / de ni ci ltar 'dod pa'i sngags/ / slob mas de la blang bar bya/ /

“If the buddhas are absent and beings are without a protector, The mantras should be given to them just as they are taught. They should be given in particular to those beings Who are destitute or powerless. Mantra practice is excellent For all beings without exception. “This mantra practice can be done at all times By those of the lowest, highest, and medium capacities, And can be used to bring benefit To all beings on any occasion.[794] “This mantra conduct should be given to those who seek it After determining their state and origin. The disciple, for his part, Should train in whatever mantra he desires.[795]

de nyid kyis bstan lam yin te/ / gzhan du de lta ma yin no/ / 'jig rten pha rol pa la ni/ / grub pa de las bslang bar bya/ / pha bzhin mgo bos phyag byas nas/ / de nas ci ltar 'dod bzhin 'gro/ / de nas gcig pu 'gro byas nas/ / mnyam par bzhag ste bzlas pa bya/ / slong mo slong bas rjes 'tsho zhing / / thub pa dus gsum zlos par byed/ / sngar ni ci ltar bstan pa bzhin/ / lam du rab tu 'jug par byed/ / de la rjes 'jug bsten pa dang / / 'dug pa dang ni gnas pa'o/ / dben pa chen po ri rtse dang / / de bzhin chu bo'i ngogs gtsang dang / / ba lang gnas dang mtsho chen dang / / dben pa skye bo rnam spangs dang / / lha khang stong dang shing dang ni/ / mtshan gcig ri ni mthon po dang / / rgya mtsho che ngogs dga' ba dang / / gling rnams chen po dag dang ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs sngar bstan pa'i/ / yul ni yid du 'ong ba dang / / 'di dag las ni phyogs gzhan du/ / mnyam bzhag sngags ni bzla bar bya/ / grogs po mtshan nyid ldan pa ni/ / sngags don lugs dang tshad mar ldan/ /

“One who desires accomplishment should follow The path taught [here], and no other. One should travel on this path, Superior to other paths. “One should bow to the master with one’s head As if to one’s father, and then depart, wherever one pleases. One should go to a secluded place And recite the mantra, fully focused. “Sustained by food obtained through alms, Observing silence except for the three recitation sessions a day, One should follow the path, Just as it was previously taught. “Then, following this conduct, One should frequent various places of abode, Such as great forests, mountaintops, And also clean riverbanks, “Secluded cow pens and forts[796] That are devoid of people, Empty temples, trees, Solitary lingams, mountain peaks, “Pleasant shores of the great ocean, Sandy islands, Or various other places as previously described, Pleasing to the mind. “One should recite the mantra in these and other places With a well-focused mind, In the company of friends endowed with auspicious marks And trained in philosophy and conduct for the sake of mantra practice.

zur gyi rnam pa de nyid shes/ / bdag dang de yang 'dra ba'o/ / dpa' zhing g.yul las rnam rgyal dang / / snyingastobs che zhing bzod dang ldan/ / rgyal bas gsungs pa'i bstan pa dang / / sngags kyi spyod pa la dad cing / / sngags pa'i mtshan nyid dang ldan la/ / bzod dang ldan pa'i grogs po la/ / de la 'bad pa med par ni/ / sngags kyi las rnams 'grub par 'gyur/ / tho rangs mal nas langs nas ni/ / mtsho chen las byung chu bo las/ / byung chu srog chags skyon med pa'i/ / bzang pos khrus ni rab tu bya/ / sa dang lci ba phye ma yis/ / sngags shes pas ni lus dril bya/ / sngags kyis de bzhin dag byas pa'i/ / dri med gtsang sbrar byas pa'i chus/ / sngags ldan bdag nyid khrus bya zhing / / ha cang ring bar 'dug mi bya/ / de nas langs nas chu ngogs 'dug / sa dag gis kyang lag gnyis bkru/ / bdun dang bdun dang yang bdun ni/ / nyi shu rtsa gcig bar du 'o/ / de bzhin du yang nye reg bya/ / so shing dag kyang yang dag byed/ / so shing rnam par bor nas ni/ / de nas skyob la phyag kyang bya/ / 'jig rten mgon la phyag 'tshal nas/ / mchod pa yid du 'ong bar bya/ / rnam pa sna tshogs mchod bstod dang / / yang dag bstod pa yang yang bya/ /

“They ought to know the nature of gestures[797] And be the same as or similar to Brave men victorious in battles, Who are honest and patient, “Who have faith in the mantra practice And the related doctrine taught by the Victorious One, Who are endowed with the excellent auspicious marks, And who are patient and forbearing. “A practitioner who has such companions Will accomplish all activities[798] without toil. He should rise from his bed early And wash himself in clean water, “The water from a stream or a big pond That is free of living organisms. Such a mantra adept should rub his body With powdered clay or cow dung “And then, having purified with the mantra Some clean water free of any dirt, Should perform ritual ablutions while reciting the mantra. He should not miss the right time for these acts. “Accordingly, after rising up [in the morning], He should stand on the bank and cleanse his hands with clay‍— Seven, seven, and again seven times‍— Twenty-one times in all. “He should then sit down there, And clean his teeth with a tooth stick. Having spat out the washed-off matter, He should praise the Protector. “Having praised the protector of the world, He should make offerings pleasing to the mind, Praising him, again and again, With complimentary hymns of praise.

dri zhim me tog de bzhin du/ / ston la zlos pas mchod yon dbul/ / sangs rgyas rnams dang de'i slob la/ / spyi bos rab tu phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'jig rten mgon po de dag gi/ / mdun du sdig pa bshags par bya/ / ras ris bar ma'i mdun du ni/ / bdag nyid dag kyang dbul bar bya/ / ku sha'i khres ni byas pa der/ / legs par mnyam gzhag 'dug nas ni/ / des ni phreng ba thogs nas su/ / 'bad pas bzlas pa bya ba yin/ / ci ltar rnyed pa'i sngags kyis bya/ / de tshe sngags gzhan bzlas mi bya/ / ha cang ngan pa spang bya ste/ / ha cang bzang po'ang de bzhin no/ / bar ma bar ma'i las dag la/ / sdom chen sngags ni rtag tu bzla/ / ha cang skad mthon 'bad pas spang / / tshig ni dma' ba'ang ma yin no/ / bar ma dbus kyi yul dag tu/ / rjes mthun rgyal bas bsngags pa'o/ / ha cang skad mtho dma' ba'ang min/ / bar mas rtag tu bzlas pa bya/ / sangs rgyas snga ma kun gyis ni/ / tshig ni legs ldan yin zhes gsungs/ /

“Also, while reciting, he should offer to the Teacher[799] A welcome offering of fragrant flowers, Bow with his head to the buddhas And then to their disciples. “He should confess his wrongdoings In front of these protectors of the world, And place food and refreshments[800] In front of the painting of middling type. “He should prepare a seat of kuśa grass And sit there with a focused mind. He should recite the mantra with keenness, Using a rosary of rudrākṣa beads.[801] “He should only recite the mantra that he was given, And not any other mantra, In a voice neither too low, Nor, indeed, too loud. “In the rites of the medium type, The vow holder[802] should always recite the mantra the ‘medium’ way. He should resolutely avoid speaking loudly, Nor should the words be too low. “In the rites of the medium type, the ‘medium’ speech Was described by the Victorious One as the best, So one should recite not too loudly And not too low, but always in between; All the buddhas of the past Employed their voice in the best possible way.[803]

rtag tu gzhan gyi rna lam dang / / gzhan gyi drung du mi bzla 'o/ / dben pa'i phyogs su'ang bdag rig pas/ / sngags kyang bar ma bzla bar bya/ / de ltar sngags bzlas rab sbyar na/ / sngags ni gang yang myur du 'grub/ / bar ma'i sngags ni 'grub 'dod na/ / yang dang yang du bzlas pa bya/ / de bas bzlas pa rnam bral dang / / sngags kyi de nyid don legs thos/ / dben zhing gdung ba med par ni/ / zlos pas sngags ni bzla bar bya/ / mtshan mo yi ni bzhi cha dang / / de phyed de bzhin phyed nyid dang / / skya rengs dmar po zung tsam la/ / nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor 'char ba na/ / dang po'i bar ma nyid du ni/ / thub pa mchog gis gsungs pa yin/ / zung tsam khru ni bzhi pa ste/ / bar mar yongs su bsgrags pa yin/ / de nas nyi ma phyed shar na/ / sngags bzlas de tshe spang bar bya/ / sngags bzlas de tshe btang ba na/ / sdom brtson mchod yon slar gshegs gsol/ /

“One should not recite the mantra near to other people, Or within their range of hearing, But in a hidden place known only to oneself, Reciting in a voice of medium volume. “If one engages in recitation in this way, The meaning of any mantra will be clearly heard.[804] One should keep reciting this mantra If one desires accomplishment of the medium type. “Consequently, the reciter should chant the mantra In a secluded place where no one gathers,[805] A place devoid of people, But where the essential meaning of the mantra can be clearly heard.[806] “He should recite during the second half Of the second half of the fourth division of the night,[807] When the copper-red disk of the sun Is four angular cubits[808] above the horizon, “For that is how the buddhas, the best of men, Have designated the ‘first junction.’ The ‘yoke length’ is the length of four cubits, Proclaimed as the ‘medium’ [length]. “One should stop the recitation After the sun has risen up into the sky. Having stopped reciting the mantra and dismissed [the deity], The vow holder should make an offering to send [it] away.
de tshe btang ba'i lhag dus la/ / thub pa'i bstan la dge ba bya/ / dam chos bklag la sogs pa ni/ / shes rab pha rol phyin la sogs/ /

“For the rest of the time henceforth, One should devote oneself to this expert instruction of the Sage: One should venerate the teachings, and so forth, of genuine Dharma, As found in the Prajñāpāramitā and other literature.[809]

glegs bam sa bcu zhes bya ba/ / mchod dang bklag pa rtag tu bya/ / de nas dus la bab gyur na/ / rang sngags sngags kyi mgon po dang / / thub pa mchog la phyag 'tshal nas/ / de nas 'tsho ba'i don du 'gro/ / dus gsum spyod dang de bzhin ldan/ / dus su zas spyod dbang po thul/ / chos can sgrub la brtson pa dang / / sangs rgyas bstan la rab tu dad/ / mi smra grong gi nang du 'dug / rtag tu gtsang sbra spyod la dga'/ / chos ldan sems can khyim du ni/ / slong dus rtag zlos byed cing 'dug / srog chags med chos grub pa yi/ / zas ni gtsang bar grags pa dang / / yang dag lta ba'i khyim dag dang / / sangs rgyas bstan la dad pa yi/ / de 'dra'i khyim la rtag tu ni/ / slong ba'i don du slong mo blang / / ci ltar dpa' bos go bgos te/ / nyam nga'i g.yul du 'jug pa na/ / rtag tu dgra ni 'joms byed de/ / dgra yis 'joms kyang mi nus pa/ / de bzhin sngags pa rtag grong du/ / slong mo'i 'tsho bas 'jug pa na/ / gzugs sgra la sogs bzang po ni/ / de ltar mthong bas chags gyur na/ / 'dod chags zhi ba'i don gyi phyir/ / dge ba mi gtsang bsgom par bya/ / lang tsho'i rnam pas brgyan pa yi/ / bud med gzugs ni mthong ba na/ / mi gtsang dri ngan bsgom bya zhing / / shin tu smad pa rnag dang gcin/ / srin bus zos dang dur khrod gnas/ / lus ni mi rtag sdug bsngal yin/ /

“Also the books, such as the one called Daśabhūmika, Should always be venerated and read aloud. When the prescribed time has arrived, One should bow to the buddhas, the best of men, “And to one’s mantra, the lord of mantras, And then depart for the sake of sustenance. Observing thus the prescribed regimen,[810] Eating at the appointed time, and controlling one’s senses, “A Dharma practitioner should always exert himself In the pure training as taught by the Buddha. Observing silence, one should go to another village,[811] Always delighting in pure conduct. “The mantra reciter should seek alms Only in houses where Dharma is followed, Where the water is filtered and free of living organisms And the food is known to be pure.[812] “A house where the housewife has correct views And where there is faith in the Buddha’s teachings‍— It is in such a household that a mendicant Should always seek and receive alms. “Just like a well-equipped warrior Would enter the heat of a battle And destroy his opponents without fail, Without himself being harmed by the enemy, “So should a mantra practitioner, Who lives on alms, always enter a village. When seeing pleasing forms, Or hearing pleasant sounds, “One should, in order to appease the passions, Contemplate that which is pleasant as unpleasant. Seeing a female body Adorned with the gracefulness of youth, “One should contemplate it being impure and smelly, Disgusting with its pus, urine, and so forth, Deposited in a cemetery and slimed over by worms‍— A body that is impermanent and a source of suffering.

byis pa sngags la rmongs pa yis/ / 'gro ba lnga po dag tu 'khor/ / las kyi skud pas bcings nas ni/ / yun ring dus su mya ngan byed/ / mi shes sgrib pas rmongs pas na/ / dmus long sdug bsngal rgyu yang yin/ / gang du blo ni phyin ci log / skye bo chags pas phongs par 'gyur/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las gar gyi/ / rnam pa du mar chags byed pas/ / yun ring res kyis gnas nas ni/ / 'gro dang 'ong bar spyod par byed/ / gar byed bzhin du spyod pa yis/ / bran bzhin du ni gtong bar byed/ / mi gtsang dga' ba'i sems can gang / / yun ring lam du phongs par 'gyur/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho'i chu 'byung ba/ / zo chun gyi ni rnam pa bzhin/ / 'gro ba de dag mi bzad pa'i/ / sdug bsngal chu yis khyab pa yin/ / sangs rgyas kyis ni bud med dag / ma 'dres sdug bsngal rtsa bar gsungs/ / nyan thos byang chub sems dpa' dang / / rang rgyal thub pas de bzhin gsungs/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho mi 'khrugs pa/ / rgya mtsho 'di ni skam par dka'/ / bud med sems kyis bslus pas na/ / gang du sems can bying gyur nas/ / dmyal ba dud 'gro'i 'jig rten dang / / yi dgas 'jig rten lha ma yin/ / de bzhin mi yi 'jig rten dang / / lha yi 'gro ba'i 'gro bar 'gro/ / bud med chags pas bslu pas na/ / kun nas yongs su 'khor 'gyur zhing / / 'dam chen nang du 'bying 'gyur la/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho btson ra yin/ /

“The childish, ignorant of mantra,[813] Cycle through the five destinies;[814] Strung upon the thread of karma, They wallow in misery for a long time. “Such fools, steeped in ignorance And blind from birth, create for themselves causes of suffering. Beings with warped minds sink in dejection Because of things they are attached to. “Dressed in the costumes of different types of karma,[815] Excited in many different ways, For a long time they are mounted upon swings And pushed back and forth. “Engaged in their dance, They are impelled to follow its steps. Addicted to what is impure, Beings remain despondent for long periods of time. “Being born in the waters of the ocean of existence, There is no end to their births, Which are awash with the water of suffering, Like a well bucket is awash with the water from the well. “For women have been declared by the buddhas To be nothing but the root of suffering. So also said the śrāvakas, the bodhisattvas, The pratyekabuddhas, and the sages. “Their minds led astray by women, Beings[816] drown in the ocean of cyclic existence That cannot be disturbed And is impossible to dry up. “They then wander through the six realms: The hells and animal realms, The realms of hungry ghosts and of the asuras, And the realms of gods and of men. “Men wander throughout all these destinies, Powerless[817] and deluded on account of women, Sinking in the great mire‍— This prison of the ocean of saṃsāra.

bud med chags pa'i blun po'i mi/ / rul ba'i ro la wa bzhin no/ / gang du mi ni chags byed pa/ / shin tu mi bzad sdug bsngal bzod/ / dkar po'i chos ni des nyams byed/ / sangs rgyas bstan la zhugs pas ni/ / sdug bsngal 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho nyid/ / thams cad yongs su zlog byed cing / / sngags zlos dga' zhing brtson pa dang / / grags pa che zhing chags dang bral/ / gzi brjid ldan zhing kun dang mdza'/ / de dag la ni sdug bsngal med/ / yang dag sdom dang tshangs bden shes/ / bla ma lha la mchod byed dang / / ma dang pha la gus pa rnams/ / de dag la ni sdug bsngal med/ / dam pa'i don la brten na ni/ / mi rtag sdug bsngal stong pa dang / / de bzhin dbyig dug zug rngu bzhin/ / zlos pas bud med lus bsam bya/ / blo ngan phung po'i lcags kyus zin/ / 'khor ba las ni 'byung mi nus/ / rtag tu bud med chags gyur pa/ / de la grub pa yod ma yin/ / zlos pa 'di la tshul khrims nyams/ / de la grub pa mchog med cing / / grub pa 'bring yang yod med de/ / grub pa tha ma'ang yod ma yin/ /

“Men fooled by craving for women Are like jackals fooled by rotten flesh.[818] Beings suffer acute pain Because of things they are addicted to. “If they take up the Buddha’s teaching, Even those who previously corrupted the virtuous Dharma Will stop all suffering And be no more in the ocean of saṃsāra.[819] “Those who are keen on and enjoy mantra recitation Know great renown, are free of craving,[820] Are majestic, are a friend to the downtrodden,[821] And are free from all suffering. “Self-controlled and knowing the great truth, They worship the master and the deities. They are devoted to their mother and father And do not suffer on the account of women.[822] “Those who apply the teachings on the absolute truth Perceive that which is impermanent to be empty and fraught with suffering. Such mantra reciters regard the female body The same as goiter.[823] “Naive sensualists, though, who are of little intelligence, Are unable to escape saṃsāra.[824] One who is consistently attached to women Will not gain accomplishment. “Such a person’s conduct will be undistinguished; It will not even be mediocre. A reciter without discipline Will not gain even the smallest accomplishment.[825]

tshul khrims 'chal la thub dbang gis/ / sngags grub par ni ma gsungs te/ / mya ngan 'das grong 'gro ba yi/ / yul dang phyogs kyang ma yin no/ / byis pa ngan pa 'di la ni/ / sngags grub pa ni ga la yod/ / skye bo tshul khrims 'chal 'di la/ / de la bde 'gro ga la yod/ / mtho ris su yang mi 'gyur zhing / / bde ba mchog tu'ang mi 'gyur na/ / rgyal bas gsungs pa'i sngags rnams ni/ / 'grub par 'gyur ba smos ci dgos/ / ta la'i shing gi mgo bo ni/ / gang tshe bcad par gyur pa na 'ang / / sngon po nyid kyi skal med na/ / myu gu nam zhig 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de bzhin sngags grub rmongs pa dang / / tshul khrims nyams shing sdig las byed/ / rtag tu bud med chags pa la/ / 'dir ni rab tu bstan pa yin/ / mi dge'i bshes gnyen bsten pa la/ / sngags kyi rgyal po ga la 'grub/ / de bas dul dang rtag bzlas byed/ / bud med skyon ni rnam spyod la/ / de la chags pa rnam spang ba/ / de la grub par brjod pa yin/ / byis pa bud med la brgyal ba/ / gzhan la grub pa bsten pa min/ / blo ldan g.yeng ba med la dga'/ / gtsang zhing ma chags shes nyen can/ / rigs mtho brtan dang dpa' ba dang / / brtser ldan mthong na dga' ba dang / / chos dang chos min rnam dpyod shes/ / de la grub pa rnyed mi dka'/ /

“The lord of sages did not prescribe mantra practice For the ill disciplined, As it would not lead to the city, Land, or even the direction of nirvāṇa. “For a debased fool such as this, How could his mantra succeed? For a person fickle in his discipline, What pleasant state could be found? “Heaven is not for him, Nor a happy departure from this world, Let alone an accomplishment Of mantras taught by the Victorious One. “When the crown of a palmyra tree Has been cut off, How will fresh green shoots arise When the tree has no greenery? “So have been described the prospects of Accomplishing the mantra for those who are foolish in this life‍— The ill-disciplined evildoers Who develop attachment to women again and again. How could the king of mantras bring success When one is associating with a nonvirtuous teacher? “A mantra reciter should therefore always be self-controlled And never stray into vice. Those who avoid contact with women Will gain accomplishment. “No accomplishment is described for the others‍— The childish ones smitten by women. On the other hand, the wise ones who dislike schisms, Who are pure and associate with skillful friends,[826] “The steadfast heroes of the noble family, Who are kind hearted and pleasant to behold, Who understand the distinction between right and wrong, Will gain accomplishment without difficulty.
