de ltar sngags shes zhugs pa ni/ / grong du slong phyir rab tu 'jug / sngar ni brtags pa'i gnas dag tu/ / ci ltar 'dod bzhin song nas ni/ / blo ldan dag pas bslang ba'i snod/ / gtsang ba'i phyogs su yang dag gzhag /

“A mantra adept, conducting himself as described, Should enter a village in order to seek alms. He should go to a place as previously described That is pleasing to him. “Having gone there, He should eat proper . . .[827] Once he has settled in a clean place, Living on alms and keeping his thoughts pure,[828]

phyi rol song nas rkang gnyis bkru/ / de nas yang ni yan lag ste/ / de tshe srog chags med pa'i chus/ / lag pa g.yas pas byin pa g.yas/ / lag pa g.yon pas byin pa g.yon/ / yang na gnyi ga dus gcig bkru/ / sa ni lag g.yon yang bzhag nas/ / sngar ni yang dag bzhag pa yi/ / bdug pa gtsang ma'i sa dag gis/ / lag pa gnyis ni rab tu bkru/ / de nas sngags kyi dag byas pa'i/ / dri med gtsang sbra dag snod la/ / ba ni ser skyas bor ba yi/ / lci ba sar pa blang bar bya/ / srog chags med pa'i chur sbyar bas/ / ston pa la ni dkyil 'khor bya/ /

“He should wipe his feet[829] And go out of his dwelling once again.[830] Using water free of living organisms, He should place his right hand[831] on his right calf “And his left hand on his left calf, And rub them. To prepare his right hand, He should cleanse it by wiping it[832] “Seven times with pure and clean clay That has been prepared before.[833] Then he should place, In a clean and stainless pot,[834] “Some fresh cow dung excreted from a brown cow And purified by the mantra.[835] He should add to it water that is free of living organisms And draw with this mixture the maṇḍala of the Teacher.[836]

dang po thub pa mchog la ni/ / khor yug khru gang tsam du bya/ / gnyis pa rang sngags mgon po la/ / gsum pa rang rig lha la'o/ / sngags pa bzlas pa gang byed pa/ / rtag tu 'ang de nyid bya ba yin/ / yang ni sems can thams cad kyi/ / longs spyod phyir ni bstan pa yin/ / g.yas su 'jig rten mgon po yi/ / dkyil 'khor 'di ni rtag tu bya/ / dkon mchog gsum gyi dkyil 'khor ni/ / gru bzhi dag tu bya ba yin/ / gnyis pa rang sangs rgyas rnams la/ / gsum pa stobs bcu ldan pa'i sras/ / dkyil 'khor bdun po 'di dag ni/ / kun nas gru bzhir bya ba yin/ /

“Thus, one should first draw the maṇḍala of the best of sages, Which should be, preferably, one cubit in diameter; Then second, the maṇḍala of the lord of one’s own mantra;[837] And third, of one’s family deity. “The mantra practitioner should always draw the maṇḍala Of that deity whose mantra he is reciting. The fourth maṇḍala is said to be For the enjoyment of all sentient beings.[838] “On the right, one should always draw The maṇḍala of the lord of the world, Which is for all the Three Jewels, And should be square in shape. “Second is the maṇḍala for pratyekabuddhas, And the third for the sons of those endowed with the ten powers.[839] These seven maṇḍalas Should all have four corners.

khru gang ngam ni khru phyed du/ / nyin re zhing ni bya ba yin/ / sdig pa 'jig byed bzlas pa ni/ / dben pa'i phyogs su nyin re bya/ / sngags pa de nas langs nas ni/ / 'bad pas lag gnyis rab tu bkru/ / gtsang ba'i chu yis nye reg bya/ / dag cing srog chags spangs pa yi/ / dri med gtsang sbras 'bad nas ni/ / gtsang ba'i snod ni de tshe blang / / mtsho chen dang ni 'bab chu 'am/ / chu mig chu bo la gnas dang / / gtsang ba'i phyogs nas byung ba yi/ / sems can dag pa lag blangs la/ / gnyis sam gsum du rtag tu yang / / sngags pas nye reg bya ba yin/ /

“One should draw them either one cubit, Or half a cubit in diameter, every single day, In a secret place. Then, reciting every day, One will be able to purify one’s sins. “When rising after the ritual, The mantra practitioner should wash his hands carefully. He should perform ritual ablutions in clean and pure water, Free of living organisms. “The water should be taken, carefully, From a spotlessly clean and pure dish, From a big lake, a stream, A pond, a spring, or a river. “The water must come from a clean place And be drawn by a pure being.[840] The mantra practitioner should touch it Always two or three times.

de nas chus reg gdong dang ni/ / de bzhin du ni rna khung dag / mig dang sna dang lag gnyis dang / / spyi bo lte ba'i phyogs reg bya/ / dge ba spyod pas lan lnga'am bdun/ / cho ga ji bzhin thams cad bya/ /

“He should then wash his mouth,[841] And likewise both his ear lobes, . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[842] His eyes, the cavities of his nose, and his arms. “He should sprinkle the pure water On his head and his navel Five or seven times,[843] Doing everything according to procedure.

gtsang sbra'i spyod pa legs ldan pas/ / zlos pa gtsang bar gyur pa yis/ / slong snod yang dag blangs nas ni/ / chu yi gzhir ni 'gro bar bya/ / gang du chu yi rgyun 'bab gnas/ / de bzhin du ni chu mig dang / / chu bo rab tu 'bab pa la/ / rtag tu zas ni bkru bar bya/ /

“Following a ritually pure regimen, The mantra practitioner, himself purified, Should take his alms bowl And go to a natural receptacle of water “Where a stream of water is dammed, Or at the water’s spring. He should always wash the alms In the current of a flowing river.

gtsug lag khang ngam gnas khang du/ / de nas langs nas 'gro bar bya/ / gang du sngon ni brten pa dang / / gang du gnas pa der 'gro bya/ / de nas zlos pas lhung bzed de/ / song nas phyogs ni der gzhag bya/ / de nas nye reg myur byas nas/ / de bzhin yang ni lhung bzed blangs/ / lhung bzed sa 'am lo ma 'am/ / dngul dang gser gyi snod dang ni/ / zangs ma shing shun dag kyang rung / / ston pa la ni dbul bar bya/ / ston pa la ni bshos phul nas/ / rang sngags sngags kyi rgyal po 'ang brjod/ / 'gron gcig sdug bsngal gyur 'ongs nas/ / ci nus par ni sbyin pa bya/ /

“After that, he should get up And go back to his monastery or dwelling. Whichever dwelling he had stayed at, There he should go. “Having reached that place, The reciter should put down his alms bowl. He should then quickly perform the ritual ablutions, And take hold of his bowl once again‍— “A bowl that may be made of clay, Leaves,[844] silver, gold, Copper, or cassia bark‍— And offer food to his teacher. “Offering the food to one’s teacher, One should utter either one’s own mantra or the king of mantras. Welcoming a lone visitor, one should also offer to him Or to the poor, according to one’s means.[845]

rnam pa kun du kha zas ni/ / ha cang mang ba sbyin mi bya/ / sngags rig lus gdung mi bya ste/ / rnam pa kun du ci rigs bya/ / lto ba'i tshad tsam gzhag byas te/ / lhag ma'i zas ni rtag tu sbyin/ / bkres dang skom pas nyen gyur na/ / sngags kyi don la rten mi nus/ / kha zas mang dang nyung zos na/ / sngags rnams mnyes par mi nus so/ / de nyid phyir na thub dbang gis/ / sems can zas kyis gnas pa'o zhes/ / lus can rnams la gsungs pa ste/ / gang gis mi rnams 'tsho ba dang / / lha dang lha min dri za dang / / klu dang gnod sbyin mi 'am ci/ / srin po yi dgas sha za dang / / 'byung po skar ma gza' rnams dag / gang zhig kha zas mi za ba/ / de ni gang yang yod ma yin/ / rags pa'i zas ni gang yin pa/ / kham gyi zas su rnam par bsgrags/ / sems can phra ba'i zas can yang / / de bzhin gshegs pa nyid kyis gsungs/ /

“Whenever one offers food, One does not need to give an excessive amount. A mantra adept should not do what is damaging to himself, But always act sensibly. “He should set aside what will fill his stomach; The rest should always be offered away. One who is afflicted by hunger and thirst Will not be able to accomplish his mantra practice. “On the other hand, one who does not eat too much Or too little will be able to attend to his mantra practice. The lord of the victorious ones therefore said About all beings that possess a body,[846] “And who find sustenance in food‍— Food that gives life to humans, Gods, asuras, gandharvas, Nāgas, yakṣas, or kinnaras, “Rākṣasas, pretas, piśācas, Bhūtas, utsārakas,[847] and grahas‍— That there is not a single one of them That would not depend on the content of his food bowl. “The Tathāgata has proclaimed That some beings live on material foods That are taken by mouth, While others depend on subtle foods.
bsam gtan zas can rnams la ni/ / gzugs kyi khams na spyod pa'o/ / gzugs med khams kyi lha dag ni/ / ting 'dzin 'bras bu la spyod pa'o/ /
“Deities[848] who inhabit the form realm Live on the food of dhyāna; Gods in the formless realm Are nourished by the fruits of samādhi.
srid pa bar ma'i sems can rnams/ / dri yi zas su rab tu bsgrags/ / de bzhin 'dod khams sems can dag / sna tshogs zas la spyod pa yin/ /
“Beings in the intermediate state[849] Are said to depend on food too.[850] Beings in the desire realm Are nourished by a wide variety of foods.

de nyid phyir ni thub dbang gis/ / las kyi rgyu yis gsungs pa ni/ / sems can zas kyis gnas pa zhes/ / thams cad la ni rab tu bsgrags/ / zlos la rtag tu brtson pas ni/ / zas kyi tshod rig bya ba yin/ / gang phyir sngags brten nus pa ni/ / kha zas la ni rab tu gnas/ / spyod pa yongs su dag pa dang / / dge zhing tshangs par spyod pa dang / / kha zas tshod ni rig pa la/ / de la grub pa rnyed mi dka'/ /

Gods of the desire realm, asuras, and humans Live on foods that are taken by mouth.[851] “It has been taught therefore by the victorious lords That based upon karmic causes, Sentient beings are sustained by food; This is well known to all. “For someone who always engages in mantra recitation The act of eating is a matter of necessity. One who relies on food Will be able to practice the mantras. “If one’s conduct is completely pure, And one is competent and lives a celibate life, Such a mantra adept, relying on food, Will attain accomplishment without difficulty.

ci ltar shing rta'i shing rta pas/ / mig ni yongs su bskus pa ni/ / yun ring dus su brten phyir dang / / khal ni 'degs par bya phyir ro/ / de bzhin sngags pa sngags shes pas/ / kha zas gnas phyir 'dzin byed dang / / lus kyang tshim par bya ba'i phyir/ / zlos pas rtag tu gso bar bya/ / sngags rnams bsgrub pa'i phyir dang ni/ / byang chub tshogs ni bya ba'i phyir/ / de bzhin du ni sngags bzla ba/ / mi yi 'jig rten bsrung bya ba'o/ / de nyid phyir na thub mchog ni/ / 'od srung zhes bya sngon byung ba/ / de tshe de dus sa steng 'dir/ / 'od chen ldan pa des gsungs pa/ / 'byung po rnams la legs don du/ / sngags 'di rab tu gsungs pa ni/ / 'jig rten ma lus sdug bsngal dang / / dman dang dbul dang skyo ba dang / / 'bad rtsol dag la nyon mongs pa/ / de dag don phyir gsungs pa ni/ / 'byung po rnams la legs don dang / / de bzhin gnas par 'dod pa yang / / 'byung po rnams la zas don du/ / sngags mchog 'di ni gsungs pa yin/ /

“He is then like a carter of a cart Who has oiled the axles well,[852] Because he can [travel] for a long time And is able to convey heavy loads. “So, too, a mantra adept with knowledge of mantras Should use food for sustenance. A mantra reciter should always take nourishment For the upkeep and sustenance of his body, “As this is necessary for the accomplishment of mantras And also constitutes a cause for the two provisions for awakening. Consequently, one should recite the mantras, As this benefits beings in this world of mortals.[853] “For this reason the supreme sage, The previous buddha known as Kāśyapa, One of great splendor, taught At that time, on that occasion, upon the earth. “He taught the following mantra For the well-being of living beings‍— All those afflicted by suffering, Miserable, stricken with poverty, “Weary, resigned, and oppressed; For their sake he spoke this mantra. He taught it for the welfare of beings Who keep circling in saṃsāra. He taught this best of all mantras So that beings may find nourishment.[854]

nyan thos dag ni thams cad dang / / byang chub la gnas thams cad nyon/ / bdag gis sngags 'di rab brjod kyis/ / nad rnams 'jig byed zung shig dang / / gang yang bkres nad kyis nyen dang / / gang yang sems can skom pa rnams/ / kun gyi sdug bsngal nyer zhi'i phyir/ / 'byor pa 'dod rnams rab nyon cig / 'od srung 'od ni chen po pa/ / thub pa mchog gis de skad gsungs/ / nyan thos rnams ni yid dga' nas/ / khyab bdag la ni gsol ba 'debs/ / chos mkhyen sngags ni bshad du gsol/ / chos kyi rgyal po thub pa che/ / sems can brtse ba'i mchog gyur pa/ / dus ni rab tu nye bar gnas/ / de skad gsol nas thub mchog gis/ / ka la ping ka'i sgra skad dang / / rnga bo che yi sgra skad dang / / tshangs dbyangs stobs ni chen po dang / / tshangs shes rgyal ba sngon 'dren pas/ / 'byung po'i tshogs ni gang su dag / 'dir lhags gyur pa kun nyon cig / rkang med dang ni rkang mangs dang / / rkang gnyis pa dang rkang bzhi pa/ / mdor na sems can kun gyi phyir/ / bde 'byung sngags ni bshad par bya/ / 'das dang ma 'ongs da ltar gyi/ / sems can gang dag 'dir lhags pa/ / 'byor pa 'dod rnams da nyon cig / mdor na bdag gis rab bshad bya/ /

“He said, ‘May all the śrāvakas and all the bodhisattvas, Who reside in awakening, listen. Please receive from me the words of this mantra, The mantra that removes all ailments. “ ‘Those of you who are oppressed by the scourge of hunger, And those who are thirsty, Hear [this mantra] to have all your suffering pacified; Those desiring prosperity, listen well!’[855] “At these words of the supreme sage, Kāśyapa of great splendor, All the śrāvakas, their hearts full of joy, Supplicated the Sage thus: “ ‘Please tell us this mantra, O great sage, O Dharma king who knows Dharma! You care for living beings in the utmost. The time has now arrived.’ “Having been thus addressed, the best of sages Taught the mantra in full. With the sound of his voice, sweet as a cuckoo bird’s And as powerful as a drum or a thunderclap,[856] “This great, valiant man with the voice of Brahmā, The Victorious One, the foremost of brahmins, said,[857] ‘Please listen, O hosts of beings Who have assembled here. “ ‘I will now say, for the sake of all beings, Whether they are legless, many legged, Two legged, or four legged, The mantra that brings happiness. “ ‘I will say it for the sake of past and future beings, And also beings of the present time who have assembled here. I will speak briefly, so please listen If you desire prosperity.

na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M ga ga ne ga ga na gany+dza A na ya sarbaM la hu la hu sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ A kar+Sha Ni/ mA bi laM ba mA bi laM ba/ ya the pe staM me saM pa dA ya swA hA/

“ ‘Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers. The mantra is: “ ‘Oṁ, bring everyone to your celestial palace in the sky, quick, quick! Remember your samaya pledge! O summoner, do not tarry, do not tarry! Give me good fortune’[858]

bcom ldan 'das 'od srung gis de skad ces gsungs nas cang mi gsung bar gyur to/ / yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'od srung gis/ bar der rig pa'i sngags kyi tshig rgya cher gsungs pa na/ nam mkha' de thams cad chen po la 'os pa'i zas kyi sprin gyis yongs su khengs par gyur to/ / stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi nam mkha'i dkyil kun du zas kyi sprin gyis khyab par snang bar gyur to/ / sems can gyi bsam pa ci ltar mngon par 'dod pa'i bza' ba dang ci ltar 'dod pa'i zas de dag la char bzhin du bab par gyur to/ / ci ltar 'dod pa'i zas dang bza' ba'i bya ba ni bkres pa'i sdug bsngal zhi ba'i don dang / skom pa rnams kyis btung bar bya ba ni/ yan lag brgyad dang ldan pa'i chu'i rgyun yid la 'dod pa bzhin du der bab par gyur to/ / de'i tshe de'i dus kyi skad cig de nyid la bkres pa'i nad thams cad rab tu zhi ba dang skom pa thams cad dang bral bar gyur to/ / thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor de yang ngo mtshar dang rab tu dga' ba thob par gyur nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa la mngon par bstod de rjes su yi rangs nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la spyi bos phyag 'tshal te de nyid du mi snang bar gyur to/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa 'od srung yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i gnas su rnam par bzhugs so/ / bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa ngas kyang de'i tshe de ltar bshad cing rjes su yi rang bar byas so/ /

“Having said this, Lord Kāśyapa remained silent. “As soon as Lord Kāśyapa, the perfectly awakened one, spoke the words of this mantra in full, the entire sky appeared filled with a cloud consisting of choicest foodstuffs. The entire great trichiliocosm appeared to have its sky canopied with a cloud consisting of food. Whatever food the beings desired to satisfy their individual needs, whatever food they wished for, that had manifested for them. Whatever food preparations the beings desired to appease the pains of hunger, whatever drinks the thirsty ones wanted to drink, a stream of water along with the eight articles of offering, [all this] fell down exactly wherever it was wished for. “All the beings, for their part, had on that occasion, at that particular time, the suffering of their hunger completely pacified and all their thirst completely removed. The entire assembly became greatly amazed and elated and rejoiced at the Blessed One’s words. Joyfully they bowed their heads to his feet and disappeared at that very moment. Lord Kāśyapa, for his part, said, ‘Lord Śākyamuni and I sojourned on earth as tathāgatas. At that time this mantra was taught in this king of manuals and celebrated.’[859]

sngags kyi rgyal po'i mchog 'di la sems can thams cad kyi don du bkres pa dang skom pa sel ba'i phyir dang / sngags thams cad zlos pa dag la yang khyad par du sel bar 'gyur ro/ / dang por re zhig zlos pas sngags 'di bsgrub par bya ste/ gal te bsod snyoms la 'gro bar spro ba med na/ ri'i rtse mor 'dzeg ste 'bum phrag bdun bzla bar bya zhing / zas dkar gsum mam 'o ma'i zas bza' zhing ri'i rtse mo de nyid du 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi ras ris bar ma gong ma bzhin bzhag ste/ mchod pa chen po byas nas shin tu rgya che ba'i gtor ma phul te/ yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung 'di nyid kyis gsungs pa'i sngags kyis seng ldeng gi yam shing gi me rab tu sbar te/ shing u dum bA ra'i yam shing la mar dang sbrang rtsis btags pa'i shing rlon mtho gang tsam mam/ bil ba'i 'bras bu'i yam shing stong rtsa brgyad kyis sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas nam phyed kyi dus mtshams su sprin nag po chen po dang rlung gi dkyil 'khor byung na 'jigs par mi bya/ langs te gzhan du 'gro bar mi bya zhing / 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi yi ge brgyad kyi snying pos bdag nyid bsrung ba dang / dkyil 'khor bcing ba dang grogs bsrung ba yang byas na/ snga ma lta bu'i sprin nag po chen po de dang rlung nag po de yang mi snang bar 'gyur te/ bud med yang rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ 'od kyi dkyil 'khor gyis phyogs thams cad snang bar byas te sgrub pa po'i mdun du 'dug nas smra ba ni/ kye sems can chen po longs shig / khyod ni grub pa yin no zhes so/ /

“This mantra[860] ought to be accomplished for the benefit of all beings, in particular the mantra reciters, to remove their hunger and thirst, just as it was previously accomplished by the reciter [Kāśyapa]. If one does not feel up to wandering around for the sake of alms, one should climb to a mountaintop and recite that mantra six hundred thousand times,[861] living on the three pure food products[862] or milk dishes. “There, on the mountaintop, one should install the medium painting of Noble Mañjuśrī and, as before, offer a big pūjā [followed] by a big bali offering of food. Employing the mantra taught by Kāśyapa and other perfectly awakened buddhas, one should make a fire of cutch tree sticks and offer into it, [while reciting the mantra], one thousand and eight sticks of either the cluster fig or bilva tree, nine inches long, [moist with sap], and smeared with curds,[863] honey, and ghee. “Then, at the midnight hour, a great whirlwind will arrive in the form of a black cloud. One should not be afraid, nor should one get up or approach it.[864] Just as before,[865] one should effect protection for oneself and the protective binding of the maṇḍala for one’s companions by means of the eight-syllable heart mantra of Noble Mañjuśrī. The black whirlwind will subsequently disappear, and in front of the practitioner will appear women adorned with all types of jewelry. One of them, with a halo of light illuminating the space around her, will say, ‘Rise up, O great being! You have reached accomplishment.’[866]

de nas sgrub pa pos sna ma'i me tog gis bsres pa'i dri zhim po'i chus mchod yon sbyin no/ / de nas de nyid du mi snang bar gyur to/ / gang de'i nyin mo nas bdag nyid dang grogs po nyi shu rtsa lnga'am/ yang na ci 'dod pa'i grogs po dag la ci 'dod pa'i kha zas dang ci ltar 'dod pa'i yo byad rnams yang dag par ster bar byed do/ / de nas sgrub pa pos ras ris la gshegs su gsol ba'i mchod yon dbul te/ lan gsum bskor ba byas nas ras ris blangs te/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams la phyag byas nas/ sngar bstan pa'i sgrub pa'i thabs ci lta bu'i gnas dgon pa chen po'am/ ri'i rtse mo'am mi med pa'i gnas su 'gro bar bya'o/ / der lo ma'i spyil po byas te bdag nyid dang grogs po gnyi gar bcas te rab tu gnas par bya'o/ / der gnas pa dang gnas de la nam mkha' la 'gro ba la sogs pa'i las byas te/ de nas sgrub pa pos snga ma bzhin du ku sha'i khres la 'dug nas/ ras ris bar ma snga ma bzhin du bzhag ste/ seng ldeng gi yam shing gis me rab tu sbar la/ dus gsum du me tog pad+ma dkar po zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis btags pa stong rtsa brgyad nyi ma nyi shu rtsa gcig gi bar du sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas mtshan phyed kyi dus su sbyin sreg gi mthar 'phags pa 'jam dpal mngon sum du mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / 'dod pa'i mchog stsol bar yang 'gyur ro/ / nam mkha' la 'gro ba dang mi snang ba dang byang chub sems dpa'i sa dang rang sangs rgyas nyid dam nyan thos nyid dam/ tshe ring ba nyid dam rgyal srid chen po dang / longs spyod chen po nyid dam rgyal po dga' ba nyid dam/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal dang lhan cig rjes su spyod par 'gyur te mdor na gang 'dod pa de thams cad stsol bar 'gyur ro/ / gang don du gnyer ba de yang rjes su stsol bar 'gyur ro/ / grub pa'i rdzas thams cad kyang 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / sems can chen po rnams kyang 'gugs par byed par 'gyur ro/ / mdor na ji lta ji ltar brjod pa de thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / sngon gyi las kyi nyes pa yang yang dag par sbyong bar byed do zhes bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gsungs so/ /

“The practitioner should then give her a welcome offering of water with floating jasmine flowers. At that very moment she will disappear. On that very day, she will give to the practitioner and twenty-five of his companions, or whomever the practitioner fancies, foodstuffs and any useful objects that they may want. At that point the practitioner should give a farewell offering and circumambulate the painting clockwise three times. He should then take the painting, bow to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas three times,[867] and go to a place of his choice that is conducive to sādhana practice as previously described, such as a big forest, a mountaintop, or any uninhabited place. There, he should build a hut and live there alone or with companions. While living there, he should do the rites that involve sky travel, and so forth. “As before, the practitioner should sit on a bundle of kuśa grass, place the medium painting before himself, and, as before, light a fire of cutch tree sticks. He should offer one thousand and eight oblations of white flowers[868] smeared with curds, honey, and ghee, three times a day for twenty-one days. “Then, at the end of the homa ritual, at the midnight hour, one will see Noble Mañjuśrī in person. He will grant a desired boon, such as the ability to fly, become invisible, an attainment of a bodhisattva level, the state of a pratyekabuddha or a śrāvaka, the five superknowledges,[869] long life, a great kingdom with its many pleasures, the affection of a king, or the ability to commune with Noble Mañjuśrī himself. In short, he will grant whatever one may wish for. Or whatever one may ask for, that he will give. One may obtain all the power substances or be able to magically summon great beings. In short, he will do anything the way it is described to him. He may also purify one’s former transgressions. This was taught by Lord Śākyamuni.

gzhan yang las kyi thabs bar ma sgrub pa yang yod de dang por re zhig de ltar khyad par du gyur pa'i gnas sam gtsang ba'i sa phyogs sam/ chu bo'am chu gling gi ngogs su snga ma bzhin du thams cad bya ste/ ras ris nub tu bstan te bzhag la bdag kyang shar du mngon par phyogs par byas nas ku sha'i khres la 'dug ste/ snga ma bzhin du rgya cher sbyar bar byas nas dus gsum du yi ge drug pa bzla bar bya ste/ bzlas pa rdzogs pa dang dong ka'i me tog la tsan+dan dkar po'am gur gum gyis bsgos pas snga ma bzhin du sbyin sreg stong phrag brgya bya'o/ / de bzhin du me sbar nas sbyin sreg gi mjug tu ras ris rab tu 'gul ba na ni blon po nyid thob par 'gyur ro/ / ras ris las 'od kyi snang ba byung na ni 'od las rgyal srid thob par 'gyur ro/ / ras ris 'od 'bar ba'i phreng bas kun du khyab na ni rgyal po chen po bzhi'i rgyal srid thob par 'gyur ro/ / ras ris las me stag byung na ni sum cu rtsa gsum gyi dbang phyug brgya byin nyid thob par 'gyur ro/ / ras ris las chos 'chad pa'i sgra byung na ni/ byang chub sems dpa' sa gsum gyi dbang phyug nyid thob par 'gyur ro/ / ras ris kyi phyag gis mgo la byug par mdzad na ni/ mngon par shes pa lnga dang / sa bdun pa thob pa dang stobs bcu la gnas pa mthar gyis thob pa yin no/ / de nas sgrub pa po la bcom ldan 'das 'od srung gis gsungs pa'i sngags bsgrubs te/ bkres pa dang skom pa rab tu bas la ba'i don rjes su thob pa de nyid kyi 'tshog chas/ sngags spyod pa'i don sgrub pa'i thabs kyi chos la yang dag par rjes su bsgrub par bya'i/ gzhan du ni 'di 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / de ltar mthar gyis sngags kyi spyod pa la rjes su 'jug cing / mdor na nges par 'bad pa la ni rdzas dang sman dang yo byad kyi khyad par dang / nor bu rin po che sngar ji skad bshad pa rnams 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“Another practice procedure that constitutes the means of accomplishing medium rites will now be taught. To start, one should select a place in a clean area or a sandy bank of a river,[870] distinguished by the necessary qualities, and do everything as before. One should position the painting to face west, with oneself facing east. Sitting on a bundle of kuśa grass, one should repeat in full the same procedure as before. One should recite the mantra at the three junctions of the day six hundred thousand times.[871] At the end of the recitation, one should offer into the fire, prepared exactly as before, one hundred thousand blossoms of the bayur tree mixed with white sandalwood or saffron. “If the painting trembles violently at the conclusion of the homa ritual, it is a sign that one will become a minister. If the painting becomes luminous with light and rays of light issue forth from it, one will obtain a kingship. If the painting is completely enveloped in a halo of light, one will obtain the kingship over the realm of the four great kings. If the painting speaks,[872] one will obtain the position of Śakra‍—dominion over the realm of the Thirty-Three. If the painting delivers Dharma instructions, one will attain lordship of the [first] three bodhisattva levels. If one touches one’s head and arms with the painting, one will obtain the five superknowledges, the seventh bodhisattva level, and the ten powers. One will certainly obtain them one after the other. “When one has accomplished the mantra taught by Lord Kāśyapa and achieved the goal of removing hunger and thirst, one should practice the teachings on the method for accomplishing the goal of mantra activity, strictly following the procedure and using the specified implements. Otherwise one will not succeed. “In brief, one should follow the mantra practice step by step in this way, and one will certainly succeed.[873] One will definitely obtain all the power substances, special implements, and medicines, as well as jewels and gems as previously described.

sngags rig sngags ni zlos pa dang / / sems ni cho ga la mkhas pa dang / / sngags pa de tshe de yul du/ / de tshe gtsang ba'i kha zas bza'/ / zos nas yid ni dga' ba dang / / rtag tu dbang po rgyas pa dang / / lhung bzed lhag ma blangs nas ni/ / chu bo gtsang ba dag du 'gro/ / dben par yongs su bor nas ni/ / sdom can gyis sbyin dud 'gro la/ / dud 'gro la ni byin nas kyang / / 'bad pas snod ni bkru bar bya/ / de nas 'bad pa byas nas ni/ / sa yi snod kyang bsreg par bya/ / lhag ma lhung bzed bya ba ni/ / snum med zas ni med pa dang / / dri nyid yongs su spang bya zhes/ / lhag ma lhung bzed thub pas gsungs/ / gang du slong ba'i lhung bzed la/ / der ni kha zas mi spyad do/ / shing thog dngos rnams thams cad dang / / bca' ba rnams kyang der mi spyad/ / pad+ma'i lo mar bza' mi bya/ / ut+pal snod la bza' ba min/ /

“A mantra reciter skilled in the art of mantra, Who is familiar with the ritual procedure, Staying in a place as described above, Should eat pure and ‘white’ foods.[874] “Having eaten, happy at heart, With his sense organs always well nourished, He should take his bowl with the remaining food And go to a river with clean water. “The vow holder should throw the food in an isolated place And leave it for animals. Having given it to them, He should wash his bowl thoroughly. “The bowl should be made of clay And carefully fired. After using it, one should remove from the bowl All traces of grease or meat[875] “And ensure there is no residual smell‍— The supreme sage said this about the bowl when it is not used. One should never eat from the bowl That one uses for doing alms rounds. “One should never eat solid foods from it, Nor fruits, or liquids. One should not eat from a lotus leaf Or leaves produced by water lilies.

me tog dri mchog la min te/ / sngags pas de la bza' mi bya/ / gang yang lo ma ku mu dang / / p+lak+sha u dum bAr las byung / / pa Ta shing gi lo ma'ang min/ / tsher ma'i shing dang ri khrod byung / / a mra'i lo ma dag la'ang min/ / de bzhin pa Ta la las byung / / sa la shri sha'i lo ma dang / / byang chub shing las yang dag byung / / gang du bcom ldan sangs rgyas ni/ / shAkya seng ge bzhugs pa yi/ / shing de 'bad pas spang bya ste/ / so shing du yang bca' mi bya/ / klu shing gi ni ge sar dang / / lo ma dag kyang mi btu zhing / / gang du'ang nam yang bza' mi bya/ / mkhas pas de kun rnam par spongs/ / thub pa'i lo ma'i spyil po las/ / rmongs pas nam yang 'gong mi bya/ /

“One should avoid leaves of fragrant plants‍— A mantra practitioner should not use them, Nor the leaves of water lilies Or those that grow on the waved-leaf fig or cluster fig tree. “Nor should one use banyan leaves, Or those from karṇa, śāka, or gulmin trees,[876] And neither the leaves that grow on mango trees Nor leaves from the dhak tree. “Nor should one use leaves from the sal tree, flea tree, Or those that grow on bodhi trees‍— This is because the blessed Buddha Śākyamuni Used to sit on them. “One should carefully avoid these trees, And never fell them for timber. One should not pluck leaves From ironwood trees. “One should never eat from any of them, As they are all avoided by the wise. Sages who dwell in huts of leaves Must never step over [such leaves].

sngags pa dam tshig nyams 'gyur bas/ / lo ma de dag la mi bza'/ / lo ma gzhan la bza' bya ste/ / sngags pas der ni bza' bar bya/ / sa dang zangs mar bstan pa dang / / de bzhin dngul dang gser las byung / / shel dang rdo yi rang bzhin las/ / rtag tu bza' ba blang bar bya/ / lo ma'i rgyab tu mi bza' ste/ / lag pa'i mthil du'ang de bzhin no/ / stobs bcu ldan dang de yi sras/ / gang yang rang rgyal bse ru dang / / nyan thos gang zag dag la ni/ / phul ba'i lo ma gang yin pa/ / de dag zlos pas spang bya ste/ / rkang pas kyang ni mi 'gong ngo / / zas snod rnam pa sna tshogs dang / / de bzhin btung dang bza' ba rnams/ / thams cad de ltar phul bas na/ / sngags pas 'bad pas blang mi bya/ /

“A mantra practitioner would break his samaya Should he eat from the leaves of these trees. He should also not eat From the leaves of other trees.[877] “One can always take food from dishes As recommended, made of clay, copper, Silver, gold-based materials, And also quartz or stone. “One should not eat from the backside of a leaf, Nor from the surface of the hand. Those leaves that may serve as an offering For the sons of the possessors of the ten powers, the enemies of Māra,[878] “Or those that may be offered to the rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddhas, Or, indeed, to the śrāvaka followers Should be avoided by a mantra reciter, And never trampled underfoot. “As for the different bakery items,[879] And food and drink in general, A mantra practitioner should not appropriate Anything that has been duly offered.

rgyal dang rgyal ba'i mchog rnams dang / / de bzhin nyan thos gang zag dang / / dkon mchog gsum la phul ba yang / / zlos pas de dag rtag tu spang / / cung zad tsam yang lus can la/ / sngags rnams de la mi 'grub ste/ / bkra shis thams cad 'dod pa dang / / legs pa bzang po smos ci dgos/ / rgyas pa dang ni zhi ba dang / / bsam pa thams cad rdzogs byed pa/ / bshos ni za bar byed de la/ / de tshe 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / gtsang zhing shes rab tshul khrims ldan/ / snying rjes snying rje'i las can dang / / gtsang sbra'i spyod la dga' ba nyid/ / sngags rnams kun du 'grub par 'gyur/ / sems can gzhan la sbyin pa'i zas/ / zlos pas de ni bza' mi bya/ / gzhan gyis rab tu ma bstabs pa'i/ / zas gzhan bza' bar mi bya'o/ / cung zad tsam gyi kha zas kyang / / rang la byin pa blang bar bya/ / sngags shes de ltar 'jug gang yin/ / de la grub pa dpag na gnas/ /

“A reciter should always avoid What has been given to the victorious ones, To their followers, the śrāvakas, And to the Three Jewels. “For those ordinary beings for whom this is even slightly the case, The mantras will accomplish nothing; What need then to speak of high qualities, Or those who desire every fortune? “The mantras of those who eat food offered as bali Will not be successful, Whether in the rites of enriching or pacifying, Or having any hopes fulfilled. “The mantras, on the other hand, of pure, skilled, disciplined, And tenderhearted followers of the Dharma Will be successful in every respect, If they take joy in their pure conduct. “A reciter should not eat food Already given by him to anyone else, Nor should he eat the food Given by others to someone else.[880] “One should eat little, and only that Which has been given to oneself. A mantra adept who lives in this way Already has an accomplishment in his hand.

zlos pa 'di yi cho ga yis/ / sdom can bza' ba blang bar bya/ / thub pa rnams kyis bsngags pa yi/ / sngags rnams ma lus bsgrub par bya/ / mdor na cho ga mthong bas ni/ / bza' ba kun bya las rnams la/ / de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / sngags kyis ma lus dbang du byed/ / de nas zlos pas nye reg byas/ / de tshe sngags ni bzlas par bya/ / sngags pas de tshe lan bdun du/ / lus sbyang phyir ni bzlas nas su/ / 'byung po'i tshogs dang lha rnams dag / de don rgya cher rab nyon cig / lus kun nye reg byas nas ni/ / thub pa'i sngags 'di brjod par bya/ /

“The mantrin, the keeper of vows, Should receive food following this procedure And should practice all the mantras Commended by the sages. “Furthermore, I will now explain in brief The rules pertaining to rites For using all types of food, And I will also teach a mantra that purifies everything.[881] “When a reciter has done his ritual ablutions, He should always recite the following mantra. Having recited it seven times, This mantra practitioner will have purified his body. “Hear it and learn its full meaning, O assembly of spirits and deities! Having rubbed his entire body, A sage should recite the following mantra.
na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M sarba kilbi Sha nA sha ni/ nA sha ya nA sha ya/ sarba duSh+Ta pra yug+tan/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra hU~M dzaHswA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! The mantra is as follows: “Oṁ, you who remove all faults, destroy, destroy all those who engage in evil! Remember your samaya! Hūṁ jaḥ, svāhā![882]

sngags 'dis bslangs pa'i zas ji ltar yongs su spyod pa'i kha zas la lan bdun du bsngags te yongs su spyad par bya'o/ / zos nas kyang snga ma bzhin du nye reg bya ste/ spyi bo la sogs pa lus thams cad tu nye reg byas nas/ de nas ngal bso bar bya ste/ ngal sos nas yud tsam gyi phyed dam thun gcig ste/ de nas ras ris dang sangs rgyas thams cad la phyag 'tshal nas dam pa'i chos kyi glegs bam bklag par bya'o/ / 'phags pa shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang / 'phags pa zla ba'i sgron ma'i ting nge 'dzin dang / 'phags pa sa bcu pa dang / 'phags pa gser 'od dam pa dang / 'phags pa rma bya chen mo dang / 'phags pa rin po che tog gi gzungs dang 'di dag las gang yang rung ba bklag par bya'o/ / nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor zung tsam gyi tshad kyi dus na/ de nas yongs su grub pa ni ji ltar nus pa de bzhin du bklag par byas nas/ glegs bam brtul ba'am gos gtsang ma bgos te/ dam pa'i chos la phyag byas nas/ de nas khrus kyi don du chu bo'i ngogs sam/ mtsho chen por song ste 'jug par bya'o/ / phyin nas srog chags med pa'i sa blangs te/ lan bdun bzlas te de chu la gdab bo/ / de yang gang zhe na/

“Whatever rice dishes one has obtained through alms, or any other food that one is going to eat, one should eat it after incanting it with the above mantra.[883] Having eaten and ritually rinsed one’s mouth, one should wash the whole body as before, in the direction toward the head, and then take rest. Having rested for three quarters of an hour, or half of a half of one night-watch,[884] one should respectfully salute the painting and recite[885] genuine Dharma texts taught by all the buddhas.[886] “The texts to be recited are the noble Prajñāpāramitā, Candrapradīpasamādhi,[887] Daśabhūmika,[888] Suvarṇaprabhāsottama, Mahāmāyūrī, or Ratnaketudhāraṇī.[889] One should recite them in turns,[890] until the sun has risen one angular cubit above the horizon. Then, when one has finished reading and bowed down to one’s ability, one should put the books aside and cover them with a clean cloth. Having bowed to this work of Dharma, one should descend to a riverbank or a big pond in order to bathe. There, one should take some clay that is free of living organisms, incant it seven times with the following mantra, and throw it into the water. What mantra?

na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M sarba duSh+TAM staM b+ha ya hU~M/ na di ba rA bA ra Ni/ ku mA ra kr-I Da rU pi Ne ban+d+ha ban+d+ha/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra phaT phaT swA hA/

“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers. The mantra is: “Oṁ, paralyze all evildoers, hūṁ! You who hold a blue lotus and possess the graceful form of a divine youth, bind them, bind! Remember your samaya! Phaṭ phaṭ, svāhā![891]

'dis bsrung ba byas nas phyogs rnams bcing ba dang / grogs rnams dang dkyil 'khor dang thab khung bcing ba dang / ma rungs pa dang rab tu ma rungs pa thams cad 'gugs par byed pa dang / skud pa dkar po la lan bdun bzlas te rked pa'i phyogs su bcings na thams cad du 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / bzlas pa'i dus thams cad dang khrus kyi dus thams cad du yang bgegs ma rungs pa rnam par 'jig pa dang / rab tu zhi bar bya ba'i phyir sngags 'di 'bum phrag gcig bzlas na/ des ni las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / gtsug phud lnga'i phyag rgya chen po dang ldan pa dgod par bya'o/ / las thams cad byed par 'gyur te gzhan du ma yin no/ / de nas sgrub pa pos sa dang lci ba'i phye ma la sogs pa blangs te/ ci bde bar khrus byas te/ srog chags med pa'i chus kyang bkrus te/ las thams cad la yang srog chags med pa'i chus bya'o/ / de nas sa dang lci ba'am gzhan yang dri zhim po dang ldan pa'i yo byad kyi khyad par gyis byugs te de'i 'og tu khrus bya'o/ / chu'i nang du bshang gci yang dor bar mi bya'o/ / chu gtor zhing dor bar yang mi bya'o/ / chu la rtse bar yang mi bya'o/ / snying rjes bdag dang sems can thams cad la so sor brtag par bya'o/ / bdag med pa dang stong pa dang / sdug bsngal gyis khyab pa/ tshor bas mngon par gnod pa dang / sdug bsngal thob pa bzhin du 'gro ba dang 'ong ba'i sbyor bas sdug bsngal ba/ de bzhin du sems can sgrub pa dang bral ba/ sngags rig pas 'di lta bur 'jig pa dang rnam par g.yeng ba dang / rnam par 'jig pa la sogs pa'i sdug bsngal gyi tshogs kyis nye bar khyab pa/ 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho brgal dka' ba la gnas pa'i bdag nyid du mthong zhing gnas med pa dang / skyob pa med pa dang skyabs med pa dang shin tu dman pa'i yid can du bdag nyid brtags la/ sgom pa pos mi gang tsam gyi chu'am lte ba tsam gyi chu la gnas te chu de nyid kyi dbus su sems rtse gcig tu nye bar gnas par bya'o/ /

“One should use this mantra to effect protection [for oneself], bind the directions, form a protective circle for one’s companions, bind the fire pit,[892] and summon all the wicked and utterly wicked beings. With this mantra one can also arrest semen.[893] One should roam everywhere with a cord tied around one’s waist and incanted seven times. One should recite this mantra one hundred thousand times in order to destroy or appease the evil obstacle makers, reciting both during recitation sessions and the time of ritual bathing. In this way one will be able to accomplish all activities. When performing any ritual, one should put on the great fivefold seal [of Mañjuśrī].[894] One will be able to accomplish everything; it cannot be otherwise.[895] “The practitioner should take some powder consisting of dried clay and cow dung and do the ritual ablutions as he pleases. He should bathe in water that is free of living organisms. In all the rites, one should always use only water that is free of living organisms. Having bathed, one should smear oneself with a paste of clay and cow dung, or other fragrant unguents that are especially helpful.[896] One must not release into the water any phlegm,[897] urine, or feces. One should not splash in the water or engage in play. One should compassionately reflect on oneself and others and on the absence of self, emptiness, and the pain of experiencing pervasive suffering, which is like the pain experienced by someone separated from their mother.[898] A mantra adept should thus imagine himself to be a being without a practice to follow, one subject to ruin, fall, decay, and destruction, all of which are attended by suffering. He should think of himself as sinking deep into the ocean of saṃsāra, without a place to rest, protection, or refuge, and miserable. He should thus meditate, focusing his mind one-pointedly, while standing right there surrounded by water, submerged up to his neck or his waist.

dang po re zhig pad+ma chen po'i rtsa lag la me tog pad+ma chen po dang ldan pa/ pad+ma chen po'i 'dab mas nye bar mdzes pa blta na sdug pa/ sdong bu rin po che bai DUr+ya'i rang bzhin las byung ba/ pad+ma'i ge sar rin po che margad las grub pa/ 'dab ma stong shel las byas pa/ shin tu rnam par kha bye ba/ de'i rjes su skyes pa'i shel dang pad+ma rA ga'i me tog gis mdzes par byas pa de'i steng du seng ge'i khri rin po che'i rang bzhin las grub pa rin po che du mas nye bar mdzes pa/ ras bcos bu zung gis rab tu bkab pa de'i steng du bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das bsgom par bya ste/ chos 'chad cing bzhugs pa gser gyi mdog ltar snang ba/ kun nas 'od 'bar ba'i phreng ba can 'od 'dom gang gi dkyil 'khor gyis brgyan pa/ sku'i tshad chen po nam mkha' la thug pa dang 'dra ba/ skyil mo krung gis bzhugs pa g.yas su'ang 'phags pa 'jam dpal rgyan thams cad kyis nye bar mdzes par byas pa/ pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa rnga yab thogs pa/ bcom ldan 'das bzhugs pa'i zur na gnas pa/ sku'i kha dog dmar skya'am gur gum bdar ba lta bu'o/ / g.yon du yang 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug kha dog ston ka'i zla rgyu 'dra ba rnga yab thogs pa de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' brgyad la 'phags pa byams pa dang kun tu bzang po dang sa'i snying po dang nam mkha' mdzod dang sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sel ba dang / ngan song sbyong ba dang 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje dang khams bzang can te/ byang chub sems dpa' bcu po de dag gi g.yas logs su rang sangs rgyas brgyad bsgom par bya ste/ tsan+dan dang spos kyi ngad ldang dang tog dang legs tog dang tog dkar dang 'dod pa dang nye ba'i 'dod pa dang mu khyud de 'di brgyad do/ / de nyid du nyan thos chen po brgyad gnas pa la 'di lta ste/ 'phags pa maud gal gyi bu chen po dang shA ri'i bu dang ba lang bdag dang ba ra dwa dza bsod snyoms len dang / pi lin da'i bu dang 'phags pa sgra gcan 'dzin dang / 'od srung chen po dang 'phags pa kun dga' bo'o/ /

“First one should visualize a huge lotus stalk supporting a big lotus flower. It is adorned with big petals and made of beautiful-looking jewels. Its pericarp is of beryl, its petals of emerald, and its stamens of crystal.[899] It has one thousand petals and is in full bloom. It is adorned with flowers made of crystal and ruby.[900] On this lotus there is a lotus throne made of precious stone, adorned with many gems, and shaded by a pair of cloth canopies. On the throne, one should visualize Lord Buddha expounding the Dharma. He is of pure golden color, surrounded by bright light, and adorned with a halo one fathom wide. He is large in size, appearing as if painted in the sky, and sitting in a cross-legged posture. “To his right, on a lotus seat, one should visualize Noble Mañjuśrī, adorned with all the superb ornaments. He is not sitting but standing,[901] and holding, in his extended hand, a yak-tail whisk to fan the Blessed One. He is of light red hue or the color of ground saffron. To the left of the Blessed One, there is the noble Avalokiteśvara, the color of a full autumn moon, with a yak-tail whisk in his hand. Similarly, the eight bodhisattvas[902]‍—the noble Maitreya, Samantabhadra, Kṣitigarbha, Gaganagañja, Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin, Apāyajaha, the noble Vajrapāṇi, and Sudhana‍—should be visualized. These are the ten[903] bodhisattvas. “To the right,[904] one should visualize the eight pratyekabuddhas‍—Candana, Gandhamādana, Ketu, Suketu, Sitaketu, Riṣṭa, Upāriṣṭa, and Nemi. In the same place[905] there are also the eight great śrāvakas‍—the noble Mahāmaudgalyāyana, Śāriputra, Gavāmpati, Piṇḍolabharadvāja, Pilindavatsa, the noble Rāhula, Mahākāśyapa, and the noble Ānanda.

nyan thos chen po de dag dang nye bar dge slong gi dge 'dun mtha' yas pa bsgom par bya'o/ / rang sangs rgyas dang nye ba na rang sangs rgyas bsam gyis mi khyab pa bsgom par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' chen po brgyad kyi gnas su yang byang chub sems dpa'i dge 'dun bsam gyis mi khyab pa bsgom par bya'o/ / de bzhin du nam mkha'i dkyil thams cad du 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor dang ldan pa bsgom par bya ste/ bdag kyang lte ba tsam gyi chu la gnas bzhin du lha dang mi'i me tog rnam pa sna tshogs pa la me tog man dA ra ba dang / man dA ra ba chen po dang pad+ma dang pad+ma chen po dang / d+ha nu ska ri dang bar shi ka dang ut+pal sngon po dang / me tog rnam pa sna tshogs la tshad chen po dang / tshan chen por gyur pa ri rab tsam gyi me tog gi snyim pas bcom ldan 'das la yang dag par mchod de nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams la lha dang mi'i phye ma dang gos dang / gdugs dang rgyal mtshan dang ba dan dag dang mar me rab tu mang po bye ba khri phrag brgya stong yid du 'ong bas yang dag par mchod par byed la/ de bzhin du lha dang mi'i gtor ma dang / bdug spos dang bshos la sogs pa bsnyen bkur thams cad dang yo byad rnams nye bar dbul bar bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i mdzod spu nas kyang 'od zer byung ste/ bdag nyid dang phyogs thams cad kyang snang bas khyab par bsgom mo/ / zlos pa po bsam gtan la zhugs ma thag tu tshangs pa'i bsod nams dang mnyam pa'i 'bras bu thob par 'gyur nges par byang chub la yang gzhol bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Next to these eight great śrāvakas, one should visualize an infinite assembly of monks; next to the pratyekabuddhas, an infinite numbers of other pratyekabuddhas; and in the eight places of the eight great bodhisattvas, infinite assemblies of other bodhisattvas. In this auspicious way should one visualize the canopy of the sky filled with this great assembly. “Still standing in water reaching up to one’s navel, one should perform a big pūjā, offering flowers of many types, earthly and celestial, including māndarava and great māndarava, lotuses and great lotuses, or, according to season, blue lotuses[906]‍—different flowers of great size, baskets with flowers, and flowers piled as high as a mountain. Also, one should perform a pūjā, pleasing to the mind, for all the śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas, offering fragrant powders, parasols, flags, and banners‍—both earthly and celestial, in great numbers‍—including thousands of millions of billions of bright lamps. One should offer, in the same manner, requisites and articles used for a bali offering, such as incense and food. “One should then visualize oneself and everything illumined by the light issuing forth from the tuft of hair between Lord Śākyamuni’s eyebrows. Immediately entering samādhi while reciting the mantra, one will obtain fruits of the accumulated great merit and will certainly become destined for awakening.

de la sogs pa'i bsam gtan ni/ / 'jig rten gang zag mchog gis gsungs/ / 'byung po kun la legs pa dang / / sngags pa rnams la phan pa'i don/ / bsam gtan de tshe dang po'i gtsos/ / sngags pa rnams la phan don du/ / gsungs pa sems can rnams la ni/ / de nas thub mchog bdun pa yis/ / dkyil 'khor rnam pa de nyid ni/ / gang yin dang po thub pas gsungs/ / gnyis pa yi ni dkyil 'khor yang / / gsum par yang ni de las gzhan/ / dang po mchog gi grub pa yin/ / gnyis pa de bzhin de las gzhan/ / tha ma grub pa phra mo zhes/ / thub pa mchog gis nges par gsungs/ / mchog dang bar ma tha ma ni/ / de bzhin ras ris bar ma bsgom/ / mdor na rnam gsum sgom pa ni/ / sdig pa'i rnyog pa ma lus 'jig /

“This and similar meditations Were taught by the best of men For the sake of all beings’ welfare And for the benefit of mantra practitioners. “The supreme seventh sage[907] Taught at that time the most important meditation, For the benefit of all mantra practitioners And for all sentient beings. “He taught the features and appearance Of the first, the second, And the third maṇḍalas, And after that, he taught the mantra.[908] “The best of men declared that With the first type of painting, the accomplishment will be supreme; With the second, it will be inferior to that; And with the smallest, the accomplishment will be very small. “Just as with the form of the painting, so too Can the meditation[909] be supreme, medium, or smallest. In short, though, this meditation Will remove all of one’s faults.[910]

mkhas pas sgom pa'i rnam pa ni/ / de las gzhan du mi bsten te/ / sngags rnams de la 'grub par 'gyur/ / bsam gtan de la rab tu gnas/ / ci 'dod cho ga bstan nas ni/ / zlos pas bsam gtan byas nas su/ / sngags kyi lha ni gshegs gsol te/ / mchod yon gsol nas ci bde bar/ / chu bzhi de las byung nas ni/ / ci bde bar ni 'gro bar bya/ / gnas kyang sngar ni bstan pa yi/ / cho ga legs dben mthong ba yi/ / sngags pas sngags ni de tshe bzla/ / ci bzhin las ni sngar bstan pa'o/ / rang gi lha ni spyan drangs pa/ / der ni sngags kyis gshegs su gsol/ / de nas rang nyid bsrung bya zhing / / de bzhin grogs po dag kyang bsrung / / dge ba'i las kyi de nyid shes/ / cho ga'i las la dga' zhing 'dod/ / bstod pa'i rnam pa mang pos mchod/ / gang zag mchog la bstod nas ni/ / rang sngags sngags kyi mgon po dang / / nyan thos rang rgyal bse ru dang / / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' che/ / 'jig rten gsum la rjes gzung mdzod/ / sngags zlos pas ni gnas de nas/ / de nas kyang ni langs nas su/ / gnas ni thag ring song nas ni/ / phyi rol rlung ni rnam spangs par/ / snabs dang mchil ma rnam par dor/ / bshang dang gci ba'ang de bzhin te/ /

“There is nothing else to rely on Than the mode of meditation the wise one uses; His mantras will be successful, And he will be stable in his meditation. “When the reciter has finished his chosen meditation That has been taught according to its procedure, He should request the mantra deity to depart, Using whatever offering he finds pleasing. “He should then come out of the water stream And go, as he pleases, To a place as described before, Applying self-control according to rules. “A mantra practitioner should recite the mantra As prescribed for the previous rite. He should then request the mantra deity, And whatever deities had been summoned, to depart.[911] “Next, the skilled[912] practitioner should perform The protection rite for himself and his friends, While knowing the true nature of the ritual[913] And taking pleasure in following its procedure. “One should praise the best of beings By offering various eulogies, And thus supplicating one’s mantra deity, the lord of mantras, The śrāvakas, the rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddhas, “And the bodhisattvas, these great beings Who are forbearingly kind toward the three realms. A mantra reciter should then Get up from his seat once again “And, having gone some distance from his dwelling, Should expel his breath completely, Discharge mucous and spittle, And void his bladder.[914]

nyin par byang du kha bltas te/ / mtshan mo lhor ni blta bar bya/ / der ni don rnams mi bsam ste/ / sngags zlos nam yang bya ba min/ / der ni sngags kyang mi bzla zhing / / las bcas rigs kyang bshad ma yin/ / rab sngags 'gros dang mtshan sogs kyis/ / de tshe sa la 'dug par bya/ / gtsang phyir gos mtha' chur gzhug bya/ / chu gtsang gis ni nye reg bya/ / 'bad pas rkang gnyis bkru bya ste/ / sa ni khyor ba bdun blangs nas/ / lan bdun sa de nyid kyis so/ / bshang ba la ni sum cus bya/ / mchil ma dor dang de bzhin du/ / snabs dor ba la re re 'o/ / de nas nye reg bya ba yin/ / sgra med de bzhin song nas ni/ / lam la sogs pa spangs pa'o/ / de nas gzhan yang ci 'dod par/ / lho phyogs mtha' ni phyi rol du/ / g.yang sa zhing dang tshwa sgo dang / / de bzhin bye mas khyab pa la/ / chu bo spang zhing ngogs kyang spang / / mi gtsang ba yang spang bar bya/ / rab tu bkab dang dben yid ches/ / bas mtha' skye bo rnam spangs pa/ / sngags pas de 'dra'i sa dag tu/ / mi gtsang ba ni dor bar bya/ / sngags zlos dus ni shes pa yis/ / ci ltar 'dod pa'i shugs dag min/ /

“During the daytime one should face north, And at nighttime, south. A mantra reciter should never Wish for material benefits. “He should not recite, for this purpose, the mantra, Nor should he talk about his family and its activities.[915] A practitioner of impeccable conduct, Adorned with auspicious marks, should sit on the ground. “He should perform ablutions in pure water That reaches up to the hem of his robe, And thoroughly wash his feet, Wiping them seven times with clay.[916] “After urinating, he should use seven handfuls,[917] After passing stool, use thirty handfuls, And clean his hands afterward. When clearing phlegm or snot, He should take two handfuls of clay.[918] “One should perform one’s toilet carefully, In a place far from one’s dwelling.[919] One should go to where no sound is heard, And where all paths disappear.[920] “There, at one’s pleasure, Outside the southern boundary,[921] In a pit submerged in saline water[922] And covered over with sand, “But not on a riverbank‍— One should avoid polluting them with feces‍— In a covered and secret place where one feels at ease, In a wilderness devoid of people, “Can a mantra practitioner go to the toilet To void his body of impurities. A mantra reciter should know the right time And not hold in feces for too long.

de nas gtsang mtha'i phyogs song nas/ / bshang gci'i bya ba byas nas ni/ / de nas gnas su ci bder gnas/ / gsal ba'am dben pa'am g.yogs pa'am/ / skye bo med pa'i sa phyogs su/ / mi smra lus reg spangs nas ni/ / rtag tu bshang gci bya ba yin/ / bshang dang gci ba med byas nas/ / sdom can gtsang sbra rtag tu bya/ / reg na 'jam dang 'dod pa yi/ / srog chags rnam par spangs pa yi/ / sa gsum yongs su blangs nas su/ / gcig gis bshang ba'i phyogs su bya/ / sa yi cha gnyis dag gis kyang / / lag pa gnyis ni bkru bar bya/ / sngags pas sa dag rtag tu ni/ / sngar bstan pa dag blang bar bya/ / 'bad pas rkang g.yon bkru bya ste/ / de nas g.yas pa bkru bar bya/ / phan tshun nyid du bshibs nas ni/ / zlos pas rkang pa bkru bar bya/ /

“One should therefore go, whenever one feels like it, To a clean and deserted spot as prescribed And build there a toilet-cabin The way one wants. “One should always relieve oneself In silence, without any company, In a secret and hidden hut, Or a place concealed by the terrain. “When urine and stool have been evacuated, A vow holder should always clean himself Using soft and well-kneaded clay, Free of living organisms. “One should divide the clay into three lumps and always use one To clean one’s anus and the remaining two to clean each hand. A mantra practitioner should always collect the clay From the ground as described before “And thoroughly wash his feet, First the right, then the left. A mantra reciter should ensure That the feet do not touch each other.[923]

sngags zlos pas ni gtsang sbra dag / sngar ni rgya cher bstan pa yin/ / dri nga med pa'i gtsang sbra yang / / thub pas sngar ni bstan pa yin/ / sngags zlos pa yi gtsang sbra ni/ / 'dir ni mdor bsdus bstan pa yin/ / dri ma bral ba'i gtsang sbra yi/ / gtsang sbra nyid ni rtag tu bya/ / rgyud rnams kun la snang ba zhes/ / thub pa'i dbang pos gsungs pa yin/ / de nas zlos pas nye reg bya/ / sdom can gyis grub las kyang bya/ / sngar bstan pa yi cho ga yis/ / yid ni nang gi dag pa yin/ / rgyud rnams kun la bsngags pa yi/ / gtsang sbra lnga yi cho ga gsungs/ /

“The personal hygiene of mantra reciters Has been taught at length before. The pure beings have formerly taught The purificatory toilet involving perfume and unguents. This purification procedure will now be summarized For the sake of those who follow the rules of mantra. “The lord of sages has said That one should always stay pure Through a toilet involving perfume and unguents, As has been indicated in this entire tantra. “One should perform ablutions while reciting the mantra, Delighting, like a devotee, in the rites that are successful,[924] Following the method as previously taught, With one’s mind inwardly pure. “In all the tantras the purity Of mantra practitioners is taught to be fivefold.[925]

lus kyi dag dang ngag dag dang / / yid kyi dag pa yin par bstan/ / bzhi pa bden pa'i dag pa ste/ / chu yi dag pa lnga par bshad/ / bden pa'i chos can khro ba thul/ / de nyid shes shing bstan bcos mthong / / phra ba'i de nyid don la mkhas/ / sngags shes las la grags pa dang / / phyi dang nang la mkhas pa dag / de la dngos grub rnyed mi dka'/ / bden pa'i chos ni rnam spangs pa'i/ / rdzun gyi tshig ni smra mi bya/ / de nyid thams cad rnam spangs pa'i/ / ma rungs rab tu ma rungs dang / / rnam par sdang dang 'khrug bcas dang / / rtsub dang gnad rnams smra ba dang / / bden pa'i chos ni rnam nyams pa/ / sems can gzhan la gnod byed pa/ / phra ma nyon mongs can sems dang / / chos kun rnam par spangs pa dang / / rtag tu 'tshe ba'i bdag nyid dang / / khrims 'chal chos min spyod pa dang / / zlos pa'i sngags pas rtag tu spang / / grong gi chos kyang de bzhin no/ /

Purity of the body, purity of speech, And purity of mind are taught as three; Fourth is the purity of truth, And fifth is the purity of water.[926] “One needs to abide by the law of truth, control one’s anger, Understand the teachings of the tantras, know the śāstras, Be proficient in understanding the significance of the subtle nature, Understand the mantras, and know the rituals. “For those with both inner and outer[927] skills, Accomplishment will not be difficult to find. One should not utter false and disrespectful words That are devoid of the quality of truth; “Words that are cruel, cruel in the extreme, Or devoid of any truth; Words that sow mutual hatred and anger; Harsh words that attack someone’s weaknesses; “Words devoid of truth or justice That hurt other beings; Or slanderous words born out of an afflicted mind That have no virtue in them at all. “So, too, one should always avoid intrinsically harmful words That spring from wrong morality and do not accord with the Dharma. A mantra reciter should likewise always avoid The vulgar pursuits of common people.

khro ba log par 'byung ba yi/ / 'jig rten pha rol 'jigs rnams la/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' dang / / blo ldan rnams kyis yongs su smad/ / rtag tu rang rgyal bse ru dang / / nyan thos kyis kyang rtag tu smad/ / brdzun pa de bzhin 'jig rten na/ / sa steng grub pa 'dod rnams la'o/ / brdzun pa nye bar smra ba dag / shin tu mi bzad dmyal bar 'gro/ / de bzhin dud 'gro yi dgas dang / / gshin rje'i 'jig rten rtag tu 'gro/ / brdzun ni nye bar smra ba yis/ / der ni rtag tu gnas pa yin/ / blo ngan mi bzad ltung ba ni/ / thig nag rab tu tsha ba dang / / yang sos ral gri'i lo ma dang / / de bzhin shal ma li nags su/ / brdzun smra ba yi gang zag ni/ / bskal pa mang por der gnas so/ / log par smra bar gyur pa dang / / rmongs pas log par brjod pa yis/ / 'byung po rnams la slu byed pa/ / de la sngags grub ga la yod/ / des na rmongs pa'i las de yis/ / sngags ni grub par ma mthong nas/ / 'di skad du ni tshig smra ba/ / sngags las grub pa med do zhes/ / de skad kyi ni tshig smra ba/ /

“All the buddhas, bodhisattvas, And other wise beings condemn The misguided ire of Those who fear the next world.[928] “Certainly, too, the rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddhas And the śrāvakas, time and again, Condemn false speech for those people Who desire accomplishment in this world. “One who speaks false words Will go to a most terrible hell, Then to the animal realm, And after that to Yama’s world of hungry ghosts. “One who makes one’s living[929] by telling lies Will have to stay there continually. Such a feeble-minded being will go to the terrible Kālasūtra or Pratāpana hell, “Or Sañjīva, Asipattra, Or perhaps Śālmalīvana, Where a person who speaks untruth Will remain for many eons. “How could the mantras of a liar Ever bring accomplishment? One who deceives beings with false words Only brings them distress. One whose actions are so deluded Is therefore not going to see mantra accomplishment. “There will be no accomplishment for the followers of mantra Who utter words in the manner just described.

gang gis sangs rgyas bstan pa 'di/ / sa steng 'dir ni spangs pa yin/ / bskal pa bye ba mang por yang / / de la grub pa ga la yod/ / des na mi bzad dmyal bar 'tshed/ / mnar med 'jigs pa chen po dang / / yang sos dang ni thig nag dang / / rab tu tsha ba'i dmyal bar ni/ / dam pa'i chos la brnyas pa yis/ / der ni bskal pa chen por gnas/ / gang yang dmyal ba mi bzad par/ / byis pa'i skye bo 'tshed byed pa/ / dam pa'i chos la brnyas byed dang / / zhe sdang mun pas bsgribs pa'o/ /

How could they win accomplishment, Even after many eons‍—tens of millions? “One who rejects, on this earth, The teaching of the buddhas Will fall into the terrible And very frightening Avīci hell. “In the Sañjīva, Kālasūtra, Or Pratāpana hell One will remain for one great eon, If one shuns these genuine instructions of mine. “Foolish people will be cooked In a frighteningly dark hell, If, blind and veiled by darkness,[930] They disdain the genuine teachings.

mi shes byis pa'i ngo bo 'am/ / rmongs pa log pa'i nga rgyal gyis/ / rig pa'i rgyal po brnyas byed pa/ / mi bzad dmyal bar 'gyur ba yin/ / de bas sdig pa mi bya zhing / / log par smra ba'ang smad pa dang / / dam pa'i chos kyang mi brnyas shing / / lta ba log pa'ang smad par bya/ / de bas rtag tu dad gyur nas/ / sngags kyi cho ga rtag tu bsten/ / chos shes bden par smra ba dang / / sems can rnams la phan par dga'/ / sngags dang sngags shes bsten gyur pa/ / nges par de la grub pa yin/ / mchog dang bar ma tha ma las/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las byed de/ / las ni bya bas byed pa ste/ / bya ba mi byed rtag tu ni/ / bya ba las ni ldan pa las/ / rtag tu de las grub par 'gyur/ / bya phyir las rnams thams cad phyir/ / las phyir rtag tu bya ba yin/ / bya ba'i don du bya ba min/ / bya ba las la sbyar ba yin/ / don bcas nyid kyi bya ba la/ / bya ba nyid kyis rtag tu bya/ /

“Because of their ignorance and childish nature, They are deluded by their false pride. Slighting the vidyārāja,[931] They will fall into a terrible hell. “One should therefore refrain from committing evil, Or any contemptible falsehood. Genuine Dharma must not be despised, And wrong views must be rejected. “Consequently, one should always have faith And always follow the mantra procedure. One who knows the mantra should speak the truth, Always for the good of sentient beings. If such a one resorts to the mantra, He will certainly obtain accomplishment.[932] “The[933] (ritual) performance makes for the (ritual) activity; Such activity would not happen without the performance. One thus performs various activities (and creates various karmas) Of the sublime, medium, and lower types. One who thus engages in ritual activity Will always obtain accomplishment.[934] “In terms of purpose, the only purpose of ritual performance Is always for the sake of aim-oriented activity. Ritual performance without a motive is a kriyā (mere performance), Whereas ritual performance with a motive is a karman (retributive[935] activity). As activity that relies on ritual bears results, One should always perform rituals.[936]

bya ba las dang 'bras bu nyid/ / bya ba las 'bras rtag tu bya/ / 'bras med pa las 'bras 'byung zhing / / 'bras bu nyid kyang rtag 'bras 'gyur/ / 'bras med 'bras bur bcas pa yang / / thams cad 'bras bu kho nar 'gyur/ / yang dag ldan pas sngags grub ste/ / yang dag ldan pas sngags grub pa'o/ / ldan pas rnam par bral ba ni/ / mi ldan ldan pa grub pa min/ / bsgrub bya sgrub pa med pa ni/ / de la grub pa mi 'grub bo/ / grub pa'i rdzas ni thams cad kyang / / grub pa'i rgyu dang 'gal ba yin/ /

“First the required procedure, then the activity, and then the result‍— This is always the order in which these three occur. That which bears no result (that is, the procedure on its own) becomes that which Produces the result (the activity), thus always ending with the result.[937] “With results or without them‍— These are the only possible outcomes. A mantra is accomplished through union; This union is what brings the accomplishment of mantra. The absence of union is separation, And separation, unlike union, is not effective.[938] “Accomplishment‍—the accomplishing of what is to be accomplished‍— Will not be won in that case. The power substances‍—the causes of accomplishment‍— Will be blocked in every respect.[939]

sngags pa ma grub sgrub byed pa/ / sngags ni sgrub par byed pa yin/ / byed pa rab 'dod las yin te/ / las la 'dod pa bya bar 'dod/ / las min las ni thams cad la/ / las kyi rgyur ni mi bya'o/ / sngags dang rgyud kyi don ldan pa'i/ / 'bras bcas las ni brtsam par bya/ / brtsam pa'i las ni brtsam par bya/ / las med nyid la brtsam mi bya/ / ma brtsams bya ba'i sngags rnams ni/ / lus can kun la 'grub mi 'gyur/ / sems can kun la thugs brtse bas/ / thub pa mchog gis sngon gsungs pa/ / sngags ni rgyu yi sgo dag nas/ / rgyal ba'i sras la dam tshig bshad/ / sgrub pa sngags ni kun shes shing / / sngags kyi rgyal po mchog 'di ni/ / sngags kyi tshul du rab bstan yin/ / yang dag rdzogs lam rgyu yin pas/ / gang du rigs pa rtags yod la/ / sngags rnams thams cad 'grub par 'gyur/ / dus ni ring po mi thogs par/ / mkhas pas grub pa thob pa yin/ / 'byung po rnams la zhi don du/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis rab tu bstan/ / lam yang sngags kyi tshul gyis ni/ / mya ngan 'das grong 'gro ba yin/ /

“For those, however, who have accomplished their mantra, Even the mantras they have not previously accomplished bring results. The activity primarily intended by the performer Is the result of the procedure enacted for the purpose of this activity. “In all activities one should not perform that which is ineffectual. Since the [effective] activity has its causes, Which are the mantra, the tantra, and the intention, One should always[940] commence an activity employing [these causes]. “One should perform activities that are viable (ārabhya); One should not undertake activities that are ineffectual. Mantras that are not part of a ritual performance Will not bring accomplishment to anyone. “The samaya, formerly taught by the supreme sages‍— The teachers of the true Dharma‍— Has been explained by the victorious ones In the teachings of the Mantra Vehicle.[941] “The practitioner who knows the complete doctrine of the mantra Has been shown, in this matchless king of manuals,[942] The path that results in awakening‍— The path whose nature (rūpa) is mantra. “All mantras for which the lineage connection Is always present will be successful. One[943] will accomplish[, in such a case,] what one desires Within a short period of time. “For the sake of pacifying every being, The perfect buddhas taught The path that consists of mantra, Which leads to the city of nirvāṇa.[944]

de bzhin rtag tu byang chub lam/ / las don thams cad rdzogs par byed/ / de yi mthar thug dpung gnyen ni/ / dang po'i gnas ni sangs rgyas nyid/ / de bzhin 'bad med grub pa ni/ / 'di las 'bras bcas thob pa yin/ / sna tshogs las dang las shes yin/ / sngags bzlas dag ni byed par 'gyur/ / tshul khrims bsam gtan rnam thar rnams/ / mdor bsdus 'di yis thob pa ste/ / don kun sgrub byed grub pa ste/ / rgyal ba mchog gis gsungs pa yin/ / nor rnams rgyas par 'thob 'gyur te/ / dam pa'i 'gro bar gnas pa dang / / de bzhin rtag tu gnod sbyin spyan/ / lha mi'i rgyal srid byed par 'gyur/ / mi lha lha min 'jig rten gyi/ / de bzhin bdag po thob 'gyur te/ / bdag po ma lus de dag gi/ / sngags pas thams cad 'thob pa dang / / 'bras bcas bya ba byed par 'gyur/ /

“Thus, the path to awakening Always fulfills the purpose of all activities. Buddhahood is its place of origin And its ultimate and final aim. “If effected through mantra recitation, This path will be accomplished without effort, And its results will be obtained Along with the knowledge of various karmic predispositions.[945] “In brief, this attainment will come To those with discipline, meditation, and [the three] liberations, And it will fulfill for them all aims‍— This has been taught by the chief among the victors. “One will obtain an increase in riches, Reside in the ultimate realm, Or be the leader, in any event, of the yakṣas And the sovereign of gods and men.[946] “One who [knows] all mantras Will obtain supremacy Over men, gods, and asuras, And will make his rites bear fruit.[947]

gtsang sbra'i spyod dang ldan pa dang / / tshul khrims bsam gtan rtag tu dga'/ / rgyud rnams kun las gsungs pa yi/ / sngags pas bzlas pa rtag tu bya/ / sngags pa 'byor pa 'dod pa yis/ / las rnams sna tshogs bya ba ste/ / de bzhin mchog dang bar ma dang / / tha ma nyid kyang bya ba yin/ / tha mas longs spyod 'phel pa'i gnas/ / 'bring gis gong ma'i lus thob cing / / mchog gis rab tu 'gro ba ste/ / zlos pas rtag tu thob par 'gyur/ / sngags pas zlos mthar ngal bso zhing / / ji srid dus su bsdad par bya/ / zlos pas dus la bab pa na/ / der ni bsgrub pa bya ba yin/ /

“One should always practice pure conduct And take joy in discipline and meditation. A mantra practitioner should recite the mantra That has been taught in all the tantras. “The mantra practitioner may perform the various types of rites, Such as those of the highest or middling type. If, however, he desires riches, He should perform those of the lowest type.[948] “The lowest rites will bring an increase of pleasures; The middling will bring a superior body. The reciter will, however, attain the highest state Only through the supreme rites. “At the end of recitation, the practitioner should rest, For as long as necessary; He should do his formal practice When the time for it has arrived.

de ltar mod kyi de la sngags pas las rnams bsgrub pa na der rtag tu bzlas na/ skyes bu rnams kyi sdig pa zad par byed cing / las rnam pa sna tshogs skye ba brgyud pa dag tu gang du gang byas pa de dag la grub pa gnas par nam zhig 'gyur zhe na/ skyes bus ji srid tshogs pa rnyed pa na/ sngags pa'i ngo bos sngags bzlas pa na sdig pa zad pa'i don dang las bsrabs pas sngags 'grub par 'gyur te/ de bzhin du mchog dang bar ma dang tha ma dang 'jig rten gyis mchod pa dang / bzlas pas sdig pa mtha' dag zad par byed cing / lus can thams cad kyi skye ba brgyud pa dag tu gang byas pa'i sdig pa de dag thams cad 'jig par byed de/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi sngags bzlas na lus rgyan rnam pa sna tshogs kyis brgyan pa yid dga' zhing / yon tan thams cad kyis grags par 'gyur ba dang / gnod sbyin gyi tshogs kyi rgyal po nyid dang rtag tu don thams cad thob pa dang ldan pa yin no/ /

“Even[949] though all his rites have succeeded, the mantra practitioner Should keep reciting in order to exhaust all the evil of human beings. What is normally done through successive rites, He can accomplish through a single rite performed according to procedure. “His accomplishment will become stable When he has acquired all that is possible for human beings to acquire. Such a mantra reciter should nevertheless continue to recite the mantra In order to exhaust evil, and then, to remove the karma of beings.[950] “May the mantras revered by the world That are supreme, middling, or inferior be successful! When recited they will exhaust all karma That has been accumulated throughout the succession of births.[951] “The evil of all the embodied beings will then be destroyed. One will obtain various body ornaments, Pleasing to the mind and possessed of all good qualities. One will obtain a place in the Yakṣa, with the permanent position of a king. Those who recite the mantra of the tathāgatas Will obtain every accomplishment.”

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga rab 'byam las/ sgrub pa'i thabs kyi las kyi gnas bzhi pa las bzlas pa dang nges par sdom pa dang sbyin sreg dang bsam gtan dang / gtsang sbra'i spyod pa dang las thams cad kyi cho ga sgrub pa'i le'u rab 'byam bcu gcig pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the eleventh chapter of “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings. This chapter constitutes the detailed fourth chapter on places suitable for the performance of the ritual; on mantra recitation, ritual observances, homa, meditation, purificatory rites, and conduct; and the performance of all the rites according to procedure.
phreng ba'i cho ga
Chapter 12

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal nyon cig / khyod kyi rig pa'i sngags rjes su spyod pa/ sems can thams cad kyi don la rjes su brtson pa/ sems can rnams gang zlos par byed pa dang gang gis zlos par byed pa dang / de'i phreng ba'i cho ga de thams cad rgyud thams cad kyi spyi sngags thams cad kyi sgrub pa'i thabs legs par rab tu nyon la yid la zung shig / de skad ces bka' stsal pa dang / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ /

Now Lord Śākyamuni again looked at the entire Pure Abode, and said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “Listen, Mañjuśrī, to [the instructions] for the followers of your vidyā mantra who strive to benefit all beings‍—what mantras[952] they should be made to recite, by whom these mantras are to be recited, and the attendant rosary rites that are methods for accomplishing all the common mantras of all tantras. Listen carefully and reflect on this well. I will teach this [now].” At these words, Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, said this to the Blessed One:

bcom ldan 'das legs so legs so/ / bdag la thugs brtse ba'i don dang / sngags thams cad kyi spyod pa dang dam tshig la zhugs pa rnams kyis sems can rnams kyi slad du de bshad du gsol/ de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ /

“Good! May the Blessed One show us[953] the favor of teaching this for the sake of all those who entered the samaya of mantra practice, as well as every other being.” After Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, spoke thus, the Blessed One said this to him:

'jam dpal nyon cig / rnam par dbye ba rgya cher bshad par bya ste/ sngags thams cad kyi spyod pa la mngon par brtson pa na sems can thams cad kyi don sgrub par byed de/ dang por re zhig sngags su 'gyur ba de gang zhe na/ na maHsarba bud d+hA nAM/ a tsin t+yAd bud d+ha rU pI NAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M ku ru ku ru/ sarbA r+thAM sA d+ha ya/ sarba duSh+TaM bi mo ha ni/ ga ga nA bi lam+pe bi sho d+ha ya swA hA/ sngags 'dis phreng ba thams cad la las bya'o/ / sbyang ba dang dgug pa dang blang ba dang rgyu ba la sogs pa'i las bya'o/ /

“Listen, Mañjuśrī, as I will teach at length and in detail how beings can accomplish all their aims by applying all the mantra conduct. And how [do they do this]? First there is [the following] mantra. Homage to all the buddhas whose forms are marvelous and inconceivable. It is: “Oṁ, act, act! Accomplish all aims, accomplish![954] O (female) sky dweller who dumbfounds all the wicked ones, effect the purification! Svāhā![955] “One should employ this mantra in the rites of crafting all types of rosaries, those that involve cleaning, drilling, threading, separating, and so forth.[956]

dang po phreng ba'i shing la ni/ / sngags kyis lan grangs nyi shu bdun/ / mngon par bsngags pa byas nas ni/ / sdom brtson rtag tu bsrung ba bya/ / mtshan gcig der ni nyal byas na/ / rmi lam nang du des mthong ba/ / mi ma yin gzugs grub pa ni/ / mi sdug mche ba gtsigs pa'o/ / sngags pa la ni des smras pa/ / nor ni ci 'dod khyer cig ces/ / sgrub byed nang par langs nas ni/ / shing de las ni 'gro bar byed/ / sngags pas shing de bor nas ni/ / gzhan dag tu ni 'gro byed na/ / mi sdug gzugs can 'jigs byed pa/ / rmi lam du yang mthong mi 'gyur/ / dang por ru drA k+Sha yin te/ / in dra \u0f71k+Sha ni gnyis pa yin/ / tha ma bo de tse yin la/ / gzhan yang 'bras bu yod pa'o/ / shing la legs par 'dzeg mkhas pa'i/ / grogs dang lhan cig 'dzeg par bya/ / grogs po med par gyur na ni/ / rang nyid de la 'dzeg par bya/ / steng gi yal ga'i 'bras gnas su/ / sdom brtson brtul zhugs can 'dzegs te/ /

“First, when making a rosary, One should incant the tree Thirty-seven[957] times. A vow holder should then perform the protection rite. “One should then sleep one night And in one’s sleep one will see A nonhuman being, either beautiful Or ugly, and baring its teeth. This friendly being will say, ‘Bring me, as is proper, something of value.’[958] “The practitioner should then rise early And go to the tree that has been indicated, Unless one saw in one’s dream A tree that is huge and misshapen. “One should avoid trees of this kind And go instead to another tree.[959] A rudrākṣa tree is the best; The next best is an arjuna tree, “A lucky bean tree, or another good tree That bears fruit suitable for beads. One should climb it together with companions Who are good at climbing trees. “If such a mantra reciter[960] has no companions, He should climb by himself. A lay vow holder should climb to the fruit Located on the uppermost branches.[961]

rtag tu de la bag yod pas/ / steng gi yal ga la byung nas/ / yal ga'i steng gi 'bras blangs te/ / steng gi las la sbyar bar bya/ / steng gi grub pa mchog tu ni/ / gang zag mchog gis gsungs pa yin/ / bar ma bar ma'i grub pa ste/ / grub pa tha ma'ang tha ma'i yin/ / rtag tu srog chags ma zos pa'i/ / 'bras bu yang dag blang bar bya/ / nub kyi yal ga las thob pa/ / rdzas kyi rgyur ni grub pa yin/ / byang gi gnod sbyin la sogs dang / / lha rnams rtag tu 'gugs par byed/ / skad cig 'gugs par byed bsten pa'i/ / 'byung po thams cad zhi phyir dang / /

“Never distracted from his task, He should pick fruits that issue from upper branches. Having thus obtained fruits from these branches, He should use them in superior rites. “For it has been taught by the best of men[962] That when a rite is superior, the accomplishment will be superior too; When it is middling, the accomplishment will be middling; And when it is minor, the accomplishment will be minor. “If one takes fruit from them,[963] One will never be disliked by sentient beings.[964] If one takes seeds from the western branches, One’s mantras will be effective in the preparation of power substances. “If the seeds are from the northern branches, One will always be able to summon yakṣa deities or those of similar stock. It is said that they should be summoned For the pacification of all beings.[965]
