lha dang lha min dri za dang / / mi 'am ci dang srin po rnams/ / dbang du bya ba'i las byed de/ / 'byung po kun yang rgyas par byed/ / don yod las ni byed pa ste/ / las rnams sna tshogs ma lus byed/ / shar phyogs yal ga las skyes shing / / yang dag 'byung ba'i 'bras bu ni/ / de tshe 'bad de byas gyur na/ / tshe ni ring ba'i rgyu yang yin/ / rtag tu sngags grub 'bras bu ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs byed pa yin/ / gang zhig lhor ni 'gro ba yi/ / yal ga lo mar rab ldan pa'i/ / sngags pas de ni 'bad de spang / / sems can rnams kyi srog 'phrog byed/ / lhor brten pa yi yal ga dang / / 'bras bu gang dag skyes pa ni/ / blangs na gdung byed dgra rnams kyi/ / srog ni 'jig par byed pa yin/ /

“The gods, asuras, gandharvas, Kinnaras, and rākṣasas, on the other hand, Can be summoned in a properly performed rite In order to provide nourishment to all beings. “One will make all the rites That are done on earth[966] bear fruit. If the seeds originate from a branch That is in the eastern quarter, “One should always employ them zealously As causes for bringing long life. Thus, one will always obtain a different mantra-accomplishment Depending on the type of seeds. “If a branch extends in the southern direction And abounds in leaves, A mantra reciter should carefully avoid it, For the seeds from it will drain the vital force from living beings. “If one recites using the seeds That are growing On branches extending south, One will destroy the life force of one’s enemies.[967]

zlos pas 'bad de spang bar bya/ / bsod nams ma yin mang po'i rgyu/ / yal ga 'og tu 'phyang gnas la/ / 'bras bu gang zhig rab bsgrags pa/ / lha min bu mo gnas pa yi/ / sa yi 'og tu 'gro bar 'gyur/ / de yi 'bras bu'i phreng ba ni/ / blangs nas 'og tu 'gro brten pa/ / sa yi 'og tu gnas par ni/ / des na de ni 'gro bar byed/ / der zhugs lha yi bde ba ni/ / zlos pas thob par 'gyur ba yin/ / lha min bu mo chags bzhin du/ / bskal par de ni gnas par byed/ / me tog phreng ba kun blangs nas/ / de nas zlos pa slar log bya/ /

“One should carefully avoid such acts, though, For they are the cause of a great deal of negativity. Seeds that are described as hanging Underneath the lower branches “Will enable one to reach Rasātala, The place where dānava women live, If one takes along a rosary made of them. So have these seeds been described.[968] “Seeds that cling to the lower branches Will enable one to reach Pātāla. Once he has entered there, Divine pleasures await a mantra reciter. “He will remain united with asura women And stay there for an eon. A reciter will be able to descend there If he takes with him a complete set of such seeds.[969]

grogs dang lhan cig bsrung byas nas/ / de nas ji ltar bde bar 'gro/ / gnas nas thag ring song nas ni/ / de bzhin gtsang phyogs cho ga bzhin/ / de nas sngags pas rtag tu 'dug / phreng ba yongs su sbyang bar bya/ / brtson pas phreng ba'i 'bras blangs te/ / kun nas yongs su dag byas nas/ / sngags pa bzang pos phreng ba dbug / gsum bdun brgyad dang gcig gam ni/ / nyi shu dang ni rtsa gcig tu/ / sngags kyi de nyid shes pas bkru/ / snga ma'i sngags kyis rtag tu yang / / bdun nam brgyad du bzlas par bya/ / de nas dag par yang dag 'dod/ / pad+ma'i rtsa lag dag las ni/ / bu mos bkal ba'i skud pa dag / gsum dang lnga ldab byas pa yi/ / sdom can gyis ni phreng skud bya/ /

“One should perform a protection rite And travel, with companions, to a place of one’s choice. Having thus traveled to a distant place, Which always must be clean,[970] “A mantra practitioner should stay there. He should purify the set of seeds, Taking each of the seed-beads And cleaning it thoroughly all over. “Having cleaned them completely, The mantra adept should drill holes in them. Repeating the mantra three, seven, eight, One, or twenty-one times, “One who knows the nature of mantra should purify the beads. Always using the same mantra as before, Repeated either seven or eight times, The purification will be ensured. “Such a lay vow holder should prepare twine Using thread spun by a virgin Joined with five threefold strains Of fibers from a lotus stalk.

sngags kyi de nyid shes pas brgyu/ / 'bru ni phra zhing shin tu zlum/ / rtag tu srog chags bu ga med/ / legs 'jam smad pa'ang med pa yin/ / mdzes dang kha dog mdzes pa dang / / de bzhin gas med bu ga med/ / ru drAk+Sha dang bo de tse/ / in drAk+Sha yi 'bras bu nyid/ / rtag tu lung tang mdzes pa dang / / gzhan yang 'bras bu 'dod pa dag / 'bad pa yis ni phreng ba dag / sngags pas brtson byas de tshe brgyu/ /

“One who knows the nature of mantra should string upon it Seeds that are fine, well rounded, Never damaged by worms, And without protrusions or other imperfections. “They must be beautiful and of nice color, Without holes or cracks, And may be either from the rudrākṣa tree, Lucky bean tree, or arjuna tree. “Applying himself to the task with care, A mantra practitioner should string a rosary of beads That is ever unspoiled, beautiful, Not deformed, and composed of identical beads.[971]

gser ram yang na dngul dag gam/ / nor bu shel las byas pa dang / / dung dang mu sa ra dag dang / / mu tig las kyang bya ba yin/ / byi ru rnam pa sna tshogs kyi/ / phreng ba dag kyang bya ba yin/ / gzhan yang rin chen bzang po yi/ / phreng ba legs par rab tu bya/ / sa ni rab bzlums ril bu dag / mnyam par bzhag nas skud pas brgyu/ / gzhan yang ril bu cung zad gang / / 'bras bu 'byung khung dag las bya/ / ku sha'i rtse mo'i mdud pas kyang / / sngags pas 'bad de bya ba yin/ / brgya rtsa brgyad dam nyi shu 'am/ / lnga bcu nyid ni bar ma yin/ / sngags pa mnyam par bzhag nas ni/ / tshad 'dis phreng ba brgyu ba yin/ / rtsa brgyad stong du bya ba ni/ / phreng ba'i mchog tu bya ba yin/ / phreng ba'i rnam pa 'di bzhi yang / / sngags pas rtag tu brgyu ba yin/ / de ltar brgyu ba byas nas ni/ / rim pa gsum mam gnyis su bya/ / lcags bzang rang bzhin gdu bur bya/ / de bzhin gser dngul dag dang ni/ / de bzhin zangs ma'i gdu bu yis/ / phreng ba kun yang bcing bar bya/ /

“Alternatively, the beads Could be made of gold, silver, Rubies,[972] crystal, Conch, musāragalva coral, or pearl. “One can make different types of rosaries, Using coral or other precious substances,[973] To create a divine rosary, Beautiful and auspicious. “With a focused mind, one should string onto the thread Round beads made of earth, Or any other beads that are more or less round, Be they seeds or mineral in origin. “Reciting the mantra with earnestness, One should string the beads using a sharp-pointed blade of grass,[974] Either one hundred and eight of them, or twenty-five,[975] Or the medium number of fifty. “A rosary of this size should be strung By a well-focused mantra practitioner. The supreme kind of rosary Would consist of one thousand and eight beads. “It is always a rosary of one of these four types That may be strung by the practitioners of mantra. When subsequently tying the knot, One should do it thrice, or at least twice.[976] “To keep the rosary tight (mālāsamāsataḥ), One should fasten [the knot][977] With rings made of flower-metal, gold, Silver, or copper.
de nas yang mig kun mthar ni/ / kun la'ang de bzhin gdags par bya/ / 'bad pas dam du bcing bya ste/ / ji ltar dam por 'gyur bar ro/ /
“Finally, one should make a plaiting loop, Adding them in succession to form a plait.[978] One should wrap the plait firmly and with care, So that it stays tight.

yongs su gsal bar byas nas ni/ / dkyil 'khor lta bur mthong ba yin/ / de ltar sbrul gyi gdengs ka ltar/ / yongs su 'khor bas brgyan pa yin/ / mu tig phreng ba 'dra ba yis/ / mgul bar brgyan pa lta bur bya/ / chu bo dag ni dri med pa'i/ / chu gtsang dag gis khrus bya zhing / / ji ltar go rims khrus byas nas/ / chu bzhi las ni ldang nas su/ / 'bad pas de bzhin nye reg bya/ / phreng ba rjes su blangs nas ni/ / ba yi rnam lngas rab tu bkru/ / de bzhin sa yi phye ma dang / / chu gtsang dag gis rab bkrus te/ / dri zhim dag gis rjes byugs shing / / rab tu bsngags pa'i kha dog kyang / / tsan+dan dkar dang gur gum mo/ / de nas de bzhin gnyi ga 'gro/ / 'bad pa yis ni rab tu bkru/ /

“One should fashion it well To make it resemble a maṇḍala With the shape of a snake’s hood Adorned by the wrapping. “The rosary may have the form of a string of pearls, Fashioned as a neck ornament. One should wash it[979] in pure water, Such as that of a clean river. “Having washed it as described before, One should take it out of the water And perform the ablutions thoroughly oneself , Holding it as one does a string of beads. “One should wipe it with the five products of the cow And, likewise, with powdered clay. One should then rinse it with clean water And smear it with fragrant unguents, “Including those of auspicious colors, Such as white sandalwood and saffron. Having thus anointed it with care, One should go to one’s hut.[980]

de bzhin khrus byas song nas ni/ / gang na ras ris bar ma de/ / rgyal ba gtso bo thub mchog ni/ / shAkya seng ge mi yi mchog / de bzhin rtag tu ston pa'i gzugs/ / sa steng rgyal ba'i ring bsrel can/ / de yi mdun du phreng ba ni/ / de dang nye bar gzhag par bya/ / de dang nye bar bzhag nas ni/ / de yi mdun du nyer gnas nas/ / stong phrag gcig dang brgyad dang ni/ / brgya dang rtsa brgyad bzlas nas kyang / / nyin zhag gcig ni smyung byas te/ / bdun pa thub la phreng ba dbul/ / snga ma de bzhin bzlas byas nas/ / tshad kyang de dang mnyam par bya/ /

“One should walk up to the place[981] Where the painting of the medium type is, With the supreme among the victorious ones, the chief sage, The best of men, the Lion of the Śākyas, painted in its center. “One should always place the rosary Before the image of the Teacher[982] that contains relics[983] Of the victorious upon the earth; It should be placed close by. “One should thus place the rosary on the canvas Before and near to the image of Śākyamuni And incant it 1000 times 108,[984] Plus an additional 108 times. “Having fasted the whole day and night, One should offer the rosary to the best of sages. One can also do the recitation as before, Identical in terms of numbers.[985]

de nas phreng ba la bzlas nas/ / de yi mtshan mo nyal bar bya/ / ku sha bting ba'i sa la ni/ / sngags shes der ni nyal bar bya/ / gal te des ni rmi lam na/ / dge ba'i rmi lam mthong na ni/ / 'bras bcas rmi lam ston pa ste/ / de la grub par bstan pa yin/ / sangs rgyas nyan thos bse ru ni/ / gal te 'di yis rmi lam mthong / / sngags pa de yi bya ba ni/ / 'bras bcas nges par 'grub par 'gyur/ / gzhon nu'i gzugs can byis pa ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs mdzes mthong ba/ / gal te rmi lam nges mthong dang / / phreng ba stsol ba'ang de bzhin te/ / don yod de ni 'grub 'gyur te/ / sngags kyi don rnams sgrub byed pa'o/ /

“Then, having incanted the rosary, One should leave it there for the night. A knower of mantras should sleep in the same place, On a bed of kuśa grass spread on the ground. “Should he behold in his sleep Beautiful dream images, They indicate the results In which he will obtain accomplishment. “If a practitioner of mantra should see in his dream Buddhas, śrāvakas, or pratyekabuddhas, His ritual actions will definitely succeed, Bearing results for him. “If he beholds in his sleep A wonderful, beautiful-looking boy In the form of the divine youth, He should offer the rosary to him. His mantras will succeed without fail, Accomplishing all his aims.”

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga las ras ris bar ma la brten pa cho ga rab 'byam las/ phreng ba'i cho ga rab 'byam bcu gnyis pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed twelfth chapter in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings. This chapter belongs to the detailed section on the procedure of the “medium” painting, and also constitutes the detailed chapter on the procedure of the rosary.
sbyin sreg gi cho ga
Chapter 13

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas/ gzhan yang thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal khyod kyi sngags mtha' dag rnam par dgod pa'i khyad par gyi cho ga dang sbyin sreg gi las la rab tu sbyor ba'i rig pa sgrub pa yod de/ me la nye bar spyod pa'i khyad par gyi cho ga'i phyir/ gang gi rig pa thams cad kyi spyod pa la mngon par brtson pa'i sems can rab tu 'jug cing gnas par 'gyur ro/ / de gang zhe na/ gsang ba'i rig sngags kyi gzhi ni 'di lta ste/

Now Lord Śākyamuni again looked at the realm of the Pure Abode, and said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “There is, O Mañjuśrī, a ritual sequence for a special worship of [the god of] fire, which is meant for those practitioners of vidyā who engage in the rite of homa according to the special procedure that has been succinctly explained in the chapter on mantras in your manual. Once established in this routine, beings become actively engage in the conduct of all vidyās. What is this sequence? The mantric words of the secret vidyā spell are as follows:
o~M ut+tiSh+Tha ha ri ping ga la lo hi tA k+Sha/ de hi da dA pa ya hUM s+pha Ta s+pha Ta sarba big+h+NAM bi nA sha ya swA hA/
“Oṁ, rise up, O tawny [flame] with red eyes! Give and cause to give! Hūṁ, phaṭ phaṭ![986] Destroy all the obstacles, svāhā![987]

'jam dpal 'di ni me'i snying po'i mchog las thams cad byed pa 'dod pa thams cad ster bar byed pa yin te/ dang po re zhig sgrub pa pos me'i snying po 'di lan cig bzlas pas/ sreg blugs gsum gyis me la sbyin sreg byas nas me spyan drang bar 'gyur ro/ / de ltar rab tu sbyar na zhi ba dang rgyas pa dang / drag po'i las dag la yam shing rnam pa gsum du 'gyur te/

“This, O Mañjuśrī, is the supreme heart [mantra] of [the god of] fire that accomplishes all activities and fulfills all wishes. “At the beginning, the practitioner should offer into the fire three oblations of ghee, incanted each time with this heart mantra of fire. For someone engaged in this way in the performance of the pacifying, nourishing, or wrathful activities, there are prescribed three types of firewood, respectively.

mya ngan med shing zhi don du/ / rlon pa nyid ni rab tu bsngags/ / mtho gang 'am ni khru gang tsam/ / sor gsum srid du bya ba yin/ / snum pa'i rnam pa rab tu bsngags/ / cho ga 'di ni bya ba yin/ / bu ga med cing nang stong min/ / de bzhin ne tso'i 'dab ma dang / / ljang dang dkar ba'i kha dog gam/ / kha dog nag pa spang bar bya/ / srin bu rnams kyis zos pa'ang spang / / bu ga yod pa'ang rnam par bzlog / gzhan yang kha dog rab bsngags min/ / tha ma nyid kyang rnam par spangs/ / ha cang skam min rlon pa'ang min/ / tshig min las ni brtsam par bya/ / rul ba dang ni yo ba'ang min/ / shin tu ring ba'ang spang bar bya/ / de nas me thab bya ba ni/ / kun nas gru bzhir bya ba ste/ / 'og nyid du yang brko ba ni/ / 'bad pas khru ni bzhi yi tshad/ / khru gsum dang ni khru gnyis dang / / de bzhin khru gcig tshad du bya/ / rtag tu srog chags spangs pa dang / / bye mas legs par sbyar ba gang / / de nas pad 'dra'i lan kan ni/ / kun nas dkyil 'khor 'dra ba'o/ / yang na 'bad pas zur bzhi yang / / de bzhin lan kan dbyibs su bya/ / rdo rje'i rnam pa 'dra ba yi/ / rtse mo gnyis su'ang rtse gsum bya/ /

“The sticks from the aśoka tree are for the activity of pacifying, Especially if they are moist with sap. The best ones are nine inches, a cubit, Or perhaps three fingers long. “The ritual instructions specify That viscid sticks are the best. They should be without holes nor be hollow, With the hue of a parrot’s plumage. “One should avoid yellow, White, or black colors. One should collect sticks without holes,[988] Rejecting also those damaged by worms. “Sticks of other[989] colors are not recommended. One should avoid only sticks of the worst kind. They should be not too dry and not too moist. Nor should one use scorched sticks. “One should also avoid those that are Rotten, crooked, or too long. One should then prepare a fire pit, Rectangular on all sides. “One should carefully dig a pit To the depth of four cubits, Or, alternatively, three cubits, two cubits, Or even one cubit. “The pit should be free of living organisms And made of sand. One should then prepare a lotus-shaped altar[990] Encircling the pit all around. “Or, one can carefully make An enclosure in the shape of a square, With corners in the shape of vajras, Both ends of which are three-pronged.[991]

me thab kyi ni thad ka la/ / khru gnyis thad kar bya ba yin/ / gtsang dang de bzhin gsal ba'i gnas/ / chu klung de bzhin chu dbus dang / / shing gcig gi ni phyogs dag dang / / dur khrod dang ni khang stong du/ / sbyin sreg legs par yang dag brtsam/ / de bzhin ri bo'i rtse dag tu'o/ / rtag tu lha khang stong pa dang / / dgon pa chen po'ang de bzhin no/ / gang yang sgrub pa'i phyogs dag tu/ / gang zag mchog gis rab gsungs pa/ / sbyin sreg gnas ni thams cad la/ / gnas de dag ni thams cad gsungs/ / ku sha'i khres ni khru gang tsam/ / de la 'dug par byas nas ni/ / sngags shes der ni sbyin sreg las/ / khyad par du yang bya ba yin/ / gnas de dag la 'dug na ni/ / myur du 'grub par the tshom med/ / shar dang byang du bltas pas kyang / / zhi ba dang ni rgyas par bya/ / lhor bltas nas ni drag po'i las/ / sngags pas de ni spang bar bya/ / shar du bltas pas zhi ba 'grub/ / byang du bltas pas rgyas pa'o/ / 'di yis sngags pa dus rtag tu/ / sngags kyi ngo bo yang dag brtsam/ /

“Inside this fire pit one should prepare A flat, two-cubit area. One who is well prepared should perform the homa[992] In a pure, cleanly swept place, “On a well-chosen riverbank,[993] Or in a lonely spot on dry land,[994] A charnel ground, an empty dwelling, Or on a mountaintop. “Also, one can always do this in an empty temple Or a big forest. Places that have been recommended by the most eminent of men As suitable for successful practice “Have also been described as suitable in every respect For the performance of the homa rite. One who knows the mantra, Having sat on a bundle of kuśa grass “One cubit in size, Should perform the homa rite in a particular way. If one remains in such places, Accomplishment will be swift, have no doubt. “For the activities of pacifying and enriching One should sit facing east or north. Violent activities, however, associated with the south, The mantra practitioner should avoid. “When one faces east, the accomplishment will be of a peaceful kind; When it is the north, it will be of an enriching kind. One should always begin the mantra recitation[995] Facing these directions.
bil ba p+lag sha n+ya gro d+has/ / rgyas pa'i las ni yongs su bya/ / mngon spyod shing las bya ba ni/ / dkar dang tshwa dang skyur dang rno/ /
“One should perform rites of enriching Using sticks of the bilva, mango, waved-leaf fig, or banyan tree. Sticks used for violent rites Should be dry, pungent, sour, or bitter.[996]

de dag thams cad spang bya ste/ / thub pa rnams kyis rtag tu bkag / zhi dang rgyas pa'i las la ni/ / shing rlon dag ni rab tu bsngags/ / drag po'i las la shing skam ste/ / thub pa rnams kyis rtag tu spangs/ / yam shing de dag med na ni/ / tha mal shing dag kun du brtag /

“All these that are meant for violent rites should be avoided, As they have been prohibited by the sages. In the rites of pacifying and enriching Sticks moist with sap are said to be the best. “Dry sticks, used in violent rites, Should be avoided, according to the sages; They can, however, be used If the right type is not available.[997]

gnyi ga'i rtse mor bya ba ni/ / ku shas kun du yang dag dkri/ / sngo dang snum pa 'dra ba dang / / rma bya'i mgrin pa 'dra ba dang / / de 'dra'i ku shas rtag tu ni/ / zhi ba dang ni rgyas pa bya/ / margad rnam pa 'dra ba dang / / rtswa skam gyis ni rtag tu yang / / sdig pa'i las rnams bya ba yin/ / 'dir ni thub pa mchog gis bkag / dri med chu ni yongs dag pa/ / srog chags dag gis rtag spangs pa/ / des ni kun nas gtor byas nas/ / g.yas phyogs su ni bskor byas te/ / sdom brtson gyis ni me sbar bya/ / cho ga ji bzhin nye reg bya/ /

“Around the fire pit one should spread An array of kuśa grass blades that are pointed at both ends, Using blades that have a glossy, yellow-green color, Like a peacock’s neck. “One should always use blades of this kind In rites of pacifying and enriching, And dried blades of other grasses Of an emerald color “In rites of evil activity; As for these, though, they are forbidden by the best of victors. One should take pure and clean water, Which always must be free of worms, “And circumambulate the fire pit clockwise, Sprinkling it all around. One should then light the fire, wholly absorbed in this task,[998] Having performed the ablutions according to procedure.

gtsang ba'i rtswa yi rtsa bas ni/ / me sgron tshad dang ldan byas nas/ / de nas chang par bcangs nas ni/ / 'bad pas me ni spar bar bya/ / kha yi rlung gis mi bya ste/ / rtag tu gos kyi mthas kyang min/ / sham thabs bla gos rnam par spangs/ / gos gzhan dag ni bkag ma yin/ / shin tu drag pas de mi bya/ / gnod par dga' ba'i ma yin na/ / rlung yab gtsang dang de bzhin gos/ / lo mas kyang ni rlung yab bya/ / rlung gis khyad du mi gsod pa/ / me ni rab tu sad byas nas/ / sngags shes pas ni me sbar te/ / sbyin sreg don du legs mnyam gzhag / lag pa de ni g.yon pa yis/ / lan gsum bar du chus gtor nas/ / der ni ba yi mar gyis ni/ / sreg blugs gsum ni des sbyin bya/ /

“With clean roots of grass, One should prepare a torch of the right size, Then take it in hand And carefully kindle the fire. “One should not blow at the kindling with one’s mouth, Nor fan the fire with the edge of one’s garment, Such as the undergarment or the upper garment, But there is no restriction on other clothes. “Nor should one fan the fire with one’s hand, Or risk putting it out by being overzealous. One should fan it with a pure frond of a palm, Or perhaps a clean cloth or leaf. “When the fire has been kindled, Fanned with the wind generated as described,[999] The knower of mantra should let it blaze And be well focused on the homa. “One should then sprinkle it three times, Using one’s left[1000] hand. Then one should offer three oblations, Using for this purpose clarified cow’s butter.

de nas kyang ni phyag bya ste/ / sangs rgyas kun dang skyob pa dang / / rang sngags sngags kyi mgon po la/ / de nas ci 'dod phyag bya'o/ / de tshe me yi snying po yis/ / sngags kyis lan bdun rtag bzlas pa'i/ / dri zhim me tog dag gis ni/ / sdom brtson me ni spyan drang bya/ / sngags shes rtag tu spyan drangs nas/ / mkhas pas gnas ni sbyin par bya/ / gdan dang gnas ni sbyin byed na'ang / / de nyid sngags yin gzhan pas min/ / zho dang mar gyis sbags pa dang / / sbrang rtsis sbags pa'i yam shing gis/ / rgyas pa'i las ni bya ba'i phyir/ / sngags kyis kun du sbyin sreg bya/ /

“One should then bow to All the buddhas, the protectors, And salute also, as seems fit, The mantra lord of one’s personal mantra. “Then, wholly dedicated to the task, One[1001] should invite the god of fire using fragrant flowers, Always incanted seven times With the heart mantra of fire.[1002] “A wise practitioner, a knower of the mantra, Should summon him and offer him a place. One should offer him a seat With the same heart mantra and no other. “In order to worship the god of fire One should offer three[1003] oblations of firewood sticks Covered in curds with ghee and smeared with honey, Performing the rite complete with the mantra.[1004]

mar dang sbrang rtsir ldan pa 'am/ / yang na zho dang ldan pa yi/ / yam shing rdzas dang ldan pa yis/ / gnyi ga la gnas de tshe bya/ / stong ngam yang na 'bum mam ni/ / yang na brgya rtsa brgyad du brtag / de tshe sngags pas sngags bzung nas/ / lan re bzlas shing me la dor/ / 'bar ba'i me yi phreng ba 'am/ / de bzhin me lce gcig gyur la/ / zhi ba'i las kyi sbyin sreg bya/ / dud pa med la rgyas pa'ang bya/ /

“One should, at that time, Smear both ends of the sticks with these substances, Applying ghee and honey, And mixing it with curds.[1005] “One can perform this 1000, 100,000, or 108 times. If one is a practitioner of a secret mantra, One should pronounce it once for each oblation cast into the fire. “When performing peaceful rites, The fire should form a circle, Or a single tongue of flame. For the rites of enrichment, it should be smokeless.[1006]

dud bcas drag po'i las la bya/ / de ni rgyal bas smad cing spangs/ / gal te me ni mdog ldan na/ / sbyin sreg las ni rab tu sbyar/ / zhi la kha dog dkar po ni/ / rgyal ba mchog gis rtag tu bsngags/ / gal te me dkar sbyin sreg byas/ / der ni sngags rnams 'grub par 'gyur/ / de bzhin rtag tu mdog dmar la/ / rgyas pa 'grub par 'dod pa yin/ / gnag dang du ba'i kha dog dang / / ser skya la ni sdig ldan las/ / kha dog rnam gsum bstan pas ni/ / rnam gsum grub pa 'di dag yin/ / mdog gzhan sprin gyi kha dog gam/ / rnam pa sna tshogs mdog ldan pa/ / sa steng 'di la sngags rnams ni/ / grub pa yod pa ma yin no/ /

“The fire should be smoky for rites of the violent type, Described by the victorious ones as forbidden. If the fire has a color, Its color is associated with a respective oblatory activity. “If this activity is peaceful, a fire that is white in color Has always been praised by the victorious ones as the best. If one offers into a white fire, The [peaceful] mantras will be successful. “The color red will always guarantee Accomplishment in the rites of enrichment. If the fire is black and the smoke is brown, Violent rites will be successful. “There are thus three types of accomplishment Associated with the three colors. The fire may also have another color, such as the color of a cloud, And may appear in different forms. “When the fire is like this, The mantras cannot possibly succeed.

de 'dra'i kha dog 'dra ba 'am/ / rnam pa sna tshogs mdog ldan pa'i/ / me ni 'bar ba de mthong na/ / las kyi sbyor ba'ang brtsam par bya/ / gal te sngags ni grub 'dod na/ / phyi rol me ni sbar bar bya/ / cho ga mthong ba'i las kyis ni/ / phyir yang sbyin sreg rab tu bya/ / me yi sngags ni zlos pa yis/ / gshegs gsol spyan drang nyid kyang bya/ / dkyil 'khor 'dir ni cho ga bzhin/ / sngar ni rab tu brtags pa yis/ / de nyid kyis ni sbyin sreg bya/ / gshegs gsol spyan drang la sogs pa'ang / / de nyid kyi ni las dag gis/ / las rnams thams cad nyid kyang bya/ / me yi las dang de bzhin gzugs/ / ras ris mdun du brtsam byas na/ / der ni sngags rnams 'grub 'gyur zhes/ / sngon gyi bde gshegs rnams kyis gsungs/ / rgyal bas bsngags pa'i las rnams dag / der ni rnam pa kun du bya/ / sdig pa dag ni khyad par du/ / gang yang rgyal bas smad pa dang / / 'jig rten 'gro bas smad pa dag / gzhan gyis smad pa'ang bya ba min/ /

When seeing the fire blazing With this color “Or with various [other undesirable] colors and forms, One should begin the rite once again. If one desires the mantra to succeed, One must perform the recitation again,[1007] “And do the homa rite once again Following the established ritual procedure. To invoke or dismiss the deity, One should pronounce the mantra of fire “Within the circle prepared beforehand, Following the right procedure. Employing this mantra, one should perform the homa Complete with the rites of invoking and dismissing the deity. “Based on this particular rite, One can accomplish any rite. One should commence such fire observances In front of the painting. “One’s mantras will then be successful, As formerly declared by the tathāgatas. One should not perform just any activities, however, But only those praised by the victorious ones. “Thus, one should not perform other activities, Especially the evil ones Censured by the victorious ones And forbidden and reviled by the world.[1008]

'khor los sgyur bzang nyid dang ni/ / byang chub sems dpa'i sa 'thob dang / / de bzhin mngon shes lnga 'thob dang / / de nas lha nyid thob pa'o/ / ras ris la rtag brtson zhing gshegs/ / sbyin sreg las la 'jigs med dang / / sa 'og gi ni bdag po 'am/ / yang na bar snang spyod par 'gyur/ / sa bdag lha dang gnod sbyin nyid/ / rtag tu gnod sbyin mo 'gugs byed/ / rgyal srid bdag po nyid dang ni/ / yul nyid dang ni grong dag dang / / rig pa 'dzin dang lha min nyid/ / sems can thams cad dbang du byed/ / bdag nyid che dang sems can che/ / 'byung po rnams ni 'gugs par byed/ /

“One will become either a universal emperor, Or a bodhisattva protecting the earth.[1009] One will attain the five superknowledges, Or the state of a god. “One who always applies the appropriate knowledge of the painting And is confident about the rite of the homa[1010] Will become the master of subterranean paradises And also be able to travel in the sky. “One will be able to change into an earth god or a yakṣa Who always attracts yakṣa maidens. One may become the ruler of a kingdom, Or a district, or perhaps the head of a village. “One may at will become a vidyādhara or an asura With the power to enthrall all beings. One will be able to summon the spirits, As well as the great and noble beings.

byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' che/ / sa bcu la ni yang dag gnas/ / sbyin sreg las kyis 'gugs byed na/ / sa steng mi rnams smos ci dgos/ / sde dpon dag dang de bzhin du/ / khyad par 'jig rten dbang phyug 'gyur/ / dbang 'gyur cig car 'byung po kun/ / de bzhin mi yi dbang po nyid/ / sems can kun la dbang don dang / / yang na rgyal po dbang du 'gyur/ / de bzhin rtag tu las kun la/ / sbyin sreg gis ni kun du bya/ /

“By means of this rite of homa, One will be able to summon the bodhisattvas, The great beings who abide on any of the ten levels, Not to mention ordinary humans on this earth. “One may become a general of an army, Or someone of exceptionally great might in this world. One may control all the spirits[1011] And, likewise, become a lord of men. “Whether it is for the sake of enthralling all beings, Or becoming the king of men on earth, One should always include, with every activity, A complete rite of homa.

thams cad kun la brtson bdag nyid/ / las kun las ni bsten byas na/ / de ni nges par 'grub 'gyur te/ / las dge'i don ni dam pa yin/ / bar ma nyid kyang 'grub par 'gyur/ / tha ma'i las kyang de bzhin no/ / rdzas rnams dag ni de bzhin du/ / grub dang ldan pa'ang rnam pa gsum/ / 'bras dang bcas par grub snang ste/ / sbyin sreg las la rab tu bstan/ / phyag rgya gtsug phud lnga bcings nas/ / sngags kyang skra can mas byas na/ / las rnams kun ni bya ba dang / / sngags pas bdag nyid bsrung ba bya/ / sbyin sreg las la rab 'jug pas/ / de nas sngags 'di brjod par bya/ / bdun nam brgyad du bzlas pa yis/ / las 'di la ni rtag tu bya/ /

“One should practice all the activities With complete dedication and in full; The supreme activity will then be successful And will serve the highest purpose. “So too will the activities of the medium And the lowest type be successful, And one will also obtain all the relevant power substances. Again, as has been said, the accomplishment can be of three types. “When the rite of homa is performed, One’s accomplishment will be rich in results. One should form the five-crested mudrā And say the mantra of Keśinī. “One should perform all activities, Having first performed the rite of self-protection. When engaging in the rite of homa, One should recite the following mantra. This mantra should always be repeated, In this rite, seven or eight times.
na maHsarba bud d+hA bo d+hi satwA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta ga tiM ga tA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M dz+wa la tiSh+Tha hUM ru ru bi shwa saM b+ha ba saM b+ha be swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, the perfect teachers. The mantra is: “Oṁ, burn! Remain, hūṁ! Ru ru, you from whom all things arise! You who are the origin, svāhā![1012]

sngags kyi sbyor ba 'di yis ni/ / yang dang yang du shing la bzla/ / gnyis sam bdun du bzlas pa yis/ / sngags rig des ni sbyin sreg bya/ / me tog bdug pa dri yang rung / / ma lus thams cad dag dang ni/ / chu la sngags rnams bzlas pa yang / / 'di nyid kyis ni sbyin par bya/ / las rnams kun gyi rgyu yi phyir/ / de nas cho ga brtsam par bya/ / las rnams dag ni thams cad la/ / snga ma'i sbyor ba nyid kyis bya/ / snga ma'i gtsug pud lnga bcings te/ / phyag rgya chen po grags ldan ma/ / snga ma'i gtsug pud lnga bcings bya/ / skra can ma nyid rab bzlas pas/ / des na srung ba byed par 'gyur/ /

“Using this mantra method, One should thoroughly recite again and again. A mantra adept, having thus recited twice or seven times, Should offer oblations into the fire. “Using water incanted with this mantra, One should sprinkle Flowers, incense, perfume, And everything all around. “One should then commence all activities According to procedure. In all one’s activities one should apply The previously described method. “Having formed the great mudrā‍— The famed five-crested[1013]‍— One should do the protection rite And then continually recite the mantra of Keśinī.[1014]

grub pa'i rgyu la 'jigs med pas/ / las rnams thams cad brtsam par bya/ / gal te la nye bzang mthong ba'am/ / rtag tu dge ba'i sgra thos na/ / de la sngags ni don yod de/ / ji ltar 'dod bzhin mchog stsol 'gyur/ / dang po'i las la rab sbyor dang / / sngags kyi rgyu la rab 'jug na/ / thams cad 'bras bu bcas pa dang / / de la grub par brjod pa yin/ / rgyal sgra rnga ni pa Ta ha/ / rnga bo che yi sgra dag ni/ / brtson byas grub pa ma lus 'gyur/ / sbyin sreg las la yang dag bsten/ / gzhan yang la nye bzang po dang / / 'dab chags dge ba'i sgra dag dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs nges pa'i sgra/ / rgyal ba rnams kyis bsngags pa dang / / bkra shis bzang po rab bsngags dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs yid 'ong sgra/ / gdugs dang rgyal mtshan ba dan dang / / bud med rgyan gyis brgyan pa dang / / de bzhin mchod yon bum pa gang / / mthong na 'grub pa'i rgyu rnams yin/ / rnam pa du ma'i kha dog gam/ / 'jig rten gyis mchod rab bsngags pa/ / de dag mthong na 'grub 'gyur ba/ / sngags rnams du ma'i spyod yul yin/ /

“One should embark on all activities Confident about the causes of accomplishment. If favorable signs are seen And beautiful sounds continuously heard, “One’s mantras will certainly produce results By fulfilling the wished-for boons. When first applying the activities And engaging with mantra‍—the cause‍— “The accomplishment of such activities Will be complete and rich in results. The cries of ‘Victory!’ will be heard, Along with the sounds of large and small kettledrums. “Accomplishment is always said to follow,[1015] If one relies on the rite of homa. Other favorable signs may also be seen Or the beautiful sounds of birds heard. “Various kinds of sounds may be heard, Whose meanings[1016] have been described by the victorious ones‍— Many kinds of exquisite sounds, Divine, auspicious, and pleasing to the mind. “Parasols, banners, and flags may be seen, Along with women bedecked in jewelry, And likewise vases full of offerings‍— Seeing them is a sign of accomplishment. “They are all of many forms and colors, Praised and venerated by the world. When they are perceived, The mantras, with their different applications, will be successful.
byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga bcu gsum pa ste/ sbyin sreg gi cho ga rab 'byam rdzogs so// //
This concludes the detailed thirteenth chapter in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
'khor los sgyur ba'i ras ris kyi cho ga'i dkyil 'khor sgrub pa'i thabs
Chapter 14

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs te/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal khyod kyi gsang ba'i rig pa yod de/ sngags thams cad kyi sgrub pa po'i thabs/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis yang dag par rjes su gnang ba/ chos kyi mdzod las byung ba/ chos kyi sprin gyi rjes su zhugs pa/ nam mkha'i ngo bo nyid 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags thams cad kyi mnga' bdag shin tu gtso bor gyur pa/ gzhon nu ji ltar de bzhin gshegs pa ni sems can thams cad kyi mchog tu brjod de/ shin tu gtso bor gyur cing dam pa yin la/ lha dang mi rnams kyi skyes bu khyu mchog sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das yin no/ / gzhon nu de bzhin du rig pa'i rgyal po 'di ni sngags thams cad kyi mchog tu bstan cing shin tu gtso bo yin te/ de bzhin gshegs pa gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das brjod du med pa dag gis sngon gsungs so/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen tog gi snying po mchog tu gsang ba kun nas bkra shis par 'dod pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis yang dag par bstod pa rab tu bsngags pa sems can thams cad yang dag par dbugs 'byin pa sdig pa thams cad rab tu 'jig par byed pa 'dod pa thams cad sbyin par byed pa re ba yongs su rdzogs par byed pa de yang gang zhe na/

Then Lord Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “There is, O Mañjuśrī, a secret vidyā mantra of yours that accomplishes all mantras. It was granted by the tathāgatas, arose from the treasury of their teachings, belongs to the ‘Cloud of Dharma,’ and is of the essence of the sky. This vidyā is the supreme lord of all mundane and supramundane mantras, just like the divine youth is the lord of all beings. This lord is described as a tathāgata, the supreme and the most excellent. Just as Lord Buddha, O divine youth, is the most eminent person among gods and men, so he‍—this supreme vidyārāja‍—is among all the mantras. He has been formerly taught by the blessed buddhas who are equal in number to the grains of sand in the river Gaṅgā and whose merits are ineffable. He has been regarded by them as the supremely secret heart mantra of the tathāgata Ratnaketu, auspicious in every respect. He is praised and extolled by all the buddhas, is the relief of all beings, and is the destroyer of every evil. He grants every wish and fulfills every hope. So what is this mantra?”[1017]

bar 'dir bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas smin mtshams kyi mdzod spu nas sangs rgyas thams cad yang dag par bskul ba zhes bya ba'i 'od zer phyung bar gyur to/ / gang 'di phyogs bcu steng 'og thams cad dang ldan pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing snang bas khyab par mdzad de/ sems can thams cad kyi yid tshim par mdzad nas slar log ste/ bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i dbu'i gtsug tor du nub par gyur to/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi gtsug tor nas kun nas 'bar ba'i 'od dang ldan pa'i lus can blta bar mi nus pa/ sems can thams cad kyis mi thub pa 'od chen pos yang dag par 'phags pa 'od kyi dkyil 'khor gyis lus brgyan pa rnam pa sna tshogs kyi gzugs dang ldan pa/ 'khor los sgyur ba chen po'i gzugs can rig pa'i rgyal po yi ge gcig pa zhes bya ba byung bar gyur to/ /

While he spoke, a ray of light called arouser of all the buddhas emerged from the tuft of hair between the eyebrows of the blessed Śākyamuni. It illuminated all the buddhafields in the ten directions, above, below, and everywhere, delighting the minds of all beings. It then disappeared into Blessed Śākyamuni’s uṣṇīṣa. Subsequently, there emerged from the same uṣṇīṣa the lord of vidyās named One Syllable, as a form ablaze all around with the light that all ordinary beings find impossible to look at, or to lay hold of. Out of this great effulgence emerged his body, consisting of a halo of light, displaying multiple aspects and the great form of a cakravartin.

byung nas nam mkha'i dkyil thams cad snang bar byas te/ rig pa'i rgyal po thams cad kyis yongs su bskor ba rig pa du ma bye ba khri phrag brgya stong 'byin par byed pa/ yi ge gcig pa'i sgra 'don cing 'od zer chen po 'bar ba rab tu 'byin pa steng gi phyogs nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la mngon du blta ba dang thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang gi 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po yang snang bar byas nas bar snang la gnas par gyur to/ /

Having emerged, he illuminated the entire sky. He had a retinue of all the vidyā kings and was attended on and worshiped by many hundreds of thousands of millions of vidyās. He was praised by all the supramundane cakravartins and vidyārājas, eulogized by all the mantras,[1018] and cherished by all the buddhas and the bodhisattva great beings who had attained the tenth level of realization. Together they filled the entire canopy of the sky. His body was adorned with celestial gems and bedecked with great jewels and gems, beautiful in appearance, supremely radiant, emanating hundreds of thousands of millions of magical creations in various forms,[1019] pronouncing the one-syllable word of his mantra, and radiating a great mass of light. He positioned himself in midair above Lord Śākyamuni, facing and looking upon the entire realm of the Pure Abode and illuminating the circle of the great assembly.

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas yi ge gcig pa rig pa'i 'khor los sgyur ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi snying po de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen tog ces bya ba'i snying po mchog tu rab tu gsang ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad las bcom ldan 'das rin chen tog gis yang dag par thob pa/ sA la'i dbang po'i rgyal po dang 'od dpag med dang bsnyen par dka' ba dang spyan bzang dang tog bzang dang me tog dbang po dang gnyid mthar phyin dang 'jig rten thub pa dang / gser thub la sogs pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa de dag gis gsungs shing rjes su yi rang ba dang 'das pa'i yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas thams cad kyis kyang gsungs shing rjes su yi rang ba de yang gang zhe na/ tad+ya thA/ oM b+h+ru~M/

Lord Śākyamuni then pronounced the One Syllable, this vidyā cakravartin, the heart essence of all the tathāgatas, the supreme secret heart essence of the tathāgata called Ratnaketu; the One Syllable that is taught and cherished by all the tathāgatas intimately connected with Lord Ratnaketu[1020]‍—Śālendrarāja, Amitābha, Duḥprasaha, Sunetra, Suketu, Puṣpendra, and the sage Supināntaloka‍—and also by the [three] tathāgatas starting with Kanaka; the One Syllable that is taught and celebrated by all the perfectly awakened ones who have gone beyond. What is this One Syllable? It is bhrūṁ.[1021]

'jam dpal 'di ni snying po dam pa de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi mchog sngags thams cad kyi rig pa'i 'khor los sgyur ba yi ge gcig pa zhes bya ba dag byed chen po 'di yang dag par bsgrubs na sngags thams cad 'grub par 'gyur te/ gzhon nu gang yang khyod kyi cho ga'i rgyal po'i mchog la sngags thams cad dang rjes su mthun pa/ mchog tu gsang ba'i mchog yang dag par rjes su gnang ba las kyi sgrib pa thams cad yang dag par sbyong bar byed pa/ dang po re zhig sgrub pa pos nges par 'bum phrag gsum bzlas brjod bya'o/ / de nas las rnams sngags dang bcas pa 'dir gzhon nu khyod kyi cho ga'i rgyal po la 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags dang rgyud rnams bsgrub par bya'o/ / 'dis bsrung ba byas na 'byung po thams cad kyis tshugs par mi 'gyur ro/ / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i bgegs thams cad kyis zil gyis non par mi 'gyur ro/ /

“This, Mañjuśrī, is the supreme essence of all the tathāgatas.[1022] This is the great means of purification, One Syllable by name, the vidyādhara-cakravartin. When used along with him, all mantras will be successful.[1023] He is, O divine youth, recommended as the secret, supreme mantra that accords with all the mantras in your excellent king of manuals. He is the purifier of obscurations in all rites. A practitioner must first utter this mantra three hundred thousand times, and then, O divine youth, the rites for all the mantras and all the worldly and transcendent mantra methods in your king of manuals will be accomplished.[1024] When protected by One Syllable, one becomes invulnerable to attacks by any being. One will also not succumb to any obstacles, whether mundane or supramundane.”

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas de gsungs ma thag tu stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams 'di thams cad rnam pa drug tu g.yos par gyur te/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad du yang snang bas khyab cing sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das thams cad kyang 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor der 'dus par gyur te/ gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang du 'khod par gyur to/ / sa bcu thob pa'i byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub las phyir mi ldog pa dang nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang rdzu 'phrul chen po dang ldan pa'i sems can thams cad dang rig pa'i rgyal po rnams 'od zer gyis yang dag par bskul nas lhags par gyur to/ / 'jig rten gyi khams mtha' yas mu med pa dag na rnam par gnas pa'i sems can mang po dbang du gyur to/ / dmyal ba dang dud 'gro dang yi dgas kyi ngan 'gro la gnas pa rnams 'od zer chen po'i snang bas reg cing snang bar byas pas sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba'i rgyun la gnas pa yid shin tu bde bas tshim zhing skyo ba med par gyur te/ nges par theg pa gsum la gnas par gyur to/ /

As soon as the One Syllable was pronounced by Lord Śākyamuni, all the world spheres of the great trichiliocosm shook in six different ways. All the buddhafields became filled with light and all the blessed buddhas dwelling there joined the circle of the great assembly gathered in the realm of the Pure Abode. So, too, all the bodhisattvas on the tenth level of realization who were irreversibly established in perfect awakening, all the śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas, all the beings possessed of great powers, roused by the light from One Syllable, the vidyārāja, arrived enthralled[1025] in the assembly. And other beings living in infinite worldly realms who followed the painful destinies of hell, the hungry ghosts, and animals, were touched by the radiance of the great light. When thus illuminated, those who were acutely suffering, immersed in their painful experience, became cheered in their minds. They entered definitively into the three vehicles.
de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor de la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/
Then Lord Śākyamuni looked again at this great circle of the assembly and said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth:

'jam dpal nyon cig rig pa'i rgyal po 'di rdzu 'phrul che ba dpa' bo gcig pu las thams cad byed pa/ rig pa thams cad kyi rgyal po 'khor los sgyur ba/ sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par mdzad pa cho ga zhib mo thams cad yongs su rgyas pa/ khyod kyi sngags dang rgyud dang / cho ga rab 'byam la yang dag par zhugs pa/ sngags thams cad sgrub par byed pa/ thun mong du gyur pa/ grags pa che ba dang / spro ba che ba dang / sems can sgrub pa po'i khyad par gyi thabs dang shes rab la mkhas pa byang chub kyi lam thams cad yongs su sbyong bar byed pa/ mya ngan las 'das pa la rab tu 'jug par byed pa/ bdud zil gyis gnon par byed pa/ byang chub kyi snying po la gnas par byed pa/ dge ba'i tshogs yang dag par 'byung bar byed pa'o/ /

“Listen, Mañjuśrī, as I tell about this vidyārāja! He possesses great magical power. As a maṇḍala deity, he is depicted without a retinue. He is suitable for all types of activity. He is the supreme monarch of all vidyās and fulfills the hopes of all beings. For all the profusion of rites,[1026] he is present in the large body of rites of the mantra system associated with you. He accomplishes all mantras and is universally applicable. He is renowned as a great lord who is very energetic and is particularly skilled in the method and wisdom that benefit beings who practice. He clears up the entire path to awakening and establishes beings in nirvāṇa. He causes one to ascend to the seat of awakening,[1027] and he [facilitates] the accumulation of virtue.

'di nyid mdor bsdu na/ cho ga zhib mo rgyas pa ras ris kyi cho ga'i dkyil 'khor sgrub pa'i thabs/ sngon gyi sngags kyi spyad pa rjes su spyod pa/ gang la rab tu gnas na sems can gyi rig pa'i rgyal po 'khor los sgyur ba chen po sgrub par 'gyur te/ rmad du byung ba chen po sngags thams cad kyi dbang phyug dam pa/ 'od byed pa/ thams cad kyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ rnam par 'dren pa/ 'gro ba thams cad la phan par byed pa/ sangs rgyas bzhin du mngon sum du nye bar bzhugs pa rang byung du gyur pa mchog dang bar ma dang tha ma'i las thams cad byed pa

“It is his extensive ritual that I will now briefly teach, including the procedure of making his painting and his maṇḍala and how it is the means of accomplishment, and also how to practice the previously mentioned mantra conduct, established in which sentient beings will succeed in the practice of this great cakravartin, the marvelous vidyārāja, the supreme lord of all mantras, the illuminator, the fulfiller of all wishes, the guide, the benefactor of the whole world, who, like the Buddha, appears directly, is self-arisen, and may be employed in all activities‍—the highest, the medium, and the minor.

shin tu bde ba dam pa shis pa dang zhi bar byed pa sdig pa thams cad rab tu 'jig par byed pa'o/ / lha rnams kyi yang lha nyid de/ / thub pa rnams kyi thub pa mchog / sangs rgyas nyi ma'i gnyen gyur pa/ / dag pa 'jig rten rnam par grags/ / chos kun rang gi ngo bo mkhyen/ / yang dag mthar gyur rnyog pa med/ / de yi cho ga mchog bshad bya/ / 'byor pa 'dod pas mnyan par gyis/ / re zhig dang por ras bzang po/ / skyon rnams dang ni ma 'dres pa/ / sar pa phra ba'i khyad par ldan/ / kha tshar dang bcas nyid la bri/ / chur ni khru do'i tshad yin la/ / zheng du khru gang tshad du bya/ / de 'dra'i bzang po kho na la/ / dri med blta na sdug pa dang / / bcos bu dkar po de bzhin du/ / phra dang legs bkrus ras bal spangs/ /

“He is blissful, auspicious, Tranquil, and destroys all evil.[1028] He is the god of the gods And the most eminent among sages. “He is a buddha, a sun, and a kinsman,[1029] Completely pure and renowned in the world. He knows the nature of all dharmas,[1030] Belongs to the peak of existence, and is not sullied. “I will now teach his best ritual, So please listen, if you desire prosperity. To start, one should prepare a high-quality canvas, Free of hair or any adhering dirt, “New, especially white, and with a fringe. On it, one should paint as described below. The canvas should be two cubits in height And one cubit across. “It should be as described‍—bright, Spotless, pleasant in appearance, Of pure white color,[1031] Well washed, and free of rough patches.[1032]

phyag dar dri ma med pa yi/ / du gu la yi ras nyid la/ / rgyu ni shing kun nyid dang ni/ / dag la rgyud ni rnam spangs pa/ / chu ngan las ni bkrus min dang / / skye bos zhal mthong phul ba'ang min/ / ma bgos pa dang de bzhin du/ / gzhan yang cung zad dam pas bsngags/ /

“One can use a white and dust-free Cloth of dukūla bark, Flaxen cloth, or cloth of any bark, Pure and free of fibers. “It should not be produced by worms, Or received from people as a gift. Thus it should not be silken, But any other kind described as suitable.[1033]

de 'dra'i ras ni bzang po la/ / gzhal med khang ni bri bar bya/ / 'od kyi dkyil 'khor phreng ba can/ / ston pa'i gzugs ni yang dag bri/ / de bzhin gser gyi mdog can ni/ / 'od zer phreng ldan bri bar bya/ / gcig pu phug na bzhugs pa ni/ / ri bo la gnas grags pa che/ / dar la'i bla re bre ba ni/ / rin chen phreng ba 'phyang ba'o/ / steng du lha ni gnyi ga yang / / 'dzin pa dag ni yang dag bri/ / ri rnams kyi ni steng dag tu/ / rin chen phreng ba rab tu bya/ / bla re'i 'khor yug mu tig gi/ / dra ba dra phyed dag gis brgyan/ / ri rgyal steng du 'bad pa yis/ / 'di dag thams cad bri bar bya/ / ri bo dag gi rtsa ba yang / / rgya mtsho chen por nub par bya/ / ras ris mthar yang me tog ni/ / kun nas 'khor bar yang dag bri/ / nA ga ge sar pun nA ga / ba ku la dang zhu ti ka / sna ma'i me tog pri yang ku/ / de bzhin ku ra ba ka dang / / ut+pa la dang dri mchog dang / / de las gzhan yang pad+ma dkar/ / me tog rigs ni sna tshogs dang / / de bzhin gzhan yang drir ldan pa'i/ / me tog dag ni 'di dag nyid/ / gang yang rung ba rtag blangs nas/ /

“On such a superior cloth One should draw the palace. One should draw the likeness of the Teacher Garlanded by a circle of light. “He should be painted a golden color, Haloed by light, sage-like,[1034] Alone, sheltered inside a cave On a mountain, in all his splendor.[1035] “One should draw a silken canopy Strung with garlands of jewels. Behind it are two gods Who are supporting it. “Above the mountain One should draw a jewel garland And, around the canopy, Decorations made of strings of pearls. “Having carefully painted all this Above the king of mountains, At the foot of the mountain One should draw the waters of the great ocean. “Around the edges of the canvas, One should draw flowers, such as The blossoms of the ironwood tree, pannay tree, Bulletwood tree, juhi jasmine, “Royal jasmine, and beautyberry. Always include red amaranth, Fragrant blue lotuses, And, further, white lotuses. “One should draw these different varieties And other fragrant species of flowers. One should always draw Only flowers of the species as described.[1036]

ston pa la ni mchod don du/ / yid du 'ong ba'i mchod yon dbul/ / sngar bstan cho gas ras ris ni/ / mchog dang de bzhin gzhan dag kyang / / dog pa tha ga pa dag dang / / ri mo mkhan yang de bzhin 'dod/ / cho 'phrul gyi ni zla phyed kyi/ / nyi ma dge ba dag la ni/ / dus ni de ltar gyur pa la/ / bzlas pa nyid kyang bya ba yin/ / 'di la sems can thams cad kyis/ / sngar bstan bzhin du yang dag spyad/ / tshon gsal rnam pa sna tshogs kyis/ / ston pa'i gzugs ni bri bar bya/ / rnam pa du mar ldan pa yi/ / dong ka'i me tog mdog 'dra dang / / tsam pa ka yi mdog 'dra dang / / gser gyi mdog dang 'dra bar bri/ / de lta'i rnam pa ldan pa yi/ / rin chen rigs skyes thub pa bri/ / chags pa chen po rin chen tog / gtso bo thub mchog dam pa ni/ / chos rnams thams cad yongs thob pa'i/ / sangs rgyas dkon mchog de bri bya/ /

“One should make offerings pleasing to the Teacher In order to worship him.[1037] Following the previously described procedure In regard to the superior painting, or the others, “And having ensured that the skein, the weaver, And the painter are as desired, One should do the painting during the prātihāra fortnight, On an especially auspicious day. “When such a time has arrived One should do the prescribed mantra recitation. One should execute everything, in every detail,[1038] Just as previously explained. “One should paint the complete figure of the Teacher Using paints of bright and vivid colors. He should be fully endowed with his many aspects, Equal in splendor to the karnikara flower. “One should paint this sage, born into the Jewel family, In golden color, With the same hue as the champak flowers And possessing all the features as described. “He is the highly illustrious[1039] Ratnaketu, The most eminent and best of sages. One should paint this jewel among buddhas Who has control over all phenomena.

rin chen ri bor gnas pa dang / / rin chen phug gis nyer mdzes shing / / skyil krung gis ni bzhugs pa dang / / chos ni rjes su 'chad cing stsol/ / cung zad 'dzum zhing brtan pa dang / / thugs ni bsam gtan la dmigs dang / / phyi rol phug ni yang dag bri/ / 'og dang de bzhin 'khor yug tu'o/ / ras mtha'i zur du sgrub pa pos/ / pus mo'i lha nga yang dag btsugs/ / bdug spos lag na thogs bzhin du/ / lus ni cung zad 'dud pa dang / / bla gos gcig tu byas nas ni/ / cha byad ji lta bzhin du yang / / bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yas phyogs kyi/ / 'og gi rgya mtsho che steng du/ / sngags pas dge ba'i don gyi phyir/ / sdom brtson rtag tu bri bar bya/ / las kyi cho ga 'di dag ni/ / 'jig rten gyi sngags bstan pa yin/ / dkyil 'khor de yi lha dag kyang / / da ni rab tu brjod par bya/ /

“He sits on a jewel mountain, Adorned with jewel caves, In a cross-legged posture, Delivering a Dharma discourse. “With a gentle smile on his face, This hero’s mind is steeped in concentration. One should also paint whatever is On the outside of his cave, below, and around it. “In the corner at the end of the canvas one should paint The practitioner, kneeling down. In his extended hand he holds incense, And his body is slightly bent forward. “One should paint him as wearing an upper garment And other clothes just as in real life, Above the great ocean that is To the lower right of the Blessed One. “One should draw him‍—the practitioner of mantra who aspires for perfection‍— Wholly applying oneself to the task. This is the procedure of doing the painting, As has been taught by those venerated by the world; Now will be taught The maṇḍala of the deity.[1040]

de tshe sngags pas rig pa'i sngags/ / de tshe sngags ni rig pa des/ / sngags la rtag tu bsnyen byas dang / / bzlas pa phun sum tshogs mngon shes/ / 'jam dbyangs cho ga 'di la ni/ / de tshe sngags pa dbang bskur ba/ / dkyil 'khor rnam pa la mkhas shing / / rtag tu gtsang sbra byed pa dang / / sngags rnams kun la dbang bskur dang / / dkyil 'khor 'di la 'jigs pa med/ / rig pa'i sngags dang sngags bcas dang / / bdag nyid bsrung dang phan 'dod dang / / grogs kyang de bzhin bsrung shes dang / / yongs su legs brtags 'od chen ldan/ / slob dpon legs par yang dag rtsom/ / rtsom zhing sbyangs yon bsten pa dang / / shes rab che zhing legs 'jam dang / / dpal ldan snying rjer rtag tu ldan/ / grogs po dag ni thams cad kyang / / mtshan nyid de bzhin kun tu bstan/ / gcig gnyis gsum dang de bzhin du/ / gzhan yang de bzhin brgyad kyi bar/ / slob ma legs par sbyang bar bya/ / mang po dag ni spang bar bya/ /

“The mantra practitioner should really understand The mantra at the time of employing it And always use it to do the preliminary practice, Training thus for success in recitation.[1041] “For this reason he should be initiated into the mantra From this manual, so beautifully[1042] taught‍— The mantra that is associated with the maṇḍala conduct And always requires initiation.[1043] “He[1044] should have confidence in the maṇḍala, Be initiated into all its mantras, Always apply himself to the tantra, And be able to perform the rite of self-protection.[1045] “The master, possessed of great splendor, should also protect His assistants with demon-slaying [mantras] and examine them carefully.[1046] He should be well established as a spiritual master And keep his observances. “He should have profound insight, be always gentle, Noble, and compassionate, And look for the same characteristics In all his assistants. “One should accept as disciples those who are well qualified‍— One, two, or three, Or perhaps eight or more of them‍— But avoid [accepting too] many.

sngar bstan cho ga ji lta bar/ / dkyil 'khor 'di la'ang yang dag spyad/ / stobs bcu ldan pas dang por ni/ / dkyil 'khor gang dag rab bstan pa/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs las gzhan min dang / / rgyu gzhan dag gis bri mi bya/ / dkyil 'khor 'od chen ldan pa yi/ / tshad ni rab tu bstan par bya/ / khru bzhi'am khru ni gnyis pa dang / / de bzhin gzhan yang khru brgyad par/ / gtsang ba'i phyogs sam chu klung ngam/ / khyad par du ni ri bo'i rtser/ / tshon sna lnga yi phye ma dang / / sngar bstan pa yi las kyis so/ / gru bzhi sgo ni bzhi pa dang / / rta babs bzhi yis brgyan pa dang / / zur bzhi mnyam zhing bzang ba dang / / lha yi rnam pa 'dra ba'i mdog /

“One should always follow, for this maṇḍala, The procedure as previously explained. Those possessing the ten powers declared This to be the best of maṇḍalas. One should therefore draw no other maṇḍala, And follow no other rite but Mañjughoṣa’s.[1047] “I will now give the measurements Of this very magnificent maṇḍala. It should be four cubits, two cubits, Or perhaps eight, or more, in diameter. “One should draw it in a clean place, Especially a riverbank or a mountaintop. One should use powders of five colors And follow the previously taught procedure. “The maṇḍala should have four corners, four doors, And be adorned with four gateways. Its four sides should be of equal length, And its splendor should equal a divine enclosure.

tshon rtsi gsal ba sna tshogs dang / / mdzes pa'i kha dog legs mdzes dang / / dri zhim bzang dang gzugs bzang dang / / grogs bzang dag gis yang dag brtsam/ / thub pa'i brtul zhugs yang dag spyad/ / yan lag brgyad pa'i brtul zhugs bsten/ / nyon mongs med sems zas tshod rig / chos ldan rtag tu zlos pa byed/ / sdig med las dang yongs srung byed/ / de bzhin zhi dang rgyas pa shes/ / de nas dkyil 'khor dbus zhugs nas/ / bstan bcos las gsungs bzhin du bri/ /

“The paints should be of bright, vivid colors, Pure and beautiful, With a nice fragrance and other aspects. One should start painting it with the help of a companion, “While observing silence and one’s temporary vows, As well as the eight [precepts].[1048] One should be untroubled in mind, moderate in eating, And virtuous; continually recite the mantra; “And refrain from evil activities, Performing only those of pacifying and enriching. One should start in the center And draw the Teacher using paints.[1049]
rin chen lha tshogs kyis brgyan pa'i/ / ri mo dang por bri bar bya/ / der bzhugs gzi brjid chen po ni/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen tog /
“First, one should paint Tathāgata Ratnaketu, Complete with adornments of various jewels, Sitting inside a cave, And of great splendor.[1050]
skyil krung gis ni legs bzhugs pa/ / chos kyi 'khor lo rjes bskor ba'o/ / ras ris la ni ji lta bar/ / bstan bcos la sngags thams cad bri/ /
“He sits in a cross-legged posture And turns the wheel of Dharma. One should draw on the canvas Everything that is normally offered to the Teacher.[1051]

ri mo'i phreng ni gsum dag dang / / phyag rgyas rab tu brgyan pa dang / / gser mdog rim pas khor yug tu/ / yongs su bri bar bya ba yin/ / gsal dang yongs su rdzogs pa dang / / drang po de yi rnam pa'o/ / 'khor los sgyur ba'i bdag po che/ / de yi dbus su bya ba yin/ / nyi ma 'char ka 'dra ba dang / / gur gum rnam pa 'dra mdog can/ / 'khor lo chen po'i rjes 'brang ba/ / 'bad par gnas pas kun tu bri/ / rgyal po chen po mnyam 'dra ba/ / gzhal med khang bcas rgyan gyis brgyan/ / sems dpa' chen po'i cod pan can/ / rgyan rnams kun gyis rab tu brgyan/ / dar la mdzes pa'i smad g.yogs can/ / sna tshogs dar las stod g.yogs shing / / phreng ldan zhi ba'i kha dog 'od/ / gos dang phreng bas brgyan pa dang / / me tog phreng ba bak+ku la/ / lag pa g.yas pas snoms par byed/ / bzhin ni cung zad 'dzum pa'i lha/ / mthu chen 'od dang ldan pa'o/ /

“It should be adorned with mudrā symbols Arranged in three rows. One should paint all that is offered,[1052] Arranged in rows all around.[1053] “They should be densely packed together, Arranged in order without mixing them up.[1054] In their center should be painted The wheel-turning lord of great power. “He has the color of the rising sun And the radiant form of a divine youth.[1055] One should paint him with care As turning the great wheel. “He is in his form of a great king, Invested with a crown and other adornments, Wearing a diadem of a great being, And adorned with every ornament.[1056] “He wears a fine silken sash around his waist And brightly colored silk garments. He is garlanded and adorned With garlands and clothes with a gentle, soft glow. “He inhales the fragrance of a cluster of bulletwood blossoms, Which he holds in his right hand.[1057] He is a deity with a gentle smile on his face, Of great valor and power.

gzugs bzang gzugs ni mdzes pa dang / / byis pa rgan po rnam par spangs/ / lag pa g.yon na 'khor lo ste/ / 'bar ba'i 'od kyi phreng ba can/ / de ni yongs su bskor ba dang / / skyil krung phyed kyis gnas pa bri/ / gzugs bzang gzugs la bsten nas ni/ / lha yi gzugs 'dra bri bar bya/ / ri bo 'od chen ldan pa'i steng / / rin chen du ma'i steng du gnas/ / sngags rnams kun la che ba dang / / rtag tu mchog sbyin la 'jug byed/ / 'bar ba'i me dang 'dra ba dang / / 'od kyi dkyil 'khor gyis mdzes pa/ / rlung gis sbar ba'i me bzhin du/ / kun nas me ni 'bar ba'o/ / de bzhin sngags kyi sbyor ba yis/ / khyab bdag me yis 'bar bar byed/ / stobs chen de dang 'dra ba yi/ / sngags kun rab tu sgrub byed pa/ / gang gis bdag nyid chen po mthong / / sdig pa kun las yongs su grol/ / mtshams med lnga po byed pa dang / / tshul 'chal blo ni chung ba dang / / sdig pa kun la 'dzud byed pa/ / khyab bdag mthong ba tsam gyis grol/ / lha yi lha ni 'khor lo'i bdag / dkyil 'khor mthong ba tsam gyis ni/ / gzhan yang sdig tu yongs bstan pa/ / de yi mod la grol bar 'gyur/ /

“He is of beautiful physique, Neither too young nor too old. In his left hand he always holds a wheel Enveloped in a garland of light. “One should paint him sitting with one leg tucked in and the other extended, His arms close to his torso.[1058] He is radiant with a divine glow, Well formed and beautiful.[1059] “He sits on a heap of jewels, With his whole body emitting a great radiance.[1060] He grants boons, always becoming active In response to any propitious mantra. “Blazing like fire, He is adorned with a halo of light[1061] And surrounded by flames Fanned by the wind. “If they apply the mantra, People on the earth will blaze with light the same way.[1062] A Dharma follower who visualizes Such a great hero “Will cause all mantras to take effect And will be freed from all his faults, Even if he has committed the five acts of immediate retribution, Is undisciplined or indolent. “All such negativity will be appeased, And he will be liberated by seeing the Lord. Merely by seeing the maṇḍala Of the lord of deities, the wheel holder, Other known types of negativity Will depart too, at that very moment.

sngags pas rtag tu khyab bdag gi/ / de nas shar sgo yang dag sbyar/ / rta babs kun nas yongs bsgreng ste/ / ba dan dag gis nyer mdzes bya/ / mtha' dag gzugs ni mdzes pa yi/ / dkyil 'khor yongs su gsal byas nas/ / bshos dang bdug pa dri dang ni/ / rtag tu phreng ba bzang po yis/ / cho ga snga ma kho na ltar/ / de dag thams cad gus par bya/ / dbus kyi bum pa gang ba ni/ / 'khor lo can gyi mdun du dgod/ / de'i bum rnam par rgyal zhes bya/ / sngags shes pas ni de mi bteg / cho ga mthong ba'i las kyis ni/ / me thab snga ma bzhin du bya/ / sbyin sreg cho ga yang dag brtsam/ / cho ga sngags ni gzhan pas min/ / sbyin sreg kyang ni brgya rtsa brgyad/ / seng ldeng bud shing me la ni/ / pa la sha dang bil ba'i shing / / bil ba u dum arka dang / / 'bad pas las rnams kun la ni/ / a pa margas sbyin sreg bya/ / til la mar gyis btags pa 'am/ / zho la sbrang rtsis bsres pa yis/ /

“Next, one should purify the eastern door With the mantra of the Lord.[1063] The maṇḍala should be clearly visualized, Surrounded by gateways, Adorned with plantain trees,[1064] And thoroughly elegant in form. “One should offer bali, always including Incense, lamps,[1065] perfume, and beautiful garlands. One should do everything respectfully, Following the previously described procedure. “In front of the wheel-holding monarch, In the center, one should place a full jar. A mantra adept should not allow this jar, Which is called ‘victory,’ to be moved. “One should then dig the fire pit, Following the right procedure, And commence the homa rite, Employing none other than the mantra of the Lord. “One should offer into the fire of cutch tree sticks One thousand and eight oblations Consisting of sticks of the dhak, sandalwood, Bilva, cluster fig, or sandan tree. “One can likewise offer devil’s horsewhip[1066] In all types of activity, applying care. Alternatively, one can offer sesame seeds smeared with ghee And mixed with burnt gandha.[1067]

las rnams kun la sbyin sreg ni/ / stong rtsa brgyad ni rtag tu bya/ / dus gsum dus ni kun bstan pa/ / khrus dang gos ni brje ba dang / / dkar gsum rgyu skar bzang po ni/ / mkhas pa rnams kyis bstan pa yin/ / las rnams sngar ni bstan pa yi/ / bzlas dang sbyin sreg de bzhin gzhan/ / sngags dang yang dag ldan pas sam/ / 'khor los sgyur ba'i rigs kyis bya/ / las rnams dag ni kun la yang / / yi ge gcig pa'i sngags kyis bya/ /

“In all types of activity, One should always offer one thousand and eight oblations At the three junctions of the day as previously described. As taught by the sages,[1068] “One should bathe, put on clean clothes, Eat the three ‘white foods,’[1069] choose an auspicious nakṣatra, And perform the previously described rituals, Including recitation, homa, and others. “One should perform all of [the above] Employing One Syllable, who is like[1070] The [entire] family of Cakravartin employed as a mantra. One should employ him in all rites.[1071]

de ni mthu chen don ldan te/ / dpa' bo gcig pu rtag pa mchog / de la rtag tu zlos byed pa/ / sngags rnams kun gyi cho ga spyod/ / 'jig rten pa yi 'jig rten 'dod/ / cho ga thams cad 'grub par 'gyur/ / 'jig rten 'das pa'i brtson 'grus che/ / rig pa'i rgyal po dka' thub che/ / sngags kun 'grub par 'gyur ba ni/ / cho ga 'di las gzhan pas min/ / thub pa rnams kyis sngags gsungs dang / / de bzhin stobs bcu ldan sras dang / / 'jig rten skyong ba brgya byin sogs/ / khyab 'jug dbang ldan tshangs pa dang / / zla ba nyi ma de bzhin gzhan/ / gnod sbyin dbang po srin po dang / / lto 'phye che dang mi 'am ci/ / de bzhin sa steng drang srong mchog / nam mkha' lding dang rlung lha dang / / sems can ming ldan 'jig rten gzhan/ / gang gis bshad pa'i sngags rnams ni/ / 'dir yang 'grub par 'gyur ba yin/ / sngags rnams kun la 'gugs byed dang / / las rnams kun la ston byed dang / / 'byung po kun gyi sngags rgyud ni/ / rgyas dang bcas pa dbang du byed/ /

yi ge gcig pa'i sngags 'di ni/ / sngags pa kun gyi rab byed pa/ / bzlas pa tsam gyis don ldan te/ / lha rnams kun ni 'gugs byed la/ / cho ga rnams ni dbang du byed/ / yi ge gcig chen bdag po yin/ / dam pa rnams kyis rab bsngags pa'i/ / rnam pa sna tshogs byed pa yin/ / 'jig rten 'jig rten 'das pa'i sngags/ / yang dag sbyar na sgrub par byed/ / ma lus mthong na mdzes pa yi/ / ras ris gsal ba byas nas ni/ / gtsang ba'i phyogs dang 'bab chu'i ngogs/ / ri bo'i rtser yang gzhag par bya/ / snga ma'i las kyi sbyor ba yis/ / nub kyi phyogs su rtag tu bstan/ / cho ga mthong ba'i las kyis ni/ / sgrub pa po ni shar du blta/ / dUr ba'i khres la 'dug nas ni/ / 'du 'dzi med par bzlas pa bya/ / sgra ni drag min ngal bas min/ / gzhan la ngan sems med gyur na/ / sangs rgyas ma lus kun gyi yang / / 'di la myur du 'grub pa yin/ /

“This mantra, One Syllable, makes the rites Of all mantra reciters bear fruit. By merely reciting it, One can attract all deities. “He, the great lord One Syllable, Is the master of all rites. He produces various wonderful results That are praised by the good. “If employed correctly, he will accomplish Both mundane and transcendent mantras.[1078] Having completed the painting, Entirely pleasant to look at, “One should place it in a clean location, On a riverbank or the top of a mountain. One should always do this facing west, Following the previously described method. “The practitioner should then turn eastward and, Following the correct procedure, Sit of a bundle of darbha grass And recite the mantra in an orderly way‍— “Not too loud and not too low, Wholly focusing on bodhicitta. If one does not hate any being, One will attain accomplishment swiftly, in this life.[1079]

rtag tu 'jig rten byams sems dang / / sdug bsngal can la snying brtser ldan/ / mgon med sems ni dman pa dang / / phongs pas nyam thag stobs chung dang / / mi bzad 'khor bar ltung ba la/ / snying rje'i sems ldan 'grub par 'gyur/ / 'bad pas ras ris mdun dag tu/ / mchod pa chen po rtag tu gzhag / dngos su 'byor dang yid kyis sprul/ / bzang po sems las byung ba dang / / rgyal dbang gzugs kyi ri mo ni/ / bsam pa'am yang na bya ba yin/ /

“One should always cultivate the mind of loving kindness Toward beings who are suffering and miserable; Who are without a protector, forlorn, Afflicted with pain, and weak; “And who are fallen into this terrible saṃsāra. One who thus feels compassion will be successful. One should always place, in front of the painting, Many offerings, with great care, “Including a visualized, celestial woman Emerging from one’s heart. One should either visualize or physically present these offerings To the completed painting of the victorious lord.[1080]

de nyid kyi ni cho ga yis/ / de nyid du ni me thab bya/ / me ni shin tu 'bar ba la/ / sgrub pas sreg blugs sbyin sreg bya/ / tsan+dan dkar dang ga pur dang / / gur gum gyis bsres mang po ni/ / brgya ni rtsa brgyad sreg blugs kyis/ / sngags rig me 'bar sbyin par bya/ / seng ldeng p+lag sha n+ya grod+ha/ / pa la sha ni gang yin pa/ / de dag las byung shing dag gis/ / me chen rtag tu sbar bar bya/ / shing de dag ni med gyur na/ / shing gzhan yongs su gzung bar bya/ / pi tsu mar da tsha dang skyur/ / po son cha las byung ba'i shing / / tsher ma can sogs spang bya ste/ / sdig pa'i las la rab tu bsgrags/ / yi ge gcig pa'i sngags nyid kyis/ / zhi dang rgyas pa byas gyur na/ / de ni myur bar 'grub par 'gyur/ / sdig pa'i las ni spyad mi bya/ /

“One should dig the fire pit at the same location, Following the procedure according to the nature of the rite. When the fire is fully ablaze, The practitioner should offer the oblations: “White sandalwood and camphor Should be offered in combination with saffron. A mantra adept should offer Into the burning fire one hundred and eight oblations. “One should always use the wood of The cutch, waved-leaf fig, banyan, or dhak tree. One should energetically light the fire Using sticks from any of the trees just mentioned. “If sticks from these trees are unavailable, One should procure other sticks, Perhaps from a neem or a mango tree, Or a thorn-apple bush. “The ones to be avoided, known to be used in evil rites, Are sticks from any plant that has thorns. Employing the One Syllable, One should perform the rites of pacifying and enriching; Accomplishment will come swiftly. Evil rites should not be performed.

sngags mchog kun kyang 'di la ni/ / las rnams cho ga rgya chen kun/ / rnam rtog med pas rab sbyar na/ / rtag tu 'grub par 'gyur ba yin/ / de tshe sngags ni 'grub 'gyur zhing / / mchog sbyin nyid du 'ang 'gyur ba yin/ / yam shing p+lag sha u dum bar/ / yang na p+lag sha n+ya grod+ha/ / mar gyis btags dang sbrang rtsir ldan/ / zho dang ldan pas mnyam bzhag nas/ / sa steng rgyal thabs 'dod pa yi/ / sngags pas dus kun sbyin sreg bya/ / lha yi rgyal po 'dod pas ni/ / gur gum tsan+dan sbyin sreg bya/ / rig pa 'dzin pa'i lha dag gi/ / bdag po nyid ni 'dod gyur na/ / pad+ma'i sbyin sreg 'bum phrag ni/ / sum cu rtsa drug ge sar bcas/ / sbyin sreg mthar ni mchod yon yang / / bstan bcos las byung bzhin du dbul/ / rgyal bas bsngags pa'i ras ris mchog / der ni kun nas yongs su 'bar/ /

“These extensive ritual instructions That include all the mantras and the rites Will always lead to accomplishment If applied without concepts. The mantra deities will then be summoned[1081] And the boons will be granted. “The mantra practitioner who desires a kingdom on the earth Should offer into the fire, in a complete homa rite, The sticks of the waved-leaf fig, cluster fig, Dhak, or banyan tree, “Smeared with ghee and curds, With the addition of honey. If he desires the queen along with the kingdom,[1082] He should offer saffron and sandalwood. “If he desires lordship Over vidyādhara gods, He should offer 3,600,000 lotus flowers With attached filaments. “At the end of the homa, One should give a welcome offering to the Teacher.[1083] A supreme painting will, at this moment, emit light, Being, [in this way], marked by the victorious ones.[1084]

de la reg pa tsam gyis ni/ / tshangs pa'i 'jig rten dag dang ni/ / 'og min gyi ni bar dag gnas/ / yang na sa 'og rim par 'gro/ / bar skabs 'dir ni grub rnams kyi/ / der ni rgyal por rtag tu 'gyur/ / stobs chen brtan zhing pha rol gnon/ / 'byung po rnams ni 'byer bar byed/ / rtag tu rig 'dzin rgyal por 'gyur/ / las rnams yongs su sbyong bar byed/ / de ni yun ring 'tsho 'gyur te/ / bskal pa tsam du 'ang gnas pa yin/ / gang tshe lus ni shi 'phos nas/ / nges par byang chub gzhol bar 'gyur/ / gzhan yang las ni 'di dag kyang / / mdo dang rgyas pa bstan par bya/ /

“Upon merely touching it, One will ascend to the realm of Brahmā, Or as far as the realm of the Akaniṣṭha gods, Or perhaps all the subterranean paradises. “When obtaining any of these accomplishments, One will certainly become a king [in the respective realm]. Firm in one’s vows and valorous,[1085] One will make the spirits flee. “In due order, one can always become, Upon completing the rite, the king of vidyādharas. Furthermore, one can live a long time, Equal to an eon, “And when one dies, after all this time, One will certainly progress toward awakening. There is also another rite, Whose details, in a condensed form, are as follows.

pad+ma dkar po yongs blangs nas/ / tsan+dan dkar dang ldan pa yi/ / sbyin sreg 'bum phrag brgya byas na/ / des ni rin chen tog mthong 'gyur/ / rgyal ba dam pa de mthong na/ / de tshe mngon shes lnga thob 'gyur/ / bskal pa chen por ring 'tsho zhing / / sangs rgyas rjes su 'gro bar 'gyur/ / mtha' yas phyogs na bzhugs pa yi/ / sangs rgyas de nas mthong bar 'gyur/ / de dag la ni rtag mchod cing / / de dag nyid dang lhan cig gnas/ / rin chen ldan zhes 'jig rten khams/ / gcig na bcom ldan de bzhugs pa/ / thub gtso mchog ni dam pa ste/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen tog /

“One should procure white lotus flowers And combine them with white sandalwood. If one offers them in ten million oblations, One will be able to see Ratnaketu. “Upon seeing this supreme victor, One will obtain the five superknowledges. One will live for a long, great eon, And will be a follower of the Buddha. “One will be able to see infinite buddhas, Located throughout the quarters of the universe. One should always worship them, And will dwell together with them. “The realm called Ratnāvatī Is the one where the Blessed One lives, The supreme and most excellent sage, The most eminent tathāgata Ratnaketu.

de la de ni rtag gnas te/ / sngags kyis dag par the tshom med/ / gzhan yang las ni 'dod pa dag / gang zag mchog gis gsungs pa ni/ / nA ga ge sar ga pur dang / / tsan+dan gur gum cha mnyam pa/ / sngags pas de tshe gcig byas nas/ / sbyin sreg 'bum phrag bdun cu brgyad/ / de tshe lha ni sbyin sreg mthar/ / 'khor lo can de 'dir byon nas/ / rtag tu dgyes nas mchog stsol te/ / sgrub byed spyi bor byug par mdzad/ / de tshe reg pa tsam gyis ni/ / sngags pas bdun bdag por 'gyur/ / rgyal sras thugs las skyes pa yi/ / byang chub sems dpar de brjod do/ / nges pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yang / / de ni lung bstan 'gyur ba yin/ / de nas brtsams nas cung zad gang / / shes dang shes bya rgyal ba'i sras/ /

“One will always dwell there, Purified by the mantra; there is no doubt. The following is another cherished rite, Which has been taught by the most eminent of men. “A mantra practitioner should blend together The blossoms of the ironwood tree, Camphor, sandalwood, and saffron. He should then offer them into the fire 7,800,000 times. “At the conclusion of the homa, The deity will arrive along with his retinue. Pleased, he will definitely grant a boon, Touching the practitioner on the head. “As soon as the practitioner has been touched, He will become the master of the seventh level of realization. He will be called ‘bodhisattva,’ A true son of the victorious ones. “Always dedicated to awakening, He will be prophesied to attain it, And from then on, he, the son of the victorious ones, Will know whatever is to be known.

shes 'gyur sngags rnams ma lus ni/ / rtogs pa'i bdag nyid cher rgyas yin/ / de la reg pa tsam gyis ni/ / mngon shes lnga ldan sngags rgyal 'gyur/ / rtag tu bdag dang gzhan bdag nyid/ / rnam pa sna tshogs byed par 'gyur/ / rnam pa kun mchog ldan pa yi/ / mchod pa'i las la rtag tu dga'/ / skad cig de nyid kho na la/ / byang chub las la brtson par 'gyur/ / de tshe skad cig tsam gyis ni/ / 'jig rten sangs rgyas zhing der 'gro/ / 'jig rten khams ni stong dag tu/ / thams cad du yang 'gro bar 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' ni/ / de tshe spyod bcas mthong bar 'gyur/ /

“He will know all the mantras, And will happily follow his exalted destiny.[1086] By merely seeing Ratnaketu[1087] He will obtain the five superknowledges and become the king of mantras. “He will always be able to assume different forms And different identities at any time.[1088] He will always delight in the act of worshiping Those who are endowed with all the best attributes. “In an instant, he will become eager Only to perform activities of awakening. He will be able to visit, instantaneously, Different worlds and buddhafields. “He will roam everywhere In thousands of world spheres And be able to see the good deeds Of the buddhas and bodhisattvas.
