mi ni sdug bsngal skye 'gyur te/ / nad kyi gzhi ni skye bar 'gyur/ / mdze can nad ni mang ba dang / / long ba 'theng bo shu bar bcas/ / za ma ma ning mo sham dang / / bud med mtshan ni ngan pa dang / / skyes pa bud med de bzhin gzhan/ / gza' ni ngan pa mthong ba yin/ / de ltar skyes gyur skyes pa dang / / 'jig rten mang po skye ba yin/ /

Such people are born into suffering‍— Their lineament being affliction. They suffer from leprosy and many diseases, Such as blindness, lameness, and boils. “They are hermaphrodites, neuter, and childless, Unlucky with and repugnant to women.[1244] In this way, men, women, and others Attest to the inauspiciousness of the planets. “They are born in many worlds, having experiences According to their astrological births.[1245]

dkar dang ser ba'i gza' mchog ni/ / de dag las skyes dge ba yin/ / mdog ni dkar dang ser ba dag / rgyal bas rab tu bsngags par gsungs/ / gza' ni gtso bo bzhir bshad pa/ / pa sangs zla ba bla ma lhag / zlos pa las rnams kun la ni/ / de dag mthong na 'grub pa'i don/ / sems can byis pa rnams la yang / / rtag tu de dag skye ba bzang / / lo ni kun la 'dod pa'ang zhes/ / 'jig rten mchog gis gsungs pa yin/ / skad cig tsam la 'ang de bzhin du/ / mig 'byed mi 'dzum se gol gtogs/ / 'di ni mdor bsdus skye ba zhes/ / 'jig rten mchog gis gsungs pa yin/ / 'di tsam gyi ni tshad dag tu/ / gza' kun 'jig rten dgongs pa yin/ / de dag de bzhin rtag tu 'char/ / 'di dag dus kyi de nyid yin/ / 'di dag dge dang sdig pa'i gza'/ / 'khor lo bzhin du rtag tu 'khor/ / 'jig rten dge dang mi dge byed/ / de nyid 'jig rten gnas pa yin/ /

The planets that are ‘white’ and ‘yellow’ are the best; Being born under them is the source of happiness. “As for the colors, the white and the yellow Have been described by the victorious ones as the best. Seeing the four main planets‍— Venus, the moon, Jupiter, and Mercury‍— “Will ensure success For the reciter in all [ritual] activities. As for the simple folks, Their births will always be fortunate. “Every desired good fortune,[1246] As explained by the most eminent of men, Will be instantly obtained, Within the twinkling of an eye or a finger snap. “Their birth-assigned position has been described in brief By the most eminent of men. Its limitations and standards are determined By the planets who oversee the world. “These planets rise regularly At their usual time, as is their nature. Auspicious or inauspicious, they always Course in their orbits. “Beings perform evil and virtue, And thus inhabit their specific realms.[1247]

des na de dag gang cung zad/ / sdig pa'i blo yang skye bar 'gyur/ / sems can dge dang mi dge'i 'bras/ / mang po yang ni skye bar 'gyur/ / gza' rnams las la spyod pa zhes/ / des na 'di ni mthong zhes gsungs/ /

They may inhabit the gods’ realms,[1248] “But somehow, to some degree, They will develop evil intents. Wholesome and unwholesome results Will thus arise for them again and again. “It is said that, according to their aspects, The planets incite karma and cause it be experienced.[1249]

myur ldan myur bcas 'od 'gyur zhing / / myur bar 'ong bas myur ldan yin/ / mig gis mthong dang ma mthong ba'i/ / se gol gtogs pa'i myur 'gros yin/ / 'di tsam gyi ni tshad dag tu/ / blo mchog rnams kyis bstan pa yin/ / de nas gzhan yang rab bshad pa/ / nges par zlos pas rtag tu bya/ / yud tsam dag ni bcu gnyis dang / / dus dang dus min 'gro ba'i rgyu/ / grub pa'i rgyu 'am ma yin pa/ / 'gro ba min pa'ang bshad par bya/ /

Swiftly, swiftly they catch up with beings; Swiftly, swiftly they approach. “Visible or not, their speedy approach happens instantaneously, In the twinkling of an eye or a finger snap‍— That is the exact amount of time Described by those of superior intellect.[1250] “Next I will explain What the birth horoscope always entails‍— The twelve moments [favorable for undertaking an activity] And the appropriate and inappropriate time in relation to causes. I will also explain who is not a suitable vessel, Or does not possess the causes for accomplishment.[1251]

'jig rten la nye bzang ba dang / / char dang char min yang dang yang / / yul 'khor 'jig dang mu ge dang / / lo legs nyi ma gsal mthong dge/ / dus dang de bzhin dbang po'i gzhu/ / skye bo rnams la rtag zhi byed/ / mjug rings sa 'gul gnam grum dang / / skar mda' dang ni lho 'ur dang / / rgyu skar gza' dang skar rnams kyi/ / spyod pa dge dang mi dge ba/ / 'byung po rnams kyi spyod pa ni/ / dge dang mi dge'i spyod pa yin/ / sha za dang ni ma mo dang / / drag po ma rungs nyer 'joms byed/ / sha za rnams kyi spyod pa ni/ / de bzhin ma rungs sems can brjod/ /

“Favorable omens, in turns, appear And do not appear to people. Kingdoms collapse, there are famines, Or there are bountiful harvests,[1252] and kings enjoy prosperity.[1253] “A person destined to die, whether a timely or untimely death, Should always act benevolently.[1254] When there are comets, earthquakes, and hurricanes, When meteors streak and smoke is present, “The behavior of constellations, days of the week, and stars, Which is either virtuous or nonvirtuous, Influences the conduct of every being, Which oscillates between good or bad. “I will now describe the behavior‍— Of the kravyādas and the mātṛs, Those fierce murderers of living beings‍— And other evil beings who feed on flesh.[1255]

gang du lha la rab dad dang / / rin chen chos dang blo mchog dang / / dge ba'i las dang rtag tu ldan/ / byams sems brtse bar ldan pa dang / / legs par spyod pa'i don ldan blo/ / gzhan gyi sdug bsngal dag la sems/ / sngags dang rig pa rnams kyis drangs/ / sman gyi don du kha zas spyod/ / gang du mtshan nyid la brten pas/ / spyod pa rgya cher bstan pa yin/ / gzhan gyi lus la gnas nas ni/ / mi lus brten nas gnas pa yin/ /

“Those with sincere faith in the deity, Rich in Dharma and of superior intellect, Who are always engaged in wholesome activities And cultivate thoughts of loving kindness and compassion, “Who use their intellects for the sake of noble endeavors And dedicate themselves to fulfilling the needs of others,[1256] Can summon the mātṛs by uttering the mantra[1257] In order to nourish them with food. “I will describe in detail the manner In which they take possession Of the bodies of others, And how they remain in the bodies of humans.[1258]

lha ni mchod pa zhes bshad de/ / lha min nga rgyal can gyi rgyus/ / gnas der gnas pa'ang rnam pa gnyis/ / rim bzhin lha dang lha ma yin/ / de yang der ni rnam gnyis te/ / drag pa dang ni thun mong yin/ / de yang der ni rnam gnyis 'gro/ / dge dang mi dge 'gro ba lnga/ /

“The gods are said to be rooted in merit, And the asuras in pride. They thus abide in these two ways, Known as gods and asuras,[1259] along with their retinues.[1260] “The latter are further subdivided Into two, the cruel and the ordinary. The last are also subdivided into two groups, The virtuous and the nonvirtuous, [liable to follow] the five destinies.[1261]

der gnas rnam gsum 'gro ba ste/ / nyi shu sum cu grangs med pa'o/ / lha dbang dang ni 'og min par/ / go rims ji bzhin sa med pa'o/ / 'jig rten khams ni mtha' med pa/ / dge dang mi dge 'jig rten yin/ / 'khor spyod sems can ji snyed dang / / 'phags pa nyan thos ji snyed dang / / sangs rgyas rang sangs rgyas rnams dang / / de yi thugs las skyes sras dang / / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' che/ / sa bcu la ni rab gnas dang / / rtag tu sems can thams cad kyi/ / sems can skye gnas yang dag brten/ / byis pa'i skye bo thams cad kyi/ / 'gro ba'i skye gnas rten pa dang / / rtag tu 'phags rnams thams cad kyi/ / mtshan nyid dang ni spyod pa dang / / tshig dang brda dang de nyid kyang / / rgya cher rab tu bshad par bya/ /

“The gods there are of three kinds‍— ‘Twenty,’ ‘thirty,’ and ‘infinite’‍— The sovereign gods up to the realm of Akaniṣṭha, The Yāma gods, and the innumerable earth guardians.[1262] “The worlds are infinite‍— Both virtuous and nonvirtuous. Therein dwell saṃsāric beings And also the noble śrāvakas, “The buddhas, the pratyekabuddhas, And their dear offspring‍— The bodhisattva great beings‍— Established on the ten levels. “Thus all beings always take Their respective types of birth. All the immature beings Follow the birth of the destinies. All the noble buddhas, on the other hand, Are liberated from the ocean of saṃsāra.[1263] “They all necessarily have their characteristics, Always follow their respective modes of conduct, Speak their own languages, and possess latent natures. I will explain this in detail.

sngags dang rgyud ni rig bcas pas/ / 'byung po kun ni dgug par bya/ / dbab dang dgug pa'i sngags shes pas/ / gzhan gyi lus la yang dag brten/ / dge dang mi dge'i las shes zhing / / bag yod rigs ni bzang ba dang / / mi blun spyod pa'i sems can dang / / tshar gcad rjes gzung spyod pa dang / / 'jig rten sa steng 'gugs byed pa/ / mi ni sngags zlos byed pa dag / de dag grub pa'i mtshan ma ni/ / de nyid thams cad bshad par bya/ / mi rnams kyi ni mdor bsdu na/ / de dag gi ni lus bzung nas/ / rtag tu shin tu chos don dang / / thar pa'i don du rnam par brtag / ma rungs rnams ni tshar gcad dang / / rnam dag rnams ni mchod pa ste/ / tshar gcad rjes gzung nyid la ni/ / sngags dang rgyud ni rab tu brtag / rlung dang bad kan mkhris can ni/ / rnam gsum dag la spyod pa'ang gsum/ / de dag zhi bar rab brtags la/ / rnam gsum nyid du rim par 'dod/ / mi rnams kyi ni gso ba la/ / sngags dang rgyud kyis rtag tu bya/ / 'byung ba chen por rnam brtags pa/ / 'byung dang 'byung min la sogs shes/ / 'byung ba min dang 'byung ba dang / / lhag par 'byung ba de la brjod/ / skye bo gang tshe lhag 'byung zin/ / de tshe bde ba med par 'gyur/ / 'byung dang 'byung min rnam pa ni/ / rnam pa gnyis su rab tu brtag / rtag tu sems can 'byung ba che/ / sems can ma yin rab tu brtag / mkhris pa bad kan de bzhin rlung / / gang gzhan rnam pa sna tshogs byas/ /

“All spirits can be summoned By those who correctly employ the mantra methods.[1264] One who knows the mantras for summoning and possession Can use them on beings who inhabit the bodies of others. “They can be summoned, in the human realm, By mantra reciters who can distinguish Between virtuous and nonvirtuous activities, Are not careless, keep reciting the mantra,[1265] Do not follow foolish conduct, And are equally tolerant of disfavor and kindness. “I will explain all the signs that indicate success According to their respective natures. In order to protect their human bodies That are always afflicted by suffering,[1266] “And for the sake of the infinite Dharma And their own liberation, it is always recommended[1267] That they ward off evil beings, And worship the pure ones. “A mantra method is thus prescribed For keeping the former in check or showing the latter favor. In this regard, the ritual procedure is threefold, Reflecting the three natures of either wind, phlegm, or bile. “To those afflicted, one should administer the rite of pacifying, Which is known to be threefold. In the case of humans, one should always Administer the remedy by means of the mantras. “A living being is a combination of the great elements, But is regarded as more than just these elements. When they are overcome by any of these elements, They are referred to as one who has an element in excess. “When a living being has any of the elements in excess, They will develop an illness. Elements, in regard to their type, Are divided into two types. “Thus, an element is always designated As either sattva or asattva.[1268] These elements are bile, phlegm, wind, And any other of the great variety of substances.[1269]

'byung ba chen po bzhi dang ni/ / lnga pa dag ni nam mkhar brjod/ / chu dang me dang ldan pa dang / / sa dang rlung du yang dag ldan/ / blo dang ldan pas rtag tu yang / / sems can min pa'i grangs su bstan/ / 'jig rten mchog gi bdag po dang / / 'od chen ldan pas gsungs pa yin/ / sems can ma yin grangs su bstan/ / sems can grangs 'gro mi ma yin/ / blo mchog smra ba dam pa yis/ / mi rnams sems can nyid du gsungs/ / mi ma yin dang mi dag kyang / / rtag tu sems can grangs nyid do/ / sems can rnams la dge don du/ / thams cad mkhyen pa'i gsung yang yin/ / 'das dang ma byon sangs rgyas dang / / de bzhin da ltar byung rnams kyis/ / dge ba'i las kyi las byung phyir/ / las 'di dag ni yongs su gsungs/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi gsung dag pa/ / las ni don med mi byed de/ / de yi rgyu mtshan rigs dang spyi/ / grub pa nyid du rab snang ste/ / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes dang / / bde zhing zhi la rtag tu gtsang / / mthar thug dag dang bdag med dang / / don dam thar pa 'dod pa ste/ / de nyid chos ni btsal bya'i phyir/ / rgyud 'di yongs su bshad pa yin/ / rgyud dang sngags dang sman bzang po/ / bka' ni yang dag gsungs pa yin/ /

“The great elements are four, Or five, if space is added. Water, which is paired with heat, And earth, which is paired with wind, “Have been declared by the wise ones As belonging to the category of asattva, And so did the most eminent lord of the world, The one of great splendor. “This best of speakers, the most intelligent one, Has said that asattva elements are associated with Nonhuman beings,[1270] And the sattva elements, with humans.[1271] “Whether a being is human or nonhuman, They are always called a sentient being. It is for the good of sentient beings That this omniscient teaching was delivered. “The past and future buddhas, And also those of the present time, Taught about activities That produce good and bad results. “The teaching of the buddhas states That activity always produces results. Being in the same category, the accomplishment Will therefore definitely manifest itself. “This accomplishment is said to be omniscient knowledge, Forbearance, tranquility, consistent purity, Certainty that phenomena are pure and devoid of self, The ultimate truth, and liberation. “This very path has been taught For sentient beings in this sūtra,[1272] Which contains the true medicine of the mantra‍— A complete teaching for this world.[1273]

byung dang 'byung 'gyur da ltar gyi/ / bstan bcos thams cad legs bsngags dang / / 'jig rten mchog dang chos bdag med/ / rtag tu zhi dang shis pa'i gnas/ / 'di ni thams cad mkhyen pa'i gsung / / de yi go 'phang mchog gnas pa/ / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes 'byung / / ma 'dres rab tu brtags pa yin/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi mthu dang ni/ / byang chub sems dpa' blo ldan dang / / sngags rnams kun gyi cho ga la/ / grub pa kun tu bstan pa yin/ / des na 'di nyid thub dbang gis/ / cho ga'i rgyal por gsungs pa yin/ / lus can rnams ni sngags tshul gyi/ / 'di nyid kyi ni lam gyis 'gro/ / zhi ba nad med phun sum tshogs/ / mya ngan 'das grong phyin par 'gyur/ / mya ngan med dang rdul med dang / / rtag tu byang chub gzhol zhing shis/ / gang 'di bstan pa dag la ni/ / sngags kun 'don par byed pa na/ / kun mkhyen shes dang shes bya yi/ / las kyi rgyud ni 'brel pa dang / / sngags zlos pa yi ched du ni/ / rgyud rnams mtha' dag sa steng gsungs/ / sngags rgyud ma lus don dag ni/ / byang chub rnam gsum gzhol ba ste/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi ye shes dag / cho ga 'dir ni rab tu bstan/ /

“Venerated in all the treatises Of the past, the present, and the future, This teaching concerns the absence of self in phenomena, Which is a state always tranquil and auspicious. “This teaching of the omniscient one Truly concerns his own highest state. It alone sets down the way For the arising of omniscient knowledge. “The power of all the buddhas And the bodhisattvas who are full of wisdom Manifests itself as an accomplishment In all activities that involve the mantras. It is in order to bring about this accomplishment That this king of manuals has been taught by the lord of sages. “Following this path meant for embodied beings, Which is the essence of mantra, One can attain the city of nirvāṇa, A tranquil place where there is no aging,[1274] No grief, and no pollution, which is a peaceful, Always auspicious state of awakening. “This instruction of all the buddhas, Intended for the mantra reciters, Has been taught for them on the earth As a complete system. “It establishes the karmic cause For the omniscient knowledge of things. The entire purpose of mantra Is directed toward the three aspects of awakening.[1275] “The entirety of the knowledge possessed by the buddhas Has been explained in this manual.

sems can rnams la'ang phan pa'i phyir/ / 'jig rten kun la rab tu bskor/ / gzhan la cho ga rab snang ba/ / cho ga'i rgyal po 'di la'ang yod/ / thub mchog thub pa'i sras dag gis/ / gzhan du cho ga gang bstan pa/ / sngags rnams thams cad 'di la yod/ / de na cho ga rgya chen yin/ / de nyid phyir na thub dbang gis/ / lus can kun la gsungs pa yin/ / gang du cho ga'i rgyal po 'dis/ / dbang 'gyur min dang bkug min pa/ / sa steng 'jig rten gsum 'di na/ / rig pa'i sngags rgyal de yod min/ /

It has been spread through all the worlds For the benefit of sentient beings. “Certain things found in this king of manuals Cannot be found in other manuals,[1276] But whatever has been taught by the best of sages And their sons in other manuals, “All of that, all the mantras, can be found in this manual. This then is a detailed manual. For this very reason the lord of sages Taught it to all beings. “There is no one on this earth, Or in the triple universe, Who would not be attracted to And enthralled by this king of manuals.[1277]

thub pa'i zla ba rab nub cing / / sa yi dkyil 'khor stongs pa na/ / cho ga 'jig rten 'dir gnas pa/ / bstan pa'i don ni byed par 'gyur/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni rtag tu dge/ / 'byung po kun la gzhon nu ni/ / de tshe sangs rgyas mdzad pa ni/ / 'jig rten bstan la byed par 'gyur/ / cho ga'i rgyal po mthu la ni/ / yun ring dus su 'dod pa rnams/ / lan cig thos kyang grol 'gyur te/ / rtag tu de la 'grub par 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi gsung dag ni/ / rtag tu dge ba don yod 'gyur/ / sngags rnams kun la sngags pa ni/ / bzlas dang sbyin sreg rtag 'dod pa'o/ /

“When the moon-like Sage is gone And the maṇḍala of this earth is empty, This manual will remain in the world And keep fulfilling the purpose of the doctrine. “The divine youth Mañjughoṣa, Who is always pure, Will continue to do the Buddha’s work And spread the doctrine to all the beings. “Those who, for a long time, have been thirsting For the power of this king of manuals, Will be liberated having heard it just once. They will certainly attain accomplishment. “This teaching bears fruit for all beings And is always pure.[1278] Mantra practitioners always delight in the recitation and the homa Performed for the sake of all beings.[1279]

dus gsum dag tu shes bya la/ / mkhyen pa gang du rab 'jug pa/ / de bzhin 'di la 'jug byed pa/ / cho ga'i rgyal po dam pa yin/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi bstan pa ni/ / sngags su rab gnas de 'dir gsungs/ / sngags de rnam par mi rtog par/ / cho ga de 'dir gsungs pa yin/ /

“Whatever knowledge is contained In the types of knowledge present in the three times, The same knowledge can be found In this supreme king of manuals. “The instructions of the buddhas Taught in this manual are founded on mantras. These mantras are nonconceptual, Yet they have been taught in this ‘conceptual’ manual.[1280]

don dang don min sems can gyi/ / dge dang mi dge byed par 'gyur/ / de tshe 'gro ba blo bzhin du/ / 'jig rten kun gyi dge mi dge/ / de nyid cho ga 'dir spros pa/ / de bzhin gshegs pa spros pa med/ / 'jig rten 'das pa rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / 'jig rten phyir ni 'dir gsungs so/ /

“Every sentient being commits virtue and nonvirtue, Whether with or without purpose. The virtue and nonvirtue present in all the worlds Accord with the intellect of beings particular to their type of birth.[1281] “He[1282] has been elaborated on in this manual By the tathāgatas, themselves free from mental elaboration. He was taught here for the sake of the world By the self-awakened buddhas who transcended the world.[1283]
las rnams kun la shin tu lhag / 'jig rten las las rab tu 'das/ / chos rnams rnam pa sna tshogs byed/ / 'jig rten kun gyis rab tu bsngags/ /
“Transcending the worldly And surpassing all dharmas, [He, the supreme] performer, does various things That are wonderful and venerated by the world.[1284]

sngags rgyal las la brtson par byed/ / de bzhin sems can tshogs la phan/ / gzhon nu 'jam pa'i dbyangs de ni/ / sangs rgyas mdzad pa byed par 'gyur/ / de don yon tan nges grub dang / / 'jig rten khams kyi dge mi dge/ / bag med ma bskul ma yin te/ / bskul nas ngas ni chos bshad do/ /

“This king of mantras engages in these activities For the benefit of large numbers of beings. He, Mañjughoṣa the divine youth, Carries out the Buddha’s work. “There is both virtue and nonvirtue in the world‍— His purpose is to spread good qualities. If I am requested, I will teach; Not requesting is said to be non-Dharma.[1285]

sems can ma lus phan nyid phyir/ / sangs rgyas kyis ni bshad pa yin/ / 'das pa'i sangs rgyas kun gyis kyang / / bshad cing ngas kyang bshad pa yin/ / sangs rgyas gdung ni mi gcod phyir/ / bdag gis kyang ni bshad pa yin/ / sngags pa'i las rnams kun la ni/ / kun mkhyen ye shes 'byung don du'o/ / kun mkhyen ye shes rab 'jug la/ / las rnams gcig tu bsngags pa yin/ / 'jig rten sngon las bdag yin te/ / de ni da ltar yongs su spyod/ / de bas las rnams rab tu bya/ / tshe 'dir dka' ba legs spyad cing / / las ldan tshe ni 'di la yang / / 'bad pa med par sngags rnams 'grub/ / las ni 'di la'ang snang 'gyur na/ / skye ba 'di la 'grub par 'gyur/ / de bas sangs rgyas thams cad kyis/ / las ni gcig pu rab tu bsngags/ / las de cho gar ldan pa na/ / de ni 'di la myur du 'grub/ / sems can byis pa cho ga nyams/ / rab tu rmongs pa 'khor bar 'gyur/ / de bas rnam pa kun gyis ni/ / las ni gcig pu rab bsngags yin/ / cho ga las ni yang dag ldan/ / sgrub pa pos ni bsgrub par bya/ /

“It is taught by the Buddha Solely for the benefit of every being. It has been taught by the past buddhas And will now be taught by me[1286] “With the earnest desire that the lineage Of the buddhas remains unbroken, And that omniscient wisdom arises In all activities of the mantra practitioners. “The only activity that deserves to be praised Is the one based on omniscient knowledge. Since previous actions performed in one’s respective world Are being experienced now,[1287] “One should perform the [right] activities, Though it may be difficult to perform them in this life. Based on these activities, the mantras will succeed Without effort even in this life. “The accomplishment will come in this life, Manifesting also in one’s activity.[1288] The ritual activity is therefore Extolled by all the buddhas as something unique. “When such activity is performed according to procedure, The accomplishment will swiftly follow, even in this life. Naive and careless beings, Who are ignorant of the right procedure, follow erroneous paths. “Thus these activities alone, with all their aspects, Have been deemed praiseworthy. The activity should follow the procedure; If it does, it will be successful.[1289]

de bzhin cho ga nyams pa'i las/ / shin tu yun ring dag gis 'grub/ / bsam gtan med par thar pa med/ / thar pa med par bsam gtan med/ / de bas bsam gtan thar pa ni/ / yang dag ldan pa byang chub brjod/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga /

Activity that lacks the right procedure Will not succeed even after a very long time.[1290] “There is no liberation without samādhi; Liberation is never devoid of samādhi. Accordingly, awakening is said To combine samādhi and liberation.”
byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ las thams cad kyi bya ba'i don gyi le'u rab 'byam bcwa lnga pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the chapter with detailed instructions on the meaning of all ritual activities, fifteenth in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
tshigs su bcad pa'i le'u
Chapter 16

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ blo dang ldan pa gnod sbyin gyi bdag po lag na rdo rjes nga la dris nas/ 'jam dpal khyod kyi don thams cad bya ba'i las kyi le'u rab 'byam 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor gyi nang du rgya cher sngar bstan pa yin no/ /

The blessed Śākyamuni looked again at the realm of the Pure Abode and spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “Mañjuśrī! Requested by the wise king of yakṣas who holds a vajra in his hand, I already taught in detail, in the middle of this assembly, your complete chapter[1291] on the ritual activities intended for all purposes.[1292]

sngags kun don dang ldan pa yi/ / rmi lam dge dang mi dge yin/ / des na zhar la 'di kun ni/ / sngags kyi zlos pa bstan pa yin/ / gnod sbyin bdag po yid dga' nas/ / thal sbyar spyi bor byas nas ni/ / ston la mgo bos phyag 'tshal nas/ / de tshe tshig ni 'di skad zhus/ / 'jig rten rjes su gzung don du/ / blo mchog rnams kyis gsungs pa dang / / bdag la'ang rjes su thugs brtse dang / / sems can rnams ni bde don du/ / zlos pa'i sngags ni thams cad la/ / rmi lam dge dang mi dge dang / / sems can mchog dang tha ma yi/ / spyod pa'i yon tan rgya cher bstan/ / bzang po'i 'gro ba'i skye gnas dang / / rgyu dang shes pa'i rnam pa spyod/ /

“I taught about the good and bad aspects of dreams And how they relate to all the mantra purposes. I taught all of it at length For the mantra reciters.”[1293] The king of yakṣas, pleased at heart, Folded his hands at his forehead and, Bowing his head before the Teacher, Said at that time, “The one of supreme intellect taught[1294] Out of his kindness for the people, Out of his compassion for me, And for the happiness of beings, “About the good and bad aspects Of all the mantras and dreams of the reciters, About the extensive qualities of the conduct Of noble and debased beings, And about determining the causes For the highest birth and destiny.[1295]

'das dang ma 'ongs shes pa dang / / dge dang mi dge da ltar gyi/ / thams cad kun 'gro'i shes pa dang / / kun mkhyen ye shes spyod pa dang / / snang med dmigs pa med pa dang / / spros med rab tu spros pa yin/ / rnam pa kun mchog ldan pa dang / / shis pa zhi ba bstan pa yin/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi mthu rnams ni/ / blo mchog gis ni bstan pa yin/ / khyad par du ni zlos pa la/ / sngags rnams don dang ldan par bshad/ /

“He taught the knowledge of what is beneficial And detrimental‍—past, present, and future. He taught the complete, all-encompassing knowledge‍— The dynamic aspect of all-knowing awareness. “He taught about the auspicious tranquility described As being without a visible form, without support, Which expands without mental elaboration And is endowed with all the supreme aspects. “The one of superior intellect Described the powers of all the buddhas In particular for those reciters Who pursue all the aims of mantra.

las dang las 'bras sems can gyi/ / bya ba dus dang de bzhin du/ / de bzhin snod dang gnas dang ni/ / cha byad rmi lam zhar la gsungs/ / gnod sbyin bdag po thub mchog ni/ / de bzhin gshegs pa bdun pa la/ / gang zhig bskal bzang sangs rgyas pa/ / shAkya'i skyes mchog bdun pa 'di/ / shAkya'i seng ge dgra las rgyal/ / 'di ni bdun par rab tu brtags/ / dus kyi tha mar rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / 'jig rten mgon po 'od byed pa/ / brtson 'grus che zhing shes rab che/ / thub pa mthu ni chen po thob/ / lag na rdo rje gnod sbyin bdag / byang chub sems dpa' phyag byas te/ / rang gi gnas su 'dug gyur nas/ / blo ldan de nas cang mi smra/ / de nas 'jam dpal shes rab che/ / de tshe thub pas dris pa ni/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas la bskul ba ni/ / thub mchog dam pa tha ma la/ / legs so bcom ldan rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / las dang shes pa rgya cher bcas/ /

“He taught the ritual activity, its complete[1296] result, And the right time for the rituals; He taught about the vessel, the place, and the possession,[1297] Which teachings were requested in the context of dreams.”[1298] The king of yakṣas then bowed to the best of sages, To the supreme seventh tathāgata. Whatever buddhas appeared in the auspicious eon, The Bull of the Śākyas was the seventh of them. He, Lion of the Śākyas who conquered the enemies, Is regarded as the seventh‍— The lord of the world, the bringer of light, A perfect buddha for the lowest eon, A sage of great diligence and wisdom, Renowned for his great energy. It was to him that the yakṣa[1299] Vajrapāṇi Bowed in homage. Mañjuśrī, the wise one, stayed silent And remained in his seat. The [seventh] sage then spoke to him, The sagacious one, as follows: “[Vajrapāṇi] requested[1300] the Buddha, The most recent and chief among sages, ‘It is good, O fully awakened Blessed One! Please teach at length the knowledge of ritual activities.

bcas pa'i gza' ni gtso bo ste/ / dge dang mi dge legs tshul bshad/ / las dang shes pa rgyur bcas pa'i/ / sems can mang po'i spyod pa gsungs/ / mchog dang tha ma'i spyod pa dang / / dge ba'i don dang ldan pa dang / / zlos pa grub pa'i mtshan ma dang / / bsgrub bya sgrub min rnam par brtags/ / 'byor pa 'dod dang de bzhin du/ / 'jig rten dbang phyug longs spyod 'dod/ / rgyal po khyad par can 'dod dang / / rig pa 'dzin pa grub 'dod dang / /

“ ‘Teach how one’s birth horoscope constitutes the chief factor In explaining one’s virtuous and nonvirtuous character traits;[1301] Explain the actions of many beings Based on the understanding of karmic causes; “ ‘Teach about the signs of the reciters’ accomplishments, Differentiated in terms of what should and should not be accomplished, [The signs] exhibited by those entered into and possessed [by spirits], And the reciters who pursue various virtuous goals;[1302] “ ‘Teach also, for the sake of those who desire, in this world, Riches, power, and enjoyments, For those who want to rise to prominence and obtain a kingdom, And for those who want to hold on to their success.[1303]

thams cad kun 'gro'i ye shes kyis/ / mdor bsdus nas ni bshad du gsol/ / rgyal ba'i sras kyis gsol btab nas/ / thub pa mchog gis gsungs pa ni/ / blo ldan ka la ping ka'i skad/ / lha yi rnga sgra'i skad dang ni/ / brtson 'grus chen po tshangs pa'i sgra/ / 'brug sgra yi ni sgra skad kyis/ / thub pa bdun pas tshig bshad nas/ / sangs rgyas gsung ni dag pas gsungs/ / gzhon nu 'di ni dngos don khyab rgyur cing / / ma byung 'jig rten phan pa sgrub byed la/ / 'gro ba kun la phan pa dge phyir ston/ / thar pa shes shing dag pa'i gnas su 'dug /

“ ‘In short, please teach The complete, all-pervading knowledge.’ ” So spoke the supreme sage, When requested by [Vajrapāṇi,] the son of the victorious ones.[1304] The seventh sage then spoke [the following] stanzas In the pure voice of the Buddha’s speech. The wise one had a voice like that of a cuckoo bird, Spreading like the sound of a celestial drum, As sweet as Brahmā’s, and resounding like A thunderous cloud of great might. “Those, O divine youth, who abide in the highest truth Gain accomplishments to benefit the world. They guide the world to every good fortune and benefit. May [the accomplishments] of these lords of liberation remain pure.[1305]

bden dang brtse dang bzod pa phan sems dang / / gang zhig rtag tu byams dang sbyin la dga'/ / de dag rtag tu grub pa thob par byed/ / kye ma gzhan la'ang grub pa yod ma yin/ / rtag tu sngags mchog la ni dga' dad dam/ / bstan dang 'khor lo 'dzin dang 'jam mchog dang / / de ni bdud 'dul chos kyi 'khor lo bskor/ / 'khor lo 'dzin par 'dir ni rigs pa yin/ / gang gi gsung ni bzang po yid 'ong zhing / / rtag tu byis pa'i skye bo rnam spangs yin/ / yid 'ong bzang po rnar ni snyan pa dang / / dga' skyed snyan pa dang ni rjes su mthun/ / sems ni tshim byed bde ba rab tu sbyin/ / 'jam zhes bya bar sangs rgyas yang dag gsung / / de dag de bzhin gshegs pa'i khyad par gyis/ / gang gis mthu ni mkhyen par mi spyod de/ / de dag gi sras de bzhin sar zhugs pa/ / 'jig rten 'das pa de bzhin bcu yi grangs/ / khyod kyang lha yi dbang phyug 'jig rten khyad par gyis/ / thub bzang shes par nus pa ma yin no/ /

“Those who possess honesty, unwavering diligence, a sober mind, And loving kindness and who always delight in generosity Will always be successful; Others will never succeed. “Those who always find joy and delight in the supreme mantra And in the instructions of the wheel holder[1306] or of Mañjuvara Will overpower Māra and turn the wheel,[1307] Just as befits a wheel holder in this world. “There is a divine speech, pleasing to the mind, From which, however, fools are ever separated. This divine speech is pleasing to the ear, captivating, Lovely, sweet, and agreeable. “It refreshes the mind and bestows happiness. The buddhas call this speech Mañju.[1308] But even they, with their superior knowledge[1309] of a tathāgata, Are unable to understand his power.[1310] “Their sons who are established on their respective levels And accordingly reckoned as falling into ten groups, perfect and divine, Even they, O lord of gods,[1311] are unable To understand his divine power, which surpasses the ordinary.[1312]

gzugs dang gzugs med de bzhin sa gnas dang / / 'dod ldan lha dang mi ni yid las skyes/ / rnal 'byor grub pa thob dang 'jig rten na/ / khyad par can kun de bzhin mi yi gtso/ / de yi che ba gang gis shes gyur pa/ / sems can gang de yod pa ma yin te/ / khyod kyi che ba 'di ni yongs shes pa/ / 'jam zhes bya bar rab shes sangs rgyas yin/ / 'jam dpal zhes byar yongs su brtags pa ni/ / khyod kyi ming ni sngon gyi rgyal bas mdzad/ / khyod kyi ming du 'di ltar brtags byas pa/ / 'das dang ma byon da ltar sangs rgyas kyi/ / gzhan du ma yengs rtse gcig yid dag pas/ / khyod kyi ming ni 'khor gyi nang du thos/ / des ni 'di la shis dang zhi ba thob/ / srid mthar byang chub mchog ni khyad par thob/ /

“The same is true for the celestials of the form and formless realms, Gods of the desire realm, or human beings, Even if they have attained yogic accomplishments, Or for outstanding individuals who surpass everyone else in this world. “There is no being anywhere Who could fully understand his splendor. The buddhas call him ‘Gentle Splendor,’[1313] Knowing that splendor is merely a concept. “ ‘Gentle Splendor’ is an imputation, A name given to you by the victors in the past. It was imputed to you as your name By the past, present,[1314] and future buddhas. “One who hears your name in saṃsāra With a one-pointed mind that is neither distracted nor impure Will obtain the auspicious peace And awakening when still in saṃsāra.[1315]

sngags rnams ma lus 'grub par 'gyur ba dang / / 'gro ba'i skye gnas mchog ni rab thob cing / / rtag tu chos mchog la ni yang dag gnas/ / bgegs rnams rnam par spang shing grub pa thob/ / 'dod pa'i sngags rnams ma lus 'grub par byed/ / byang chub shing dbang drung du myur du 'gro/ / song nas byang chub mchog ni thob par byed/ / song nas sems can phan phyir der 'dug ste/ / sangs rgyas byang chub 'khor lo rab tu skor/ / de ltar rgyal ba'i gtso bos yon tan gsungs/ / 'jam dpal zhes ni khyod kyi ming dran pa/ / yon tan bsam mi khyab ces rgyal bas gsungs/ / rgyal ba'i gtso bo sngar gshegs thams cad kyis/ / rtag tu khyod kyi mthu ni bstan pa yin/ / gzhon nu dag pa khyod kyi sngags rtogs pa/ / bskal pa grangs med rtag tu'ang ston mi nus/ / 'jam dpal khyod kyi sngags kyi spyod pa ni/ / sangs rgyas ma lus dag gis rab tu bshad/ / gzhon nu 'di ni thams cad kun tu 'gro/ / nga yi bstan la khyod ni mi mchog bstan/ / dag pa'i gnas la gnas pa'i skye bo rnams/ / 'dir ni ma lus mtha' dag zhi bar 'gyur/ / khyod kyi sngags ni nam yang 'da' ma gyur/ / khyod kyi sngags ni nam yang nyams ma gyur/ /

“He will accomplish all the mantras And obtain the best possible rebirth and destiny. One who always relies on the supreme Dharma Will be free from obstacles and will attain accomplishment. “One will thus master all the desired mantras And swiftly attain the pleasant[1316] awakening in this world. The chief among sages arrives at the Bodhi tree And sits there for the benefit of beings.[1317] “He awakens to realization and turns the wheel [of Dharma], The quality of which has been described by the chief victors. [The same] chief victors [also] described your name, remembered as ‘Glory’ (Śrī) that is called ‘Gentle’ (Mañju), as having inconceivable qualities. “The chief victors of the past, however many there have been, Even if they were to explain your power continually Over innumerable eons, would not be able to describe it Nor [the power of] the hundreds of mantras, O pure divine youth! “All the buddhas, without exception, have taught The complete mantra system of Mañjuśrī. These instructions of yours, O divine youth, cover everything, And the diligent ones derive the highest pleasure from them.[1318] “Beings who dwell in the Pure Abode, And all beings without exception, will attain peace[1319] If they never violate your mantra In any way whatsoever.”[1320]

Now Lord Śākyamuni entered the samādhi called the magical display of all the tathāgatas. As soon as he entered this samādhi, rays of blue, yellow, dazzling white, red, and crystal-colored light issued from the tuft of hair between his eyebrows. They brightened the entire buddhafield and illuminated the interior of every realm of the universe, while darkening all the planets and constellations and summoning them in an instant. After summoning them, the light assigned them to their respective places and drew them, by the power of the Buddha’s blessing, into the circle of the assembly. It then disappeared into the same tuft of hair between Lord Śākyamuni’s eyebrows. All the planets, constellations, and stars, their light blocked, approached Lord Śākyamuni, pained and frightened. They stood with folded hands, trembling and prostrating themselves on the ground again and again.

Lord Śākyamuni then gave the following talk For all the celestial bodies such as planets, constellations, and stars. He gave it as an act of kindness for all the beings Born with the intelligence of a child.

“Listen, esteemed friends, hosts of gods along with men. The karma of individual beings causes them to experience the world differently. The way the bodies of beings manifest, whether the vajra bodies of the blessed buddhas or the various bodies of gods, asuras, and humans circling in saṃsāra, lost in its wilderness‍—all of this is a product of karma. This karma, whether it is good or bad, still constitutes fetters. There is no creator here who creates, nor godhead, nor the puruṣa and prakṛti as espoused in the Sāṃkhya system. Nothing of this kind exists, except for that which is produced by karma. Everything that is generated in dependence upon karma thus has a cause. This cause, in turn, depends on its own causes and conditions. In this way, everything is mutually interconnected, being generated through dependent origination. Living beings are generated from the [five] great elements that coalesce together.[1321] “These great elements exist within the five aggregates[1322] throughout the beginningless transmigrations. They manifest in the place of another birth, developing into an elaborate [whole] with all the [constituent] parts. The habitual tendencies generated by karmic actions can, however, be completely burnt by the fire of gnosis that blocks and prevents [the arising of elements] at another time. One can effectively accomplish the equality of the three vehicles and the state without conceptual elaboration. This will happen as the result of the karma produced by following the Mahāyāna for a long time. Following [the Mahāyāna] for a medium length of time will bring about the self-arising gnosis of a rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddha. Within a short time, one can attain the regal state of a śrāvaka[1323] who listens to the teachings of others. If naive and confused people do not turn to non-Buddhist doctrines, their intelligence will grow.[1324] “This world, with its different places and situations, is produced by different types of karma. Its cessation‍—the auspicious state without old age, sorrowless and pure‍—[is produced by] karma based on worldly accomplishments that are pure, [namely] the detached eightfold karma that arises out of the [eightfold] path. Karma is produced by karma and has no other basis but itself.
las dang las ma yin pa las rnam par grol te/ spros pa med pa la nye bar gnas pa yin no/ / theg pa rnam gsum rab 'jug las/ / zhi ba gzhan yang yod min te/ /
“One who is free from dualistic thinking Will remain free from both action and inaction. Following the threefold path, one will obtain No other tranquility [but that of the path].

sngags kyang rnam pa gsum du 'gyur/ / rnam gsum las su yang dag bsgrags/ / de las rnam zlos rnam gsum las/ / rnam pa gsum du rab tu snang / / rigs kyang rnam gsum gsungs pa ni/ / sngags rnams kun gyi gzhi yang yin/ / rigs gsum rnam pa brgyad du yang / / rgyud dag la ni rab tu snang / / rnam pa gcig tu 'ang rigs snang ste/ / sngags rnams kun gyi gnas kyang yin/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi dag pa'i thugs/ / rigs ni zhi ba mya ngan 'das/ / yan lag so so de nyid las/ / sngags rnams kun tu rab tu bstan/ / 'jig rten skar mkhan yan lag ni/ / grub pa'i rgyur ni rab tu brtag / de nyid yan lag las yin te/ / rkyen gyi yan lag dag la 'jug / ji ltar sA lu'i 'bru rnams ni/ / myu gus rnam par shes par byed/ / de bzhin grub pa'i rdzas rnams ni/ / mtshan nyid kyis ni rnam par shes/ /

“The mantras thus fall into three groups, And the [resulting] activity is of three kinds. The fruit [thereof] is threefold And the reflection [thereupon] is threefold too.[1325] “Inverted activity[1326] is threefold And is regarded as such. Virtue is regarded as threefold, As can be gleaned from the tantras.[1327] “The religious community is also such,[1328] And so[1329] is the entire[1330] seat of the mantras. The community of buddhas with pure minds Abides in the peace of nirvāṇa. “This karma[1331] is here taught, section by section, As part of the science of mantras. For the sake of success in the world, The discipline of astrology has also been taught. Its subdivision, [the science of] karma, Is part of the teachings on causation.[1332] “Just as [the cause in] a grain of rice Can be inferred by the sprout, So too [the cause in] the power substances Can be inferred by their effects.

ji ltar kha dog dkar po ni/ / tha snyad kyis ni rnam par brtags/ / de bzhin skar ma ldan pas ni/ / tha snyad don du rab tu brtag / thams cad du ni thams cad ldan/ / las ni gcig pu rab tu bsngags/ / las rnams med par mtshon pa med/ / gang na 'ang lus ni yod ma yin/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni spyod pa dang / / skye ba dang ni rigs dang gnas/ / rtag tu la nye sna tshogs pa/ / las de las ni nye bar dmigs/ / las ni gang du'ang lus can min/ / nang na gnas shing mtshon pa med/ /

“Just as the color white Is imputed [to an object] based on a convention, So, too, the astrological influences Are imputed [to a person] based on conventions. However, it is only karma that is deemed Wholly responsible for all such influences. “Karma never resides in a body Without being indicated by [certain] signs, Such as marks, behavioral patterns, or a birth Into a particular category of practitioners. “Karma can always be ascertained By various omens. Karma never itself possesses a body;[1333] It is hidden and can be discerned by other [signs].

kun nas skye bo rgas pa na/ / rnam par 'gyur las nye bar dmigs/ / de bzhin lus la brten nas ni/ / las ni lus can dag la snang / / 'bras bu dge dang mi dge'i rtags/ / skye bar yang ni rab brjod dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs la nye bzang / / las rnams sna tshogs dag las byung / /

“[The condition of] a person thoroughly afflicted by fever[1334] Is indicated by the alterations [in their appearance]. The various omens reflect the various types of karma That beings are produced by.[1335]

All these branches [of knowledge] are therefore The topic of the Sage’s teachings. “The omniscient Śālendrarāja Sat upon the seat of awakening[1340] And pronounced the mantra That removes all obstacles, One that removes bad dreams, Bad omens, and difficulties. “While the mind of the omniscient great being Was thus steeped in awakening, Māra, with his evil mind, Created very frightening obstacles. “Śālendrarāja, [sitting at] the root of the tree,[1341] Saw that all this great terror was baseless; The many frightening forms Were, for him, without any basis. “Having made aspirations over a long period of time, He accumulated merit and power; Consequently, by the power of his mantra, Namuci was defeated.[1342] “Śālendrarāja is endowed with magical powers and great energy. Being restrained, he possesses great splendor. One should strive to obtain the supreme awakening, Using the power of his mantra. “This mantra, which obliterates bad omens,[1343] Will now by revealed.[1344]

It removes bad dreams and difficulties, And wards off evil beings. “Please hear it, O hosts of gods; This king of mantras [controls] Planets, constellations, and other celestial entities. It was formerly taught by the victorious Śālendrarāja. “It is used in order to suppress the wicked Planets, constellations, and stars, And to awaken gentle thoughts In all beings. “Please hear it, O hosts of spirits, All of you who roam the earth! Those without legs, with many legs, Or with two or four legs! In short, all the beings and inanimate objects Present in the three worlds.[1345]
na maHsarba bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ kha kha khA hi khA hi hU~M hU~M dz+wa la dz+wa la/ pra dz+wa la pra dz+wa la/ tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha Sh+Ti phaT phaT swA hA/
“Homage to all the buddhas, the perfect teachers! “Oṁ, kha kha! Eat, eat! Huṁ huṁ! Burn, burn! Blaze, blaze! Remain, remain! Ṣṇīḥ, phaṭ phaṭ, svāhā![1346]

gtsug tor 'bar ba zhes bsgrags pa'i/ / sngags 'di sngags rnams kun gyi mchog / gang zhig las rnams stong phrag ni/ / dgu bcu rtsa bzhi dag dang ni/ / bkra shis thams cad 'dod pa yi/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las rnams byed/ / rmi lam ngan dang mtshan ma ngan/ / lan cig bzlas pas sel bar byed/ / las rnams gzhan yang byed pa ni/ / sngags rnams kun gyi bdag po yin/ / 'byung po kun la dbang byed pa/ / bla ma mnga' bdag sangs rgyas 'di/ / sngags 'di dran pa tsam gyis ni/ / sngags rnams ma lus rab tu sems/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas pa lha yi lha/ / thub mchog gis ni de gsungs nas/ / yud tsam mi gsung bzhugs nas ni/ / cung zad dus ni bzhes par mdzad/ / de tshe gnas gtsang gnas pa yi/ / lha tshogs dag kyang 'dug par 'gyur/ / lha rnams gtso bo thams cad ni/ / rgyu skar gza' dang skar ma rnams/ / gtsug tor sngags kyi byin rlabs kyis/ / 'jigs shing dam tshig la gnas phyir/ / gtsug tor zhes bya mthu bo che/ / mthu mnyam mthu ni chen po ste/ / brgya phrag lnga 'am bzhi 'am ni/ / de bzhin bdun nam brgyad dang dgu/ / gnyis dang drug dang lnga dang bdun/ / gtsug tor dbang por rab tu bsgrags/ / de ltar grangs dang grangs med ni/ / gtsug tor rgyal po dge ba yin/ / de dag dang ni sngags 'di mtshungs/ / sngon gyi rgyal ba rnams kyis bshad/ /

“This mantra is known by the name of Jvāloṣṇīṣa, Its dazzling white light coming from the Buddha.[1347] “There are thousands of rites‍— Eighty, nine and five.[1348] One who performs various rites With his thoughts completely attuned to virtue Can destroy bad dreams and omens With a single repetition [of the Jvāloṣṇīṣa]. “One may perform other rites, Having mastered all the mantras; This mantra[, however, the Jvāloṣṇīṣa,] is a buddha, A powerful master who enthralls sentient beings.[1349] “Through merely calling this mantra to mind, All the obstacles will be destroyed,[1350] And one will become a perfect buddha superior to the gods.” Having spoken this, the supreme among sages Remained silent for a while, And looked on. The hosts of gods, too, Waited above the Pure Abode. All the chief deities [Who personify] the constellations, planets, and stars, Frightened, took their samaya vows As they were told the mantra of Uṣṇīṣa.[1351] The lords called uṣṇīṣa are capable, Very diligent, and of great brilliance. They are said to be four or five hundred in number, Or seven, eight, ninety,[1352] One hundred and twenty, thirty-five, or another[1353]‍— So it has been proclaimed. The number of these auspicious kings That are born from the [Buddha’s] head is incalculable. The aforementioned mantra is identical with them, As explained by the victors in the past.[1354]

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ las bdag gir byas pa'i rkyen gyi le'u rab 'byam las bcu bdun pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter on the ascertainment of one’s personal karma, seventeenth in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.

Chapter 24

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas rgyu skar dang gza' dang skar ma dang skar mkhan thams cad 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du gtogs pa dang / phyogs thams cad du rnam par gnas pa'i rdzu 'phrul chen po dang ldan pa'i mchog rnams la bka' stsal pa/ grogs po dag khyed cag nyon cig / gza' dang rgyu skar thams cad kyi mthu'i tshig khyed cag thams cad dag la yang ston cig / khyed kyi sngags bya ba'i don thams cad kyang sgrubs shig / khyed kyis dam tshig la yang gnas par gyis shig / sngags kyi rgyal po 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis bstan pa 'di grub na/ de nas gzhan cho ga'i rgyal po grub pa la yang khyed cag yid dad par gyis shig ces so/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas/ gza' rnams kyi spyod pa sems can thams cad kyi don du gsungs te/ zlos pa thams cad la phan pa'i phyir dang sngags kyi don yang rab tu bsgrubs pa'i phyir thams cad kyang thams cad mkhyen pas gsungs so/ /

[1355]The blessed Śākyamuni now addressed all the most important grahas among the constellations, planets, stars, and celestial bodies that exist in all the world spheres‍—the grahas dwelling in all the directions and endowed with great magical powers: “Listen, venerable friends, to my presentation on the respective powers of all the planets and constellations. Show your power, sirs, and accomplish the purpose of all the rituals involving the mantra. Keep your samayas and eagerly pursue an accomplishment in the doctrine contained in this sovereign manual of Mañjughoṣa and later expounded in other manuals as well.” In the interest of all beings, the blessed Śākyamuni then taught about the action[1356] of the grahas. He, the omniscient one, taught everything for the benefit of all mantra reciters and in order to fulfill the aims of the mantra [system].

tha skar dang ni bra nye dang / / smin drug dang po'i rgyu skar te/ / rgyu skar gsum po 'di dag la/ / mig dmar gza' ni bdag po yin/ / lug ni khyim du bstan pa ste/ / 'di la grub pa yod ma yin/ / grub mchog bar ma tha ma nyid/ / grub pa yin par 'dod pa yin/ / las rnams kun tu'ang mi 'gro zhing / / ma rungs gza' ni rnam par zlog / snar ma mgo dang de bzhin du/ / lag tu rgyu skar brjod pa yin/ / rgyu skar nab so rgyal dang ni/ / skag tu'ang rab tu brjod pa yin/ / mchu dang de bzhin gre dang dbo/ / de bzhin me bzhi nag pa dang / / sa ri sa ga lha mtshams dang / / snron dang de bzhin snrubs dang ni/ / chu ni stod smad dge ba ste/ / zlos pa la phan rab tu bsngags/ / rgyu skar gro bzhin mon gru ni/ / drag po'i las la rab tu bsngags/ /

“The three nakṣatras, Aśvinī, Bharaṇī, and Kṛttikā, Are ruled[1357] by the planet Mars. “They are said to belong to the zodiacal sign of Aries, And no accomplishment will arise [when the moon is] in them. Accomplishments are classified into The highest, medium, and lowest types. One should not embark on any journey Whenever one is obstructed by the[1358] cruel planet. “Rohiṇī and Mṛgaśirā, along with Ārdrā, Are said to be nakṣatras too, And so are the celebrated Punarvasus,[1359] Puṣya, and Āśleṣā. “Further, there are Maghā, the two Phalgunī, As well as Hastā, Citrā, Svāti, Viśākhā, Anurādhā, Jyeṣṭhā, and Mūlā. “The two Āṣāḍhās[1360] are praised as auspicious And good for mantra reciters. The nakṣatras of Śravaṇā and Dhaniṣṭhā Are recommended for cruel rites.

mon gre khrums ni stod smad gnyis/ / rgyu skar grub pa'i rgyu yin no/ / nam gru las skye dpal dang ldan/ / 'thab la dga' zhing 'jigs pa med/ / rgyu skar lhag ma gtso bo ni/ / dus kyi tha mar 'byung ba min/ / byi bzhin legs par spyod pa dang / / grub dang bsod nams rab tu bsgrags/ / nye rgyal dang ni tha chungs dang / / 'dod pa dag ni nyid yin no/ /

“Both Śatabhiṣā and the two Bhadrapadās Are conducive to accomplishment. Revatī brings good fortune And also competence and fearlessness in battle. “The main ones among the remaining nakṣatras Do not occur during the lowest eon. Abhijit is known to have an auspicious influence And to bring accomplishments and merit. Tiṣya is secondary in importance; It is the last and the least significant.[1361]

yang dag bden dang 'jig rten dang / / snang bar yang ni brjod pa yin/ / longs spyod sbyin dang dge sbyin dang / / ma 'gags pa dang 'gags pa nyid/ / grags sbyin gzi brjid rgyal po dang / / de bzhin rgyal po 'jig rten dang / / rgyu skar mang po gsungs pa ste/ / stong phrag drug cu rtsa bzhi'o/ / dus kyi tha ma 'di la ni/ / 'di dag gi ni nus pa yod/ / cho ga rgyal 'di bde don du/ / de tsam shes par gsungs pa yin/ / rang nyid 'od ldan sems can ni/ / de yi dus su rdzogs ldan yin/ / thams cad nam mkha' la 'gro zhing / / rga dang 'chi ba rnam par spangs/ /

“Truth and honesty are praised As the light of the world.[1362] [This light] brings happiness and virtue When unobstructed, but can also be obstructed. It is a majestic king that grants renown, And it is the king of the world.[1363] “Nakṣatras are said to be many‍— Sixty-four thousand in all. However, during this lowest eon They do not[1364] possess this power.[1365] They are taught in this king of manuals that brings happiness Simply for the sake of information. “During the golden age, Beings’ powers manifested by themselves. They all could travel through space And were free from old age and death.

de yi dus su rgyu skar med/ / nyi ma zla ba skar ma med/ / lha dang lha min 'jig rten med/ / dang po'i dus ni dus mchog yin/ / ming med rigs kyang yod ma yin/ / tshes dang skye ba'i skar ma med/ / smyung ba med cing sngags kyang med/ / dge dang mi dge'i las kyang med/ / 'di dag rang dgar spyod pa ste/ / bza' dang bza' bar bya ba'ang med/ / 'di dag nad med dag pa ste/ / rtag tu sems can rnam mang po/ /

“At that time there were no nakṣatras, No sun or moon, and no stars. During the best of eons at the beginning of time There were no gods and no asuras. “There were no names and no clans; No lunar days and no birth horoscopes; No fasts, no mantras, And no karma, whether good or bad. “Beings could wander as they pleased Without food or eating. They were always Very pure and healthy.[1366]

de nas dus ni bri ba na/ / 'jig rten snod min rab tu 'jug / sngon gyi las kyis drangs nas ni/ / de nas sa yi steng du 'gro/ / sa steng lha gnas gzhal med khang / / lha dang lha min yang dag byung / / bar ma'i dus su phyin gyur nas/ / mi yi lus la yang dag brten/ / bza' dang btung la brkam chags pas/ / 'od de dag ni rab tu nyams/ / lus ni sra ba nyid gyur cing / / dge dang mi dge rnam par spyod/ / de nas nyin zhag zla ba dang / / gza' yi 'od ni byung bar gyur/ / de nas bzung nas gang cung zad/ / skar ma'i dpyad shes pa nyid dang / / sems can rjes su gzung bar brjod/ / ngas ni de dag bstan pa yin/ / sngon ni drang srong cha byad gyur/ / blo ldan tshangs pa'i cha byad dang / / dbang phyug chen po'i lus bstan cing / / yang na khyab 'jug cha byad kyis/ / nam mkha' lding gi lus spyad dang / / gnod sbyin srin po dri za dang / /

“However, their consciousness became ‘seized,’ Making them into worldly beings.[1367] Drawn by their previous karma They subsequently fell down to earth, “Where they lived in celestial mansions, Commingling with gods and asuras. Then, when the middle eon arrived, They took on human bodies. “Being fond of food and drink, They lost their [physical] luster. Their bodies became solid, And their conduct ambivalent‍—good and bad. “From then on they became bounded by Days, months, planets, and other celestial bodies. From that time onward, Whatever astrological knowledge there was, “I taught all of it, showing patience And kindness to sentient beings. I formerly assumed the appearance of sages, Such as the sagacious Brahmā. “I took on the body of Maheśvara And also assumed the guise of Viṣṇu. I used a body of a female garuḍa, And the bodies of yakṣas, rākṣasas, and gandharvas.[1368]

sha za dag gis lus nyid gyur/ / skye dang skye bar bdag nyid skyes/ / byang chub sems dpa' mkhas par ni/ / de dang der ni skye ba la/ / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod don phyir/ / rtag tu skye ba'i dbang gis so/ / bdag nyid de tshe dus dag tu/ / sngon ni byang chub sems dpar gyur/ / mi shes mun pas bsgribs pa yi/ / bdag ni de tshe byis par gyur/ / 'jig rten ji snyed yod pa yi/ / khyab 'jug gis byas gzo spyad dang / / lugs kyi bstan bcos sngon gyi rabs/ / de bzhin rig byed brda sprod pa/ / sdeb sbyor skar ma'i dpyad nyid dang / / rtsis dang sgyu rtsal 'dod pa dang / / log shes de bzhin shes pa dang / / de bzhin log par spyod nyid dang / / 'jig rten bstan bcos thams cad ni/ / yun ring bdag gis sngon bstan to/ / zhi ba thub bdag ji lta bar/ / ye shes bdag gis thob ma yin/ / byang chub rgyu ni grol don dang / / de bzhin du ni thar pa'i phyir/ / 'khor ba'i btson rar rab bcings pas/ / las rnams las kyang bdag ma grol/ / zhi ba rnam rgyal sangs rgyas nyid/ / ma nyams go 'phang mya ngan 'das/ / yun ring don du mngon 'dod cing / / legs par yongs su btsal bas thob/ / de ltar bdag gis rig ldan pas/ / tshegs chung bya bas thob pa yin/ /

“I was born in a body of a female piśāca, And I was born again and again, Becoming, in these consecutive births, A skillful bodhisattva. “I was a bodhisattva in the past, During that particular eon, Because of my power to always choose A birth suitable for practicing the conduct of awakening. “I also was, in former times, A naive person veiled by the darkness of ignorance. In this world, however many disciplines of Knowledge, crafts, and occupations there are‍—[1369] “Whatever is found in the scientific treatises, Works on polity, the Purāṇas, the Vedas, works on grammar, Sacred hymns, or works on astrology or arithmetic‍— All are regarded as conceptual construct,[1370] “False knowledge, and ignorance,[1371] As well as mistaken conduct. I formerly recited in this world All the treatises for a long time, “Yet I found no knowledge whereby I could become a sage who remains at peace‍— A knowledge that brings awakening And also constitutes the cause of liberation. “My actions confined me in the prison of saṃsāra, Rather than deliver me into Stainless[1372] buddhahood and peaceful nirvāṇa From where there is no falling back. “But now I have attained the perfect awakening That I had desired for so long. I attained it solely by myself, By applying the rituals as prescribed.[1373]

rgyal bas sngon ni bstan pas na/ / rang byung ye shes thob pa yin/ / de 'dra'i gnas ni rab mthong ba/ / phyi rol lam gyis thob ma yin/ / byang chub rgyu ni rnyed dka' bas/ / 'khor ba'i dgon par 'khyams pa yin/ / bdag gi rang byung 'di 'dra ba/ / ye shes bdag gis thob pa min/ / rig pa bzang po'i las dga' bas/ / da ni mya ngan 'das pa thob/ / bdag gis bstan bcos 'di dag ni/ / bsdus pa 'ba' zhig byas pa yin/ / las las grol ba med par ni/ / grub pa'i rgyu ni rnyed ma yin/ / 'khor ba'i yun ring zhags pa 'dis/ / las kyi 'ching bas nges par bcings/ / de yi 'gro 'di bdag nyid che/ / dge dang mi dge'ang smin par 'gyur/ / rgyu skar gza' dang skar ma'i dpyad/ / mtshon par byed pa kho nar zad/ / chos dang mi ldan mi rnams dang / / gzhan la rtags ni snang mi 'gyur/ / de nyid kyis na gza' gsungs pa/ / dge dang mi dge'i rjes gzung phyir/ / 'jig rten skyong ba bzhi dag dang / / khams ni bzhi po dag dang ni/ / chu dang sa dang rlung dang me/ / nam mkhar yongs su bstan pa yin/ / 'byung ba yang dag bsdu ba'i phyir/ / 'di dag 'byung ba chen po yin/ /

“I attained the self-arising[1374] knowledge That was formerly taught by the victorious ones. I do not see the state attained By external methods as the same.[1375] “When lost in the wastelands of saṃsāra Where causes of awakening are difficult to find, I could not obtain knowledge Of the kind that arises by itself. “But now, as I have attained nirvāṇa by employing The ritual activity and delighting in what is good,[1376] I will teach specifically This collection of topics. “Without ritual activity,[1377] Causes of accomplishment cannot be won. This yarn of saṃsāric existence is very long; It is woven and held together by karma. “This yarn has many destinies [strung along it]. The nakṣatras, grahas, and other astrological entities Merely indicate the good and bad [results] That are in the process of ripening. “For people not attuned to the Dharma No other signs can be observed [except for the planets and so forth.] Consequently, the planets and other [astrological entities] Are said to fall into the categories of either good or bad. “The four guardians of the world‍— Water, earth, wind, and light[1378]‍— Are known to constitute the celestial luminaries. These same [four] great elements Account for [all] the assemblages of elements.[1379]

sems can yang dag bsdu ba'i phyir/ / bag med las kyis byas pa yin/ / de dag dus ni nges pa yis/ / sngags rnams grub par 'gyur ba yin/ / de yi skye ba 'bad pa yis/ / dge dang mi dge bsrung bar bya/ / rang bzhin gyis ni 'jig rten gtso/ / lha yi dbang phyug brgya byin sogs/ / de yang de tshe de dus su/ / dus kyi mthar ni yongs su brtags/ / dus kyi tha ma dag la ni/ / sngags rnams grub pa nges pa yin/ / de nyid kyis na thub dbang gis/ / gzhon nu yongs su brtags pa ni/ / shes rab chen po 'jam pa'i dbyangs/ / byis pa gzhon nu'i gzugs dang ldan/ / 'jig rten 'dir ni kun tu rgyu/ / sems can rjes su gzung bar bzod/ / de yi dus su grub pa ni/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni rab tu mthong / / rgyu skar skar ma'i dpyad shes pa/ / de yi tshe na 'byung bar 'gyur/ / nyi shu rtsa bdun rgyu skar dang / / yud tsam dag tu rab tu bsgrags/ / dus kyi tha ma de la ni/ / bcu gnyis khyim yang yod pa yin/ / rgyu skar tshogs la brten nas ni/ / de dag gza' ni rnam par dbye/ / thams cad so sor gyur pa ni/ / 'jam dpal gyis ni so sor mdzad/ /

“Thus they conglomerate to form living beings When stirred to do so by karma.[1380] The mantras will be successful Within the limitations of [astrological?] time periods.[1381] “In these births, one should be protected With great care, in weal and in woe. For this task, at the time at the end of the eon, The lords of gods have been assigned. They are Śakra and so forth, Distinguished and eminent in the world. “The mantras, applied with care, Will produce accomplishments during the lowest eon. Because of this, the victorious ones Appointed the divine youth‍— “Mañjughoṣa of great wisdom, In the form of a young boy. He will wander throughout this entire world, Ready to show kindness to beings. “At that time achievements pertinent to Mañjughoṣa will be seen‍— The science of astrology Will come into existence at that time. “At that time, during the lowest eon, The twenty-seven nakṣatras will become known, As will the muhūrtas, And the twelve signs of the zodiac. “The planets are assigned to the zodiacal constellations Of the nakṣatras, which they inhabit. Occupying wide spaces, They each have a separate location.[1382]

skye ba dang ni spyod pa nyid/ / khyim rnams kun la rab tu gnas/ / skye bo rmongs pas khyab 'gyur la/ / dge dang mi dge'i 'bras bu 'byung / / de nyid las kyi 'ching ba yis/ / de dag khyim ni yang dang yang / / sems can rnams kyis grub pa tsam/ / dge dang mi dge rtog par byed/ / rgyu skar snar mar ldan par ni/ / skye bar yongs su rab brtags pa/ / dpal ldan bzod pa phun sum tshogs/ / tshe ring bu ni mang ba dang / / rtag tu de tshe nor skal ldan/ / de ni dmag gi bdag po byed/ / 'di ni khyu mchog khyim skyes na/ / khyu mchog nyid la yongs su 'chi/ / mgo nyid la ni 'jig rten shes/ / chos ldan mthong na dga' bar 'gyur/ / smin drug char skyes rtag tu ni/ / sa bdag rgyal por snang ba ste/ / yang dag skye ba de la brten/ / rtag tu rgya mtsho gsum bdag 'gyur/ /

“Regarding their horoscope and course of life, Beings depend upon their birth sign. They are born ignorant, do things the wrong way,[1383] And reap good and bad results. “For that reason, their birth sign can indicate Their [particular] karma time and again. [These signs] determine what course will be successful For beings to pursue, whether it is virtuous or not. “If the nakṣatra linked to the birth horoscope Has been charted out as Rohiṇī, One will enjoy good fortune, Have many sons, and live a long life. “One will always be wealthy And will do well as the general of an army. If one’s birth sign is Taurus And this constellation is traversed In the nakṣatra of Mṛgaśirā,[1384] One will understand people and be virtuous and good looking. “Similarly, if the Kṛttikā part of Taurus is traversed[1385] And ‘King’[1386] looks upon Earth,[1387] One could become a ruler over the three oceans. This may manifest based on one’s birth horoscope.

phyogs gcig skyes pa bgrod dka' ba'i/ / phyogs gcig rgyal por 'gyur ba yin/ / gza' ni bla mas mtshan pa yi/ / gal te skye bar 'byung 'gyur na/ / sa ni khor yug ma lus par/ / rjes su spyod par 'gyur ba yin/ / lo ni bcu dang lnga po nyid/ / de yi rgyal thabs byed par 'gyur/ / tha skar bra nye nyid dang ni/ / smin drug cha las skyes gyur pa/ / khyim 'di dag gi nus pa ni/ / tshong gi don gyis nor sgrub 'gyur/ / gal te skyes pa des byung na/ / dbang phyug longs spyod phun sum tshogs/ / rgyu skar 'di la skyes pa na/ / nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor dmar bar 'gyur/ / de bzhin nyi ma nub pa na/ / de ni 'chi bar 'gyur ba yin/ / ma rungs tsham tshom med pa dang / / bden par smra ba ma yin dang / / lus kyi lpags srab dmar ba'i mdog / sa yi steng na de snang ngo / / 'di yi 'gro ba skad cig ni/ / mig 'byed 'dzums su rab tu bstan/ / 'di yi bar du gang skyes pa/ / rgya che yon tan de 'di yin/ / se gol gtogs gnas tsam du ni/ / 'di yi 'gro ba rab tu bstan/ / des na de dag 'gro ba nyams/ / gza' rnams kyis ni mthong ma yin/ / skye ba rnam par 'dris gyur pa'i/ / sems can rnam pa sna tshogs skye/ /

“Alternatively, one may become a king in a province, Or a place difficult to access. If the planet is designated as Jupiter And one’s horoscope is right, “One will come to enjoy The entire earth all around; One may be appointed to kingship Within ten or five years. “One born under the sign of Aries, Which spans the nakṣatras Aśvinī, Bharaṇī, And a part of Kṛttikā, is very smart. He would do well in business and accumulate much wealth. “If, through one’s birth sign, One is endowed with power and pleasures, But, at the time of one’s birth A red disk of the sun, “When it is about to set, is in one’s nakṣatra, Things will go wrong‍— One will be born cruel, impetuous, And prone to telling lies. “One is then observed, in one’s life on earth, To have delicate skin of reddish hue, And, it is said, one will open and close One’s eyes at the time of one’s birth. “One born at these junctures Will possess these qualities in abundance. However, as for those whose delivery at birth Is said to take the time equal to a finger snap, “They do not fit their [astrological] stereotype, As they are deprived of their planetary influences.[1388] Beings are born different, As their birth influences are a combination of many things.[1389]

'dres pa'i 'gro ba phun sum tshogs/ / 'dren pa'i longs spyod ldan pa yin/ / de nyid kyis na mi skye ste/ / skye ba nyid na brjod pa yin/ / skye ba'i skar ma sum cu ni/ / dge dang mi dge'i 'bras bu 'byung / / gza' ni mig dmar gyis mtshan pa/ / 'di ni ma rungs skye bar 'gyur/ / gsus che lus ni snum pa dang / / mig dkyus ring zhing snyan par smra/ / gza' ni phur bus bltas pa ni/ / rtag tu brtan ldan skye bar 'gyur/ / chu tshod zung tsam nyi ma dang / / zla ba'i lha ni rab bshad pa/ / de bzhin rtag tu nyin mtshan la/ / yang dag skye bar 'dod pa yin/ / phyin ci log pa'i skye ba gzhan/ / phyin ci log tu'ang brtags pa yin/ / gza' ni mi dge mthong ba dang / / mi dge'i skye ba dge mi dge/ /

“The modes of existence that manifest for them Are mixed, and so are their fortunes. For that reason they are not born Exactly as their horoscopes describe. “Astrologically, there are thirty types of birth influences; They bring results that may be good or bad. Those who are marked by the planet Mars Will be of the cruel type (jāti). “One who is under the influence of Jupiter Is always born steadfast, With a prominent belly,[1390] lovely appearance, And elongated eyes, and soft-spoken. “Similarly, if the deities Sun and Moon have both risen And the sun is four angular cubits above the horizon,[1391] One can definitely expect a birth That is continually auspicious, day and night. “Those with other horoscopes that are unfavorable, Who have been allotted [at birth] the opposite lot, Ought to gain control of their planetary influences [that govern] The positive and negative aspects of their inauspicious birth.[1392]

mi dge'i 'bras bu grub pa dang / / yang dag skye ba bzang po 'byung / / 'gro ba'i skye gnas la brten nas/ / khyim la skye bar rab tu gnas/ / gza' ni ngan spong bus mtshan pa/ / sbyin byed sems dpa' che ba ste/ / lag dang na ba so dag dang ni/ / skag gi cha la rab tu brjod/ /

“When the unwholesome results manifest, one can thus bring on, Through correct knowledge, that which is wholesome. Having taken a particular birth, One belongs, in this birth, to an astrological house. “Beings [born] under the influence of the planet Venus Are by nature noble and pure.[1393] I will now describe [the influence of] the nakṣatras Of Ārdrā, the Punarvasus, and a part of Āśleṣā.[1394]

'di dag la skyes gtong ba che/ / g.yo sgyu can ni bab col byed/ / don dang don med 'byor ba la/ / rtag tu brkam chag bud med chags/ / gzhan gyi bud med mngon 'gro zhing / / de nyid nag po la spyod dang / / dud pa'i mdog 'drar skye 'gyur te/ / drag cing 'khrig pa la yang dga'/ / sbyor ba'i khyim la rab brten nas/ / de ni spen pa dag la skye/ / nyin dang mtshan du yang dang yang / / der gnas spen pa rgyu bar byed/ / de las skyes pa nyi ma phyed/ / sems ni stobs dang ldan par 'gyur/ / de yi dus la gang skyes pa/ / de yi mtshan nyid brjod par bya/ / nor ni grub par 'gyur ba dang / / dbang phyug gis ni legs mtshan pa'o/ / rgyu skar de bzhin rgyal dang ni/ / skag la yang ni gang skyes pa/ / 'di ni sbal pa'i khyim yin te/ / dge dang ldan zhing rdzu 'phrul che/ / mdog ni ser po dang ldan zhing / / de ni skye ba mchog tu bstan/ / rtag tu de bzhin mtshan phyed du/ / 'di ni skye bar bstan pa yin/ / de yi dus kyi tshad la ni/ / gal te sems can skye bar 'dod/ /

“A person born under these nakṣatras is very generous, But also impetuous and deceitful. He is always attached to women, lustful, And full of hatred whether with or without a motive. “He makes sexual advances on other people’s wives, And his [skin color] is black or dark. He is born with a smoky complexion, Is very fierce, and is fond of sex. “One may be born under the sign of Gemini With Saturn, positioned there, Slowly traversing [the sign] Day and night, bit by bit. “If such a person is born at midday, He will possess great mental faculties. This is said to be the guiding characteristic For someone born at this time. “He will own great wealth And be distinguished on earth by power and influence. If one is born in the nakṣatra of Puṣya or Āśleṣā, One’s zodiac sign is Cancer. “For such a person, a connection[1395] With Jupiter[1396] betokens great magical powers.[1397] One’s complexion will be yellowish. This birth is proclaimed to be the best. “For a person [of this sign] born at midnight, The following horoscope is given: One born at this time Will generally seek goodness and truth.[1398]

cho ga mthong ba'i rgyu yis na/ / 'di ni don rnams thams cad sgrub/ / de ni shin tu gzhon pa nas/ / rgyal thabs byed cing nor rnams thob/ / mdog ni ser dang sngo bsangs ni/ / kha dog rgyas pa snang bar 'gyur/ / gtsang sbra'i spyod la dga' ba dang / / de ni dpal ldan 'jigs med skye/ / mchu dang de bzhin gre dang ni/ / de bzhin dbo yi cha dag ni/ / snang byed kyi ni zhing du 'gyur/ / seng ge'i khyim du bya ba yin/ / de la skyes pa dpa' bo che/ / sha yi kha zas de la dga'/ / ri yi rdzong la brten nas ni/ / rgyal thabs dbang phyug byed par 'gyur/ / gal te der skyes thob gyur na/ / zhing la gnas shing des sdom rten/ / de bzhin nyi ma 'char ba na/ / skyes pa 'di la brjod pa yin/ /

“Such a person will accomplish all his tasks, If he applies the prescribed methods. He will obtain a kingdom and wealth, Starting already in childhood. “His complexion will be yellowish or dark, And he will appear healthy and strong. He will delight in pure conduct, Will have good fortune, and will be fearless. “When the nakṣatras of Maghā, [the first] Phalgunī, And a part of the second[1399] Phalgunī Become the sun’s house, The designated sign is that of Leo. “Great heroes are born under this sign, Who are fond of eating meat. They establish their power and kingdom In mountainous places difficult to access. “[Whatever planets] are traversing through One’s zodiac sign at the time when the sun is rising, One is said to be born Under the influence of these [planets].[1400]

rgyu skar dbo yi cha dang ni/ / de bzhin me bzhi nag pa nyid/ / rgyu skar de la skye gnas pa/ / mi ni yongs su dpa' bar 'gyur/ / sdom min gzhan gyi bud med 'gro/ / de ni dmag dpon byed par 'gyur/ / gal te skye ba thob 'gyur na/ / nges par rgyal thabs byed par 'gyur/ / gang du skar ma de dag gnas/ / 'di ni bu mo'i khyim du 'gyur/ / 'di yi bdag po gza' lhag ste/ / kha cig tu ni gzhan yang yin/ / 'di dag skar ma mchog la ni/ / gza' ni mi bzad bsrung bar 'gyur/ / zla ba yang ni bzang ba ste/ / yang na zla ba'i bu bdag yin/ /

“If one is born in the nakṣatras of [The Virgo] part of the second Phalgunī, Hastā, or the [Virgo part] of Citrā, One may become a powerful thief.[1401] “One will lack restraint with regard to the wives of others. One may also become a general of the army. If this is indicated in one’s birth horoscope, One will obtain a kingdom. “The house where these stars[1402] belong Is the sign of Virgo. Their dual regents are [the sun and the moon], Or another planet, depending on the location.[1403] “The seniormost of these stars[1404] Are guarded by either the cruel planet,[1405] Or by the gentle planet,[1406] Or by the ever joyful and auspicious lord.[1407]

nyin phyed rdzogs na skye ba ni/ / 'di yi skye bar snang ba yin/ / nag pa'i cha dang sa ri dang / / sa ga'i phyed kyis lhag pa la/ / srang gi khyim ste bzang po'i don/ / zla ba la spyod sems can gyi/ / 'di ni mi bzad zhing yin te/ / skal med ma yin nor gyi gnas/ / 'di yi skye ba skye gyur gnas/ / mtshan mo'i thun gyi tha ma'o/ / mi ni 'di la skyes gyur pa/ / rtag tu btung ba dag la dad/ / spyi mtshan ma yin ngo tsha med/ / mang pos bkur cing mchod pa dang / / la lar rgyal srid longs spyod dang / / nor chen thob par 'gyur ba yin/ / nges med skye ba yongs snang zhing / / byis par mas ni spangs pa yin/ / gal te skye ba thob 'gyur na/ / bu mang bde ba skye bar 'gyur/ / rgyu skar lha mtshams las skyes pa/ / bzo yi las ni sgrub pa dang / / byams pa'i bdag nyid grogs po mang / / rtag tu dpa' zhing rtul phod che/ / 'jig rten snron la skyes pa ni/ / mi ni rab gtum brtan pa yin/ /

“If one is born in the afternoon And one’s birth [nakṣatras] Are those of Citrā, Svāti, Or the greater part of Viśākhā,[1408] “Then the sign of Libra will bring much wealth. For beings who are under the influence of the moon, This is a terrible house. It will not make them unfortunate, though, but grant wealth.[1409] “People who are born Under the same influences But at night, at the end of a watch, Will always be fond of drinking.[1410] They are discreet, respected for their modesty,[1411] Honored, and venerated. “They may sometimes obtain a kingdom, Sometimes pleasures, and sometimes wealth. Unless determined by their horoscopes to be otherwise, Women [born under this sign] will be childless. If, however, their horoscopes are favorable, They will give birth to many children with ease. “The [birth] influence of Anurādhā[1412] Brings perfect fulfillment of activities.[1413] One will have a loving nature, many friends, And will always be valiant and daring. “It is said about Jyeṣṭhā that a person Born into the world [under its influence] will be fierce.[1414]

sdug bsngal mang po bzod pa dang / / mi ni ma rungs skye bar 'gyur/ / khyim ni sdig par bshad pa ste/ / rtag tu rno zhing bab col byed/ / 'di dag nyid la rtag skyes pa/ / skye bar yang dag brjod pa yin/ / de bzhin nyin phyed nyi ma la/ / gal te mi ni skye gyur na/ / drag cing g.yul las rnam rgyal ba'i/ / rgyal por de ni nges par 'gyur/ / byis pa gzhon nu'i gzugs yod pa'i/ / de yi skad cig gzas mthong 'gyur/ / sa yi lha mo'i bur gyur pa/ / gang yin de ni mig dmar gsungs/ /

He will experience and will have to put up with much suffering. People born [in this nakṣatra tend to be] cruel. “The sign of Scorpio is described as Always intense and impetuous. I will now describe the types of birth And the astrological influences particular to this sign. “If a person is born When the sun ‘marks’ noon, He will certainly become a fierce king Who wins battles. “At such times, the planet in the form of a young boy Will exercise its influence at the precise moment. This planet is specified as Mars, Who [shines] his light onto the goddess Earth.[1415]

de nyid phyir na sa la spyod/ / rang bu nyid kyis gsod par byed/ / de las gzhan pa bzlog pas ni/ / dge dang mi dge'i skye ba nyid/ / tshe ring gzi brjid ldan pa dang / / shes ldan nyid du'ang skye bar 'gyur/ / lha mtshams la ni rab skyes pa/ / shes rab che zhing grogs la byams/ / mig dmar gyi ni zhing 'di yin/ / yang na rtag tu gza' 'dres yin/ / rgyu skar snrubs las skyes pa dang / / de bzhin du ni chu stod dang / / chu smad kyi ni cha dag la/ / gzhu yi khyim du rab tu bstan/ / de yi skye ba'i skye ba ni/ / phur bu'i zhing der brtan pa yin/ / nyi ma phyi dror gyur pa dang / / zla ba nam smad gyur pa la/ / de yi skye ba zhes bstan pa/ / gang zhig skyes pa skye ba'i rgyu/ / snrubs las skyes pa rang rigs 'jig / tha mar bzang por 'gyur ba yin/ / skye gnas bar mar longs spyod ni/ / thob par de ni the tsom med/ / gzhon pa yongs su 'das pa na/ / snang byed dkyil 'khor ji lta bar/ / rgas par gyur na rgyal por 'gyur/ / longs spyod che zhing nor cher 'gyur/ /

“Because of this, [such a king] rules the earth, Protected by his own son.[1416] If one’s position in life turns out to be different, It will be a mixture of good and bad things. One will, however, live long And be energetic and intelligent. “One born in Anurādhā will possess Great wisdom and loving friends. This house belongs to Mars And always has mixed planetary influences. When the nakṣatra of Mūlā sets in,[1417] Followed by the first Āṣāḍhā and “The [Sagittarius] part of the second Āṣāḍhā, [These three] are proclaimed as the sign of Sagittarius. This sign is the house of Jupiter. Its horoscope is as follows: “When the sun ‘marks’ the afternoon, Or when the moon ‘marks’ the second part of the night, It is said that birth at this time Will predestine one to obtain a kingdom. “[One born] at the onset [of Sagittarius] will destroy one’s family; [Birth] at the end of it is said to be auspicious. One born in the middle of it Will obtain pleasures, there is no doubt. “When one’s youth has passed, As illustrious as the orb of the sun, One may become, in one’s old age, A king rich in pleasures and wealth.

dma' ba'i phyogs su lus 'gyur gyi/ / gzhan gyi phyogs su ma yin no/ / de las gzhan du bzlog par ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs skye bo snang / / chu smad kyi ni cha dag dang / / gro bzhin nyid du brtan pa dang / / mon gru rgyu skar mchog nyid ni/ / khyim 'di chu srin kho na yin/ / 'di ni spen pa'i zhing yin te/ / yang na gza' gzhan gyis mtshan pa'o/ / rtag tu 'di la skye gnas pa/ / de yang sa steng 'di la snang / / dang po'i mtha' dang bar ma'i mtha'/ / mtshan mo'i cha ni 'das pa la/ / de dag las skyes longs spyod cher/ / kun nas snang bar gyur pa yin/ / mtho dang dma' ba'i rigs gnas shing / / de dag sa yi bdag por 'gyur/ / rab gtum kha dog nag po'am/ / sngo bsangs mdog tu de dag 'gyur/ /

“As a king, one would become powerful in the lowlands; This would not be so in other places, so it is told.
