But there also other people of different types For whom these influences are reversed. “[The next nakṣatras] are said to be The second Āṣāḍhā, the Śravaṇā, And the superior nakṣatra of Dhaniṣṭhā; Together they constitute the sign of the Sea Monster.[1418] “This sign is the house of Saturn But is influenced also by other planets. The following horoscope applies on earth Always to the just mentioned nakṣatras: “Those born when night has set in, Either at the end of the first or during the middle watch, Are observed to enjoy Great pleasures in all respects. “Whether born in high or low families, They become rulers over the earth. They are fierce, swarthy, And of dark-bluish[1419] complexion.

mig mtha' dmar zhing 'jam pa dang / / rtag tu dpa' zhing rtul yang phod/ / de bzhin chu yis khyab pa yi/ / phyogs su rgyal po byed par 'gyur/ / tshe ring bu ni med pa dang / / sdug bsngal mang po bzod par 'gyur/ / de las gzhan pa bzlog pa la/ / skye bo rnam par bzlog pa snang / / mon gru'i phyed dang mon gre dang / / de bzhin khrums stod phyed dag ni/ / de yi khyim du 'gyur ba ni/ / bum pa zhes ni brjod pa yin/ / 'di la gza' yi gtso bo ni/ / zhing du rtag tu brten pa yin/ / de bzhin 'dres pa'ang zla ba dang / / blo ldan pa wa sangs nyid yin/ / 'di dag skye bar 'gyur ba ni/ / mtshan mo'am nam ni langs par snang / / rtag tu skye 'di bzang po ste/ / 'jig rten spyod pa dag pa yin/ /

“They have red eyes and are of delicate constitution; They always are valiant and daring. As kings, they may rule countries Surrounded by water. “They may live long lives but have no offspring. Others, for whom the influences are reversed, May experience a lot of suffering. They are regarded as deviations from the norm. “The nakṣatras of Dhaniṣṭhā, Śatabhiṣā, And the first Bhadrapadā Are together parts of the sign That is called Aquarius. “This sign is always inhabited by The best of planets‍— Different [aspects] of the moon and Venus, But not Jupiter. “If a birth under these nakṣatras Occurs at night or in the morning, One’s horoscope will always be excellent; It indicates pure conduct in the world.

mi ni ma rungs las byed cing / / blo dang ldan par brjod pa yin/ / longs spyod sna tshogs phun sum tshogs/ / sa steng rjes su spyod par 'gyur/ / de las gzhan du bzlog na ni/ / dbul zhing nad rnams snod du 'gyur/ / rgyu skar khrums smad nyid dang ni/ / nam gru zhes ni brjod pa dang / / khrums stod kyi ni bzhi cha la/ / khyim ni nya ru rab tu brtags/ / skye ba de dag rtag gnas pa/ / kun tu ji ltar snang zhe na/ / mtshan mo'i thun gyi bar ma dang / / nyin par nyi ma shar ba dang / / nyi ma thun phyed 'das pa dang / / nyin phyed cung zad 'das pa dang / / lhag ma khru gang tsam 'das par/ / 'di yi dus su'ang skyes pa ni/ / dag pa dang ni rab dag nyid/ / pa sangs nyid kyis rab tu mchod/ / pa wa sangs kyi zhing zhes pa/ /

“One may become involved in cruel rites,[1420] But will be described as intelligent, And will enjoy Various pleasures on earth. “Others, whose horoscopes are unfavorable, Will be afflicted by poverty and disease. Now I will describe the nakṣatras Of Bhadrapadā and Revatī. “The sign of Pisces[1421] starts In the [latter] part of the first Bhadrapadā. The following horoscope applies Universally to the [nakṣatras of Pisces]: “If one is born at night during the middle watch, Or during the day when the risen sun Is half a watch above the horizon, A little behind the midday point, “Or when it[1422] is a short distance from setting, With [about] one cubit left to go, Such a birth is unique; It is very pure And strongly connected with Venus.

lha yi rigs zhes tshangs par spyod/ / ser dang dkar ba'i mdog dag gi/ / gza' yis kyang ni rab tu bsten/ / des shing rtag tu dge ba dang / / chos ldan mchog tu bzang ba yin/ / mi ni de la skyes gyur pa/ / yan lag kun kyang shin tu mdzes/ / brtson 'grus che zhing rgyal po 'dod/ / gnyen dang bshes ni brtan pa dang / / tshe ring longs spyod che ba dang / / dma' ba'i yul la yang dag brten/ / shar gyi phyogs la brten nas ni/ / de dag rtag tu skye bar 'gyur/ / de dag mya ngam phyogs su ni/ / rtag tu skye bar mi 'gyur te/ / nya ni thang la yongs spyod par/ / nam yang snang ba ma yin no/ / drang srong rnams kyi chu gnas dang / / chu bo dag tu 'phel bar 'gyur/ / de la skye bar rab brtan pa/ / khyim nyid du ni rab tu bstan/ / mi ni de dag las skyes pa/ / dma' ba'i yul du rnam par 'phel/ / rtag tu shar gyi phyogs gnas pa'i/ / sa bdag skal ba chen por 'gyur/ / phur bu dang ni spen pa dag / gza' mchog gi ni mngon par bltas/ / shar gyi phyogs kyi bdag po byed/ / de dag las skyes the tshom med/ /

“The gods from the realm of Brahmā know This sign to be the house of Venus.[1423] It is inhabited by yellow And whitish planets. This sign is the sign of good fortune, Righteousness, and supreme virtue. “People born under these nakṣatras Are beautiful in every limb. They are desirous of kingship, very valiant, And steadfastly loyal to their friends. “If they live in the lowlands, They will enjoy long life and great pleasures. If they live in the east, They will always reach an old age. “If they live in an arid country, They might reach an old age, or not[1424]‍— No fish are ever seen Thriving on dry land. They instead thrive in water; The abode of fish[1425] is in water. “Birth under these nakṣatras[1426] Is well known to like that, and so is the sign. People born under them Thrive best in the lowlands. “Rulers of the earth who enjoy great pleasures Are always established in the east. The planets considered the best [for them] Are Jupiter and Saturn. “They will help establish a dominion in the east For those born under their influence, there is no doubt.

khyim ni rnam pa mang po dang / / rgyu skar du ma gsungs pa yang / / rnam pa sna tshogs gza' mchog kyang / / sngon gyi dus yin da ltar min/ / mi rnams de las skyes pa yang / / de bzhin tshes grangs bco lnga dang / / nyin zhag sum cu dag nyid de/ / des na zla bar rab tu bstan/ / zla phyed nyin mtshan bco lnga ste/ / zla phyed gnyis la zla bar brjod/ / des na zla ba bcu gnyis la/ / lo gcig tu ni rab tu bsgrags/ / 'di tsam dus kyi tshod la ni/ / dus kyi tha mar yongs su brtags/ / rtsod pa'i dus su phyin pa na/ / 'di yi grangs su rab tu bstan/ / mi rnams tshe ni de bzhin du/ / lo brgya dag tu bsgrags pa yin/ / de dag lo tshigs phyin pa na/ / dus ni drug tu rab tu brjod/ / dang po bar dang tha mar ni/ / de dag gsum du rab tu bstan/ / lha mtshams la ni sa 'gul na/ / mi rnams 'dir ni tshe ring 'gyur/ / de dag mi yi 'jig rten 'dir/ / skye zhing 'phel bar 'gyur ba yin/ /

Signs of the zodiac are explained in many different ways, As there are many nakṣatras. “The chief planets fall into three categories.[1427] Human knowledge of them Has been accumulated over a long time, not suddenly. There are also fifteen lunar days [in a fortnight]. “A month is said To have thirty days. Its fortnight has fifteen [units of] day and night; A month has two such fortnights. “One year is said to consist Of twelve months. This [yearly] measure of time Is said to delimit the end of the[1428] eon. “When the dark eon sets in, The following calculations are done: The human lifespan Is said to decrease to one hundred years. “Such years are said To be comprised of six seasons, Each subdivided into three parts‍— The first, the middle, and the last. “The lifespan of humans Ranges from long to short in this world, Where unexpected calamities Are known to occur.[1429]

mi ma yin pa 'jig rten 'dir/ / phan tshun du ni 'byer bar 'gyur/ / de dag rnam skrag 'jigs pa dang / / phan tshun du ni rnam par rgyu/ / lha dang lha min gtso bo ni/ / gang tshe 'thab par rab 'jug pa/ / de tshe mi yi 'jig rten 'dir/ / nad ni 'byung bar byed pa yin/ / mjug rings las dang skar mda' dang / / gnam lcags dang ni rdo rje dang / / dud pa phyogs ni mtha' dag tu/ / du ba mjug rings rab tu snang / / zla ba nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor la/ / mun nag gis ni khebs par gnas/ / nyi zla rdzu 'phrul chen po dag / bug pa yod par snang ba dang / / de ltar rnam pa sna tshogs pa/ / rnam mang yang ni snang gyur na/ / mu ge tshe ni nyams pa dang / / de bzhin yul 'khor 'jig pa dang / / mi yi bdag po 'chi ba dang / / sdom brtson 'jigs pa chen po 'byung / / 'jig rten dag ni thams cad la/ / der ni 'jigs su rung ba 'byung / / mchu dang tha skar dag dang ni/ / nab so la ni sa 'gul na/ / de tshe dbus kyi yul dag tu/ / rkun ma bab col byed la gnod/ / lho yi phyogs la gnas pa yi/ / rgyal po chen po rnam par 'jig /

“[At that time] the nonhuman beings in this world Run and escape in different directions. They are frightened and very scared, And run here and there. “Whenever a war ensues between The prominent gods and asuras, They cause, in the human world, Outbreaks of disease, Comets, meteors, earthquakes,[1430] And bolts of lightning. “[At that time] smoke will be seen all around, As well as smoke-tailed falling stars. The orbs of the moon and the sun will appear [At that time] like Kabandha-shaped[1431] splinters.[1432] “A hole will be seen in the sun And also in the majestic moon. In this way different phenomena will be observed In abundance, occurring repeatedly. “There will be famines and the shortening of life, As well as the breakup of the kingdom. The king will die and religious devotees Will be in great danger. “All the people in that country Will be struck with terror. If an earthquake occurs in the nakṣatras Of Maghā, Aśvinī, or the Punarvasus, “The central regions will be oppressed And the thieves, at that time, will be very audacious. Great kingdoms will be ravished By the people from the south.[1433]

bra nye smin drug nyid dang ni/ / gang tshe snar ma dang ni mgo/ / 'gul na 'jig rten 'jigs pa che/ / de la dogs pa rab tu 'byung / / nub phyogs na ni gnas pa yi/ / de tshe rgyal po 'chi bar 'gyur/ / gang yang mtha' 'khob gnas pa yi/ / kla klo rku bas 'tsho byed dang / / de bzhin 'bigs byed steng gnas dang / / nang du mi yi dbang phyug gnas/ / de yang de yi dus dag tu/ / nad kyis brgyal zhing gnod par 'gyur/ / de dag la ni dgra rnams 'byung / / gcig la gcig ni yul 'phrog 'gyur/ / rgyu skar lag dang rgyal dang ni/ / skag dang de bzhin gre dang dbo/ / 'di dag la ni sa 'gul na/ / mi bdag kun ni mi mthun nas/ / phan tshun gnod pa byed 'gyur ba/ / gsod dang 'ching dang gnod pa dang / / mu ge dag kyang rab tu 'byung / / me bzhi nag pa sa ri dang / / de bzhin lha mtshams snron nyid la/ / snod kyi 'jig rten sar gyur pa/ / 'di la gang tshe 'gul gyur na/ / kha ba can gnas kla klo dang / / rkun ma kun nas gnas pa dang / / bal yul gyi ni bdag po dang / / kha sha'i lung par gnas pa yi/ / der ni mi bdag ma lus pa/ / phan tshun du ni mi mthun nas/ / thams cad g.yul la spyod 'gyur bar/ / 'dir ni the tshom med pa yin/ /

“If an earthquake occurs During the nakṣatras of Bharaṇī, Kṛttikā, Rohiṇī, or Mṛgaśirā, A great fear and anxiety will set in. “At that time, the kings Who live in the west will die. The barbarians who inhabit The borderlands and live by theft, “And the kings on the Vindhya frontier, Nestled in the valleys, Will also suffer at that time, Weakened by disease “And having their enemies unite against them. People will seek dominance over one another.[1434] If an earthquake occurs during The nakṣatras of Ārdrā, “Puṣya, Āśleṣā, or the Phalgunī, Whether it is the first Phalgunī or the second, It will render all the kings volatile, “And wishing To drive each other out. Killings, enslavement, And famines will proliferate. “If an earthquake occurs In this part of the world During the nakṣatras of Hastā, Citrā, Svāti, Anurādhā, or Jyeṣṭhā, “The barbarians from the Himalayas, The brigands who live everywhere, The Khasas and the Droṇis[1435] Allegiant to the king of Nepāla, “As well as all the kings, Will turn against one another, All of them eager for battle; There is no doubt about this.

rgyu skar gang yin snrubs dang ni/ / chu ni stod smad gnyi ga la/ / sa yi steng du 'gul bar ni/ / 'di dag la ni rab mthong na/ / shar gyi phyogs kyi mi rnams dang / / pon dra o Ta kA ma ru/ / b+hang+ga la bdag rgyal po ni/ / 'chi bar 'di la the tshom med/ / gau TA'i bdag po dpal dang ldan/ / yul 'khor gzhan gyis yongs bskor ba'am/ / 'phral la na bar gyur pa dang / / la lar yang na 'chi bar 'gyur/ /

“If an earthquake occurs during The nakṣatras of Mūlā or Āṣāḍhā, Whether it is the first Āṣāḍhā or the second, And the ground appears to be moving, “It will affect the eastern people and countries‍— Pauṇḍra, Oḍra, and Kāmarūpa. The king of Vaṅga will die; There is no doubt about this. “The glorious king of Gauḍa Will engage in hostilities with other kingdoms; He will suddenly either become incapacitated Or die somewhere.

'jig rten rgya mtsho'i ngogs gnas dang / / gang+gA'i 'gram du yang dag gnas/ / chu yis thams cad khyer ba'am/ / nad rnams mang po kun gnod byed/ / gro bzhin dang ni mon gru dang / / mon gre dang ni chu stod dang / / de bzhin du ni chu smad dang / / gal te nam gru las skyes pa/ / rab tu 'gul ba nyin phyed la/ / snod kyi 'jig rten yang dag 'gul/ / sa rnams thams cad rab 'gul ba/ / ri bo dang ni nags su bcas/ / rtag tu nam mkha' la snang ba/ / 'phar zhing 'og tu 'byung byed na/ / byang phyogs kyi ni yul dag dang / / nub phyogs la ni yang dag gnas/ / lho yi phyogs ni thams cad dang / / phyogs rnams kun la gnas byed pa'i/ / mi mchog sa ni mang spyod pa/ / phan tshun du ni gnod pa byed/ / sems can rnams ni gnod chen ldan/ / mu ges yul 'khor 'byer bar 'gyur/ / tho rangs sa ni 'gul gyur na/ / lus can shis dang zhi bar 'gyur/ / de las cung zad phyi dus na/ / drag po'i 'gul ba rab tu skye/ / de nas cung zad phyis 'gul na/ / yul ni ma ga d+hAr gnod dang / /

“People living by the ocean Or on the banks of the Gaṅgā Will all experience flooding And will suffer from many diseases. “If an earthquake occurs in the nakṣatras of Śravaṇā, Dhaniṣṭhā, Śatabhiṣā, or the Bhadrapadās, Whether the first Bhadrapadā or the second, Or during the Revatī, “If there is a powerful temblor at noon Causing the inhabited lands to sway; If the entire earth shakes Along with its mountains and forests; “If all the celestial bodies, always visible in the sky, Are altered or obscured, Then all the most powerful and wealthy kings[1436] Who live in the countries “To the north, the west, The south, and all around‍— In all the directions‍— Will turn against one another. “Many beings will die due to pestilence, Starvation, and the dissolution of the kingdom. If the temblor occurs before dawn, When beings experience blissful peace, “And if, a little later, It is followed by a terrifying aftershock, And later still, by another one, It will be deadly for the inhabitants of Magadha.

ang+ga'i yul du gnod 'gyur te/ / ma ga d+hA rgyal de bzhin no/ / de nas cung zad nyin phyed dam/ / phyi dro'i dus su gyur pa na/ / gal te sa ni 'gul bar gyur/ / sa steng ma lus nyid dag gi / rab tu byung ba thams cad la/ / rtag tu nad ni 'byung ba 'thob/ / rims dang yi ga 'chus dang gzer/ / de bzhin nad ni 'brum bu yis/ / zhag bdun btab par gyur nas ni/ / de nas de dag sos par 'gyur/ /

“The inhabitants of Aṅga will suffer, And so will the king of Magadha. [If an earthquake occurs] when the sun ‘Marks’ the afternoon, shortly after midday, “And extends over the entire Surface of the earth, All the religious renunciants Will certainly contract an array of diseases‍— “They will be afflicted with illnesses Such as fever, severe pain, and tumors. They will suffer for seven days, After which they will improve.

de nas nyi ma yang 'das nas/ / sa ni gal te 'gul gyur na/ / rigs bzhi dag gi mchog gyur pa/ / bram ze rtswa ni so ma 'thung / / nyon mongs rgyal po'i blon po ni/ / 'chi bar 'gyur bar the tshom med/ / mdun na 'don ni chos dang ldan/ / blon po'am zham 'bring byed pa na/ / gzhan yang sdom can gtso bo ni/ / sngags rgyud don la mkhas pa dang / / bram ze dang ni rgyal rigs dang / / de bzhin dmangs rigs rje'u rigs dang / / brtan pa mkhas pa dag dang ni/ / bstan bcos de nyid don lugs ldan/ / gsod dang rab tu nyams pa'am/ / dran ldan thos dang de nyid shes/ / sngon byung ba ni sems pa dag / myur du nad kyis 'jigs 'gyur te/ / gnam lcags rdo rjes shing la bzhin/ / de nas nyi ma nub pa na/ / de nas yang ni song ba na/ / phyi dro dus kyi mtha' la ni/ / gal te sa ni rab tu 'gul/ / de bzhin sems can 'dres pa dang / / dud 'gro dag gi 'gro ba dang / / mi yi 'jig rten gtso bo dag / de tshe 'gum dang rnam par 'jig /

“If there is [another][1437] temblor When the sun has moved a short distance, Then the soma-drinking brahmins, The best among the four castes, “Will suffer and perish. The same will happen, without a doubt, To the king’s advisers, religious priests, Ministers, and servants. “The others, such as the prominent vow holders Who know the purview of the mantra system, The brahmins, kṣatriyas, Vaiśyas, and śūdras, “And also the clever, learned men who know The true meaning of sciences and possess the political acumen, Will be attacked, destroyed, Or tormented by diseases.[1438] “Those who know the smṛti and the śruti,[1439] and thus understand reality, And also those who are familiar with history, Will soon be smitten by disease Just like a tree by lightning. “If an earthquake occurs When the sun sets, And then again after it completely disappears, Or in the afternoon, at the end of the meridian hour,[1440] “The beings of the animal realm Will all run helter-skelter. The most prominent people of this world Will perish in this temblor.

mtshan mo'i thun ni dang po la/ / gal te sa ni 'gul gyur na/ / sems can 'dres pa sna tshogs dang / / dud 'gro'i skye gnas rnams dang ni/ / mi ni 'jig rten gtso rnams su/ / char chen rab tu 'byung bar 'gyur/ / cung zad thun de bri gyur la/ / sa ni 'gul bar gyur pa yi/ / de tshe rtags de snang gyur na/ / rlung dang char pa'i 'jigs chen 'byung / / de nas thun de zad pa'i mthar/ / 'gul snang las ni mi bzad pa/ / nub phyogs mi yi bdag po yi/ / pha rol dmag tshogs 'byung bar shes/ /

“If the earthquake occurs During the first watch of the night, A torrential rain will fall,[1441] Causing [landslides with] falling boulders. “If the earth shakes Later during the same watch,[1442] When this sign is observed A great, rain-filled hurricane will come. “If there is a terrifying earthquake At the end of the [first] watch,[1443] It should be known that a hostile army Of the western king will invade.
thun ni gnyis pa dang po la/ / gal te sa ni 'gul ba byung / / gzhan gyi dmag tshogs nad dang 'chi/ / khong pa'i nad ni mi bzad 'byung / /
“If an earthquake occurs At the beginning of the second watch, There will be death, disease, invasions by foreign armies, And severe stomach disorders.
mkhris pa bad kan las gyur nad/ / skye bo rnams la 'byung bar 'gyur/ / 'byung po rnams ni skyo 'gyur zhing / / de tshe phyogs dang phyogs su 'gro/ /
“Afflicted by the disorders of bile and phlegm, The people will be prone to anger.[1444] Agitated, beings will run From one place to another.

de nas gnyis pa'i thun dkyil du/ / sa ni rab tu 'gul byung na/ / rlung chen 'byung bar shes bya ste/ / shing dang lha khang 'gyel bar 'gyur/ / yang thog ra ba ri rnams kyi/ / rtse mo 'jig par the tshom med/ /
“If an earthquake occurs Halfway through the second watch, A great wind will arise, Breaking trees and destroying temples “And the tall mountain ridges and peaks. There is no doubt.
gnas dang 'dug gnas bzang po dang / / khang pa dang ni rta babs dang / / dud 'gro rnams kyi 'dug gnas kyang / / sa la myur du ltung bar 'gyur/ /
It will destroy the nice monastery buildings And the temples adorned with gateways. It will swiftly knock down the dwellings Of living beings and animals.

de nas mtshan phyed dus dag tu/ / gal te sa ni 'gul ba byung / / de tshe shar phyogs yul gyi bdag / mi mchog gtso bo 'chi ba'am/ / de bu 'chi bar 'gyur ba'am/ / mu ge 'byung bar rab tu ston/ / bar ma'i thun ni bri gyur nas/ / tha mar nye la 'gul ba byung / / sa rnams dag ni ma lus la/ / zhi zhing nad med nges par ston/ / de nas mtshan phyed mthar gyur la/ / gal te sa ni 'gul bar snang / / gsher chen yul gyi dbus dag tu/ / mi yi bdag po nad kyis gnon/ / phan tshun mi mthun gyur nas ni/ / sdug bsngal mi bzad 'chi bar 'gyur/ / thun ni gsum par phyin nas 'gul/ / byis pa rnams la bde ba 'byung / / sbrang bu sha sbrang phye leb dang / / rkun po rnams ni 'jig par 'gyur/ / tho rangs 'gul bar gyur na ni/ / tshe ring nad med lo legs byed/ / grong khyer gyi ni khor yug dag / me yis tshig par shes par bya/ / nyi ma 'char ba'i dus dag tu/ / sa ni rab tu 'gul ba byung / / dbus kyi yul ni thams cad du/ / rkun mas rnam par 'tshe bar 'gyur/ / de tshe zhag ni bdun dag las/ / rgyal po 'chi bar snang ba yin/ /

“If an earthquake occurs At midnight, The chief and most eminent king In the eastern countries will die‍— Either the king himself or his son. Such an earthquake also portends famine. “An earthquake that occurs all over the earth In the last watch of the night, Shortly[1445] after the middle watch, Portends peace and freedom from disease. “If an earthquake occurs Shortly after midnight, The kings of the swampy central regions Will be afflicted with disease. They will die in terrible pain, Fighting one another. “If the earth shakes during the third watch, This portends the well-being of children. Mosquitoes, wasps, and stinging insects, As well as all robbers, will perish. “An earthquake that occurs before dawn Brings long life, good health, and an abundance of food, [But there will also] be fires In the cities everywhere. “If an earthquake occurs When the sun is rising, All central regions Will be infested with bandits. After seven days The king will die.

gang du stobs ni rab che ba/ / sa ni 'gul bar gyur pa yin/ / de tshe gnas ni de dag tu/ / dge dang mi dge'i spyod pa snang / / skar mda' gnam grum sa 'gul ni/ / skar mda' dkar po 'bar gyur na/ / des ni sngar bstan sel bar byed/ / de bzhin dkar mdog rtag tu ni/ / dge zhing rab tu bsngags pa yin/ / mi bzad chen po kha dog dmar/ / me yis tshig par nye bar ston/ / dud ka'i mdog nag nag po ni/ / rgyal po 'chi bar ston pa yin/ / ser ba'am yang na ser skya 'am/ / 'dres pa'i mdog ni snang gyur na/ / de tshe 'dres pa'i las 'gyur ba/ / skar mda' ltung bas rnam par ston/ / gnam grum nyid du bstan pa ni/ / gar byung der ni ston pa ste/ / gal te dbus na de tshe dbus/ / yul nyid du ni rab tu bstan/ / sgra brnyan snyan pa byung na ni/ / bde zhing nad med ston par byed/ / ma rungs mi bzad 'jig rten du/ / rnga sgra yis ni dge ba sbyin/ / 'jigs dang shin tu 'jigs rung sgra/ / der ni mu ge ston pa yin/ /

“Whenever and wherever an earthquake Manifests with great force, At that time and place Good and bad behavior will manifest. “If an earthquake occurs At the same time as a meteorite bursts, The white light of the meteorite Will destroy anything that is crooked or dishonest.[1446] “Thus, white meteorites are always Auspicious and bring what is good. Red ones are very frightening, As they portend conflagrations. “Smoke-colored or black ones Portend the death of the king. Yellow ones, brown ones, Or those of mixed color “Portend the rise in activities Of mixed character. This will happen in the place indicated By the bursting meteorite. “If it [bursts] in the center [of the sky], The central regions are indicated. If the sound produced thereby is pleasant, This indicates prosperity and freedom from disease. “A terrible sound will bring unpleasant things to the world, Whereas a sound like a drum will bring what is good. A sound that is frightening or terrifying Indicates famine.

de la sogs par sbyor ba ni/ / rtag tu gza' rnams 'dod pa yin/ / rgyu skar 'di dag mthong ba la/ / grub pa'i las ni de tshe bya/ / tha skar snar ma nyid dang ni/ / rgyal dang khrums ni stod smad gnyis/ / nam gru dang ni lha mtshams dag / bzlas pa'i dus su rab tu bsngags/ / 'di dag la ni sngags rnams 'grub/ / grub pa'i don yang ster bar byed/ / skar ma dag ni 'di dag la/ / dkyil 'khor nyid kyang bri bar bya/ / gza' yi res kyi gtso bo ni/ / ser dang dkar bar snang ba yin/ / tshes ni 'di dag la dge ste/ / rtag tu zla ba nya ba yin/ / yul gzhan dag tu 'gro byed dang / / dkyil 'khor dag kyang bri bar bya/ /

“Such are always the applications Of planetary forecasts whenever they occur. One should perform rites for success Whenever the nakṣatras are auspicious. “The nakṣatras of Aśvinī, Bharaṇī,[1447] Puṣya, both Bhadrapadās, Revatī, and Anurādhā Are excellent for mantra recitation sessions. In these nakṣatras, the mantras Will be accomplished and will fulfill one’s goal. “The maṇḍala should be drawn In the same nakṣatras with [the same] stars,[1448] When the chief planets of the days of the week Glow either yellow or white. “Also, the lunar day should be auspicious, Such as the fifteenth‍—that is, the day of the full moon. [On that day] one should not[1449] travel abroad, But one may draw the maṇḍala.

dang po gsum pa lnga pa dang / / bcu pa dang ni bdun pa dang / / bcu gsum pa la ci bde bar/ / mi yi bdag po 'gro bar brtag / skye bo kun la dge ba sbyin/ / chas shing 'gro bar rab tu bsngags/ / dkyil 'khor gyi ni sngags rgyud dag / sngags rnams thams cad mi bri'o/ / 'di dag la ni sngags mi 'grub/ / bgegs kyi rgyur ni bstan pa yin/ / 'gro dang sbyin sreg grub pa la/ / tshes grangs gza' ni dam par ldan/ / phur bu pa sangs zla ba dang / / gza' lhag mchog ni las kun la/ / gza' mchog 'di dag rtag tu ni/ / bzhi po tshes dang ldan pa ni/ /

“The kings should plan their journeys For either the first, the third, The fifth, the tenth, the seventh, Or the thirteenth lunar day. Going on a journey on these days is excellent And brings good fortune to all the people. “[On these days], one should not draw the maṇḍala Of any mantra [deities] in the mantra system.[1450] The mantras will not succeed on these [days], And are taught to be the cause of obstacles.[1451] “A pilgrimage for the sake of homa will be successful When the best planets are joined[1452] with the lunar days; Jupiter, Venus, Moon, and Mercury Are superior in all rites. “These four planets are always the best When dwelling in the [right] lunar day.
sa steng 'jig rten kun tu ni/ / 'gro ba'i las ni grub par byed/ / ma rungs 'chi ltas bral ba yi/ / nyi ma la ni brtag par bya/ / yud tsam bcu gnyis kho na ni/ / de yi dus su rab tu sbyar/ /

A pilgrimage made [at that time] Here on earth will be successful. “One should opt for the days That are free from ill omens‍— The days that are free From [the danger of] swift destruction.[1453] “During that period, one should Choose only the following twelve muhūrtas:

dkar dang byams ldan nyid dang ni/ / mig dmar du yang rab tu bstan/ / drag bu dbang chen dag pa dang / / byi bzhin nyid dang legs mdzes dang / / 'khor dang 'khor bar byed pa nyid/ / dge ba sbyin zhes bstan pa yin/ / zla ba mchog ni sbyin pa nyid/ / 'di dag bcu gnyis mtshan nyid yin/ / yud tsam dag tu bstan pa ni/ / nyin zhag sum cu nyid la'o/ /

bcu pa char ni 'bab 'gyur te/ / bcu bzhi pa ni yul 'khor 'jig / brgyad pa bcu gnyis pa nyid dang / / bzhi pa nyid ni spang bar bya/ / myur la sogs pa'i grangs dang ldan/ / mar ngo la ni mtshan mo yin/ / lhag ma bgegs ni byed pa yang / / log 'dren yin te bzhi pa'o/ /

If rain falls on the tenth lunar day, Or the fourteenth, at night,[1457] “During the dark fortnight, at night, One should engage in quick counting,[1458] Avoiding the eighth, the twelfth, And the fourth days. “On these [days], Vināyaka In its four emanations will create obstacles.

'di dag grangs ni ldan pa la/ / dus 'di dag tu rab tu bstan/ / mig ni 'byed dang 'dzums pa dang / / se gol myur ba'i 'gros 'di ni/ / 'di dag dus kyi tshad dag ni/ / rgya cher yang ni bstan par bya/ / se gol brgya yi tshogs dag la/ / rtsa rgyun gcig tu bstan pa yin/ / rtsa rgyun bzhi la chu tshod bstan/ / chu tshod bzhi la thun zhes bya/ / thun bzhi la ni nyin par te/ / mtshan mo dag kyang de bzhin bstan/ / de ltar brgyad dang ldan pa la/ / nyin mtshan du ni rab tu brtags/ / mig gi 'byed 'dzums bcu la ni/ / skad cig tsam du rab tu brtags/ / skad cig bcu zhes bshad pa ni/ / yud tsam du ni yongs su brtags/ / yud tsam bzhi la thun gcig ces/ / sngags rig pas ni yongs su brtags/ / 'di tsam dus kyi tshad la ni/ / gsum gyi grangs su yongs su brtags/ / sbyin sreg dus dang bzlas pa yi/ / grub pa'i dus dang sbyar bar bya/ / nyal ba'i dus dang mi nyal dang / / rtag tu nyin zhag phrugs btungs la/ / nyin dang mtshan ni nyi ma zhes/ / de ltar ming ni 'jug pa yin/ / nyi ma bcwa lnga nyid la ni/ / zla ba phyed du rab tu bstan/ / zla phyed gnyis la zla ba zhes/ / rtsis shes 'jigs pa med pas bstan/ / de bzhin zla ba zla drug gis/ / sgra gcan gyis kyang 'dzin pa yin/ /

Using the count as follows, The following time units are proclaimed. “Unmeṣanimeṣa,[1459] Or acchaṭā, are [the units of time] that pass quickly. I will now elaborate On the measure of time further. “One hundred acchaṭās, or finger snaps, Are said to be one nāḍikā. Four nāḍikās are called ghaṭikā; Four ghaṭikās are known as prahara. “One day or one night Are each said to be four praharas long. Eight of them together Make one unit of day and night. “Ten unmeṣanimeṣas Make one kṣaṇa. The duration of ten tālas Is said to make one kṣaṇa.[1460] “The duration of ten kṣaṇas Is said to make one muhūrta. According to mantra adepts Four muhūrtas make one prahara. “One should observe these time measures At the three junctions of the day,[1461] And apply them accordingly at the time of homa, When seeking accomplishment through recitation “And during the periods of sleep, wakefulness, Bathing, or traveling. The name day (divasa) applies To the period of a single day and night. “Fifteen such days are proclaimed To be one fortnight. Two fortnights are one month‍— So say the fearless ones skilled in calculations. “Then, within six months, Rāhu swallows the moon.[1462]

de nas zla ba bcu gnyis la/ / lo yi sgrar ni rab tu bsgrags/ / de nas lo ni bcu gnyis la/ / lo chen zhes ni de la bya/ / gza' dang rgyu skar phyin ci log / lha min dbang po thams cad kyang / / de nas lo ni bcu gnyis la/ / 'dir ni dge dang mi dge byed/ / gang tshe yar ngor lha min dbang / / sgra gcan rab tu snang 'gyur zhing / / zla ba nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor ni/ / ma lus rab tu zin gyur na/ / mtshon gyi tshogs ni chen po yang / / sa yi steng du snang bar 'gyur/ / de la sogs pa chen po ni/ / dus dang dus su rab sbyor 'gyur/ / rnam pa du ma mang po yi/ / bgegs ni mi bzad snang bar 'gyur/ / dus kyi tha mar phyin pa na/ / 'jig rten snod ni chos min la/ / rgyu skar snrubs la gnas pa la/ / zla ba ma lus 'dzin 'gyur zhing / / mtshan mo ma lus 'dzin pa nyid/ / zla ba 'dzin pa nub bzhin dang / / gal te nyi ma nyin par ni/ / nub bzhin du ni 'dzin 'gyur dang / / nyi ma dang ni zla ba nyid/ / mtshan phyed dag tu gzung gyur nas/ / lha min dbang po'i grib ma yis/ / gal te 'jigs shing nub gyur na/ / shar phyogs gnas pa'i rgyal po ni/ / sdang bas gsod par the tshom med/ /

The period of twelve months Is known as a year. “Then, the period of twelve years Is called a great year. The dānava lords always bring Unfavorable planetary and stellar influences. In the twelfth year, they bring a mixture Of good and bad things in this world. “If Rāhu, the lord of asuras, Can be seen during a single fortnight Completely obscuring both The moon and the sun, A great armed conflict Will be seen on earth. “This and other such [signs] Should always be applied on every occasion. Many different, terrible obstacles Will be experienced “By the nonvirtuous beings When the end of the eon arrives. If the entire moon is swallowed While in the nakṣatra of Mūlā “And sets at night While [still] eclipsed, Or if it sets during daytime While eclipsing the sun;[1463] “If there is an eclipse of the sun Or the moon at midnight; Or if they set frightened By the shadow of the lord of dānavas,[1464] “The evil king who lives in the east Will be killed without a doubt.[1465]

rang nyid 'chi ba'i 'jigs pas sam/ / gzhan gyis de ni gsod par 'gyur/ / kla klo yi ni bdag po nyid/ / shar phyogs su ni gsod par byed/ / o Da'i yul gyi mi rnams dang / / de tshe rdo rje zhes bdag kyang / / gal te tha skar snar ma dang / / de bzhin du ni bra nye dang / / smin drug dag la nyi zla ni/ / gang tshe 'dzin par snang 'gyur na/ / rnam pa sna tshogs bad kan dang / / mkhris pa dang ni rlung gyur dang / / de bzhin 'dres par gyur pa ni/ / gzhan yang lus can kun la 'byung / / byis pa dag ni thams cad la/ / rnam pa du ma'i nad rnams 'byung / / gal te rgyu skar mchu dang ni/ / gre dang de bzhin dbo nyid dang / / me bzhi nag pa sa ri dang / / sa ga dag gi rgyu skar ni/ / de la nyi zla shar ba na/ / 'dzin par the tshom med 'gyur zhing / / nyi zla gnyis ni shar phyogs su/ / sgra gcan gyis ni zin gyur na/ / shar phyogs mi yi bdag po dang / / lA Da yul gyi bdag po dang / / ang+ga ma ga d+hA rgyal po/ / mig gi nad kyis 'debs pa'am/ /

He will be at the risk of death by his own men, Or he will be destroyed by others. “The king of barbarians And his country in the east will be destroyed. So, too, will be the entire population of Oḍra And the king of the Oḍras.[1466] “If the sun or the moon Are seen eclipsed in the nakṣatras Of Aśvinī, Rohiṇī, Bharaṇī, or Kṛttikā, “There will be a proliferation of diseases Caused by phlegm, bile, and wind. Other diseases, caused by combinations of humors, Will also affect embodied beings. “If the eclipse happens in the nakṣatras of Maghā Or the Phalgunī‍—whether the first or the second‍— A proliferation of various diseases Will be observed in all the children‍— “Also, if the eclipse happens in the Hastā, Citrā, Svāti, or the Viśākhās. This will happen without a doubt If the moon or the sun are eclipsed in these nakṣatras. “If the sun or the moon Are eclipsed by Rāhu in the east, The kings of Prācya, Lāḍa, Vaṅga,[1467] Aṅga, and Magadha Will be seized by pain in the eyes.

bu rnams 'chi bar 'gyur ba'am/ / de rnams 'chi bas nyer 'jigs 'gyur/ / dgra rnams sdang ba'i sems ldan pa'i/ / tshogs kyang de tshe 'byung bar 'gyur/ / mgo dang lag dang nab so dang / / de bzhin rgyal dang skag nyid dang / / nyi ma zla ba 'di dag la/ / sgra gcan gyis zin snang gyur na/ / ma ga d+hA rgyal gnod 'gyur zhing / / de bzhin yul mi dag la'ang gnod/ / blon po nad 'jigs shes par bya/ / 'ching dang nyon mongs grong khyer 'gyur/ / lha mtshams dang ni snron dag la/ / sgra gcan gyis zin kun la snang / / de tshe nad rnams kun tu 'gro/ / yul mi kun la'ang nad rnams 'byung / / gsod dang 'ching dang nyon mongs dang / / gnod pa rnam pa du ma 'byung / / 'ching dang gzhan gyi dmag tshogs ni/ / skye bo'i gtso la de dag skye/ / chu stod dang ni gro bzhin dang / / de bzhin chu smad kho na la/ / nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor dbus gnas dang / / zla ba la ni dmar bar snang / / gza' ni 'dzin par snang gyur pa/ / rtag tu mu ge 'byung bar 'gyur/ /

“Or perhaps their sons will die, Or their wives will be in the danger of dying. Or possibly a war will break out With wicked-minded enemies. “If Rāhu is seen eclipsing The sun or the moon while these planets Are in the nakṣatras of Mṛgaśirā, Ārdrā, The Punarvasus, Puṣya, or Āśleṣā, “The king and the population of Magadha Will be oppressed, The ministers will be at risk of falling ill, And the cities will be held captive with the citizens distressed. “If a total eclipse by the lord of the dānavas Is observed in the nakṣatras of Anurādhā or Jyeṣṭhā, This will affect all the population centers With pandemic outbreaks of disease. “This will likewise bring killing, enslavement, And various afflictions that are hard to bear. The bondage and confinement imposed upon the population By prominent people will increase.[1468] “If the disk of the sun is obscured[1469] Or the moon becomes red,[1470] Invariably indicating the coming of Rāhu (graha), In the first Āṣāḍhā, Śravaṇā, Or the second Āṣāḍhā, A famine will follow.

gro bzhin mon gre'i rgyu skar dang / / de bzhin du ni khrums stod dang / / gang tshe mon gru dag la ni/ / gal te nyi zla gzas zin te/ / gza' ni byung bar shes gyur na/ / kha dog nag pa la brten nas/ / mya ngan chen po nyon mongs dang / / mu ge kun tu 'byung bar ni/ / yul mi kun la 'byung ba dang / / rgyal po rkun ma'i 'jigs chen 'byung / / nam gru rgyu skar nyid dang ni/ / gang tshe khrums smad dag la ni/ / zla ba nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor du/ / shar nas sgra gcan 'dzin pa na/ / nub phyogs nas ni nyi ma 'dzin/ / ma ga d+hAr ni mi yi bdag / sems can rgyal po'i thabs nyams par/ / zla phyed gcig gis snang bar 'gyur/ /

“If the moon or the sun is eclipsed In the nakṣatras of Śravaṇā, Dhaniṣṭhā, The first Bhadrapadā, Or Śatabhiṣā, “And it has thus darkened over, One knows that Rāhu (graha) has arrived. This will result in severe suffering And famine everywhere. All human habitations will be At great risk from the king’s thieves.[1471] “If, in the nakṣatras of Revatī Or the second Bhadrapadā, The bright disk of the moon Is swallowed by Rāhu from the east,[1472] Or the disk of the sun, obscured from the west,[1473] Is only partially visible, “Every king and lord of Magadha Will lose his dominion.[1474]

rtag tu sgra gcan 'gro ba yi/ / mtshan ma 'di dag bstan pa yin/ / zla ba nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gyis/ / phyogs ni gang nas zin gyur pa/ / de dang de yi phyogs dag tu/ / dge dang mi dge 'byung bar 'gyur/ / gang nyid sa steng 'gul ba ni/ / 'jig rten mtshan mas bstan pa dag / dge dang mi dge de dang der/ / de bzhin gzas zin shes par bya/ / khug rna ser ba mjug rings ni/ / nyi ma lnga yi bar du yod/ / de 'og 'jig rten sems las 'byung / / ngogs la spyod cing gnas pa yi/ / yul mi thams cad 'jig 'gyur zhing / / nad kyi gzhi ni 'byung ba yin/ /

These are said to be the manifestations Of the coming of Rāhu. “The quarters where the sun Or the moon disk is eclipsed Are the ones where, at that time, Good and bad things will occur. “The earthquakes that occur on earth Are said to be indicated by signs. Based on the color of the eclipse,[1475] there will be The corresponding good and bad occurrences. “A smoky color is the sign Of a rain that will last for five days. Halfway through it, this will become a matter of concern For the people living in Tīrabhukti.[1476] “All the populated places will be destroyed And will become centers of disease.

byang phyogs gang gA'i 'gram gyi ni/ / rgyal po dag kyang 'jig par 'gyur/ / de bzhin kha ba can gyi dbus/ / bgrod dka' khrad khrod la gnas dang / / sa yi bdag po la gnas dang / / kho ra yug na rtse rje dang / / byang phyogs gang gA'i 'gram dag na/ / de tshe 'gram spyod bdag po dag / mya ngan gdung ba du ma yis/ / skye bo'i bdag po de 'ching 'gyur/ / rgyu skar gang la sa 'gul ba/ / de la khug rna yang dag bstan/ / phyogs rnams ma lus khug rna ni/ / mi bzad 'od ni spangs pa dang / / nyin zhag lnga yi bar du yang / / rtag tu nyin zhag mang por ni/ / phan tshun chos ni mi mthong dang / / mi yi spyod yul mthong ba min/ /

The kings who rule on the northern bank Of the Gaṅgā will perish, “And so will the kings who live, Protected all around, in their forts In the impenetrable recesses of the Himalayas, So difficult to access. “The king of Tīrabhukti, On the northern bank of the Gaṅgā, Will also die,[1477] Tormented by grief and tribulations of different kinds. He will perish along with His wives and sons.[1478] “If the nakṣatras, during which the earthquake occurs, Can be described as hazy, Then within five days All the directions will become filled with smoke. Without any rain,[1479] it will be terrible. This will continue for many days without interruption. “People within the range of vision Will not see one another.[1480]

mi rnams dag ni phan tshun du/ / der ni mthong bar 'gyur ma yin/ / der ni 'jig chen 'byung bar shes/ / rgyal po yul 'khor bcas te 'jig / skar mda' 'khor yug dag tu ni/ / gang dag las kyis byung gyur pa/ / phyogs kyi mthar ni rab snang ba/ / gnyis dang gsum ni mi bzad yin/ / mtshan mo dbang po'i gzhu nyid dang / / bya rog gal te 'dab ma dkar/ / dkar ba'am yang na kha dog nag / yang na dkar dang nag par mthong / / phyin log 'dab chags kha dog dang / / phyin ci log gi dus sgra dang / / phyin ci log gi bya rnams yod/ / gang du der ni 'jigs chen 'byung / / rkang gnyis rkang pa bzhi nyid dang / / rkang med dang ni rkang mang dang / / 'dab chags dud 'gro srog chags rnams/ / phyin ci log 'gyur 'jigs chen byung / / khyi ni gyen du gdong bltas te/ / yang dang yang du zugs gyur pa/ / nyin par ram ni mtshan mo ru/ / gang du der ni 'jigs chen 'byung / /

Human vision will not penetrate there To see one another. “There will be great dangers there That will destroy kings and states That have the karma for this.[1481] There will be shooting stars all around, “With terrible double or triple Circles around them. If rainbows appear at night And the wings of crows appear white; “If the color white appears as black And black as white; If the colors of birds and their cries, Particular to the season, are altered; “And if the birds are acting out of character, Wherever this occurs, there will be great dangers there. Also, if the two-legged, four-legged, Legless, and multi-legged beings act out of character, “And if the birds and other animals behave in strange ways, This indicates great danger. If dogs with distended bellies Keep howling again and again, Whether at daytime or nighttime, This indicates great danger.

de ltar rnam pa du ma dang / / rnam mang gang du rab brtags pa/ / der ni char mi 'bab par 'gyur/ / rgyal po'i tshogs kyang rnam par 'jig / ji ltar skye ba'i skar ma ni/ / dge dang mi dge'i srog chags yin/ / de bzhin mtshan ma gang skyes pa/ / dge dang mi dge byed pa yin/ / sngon gyi rgyu ni ma yin pa/ / rgyu mtshan cung zad mi mthong ste/ / rgyu med rab tu 'jug byed pa'i/ / bgegs 'byung ba ni yod ma yin/ /

“In places where many such omens Occur in profusion, There will be a drought And the king will lose his royal wheel. “Whatever the birth horoscope of sentient beings, With its good and bad influences, is said to be, The corresponding omens will occur, Bringing, in this life, good and bad results. “Otherwise, if there is no previous cause, No signs will be perceived. Obstacles never happen without a cause, And they arise according to omens.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ skar ma'i dpyad kyi rgyu mtshan shes pa'i le'u rab 'byam las bcwa brgyad pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed twenty-fourth chapter,[1482] on the astrological knowledge of signs, from “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
yi ge gcig pa 'khor los sgyur ba 'byung ba'i le'u
Chapter 25

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gza' dang rgyu skar dang skar ma dang skar mkhan gyi tshogs rnams la bka' stsal pa/ kye kye gza' dang rgyu skar kyi tshogs rnams khyed cag thams cad nyon cig / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i cho ga'i rgyal po 'di las 'da' bar ma byed cig / sngags dang / rgyud dang / dbang bskur ba dang / dkyil 'khor dang / cho ga rnams dang / bzlas pa dang / nges par sdom pa dang / rig pa sgrub pa la 'jug pa dang / rig pa 'dzin pa rnams kyi cho ga dang / rgyu skar kyi spyod pa dang / rtsis mngon par shes pa rnams kyi cho ga'i rgyal po de la khyed cag rnams kyis der bgegs ma byed cig / bstan pa la rab tu zhugs pa rnams la lha'i tshogs thams cad kyis kyang de la srung bgyis shig / sems can ma rungs pa thams cad kyang dgag par gyis shig / bstan par gyis shig / thams cad kyi thams cad du gsod par ma byed cig / stobs bcu dang ldan pa rnams kyi bstan pa la rnam par gzhag par gyis shig /

Lord Śākyamuni once again addressed the planets, the nakṣatras, the stars, and other celestial bodies: “Please listen, all of you, venerable sirs, the planets and the nakṣatras![1483] This sovereign manual of the divine youth Mañjuśrī, which contains ritual instructions on the empowerment and the maṇḍala according to the mantra system,[1484] should not be transgressed against. You honored celestial bodies should not obstruct the knowledge holders trained in this supreme manual who engage in the practice of recitation, homa,[1485] the observance of rules, and magic. Nor should you hinder the insights gained by the calculations of the behavior (carita) of the asterisms and nakṣatras.[1486] Instead, you and the hosts of gods should all protect those who engage in the instructions thereof. All the wicked beings should be warded off, restrained,[1487] and properly instructed. None of them should be hurt in any way. [Instead,] they should be established in the stages of this doctrine that confers the ten powers.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas sems can thams cad kyi ma rungs pa thams cad bzlog pa'i phyir/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi gtsug tor mngon par 'phags pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ / bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu/ phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams na rnam par bzhugs pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang na bzhugs pa la rnam par blta ba'i phyir nye bar lhags par gyur to/ / bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i sangs rgyas nye bar lhags pa rang rang gi byin gyis brlabs kyis bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la bos te/

Lord Śākyamuni then entered the samādhi called the erect uṣṇīṣa of all the tathāgatas in order to keep away all evildoers from every sentient being. As soon as the blessed Śākyamuni entered this samādhi, all the tathāgatas dwelling in the world spheres in the ten directions clearly saw the blessed Tathāgata Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode and came over to him. They approached with their inconceivable buddha mien, and spoke to the blessed Tathāgata Śākyamuni as follows:

gsungs shig gsungs shig dpa' bo che/ / 'jig rten rnams la'ang phan pa'i phyir/ / sngags rgyud cho ga ji lta bar/ / sngags rnams kun la rab 'jug phyir/ / rig pa'i rgyal po rdzu 'phrul che/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis gsungs pa yi/ / gtso mchog yi ge gcig pa ni/ / dus nyams rtsod pa'i dus dag tu/ / sngags rnams kun gyi rab mchog ni/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis gsungs pa yin/ / gtsug tor rgyal po stobs po che/ / 'byung po kun ni zlog par byed/ / gza' dang rgyu skar ma mo rnams/ / ma rungs sems ldan 'gog par byed/ / 'jig rten bgegs rnams ji snyed dang / / de bzhin gzhan yang gdug sems ldan/ / sems can rnams ni rjes gzung dang / / zlos pa rnams ni bde bya'i phyir/ / bstan pa 'di la cho ga mchog / stobs chen 'khor los sgyur ba yin/ / gtsug tor rgyal po mthu bo che/ / kun la dbang phyug dam pa ni/ / gang gi dus ni 'di yin pa/ / de bzhin gshegs pa khyod kyis gsungs/ / de skad gsungs nas sangs rgyas rnams/ / mi gsung bar ni bzhugs par gyur/ /

“For the good of beings, Please teach, O great hero, The single syllable that can be used instead of[1488] any mantra; Teach it along with its instructions as prescribed. “This vidyārāja of great magical power Was taught by all the buddhas. This single syllable is the best mantra For the time of destruction during the lowest eon. “It was taught by all the buddhas As the best of all mantras, The Uṣṇīṣarāja, the great hero Who wards off all spirits. “It restrains grahas, nakṣatras, The evil minded mātṛs, All the obstacle makers, And whatever other evil beings there are in this world. “He,[1489] the cakravartin of great power, Who confers benefits and happiness On the beings who recite him, Is the most important [mantra] in this entire teaching “He is Uṣṇīṣarāja of great valor, The supreme lord of everything. Teach him to us, O Tathāgata, If the time is now right for this.” Having said this, the buddhas Fell silent and waited.

de nas sangs rgyas 'dus pa de rnams kyis/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du sems can thams cad snod kyi 'jig rten rnams gcig tu 'bar bar gyur la/ sangs rgyas kyis byin gyis brlabs kyis sems can gcig la yang gnod par ma gyur te/ snang ba chen po yang dag par snang bar gyur to/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs te/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de dag dang de na gnas pa'i lha'i bu rnams dang nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang bcom ldan 'das dang 'khor chen po 'dus pa la bka' stsal pa/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams dgongs su gsol/ yi ge gcig pa 'di ni rig pa'i 'khor los sgyur ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi gtsug tor gong nas gong du gnas pa bstan pa thogs pa med pa/ dpag tu med pa'i stobs dang pha rol gnon pa/ bcom ldan 'das gtsug tor gyi rgyal po 'khor los sgyur ba'i cho ga yang ngas bshad par bya'o/ / bstan pa nub pa'i dus su rtsod pa'i dus 'di la bcom ldan 'das gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba de bstan pa 'di la srung ba gcig pur 'gyur zhing dus thams cad du grub par yang 'gro ste/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyi bstan pa nub pa'i dus tshod la 'di nyid sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das yin te/ bstan pa'i don byed par 'gyur ro/ / yi ge gcig po 'di la bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi chos kyi mdzod 'dus par 'gyur ro/ / kye lha'i tshogs dang sems can thams cad nyon cig /

At that time, the entire congregation of the buddhas and all the world spheres within the great trichiliocosm, with all the living beings and inanimate objects there, became bathed in the same light. Through the Buddha’s blessing, not a single being suffered pain, and a great light could be seen. The blessed Śākyamuni, looking at the entire realm of the Pure Abode, the bodhisattva great beings there, the gods, all the śrāvakas, the pratyekabuddhas, and the blessed buddhas congregated in this great gathering, then said: “Pay attention, O blessed buddhas and all the pratyekabuddhas and noble śrāvakas, to this teaching on the ritual of this vidyā cakravartin, the one syllable who resides above the uṣṇīṣas of all the tathāgatas. He is Uṣṇīṣarāja, the blessed cakravartin, the perfect teacher of infinite power and valor. I will teach his ritual again now, during the lowest eon. I will now, at this time in the lowest eon, say again the mantra of that blessed teacher of the triple universe whose instructions are difficult to find, who is honored by all the gods, nāgas, yakṣas, gandharvas, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, and mahoragas, and who fulfills the goal of every activity.[1490] “At the time when the Buddha’s teaching disappears, he‍—the universal blessed cakravartin Uṣṇīṣa‍—becomes the preserver of the teaching. He bestows accomplishments. He, a blessed buddha, fulfills the interests of beings during the entire time when the teachings of all the buddhas have disappeared. He, the blessed one, is the preserver[1491] in whom the entire Dharma basket of all the tathāgatas is condensed. O venerable hosts of gods and all beings! Please listen!

b+h+rUM/ bcom ldan 'di ni thams cad mkhyen/ / sangs rgyas sngags gzugs rnam par gnas/ / ston pa thugs rje che dang ldan/ / sems can kun la rnam par spyod/ / sngags rnams bdag po dpal dang ldan/ / gtsug tor las byung bstan pa yin/ / snying rje dbang la brten nas ni/ / 'di ni yi ge gcig tu gnas/ / chos kyi dbyings la brten nas ni/ / 'di ni sna tshogs gzugs la gnas/ / ji ltar sangs rgyas sku rnams ni/ / skye bo rnams la sku gdung gyur/ / 'jig rten gyis mchod zang zing bcas/ / zang zing med pa'ang khyad par du/ / dam chos sku gdung dag tu bstan/ / 'jig rten zang zing med pa'i rgyu/ / sku ni zang zing bcas par gsungs/ / thub pa'i zla ba zag pa med/ / zang zing bcas dang zang zing med/ / 'jig rten rgyur ni gsungs pa yin/ / chos kyi dbyings la brten nas ni/ / thugs rje'i dbang gis sems can la/ / 'jig rten mgon po 'od byed pa/ / sngags kyi tshul gyis bzhugs pa yin/ / sna tshogs gzugs can thams cad mkhyen/ / sa steng 'di la snang ba yin/ / sems can rnams kyis sngags sgrub pa/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis gsungs pa yin/ / sngags 'di yongs su mdor bsdu na/ / rang gis cho gas 'dir bzlas na/ / sngags rnams ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin/ / rtag tu 'bras bcas byed par 'gyur/ / 'di yi cho ga mdor bsdus nas/ / dus su yang ni bshad par bya/ / dus mthar thub mchog 'jig rten du/ / de bzhin gshegs pa nub pa na/ / de yi dus su cho ga 'grub/ / sngags 'grub par ni gsungs pa yin/ /

“Bhrūṁ. “This syllable is the blessed, all-knowing lord Cast by the buddhas into the form of a mantra. He extends himself to all embodied beings As a most compassionate teacher. “He is the glorious lord of mantras, Honored and celebrated as Uṣṇīṣa.[1492] A receptacle of compassion,[1493] He is merged into and abides as this very syllable. Emanating as the sphere of phenomena,[1494] He abides as all forms. “As the bodies of the buddhas Remain for people in the form of relics, They are worshiped in their material form. The immaterial relics, in particular, “Are those of the true Dharma Taught for the sake of people. The material relics, said to be the bodily remains Of the lordly victors, possess great power.[1495] “The moon-like sages, who are free from karmic influences, Described different types of relics That issue forth, for the benefit of beings, In either material or immaterial form. “Inseparably infused, out of compassion for beings, With the sphere of phenomena,[1496] The sun-like lord of the world Abides in the form of the mantra. “On earth, he is perceived As omnifarious and omniscient. He is the mantra that fulfills all purposes And has been taught by all the buddhas. “This condensed mantra should be recited By oneself according to the instructions. It will accomplish all activities And always bring the desired results. “Its ritual, in its condensed form, Will be taught again at another time, At the end of the eon, when the best of sages, The Tathāgata, has departed. It is said that the ritual and the mantra Will both be accomplished at that time.

de nas bcom ldan 'das 'khor los sgyur ba de bzhin gshegs pa'i gtsug tor gzhan gyi las kyis sbyor ba rnam par 'jig par byed pa/ ma rgyal ba las rgyal ba/ sngags thams cad kyi bdag po/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis don du gnyer ba gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba'i cho ga yi ge gcig pa sngar rgya cher bstan nas/ yang mdor na re zhig dang po bzlas pas gang du gnas pa las/ dpag tshad lnga'i nang nas ma rungs pa'i gdon thams cad 'byer bar 'gyur ro/ / grub pa thams cad kyang nus pa med par 'gyur zhing lha thams cad kyi nus pa dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ / sgrub pa po'i 'dod pa ma gtogs par lha thams cad kyang gnas par mi 'gyur ro/ / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sgrub pa po gzhan rnams kyis grub pa 'phrog par byed cing / gzhan gyi sbyor bas gsang sngags bcad pa dang bcom pa dang phur bus btab pa'ang thar bar byed do/ /

“Now, the ritual of One Syllable,[1497] previously taught at length, will be taught in brief‍—the ritual of the blessed cakravartin, the tathāgata-uṣṇīṣa who frustrates the activities employed by one’s enemies and conquers the unconquerable[1498] ones, the lord of all mantras who is respected by all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, Uṣṇīṣa the cakravartin. “Right from the beginning, in whatever place he is recited,all the evil grahas within the radius of one league will flee; no other mantra, even though it may have been accomplished, is more powerful, and all the gods will depart the vicinity for some other place. He can take away the accomplishments of other practitioners, whether worldly or supramundane, if this were the wish of the practitioner. He can break, destroy, and nail down[1499] the mantras employed by others.

bdag gis gzhan gyi rig sngags gcod par 'dod na/ rtswa ku sha sngon po chang pa gang blangs la/ lan brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags pa byas nas mtshon gyis bcad na/ rig pa gang gi phyir dmigs te bcad pa de gcod par 'gyur ro/ / gzugs brnyan byas te 'dis seng ldeng gi phur pas snying la btab na gnad la bab par 'gyur ro/ / le brgan du btsos pa'i skud pa la lan bdun bzlas brjod byas te/ mdud pa bor na bcing bar 'gyur ro/ / kham phor kha sbyar gyi nang du brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas te kha bkab pa byas na rengs par 'gyur ro/ / mtshon chas snying dum bu gnyis su byas na gnyis su gas par 'gyur ro/ / ske tshe la dug dang khrag gis btags pas bsku ba byas na 'chi bar 'gyur ro/ / ka ra bI ra'i lcug mas kun tu brdeg na gnod par 'gyur ro/ / gzhan gyi rig pa thams cad la mngon spyod bya ba ni ci dgar byar rung ngo / /

“If one wishes to break a vidyā of others,[1500] one should grasp a handful of green kuśa grass, incant it [with the Uṣṇīṣarāja] one hundred and eight times, and, targeting the vidyā, cut the grass with a weapon. The vidyā will be broken. If one makes an effigy[1501] with the same[1502] and nails it through the heart,[1503] the vidyā will be nailed. If one makes a knot on a safflower-red thread incanted seven times,[1504] the vidyā will be bound. If one encloses [the effigy] within an earthenware vessel incanted one hundred and eight times, the vidyā will be arrested. If one slices [the effigy] in two with a weapon through the heart, the vidyā will be broken. If one paints [the effigy], using brown mustard[1505] stained red with poison and blood, the vidyā will be chastised.[1506] If one strikes [the effigy] with a vine of oleander, the vidyā will be afflicted with pain. One can thus assail any vidyā at will in any way whatever.

sngar gsungs pa'i las thams cad la 'o mas khrus byas nas sbyin sreg byas na zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / mar gyi sbyin sreg gis ni thams cad zhi bar 'gyur zhing nyams rtas pa byas par yang 'gyur ro/ / khu tshur bcings pas sngags thams cad rengs par 'gyur ro/ / yid kyis ni dgrol bar bsams pas bkrol bar 'gyur ro/ / sngags sgrub par 'dod pas kyang 'di nyid kyis bcing ba byas te bsgrub par bya'o/ / cho ga gang sgrub par 'dod pas kyang de nyid 'dis bsgrub par bya'o/ sngags sgrub pa dang 'di nyid kyi sngags kyis spyan drang ba bya ba dang yang slar gshegs su gsol ba bya ba yin no/ / gang 'di nyid kyis srung bar byed pa thub par dka' bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Apart from the rites just mentioned, if one performs a homa having bathed in milk, one will attain peace. By offering a homa of ghee, one will bring peace and prosperity to everyone. By making one’s hand into a fist, one can block all mantras. One can then unblock them mentally. If one wants to accomplish a mantra, one can gain mastery of it by first blocking it with the [Uṣṇīṣarāja]. If one wants to accomplish another rite, one can do this with the same [Uṣṇīṣarāja]. With this mantra alone one can summon a deity and also dismiss it. One for whom a protection rite is performed with this mantra will become invincible.

gang gis sngags 'di ma grub bam lan ma thob na 'di nyid dang lhan cig tu bzlas brjod byas na/ myur du 'grub bam lan thob cing / gal te ma grub bam lan ma byin na de ring por mi thogs pa nyid du 'jig par 'gyur ro/ / sngags gang la dmigs te zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis til la btags te brgya rtsa brgyad sbyin sreg dus gsum du zhag bdun byas pa de 'di'i dbang du 'gyur zhing / gang brjod pa de'i las byed par 'gyur ba'am lan thob par 'gyur ro/ / lha dbang du bya bar 'dod na thang shing gi yam shing gi brgya rtsa brgyad sbyin sreg byas na zhag bdun gyis dbang du 'gyur ro/ / klu dbang du bya bar 'dod na mngar gsum gyi sbyin sreg bya'o/ / dri za dang dri za mo thams cad dbang du bya bar 'dod na shing mya ngan med pa dang pri yang ku'i yam shing ngam me tog gi sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

“If any mantra does not produce the intended result or carry out the order,[1507] it should be recited together with the [Uṣṇīṣarāja]. It will then produce results or fulfill the command. If it does not produce the result or carry out the order, it will die.[1508] “One should offer into the fire sesame seeds smeared with curds, honey, and ghee one hundred and eight times, three times a day, for seven days. Then, whatever [deity] mantra one pronounces, that [deity] will come under one’s control. It will carry out whatever task is mentioned and fulfill any command. “If one wishes to enthrall gods, one should offer cedar sticks one thousand and eight[1509] times‍—one will enthrall them within seven nights. If it is nāgas that one wants to enthrall, one should offer into the fire the three sweet substances[1510]‍—the nāgas will become enthralled. If one wants to enthrall yakṣas, one should offer a dish made of curds‍— they will become enthralled. One should [also] offer a curd dish if one wants to enthrall a yakṣiṇī.[1511] One will enthrall gandharvas with [a homa of] ‘all fragrances,’ or with [a homa of] sticks or flowers of the aśoka or the beautyberry tree.

gnod sbyin mo dang klu mo'i gdon rnams la ni ske tshes bya'o/ / rgyal po rnams la ni yungs dkar gyi bya'o/ / bram ze rnams la ni me tog gi sbyin sreg bya'o/ / rje'u rigs la ni zho dang 'o ma dang mar gyi bya'o/ / dmangs rigs la ni phub ma'i rdul gyi bya'o/ / bud med la ni lan tshwa'i sbyin sreg bya'o/ / gdol pa la ni mon sran gre'u dang dzam bu li ka'i sbyin sreg bya'o/ / bu mo gzhon nu ma la ni 'bras yos kyi sbyin sreg bya'o/ / sems can thams cad la ni mar dang til gyi sbyin sreg byas na dbang du byed do/ / thams cad du yang dus gsum du zhag bdun du bya'o zhes

“To enthrall yakṣiṇīs, nāgas,[1512] nāginīs, or grahas, one should use brown mustard. One can enthrall a king with a homa of white mustard; a brahmin, with a homa of flowers; a vaiśya, with a homa of curds, milk, and ghee; a śūdra, with a homa of chaff dust; a woman, with a homa of salt; a harlot, with a homa of beans or jambul; and a virgin, with a homa of parched rice. One can enthrall anyone, in any place, with a homa of ghee and sesame oil offered at the three junctions of the day for seven days.”

gsungs nas/ rgyal ba'i mchog cang mi gsung bar gyur to/ / thub mchog bdun pas sngags 'di ni/ / de tshe lha yi tshogs la gsungs/ / 'jig rten chos shes grol ba dang / / de tshe de ni chags bral zlos/ / de tshe thub pa mchog gis ni/ / sangs rgyas sras po thu bo lha/ / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / 'jam dpal la ni de tshe gsung / / lha yi lha ni blo ldan pa/ / mgon po 'khor lo'i bdag po yi/ / cho ga 'di ni rgya che bas/ / gang gi bskal pa'i tshad du yang / / rgyal bas kyang ni bshad mi nus/ / mi rnams la ni phan pa'i phyir/ / cho ga yi ni phyogs gcig tsam/ / mdor bsdus nas ni bshad pa yin/ / de tshe de skad gsungs nas ni/ / dpal ldan 'jam dbyangs rdzu 'phrul che/ / gtsang ma'i gnas kyi steng bzhugs pa'i/ / sangs rgyas de la skul bar byed/ / gsungs shig gsungs shig dpa' bo che/ / rkang gnyis dam pa rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / dus mtha' 'jigs pa'i dus su ni/ / mi rnams bde ba skyed pa'i phyir/ / mthu chen sngags kyi rgyal po ste/ / gzi brjid chen po 'di yis ni/ / ras ris ji ltar grub par 'gyur/ / myur du ras ris 'grub par gsungs/ /

Having said this, the supreme Victor remained silent. The eminent seventh sage Addressed this to the hosts of gods. Smiling, familiar with worldly matters, liberated, With his mind fully controlled,[1513] The supreme sage then spoke this To Mañjughoṣa, The senior son of the buddhas, A bodhisattva of great power: “I now have taught the extensive Ritual of the wheel holder[1514]‍— The integrated ritual Of the sagacious lord, the god of gods. “The extent of his rites cannot be expressed Even by the victorious ones. I will teach[1515] them further in brief To increase the welfare of human beings.” When this was said, The glorious Mañjughoṣa of great power Supplicated the Buddha, who was staying Above the realm of the Pure Abode: “Please teach! Please do, O most courageous one! You are the perfect buddha, the supreme human being! Teach to bring happiness to humans At the time of destruction at the end of the eon! “What is the most powerful mantra king Of that great hero like? How can the accomplishment of the painting be observed before long? What is the painting procedure?”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ yi ge gcig pa 'khor los sgyur ba 'byung ba'i le'u rab 'byam las bcu dgu pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed twenty-fifth[1516] chapter, on the benefits arising from the cakravartin One Syllable, from “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
yi ge gcig pa'i 'khor los sgyur ba'i las kyi cho ga dang ras ris bstan pa'i le'u
Chapter 26

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal nyon cig / mdor na yi ge gcig pa 'khor los sgyur ba rdzu 'phrul chen po'i ras ris kyi cho gar 'gyur ba rgya che ba ni sngar bstan to/ / de ni dus kyi tha ma'i dus su sems can rnams brtson 'grus chung bar 'gyur zhing / shes rab chung ba dang / yid gzhungs pa dman pa'i phyir ras ris kyi tshad rgya che ba'i sbyor ba sgrub pa nyams par 'gyur bas/

At that time Blessed Śākyamuni, looking again[1517] at the realm of the Pure Abode, addressed Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “Listen, Mañjuśrī, to my short teaching on the painting procedure of One Syllable‍—the cakravartin of great power. This procedure was previously taught at length, but now only briefly.[1518] “During this lowest eon beings have little diligence or wisdom, and are rather dull. They would be unable to successfully execute the painting in its extensive version.[1519]
sems can rnams la phan par 'dod pas zlos pa pos ji ltar dngos grub mchog thob par 'gyur ba de ltar ngas mdor bshad par bya ste/
“Out of my desire to benefit beings I will teach it in a condensed form, So that the reciters [of One Syllable] Accomplish the supreme goal.

sgrub pa mchog byed par 'dod pas ras ma nyams pa kha tshar ma bcad pa skra dang bral ba dag la tshon ma 'dres pa dag gis bcom ldan 'das 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ chos kyi rgyal po chos kyi 'khor lo rab tu bskor ba 'jig rten thams cad kyi bdag po skyes bu dam pa rkang gnyis rnams kyi mchog / de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen tog ces bya ba rgyal ba'i mchog chos 'chad pa kun nas 'bar ba'i 'od kyi dkyil 'khor dang ldan pa'o/ /

“If one wants to perform the supreme[1520] sādhana, one should paint the Blessed One on an undamaged cloth with untrimmed fringes, shorn to remove loose fibers, using uncontaminated paints. [The Blessed One,] the Dharma king who turns the wheels of Dharma, the supreme[1521] lord of all worlds, the best of humans, the most eminent among two-legged beings, the jewel of[1522] a tathāgata, the supreme victor by the name Ratnaketu[1523] should be depicted teaching the Dharma with a halo of light surrounding him.

'og tu ni tshangs pa dang 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje/ steng du ni phreng ba 'dzin pa'i lha'i bu gnyis 'og tu sgrub pa po de'i mdun du dus gsum du a ga ru sreg cing 'bum phrag bcu bzlas pa bya'o/ / de nas las su bya ba ni

“Below [Ratnaketu] are Brahmā and Vajrapāṇi, and above, holding garlands, two gods. Below there is the practitioner. One should recite [One Syllable] in front of the painting at the three junctions of the day while burning agalloch incense, until one has completed one million repetitions. Afterward one may perform the following rites.

dang po 'khor lo'i sgrub pa byed par 'dod na/ lcags bzang po'i rang bzhin las rtsibs bcu gnyis pa'i 'khor lo byas te/ cho 'phrul gyi zla phyed la bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar dus gsum du a ga ru'i dud pas bdug cing 'bum phrag bcu bzlas pa bya'o/ / tha mar zla ba nya ba la mchod pa rgya chen po byas nas lag pas bzung ste/ ji srid rab tu 'bar ba'i bar du bzlas pa bya'o/ / de bzung na rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ / gang gis mthong ba de dang lhan cig nam mkha' la 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The sādhana of the wheel. “First, if one wants to perform this sādhana, one should construct a twelve-spoked wheel out of ‘flower-metal’ and, during the prātihāra bright fortnight, recite the mantra one million times before the Blessed One, while burning an incense of agalloch, at the three junctions of the day. At the final stage during the full moon, one should prepare many offerings and, holding them up in one’s hands, recite the mantra until the wheel blazes with light. By grasping it, one will become a monarch of vidyādharas. One will fly through space together with those of them who see him, or whom he himself sees.

de nas gdugs bsgrub par 'dod na/ gdugs kha dog sna tshogs pa sar pa byas la gser gyi 'khor los mtshan pa ka shi ka'i gos 'phyang ba/ de nyid kyi cho gas mgo la gdugs bzung bar byas te/ bzlas pa byas na rig pa rang nyid nye bar bzhugs par 'gyur ro/ / 'di nyid kyis bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar dus gsum du a ga ru'i dud pas bdugs te/ 'bum phrag bcu bzlas pa byas la/ tha mar zla ba nya ba la mchod pa rgya chen po byas nas lag pas bzung ste/ ji srid du rab tu 'bar ba'i bar du bzlas pa bya'o/ / de thogs na rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ / zla ba re re zhing zla ba nya ba dang cho 'phrul gyi zla ba phyed lnga'i bar gyis 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / 'di grub pa tsam gyis chos thams cad mngon sum du 'gyur ro/ / mngon par shes pa thams cad rab tu thob par 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad mngon par dgyes pa dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis rjes su bsngags pa 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / 'jig rten gyi khams gzhan dag gi 'khor los sgyur ba stong gi g.yog 'khor dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ /

“The sādhana of the parasol. “If one wants to perform this sādhana, one should commission a new, white,[1524] bright parasol marked with a golden wheel and adorned with hanging [strips of] silk.[1525] According to procedure, one should place the parasol above one’s head and recite the mantra. The vidyā will attend upon one of her own accord. One should recite the mantra in this manner one million times before the Blessed One, at the three junctions of the day, while burning agalloch incense. At the final stage during the full moon, one should prepare many offerings and, holding them up in one’s hands, recite the mantra until [the parasol] blazes with light. When taking hold of it, one will become a monarch of vidyādharas. Doing this during the full moon every month, one will succeed within five fortnights, during the prātihāra fortnight. Once this practice is accomplished, all phenomena will become apparent. One will attain all the [five] superknowledges. One will become a siddha praised by all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, and one will be able to adapt to every being.[1526] In the next world, too, one will become a monarch with a retinue of thousands.

de nas gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba bsgrub par 'dod na/ gser dang / dngul dang / zangs ma dang / nor bu'i rang bzhin gyi dbyug pa khru gang tsam byas la ji srid rab tu 'bar ba'i bar du bzlas pa byas nas de blang na nam mkha' la 'gro ste/ thams cad la chos ston par 'gyur ro/ / bskal pa chen por 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The sādhana of Uṣṇīṣa. “If one wants to perform this sādhana, one should make a stick, one cubit long, out of gold, silver, copper, or precious stone. One should then recite the mantra until [the stick] emits light. When one takes hold of it, one will be able to go[1527] wherever one pleases and teach Dharma to sentient beings. One will live one great eon.

ci ste bum pa bzang po bsgrub par 'dod na/ gser gyi bum pa bzang po byas la 'bru thams cad dang rin po che dang sman gyis yongs su bkang la/ ras dkar pos bcings te de la sngags 'dis bsgrub par bya ste/ cho 'phrul gyi zla phyed gcig la brtsams na gnyis pa la 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de la lag pa rab tu bcug na ci 'dod pa de thob cing mi zad par yang 'gyur ro/ /

“The sādhana of the auspicious pot. “If one wants to perform this sādhana, one should make a pot out of gold; fill it completely with all types of seeds, jewels, and herbs; cover it with white cloth; and imbue it with magical power by means of the same [mantra]. If one starts in a prātihāra bright fortnight, one will accomplish the sādhana in the next prātihāra fortnight.[1528] If one places this pot in one’s hand, one will obtain whatever one wishes for. [The wealth] will be inexhaustible.

ji ste nor bu rin po che bsgrub par 'dod na gser gyi dbyug pa'am/ nor bu bzang po dang shel gyi nor bu byas te/ gos 'phyang bar byas la cho ga 'di nyid kyis bsgrubs na gang bsams pa de thams cad 'grub par 'gyur te/ lha dang mi'i nang du thogs pa med cing stobs dang pha rol gnon par 'gyur ro/ / ci ste bcom ldan 'das la bzlas pa bye ba byas na rang gi lus kyis nam mkha' la 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / lha'i lus thob cing bskal pa chen por 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The sādhana of the wish-fulfilling gem. “If one wants to perform this sādhana, one should fashion a jewel out of precious gems, crystal, or gold, with a golden handle,[1529] and attach to it [strips of] cloth. By this method one will succeed. One will accomplish anything one can think of. By taking hold of it, one will be free of impediments and will surpass in power gods and men. If one recites the mantra of the blessed [One Syllable] ten million times, one will be able to levitate. One will obtain the body[1530] of a god and will live for many great eons.

gzhan gang yang gtsug tor gyi rgyal po gdugs dkar po la sogs pa de yang 'dis bcom ldan 'das la 'bum phrag bcu bzlas pa byas na las rnams byed par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar thogs pa med pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i gtsug tor gzhan gyi rtog pa'i cho gas ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar ring po mi thogs par 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po la 'bum phrag bcu bzlas na/ thams cad la 'grub par 'gyur ba rig pa dang sngags thams cad kyi bdag po 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ /

“There are also other chief [uṣṇīṣa kings], starting with Sitātapatra. By incanting [the wish-fulfilling gem] one million times with the mantra of this blessed lord, one will succeed in all the tasks that need to be performed. This inviolable tathāgata-uṣṇīṣa will thus accomplish, before long, whatever he is employed at, even if it involves the rites of other [religions]. “Similarly, one will be able to accomplish anything with one million repetitions of the mantra of the blessed uṣṇīṣa [king] Cakravartin, the lord of all the vidyā mantras.

ji ste rdo rje bsgrub par 'dod na tsan+dan dmar po la rdo rje rtse gcig pa'am yang na lcags bzang po las byas te/ ba'i rnam lngas bkrus la yar gyi ngo'i bcwa lnga la ras ris kyi mdun du mchod pa chen po bya zhing mar gyi mar me brgya sbar la dri'i chus rdo rje bkrus te/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la bdag nyid phul nas/ gtsug tor gyi rgyal po'i 'khor ram gzi brjid phung po'am/ gtsug tor gdugs dkar po'i sngags 'dis bsrung ba byas la/ dkyil 'khor gyi nang du grogs la yang bsrung ba byas nas rdo rje lag pa g.yas pas blangs te/ thun dang po 'das shing thun gnyis pa la nye bar 'dug ste/ sems rtse gcig pas ji srid rab tu 'bar ba'i bar du bzlas pa bya'o/ / skabs 'dir rig pa 'dzin pa lha dang klu dang gnod sbyin thams cad 'dus te/ rig pa 'dzin pa'i rgyal po thams cad kyang 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / de dag rig pa 'dzin pa'i bstod pa byed cing khyim du 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ / lus phyag na rdo rje dang 'dra zhing phyag na rdo rje dang 'dra bar mgyogs pa'i mtshan nyid du 'gyur ro/ / skad cig gis 'og min gyi lha'i gnas su 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / bskal par gnas par 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa byams pa mthong zhing chos nyan par 'gyur ro/ / shi nas gang du 'dod pa der skye bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te phyag na rdo rje'i zhabs drung du yang skye bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The sādhana of the vajra. “If one wants to perform this sādhana, one should make a one-pointed vajra from red sandalwood or ‘flower-metal’ and wipe it with the five products of the cow. Then, on the fifteenth day of the bright fortnight, one should lay out before the painting many offerings, light butter lamps,[1531] and rinse the vajra with scented water. One will thus enthrall the yakṣas.[1532] “Commending oneself to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, one should perform the protection rite for oneself and also for one’s assistants within the confines of the maṇḍala, using the mantra[1533] of Uṣṇīṣarāja with his retinue, or of Tejorāśi or Sitātapatra.[1534] One should take the vajra with one’s right hand and, starting when the first watch of the night has passed and the second set in, recite the mantra with a one-pointed mind until the vajra emits light. As the result, all the vidyādharas, gods, nāgas, and yakṣas will arrive together. All the vidyādhara kings will arrive too. Praised by them, one will ascend to the abode of vidyādharas and will become their emperor. With the body like that of Vajrapāṇi and a power[1535] equal to his, one will be able to ascend, within an instant or a brief moment, to the realm of the Akaniṣṭha gods. Remaining [there] for one great eon, one will behold the noble Lord Maitreya and hear the Dharma. After death, one will be born wherever one wishes to. If so wishing, one will arrive in the presence of Vajrapāṇi.

ci ste ral gri bsgrub par 'dod na skyon med pa'i ral gri blangs nas nyin zhag gcig smyung bar byas te/ bcom ldan 'das la mchod pa rgya chen po byas nas ji srid du rab tu 'bar ba'i bar du bzlas pa bya'o/ / de grub na g.yog 'khor dang bcas pa nam mkha' la 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / skra rna cha gdub kor dang 'dra bar 'khyil ba dang / lo bcu drug pa'i cha byad can dang mi mthun pa'i phyogs med cing / rig pa 'dzin pa thams cad kyis mi tshugs pa dang bar gyi bskal par 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The sādhana of the sword. “If one wants to perform this sādhana, one should take a sword without any defect and, having fasted for one day and one night, offer worship with many offerings to the Blessed One. One should recite the mantra until the sword blazes with light. Having accomplished that, one will fly through space with one’s retinue. With curly hair[1536] and the form of a sixteen-year-old, never discommoding‍—or discommoded by‍—any vidyādhara, one will live among them for one intermediate eon.

ci ste ldong ros bsgrub par 'dod na dpa' bo'i tshong gis nyos te/ rgyal dang ldan pa'i dus su zhag gsum smyung ba byas te/ dge slong bzang po'i dge 'dun la bshos drangs nas bka' lung stsal par bskul lo/ / sgrub pa po la der rjes su gnang nas rang gi gnas su rab tu zhugs te/ mchod pa rgya chen po byas nas mar gyi mar me stong rab tu sbar nas zhag gsum smyung ba byas la/ sems can thams cad la byams pa bskyed nas bdag nyid phul te ldong ros blangs nas/ ji srid grub pa rnam gsum thob pa de srid du bzlas pa byas te/ dro ba dang du ba 'thul ba dang 'bar bas sngar gang bsams pa nyid du grub par 'gyur te/ dro bar gyur pas dpral bar thig le byas na/ lha dang / klu dang / gnod sbyin dang / 'byung po thams cad dang / sha za la sogs pa dang / 'dzam bu'i gling na gnas pa'i sems can bran du 'gyur zhing gang cung zad thams cad sgrub par byed par 'gyur ro/ / lo stong gi bar du 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The sādhana of red arsenic. “If one wants to perform this sādhana, one should purchase some red arsenic in an honorable transaction, fast for three nights when the moon is in the asterism of Puṣya, offer food to the members of the saṅgha, and request their permission. When this has been granted, one should commence the sādhana.[1537] One should give many offerings and light one thousand butter lamps. Having fasted for three nights while giving rise to loving kindness for all beings and commending oneself to the buddhas, one should take hold of the arsenic and recite the mantra until one has attained the threefold accomplishment, namely that the arsenic emits heat, smoke, and flames. Whatever one has previously thought of will be accomplished.[1538] “If, without losing this accomplishment, one places a bindi on one’s forehead while the arsenic is emitting heat, all the gods, nāgas, yakṣas, bhūtas, piśācas, and so forth, and all the beings dwelling in Jambūdvīpa, will become one’s servants attentive to orders. One will live one thousand years.

du ba 'thul ba la ni dpral bar thig le byas na mi snang bar 'gyur te/ gal te 'dod na lha rnams kyis kyang mi mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / skad cig thang cig yud tsam la snang zhing yang mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / mi snang ba thams cad kyi rgyal por 'gyur zhing lo sum stong gi bar du 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / 'bar bas ni rig pa 'dzin par 'gyur te/ g.yog 'khor dang bcas pa nam mkha' la 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / rig pa 'dzin pa'i rgyal por 'gyur te/ lha gzhon nu'i lus su 'gyur zhing lha thams cad kyis kyang mi thul bar 'gyur na/ rig pa 'dzin pa rnams kyis lta smos kyang ci dgos te/ bskal par yang gnas par 'gyur ro/ / dus byas nas dga' ldan gyi lha'i ris su skye bar 'gyur ro/ /
