gzhan yang las su 'gyur ba ni zla ba gzas zin gyi dus su shing pa la sha'i yam shing gis me rab tu sbar te/ mar gyi sreg blugs stong rtsa brgyad byas na tho rangs yul gyi bdag po'i rgyal po spyan drangs par 'gyur ro/ / de dang lhan cig tu gros byas na bsam pa bden pa nye bar ston par 'gyur te/ de la bstan ngag byas na zla ba drug gi nang du bsod snyoms stong yod pa'i grong ster bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te mtshan phyed du sbyin sreg byas na zla ba gsum gyis ster bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te thun thams cad kyi mtshan mo sbyin sreg byas na zla ba gcig gis thob par 'gyur ro/ / gal te zla ba gcig gi mtshan mo re re la sbyin sreg byas na yul thob par 'gyur ro/ / yang na yul dang 'dra ba'i grong ngam yang na gzhan cung zad nor yod pa la yang dgra yod par mi 'gyur te/ gal te dgra yod na yang las rnams byas pa yin te/ zla ba gzas zin pa na shing a pa margas me rab tu sbar la/ shing pa la sha'i yam shing la zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis btags pas bram ze'i skra la sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad bya'o/ / de'i tha mar shing pi tsu marda'i lo ma la ske tshe'i 'bru mar gyis btags pa'i sreg blugs kyis sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad byas na tho rangs bram ze'i dgra zhi bar 'gyur ro/ /

“There is also the following rite. At the time of a lunar eclipse, one should light a fire with sticks of the dhak tree and offer one thousand and eight oblations of ghee. In the morning, the king of the country will accept advice on matters that require consultation. One will be able to point out to him what is right to do.[1654] If one instructs him, he will donate, within six months, a village capable of providing one thousand alms of food. If one does the above homa for half a night, one will obtain the village within three months; if one does the homa throughout all the watches of the night, within one month. If one does the homa every night for one month, one will obtain a district, or a village equal to a district, or another domain with some wealth. One will not have any enemies; should enemies appear, one should do the rite again. “At the time of a lunar eclipse, one should light a fire with sticks of devil’s horsewhip. If one’ enemies[1655] are brahmins, one should offer one thousand and eight oblations of dhak sticks smeared with curds, honey, and ghee, and after that, one thousand and eight oblations of neem tree leaves, smeared with white mustard oil. In the morning the brahmins will be appeased and the king will cease to be hostile.[1656]

gal te rgyal po sdang bar 'gyur na las gzhan yang yod de/ zla ba gzas zin la shing ci rnyed pas me rab tu sbar la mar gyi sreg blugs kyis sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad byas la sbyin sreg gi tha mar phyogs gang na rgyal po yod pa de'i phyogs su thal ba de gtor na de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / dus gang la longs spyod gang 'dod pa rgya che ba de dag gi grogs kyang byed par 'gyur ro/ / grong nyung ba'am mang po rab tu ster bar 'gyur te/ nges par zla ba drug gis don yod par 'grub par yang 'gyur ro/ / de nas rigs bzhi las gang yang rung ba rtags gtso bo dang ldan pa'am lha gzhan nam 'jig rten pa la dad pa dag sems 'khrugs par gyur na/ phyogs gang na gnas pa der thal ba de gtor na yul gzhan du 'gro bar 'gyur ba'am skyo bar 'gyur ba'am mtshan mo glal bar 'gyur ba'am nye du la gnod par 'gyur ro/ / de phyir gso ba ni 'o ma'i sreg blugs stong rtsa brgyad kyis sbyin sreg byas na sos par 'gyur ro/ /

“There is also the following rite. At the time of a lunar eclipse, one should light a fire of whatever sticks are available and offer one thousand and eight oblations of ghee. At the end of the homa, one should throw the ashes in the direction where the king lives; he will become enthralled. He will grant in abundance whatever enjoyments, and at whatever time, one desires, including his [personal] assistance. He will donate a small, medium, or large village or district. Within six months, one will certainly obtain an unfailing (amogha) accomplishment.[1657] “If a member of any of the four castes develops a cruel disposition, then, regardless of whether he is of a degraded or an elevated status, or is a devotee of other deities or worldly beings, if one casts the ashes in the direction where he lives, he will be driven from his home to another country. He will feel uneasy and escape at night, or his family will be destroyed. To undo this, one should offer one thousand and eight oblations of milk; [the target] will become well.[1658]

yang na gza' bzhi po nyid kyi cho gas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa'i sku gzugs dang ras ris sam dam pa'i chos kyi glegs bam mam sku gdung dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la gos gtsang ma bgos shing nyin zhag gcig smyung ba byas te/ srog chags med pa'i chus las bya zhing me tog dkar po dri zhim po dang gur gum dang ldan pa dang ga pur gyi dud pas bdug par bya'o/ / gang du las la sbyar ba ni bram ze'i dgra la ni shing pa la shas bya'o/ / rgyal rigs kyi dgra la ni shing a shwat+thas bya'o/ / rje'u rigs kyi dgra la ni shing seng ldeng gis bya'o/ / dmangs rigs kyi dgra la ni de las gzhan pa'i shing gi me rab tu sbar la de nyid kyi las bya'o/ / bram ze la ni shing pa la sha'i yam shing dang rgyal rigs la ni a shwat+tha'i yam shing dang rje'u rigs la ni seng ldeng gi yam shing dang dmangs rigs la ni a pa marga'i yam shing ngam de las gzhan pa ji snyed pas mar gyi sbyin sreg bya'o/ /

“There is also another rite.[1659] It should be performed during a lunar eclipse following the same procedure,[1660] before a painting depicting the buddhas and the bodhisattvas, before a holy scripture, or before a caitya containing relics, by a practitioner who is clean, wears clean clothes, and has fasted for one day and one night on water free of living organisms. He should fumigate the place [for the rite] with an incense of camphor, fragrant dried[1661] flowers, sandalwood, and saffron. “If the rite is performed on account of enemies who are brahmins, one should light the fire with sticks of the dhak tree; if they are kṣatriyas, with sticks of the bodhi tree; if they are vaiśyas, with sticks of the cutch tree; if they are śūdras, with sticks of some other tree. One should then undertake the rite proper. The sticks to be offered in the homa for the brahmins should be of the dhak tree; those for the kṣatriyas, of the bodhi tree; those for the vaiśyas, of the cutch tree; those for the śūdras, of devil’s horsewhip, or another tree as available. The homa rite should be performed using ghee.[1662]

de bzhin du las gzhan yang bya ba ni/ rgyal po chen po la ni shing a pa ra dzi ta'i rtsa ba'i yam shing dang mar gyi sreg blugs stong rtsa brgyad kyis sbyin sreg bya'o/ / tha mar yang de nyid kyi thal bas gtor bar bya'o/ / gang gi phyogs nas sdang ba'i sems dang ldan pa 'ong ba de'i phyogs su gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba yi ge gcig pa'i phyag rgya bcings nas gtor ro/ / yang na ut+pa la'i phyag rgya bcings na de 'jigs nas ldog pa'am/ dmag gi tshogs nyams par 'gyur ba'am/ gzhan gang cung zad rnam par ltung ba chen por 'gyur ba'am/ 'go ba'i nad chen po'am/ sems sdug bsngal bar gnas pa'am/ gang gis 'di'i ngag ldog par 'gyur ba'am/ 'di dag dang gzhan yang ji ltar 'dod pa'i las rnams byed par 'gyur ro/ / gos la mngon par bsngags te bgos na skal ba bzang por 'gyur ro/ / mig sman la mngon par bsngags te mig la bskus na skye bo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / mig dang gdong la lan bdun bsngags pa byas la khros pa'i gdong la bltas na zhi ba dang dbang du 'gyur ro/ / me tog dang 'bras bu'am gzhan gang cung zad dri zhim pa la lan bdun mngon par bsngags pa byas la rgyal po la byin na de bsnams pa tsam gyis dbang du 'gyur ro/ / gzhan sems can gang la la mthong ba tsam gyis de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / yan lag thams cad na ba la brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bzlas pa byas la/ chu dron pos khrus byas na bde legs su gnas par 'gyur te las 'di rnams ni bya ba yin no/ /

“Similarly, for a homa on account of an important king, one should offer one thousand and eight oblations of the root of butterfly pea and the same number of the oblations of ghee. At the end, one should throw the ashes in the direction where the wicked-minded king lives, or from where he will arrive. One may, in addition, form the mudrā of the one-syllable uṣṇīṣa cakravartin, or the utpala[1663] mudrā. The king will become frightened and will turn back, or his army will fall, or another unexpected calamity will befall him. He may be struck by disease, develop mental problems, or have his words refuted. “There are these and other rites‍—any that one may wish for. If one incants clothes and wears them, one will become very prosperous. If one incants [collyrium] and anoints the eyes, one will be loved by all people. If one incants the eyes and one’s entire face seven times and then looks an angry person in the face, they will become enthralled and peaceful. If one incants seven times a fruit, a flower, or anything with a pleasant smell, and then offers it to the king, he will become enthralled through merely smelling it. Any other being will become enthralled through merely seeing it. If one suffers from pain in any limb, one should wash it with warm water incanted one hundred and eight times; one will become well again.

sems can sdug bsngal ba thams cad dang / mgon med par gyur pa dang / bkren pa dang / bstan pa 'di'i brtul zhugs can dang / dkon mchog gsum la dad pa la ni 'di lta bu'i las mi bya'o/ / bud med la yang las mi bya'o/ / de bzhin du byis pa dang rgan po dang nad pa dang dbul po dang sdug bsngal ba dang sems can phra mo dang skye gnas ngan par skyes pa 'di dag la yang mi bya ste/ las 'di dag ni sems can chen po dag la rab tu sbyar bar bya'o/ /

“These rites[1664] should not target Beings that are afflicted by suffering, Those without a protector, the morally fallen, the weak,[1665] Or those who observe vows in this tradition. “Rites of this kind should not target Those who have faith in the Three Jewels. They should not target women, The young, the old, or those who are sick. “Likewise, they should not target The destitute, the suffering, The insignificant, or those of inferior birth. They should target beings of stature,[1666]

dpa' zhing brkam chags bab chol med/ / phyogs chen nor ni che ba dang / / mngon pa'i nga rgyal rab gtum la/ / las ni 'di 'dra bya ba yin/ / bstan la zhe sdang khro ba dang / / gzhan gyi nor ni 'phrog byed dang / / sngags rnams kun dang sman rnams dang / / rnal 'byor ldan la ma dad dang / /

“Such as warriors, the impetuous,[1667] the greedy, Those with a large following or much wealth, The haughty, or the violent. It is them that such rites should target. “Also, those who hate the teachings; The cruel; those who steal others’ property, Who have no trust in any mantras, Remedies, or yogins;[1668]

spyis brtsan gdug pa'i sems ldan dang / / 'jig rten gyis smad rgyal po ste/ / 'di dag la ni las sbyar bya/ / chos dang ldan la rnam par spang / / las rnams gzhan yang 'di skad brjod/ / blo yis de ni yongs su spang / / de nyid khros pas thal ba ni/ / bzlas pas phyogs su gtor byas na/ / de rnams dgra ni rab khros dang / / rgyal po dag kyang rnam 'jig 'gyur/ / nges par skye bo de dag kyang / / yun ring nad kyis thebs par 'gyur/ / de dag phyogs su 'chi ba mang / / 'go ba'i nad kyang rab tu snang / / shin tu nyon mongs cher gyur kyang / / las rnams 'di dag bya min te/ / der ni skye bo'i bdag po kun/ / zhag bdun gsum gyis nyams par 'gyur/ / las rnams brtsams nas sngon du ni/ / bdun phrag gnyis la yang dag brtul/ /

“And also impudent ones with wicked minds, Or kings despised by the subjects‍— It is them that the rites should target, Not those who are righteous. “The following rite is said to be forbidden By the buddhas[1669] [to target the righteous]. If the reciter casts the ashes,[1670] With an angry mind, in a particular direction, “Any cruel enemies who are there Will perish along with their king. All the people there will inevitably Suffer from a long-term exhaustion, “And terrible, deadly plagues Will be seen in that place. However, one should not perform [such] rites, Lest one also falls into distress. “After three weeks all the people And kings there will perish. Once the rite takes full effect, One should terminate it within fourteen days.[1671]

bdun pa dang pos sems rnams g.yeng / / zhag bdun gnyis pas nad kyis 'debs/ / bdun pa gsum gyis 'chi bar 'gyur/ / de bas de ni yongs su spang / / dang po 'di dag rnam par 'byer/ / gnyis par phyogs su rnam par 'khyam/ / zhag bdun gsum par rnam par 'jig / de bas las 'di bya ba min/ / sems can gdul bya'i don nyid la/ / 'jig rten 'dren pas bstan pa yin/ / sangs rgyas thugs ni dag pa yis/ / gdug pa'i las 'di gsung mi 'gyur/ / srog la gnod par byed pa'i las/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis smad pa yin/ / grub pa mchog ni rab 'dod pa'i/ / zlos pa de dag bya ba min/ / dmyal ba dag tu skye ba'i las/ / 'di dag nyid la rab tu snang / / dkar nag 'bras bur 'byung byed pa/ / 'di dag kho na bstan pa yin/ / las rnams sna tshogs bdag nyid che/ / rkang gnyis mchog gis ji bzhin gzigs/ / rtag tu dkar las dkar ba byung / / nag las nag pa rab tu smin/ /

“In the first [week, the target] will become mentally disturbed; In the second, they will become exhausted; And in the third, they will die‍—that is why One should avoid [continuing the rite beyond the second week]. “In the first week, they will flee, In the second, they wander throughout the country, In the third, they perish‍— One should not perform such rites. “These rites have been designated by the guides of the world To be solely for the purpose of guiding beings, Because the buddhas, having pure minds, Do not resort to violent means. “All the buddhas abhor The rites that obstruct the life force; No reciter should do such rites, If he desires supreme accomplishment. “One indulging in such wantonness Will only see one’s own fall into hell. This has been described as the ripening[1672] Of one’s solely black[1673] karma (the result of solely black rites). “As observed by the most eminent among two-legged beings, The diversity and efficacy of rites (karma) Always makes the arising of virtue possible; Black rites of the [practitioner] can still produce virtuous results.[1674]

'dres las 'dres pa'i las rnams ni/ / 'dres pa dag tu rnam par smin/ / de bzhin las 'di sna tshogs su/ / de nyid sangs rgyas gzigs pa yi/ / thugs rje can gyis gsungs pa'o/ / de las zlos pa spang bya ba/ / nag dang 'dres pa'i las nyid do/ / dge byed dkar po bsten par bya/ / dge ba'i las kyi 'bras bu 'byung / / srog gcod pas ni zlos pa dag / yang dang yang du dmyal bar 'gro/ / de bzhin de las log pa'i chos/ / 'tshe med las ni dam pa yin/ / dge ba'i blos ni sngags rnams dang / / de bzhin mtho ris thar pa 'grub/ / legs byas las kyis thob pa yin/ / 'gal ba'i las kyis 'gal bar gsungs/ / ji ltar chos dang chos min gsungs/ / thams cad mkhyen nyid spyod pa yin/ / zlos pa grub par 'dod pa yis/ / dge ba'i las ni brtsam par bya/ / zlos pa dge la gnas pa la/ / de yi sngags ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / dkar po'i las la gzhol byed la/ / de yi thar pa mi ldog 'gyur/ / sngags kyis dge ba 'grub 'gyur zhes/ / de bzhin gshegs pas rab tu gsungs/ / las rnams sna tshogs gsungs pa ni/ / sgrub pa rnams la bsdus don yin/ /

“Accordingly, the karma is mixed And is taught as such. This is why such a variety of rites Have been taught by those who know reality.[1675] “The reciter should avoid Black or mixed rites (karma), But rely on the auspicious white ones, Which will bring the karmic results of good karma (activities). “Through destroying life, The reciter will end up in hell again and again. Desisting from it, which is the practice of ahiṃsā, Is the supreme activity (karma). “Mastering the mantras Leads to paradise and happy rebirths, Which are obtained through skillful rites (meritorious karma) And blocked by the rites (karma) that are (is) their (its) opposite. “I have explained Dharma and non-Dharma, Differentiated (viceṣṭita) based on omniscient knowledge. If the reciter desires accomplishment, He should always perform virtuous rites (create good karma). “When virtue is present, The mantras of the practitioner will be successful. If he is dedicated to white rites (to accumulating good karma), His liberation is guaranteed. “The tathāgatas proclaim that, for a mantra practitioner, Accomplishment is obtained through virtue. For guiding ordinary beings, though, They teach different types of rites.[1676]

ci 'dod las ni stong phrag brgyad/ / phra mo'i las ni byed pa na/ / sgrub pa po ni mi 'grub ste/ / grub pa mchog ni mi 'thob bo/ / 'bad pas bzlas dang sbyin sreg bya/ / grub pa 'bring ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / cho ga mthong ba'i las kyi ni/ / tha ma myur du 'grub par 'gyur/ / mchog dang tha ma bar ma yi/ / las ni rnam pa gsum du bstan/ / dka' thub can ni zlos mchog gis/ / de bzhin grub pa mchog thob 'gyur/ / de bzhin bzlas pa bar ma yis/ / bar ma las grub thob pa yin/ / de bzhin zlos pa tha mas ni/ / tha ma'i las la yang dag brten/ / grub pa phra mo thob par yang / / gzhan gyi grub pa thob ma yin/ / dus dang tshod dang bzlas pa dang / / sbyin sreg mthong bas de bzhin 'grub/ / mchog gis mchog ni 'grub pa dang / / bar mas bar ma'i grub pa snang / / tha mas tha ma'i las dag la/ / phran tshegs grub pa thob pa yin/ /

“One may accomplish, if one so desires, One thousand and eight rites. Still, if one performs inferior rites,[1677] One will not obtain the highest accomplishment. “By putting effort into the recitation and the homa, One will obtain a middling accomplishment. The inferior accomplishment will be won swiftly If the rite is [simply] performed according to procedure. “The rites (karma) have been taught To be of three types‍—supreme, middling, and inferior. A superior reciter who is an ascetic Will obtain the supreme. “A middling reciter will obtain Success in the middling (will accumulate middling karma). An inferior reciter will always Be limited to inferior rites (accumulating inferior karma). “He will win an inferior accomplishment; He cannot attain any other. The recitation synchronized[1678] with the homa Is again of three types. “Superior accomplishment results from superior recitation, The middling is seen as the result of the middling, And the inferior accomplishment is obtained If the rite (karma) is minor and inferior.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ yi ge gcig pa rtsa ba'i rgyud 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi snying po'i cho ga rab 'byam las/ le'u nyi shu rtsa gcig pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter with instructions on the ritual procedures for the rites of the one-syllable root mantra‍—the heart essence of Noble Mañjuśrī‍—that include the painting,[1679] twenty-seventh[1680] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
le'u nyi shu rtsa gnyis pa
Chapter 28

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal gzhan yang khyod kyi ras ris kyi cho ga sgrub pa'i thabs la las thams cad kyi don sgrub pa nyon cig / 'di nyid kyi yi ge gcig pa'i snying po'i sngags sam yi ge drug po ma'i mtha' can khyod kyi sngar bstan pa'i yi ge drug pa'i snying po'am dang po na o~M yod pa'i yi ge gcig pa'i ras ris dang po 'di nyid kyi cho gar 'gyur ba ni phyi ma'i dus phyi ma'i tshe na/ de bzhin gshegs pa nga yongs su mya ngan las 'das te/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing stongs shing rtsod pa'i dus tha mar phyin pa na 'jig rten skyob pa med pa dang skyabs med pa dang gnas med pa dang / dpung gnyen med pa na/ cho ga'i rgyal po 'di nyid skyob par gyur pa dang / skyabs su gyur pa dang / gnas su gyur pa dang / dpung gnyen du gyur par 'gyur ro/ / dang por re zhig snga ma bzhin du ras ma nyams pa skra shad dang bral ba/ zhag bdun nam zhag bdun gsum gyi bar du thag pas btags pa kha tshar dang bcas pa/ gur gum dang tsan+dan gyi chus bsang gtor byas te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs shing chos 'chad pa/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la gzigs pa bri bar bya'o/ / g.yas phyogs su nor bzang dang 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa dang 'jam dpal yang bcom ldan 'das la phyag 'tshal bar byed pa/ gzhon nu'i gzugs can lus rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa bri bar bya'o/ / g.yon phyogs su kun tu bzang po dang 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug dang bzang skyong dang legs skyes kyang bri bar bya'o/ /

Now the blessed Śākyamuni looked again at the realm of the Pure Abode and said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “There is, Mañjuśrī, in your ritual a painting procedure‍—a sādhana aid that accomplishes all activities. The ritual performed in front of this painting[1681] should employ the aforementioned one-syllable heart mantra, or the six-syllable mantra that ends with ma, or your six-syllable root mantra that starts with oṁ, or the one-syllable mantra.[1682] This king of rites will become the means of protection in the future time, when I, the Tathāgata, am in parinirvāṇa and the buddhafield is empty‍—at the time when the lowest eon has arrived, and the world is without protection or refuge, and with nothing to resort to. This king of rites will then become the refuge, the succor, the place of rest, and the final resort. What is this rite? “To begin, one should draw Blessed Śākyamuni just as before, on an undamaged cloth that is shorn to remove loose fibers, seven cubits long and three cubits across,[1683] with a fringe, and infused with the essence of saffron and sandalwood. He is sitting on a lotus seat and expounding the Dharma, while looking at the divine youth Mañjuśrī. On his right, one should draw Sudhana, Subhūmi,[1684] the noble Akṣayamati, and Mañjuśrī, all of them bowing to the Blessed One. Each of them has the form of a divine youth with limbs adorned with all kinds of jewelry. On his left, one should draw Samantabhadra, the noble Avalokiteśvara, Bhadrapāla, and Suśobhana.[1685]

bcom ldan 'das kyi sku las shin tu chung bar 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug dang nor bzang ni lag na rnga yab thogs par bya'o/ / 'og tu ni sa'i lha mo rin po che'i za ma tog lag na thogs pa/ ro stod sa las byung ba 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / steng du ni rig pa 'dzin pa gzhon nu gnyis phreng ba 'dzin pa sprin gyi nang nas char gtong ba rig pa dang bcas pa bri bar bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyang lag na me tog thogs pa/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhal la rnam par lta ba dang rgyan dang ldan pa/ dang ba'i lta ba dang ro stod bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs la 'dud pa dang bcas pa 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ /

“They should all be painted smaller than the Blessed One. Avalokiteśvara and Sudhana should be painted with yak-tail whisks in their hands. Below the Blessed One, Vasudhā should be drawn with a basketful of jewels in her hand and the upper half of her body emerging from the earth.[1686] Two vidyādhara youths adorned with garlands, and clouds releasing rain and lightning,[1687] should be painted above the Blessed One. All the bodhisattvas hold flowers and jewels and look at the Blessed One’s face.[1688] They should be painted adorned with all types of jewelry, looking peaceful and happy, with the upper half of their bodies inclined in a sitting position.[1689]

de 'di lta bu'i ras ris sku gdung dang ldan pa'i mchod rten gyi drung du nub tu bstan te bzhag la 'jam dpal 'di'i yi ge gcig pa bzlas pa 'bum bya'o/ / shing bzhin du mi smra ba'i dka' thub dang dus gsum du khrus byed pa dang gos lan gsum brje ba dang rtag tu gso sbyong byed pa dang / tshod rngad dang nas chan khyor gang tsam dang 'o ma dang slong mo'i zas kyis 'tsho ba'o/ / zas kyang cha rnam pa bzhir bya ste/ cha gcig ni dkon mchog gsum la'o/ / gnyis pa ni 'jam dpal la'o/ / gsum pa ni sems can thams cad la'o/ / bzhi pa ni bdag nyid nye bar spyad par bya'o/ / mi dub pa'i lus kyis bcom ldan 'das yid la bya ste/ sems can thams cad la dmigs pa'i yid dang bdag nyid kyi don ci yang mi byed cing gzhan sems can thams cad kyi don 'dir bya'o zhes bsgoms nas bzlas pa bya'o/ /

“One should place the painting near to a caitya containing relics and recite the syllable of Mañjuśrī one hundred thousand times while facing west. One should carefully observe the vow of silence, bathe three times a day, use three pieces of clothing,[1690] and continually fast, eating dishes of vegetables and barley and whatever has been obtained as alms.[1691] One should divide the food into four parts and offer one part to the Three Jewels, one part to Mañjuśrī, one part to all beings, and use one part oneself. Not weakened in one’s body, one should visualize the Blessed One and, with the mind focused on all beings, recite the mantra while contemplating, ‘May I never do anything for my own sake, but always for the sake of all beings.’

khrus dang dri dang me tog dang spos dang bshos dang mar me dag kyang dbul bar bya'o/ / khrus ni ras ris kyi grib ma'am gzugs brnyan la bya'o/ / dri ni 'og tu gtor bar bya'o/ / me tog dang bshos kyang rtag tu dbul lo/ / de nyid du 'di dag la sngar mchod par bya ste/ dang po dkon mchog gsum dang / de'i 'og tu byams pa dang / de'i 'og tu spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug dang / 'phags pa kun tu bzang po dang / nam mkha'i snying po dang / 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa dang / zla 'od gzhon nu dang / sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sel ba dang / 'phags pa rdo rje 'dzin dang / 'phags ma sgrol ma dang / 'phags ma rma bya chen mo dang / 'phags ma gzhan gyis mi thub ma dang / bcom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma la dri dang / me tog dang spos dang gtor ma dang mar me 'di dag thams cad la sngar mchod nas phyis ras ris la mchod par bya ste/

“One should offer water for bathing, fragrances, flowers, incense, a bali, and lamps, placing the water in the painting’s shadow, the fragrances below the painting, and the flower and bali articles all around. One should first offer these things to the Three Jewels, then to Maitreya, and immediately after to Avalokiteśvara, Noble Samantabhadra, Noble Ākāśagarbha, Noble Akṣayamati, the divine youth Candraprabha, Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin, Noble Vajradhara, Noble Tārā, Noble Mahāmāyūrī, Noble Aparājitā, and Blessed Prajñāpāramitā. First one should offer all of the fragrances, flowers, incense, and the bali articles[1692] to those [just mentioned], and then to the painting.

de nas phyi rol gyi phyogs 'ga' zhig tu sbrul dang rnga mo dang bong bu dang glang po che dang log 'dren gyi gzugs grog mkhar gyis las byas te de dag gi lhag ma sbyin par bya'o/ / sems kyis dran par bya ba ni til gyi tshigs ma dang gu gul gyi tshigs ma dang til las byas pa'i bza' ba dang rgya sran dang nya dang sha dang skyu ru ra dang bcas pa dang ba ra ta ka'i bza' ba dang pad+ma'i lo ma dang khar ba'i snod rnams kyang yongs su spang bar bya'o/ /

“Afterward, at some place outside, using clay from an anthill, one should make figurines of all the vināyakas in the form of camels, donkeys, dogs, and elephants,[1693] and offer everything to them. One should remember to avoid oil-seed cakes,[1694] cakes made of pounded sesame seeds, horse gram (kulattha), fish, meat, root vegetables, and eggplant. Vessels made of lotus leaves or bell metal should also be avoided.

ku sha'i khres la 'dug cing de nyid du gnas nas/ sangs rgyas rjes su dran pa bsgom par bya ste yid kyis bzlas pa bya'o/ / dben pa'i gnas gzhan du ku sha stan du gding bar bya'o/ / ha cang btung ba mang ba dang ha cang bza' ba mang ba dang ha cang 'gro ba mang ba dang ha cang lta ba dang ha cang nyal ba spang bar bya'o/ / dus gsum du sangs rgyas rjes su dran par bya'o/ / sa bon bsdam par yang bya'o/ / rmi lam bzang po rnams gzhan la rab tu bstan par mi bya ste/ bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar brjod par bya'o/ / de bzhin du mthar gyis ha cang mi myur bar yi ge gcig pa'i bzlas pa 'bum bya'o/ / tha mar yang bcom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma bklag par bya'o/ / bzlas pa'i dus su bcom ldan 'das sam yang na 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i zhal du bltas la/ tshig dang yi ge ma 'khrugs pas bzlas brjod bya zhing bgrang phreng la phyag byas te dbul bar bya'o/ / cho ga 'dis sngon du bsnyen pa byas te/ gang du yid dge ba yod pa'i gnas dag tu ras ris de gzhag par bya'o/ / ras ris kyi cho ga dang po rdzogs so// //

“One should practice the recollection of all the buddhas while sitting and resting on a bundle of kuśa grass. Mantra recitation should be performed mentally. One should prepare a bed in some other secluded place overspread with kuśa grass. One should avoid taking too much food or drink, or going out, seeing people, or sleeping too much. One should thus contemplate the buddhas three times a day and ensure the retention of semen.[1695] One should not disclose one’s auspicious dreams to anyone but offer them instead to the Blessed One. “Proceeding on, one should speedily[1696] recite the One[1697] Syllable one hundred thousand times. At the end, one should read aloud [the text of] the blessed Prajñāpāramitā. At the time of recitation one should look at the face of Blessed One or the divine youth Mañjuśrī[1698] and recite without mixing up the syllables or words. [Each time] one reaches the end of the rosary, one should bow [to them] and offer [oneself to the deity]. Having, in this manner, completed the preliminary practice, one should install the painting in some good place, where one will be able to do the [main] rite in a happy frame of mind.” This concludes the instructions on the painting procedure.

de nas bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal tsan+dan dkar po las byas pa pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa/ bcom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma phyag gcig na 'dzin pa/ phyag g.yas pa na ma du lung ga'i 'bras bu 'dzin pa bya'o/ / de gtsang ba'i phyogs gcig tu nub phyogs su bstan la gzhag par byas la de'i mdun du me thab byas te/ las thams cad la zur bzhi pa mtho do tsam gyi tshad du bya zhing 'og tu 'bru thams cad gzhug par bya'o/ / de nas de'i steng du bya ba ni cho ga 'dis me sar pa bskyed de/ shing a shwat+tha'am mya ngan med kyi yam shing dang mar dang 'bras thug po che'i chan dang 'o ma dang zho dang sbrang rtsi thams cad blangs te/ zangs ma'i snod du gzhag par byas la stong rtsa brgyad yongs su bzlas shing blugs gzar gyis sbyin par bya'o/ /

“Subsequently, one should fashion out of white sandalwood [an effigy of] Blessed Mañjuśrī sitting on a lotus seat, with the text of the blessed Prajñāpāramitā in his left hand and, in his right, a fruit.[1699] One should install the effigy facing west in a secluded, clean place and dig a fire pit in front of it. The pit should be, for all rites, square and two vitastis across. At the bottom, one should place the fragrances and all kinds of grain and make [the fire] above it.[1700] Following this procedure, one should start a new fire, using sticks of the bodhi tree or aśoka tree. One should procure ghee, rice grains, boiled rice, milk, curds, and honey, and place all of it together in a copper bowl. Having incanted it one thousand and eight times, one should perform the complete homa.[1701]
phyi nas nyin zhag gzhan la yar ngo'i tshes nas brtsams te las bya'o/ / shing a shwat+tha'i yam shing gi me rab tu sbar la du ba med par mthong na me spyan drang bar bya ste/

“Later, on another day, starting during the bright fortnight, one should perform the following rite. One should make the fire using bodhi tree sticks and, seeing that the fire is without smoke, one should summon the god of fire:
A gats+tsha ha ri ping+ga la/ dIp+ta dzi hwa lo hi tAk+Sha/ de hi da dA pa ya swA hA/
“Come! Come, O tawny-yellow one! One with a flaming tongue and red eyes! Give, give generously, O tawny-yellow one! Svāhā![1702]
sngags 'dis sreg blugs gsum dbul lo/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa spyan drang bar bya ste/
“With this mantra, one should offer three oblations, and then summon Blessed Mañjuśrī[1703] with the mantra:
A gats+tsha/ A gats+tsha/ ku mA ra b+hU ta sarba satwAr+tha mu d+ya to& haM/ sA hA y+Yekalpa ya/ gan+d+haM d+hU paM tsa pra ti gr-ih+Na swA hA/
“Come, come, O divine youth! Please help me as I strive for the welfare of all beings! Take these fragrances, flowers, and incense! Svāhā![1704]

gang sbyin par byed pa de sngags 'dis sbyin par bya'o/ / byon na mchod yon dri zhim po'i me tog dang chu dbul bar bya ste de nas sbyin sreg bya'o/ / sreg blugs la lan bdun bzlas te lan cig gtor ro/ / de bzhin du nyi ma bdun gyi bar du mar dang 'bras thug po che'i chan gyis tshim par bya'o/ / skabs 'dir nges par 'jam dpal gzhon nu'i gzugs mthong bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Whatever one offers, one should offer with this [mantra]. When the Blessed One arrives, one should present him with a welcome offering consisting of water with fragrant flowers and later perform a homa rite. One should offer only one oblation incanted seven times. In this way, one should gratify him with ghee, rice, sesame, and barley for seven days.[1705] At some point during this period one will certainly see Noble Mañjuśrī in the form of divine youth.

tsan+dan gyi yam shing sor gnyis tsam gyi tshad kyis stong rtsa brgyad byas na rgyal po dbang du 'gyur ro/ / me tog pad+ma la zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis btags nas sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad byas na nor rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / shing shri sha'i me'i yam shing gis me rab tu sbar la til gyi sbyin sreg byas na nor gyi bdag por 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu chus chu la sbyin sreg byas te nang par langs na skye bo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / shing arka'i yam shing dang zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis btags la sbyin sreg 'bum byas na/ gang bsod snyoms stong dang ldan pa thob bo/ / shing ba hu pu tri ka zhes bya bas sbyin sreg byas na bu mo gang 'dod pa de rnyed do/ / shing a pa margas sbyin sreg byas na nad rnams rab tu zhi bar 'gyur ro/ /

“One should offer one thousand and eight oblations of sticks of sandalwood, two fingers long. If one does this every day, one will enthrall one hundred princes.[1706] If one offers one hundred thousand flowers of royal jasmine, one will enthrall a king.[1707] If one offers one thousand[1708] lotuses smeared with curds, honey, and ghee, one will obtain power substances.[1709] If one lights a fire of śamī sticks and offers into it sesame seeds, one will become an owner of great wealth. If one always gets up early and offers oblations of water into water, one will become dear to all the people. If one offers one hundred thousand oblations of sticks of the crown flower plant smeared with curds, honey, and ghee, one will obtain a village [able to provide] one thousand alms rations. If one offers oblations of fenugreek, one will obtain whatever virgin girl one desires. If one offers [sticks of] devil’s horsewhip, one will pacify any pestilence.

'o ma can gyi shing gi me rab tu sbar la til gyi sbyin sreg byas na gang sems par byed pa de thob bo/ / yul 'dod pas pad+ma'i sbyin sreg 'bum byas na yul rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / nang gi sbyin sreg 'bum byas na zas mi zad pa thob par 'gyur ro/ / gu gul dang me tog pri yang ku mar dang lhan cig sbyin sreg bya'o/ / shing arka dang sna ma'i me tog gis chu la sbyin pa byas na zhag bdun gyis grong thob par 'gyur ro/ / sna ma'i me tog gi chu la me tog re re blangs te sbyin pa byas pa dang lhag ma dkyil 'khor la bzhag na/ gang la snom du bcug pa de bsnams pa tsam gyis dbang du 'gyur ro/ / gur gum dang gla rtsi dang li shi'i me tog khar bcug ste/ bzlas pa byas na gang dang lhan cig gtam byed pa de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / na le sham la stong rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags pa byas te khar bcug na khros pa yang tshig gis dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / gtsug pud la 'di nyid kyi sngags kyis bcings na mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / yid la rjes su dran na dgras mthong na yang khro ba med par 'gyur ro/ /

“If one lights a fire with sticks of a tree rich in sap and offers into it one hundred thousand[1710] oblations of sesame, one will obtain whichever girl one wishes for. If one desires sensual pleasures, one should offer one hundred thousand lotuses, and one will obtain them. By offering one hundred thousand oblations of barley,[1711] one’s food supply will become inexhaustible. If one offers oblations of bdellium and beautyberry together with ghee, one will obtain a son.[1712] If one offers royal jasmine flowers into the water where the crown flower plant [grows on] the bank,[1713] one will obtain a village within seven days. If one offers into the water royal jasmine flowers one by one,[1714] one will enthrall any person to whom one gives the remaining fragments to smell‍—the enthrallment will happen through merely smelling them. If one recites the mantra, having put in one’s mouth some saffron, musk, and cloves, the person that one subsequently engages in conversation will become enthralled. “If one puts in one’s mouth some black pepper [seeds], having incanted them one thousand and eight times, one’s words will be endearing even though one may be angry. If one ties these [seeds] into one’s topknot, one will become invisible. If one looks at an enemy and keeps them in mind, the [enemy’s] anger will depart.

rtag tu bzlas pa byas na skye bo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / tho rangs chen po nas langs nas gtsang ba'i phyogs su sna ma'i me tog dang ldan par chu la sbyin pa byas na tshig btsun par 'gyur ba'i blon por 'gyur ro/ / 'jigs pa yang dag par byung bar gyur na yid la byas pas 'jigs pa med par 'gyur ro/ / pha rol khros par gyur pa la yang byams pa bsgoms nas rjes su dran zhing gdong la rnam par bltas na khro ba med par 'gyur ro/ / dri zhim po'i me tog gis sbyin sreg byas na gang gi ched du byas pa de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / tho rangs lan bdun chu la bsngags te 'thungs na nges par myong bar 'gyur ba'i las kyang zad par 'gyur ro/ / lan bdun bsngags pa'i chus gdong rab tu bkrus na skye bo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / me tog la lan bdun bsngags pas gzhan la byin na de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / 'bras thug po ches sbyin sreg 'bum phrag gcig byas na slob dpon nyid du 'gyur ro/ / til gyi sbyin sreg gis ni yul gyi bdag por 'gyur ro/ / pad+ma'i sbyin sreg stong byas na ti na ra stong thob par 'gyur ro/ / gu gul dang sra rtsi pog dang gan da ra sa dang ga pur rnams dpa' bo'i nyo tshong gis nyos nas gcig tu byas la/ sbyin sreg byas te tshes lnga lnga zhing zla ba drug yongs su tshang bar byas na stong 'gyur thob par 'gyur ro/ / dri thams cad pa'i gzugs brnyan byas te mtshon rnon po so gcig pas skyes pa yi ni rkang pa g.yas pa bud med kyi ni rkang pa g.yon pa bcad cing sbyin sreg byas na gang 'dod pa de dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

“If one recites the mantra continually, one will be loved by all people. If one gets up very early and offers water with [the petals of] royal jasmine flowers, [spilling it] onto a clean place on the ground, one will become a minister whose words cannot be challenged. When fear arises, one should bring to mind [the mantra],[1715] and the fear will go away. If one looks at the face of an angry person while engendering and sustaining loving kindness, their anger will depart. “One should offer a homa consisting of all flowers with nice fragrance. Whoever one does this for will become enthralled. If, early in the morning, one drinks water incanted seven times, one will purify the imminent experiences of [ripening] karma. If one washes one’s face with water incanted seven times, one will be loved by all people. Whomever one gives incanted flowers to will become enthralled. “By offering one hundred thousand oblations of [incanted] rice grains, one will become an ācārya. If one does the same with sesame seeds, one will obtain dominion over a district. If one offers one thousand lotuses, one will obtain one thousand dinars. If, on every fifth lunar day, one offers an oblation of bdellium, sarja[1716] resin, myrrh, and pine resin, all obtained in a fair bargain and blended together, one will obtain, when six months have passed, one thousand times more. “One should make an effigy of the desired person out of ‘all fragrances,’ chop up its foot with a sharp, single-bladed weapon, and offer the bits as oblations. If the target is a man, one should chop the right foot; if it is a woman, the left. One will thus enthrall whoever one desires.

zhag bdun la dus gsum du dar du ra ka'i me tog gis sbyin sreg byas na ba rnams thob par 'gyur ro/ / arka'i me tog gis byas na 'bru rnams thob par 'gyur ro/ / shri sha'i me tog gis byas na rta rnams thob par 'gyur ro/ / shing mya ngan med kyis byas na gser thob par 'gyur ro/ / nad 'joms par byed pa'i me tog gis byas na gos rnams thob par 'gyur ro/ / gang dang gang 'dod pa de dang de thams cad ni sna ma'i me tog gi sbyin sreg byas na byed par 'gyur te/ me tog ci 'dra ba'i kha dog gis chu la nyi ma shar ba'i dus su sbyin sreg byas na de dang kha dog 'dra ba'i gos thob par 'gyur ro/ / mig sman la lan bdun bzlas pa byas te/ slong mo la 'gro na slong mo mi zad pa thob bo/ / rmi lam ngan pa mthong nas langs te bdag nyid kyis bzlas pa byas nas yang nyal na rmi lam bzang po mthong bar 'gyur ro/ /

“If one offers oblations of thorn apple flowers for seven days, three times a day, one will obtain cattle. Similarly, if one offers sticks of the crown flower plant, one will obtain grain. With flea tree flowers, one will obtain horses; with aśoka flowers, gold; with vyādhighātaka, clothes. One can obtain anything one desires with oblations of royal jasmine flowers. Whatever are the colors of the flowers that one offers into the water at sunrise, one will obtain clothes of the same colors. If one does alms rounds with a bowl[1717] incanted seven times, one’s supply of alms will never wane. If one gets up at night[1718] and incants one’s own body, one will have auspicious dreams.

de nas rgyal po dbang du byed par 'dod na de'i rkang pa'i rdul rnams blangs te/ yungs kar dang til dang bsres nas zhag bdun la dus gsum du sbyin sreg byed na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / rgyal mo dbang du byed par 'dod na lcam pa'i lo ma dang shud ti dang sman ba ra hi rnams gcig tu byas te/ zhag bdun la dus gsum du sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / blon po dbang du byed par 'dod na go bye dang til dang shu dag rnams kyis gzugs brnyan byas te/ zhag bdun la dus gsum du sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / mdun na 'don dbang du byed par 'dod na spos pra ma tsa ri dang shu ti gcig tu byas te/ zhag bdun la dus gsum du sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

“If one wants to enthrall a king, one should obtain some dust from his feet, mix it with mustard and sesame seeds, and offer this as an oblation for seven days, three times a day. The king will become enthralled. If one wants to enthrall a queen, one should blend together sochal salt, dill, and yams, and offer this as an oblation for seven days, three times a day. She will become enthralled. If one wants to enthrall a royal minister, one should make his effigy out of cashew nut, sesame, and sweet flag, and perform the homa for seven days, three times a day. He will become enthralled. If one wants to enthrall the family priest, one should blend together tubeflower and dill and offer this as an oblation for seven days, three times a day. He will become enthralled.

bram ze rnams dbang du byed par 'dod na ni/ 'o thug mar dang lhan cig pas zhag bdun la dus gsum du sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / de nas rgyal rigs dbang du byed par 'dod na/ 'bras sA lu'i chan mar dang ldan pas zhag bdun la dus gsum du sbyin sreg bya'o/ / rje'u rigs dbang du byed par 'dod na/ nas chan khyor gang bu ram dang ldan pas zhag bdun la dus gsum du sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / til gyi tshigs sam mar gyis sbyin sreg byas na dmangs rigs dbang du 'gyur ro/ / thams cad gcig tu byas te sbyin sreg byas nas bzhi mdo'am khang stong ngam shing gcig pa dag tu gtor ma btang na nad pa de de las rnam par grol bar 'gyur ro/ / gdong la bltas te bzlas pa byas na nad dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ / brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas nas gtsug pud la bcings na nad thams cad las yongs su grol lo/ / nad thams cad la ni skud pa la mdud pa bya zhing gtsug pud bcing ba byas te/ bzlas pa byas na nad thams cad las grol bar 'gyur ro/ / nad kyis btab pa la ni bzlas pa tsam gyis yongs su thar bar 'gyur ro/ / mgul pa'i nad la ni grog mkhar gyi sa la bzlas pa byas te/ 'de gus byug pa byas na nad las grol bar 'gyur ro/ / mig gi nad la ni zar ma'i me tog gi sbyin sreg byas na nye bar zhi bar 'gyur ro/ /

“If one wants to enthrall brahmins, one should offer oblations of milk blended with ghee. All of them will become enthralled. If one wants to enthrall kṣatriyas, one should offer an oblation of rice gruel mixed with ghee for seven days. To enthrall vaiśyas, one should offer barley with sugar. They will become enthralled. If one offers oil-cakes,[1719] śūdras will become enthralled. If one mixes all these ingredients together, all the castes will become enthralled.[1720] “If anyone suffering from exhaustion offers a bali at a road junction or in an empty house, they will be freed from exhaustion. If one recites the mantra while touching[1721] someone’s face, their fever will depart. If one’s knot of hair is incanted one hundred and eight times, one will be freed from all disease. For any disease, one should make a knot on a thread,[1722] tie one’s hair [with it], and go to sleep;[1723] all diseases will depart. When one is ravaged by a disease, one can be freed through mantra recitation alone. When one is seized by a throat obstruction, one should incant some clay from an anthill and apply it as a plaster. The disease will depart. In the case of eye disease, one should offer oblations of nīlīkalikas;[1724] it will go away.”
This concludes the section on the rites that rely on the painting procedure.[1725]

ras ris kyi cho ga'i las gzhan yang sngar bstan pa'i cho gas ras ma nyams pa/ skra med pa la 'phags pa 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ kha dog dmar ba/ gzhon nu'i gzugs can/ pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa/ g.yas ngos su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug / g.yon ngos su kun tu bzang po 'phags pa 'jam dpal las cung zad chung ba/ ras ris de bzhag la bzlas pa bye ba byas na rgyal por 'gyur ro/ / tsan+dan gyi yam shing la gur gum gyis btags pas sbyin sreg 'bum byas na rgyal por 'gyur ro/ / sna ma'i me tog mar gyis btags pas sbyin sreg bye ba byas na rgyal por 'gyur ro/ /

“Following the previously described procedure, one should draw on an undamaged cloth, shorn to remove loose fibers, the divine youth Noble Mañjuśrī. He is fully adorned, red in color, has the form of a divine youth, and sits on a lotus seat. On his right is Noble Avalokiteśvara, and on his left, Samantabhadra. Both of them are a little smaller [than Mañjuśrī]. Having installed this painting, one should recite the mantra ten million times; one will become a king. One will, likewise, become a king if one offers one hundred thousand oblations of sandalwood sticks smeared with saffron. The same will occur if one offers one hundred thousand oblations of agalloch sticks smeared with curds, honey, and ghee.[1726] The same will occur if one offers ten million oblations of royal jasmine flowers smeared with ghee.

gang gi tshad dang ldan pa'i pad+ma'i tshogs kyis sbyin sreg byas pa de'i tshad kyi ti na ra'i tshogs rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / ji srid du bzlas pa de tsam gyi tshad dang ldan pa'i ti na ra ma blangs pa de ni rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ / go bye'i sbyin sreg 'bum byas na ti na ra stong sbyin par byed do/ / nad 'joms par byed pa'i 'bras bus sbyin sreg 'bum byas na nor bdag chen por 'gyur ro/ / gu gul gyi yam shing stong rtsa brgyad kyis sbyin sreg byas na nor dang 'bru rnams thob par 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu til gyis sbyin sreg byas na 'bru rgyun mi chad par rnyed par 'gyur ro/ /

“If one offers into the fire a pile of lotuses, one will obtain a hoard of dinars equal in number to the lotuses in the pile. If one does not obtain them while repeating the mantra over each lotus,[1727] one will become the monarch of the vidyādharas. If one offers one hundred thousand oblations of cashew nuts, this will bring one thousand dinars. If one offers one hundred thousand oblations of vyādhighātaka fruits, one will become an owner of great wealth. By offering one hundred and eight oblations of agalloch sticks, one will obtain grain.[1728] If one continually offers oblations of sesame, one’s supply of grain will, likewise, be unbroken.

ba glang gi lci ba las byung ba'i 'bras thug po che zho dang bcas pas sbyin sreg 'bum byas na ba stong thob par 'gyur ro/ / bo de tse'i 'bras bu dang sho ma'i 'bras bu gcig tu byas te sbyin sreg byas na gang 'dod pa'i bu mo rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / sho ma'i lo mas sbyin sreg byas na 'dod pa thams cad ster bar 'gyur ro/ / zar ma'i me tog la 'o mas btags pas sbyin sreg bya ba ni bram ze dbang du bya ba la'o/ / shing ka ra bI ra'i me tog la shing 'o ma can 'o ma med pas sbyin sreg bya ba ni rgyal rigs dbang du bya ba la'o/ / dong ka'i me tog gis sbyin sreg bya ba ni rgyal po dbang du bya ba la'o/ / d+ha du ra'i me tog gis sbyin sreg bya ba ni dmangs rigs dbang du bya ba la'o/ / shing arka'i me tog la zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis btags pas sbyin sreg 'bum byas na nad thams cad las yongs su grol bar 'gyur ro/ /

“If one offers into the fire one hundred thousand oblations of cow’s rice[1729] mixed with curds, one will obtain one thousand cows. If one offers fenugreek seeds mixed together with śamī fruits, one will obtain whatever virgin girl one desires. If one offers śamī leaves, this will bring all types of pleasure. If one offers flowers of the agati tree[1730] smeared with milk, one will enthrall a brahmin. If one offers flowers of white oleander,[1731] one will enthrall a kṣatriya. If one offers blossoms of the bayur tree, one will enthrall a king. If one offers flowers of the thorn apple, one will enthrall a śūdra. If one offers one hundred thousand oblations of flowers of the crown flower plant smeared with curds, honey, and ghee, one will be freed from all disease.

'di nyid kyi cho gas me tog dri zhim pa la lan 'bum bzlas te/ zhabs kyi drung du bzhag na rtag tu bde bar 'gyur ro/ / shing a shwat+tha'i yam shing gis me rab tu sbar la sha ma'i me tog gis sbyin sreg byas na/ rgyu skar gyi gnod pa nye bar zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / gi wang la sngags mngon par bris te spyi bo la bcings nas g.yul du 'jug na/ mtshon gyis reg par mi 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i ras ris glang po che'i mtshog ma la bzhag ste/ dpung gi tshogs kyi sngon du btang na mthong ba tsam gyis gzhan gyi dpung 'jig par 'gyur ro/ / gzhon nu'i gzugs can gser gyi rma bya'i gdan la bzhugs pa bya ste/ rgyal mtshan gyi rtse mor btags nas g.yul du zhugs na mthong ba nyid kyis gzhan gyi dpung 'jig par 'gyur ro/ / sna ma'i me tog la lan 'bum bzlas te zhabs drung du bzhag la de nyid du ku sha bting ba'i stan byas na rmi lam du 'di la ji ltar 'dod pa ston par 'gyur ro/ / mar me stong la de bzhin du mar me re re la yang pad+ma'i skud pa'i snying po byas te/ shing mngar gyis dkri ba byas la me rab tu sbar nas phul na/ nges par 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa ji lta ba mthong bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Following the same procedure, one should offer one hundred thousand fragrant flowers at the feet;[1732] one will definitely obtain happiness. If one lights a fire using sticks of the bodhi tree and offers one thousand oblations of śamī flowers, one will pacify the problems caused by the nakṣatras. If one goes into battle with the mantra inscribed with bovine bezoar tied to one’s head, one will not be touched by weapons. If one places the Mañjuśrī [mantra] on the shoulders of the elephants in the front line of the army, the enemy army will be crushed through merely seeing it. If one goes into battle, having affixed, at the end of a banner, a figurine of the divine youth sitting on a golden peacock throne,[1733] the enemy army will be crushed through merely seeing it. “One should offer one hundred thousand flowers of royal jasmine at the feet[1734] and go to sleep on a bed of kuśa grass spread at the same spot. In one’s dreams one will be told whatever one wanted [to know].[1735] Having offered one thousand lamps, one should prepare a single lamp with a wick of lotus stalk fibers, wrap it in licorice, light it, and look on; one will behold Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, as he really is.”
ras ris kyi cho ga gnyis pa rdzogs so// //
This concludes the second [group of rites that rely on] the painting procedure.

gser ram dngul las gzhon nu'i gzugs byas te phyag g.yas pa mchog sbyin pa dang / g.yon pa bcom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma'i glegs bam 'dzin pa 'di lta bu sku gdung gi za ma tog mdun du bzhag la yi ge gcig pa'i bzlas pa 'bum bya'o/ / mchod pa rnams ni nyin par bya'o/ / zhabs g.yon pa'i mdun du bu mo la kha zas sbyin par bya'o/ / glu dang rol mo dang glegs bam bklag par yang bya'o/ / bzlas pa yongs su rdzogs pa dang me tog gsum gyis mchod yon gsol te slar gshegs su gsol lo/ / cho ga snga ma bzhin du spyan drang ba dang gshegs su gsol bar bya'o/ /

“One should make a figurine of the divine youth out of gold or silver, with the right hand forming the boon-granting gesture and the left holding a text of the blessed Prajñāpāramitā. Having placed it before a suchlike[1736] basket containing relics, one should recite the one-syllable[1737] mantra one hundred thousand times. One should worship it with offerings during the daytime and feed, in front of the figurine, male and female children.[1738] One should provide song, music, and book reading. When the mantra recitation [of one hundred thousand repetitions] is completed, one should make a farewell offering of the three types of flowers and ask [the deity] to depart. This should be done following the previously described procedure for the summoning and the dismissing.

pad+ma'i phyag rgya bcings nas ni bzlas pa bya'o/ / rgya mtshan gyi phyag rgyas ni spyan drang bar bya'o/ / bkra shis ldan gyi phyag rgyas ni bzhugs su gsol lo/ / gang ba'i phyag rgyas ni mchod yon no/ / rtags gcig pa'i phyag rgyas ni me tog dbul lo/ / yid la re ba'i phyag rgyas ni mar me'o/ / g.yo ba'i phyag rgyas ni spos so/ / rma bya'i gdan gyi phyag rgyas ni dri'o/ / srog shing gi phyag rgyas ni bshos so/ / cho ga 'di nyid kyis mtshan mo dang nyi ma re re zhing ji srid bzlas pa rdzogs kyi bar du bya'o/ / phyi nas ni las rnams bya'o/ /

“One should form the padma[1739] mudrā and recite the mantra. Then, with the banner mudrā, one should do the invoking; with the swastika mudrā,[1740] one should offer the seat; with the complete mudrā, the welcome offering; with the single liṅga mudrā, flowers; with the wishing mudrā, lamps; with the twin mudrā,[1741] incense; with the peacock throne mudrā, fragrances; and with the staff mudrā, a bali. Following this procedure, one should practice day and night, day after day, until the mantra recitation [of one hundred thousand repetitions] is completed. After that, one can commence the rites.

sna ma'i me tog gis rgya mtshor 'gro ba'i chu bo la 'bum gyis gtor na yul thob par 'gyur ro/ / mtshan mo sna ma'i me tog gi tshogs bcom ldan 'das kyi mdun du byas nas nyal na/ bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpas yongs su bskor ba chos 'chad pa mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / gang gi don du byed pa de nyid kyi las bya'o/ /

“If one sets afloat on a river that flows toward the ocean one hundred thousand flowers of royal jasmine, one will obtain a dominion. If one places, at nighttime, a heap of royal jasmine flowers before the Blessed One and goes to sleep there, one will see in one’s dream the Blessed One teaching the Dharma, surrounded by bodhisattvas. One should do this rite only for the intended person and no one else.[1742]

gso sbyong byas shing yar ngo'i tshes nas brtsams te/ ga pur sbrang rtsi dang bsres pa'i spos kyis sbyin sreg byas na rgyal thabs thob par 'gyur ro/ / bzlas pa bye ba byas na 'jam dpal rang nyid mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / chos 'chad par yang mdzad de/ de dang lhan cig smra ba dang mngon sum du snang bar yang 'gyur ro/ / phyir mi ldog pa'i byang chub sems dpar 'gyur ro/ /

“If one offers, while fasting, oblations of pine resin incense mixed with honey, starting during the bright fortnight, one will obtain a kingdom. If one recites the mantra ten million times, one will behold Mañjuśrī in person, and he will teach the Dharma. If one brings [him] up[1743] [in conversation] with someone, he will appear directly. One will become a bodhisattva irreversibly established on the path to buddhahood.”
ras ris kyi cho ga gsum pa rdzogs so// //
This concludes the third group of rites that rely on the painting procedure.

tsan+dan dmar po las byas pa'i gzhon nu'i gzugs can phyogs gcig na gnod sbyin dga' bar byed pa/ phyogs gnyis pa na ni 'phrog ma shing mya ngan med kyi rtsa na 'dug pa de 'dra ba bzhag la/ lan tshwa dang yungs kar dang ske tshe dang bsres pa'i tsan+dan dmar po'i gzugs brnyan byas nas bcad cing bcad cing sbyin sreg byas na gang gi ming bzung ba de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / shing u dum bA ra'i 'bras bus gang gi ming bzung zhing sbyin sreg byas na de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / rgya shug gi 'bras bus sbyin sreg byas na gang gi ming bzung ba de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / khwa dang 'dra ba'i shing u dum bA ras sbyin sreg byas na gang gi ming bzung ba de dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

“One should fashion out of red sandalwood the form of the divine youth flanked by Priyaṅkara on one side and Vīramatī, sheltered by an aśoka tree, on the other. One should place them to one side and make a replica [of them] from red sandalwood mixed with salt, mustard, and brown mustard. One should finely chop [the replica] and offer [the fragments] as oblations. One whose name one recites while making the offering will become enthralled. Similarly, one whose name one recites while offering udumbara fruits will become enthralled.[1744] So too, one whose name one recites while offering kākodumbarikā fruits will become enthralled.

shing sring ga ta gas sbyin sreg bya ba ni bram ze dbang du bya ba la'o/ / pad+ma'i rtsa ba ni rgyal rigs dbang du bya ba la'o/ / ut+pa la'i rtsa bas sbyin sreg bya ba ni dmangs rigs dbang du bya ba la'o/ / lan tshwa dang sha kha ras sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad nyi ma bdun la dus gsum du byas na gang gi ming gis sbyin sreg byas pa de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / nim pa'i lo ma la yungs mar gyis btags pa'i sreg blugs kyi sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad zhag bdun la dus gsum du byas na gang gi ming gis byas pa de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / thams cad kyi sbyin sreg byas na thams cad dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

“If one wants to enthrall a brahmin, one should offer oblations of śṛṅgāṭaka;[1745] if it is a kṣatriya, one should offer lotus roots; if it is a vaiśya, one should offer kaśeruka[1746] roots; if it is a śūdra, one should offer oblations of śālūka.[1747] If one offers one thousand and eight oblations of salt and sugar grains three times a day for seven days, whoever’s name one recites while offering, that person will be enthralled. If one offers one thousand and eight oblations of neem tree leaves smeared with mustard oil three times a day for seven days, whoever’s name one uses while offering, that person will be enthralled. Each of these homa rites will result in enthrallment.

sman bri ha ti'i me tog gis sbyin sreg 'bum byas na gser rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / shing ka lany+dzA ri ka'i me tog la sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad byas na grong chen po thob par 'gyur ro/ / ba ta la'i me tog gis sbyin sreg byas na 'bru mi zad pa thob par 'gyur ro/ / bil ba'i me tog gis sbyin sreg byas na gser rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / shu dag la zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis btags te sbyin sreg byas na rgol ba thams cad la lan 'debs nus par 'gyur ro/ / sman bram hi'i khu bcud mar dang ldan pa zangs ma'i snod du bzhag la/ bzlas pa khri rdzogs pa'i bar du bzlas nas de nas 'thungs na rgol ba thams cad las rnam par rgyal bar 'gyur ro/ / shin tu zhe sdang ba la ni stong rtsa brgyad bong ba la mngon par bsngags te khros pa'i mdun du bor na khro ba med par 'gyur ro/ /

“If one offers into the fire one hundred thousand flowers of yellow-berried nightshade, one will obtain gold. If one offers one thousand and eight kālāñjikā[1748] flowers, one will obtain a large village. If one offers flowers of the trumpet flower tree,[1749] one’s supply of grain will be inexhaustible. If one offer flowers of śrīparṇī,[1750] one will obtain gold. If one offers sweet flag smeared with curds, honey, and ghee, one will have an upper hand in all debates. If one places in a copper dish juice of the brāhmī plant[1751] blended with ghee, incants it ten thousand times, and drinks it, one will be victorious in all debates. If one throws, in front of an angry person, a lump of earth incanted one thousand and eight times, their anger will depart.”
ras ris kyi cho ga bzhi pa rdzogs so// //
This concludes the fourth group of rites that rely on the painting procedure.

ras mnyam pa skra med pa la ri mo mkhan gso sbyong byas pa/ tshon ma 'dres pa dag gis 'phags pa 'jam dpal pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs shing chos 'chad pa 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / g.yon phyogs su 'phags pa 'og pag chen mo/ g.yas phyogs su 'phags pa shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa gzugs can ma rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gos dkar po bgos pa bri bar bya'o/ / de'i 'og tu pad+ma'i mtsho me tog rnam pa sna tshogs kyis khyab pa na klu'i rgyal po gnyis ro stod chu'i nang nas byung ba/ pad+ma'i sdong bu la lag pas 'dzin pa'o/ / 'phags pa gzhan gyis mi thub ma phyogs gcig tu bri bar bya ste/ log 'dren gyi bgegs 'jigs par byed pa/ me 'bar bar mngon par 'byin pa/ spyan khro gnyer can du byas pa/ phyogs gzhan du ri khrod ma lo ma gyon pa/ zhags pa dang dgra sta lag na thogs pa/ kha dog nag pa/ mig dmar ba/ rma bya'i rgyab tu zhon pa/ sgrub pa po la srung bar byed pa bri bar bya'o/ / sgrub pa po yang pad+ma'i phreng ba lag na thogs shing / bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal gyi zhal la rnam par blta bar bya'o/ / steng du ni rnga yab dang me tog gi phreng ba dang rnga 'dzin pa'i lha'i bu rnams bri bar bya'o/ /

“One should commission a painter to paint, while observing the ritual fast, on an undamaged, shorn[1752] cloth and using uncontaminated paints, Noble Mañjuśrī sitting on a lotus seat and teaching the Dharma. On his right is Noble Mahāmekhalā, and on his left, Noble Prajñāpāramitā. The latter is reciting mantras, is adorned in all types of adornments, and is dressed in white clothes. Below Noble Mañjuśrī, there is a lotus lake dotted with many different species of lotus, where two nāga kings, their bodies submerged, hold lotus stalks in their hands.[1753] “Noble Aparājitā, to one side, is destroying vināyakas and obstructers. Her mouth[1754] is blazing with fire and her brow is knitted. On the other side there is Noble Parṇaśavarī. She is dark, with red eyes, and she holds a noose and an axe in her hands. Mounted upon a peacock, she is the practitioner’s protectress. The practitioner, for his part, should be painted holding a garland of lotuses in his hands and looking at the face of Noble Mañjuśrī. Above Noble Mañjuśrī two gods should be painted, holding in their hands yak-tail whisks, flower garlands, and drums.

ras ris de nub tu bstan te bzhag la sku gdung dang bcas pa'i mchod rten gyi mdun du bzlas pa bye ba bya'o/ / bzlas pa'i mtha' mar me'i mchod pa chen po bya zhing / bcom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma bklags la bzlas pa stong phrag bcu 'jam dpal gzhon nu'i zhal la lta zhing bzlas pa bya'o/ / de nas ras ris 'gul bar gyur na rgyal srid thob par 'gyur ro/ / lha'i mig thob cing rig pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ / 'khor los sgyur ba chen por yang 'gyur ro/ / bzlas shing bzlas na byang chub sems dpa'i sa dang po thob par 'gyur ro/ / 'di'i chos ston pa yang thob par 'gyur ro/ /

“One should install this painting facing west in a caitya containing relics and recite the mantra ten million times. At the end of the recitation, one should offer a large pūjā,[1755] have the Prajñāpāramitā read aloud, and recite the mantra ten thousand times while looking at Mañjuśrī’s face. The painting will subsequently shake. One will obtain a kingdom and the divine[1756] eye. One will become a vidyādhara and will laugh,[1757] will become a wheel turner, and will teach. One will attain the first bodhisattva level and will listen to Mañjuśrī’s Dharma teachings.

ras ris de nyid kyi mdun du ba ser mo be'u yod pa'i mar khu blangs la zangs ma'i snod du bzhag nas ji srid du dro bar 'gyur ba dang du ba 'thul bar 'gyur ba dang rab tu 'bar bar 'gyur ba de srid du bzlas pa byas na/ dro bar gyur pa na 'thungs na ni mchog tu yid gzhungs pa dang thos pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ / du ba 'thul ba na 'thungs na ni mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / rab tu 'bar ba na 'thungs na ni nam mkha' la 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / kham phor so ma btang ba kha sbyar la shu dag sna ma'i me tog gis dkris pa bzhag la/ ji srid myu gu 'byung ba de'i bar du bzlas brjod bya ste de zos na thos pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ / bzlas brjod gzhan bye ba byas na 'jam dpal mngon sum du mthong zhing chos ston pa yang thos la de la dad par yang 'gyur ro/ /

“One should, in front of the same painting, obtain ghee from a tawny cow that has given birth to a calf of the same color, place it in a copper bowl, and recite the mantra until the ghee becomes hot, then emits smoke, and then bursts into flames. If one drinks it when it becomes hot, one will become supremely intelligent with the power to remember [everything heard]; if one drinks it when it emits smoke, one will become invisible; if one drinks it when it bursts into flames, one will be able to walk on air. One should place the ghee inside a bowl of unbaked clay with a lid, wrap the bowl in sweet flag and royal jasmine flowers, and recite the mantra until sprouts appear. If one eats the sprouts, one will be able to retain in one’s memory [everything heard]. If one recites the mantra another ten million times, one will behold Mañjuśrī in person, hear his Dharma teachings, and have faith in them.

gser gyi pad+ma 'dab ma brgyar bya ste/ pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs te/ ji srid 'bar gyi bar du bzlas pa byas na de blangs pa tsam gyis rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ / gzhan gyis mi thub par 'gyur ro/ / ldong ros sam ba bla'am lig bu mig gam bil ba'i lo ma chu la bcug ste ji srid khu la khu la zhes bya ba'i sgra byed pa de srid du bzlas na/ de blangs pa tsam gyis sa la spyod pa'i srin po dang sha za rnams kyi bdag po dang mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ /

“One should make a hundred-petaled lotus out of gold, place one’s right knee on the ground, and recite the mantra until the lotus emits flames. Through merely holding it, one will become the monarch of the vidyādharas, unassailable by others. One should put some red arsenic, yellow orpiment, or collyrium in a box make of śrīparṇī[1758] wood and recite the mantra until the substance makes a crackling sound. Through merely holding it, one will become an invincible[1759] master of the rākṣasas and piśācas who roam the earth.

mtshan nyid dang ldan pa rma med cing ma 'dres pa'i ral gri blangs la ji srid sbrul gyi gdengs ka bzhin du byas te/ 'dug pa de srid du bzlas pa byas la de nas de blangs na rig pa 'dzin pa'i 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur ro/ / bskal par tshe gnas pa dang gzhan gyis mi thub par 'gyur ro/ / ldos ros lcags gsum gyis dkri ba byas te khar bcug la ji srid tsu lu tsu lu'i sgra byung ba de srid du bzlas pa byas na thub pa med par 'gyur ro/ / dgra thams cad 'joms par byed par 'gyur ro/ / rigs thams cad dbang du byed de 'dod pa dbang du byed pa ni ma gtogs so/ / shing sha mi las skyes pa'i shing a shwat+tha'i snying po blangs la/ lcags gsum gyis dkri ba byas nas khar rab tu bcug na ji srid tsu lu tsu lu'i sgra 'byung ba de srid du bzlas pa byas na mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / lo stong du 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ /

“One should take an undamaged sword with all the characteristics of good quality and recite the mantra until the sword acquires a hood like a snake. By holding the sword, one will become an unassailable emperor of vidyādharas and live for an eon. One should wrap some red arsenic in the three metals,[1760] place it in one’s mouth, and recite the mantra until it makes a gurgling sound. One will become an invisible sword bearer.[1761] Unseen, one will be able to pursue all kinds of virtuous quests, except for the hedonistic ones. One should obtain some pith from a bodhi tree that grows on[1762] a śamī tree, wrap it in the three metals, place it in the mouth, and recite the mantra until it makes a gurgling sound. One will become invincible[1763] and will live one thousand years.

dngul gyi 'khor lo byas te lha ma yin gyi khung bu'i sgor bzhag la/ ji srid du 'khor los lha ma yin gyi 'khrul 'khor bcad nas rab tu 'jug pa de'i bar du bzlas pa byas na de'i mod la lha ma yin gyi na chung rnams byung nas/ de dang lhan cig rab tu zhugs nas bskal par gnas par 'gyur ro/ / lcags las byas pa'i mdung rtse gsum byas te/ khung bu de dag gi sgor bzlas pa byed na/ der 'khrul 'khor thams cad 'jig par 'gyur zhing / ji snyed sgrub pa'i grogs mchog dang lhan cig 'dod pa de snyed dang lhan cig rab tu 'jug cing bskal par gnas par 'gyur ro/ / byams pa yang bzhugs shing de mthong bar yang 'gyur ro/ /

“One should place a silver wheel in front of an asura opening[1764] and recite the mantra until the wheel has breached the [locking] devices set by the asuras and enters there. At that very moment, asura girls will emerge. If one enters their place with them, one will live one eon. One should place an iron trident at the opening of that passage and recite the mantra there. All the locking devices in there will break up. One will be able to enter with the girls that one desires[1765] and live there for one eon. One will behold Blessed Maitreya.”[1766]
ras ris kyi cho ga lnga pa'o// //
This concludes the fifth group of rites that rely on the painting procedure.

shing arka dkar po las mthe bo tsam gyi bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal byas la/ shing arka'i me tog 'bum phul na blon po chen po thob par 'gyur ro/ / shing ka ra bI ra dkar po'i rtsa ba las mthe bo tsam byas te/ 'di nyid kyi me tog bye ba gcig phul na bka' la gtogs par 'gyur ro/ / shing ka ra hA Ta las mtho gang gi tshad tsam du byas la de'i me tog 'bum phul na dmag dpon thob par 'gyur ro/ / tsan+dan dkar po las mtho phyed tsam gyi bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal byas la sna ma'i me tog 'bum phul na mdun na 'don thob par 'gyur ro/ / shing a shwat+tha las sor gcig tsam gyi tshad du byas la/ rnyog pa med pa'i chus bum pa bkang ba phul na skye bo mang pos bkur bar 'gyur ro/ / dri thams cad las byas la me tog thams cad phul na gang 'dod pa de thob par 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu yul ma ga d+hA'i yam shing ma nyams pas sbyin sreg byas na blon po skye bo mang pos bkur bar 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu bzlas pa byas na mtshams med pa lnga yang 'byang bar 'gyur ro/ / shi ba'i dus su yang 'jam dpal gyi zhal mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / 'di la chos ston par yang mdzad do/ /

“One should commission [a figurine of] Noble Mañjuśrī, the size of a thumb, made from the white crown flower plant. If one offers to it one hundred thousand flowers of the crown flower plant, one will obtain a vassal kingdom. If [the figurine] is made from the root of white oleander, one thumb in size, and one offers to it ten million flowers of the same plant, one will become a minister. If the figurine is made of karahāṭa wood, one vitasti in size, and one offers to it one hundred thousand flowers of the same tree, one will become the general of an army. If the figurine of Noble Mañjuśrī is made of white sandalwood, one vitasti in size, and one offers to it one hundred thousand flowers of royal jasmine, one will become a family priest. “One should commission a figurine of Noble Mañjuśrī made from the wood of the bodhi tree, one finger in size. If one offers to it a jar of unsullied[1767] water, one will be highly esteemed by many people. If the figurine is made of ‘all fragrances,’ one will obtain, by offering to it flowers of all the fragrances, whatever one desires. If a practitioner of mantra continually offers oblations of agalloch sticks, he will be highly esteemed by many people.[1768] By reciting continually he will purify even the five karmas of immediate retribution; he will see Mañjuśrī at the time of death; and he will propagate Mañjuśrī’s teachings.

langs shing langs shing brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas na sems can thams cad kyis mi thub par 'gyur ro/ / mig la yongs su bzlas na bdag po mthong zhing bka' drin stsol bar 'gyur ro/ / gang gi ched du las byas pa nyin zhag bdun gyis de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / grong gzhan du gnas pa la ni zhag nyi shu rtsa gcig gis so/ / yul gzhan la gnas pa la ni zla ba gnyis so/ / gzhon nu'i bdag po'i cho gas yin gyi/ / sngags gzhan gyi cho gas ma yin na/ las ma lus par byed par 'gyur ro/ / 'dod pa dang mngon spyod dbang du byed pa ni ma gtogs so/ /

“If one recites the mantra one hundred and eight times every time one rises up [in the morning], one will be unassailable by any being. If one looks at the master, having incanted one’s eyes, he will become kindly disposed. Whoever one targets with the rite will be affected within seven days if they are in the same locality;[1769] if they are in another village, within twenty-one days; if they are in another province, after four[1770] months; if they are in a river, after six months.[1771] One may thus accomplish every activity, except for the pleasure-oriented or violent, using the procedure particular to one’s own lineage, and not other mantra [lineages].”[1772]
cho ga drug pa 'di bstan pa/ /
This concludes the sixth group of rites that rely on the painting procedure.

dus kyi mtha' la sems can rnams/ / bsod nams chung la phan don du/ / thub pas sngon ni bstan pa yin/ / shAkya seng ge skyob pa yi/ / bstan pa nub par gyur pa na/ / dus ni mi bzad 'jigs pa na/ / de tshe grub par 'gyur ba yin/ / cho ga'i rgyal po bde byed pa/ / bdun pa 'dir ni bshad par bya/ / de tshe dus ni mi bzad la/ / cho ga 'di ni nga yis bshad/ / sems can bsod nams chung ba la/ / lam ni 'di dag rab tu bstan/ / byang chub tshogs kyi rgyu don du/ / theg gsum lam la rab tu gzhol/ / de yi dus su sems can la/ / thabs la mkhas pa bstan pa yin/ / sred pas rmongs pa'i sems can dang / / 'dod chags zhe sdang gis 'khrugs pa/ / srid pa mthar ni gtug bya'i phyir/ / de dag la bstan lam 'di yin/ / sred pa'i 'ching bas bcings pa la/ / dge ba'am dge ba'i las kyi rgyur/ / grub dang sgrub dang de bzhin rdzas/ / sngags dang rgyud ni nga yis bstan/ / sgrub pa zlos pa rnams la 'dir/ / cho ga'i rgyal po bdag nyid che/ / sems can rnams ni gdul don du/ / 'jig rten 'dren pa rnams kyis gsungs/ /

“This bliss-granting king of manuals[1773] Is said to be of benefit at the end of the eon. It was formerly taught by the Sage For beings with little merit. “It will bring accomplishments At that terrible and dreadful time When the teaching of the Teacher, The majestic Lion of the Śākyas, has disappeared. “Now the seventh procedure will be taught In this king of manuals that brings happiness. This ritual procedure of mine is taught For that terrible time. “This method is intended especially For beings with little merit. It is the root cause for the accumulations[1774] that lead to awakening; It is oriented toward the path of the three vehicles. “During this period, I teach beings The skill in means, As they will be stupefied by craving And confused by desire and hatred. “I teach this method for those Who are controlled by the power of craving[1775]‍— The method that is the cause of good karma For those bound by the fetters of craving. “The accomplishment, that which is to be accomplished, And the power substances arise based on the mantra methods‍—[1776] They are taught by the guides of the world For those beings who require guidance. These rites possess great efficacy [When performed by] practitioners who recite mantras.”[1777]

shAkya seng ge mi yi mchog / thub pa mchog gis de gsungs nas/ / de tshe dus kyi tha ma la/ / grub pa don yod bstan pa dang / / sngags dang rgyud kyi stobs dang ni/ / brtson 'grus rgya che ldan bstan nas/ / de tshe gnas gtsang lha tshogs la/ / rgyal ba mchog gis gsungs pa ni/ / cho ga'i rgyal po rgya che ba/ / 'jig rten kun la phan pa'i phyir/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis bstan pa la/ / grogs po de ni nga yis bstan/ /

This was spoken by the eminent Sage, The Lion of the Śākyas, the supreme being. Having thus taught at length about The power and efficacy of the mantra system, He then explained the accomplishment[1778] That never fails during this debased eon. The supreme Victor then said to the hosts of gods In the realm of the Pure Abode: “Whatever, friends, was taught at length[1779] In this king of manuals Constitutes the instructions of Mañjughoṣa Intended for the benefit of the world.

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ cho ga'i bya ba 'jam dpal gyi cho ga rab 'byam las/ le'u nyi shu rtsa gnyis pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter that belongs to the section on the ritual procedures of Noble Mañjuśrī, twenty-eighth[1780] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
'jam dpal gyi ras ris kyi cho ga'i le'u
Chapter 29

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal khyod kyi las kyi cho ga'i le'u las ras ris kyi cho ga bdun pa yod de/ gang gis dus kyi mtha' ma de la bsgrub par gyur na de la don yod par 'grub par 'gyur te/ 'bras bu dang bcas pa bde ba 'byung ba/ bde bar rnam par smin pa/ mthong ba'i chos la myong bar 'gyur ba/ ngan song thams cad las zlog par byed pa/ nges par byang chub la gzhol bar byed pa 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i snying po gsungs pa ni/ yi ge drug pa 'gro ba drug las grol bar byed pa'i bdag nyid bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ mi mnyam pa/ zla med pa/ rdzu 'phrul che ba/ srid pa'i rgya mtsho thams cad dang sdug bsngal gsum gyi sdug bsngal las grol bar byed pa/ 'byung po thams cad kyis bzod par dka' ba/

At that time the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, as follows: “There is, Mañjuśrī, in this division of your ritual prescriptions, a seventh [set of] rites involving a painting that will be effective at the end of the [dark] eon and will without fail lead to accomplishment. This accomplishment will include the arising and maturing of happiness, the knowledge of the physical world, and the forestalling of all painful destinies, and it will certainly lead to awakening.” The blessed Śākyamuni then taught the heart mantra of Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “It contains six syllables whose nature is to liberate from the six destinies; It has an inconceivable, unequaled, and immeasurably great power; It liberates from the ocean of all the oceans of existence, From the misery of the three sufferings, and from the fetters that bind one to existence.

'jig rten thams cad kyis ma gos pa/ 'byung po thams cad kyis mi thub pa/ sred pa'i las thams cad rnam par sbyong bar byed pa/ sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams thob par byed pa/ ma rungs pa thams cad zlog par byed pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis rjes su yi rang bar mdzad pa/ phun sum tshogs pa thams cad byed pa/ 'jam dpal gyi bstan pa la sngags thams cad kyi mchog de gang zhe na/

“It can touch all the worlds[1781] And no spirit can withstand it. It purifies the paths of [cyclic] existence, Invincible to all spirits. “It brings about the qualities of buddhahood And wards off all evil beings. All the buddhas rejoice in it, As it produces every good fortune. It is the most eminent among all the mantras Included in the teachings of Mañjuśrī. “What is this mantra? It is:
o~M bA kye da~M na maH/
“Oṁ vākyeda namaḥ!

'di'i cho gar 'gyur ba ni/ tshod rngad dam/ nas chan khyor gang ngam/ slong mo'i zas kyis 'tsho la/ dus gsum du khrus byed cing gos lan gsum brje bas yi ge 'bum byas na sngar bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / kha tshar gyi rtse mo ma bcad pa'i ras la ri mo mkhan gso sbyong byas pas/ tshon ma 'dres pa dag gis 'phags pa 'jam dpal pad+ma'i gdan la chos 'chad cing bzhugs pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gzhon nu'i gzugs su 'dug pa bla gos phrag par gzar ba 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ /

“Now its ritual will be taught.
