Living on a diet of solid and liquid dishes of vegetables or barley, bathing and changing clothes thrice a day, one should recite the mantra one hundred thousand times. This constitutes the preliminary practice. Then, one should commission a painter who is fasting to paint Noble Mañjuśrī on an undamaged cloth with fringed edges, using uncontaminated paints. He sits on a lotus seat and teaches the Dharma in the form of a divine youth, adorned with all the ornaments, with his upper robe over one shoulder.[1782]

g.yon du 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug phyag na pad+ma bsnams pa/ g.yas su ni 'phags pa kun tu bzang po/ / steng du ni rig pa 'dzin pa gnyis phreng ba thogs shing sprin gyi nang nas byung ba bri bar bya'o/ / 'og tu ni sgrub pa po lag na spos snod thogs pa'o/ / khor yug tu ni ri'i rtse mo'i 'og tu ni pad+ma'i mtsho 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ /

“To his left there is Noble Avalokiteśvara with a lotus and a yak-tail whisk[1783] in his hands,[1784] and to his right, Noble Samantabhadra. Above [Mañjuśrī], two vidyādharas should be drawn emerging from the clouds and holding garlands. Below [Mañjuśrī] should be drawn the practitioner, holding an incense holder in his hand. Mountain peaks should be drawn all around, and below, a lotus lake.

sku gdung dang bcas pa'i mchod rten dang ras ris nub tu bstan te rab tu bzhag la mchod pa rgya chen po byas nas mar gyi mar me yang rab tu sbar zhing sna ma'i me tog la re re la yang mngon par bzlas nas me tog stong rtsa brgyad 'jam dpal gyi zhal la gtor ro/ / de nas zab pa chen po'i yi ge hU~M gi sgra thos pa'am ras ris rab tu 'gul bar 'gyur ro/ / yi ge hU~M gi sgras ni sa kun la dbang ba'i rgyal por 'gyur ro/ / ras ris 'gul bas ni rgol ba thams cad la lan 'debs nus pa dang / 'jig rten pa thams cad kyi bstan bcos shes par 'gyur ro/ / ci ste ma grub kyang las thams cad la nus pa dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ /

“One should install this painting, facing west, in a caitya containing relics, offer a large pūjā, light butter lamps, and cast one thousand and eight flowers of royal jasmine at Mañjuśrī’s face, one at a time, incanting each of them with the mantra. Subsequently, a loud and deep sound of hūṁ will be heard, or the painting will shake. If the sound is heard, one will become a king over the entire earth; if the painting shakes, one will excel among all speakers and will become an adept of all worldly treatises. If one does not succeed [in this], one will become proficient in all rites.”[1785]
'di ni cho ga dang po'o/ /
This concludes the first rite.

a ga ru'i yam shing sor phyed dang gnyis kyi tshad la/ tu ruSh+ka'i thang chus sil ha ras btags pas seng ldeng gi mdag ma du ba med pa la mtshan thog thag tu sbyin sreg byas na/ skya rengs 'char ba tsam na 'phags pa 'jam dpal mthong bar 'gyur zhing / de ci 'dod pa'i mchog stsol bar 'gyur te/ 'dod pa dbang du bya ba ni ma gtogs so/ / de nyid kyi ras ris kyi mdun du tsan+dan gyi spos kyi rgyun chad pa med par mtshan thog thag tu bdugs te/ bzlas pa byas na de'i 'og tu 'phags pa 'jam dpal mngon sum du gshegs te zab mo'i chos ston pa de la mos par 'gyur ro/ / mos nas kyang nad thams cad las rnam par grol bar 'gyur/ dbang thob par 'gyur/ byang chub sems dpa'i sa rjes su thob par 'gyur ro/ /

“One should offer oblations, throughout the entire night, of agalloch sticks smeared with mustard oil, more than half a finger long, onto the smokeless embers of cutch firewood. At sunrise, one will behold Noble Mañjuśrī, who will grant whatever boon one desires, except for hedonistic ones. “One should recite the mantra all night, while burning sandalwood incense in front of the painting without interruption. Subsequently, Blessed Mañjuśrī will arrive in person and give profound Dharma teachings. One should apply oneself to them with confidence. By doing so, one will be free from all disease and able to fully exercise one’s own will.[1786]

tsan+dan dmar po las byas pa'i pad+ma rtsa lag dang bcas pa sor drug tsam tsan+dan dmar po'i 'de gus bskus nas/ lan stong bsngags shing dgang gzar gyis lan stong blug pa byas la/ zla ba nya la ras ris kyi mdun du pad+ma'i snod bzhag la lag pas bzung nas ji srid rab tu 'bar ba de srid du bzlas pa byas na/ de bzung bas lo bcu drug gi na tshod dang mdog gser btso ma 'dra ba dang nyi ma bas lhag pa'i gzi brjid dang ldan pa dang lha gzhon nu lta bur 'gyur ba dang rig pa 'dzin pa thams cad kyis phyag byas pa dang bskal pa chen por 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / lus zhig nas mngon par dga' bar skye bar 'gyur ro/ /

“One should make a lotus flower out of red sandalwood, six fingers in circumference, complete with a stem, and wipe it with red sandalwood paste. One should then incant the residue of one thousand such oblations one thousand times.[1787] Then, during the full moon, one should place it on a lotus leaf[1788] and hold it up in one’s hands in front of the painting. One should recite the mantra until the substance emits light. By taking hold of it, one will obtain the form of a sixteen-year-old divine youth, the color of molten gold, exceeding in splendor the sun itself. One will be honored by all the vidyādharas and will live one great eon. After death, one will be reborn in Abhirati.

zla ba gzas zin pa la shu dag dkar po blangs la ba'i rnam lngas bkrus te/ shing a shwat+tha'i lo mas bkab pa byas la ji srid drod dang du ba 'thul ba dang 'bar ba de srid kyi bar du bzlas pa byas na/ dro ba byung bas ni skye bo thams cad dbang du 'gyur ba dang rgol ba thams cad las rgyal bar 'gyur ro/ / du ba 'thul bas ni mi snang ba dang stong phrag sum cur 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / 'bar bas ni nam mkha' la 'gro ba dang bskal pa chen por 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / ba ser skya'i be'u dang bcas pa'i mar khu blangs la/ zangs ma'i snod du shing a shwat+tha'i lo ma bdun gyis bkab ste bzhag la/ ji srid grub pa rnam gsum thob pa de srid kyi bar du bzlas pa byas la de 'thungs na thos pa 'dzin pa dang mi snang bar 'gyur ba dang nam mkha' la 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / sman pu skar mU la'i sa bon zla ba gzas zin pa la khar bcug na ji srid du tsu lu tsu lu zhes bya ba'i sgra 'byung ba de srid du bzlas pa byas la/ sman de phyung nas lcags gsum gyis yongs su dkri ba byas la yang khar rab tu bcug na mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / sman de skyugs na ni snang bar 'gyur ro/ /

“During a lunar eclipse, one should get some white sweet flag, wipe it with the five products of a cow, stuff some pipal leaves underneath it, and recite the mantra until the sweet flag gets hot, then emits smoke, and then bursts into flames. If it gets hot, one will be able[1789] to enthrall all people and outmatch all speakers. If it emits smoke, one will become invisible and live thirty thousand years. If it bursts into flames, one will be able to walk on air and will live for one great eon. “One should obtain some ghee from a tawny cow that has given birth to a calf of the same color, place it in a copper bowl stuffed with seven pipal leaves, and recite the mantra until the triple effect occurs [of the ghee becoming hot, emitting smoke, and bursting into flames]. After drinking it, one will be able to, [respectively], retain in one’s memory everything that one has heard, become invisible, and walk on air. “During a lunar eclipse, one should place some puṣkara seeds in one’s mouth and recite the mantra until the seeds make a bubbling sound. If one places them in the mouth wrapped in the three metals, one will become invisible.[1790] One will become visible again after spitting them out.

li shi dri zhim po khar bcug la bzlas pa 'bum byas na gang dang smra ba de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / 'o ma dang nas chan khyor gang za zhing bzlas pa 'bum phrag bcu gnyis byas na rig pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ / slong mo'i zas kyis 'tsho la shing bzhin du mi smra ba'i dka' thub byed cing bzlas pa 'bum byed na mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / bzlas pa bya ba byas na ji ltar srid pa tha ma pa'i byang chub sems dpa' 'phags pa 'jam dpal chos ston pa de bzhin du 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu bzlas pa byas na don thams cad 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / gang gi gzugs brnyan dri thams cad pas byas la bcad cing sbyin sreg byas na zhag bdun gyis dbang du 'gyur ro/ / gu gul gyi ril bu rgya shug gi tshig gu'i tshad tsam la mar gyis btags pas brgya phrag stong gi sbyin sreg byas na rgyal po dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

“One should place in one’s mouth some fragrant cloves and recite the mantra six hundred thousand[1791] times. Whoever one speaks to will become enthralled. If one recites the mantra one million two hundred thousand times[1792] while subsisting on dishes of milk and barley, one will become a vidyādhara. If one recites the mantra one hundred thousand times while living on alms and observing a strict vow of silence, one will become invisible. If one recites the mantra ten million times, one will receive Dharma teachings from Noble Mañjuśrī [himself] so that one becomes a bodhisattva who sojourns on earth for the last time. If one recites continually, all one’s aims will be accomplished. “The target whose effigy, made of ‘all fragrances,’ one chops up and offers the fragments of as oblations will become enthralled after seven nights. If one offers one hundred thousand oblations of bdellium pills, the size of a kernel of the jujube[1793] fruit, smeared with ghee, one will obtain one hundred thousand dinars.[1794]
til la zho dang mar gyis btags pas sbyin sreg 'bum phrag stong byas na thams cad kyi dam pa'i khyim gyi bdag po chen por 'gyur ro/ /

“One should descend to a river that empties into the ocean and offer one hundred thousand lotuses. One will obtain a great treasure equal in size to the heap [of the offered] lotuses. This treasure will never become exhausted. If one offers into the fire one thousand and eight oblations of white mustard seeds smeared with saffron [paste], one will enthrall a king. If one offers one hundred thousand oblations of sesame seeds smeared with curds, honey, and ghee, one will become a great householder who gives everything away.[1795]

ba'i lci ba sa la ma lhung bas dkyil 'khor byas la/ de la me tog gis gcal du bkram ste/ bzlas pa brgya rtsa brgyad byas la de nas dam pa'i chos kyi glegs bam bklag par byas na/ zla ba gcig gis mchog tu yid gzhungs par 'gyur ro/ / gi wang la brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas te dpral bar thig le byas na skye bo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / gtsug pud la lan bdun bzlas pa byas na sems can thams cad kyi gnod pa med par 'gyur ro/ / me tog gi ri ma las sbyin sreg 'bum byas na nad thams cad las grol bar 'gyur ro/ / nyin re zhing bzlas pa bdun bdun byas na nges par myong bar 'gyur ba'i las rnams zad par 'gyur ro/ / bzlas pa brgya rtsa brgyad byas na 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi zhal thams cad mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / le'u bdun pa'i ras ris kyi cho ga'o// //

“One should draw a circle with uncontaminated cow dung, bestrew it with flowers, and recite the mantra one hundred and eight times. If one subsequently reads aloud a genuine Dharma text, one will become supremely intelligent within one month. If one incants bovine bezoar one hundred and eight times and applies it as a bindi, one will be loved by all the people. If one incants [one’s] topknot seven times, one will become invulnerable to assault by any being. “If one offers ten thousand[1796] oblations of kiri[1797] garlands, one will become free from all disease. If one recites the mantra seven times every day, one will purify the karma that would otherwise be inevitably experienced. If one recites the mantra one hundred and eight times at the time of death, one will behold the complete [form of] Noble Mañjuśrī face to face. This concludes the seventh [set of] rites [that employ] the painting.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las 'jam dpal gyi ras ris kyi cho ga'i le'u rab 'byam las/ nyi shu rtsa gsum pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter with the seventh[1798] [set of] rites in the section on the ritual procedures that employ the painting of Noble Mañjuśrī, twenty-ninth[1799] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
zhing dang dus kyi cho ga nges pa'i le'u
Chapter 30

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal khyod kyi sngags dang rgyud dang rig pa'i rgyal po dang 'khor los sgyur ba la sogs pa dang de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi gtsug tor la sogs pa dang sngags thams cad kyi grub pa'i gnas yod de/ de yang mdor na byang phyogs su de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi rig pa'i rgyal po 'grub par 'gyur te/

At that time, the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, as follows: “There is, Mañjuśrī, in your mantra treatise, a list of places for accomplishing any vidyārāja mantra, starting with the mantra of Cakravartin‍—the foremost among all tathāgata-uṣṇīṣas.[1800] In brief, everywhere in the northern regions, the mantras of tathāgata-[1801]vidyārājas will become accomplished.

rgya dang rgya ni che nyid la/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni rab 'grub 'gyur/ / gang yang de yi sngags rnams ni/ / der ni rab tu 'grub par 'gyur/ / gtsug tor rgyal po thams cad dang / / de dag tu ni grub par snang / / kA bi she dang bag kha la/ / o Ti ya ni 'khor yug yul/ / kha che dang ni sin d+hu'i yul/ / kha ba can gyi mtshams kun dang / / byang phyogs su ni gnas brten la/ / dge ba'i sngags ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / gang yang sangs rgyas sngon gsungs dang / / da ltar yang ni gsungs pa dang / / ma 'ongs sangs rgyas rnams kyis kyang / / zhi ba'i rgyur ni gsungs pa ste/ / kha ba can ri'i nang byung ba/ / der ni thams cad 'grub par 'gyur/ / skye bo skal ldan bzang po ni/ / zhi ba'i las ni rtsom par byed/ / de bzhin sngags ni yul dbus su/ / pad+ma'i rigs ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / mdzod dang nor bu'i rigs dag kyang / / der ni 'grub par rab tu snang / /

“In Tibet and in China, Mañjughoṣa will be accomplished. The mantras that are his Will be successful there. “[The mantras] of uṣṇīṣa kings Will be successful there in every respect. In Kāviśa, Vakhala, Everywhere in Uḍḍiyāṇa, “In Kaśmīra, Sindhudeśa, At the foot of the Himalayas‍— In these northern countries, The mantras that are virtuous are effective. “The mantras that are said to effect pacifying, Whether those chanted by the buddhas in the past, Those in use today, Or those that will be uttered by the buddhas in the future, “All of them are effective In the foothills of the Himalayas; In that auspicious and virtuous region[1802] One should undertake pacifying activities. “The mantras originating in the Lotus family Are accomplished in Madhyadeśa. Commonly observed there are also the accomplishments Of the Elephant and the Jewel families.[1803]

gnod sbyin lngas rtsen dag dang ni/ / 'phrog ma gnod sbyin skye gnas dang / / gang dag dri za'i sngags rnams ni/ / de dag tu ni grub par gsungs/ / de nas rtag tu ku sha'i grong / / ma ga d+hA ni khor yug dang / / ngogs dga' chu bo snar ma dang / / bang ga'i yul ni thams cad du/ / de bzhin nor bu'i rigs gsungs pa'i/ / dzam b+ha la ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / rgya mtsho dang na gling ngogs dang / / chu yi gzi ni thams cad dang / / dga' ba'i grong khyer sing ha lar/ / sngags kyi lha ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / sgrol ma khro gnyer can dag dang / / dpal chen ma dang grags chen ma/ / gdugs dkar rnams kyi sngags rnams dang / / zla ba'i grong khyer rgya mtsho dang / / shar gyi yul ni kho ra yug / der gnas pa la 'grub par 'gyur/ / 'bigs byed ri nang gnas pa dang / / yul ni mchog dbang khor yug tu/ /

“The mantras of beings of yakṣa origin, Such as the yakṣa Pañcika, and [the yakṣiṇī] Hārītī, And also the mantras of gandharva beings, All bring their respective accomplishments there. “Indeed, in the city of Vārāṇasī;[1804] Everywhere in Magadha; In Aṅga in the east,[1805] And everywhere in Kāmarūpa;[1806] “On the pleasant banks of the Brahmaputra, And everywhere in Vaṅga, One will accomplish [the mantras of] Jambhala, Who, likewise, is said to be of the Jewel family. “On the ocean shore or the islands, Everywhere near a [large] body of water, And in the pleasant city of Laṅkā, The [following] mantra deities can be accomplished: “Bhṛkuṭī, Tārā,[1807] Mahāśriyā, Yaśasvinī, All the mantras [of the goddess] called Sitā,[1808] And the four Kumārīs [who live] in the great ocean.[1809] “They can be accomplished in these places And everywhere in the east, In the foothills of the Vindhyas, And everywhere in the Himalayas.[1810]

smin drug bu bzhin 'jam dpal ni/ / khor yug tu grub pa yin/ / ri rtse tshang tshing nang dang ni/ / ri sul dang ni nags bcas la/ / log 'dren bgegs ni byed pa yi/ / bzlas pa dag ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / glang po'i cha byad yang dag ldan/ / mche ba gtsigs pa gzi brjid che/ / de bzhin rta gzugs du ma dang / / du ma'i rnam par grags pa yin/ / lha ni dbang dang ldan pa'i bu/ / rnam pa sna tshogs bgegs byed pa/ / de bstan sngags dang ldan pa yi/ / grub pa'i zhing du rab tu snang / / ma mo mi bzad rnam sna tshogs/ / gza' nyid shin tu mi bzad dang / / yi dgas skye gnas bstan pa yin/ / mi yi zas byed bden bral dang / / yi dgas rgyal por bstan pa dang / / de dag zhing du grub par gsungs/ / de la sogs pa'i 'byung po kun/ / grub pa'i zhing du gsungs pa yin/ / rdo rje khro bo brtson 'grus che/ / de dag phyogs su grub pa yin/ / lha min sngags kyi gtso bo dang / / gang gzhan de bzhin 'jig rten pa'i/ / sngags rgyud lho phyogs dag tu ni/ / brten pa dag la 'grub par 'gyur/ / rtag tu yi dgas rgyal po dang / / gshin rjes kyang ni bstan pa dang / / zhi ba khyab 'jug gis bstan pa'i/ / sngags gzhan dag kyang 'grub par 'gyur/ / gdug cing gdug pa'i las dag ni/ / lha yi gnas su bstan pa yin/ / sngags rnams gdug pa'i las rnams ni/ / lag na rdo rjes bstan pa dag /

“[The mantras of] Kārttikeya and Mañjuśrī Can be accomplished anywhere in places Such as lovers’ hideouts,[1811] caves, Mountains, and wild forests. “One can accomplish there [the mantras of] vināyakas Who create obstacles for mantra reciters‍— Powerful, single-tusked, And furnished with a trunk[1812]‍— “And also [the mantras of] those with the form of a horse And many other forms. They are the divine sons of Īśāna Who create various obstacles. “The places thus described are also noted As the places of success for the mantras Of the mātṛs in their various shapes And the terrifying grahas. “[The beings] designated as pretas by birth, Who feed on humans, [are associated with] the southwestern sector;[1813] [The mantras of] the preta king[1814] are recommended for that quarter, As it is the place where the corresponding accomplishments will arise. “It can also be recommended as the place of success [In controlling] all the spirits. [The mantras of] the valiant Vajrakrauñca[1815] Will be successful in his quarter. “The main asura mantras And other worldly mantras Will be effective there. The mantras belonging to the southern quarter “Are those of the king of the pretas Known as Yama‍—they are recommended [for that quarter]. The authentic Śaiva or Vaiṣṇava mantras Will also be effective [there].[1816] “When using cruel mantras in peaceful rites, These places are not suitable. For those who perform cruel rites, The mantras of Vajrapāṇi are recommended.[1817]

lho yi phyogs la bsten na ni/ / sdig pa'i las ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / de dag gi ni phyogs dag tu/ / myur du yang dag 'grub par snang / / nyi mas bshad pa'i sngags rnams ni/ / nyi ma'i sngags zhes rab tu bsgrags/ / nub phyogs na ni gang yod pa/ / sngags dang rgyud ni rab tu 'grub/ / gnod sbyin dbang po rdzu 'phrul che'i/ / der ni rang sngags 'grub par 'gyur/ / byis pa rnams ni rmongs pa yi/ / 'byung po kun la nor sbyin zhing / / cho ga mthong ba'i rgyu yis ni/ / skye bo rnams la nor sbyin byed/ / longs spyod ldan zhing mdzod 'phel ba/ / nub kyi phyogs su 'grub par 'gyur/ / nor sbyin zhes bya'i ming gis ni/ / sa yi steng du rnam par grags/ / gnod sbyin lag na rdo rje rang / / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / sngags pa mchog ni dam pa ste/ / rang nyid sa bcu'i bdag po yin/ / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs dag gi/ / de dag sngags ni grub pa yin/ / de bzhin rigs brgyad sngags dag ni/ / phyogs brgyad dag tu gnas pa yin/ /

“The mantras of those who perform evil rites Are effective in the south. In that quarter will also be observed the arising Of the [corresponding] nonvirtuous results.[1818] “The mantras taught to be of Āditya, Those known to be of Soma, And the mantras of Indra Are effective in the western quarter, the auspicious.[1819] “The powerful lord of yakṣas himself[1820] Will be accomplished there. He grants wealth to all beings. To the naive and foolish “He grants common sense. [These gifts are] his ritual specialty. This blissful fulfiller of aims Can be accomplished in the west. He is known here on earth As Dhanada, the ‘wealth giver.’ “Vajrapāṇi, himself a yakṣa, Is a bodhisattva of great magical power. Chief among the mantra deities, He is a master of the ten bodhisattva levels. “All the mantras‍—those that originate In the Vajra and Lotus families And those of all the eight families‍— Belong to [their respective] eight quarters.

rgyal ba'i rigs kyi sngags dag ni/ / byang gi phyogs su 'grub pa yin/ / pad+ma'i rigs las byung ba'i sngags/ / de bzhin shar gyi phyogs su 'grub/ / lho yi phyogs su gnas pa la/ / rdo rje'i rigs ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / nub phyogs su ni mdzod 'grub gsungs/ / phyogs mtshams dag tu rin chen rigs/ / de bzhin nub byang mtshams su ni/ / de dag 'grub par rab tu brtags/ / lho nub kyi ni mtshams dag tu/ / de bzhin gnod sbyin rigs kyang 'grub/ / shar lho dag gi cha dag tu/ / nyan thos rnams ni gzi brjid che/ / de dag rigs su snang ba ni/ / der gnas pa la 'grub par 'gyur/ / byang shar dag gi cha dag tu/ / rang rgyal rnams su yang dag 'byung / /

“The mantras that originate from the Victorious One[1821] Can be accomplished in the northern quarter. Those that originate from the Lotus family Can be accomplished in the eastern quarter. “The mantras that belong to the Vajra family Can be accomplished in the southern quarter. The Elephant family is said to be in the west, And the Jewel family is at the intermediate point(s) of compass.[1822] The junction between the western and the northern quarters Is where the success of their[1823] [mantras] is said to belong.[1824] “At the junction between the western and southern quarters, [The mantras of] the yakṣa family [can be accomplished], And in the intermediate quarter between south and east, [The mantras of] the powerful śrāvakas. “[The mantras] indicated by the family name Will be effective in the places [as mentioned]. [The mantras] of the pratyekabuddhas Originate in the northeastern quarter.[1825]

rigs ni 'jig rten kun gyis mchod/ / de dag der ni 'grub pa yin/ / 'og gi phyogs kyi cha dag tu/ / 'jig rten pa yi sngags rnams 'grub/ / sa 'og 'jug par gyur pa'i sngags/ / rigs brgyad kun la 'grub par 'gyur/ / de bzhin 'jig rten 'das pa'i sngags/ / gtsug tor la sogs rab bsgrags pa/ / steng du 'gro ba'i grub par ni/ / rgyal ba 'khor lo sgyur bas gsungs/ / thad kar kun nas khor yug tu/ / rdo rje can gyi 'grub pa yin/ / de bzhin gzhan yang sngags rgyal kun/ / pad+ma'i rigs las byung ba ni/ / thams cad du ni thams cad 'grub/ / sngags rnams kun kyang longs spyod ster/ / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs dag kyang / / dus rnams kun tu 'grub par 'gyur/ / 'di dag zhing du bstan pa ste/ / de yi dus ni yongs su bstan/ / rgyal ba'i rigs kyi sngags grub pa/ / sangs rgyas rnams la sngon byung ba'o/ /

“[Wherever] in the world [a particular] family is highly esteemed, In those places [its mantras] will be effective. All the worldly mantras will be effective In the world division below. “Thus, for entering the subterranean paradises, The mantras of [all] the eight families will be effective. There are also supramundane mantras‍— They are the uṣṇīṣa mantras, and so forth. “Originating from[1826] the wheel-turning victors, They can be accomplished in the world division above. The mantras of the vajra holder Are effective everywhere, in all world divisions.[1827] “Similarly, the other mantra-kings, Such as all those that originate in the Lotus family, Can all be accomplished everywhere. The same is true for all the mantras that bring enjoyments and profit. “[The mantras] of the Vajra and Lotus families Are effective throughout the entire period [indicated for them]. The recommended places have already been specified; Now the time is being told: “The mantra accomplishments related to the victorious ones[1828] Arise at [the time of] the arising of any buddha.[1829]

pad+ma rdo rje'i rigs dag ni/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi bar ma'i dus/ / gzhan gyi dus su sngags dag ni/ / de las gzhan pa'i rigs 'grub yin/ / de dag grub pa'i dus su gsungs/ / dus gzhan rab tu bstan ma yin/ / dka' thub kyis ni grub pa mchog / skye ba gsum gyis thob par 'gyur/ / rtag tu sngags rnams zlos pa dang / / der dang yid ni der sems dang / / rgyal sras rnams la rab dang ba/ / skye ba 'di la'ang 'grub par 'gyur/ / dkon mchog gsum la gus pa dang / / byang chub sems kyis brgyan pa dang / / shes rab che zhing sdom la gnas/ / sngags dang rgyud la 'jigs pa med/ / byang chub sdom la gnas pa dag / 'bad pa med par sngags rnams 'grub/ / sems can rnams kyis las grub dang / / bdag kyang grub par nyer bstan pa/ / rtag tu sngags nyid grub pa yin/ / rmongs pa'i sems can 'grub pa med/ / de nyid phyir na rgyal dbang gis/ / cho ga'i rgyal po gsungs pa ni/ / sangs rgyas gtso bo bdun pa yis/ / sngags rnams rgya che'i las dag bstan/ /

During the middle time of the buddhas, The accomplishments related to the Lotus and Vajra families arise. “The mantras belonging to other families Are accomplished at other times. Their success depends on the right time; It is said not to arise at other times. “The highest accomplishment comes from ardor; It can be attained within three births. However, those who recite the mantra continually, Are mentally devoted to it, “And have faith in the bodhisattvas Can attain accomplishment even in this life. If they have faith in the Three Jewels, Are adorned with bodhicitta, “Observe the prescribed conduct, have great insight, And have confidence in the tantras and mantras, Their mantras will be accomplished without effort, As they thus maintain the conduct of awakening. “Ordinary beings, [too], can accomplish their rites And fulfill their specified individual aims. The mantras can always be accomplished, But not by beings who are deluded. “For this reason, the victorious ones Have taught this king of manuals, And so, [too], the seventh chief buddha[1830] Teaches in detail its rituals and mantras.”

sangs rgyas sras kyi thu bo ni/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni gzi chen la/ / thub pa'i zla ba rdzu 'phrul che/ / des ni gsung mchog rab tu bstan/ / sngags rnams kyi ni mthar thug mthu/ / gzhon nu rab tu nyon cig dang / / gang tshe sangs rgyas rtag tu ni/ / 'jig rten 'dren pa bzhugs gyur pa/ / de tshe de bzhin grub pa ni/ / gtsug tor la sogs rab grags pa/ / de bzhin 'khor los sgyur ba dang / / gzi brjid phung por rab bstan dang / / rgyal ba gtsug tor gdugs dkar po/ / rgyal bas mang por gsungs pa ni/ / de la sogs pa'i gtsug tor ni/ / de yi tshe ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / gang tshe 'khor los sgyur ba ni/ / 'dzam bu'i gling du 'byung 'gyur zhing / / chos kyi rgyal po rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / rkang gnyis dam pa bzhugs pa na/ / sngags rnams ma lus bshad pa dag / de yi tshe na 'grub par 'gyur/ /

The foremost among sages, This majestic moon among buddhas, Further said to the seniormost son of the buddhas, Mañjughoṣa of great splendor: “Listen, O divine youth, about the power of mantras To manifest the highest destiny.[1831] At the time when the buddhas, the guides of the world, Are physically present, “At that time the accomplishment Of uṣṇīṣa and other such mantras is noteworthy. At that time King Cakravartin And Tejorāśi become celebrated. “[Also,] Sitātapatra and Jayoṣṇīṣa Are extolled by the victorious ones. These and other uṣṇīṣa [kings] Will be accomplished at that time. “At the time when the wheel turner[1832] Is reborn in Jambūdvīpa And remains there as the supreme among two-legged beings‍— The Dharma king, the fully realized Buddha‍— At that time all the mantra utterances Will lead to accomplishment.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ zhing dang dus kyi cho ga nges pa'i le'u rab 'byam las/ nyi shu rtsa bzhi pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter on the ritual restrictions concerning the place and the time [of accomplishing the mantras], thirtieth[1833] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
gdon 'jug pa'i spyod pa'i cho ga'i le'u
Chapter 31

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa ras ris ni sngar bstan te/ sems can la yod pa'i spyod pa dge ba dang mi dge ba'i mtshan ma rnams ni bshad par bya yi nyon cig / de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa stan las langs te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la spyi bos btud nas thal mo sbyar te 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das sems can rnams ni gzhan gyi lus la 'jug pa'i sems can rnams te/ 'phags pa dang lha'i skye gnas dang grub pa dang dri za dang gnod sbyin dang srin po dang sha za dang lto 'phye chen po la sogs pa las sna tshogs kyis byas pa'i lus rnam pa sna tshogs la brten cing gnas pa/ cha byad rnam pa sna tshogs dang rtags sna tshogs dang mi dang mi ma yin pa dang 'byung po thams cad kyi sems kyi spyod pa bcom ldan 'das bstan pa'i dus lags/ bde bar gshegs pa bstan pa'i dus ni lags te/ de'i dus la bab par mkhyen na legs par bshad du gsol/ de skad ces rgyal ba'i mchog 'jig rten gyi 'dren pa gau ta ma bdun pa la gsol ba btab nas/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa cang mi smra bar gyur te/ rang gi stan la 'dug par gyur to/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas sems can rnams kyi sems kyi spyod pa dang mtshan ma shes pa dang rtags dang dus gsungs pa/

At that time the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and said to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “Listen Mañjuśrī, divine youth, as I teach about the ways of spirits who possess other beings, and the accompanying auspicious and inauspicious signs.” Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, rose from his seat, prostrated at the feet of the Blessed One, folded his hands, and said to the Blessed One: “Good it is, O Blessed One! Please teach about the thoughts and actions (cittacaritāni) of beings who enter other beings’ bodies‍—the noble and divine siddhas, gandharvas, yakṣas, rākṣasas, piśācas, mahoragas, and so forth, and the human and nonhuman beings whose bodies are generated by different types of karma and who have taken different types of birth and have different forms and characteristics. Now it has come to pass, O Blessed One! Now it has come to pass, O Sugata, if you think that the time is right!” Having thus spoken, Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, became silent. Having made his request, he now remained in his seat, waiting for Gautama, the supreme Victor, the guide of the world, the seventh of the victorious ones.[1834] Blessed Śākyamuni, for his part, taught the knowledge of the thoughts, actions, external aspects, and characteristics of such beings, and also the time when the possession occurs.

gzhan gyi lus zhugs sems can ni/ / sngags kyi sbyor bas drang bar bya/ / kha cig zas la chags pa yi/ / sa steng mi ni 'dzin par byed/ / gzhan dag khro ldan sems kyis ni/ / sa steng dag tu mi bzad pas/ /

“A being who entered the body of another Can be drawn forth by the application of mantras. Some such beings seize a human being on earth Because of their desire for food. “Others do this because of their cruel disposition; Others yet, because of previous enmity. Very fearsome, they seize human beings On the surface of the earth.[1835]

rtag tu chags dang bral ba dag / snying rje'i dam tshig dag gis ni/ / mi yi 'jig rten dag 'jug pa/ / dge ba'i mi la 'dzin par byed/ / rab bsngags dge dang g.yo ba med/ / mi rnams kyi ni mdog kyang sgrub/ / nyi ma dag ni 'char ba la/ / de dag 'jug par brjod pa yin/ / mi rnams nyi ma nub pa yi/ / de yi dus su 'jug par 'gyur/ / mtshan mo'i thun gyi dang po la/ / yar ngo la ni snang bar 'gyur/ / rab bsngags dge ba'i las dag dang / / rtag tu gang zhig chos ldan mi/ / gang zhig shes nyen ldan pa ni/ / de dag la ni 'jug par snang / / 'dod chags bral ba rdzu 'phrul che/ / des na mi la 'jug pa yin/ / phyogs gtsang skye bo gtsang ba dang / / rgyu skar skar ma bzang ba dang / / nyin zhag sngags dang zla res bzang / / yar ngo dge ba'i nyin zhag dang / / gza' bzang yang dag ldan pa dang / / tshes grangs rdzogs dang yang dag ldan/ / de bzhin zla ba nya ba la/ / de dag la ni 'jug par snang / / chags bral rdzu 'phrul chen po ni/ / 'jug par 'gyur ba'i mtshan ma yang / / nam mkha' la ni ta la tsam/ / sa las 'phags te 'dug pa yin/ / de ni skyil krung 'dug nas kyang / / nam mkha' la ni gnas par snang / / tshig kyang bzang po mtshungs med dang / / tshangs dbyangs de bzhin rnar snyan dang / / gang du 'dod chags bral de gnas/ / sems dpa' chen po de dag smra/ /

“Others again, themselves free from desire And bound by the pledge of compassion, May descend into this world of mortals And seize pure human beings. “Among people, those who are praiseworthy, Pure, not deformed, and of clear complexion Are taken possession of, it is said, When the sun is rising. “On such an occasion, the descent[1836] occurs In the evening when the sun sets, Or during the first watch of the night, When the moon is waxing. “Such a descent is known to occur for the mediums Who are praiseworthy because of their pure actions, Always live in accord with the Dharma, And engage in virtuous and skillful pursuits. “If they are as described, mortals can be entered By powerful beings who have extinguished their passions, If the place and the person are pure And the stars and nakṣatras are auspicious. “Their descent may be observed On an auspicious day of the week And an auspicious lunar day of the bright fortnight Whose lunar asterism is governed by auspicious planets And perfect conjunctions. It can also occur when the moon is completely full. “When powerful, desire-free beings have thus descended, They will be indicated by the following signs: They will remain floating above the ground At the height of a fan-palm tree. “They will appear sitting unsupported[1837] In a cross-legged position, Saying various divine and peerless words,[1838] As pleasant to the ears as Brahmā’s. “These great beings will speak About matters that cause them concern.[1839]

gtsug tor phyag rgyas drangs pa yi/ / sa yi steng du 'dug par gyur/ / sa steng de la 'dug pa na/ / de yi mod la mchod yon sbyin/ / sna ma'i me tog dag la ni/ / tsan+dan bzang po gur gum bsres/ / bsres pa'i chu dang chu gtsang ni/ / de yi mod la dbul bar bya/ / sngags pas sa la rab btud nas/ / phan pa'i blo yis gsol ba gdab/ / dpa' ba'i rang bzhin sems kyis ni/ / sems can des ni gsol ba gdab/ / tshig ni bzang po 'don byed cing / / rnar snyan de bzhin rmongs pa med/ / sngags shes cho ga 'jigs med pas/ / de nas ji ltar 'dod pa 'dri/ / 'jam dbyangs yang dag dran nas ni/ / de yi dus su 'jigs med bya/ / gtsug pud lnga pa'i phyag rgya 'am/ / gtsug tor las byung gzhan pa'ang bcing / / de nas phyogs ni bcing bya ste/ / steng dang 'og tu'ang de bzhin no/ / de nas de yi 'byung ba kun/ / bar dang tha mar rab tu brjod/ / de bzhin dang po bar ma'i dus/ / byung dang ma 'ongs dus dag dang / / de bzhin da ltar byung gyur pa/ / 'od ldan des ni ston par 'gyur/ / de bzhin 'dzum med mig gis ni/ / chags bral des zin rab tu lta/ /

Drawn by the uṣṇīṣa mudrās, They will come down to the ground. “One should wait for the moment before the great beings touch the ground,[1840] And immediately present them with a welcome offering Consisting of water mixed with flowers of royal jasmine, White sandalwood, and saffron. “One should thus promptly offer Water for the feet, prepared [as described].[1841] The mantra practitioner should prostrate themself on the ground And, motivated by kindness, should supplicate the great beings, “Who, for their part, Without any selfishness, Will say divine words With a pure voice pleasant to the ears. “One who knows the mantras with confidence[1842] Should ask them whatever one wants. One should not be afraid at this time, But remember Mañjughoṣa. “Forming the mudrā five-crested, Or another one that arises from the uṣṇīṣa, One should bind the directions, Including the ones above and below. “The great beings will then tell everything From the middle to the end, And from the beginning to the middle, Truthfully, about the past, the future, “And the present, as it really is. Such splendorous beings will express it. With unblinking eyes and without moving, They will look on without fear or hatred.[1843]

gang yin des bstan tshig gis ni/ / bden par 'gyur gyi gzhan du min/ / de bzhin grub dang bsgrub bya'i rdzas/ / gang zhig tshogs kyi rnam pa dang / / rang rgyal byang chub dgra bcom dang / / nges par byang chub chen po'ang de/ / nges par sangs rgyas nyid rig nyid/ / de bzhin byang chub sems rigs dang / / rigs med nyid dang dus dang ni/ / sems can skal ldan brjod pa'ang yin/ / dam tshig gis ni mngon mtshon pas/ / bden pa kun ni des ston 'gyur/ / skad cig tsam ston rnal 'byor la/ / dus ring dus su sdod ma yin/ / skad cig de la gang cung zad/ / yid la bsams shing don du gnyer/ / myur du sngags grub kho na la/ / de dag thams cad ston par byed/ / ci 'dod mngon par re ba dag / phun sum tshogs pa thams cad thob/ / sngags pas slar ni gshegs gsol ba/ / myur du mchod yon phul nas 'gyel/ / cho ga mthong ba'i las kyis ni/ / snod ni yang dag bsrung ba bya/ / sems can lus ni 'gyel ba yang / / sa yi steng du nyal ba nyid/ / gtsug tor sngags dang ldan pa yi/ / sngags ni cho gar gsungs pa dag / de nyid kyis ni bsrung ba dang / / phyag rgya gtsug phud lnga yis so/ / de tshe lus ni bde legs 'gyur/ / sa yi steng las ldang bar 'gyur/ /

“Whatever they say is true And will not turn out to be otherwise. Regarding accomplishing what is to be accomplished, Whether it is power substances, the course of rebirth, the destinies, “Or the attainment of pratyekabuddhahood, bodhisattvahood, Arhatship, or the great awakening, it will inevitably come to pass. Similarly, they will correctly ascertain the buddha family Or the bodhisattva lineage.[1844] “The period without the Buddha lineage And the powerful beings in the future[1845] ‍— All this they will truthfully describe, Indicating also the time of their occurrence. The practitioner should speak, taking advantage of the moment, And not wait for another occasion. “Whatever one requests at that particular moment, Motivated by good intentions, Will all be swiftly obtained‍— In particular, the mantra accomplishment. One will obtain all good fortune According to one’s desires and hopes. “Having requested the great beings to depart With a prompt offering that is agreeable to them, The mantra practitioner should perform The bowl protection rite, following the prescribed procedure. “One should place the collapsed body[1846] On a bed on the ground, And employ the mantra as taught by the victorious ones[1847] In conjunction with the uṣṇīṣa mudrā. “Using this mudrā, or the five-crested, One should perform the protection rite. Then the being left behind[1848] on the ground Will become well in their body.

sems can kun la'ang 'jug pa yi/ / srung ba 'di ni rab tu brtag / snod la brten te 'tshe byed par/ / gdug pa'i sems can gyis mi nus/ / skye bo snod du gyur pa la/ / 'di ni srung ba chen po yin/ / de yi tshig ni bar mar gnas/ / dbus kyi yul gyir rab tu bsgrags/ / lha yi skye gnas la brten pa'i/ / 'og min gzugs dang ldan pa dang / / de dang de yi rtags rnams dang / / gzugs ni rab tu snang ba yin/ / 'dod pa'i khams kyi dbang phyug dang / / 'dod dang ldan pa'i lha dag dang / / de las dman pa'i 'gro ba'i rtags/ / tshig nyid kyang ni shin tu snyan/ / de nas sa la gnas pa dang / / gzhal med khang gnas lha rnams kyi/ / tshig ni ku sha'i grong khyer mtshungs/ / ma ga d+hA yi gnod sbyin tshig / de bzhin ang+ga'i yul gyi tshig / lto 'phye chen por rab tu bstan/ / gzi brjid chen po nam mkha' lding / / de dag shar phyogs tshig tu 'gyur/ / bang ga'i yul du yang dag skyes/ / gang dag tshig tu bstan pa ni/ / de bzhin mi'am ci yi tshig / de yi tshig tu rab brtag bya/ / rtag tu piN+Da'i tshig gyur pa/ / grub dang ral gri'i rig pa 'dzin/ / de tshig rig pa 'dzin pa dang / / drang srong 'dod pa'i gzugs can yin/ / de tshig mngon shes lnga dang ni/ / drang srong rnams kyis yongs su brtags/ /

“This protection is prescribed For all possessed beings. Evil beings will not then be able To harm those used as such vessels. This protection is indeed great For people who become vessels. “If the words of the [medium] are heard in midair, And the language is that known in Madhyadeśa,[1849] It indicates that [the possessing being] is of divine birth, From the Akaniṣṭha or other heavens in the realm of form. Other signs indicating their origin In the realm of form will also be observed. “For the lords of the desire realm, Ruling over the gods of this realm, The signs will indicate their [relatively] inferior birth, And their speech will be very sweet. “If they are divine yakṣas dwelling in palaces Manifested here on earth, The language of these yakṣas will be the same As that of Vārāṇasī along with Magadha. “Similarly, the language of Aṅga Is known to be that of mahoragas. The language of Pūrvī[1850] Is that of the powerful garuḍas. “Similarly, the same language That is spoken in Vaṅga Is also known to be the speech of kinnaras, And, as such, indicates them [as the possessing beings]. “The language of Oḍra[1851] is invariably That of the sword-wielding siddhas, the masters of magic. This language of the vidyādharas . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[1852] “The language of Kāmarūpa is the language Of the sages who can assume any form. It indicates that [the possessing beings] Are the sages with the five superknowledges.

gang yang yul tshig ma ga d+hA/ / gang yang ha ri ki la'i tshig / mi gsal mi dod nyid dang ni/ / yi ge ta la shin tu brten/ / la yi yi ge mang ba'i tshig / sha za'i tshig tu brjod pa yin/ / las tshon zhes bya'i gling dang ni/ / na li ke ra 'byung ba'i gnas/ / gling ni rtsub par byed nyid dang / / gcer bu stobs ldan bu gnas kyang / / sems can dag byed gnas pa dag / de bzhin 'di dag gling las byung / / yi ge la mang tshig dag dang / / tshig ni gsal ba'i rnam pa med/ / mi gsal bsri ba med nyid dang / / khro bcas yi dgas skye gnas tshig / lho phyogs pa yi tshig dag dang / / an+d+ra kar Na dra bi DA/ / sems can ko sa la 'brog gnas dang / / sing ga la yi gling dag na/ / yi ge ga dang rar bcas pa/ / de ni srin po'i tshig tu shes/ /

“The language of Samataṭa[1853] And the language of Harikela Are based on the sound ḍ And are indistinct and unclear.[1854] “Languages where the sound l abounds Are said to be piśāca. They are found on the islands Of Karmaraṅga, Nārikela, “Vāruṣaka,[1855] Nagna, and Bali,[1856] And also among the inhabitants Of the island of Java and other islands. “Indistinct languages where The sound r[1857] abounds, Both wispy and harsh, Are spoken by the angry pretas. “They are found in the southern countries, Among the inhabitants of Andhra, Karnāṭaka, Drāviḍa, Kośala, Aḍavi,[1858] And on the island of Siṃhala. “Languages that abound in the sound ḍ,[1859] In combination with the guttural ra, are known as rākṣasa.

de dag gling la gnas pa de'i/ / ming ni gang zhig brjod pa yang / / ma mo rnams ni gzi brjid che/ / de yi tshig 'dir gsungs pa yin/ / tshig ni nub phyogs phyogs mtshams dang / / ma la ba yi tshig dag dang / / be'u nya dang rgya mtsho'i tshig / shur se yi rnam brtags dang / / rgya mtsho bcu 'dus chu bo 'dus/ / dpal mgrin dang ni ko dz+wa ri/ / 'di dag tshig ldan 'jug pa ni/ / nyi ma la sogs gza' mchog gdon/ / de las gzhan gdon gtso bo ni/ / yul ni ba ri ya tra'i tshig /

They are spoken by people Inhabiting other islands.[1860] “The language of the mātṛs of great vigor Is the same as the one just described;[1861] The languages that indicate [these mātṛs as the possessing beings] Are the western languages of Vidiśa and Mālava.[1862] “If the language [spoken by the medium] Is recognized as that of Vatsamatsārṇava,[1863] Śūrasena, Daśārṇava,[1864] The hilly Śrīkaṇṭha, or Gurjara, “This indicates that [the possessing beings] Are the chief grahas, Āditya and so forth. If the language is recognized as that of Pāriyātra, [The possessing beings] are other grahas.[1865]

yul ni ar bu ta sa h+ya/ / ri ni mA la yar gnas dang / / lang ba'i yul du yang dag skyes/ / tshig ni ci 'dra yod pa yi/ / de 'dra'i tshig tu smra ba ni/ / grul bum skye gnas 'dzin pa yin/ / yi ge sha Sha sa dang ni/ / ra la ba las yang dag byung / / yi ge g+ha dang ldan pa'i tshig / lha ma yin du nges par bstan/ / kha che'i yul las byung ba dang / / skye ba'i gnas ni ka bi sha/ / gnod sbyin rgyal po'i rigs las byung / / phyag na rdo rje'i rigs su bstan/ / de dag lnga yi gtso bo ni/ / kun gyi tshig tu 'dod pa yin/ /

“If the languages resemble those spoken By the mountain dwellers in Arbuda, Sahya, or Malaya, Or those spoken by the inhabitants Of Khaṣadroṇi,[1866] “They indicate that [the possessing beings] Are kuṣmāṇḍas and so forth. These languages are based on the sounds Śa, ra, ṣa, and sa; and ya, ra, la, and va. “Languages abounding in the sound gha Indicate that [the possessing beings] are dānavas. Such languages are found In the countries of Kaśmīra and Kāviśa. “All languages originate from the buddha families, [And the previously mentioned] belong to the family of Vajrapāṇi. For each of the main mantras There is one language that suits the best.[1867]

de bzhin dbus kyi phyogs gnas dag / pad+ma'i rigs kyi skye gnas rten/ / tshig dang 'gros dang mtshan ma yang / / pad+ma'i rigs su snang ba yin/ / rgyal ba'i sras kyis rnam brtags pa/ / snga ma nyid du bstan pa yin/ / 'dod chags bral ba'i mtshan ma gang / / rgyal ba'i mtshan mar rab tu 'byung / / yul phyogs gang gi tshig smra ba/ / der gnas 'gros dang spyod pa yin/ / der bstan sems can nyid dang ni/ / 'gros dang mtshan ma'ang kun tu bstan/ / kha ba can gyi nang gnas pa/ / dri za drang srong skye bo'i tshig / gang gA'i ngogs kyi byang phyogs pa/ / gnod sbyin tshig tu rab tu snang / /

“Similarly, the Lotus family belongs in Madhyadeśa, [And the languages there] originate from this family. These languages, along with the outward manner of acting [Of the medium], will indicate an origin from the Lotus family. “It has been explained earlier [how] to recognize [The possessing beings] as the sons of victors;[1868] The signs that betoken their freedom from desire Belong to [the family of] the victorious ones. “The manner of acting [of the medium] will be particular To the place where the language [they use] comes from. This alone will indicate the [type of] the possessing being, As a sign that reveals everything. “The languages of the people living In the foothills of the Himalayas North of the river Gaṅgā Indicate the yakṣas, gandharvas, and ṛṣis.[1869]

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas/ gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal khyod kyi sngags rnams rgyud thams cad la yang dag par 'jug pa/ rig pa thams cad la 'os pa/ dus dpag tu med pa'i yon tan ma lus pa'i 'bras bu 'byung ba yang rjes su 'brel ba'i mtshan ma'i tshad yod de/ de 'grub par bya ba'i rgyur bshad pa ni 'di lta ste/

At that time the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “Your mantras, Mañjuśrī, hold the key to the complete understanding of all the tantras; they possess the secrets of all the vidyās,[1873] and, in consequence, they can also cause the ripening of all the results of good qualities accumulated over a long period of time. I will now authoritatively teach the factors of accomplishment, which are as follows:

skye ba gzhan gyis 'grub pa nyid/ / dus kyi rgyus ni 'grub pa med/ / de yi tshad dang sbyor ba ni/ / sngon byung rgyu las byung ba yin/ / rtse gcig bdag gir byed pas 'grub/ / grub pa rigs pa rnam dpyod pa'o/ / rigs pa gzhon nu khyod bsten na/ / lus can kun la rab tu snang / / mthar gyis byas pa'i las rnams ni/ / rigs pa zhes ni bya ba yin/ / dpa' bo'i rigs ldan de sbyor bas/ / grub pa mchog ni thob par 'gyur/ / grub med bsgrub bya'i las rnams med/ / las rnams med par 'grub pa'ang med/ / las dang byed par yang dag ldan/ / yang dag ldan pas grub pa 'thob/ / cho ga ldan pa'i rgyu yis ni/ / gnas pa mchog ni thob par 'gyur/ / sngags pa sngags ni mi sgrogs na/ / sngags min pa yang sngags par 'gyur/ /

“As time is not its primary cause, Accomplishment can arise in another life. The governing principle is rather that it arises Subject to previously created causes. “One who lacks benefits[1874] can attain accomplishment Through correctly ascertaining the right means. The means attested as right for all beings Is to resort to you, the divine youth.[1875] “What is here called the right means Is the ritual activity performed in advance.[1876] One who is steadfastly engaged in this way Will obtain the supreme accomplishment. “Ritual activity accomplishes that which has not been accomplished;[1877] There is no accomplishment without ritual activity. There must be the activity and its agent‍— When these are present, accomplishment will be achieved. “One will obtain the highest level Through applying the right procedure. When the mantra practitioner does not say the mantra, Even what is not the mantra will become a mantra.[1878]

thub pa'i las ni yang dag spyod/ / grub pa rgyas pa thob par 'gyur/ / rigs kyi sa bon la brten na/ / blo yi mchog la gnas par 'gyur/ / gnas mchog dam par nges sdom na/ / dang po'i bgrod pa thob par 'gyur/ / blo dang bsam pa legs gnas na/ / nad med go 'phang 'thob par 'gyur/ /

“By observing the ritual conduct of silence, One will win complete accomplishment. Through withholding his semen,[1879] The practitioner will obtain supreme intelligence. “When passing away, one will obtain the ‘first destiny’[1880] At the best possible location. “If one desires accomplishment, But the signs indicate that the time is not right, One will not accomplish the mantras, Even if one is Śakra himself. “Moreover, one’s endeavors are ill-timed If one does not benefit spirits and people. No accomplishment will manifest for such a one, Even if he is a high-minded brahmin. “If one is lazy, full of cravings, Arrogant, proud, Loose of tongue, And always delights in vulgar company, Is slothful, and indulges in sex, How will he obtain accomplishment?

“Even the most prominent gods, Or the most prominent asuras, Will not be able to accomplish the mantra If they fail to follow the procedure. A rite without the right procedure Only causes the mind to wander. “If beings recite unsuitable mantras, Violating the right procedure, Such mantras will produce Deluded views in those naive beings. “These ignorant, senseless beings Will end up in the most miserable state of existence. The mantra holders will subsequently rescue them though, And set them free again. “In stages, they will obtain accomplishment And a pleasant state of existence. The mantras will thus establish Such reciters in an unshakable state of bliss. “The tathāgatas have thus taught Mantra recitation that never fails. Even if one has strayed from the right view, One will be the object of their kindness. “There are spiritual friends, And there are their dear children‍—ordinary beings. For the latter, accomplishments have been taught Consistent with the three vehicles. “One should therefore recite the mantra In all earnestness and fully concentrated. If the reciters employ the mantras Apart from the prescribed rituals, “It will take them a long time Before they are liberated from saṃsāra; A long time will pass before one sees The accomplishment of such mantras. “If, on the other hand, the mantras are employed according to procedure, One will swiftly obtain accomplishment And will see the results manifesting in full‍— Such mantras are said to be not without results. “Such mantras will be accomplished in this very life, With the corresponding results arising accordingly.[1882]

The reciter of such [rites] will, in this life, Attain the deathless state[1885] “[Where] the world is said to be blissful, And [the reciter] is delivered into a tranquil state.[1886] Such a follower of the Buddha’s path Will enter there, the great destiny. “During the inauspicious lowest eon, He will see his own accomplishment. In this very life he will obtain accomplishment That will last beyond the end of this life. “Until the final liberation there will be peace‍— This is the unconditioned, auspicious path. It has been explained to the world As the pure, auspicious state. “The victorious ones taught about buddhahood, Explaining everything in full. “It is taught that accomplishment can manifest for beings As a real experience during this life. “During the intermediate period, one can accomplish the Lotus family; Toward the end of the eon, one can accomplish the Vajra family. Powerful mantras are taught By Viṣṇu and all the bhūtas. “These mantras can be accomplished by reciters Toward the end of this lowest eon. “The number of syllables That is the norm in the mantras Taught by the bodhisattvas Could be just one or two, or five hundred. “The composition of a mantra is said to be An arrangement of words that consist of syllables.
