[Mantras] are adorned with the individual meanings of verbal roots. “[Mantric] speech should be recited well, In a manner that follows tantric [principles]. How would accomplishment ever arise If [mantras] were without word-sounds? “Combining mudrās[1909] with words that contain retroflex sounds, Followed by the palatal and ending with the ‘hot’ sounds,[1910] And producing dental, labial, and guttural sounds‍— So is the sādhana performed.[1911] “One should avoid indistinct pronunciation And recite the mantras correctly. One who pronounces the words fully and correctly, Observing the right prosody, will succeed. “If, on the other hand, one strays from the right procedure, Neglects the ritual performance, and misses the word meanings, One’s mantras will not be accomplished soon; One may expect this to take a long time. “The accomplishment of a reciter who does not recite Merely for show, will not be in vain.[1912]

skye ba gzhan du'ang snang ba ste/ / sngags grub mchog kyang ster bar 'gyur/ / yun ring dus su bzlas pa yi/ / de yi sngags kyi mthu yis ni/ / sngags rig skye bo'i sngags de ni/ / don med las ni byed ma yin/ / sngags rnams kun kyi tha ma ni/ / mi ma yin pa'i 'jig rten pa/ / 'byung po kun ni ser snar bcas/ / gang yin des ni sngags bstan pa'o/ / yi ge gang dag des bstan pa/ / gcig dang gnyis kyi grangs dag dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs kla klo'i skad/ / yul gyi skad du bstan pa ste/ / phreng du bsdebs dang ldan pa dang / / sgra ni 'dres par gyur pa yin/ / de dag yi ge gcig pa nas/ / rtsa brgyad stong gi bar du 'o/ /

Even in their next life, they will see the boons and blessings Of their mantra accomplishment. “Because of the power of the mantras Of such long-term reciters, Their rites, attended by these mantras, will be fruitful, Since they are mantra adepts.[1913] “The lowest of all mantras Are the worldly mantras of humans,[1914] The mantras taught by any of the spirits, And the mantras that cater to one’s greed. They are said to include cerebralized letters[1915]‍— One, two, or three of them.[1916] “Various foreign languages, Known to be spoken in [particular] countries,[1917] Have a linear structure, With the sounds arranged in a line‍— One thousand and eight, one hundred and eight, And down to a single letter.[1918]

tshig rkang bzhi dang rkang med dang / / rkyang pa tshigs su sbyar des bstan/ / tshigs bcad rgyun chags cha dag dang / / tshigs bcad tshigs su brjod pa yin/ / yang dang yang ni brjod don ldan/ / gsal ba'i don gyis brgyan pa yin/ / zur chag legs sbyar sgra nyams kyang / / don ni rab tu brtag pa yin/ / mi gsal gsal ba med pa dang / / yi ge nyams kyang 'dod pa yin/ / 'gro ba yul dang rnam bral ba/ / de la'ang sngags ni 'grub par brjod/ / de ltar sngags rnams kun la ni/ / rtag tu phan pas rigs par gsungs/ / zag med zag bcas thams cad kyi/ / sngags rnams 'di yi mtshan 'di yin/ /

“The speech may be in prose or in verse, Such as four pādas long, or just half a pāda. The verse could also be of the daṇḍaka[1919] type, measured in syllables, Or an extended, ‘shallow,’ skandhaka type, measured in mātras.[1920] “[The speech,] endowed with meaning word by word, Is thus adorned with thousands of meanings.[1921] If the words, whether Sanskrit or Apabhraṃśa, Are devoid of meaning[1922]‍— “If they are pronounced indistinctly, Or lack the metrical rhythm‍— It is said, when describing the accomplishment of such mantras, That it has no function or place.[1923] “The following characteristics apply to all mantras.[1924]

gang la yi ge sa mang zhing / / o~M ni ta yis brgyan pa ni/ / de las de yi mod la ni/ / de dag la ni nges 'grub 'gyur/ / dang po sngags ni yi ge o~M/ / mtha' na yi ge ma yod la/ / yi ge sa ni rkang par ldan/ / de bzhin ta yis bar mdzes shing / / ta yi rnam pa zur bzhir ldan/ / mtha' gnas yi ge rnam par spangs/ / ra gnyis ldan pa yi ge ta/ / sngags rnams kyi ni grub pa byed/ / dang por ra gnyis mang ba dang / / yi ge hU~M gi yon tan yod/ /

The mantras with multiple occurrences of the syllable śa, Adorned by the import of the syllable oṁ, And containing the syllable ta that indicates their belonging to the tantra Are certain to bring accomplishment.[1925] “If the mantras that start with oṁ And end with m[1926] Also contain the syllable śa, They are auspicious and will bring results. “Mantras with the form of a square[1927] containing the syllable ta That are not contracted at the end, And where the syllable ta is joined with the letter r, Are effective in ritual performances. The letter r occurring twice or many times at the beginning Will bring out good qualities of the syllable huṁ.[1928]

yi ge tsa ni gru bzhir snang / / de dag yi ge sgrub par brjod/ / yi ge b+ha ni rar ldan zhing / / yig mthar ma dang yi ge gnas/ / dang por ma dang mang yi ge/ / de ni sngags kyi mchog tu bstan/ / gang yang yi ge na mang zhing / / rgyud rnams kun la snang ba yin/ / sngags de dag ni zhi bar gsungs/ / gshin rje hU~M gis brgyan pa yis/ / yi ge b+ha ni mang ba de/ / dbang po rlung gi phyogs su gsungs/ / yi ge ba ni chu lhar gsungs/ / 'jig rten phan zhing rgyas byed yin/ / sngags gang yi ge e mang ba/ / dbang chen de ni rab tu snang / /

“When the syllable va[1929] is at the end of the square,[1930] The letters [of the mantra] will render the sādhana effective. The syllable ka[1931] may be joined with the letter r, And the syllable ma at the end become merely an m.[1932] Mantras that begin with the syllables ma or na Are said to be the best. “Mantras that have many syllables ta[1933] Can be found in all the tantras; They are said to be associated with the north. Those associated with the south are adorned with huṁ. Those that have many syllables bha Are associated with the east and the northwest. “The syllable ca[1934] belongs to Varuṇa; It is said to nourish and bring welfare to the world. The mantra that has many syllables va[1935] Is regarded as belonging to the great Indra.[1936]

dang po dkon mchog gsum skyabs 'gro/ / gang yin sngags ni de bzhin du/ / phyag 'tshal ba la rab 'jug dang / / zhi ba'i rgyu dang bde ba byed/ / de las gzhan pa'i lha rnams la'ang / / phyag 'tshal don du rab tu sbyar/ / sngags dang rgyud la rang gi sngags/ / rang sngags las ni thams cad pa/ / gang la yi ge ra mang zhing / / mtha' na yi ge phaT hU~M bcas/ / 'di dag sngags ni gdug pa che/ / gzi brjid ldan zhing gzi mdangs che/ / mi zhi srog gcod byed pa ste/ / gdug pa'i sems can dag la sbyar/ / khyad par du ni sdig yod pas/ / de bas las de mi bya'o/ /

“If it starts with a recourse to the Three Jewels, The mantra is one of refuge. If it includes, further on, an homage, It is the cause of peace and brings happiness. “Otherwise, a mantra may be used For paying homage to all the gods. One’s own mantra and also the ‘lord of mantras’[1937] Are suitable for all types of activity. “Mantras that contain many syllables ḍa,[1938] And end with the syllable phaṭ [preceded by] huṁ,[1939] Are very cruel ones; They have great intensity and power. “They instantly block [the target’s] life force And may be skillfully employed [to target] cruel beings, Especially those that commit evil; They should not be used against any others.[1940]

rtag tu thub pas spangs pas na/ / 'bad de zlos pos spang bar bya/ / sngags ni zhi dang rgyas pa dag / gnyis kyi don ni 'grub 'gyur te/ / las la ji srid gsungs pa dag / skad cig gis ni thams cad 'grub/ / 'di dag sngags ni legs bzlas na/ / gzi brjid ldan zhing rdzu 'phrul che/ / rgyal bas gsungs pa'i sngags kyis ni/ / zhi ba'i las ni bya ba yin/ / rin chen rigs kyi bya ba ni/ / rgyas pa'i las ni thams cad do/ / gang dag sdig pa'i las rnams kun/ / mngon spyod la ni rab tu sbyar/ / mngon par spyod pa'i las rnams ni/ / rdo rje'i rigs kyis bya ba yin/ / 'jig rten mgon gyis bkag na yang / / gnod sbyin dbang la rab tu bstan/ /

“The reciter should always avoid Those things that are avoided by the sages. The mantras of pacifying and nourishing Will accomplish both [one’s own and others’] interests. “They can accomplish all the rites, Whatever have been taught. When they are recited the right way, Mantras possess energy and magical abilities. “One should perform rites of pacifying Using the mantras taught by the victorious ones.[1941] For all the rites of nourishing, One should use the mantras of the Jewel[1942] family. “All evil rites are employed In the activities of assault. All rites of assault should be performed Using the mantras of the Vajra family. Though forbidden by the lords of the world, Such mantras have been taught by the lord of yakṣas.[1943]

sems can rnams ni gdul ba'i phyir/ / sngags kyi che ba'i bdag nyid gsungs/ / rigs gsum nyid kyis thams cad du/ / rnam pa gsum du bstan pa yin/ / thub pa nyid kyis rigs dag ni/ / gang yang brgyad du yang dag bstan/ / grub pa de dag rnam gsum 'gyur/ / rnam pa gsum du yang dag bstan/ / mchog dang bar ma tha ma ni/ / de dag rnam pa gsum 'byed pa/ / zhi dang rgyas pa dag dang ni/ / mngon spyod par ni 'dod pa yin/ / sngags dang ldan pa nyid dag dang / / rgyud dang ldan pa kho nar bstan/ / sngags kyi 'gro ba'i bdag nyid che/ / mngon par spyod la sbyar ba yin/ / 'di dag las ni mi 'dod de/ / thub pa mchog gis smad pa yin/ / shin tu nyam ngar gyur kyang ni/ / srog la gnod las mi bya'o/ / mdor bsdu na ni ma 'dres par/ / las kyi bdag nyid chen por bstan/ / der ni rigs dang cho ga sngags/ / las ni rgya che rgya che ba/ / cho ga'i rgyal po 'di la gsungs/ / rgyud gzhan dag la'ang snang ba yin/ / las nyams rnams ni mi bsten cing / / sngags rnams kun la rigs par ldan/ / 'jig rten sngags rnams ji snyed pa/ / de bzhin cha bcas cha med pa'o/ / 'jig rten 'das pa thams cad kyang / / 'di 'dra'i yon tan shes par bya/ / sngags grub grangs ni med gyur kyang / / de grangs yongs su brjod par bya/ / dang po grangs gcig 'byung ba ste/ / de bzhin nyi shu'ang ldan par 'byung / / de nas mdor na sum cu ste/ / de las gzhan yang bzhi bcu yin/ /

“The mantras, in all their greatness,[1944] Manifest in order to guide sentient beings. They are said to be of three types, Always belonging to [one of] the three families. “As for the eight families Enumerated by the Sage himself, The accomplishment in them is threefold, As it arises in three different ways‍— Supreme, middling, or inferior. This is its threefold division. “It can be of a peaceful, Nourishing, or cruel type. This is taught exclusively In the context of mantra and tantra. “When the exalted function of mantras Is utilized in the activity of assault, Such rites are debased And condemned by all the omniscient ones. “Even when one is in trouble, one must not perform Any rite that interrupts the life force [of the target]. The magnitude of the karma incurred Is described here only briefly: “The karmic consequences of mantras Employed in tantric procedures are far reaching and extensive. This has been taught in this king of manuals And can also be found in other tantras. “Although one may be able to use any mantra, One should not perform inferior rites. Whatever worldly mantras there are, They are all of dubious benefit. “All the supramundane mantras, on the other hand, Are always endowed with good qualities. The mantra accomplishments are infinite, As they are proclaimed to be. “The count begins from one, But, similarly, twenty are described. Then thirty, if put briefly, And after that, forty.

de phyed bsnan na drug cu ste/ / de bzhin bcus bsnan bdun cu yin/ / de steng bcus ni bsnan pa la/ / brgyad cu'i grangs su gsungs pa yin/ / de la bcus bsnan dgu bcur gsungs/ / bcu gzhan gyis bsnan brgya yin te/ / brgya yi grangs kyis bgrang ba yi/ / de dag bcu la stong phrag gcig / stong phrag bcu la khri yin te/ / khri bcu la ni 'bum phrag gcig / 'bum phrag bcu la sa ya ste/ / sa ya bcu la bye ba yin/ / bye ba bcu la dung phyur ste/ / dung phyur bcu la ther 'bum yin/ / de bcu ther 'bum chen por bstan/ / de bcu la ni shu rdog ste/ / shu rdog bcu la mchog nyal yin/ / mchog nyal bcu la rkyang phye ste/ / rkyang phye chen po de bcu yin/ / de bcu la ni khyad phyin yin/ / khyad phyin chen po de bcu yin/ / de dag bcu la sgyu mar brjod/ / sgyu ma chen po de bcu yin/ / de bcu la ni mtsho yas zhes/ / 'jig rten 'dren pas gsungs pa yin/ / mtsho yas chen po de dag bcu/ / mtsho yas chen po de bcu la/ / dug chen pa yi rgya mtsho yin/ / de dag nyi shu'i phyed la ni/ / dug chen rgya mtsho chen po yin/ / dug chen rgya mtsho bcu la ni/ / mchog yas zhes ni brjod pa yin/ / mchog yas bcu zhes bstan pa ni/ / ban bun dag tu rab tu bstan/ / ban bun de dag bcu la ni/ / de ni ma lus pa zhes brjod/ / de dag nyi shu phyed la ni/ / ma lus chen po zhes su brjod/ / de tshe grangs kyi tshad du ni/ / 'jig rten 'dren pas gsungs pa yin/ / bcu yi grangs kyis bcur byas na/ / grangs ni grangs med ces su brjod/ / grangs med bcur ni bsgyur byas na/ / de las gzhan du dpag med yin/ /

“Next is sixty‍—[a number] divisible by three.[1945] With an extra ten, it becomes seventy. If another ten is added, The number, they say, is eighty. “If another ten is added, the number is called ninety, And with another ten, it is a full one hundred. One hundred now being the base for counting, Ten of these makes one thousand. “Ten thousands is one ayuta;[1946] Ten ayutas is one lakh. Ten lakhs is one vilakh (one million), And ten of these is one koṭi (ten million). “Ten koṭis is one vikoṭi (one hundred million), And ten of the latter is one arbuda (one billion). Ten arbudas is one nirbuda (ten billion), And ten of these is, as expected, one khaḍga (one hundred billion). “Ten khaḍgas is one nikhaḍga (one trillion), And ten nikhaḍgas is, as expected, one kharva (ten trillion). Ten kharvas is one padma (one hundred trillion), And ten padmas is one mahāpadma (one quadrillion). “Ten mahāpadmas[1947] is one vāha (ten quadrillion); Ten of these is one vivāha (one hundred quadrillion). The next after that is known as mahāvivāha (one quintillion), And ten of these is called māya (ten quintillion). “Ten māyas is one mahāmāya (one hundred quintillion); Mahāmāya, after another multiplication by ten, Is termed by the guides of the world samudrā (one sextillion), As [known] in the science of algebra. “The next number, after the multiplication By the ‘half of twenty,’ is mahāsamudrā (ten sextillion); Mahāsamudrā, when multiplied by ten, Is called sāgara (one hundred sextillion). “When multiplied by the ‘half of twenty,’ It becomes mahāsāgara (one septillion); The latter, multiplied by ten, Is called pragharā (ten septillion). “Ten pragharās, as they are called, Are proclaimed to be one gharā (one hundred septillion); Ten of the so-called gharās Are said to be one aśeṣa (one octillion). “Aśeṣa, multiplied by the ‘half of twenty,’ Becomes mahāśeṣa (ten octillion). This, according to the guides of the world, Is the limit beyond which a number is incomputable. “Counting is said to rely on multiplying by ten, But then, it is an incomputable number that is multiplied. Multiplying an incomputable number by ten Gives a number even more incomputable.[1948]

dpag med stong du bsgyur byas na/ / 'jig rten zhes ni yongs su bstan/ / 'jig rten de bcu 'jig rten che/ / 'jig rten chen po bsgres byas na/ / de 'og mun pa zhes su brjod/ / mun pa las ni snang bar brjod/ / snang ba chen po de dag bcu/ / de bcu la ni phung por brjod/ / phung po de bcu bsgres na ni/ / phung po chen por de brjod do/ / phung po chen po de bcu la/ / 'di ni zab pa zhes brjod do/ / zab pa las ni brtan par brjod/ / brtan pa la ni rab brtan 'gro/ / de nas gong du mang ldan yin/ / mang por 'dod pa gnas su brjod/ / rtsis shes dam pas gnas su brjod/ / de nas gnas ni chen por 'gro/ / chen po'i gnas zhes 'dod pa yin/ / dpag dang dpag med mnyam byas nas/ / de don chen por yongs su bsgrags/ /

“This world is proclaimed to be multiplied A thousandfold infinite number of times. The cosmic unit next to this world Is a great world, which is manifolded further. “Beyond that, there is the so-called darkness, And beyond that, the so-called light. After light is the so-called great light, And when this is multiplied, it is called multitude.[1949] “After the multitude is the so-called great multitude, And after the great multitude[1950] is one called the deep.[1951] After the deep is one called the stable, And after the stable comes the more stable. “Beyond that is the abundant,[1952] And beyond the abundant, the basis.[1953] According to those who delight in the art of enumeration, Beyond the basis[1954] is the more basic. “After that comes the great basis, And the one after the great basis is known as the fixed. When we have moved from the fixed to the more fixed,[1955] The next [on the list] is known as the great thing.[1956]

don chen rab 'byor gnas dang ni/ / de nas rgya mtsho chen por 'gro/ / dang po rgya mtsho chen por bstan/ / dang po'i dang por phan pa dang / / dang po mchog ces bya bar bstan/ / mchog las gtso bor brjod pa ste/ / gtso las khyim gyi ming yin no/ / de ni bsam mi khyab par brjod/ / bsam mi khyab las mi bzad gzugs/ / mi bzad gzugs las rgyal thabs 'dod/ / rgyal thabs las gzhan gter yin te/ / de yi 'og ma dge ba yin/ / dge ba'i pha rol sems las byung / / de las gzhan pa sems byung che/ / sems las sems ni rnam par g.yeng / / brjod pa zhes ni de la bya/ / brjod pa las ni brjod med nas/ / bsnyad yas su yang brjod pa yin/ / bsnyad yas las gzhan bsnyad yas che/ / de tshe phyar phyur zhes kyang brjod/ / phyar phyur las ni phyar phyur che/ / shu rdog de bzhin shu rdog che/ / rtsis kyi pha rol phyin pa'i gnas/ / dge zhing zhi ba zhes su bstan/ / de nas bgegs chen mthong ba ste/ / chu 'byung zhes ni de las brjod/ / chu 'byung de las sems 'phrul nas/ / de las gzhan pa dam pa yin/ / de las pha rol sangs rgyas yul/ / de las gzhan ni 'phel byed sa/ /

“After the great thing there is the famous basis,[1957] And after that comes the great ocean. After the great ocean is one called the primal, And after the primal is the more primal. “The one after the [more] primal is called excellent, And the one after the excellent, the most excellent. After the [most] excellent is one called dwelling place, And after the dwelling place, one known as the inconceivable. “[After] the inconceivable there is the terrible;[1958] [After that,] the terrible, the kingdom. Beyond the kingdom is the home of the treasure,[1959] And beyond[1960] that is the virtuous. “Beyond the virtuous is the great mind, And the next after that is the no-mind. After the no-mind is the confused mind,[1961] And after that is what is called expressible. “After the expressible is the inexpressible.[1962] Next is one called the universal,[1963] And after the universal is the great universal. Next is one called asvara.[1964] “After the asvara is the place of the great asvara, After which there is the kharva.[1965] The place auspicious peace is so called By those who have reached the limit of enumeration. “After the very courageous is the courageous,[1966] And then one called the watery. After the watery is the confused mind,[1967] And after that, another place [called] the ultimate. “Beyond the ultimate is the domain of the buddhas, With its superior levels.[1968]

'jig rten mi yi rtsis dag ni/ / bgrang bar yang ni mi nus so/ / de las gzhan du sangs rgyas kyi/ / go 'phang dang ni spyod yul yin/ / sangs rgyas zhing ni gang gA'i klung / / bye ma snyed du brjod pa ni/ / bsdus nas rdul gyi tshogs dag ni/ / 'dren pas bstan pa mdzad pa yin/ / 'di dag dper ni byas pa ste/ / tshad ma shes pa'i spyod yul min/ /

It is impossible for human beings to Go over all these world divisions. “There is nothing that would be regarded As superior to the domain of the buddhas.[1969] Buddhafields are believed To be as numerous as the grains of sand in the Gaṅgā. “Dissecting[1970] [the physical matter,] The guides [also] taught about the smallest particles. This was done by way of examples [Within] the domain of analytical investigation.[1971]

rgyu yis dngos po bsgrub bya ste/ / rtsis kyi pha rol phyin mi nus/ / 'di tsam rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas la/ / sngon ni nga yis bsnyen bkur byas/ / dpag med bskal pa dag tu ni/ / de dag la ni mnyes byas nas/ / de tsam dus kyi mthar thug par/ / nga ni byang chub sems dpar gyur/ / sems can don ni bsgrub bya'i phyir/ / sangs rgyas nyid du'ang yang dag bstan/ / de dang der ni bdag gi sngags/ / cho ga rgya chen bstan pa yin/ / cho ga yi ni rab mchog 'di/ / sangs rgyas 'di dag kun gyis gsungs/ / 'di tsam tshad kyi sangs rgyas kyis/ / sngon chad 'di ni gsungs pa yin/ / dus kyi tha ma'i skye bo la/ / gzhon nu nga yang nga yis bstan/ / ji snyed 'jig rten sngags rnams dang / / cho ga'i rgyal po'i snod dang ni/ / de bzhin 'jig rten 'das pa dang / / mi dang lha dang lha min dang / / thams cad kun gyi sngags rnams ni/ / rgyud dang rigs par rab tu bstan/ / cho ga'i rgyal po rdzu 'phrul che/ / gang du kun gyis yongs su bkur/ / de dag cho ga zhib mo yis/ / 'jam pa'i ngag ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyi cho ga ni/ / 'di nyid kyi ni zhib mo zhes/ / de dag 'grub par gsungs pa ste/ / thams cad kun pas mthu ldan 'gyur/ /

Physical matter can be established through logic (hetunā); It cannot be established by relying [solely] on enumeration.[1972] “In the past, I served fully realized buddhas Whose number matched such enumeration. I worshiped them During this inconceivable[1973] eon. In the infinity of time, I became a bodhisattva long ago. “For the sake of beings, I became fully realized and attained buddhahood. I taught tantra in different places, Providing full details of the rituals. “Taught by the buddhas, This supreme [manual of] rites is the best. It was taught to me[1974] in the past By so many fully realized buddhas. “And now, O divine youth, I teach it myself During my final embodied existence. However many worldly mantras And auspicious kings of rites there are, “However many supramundane or divine mantras there are Among men, gods, and asuras, I have explained tantric applications For all of them. “This king of manuals,[1975] celebrated everywhere, Has great magical power. By applying the ritual procedures of the mantras One will attain accomplishment and become like Mañjughoṣa.[1976] “It has been declared by Mañjughoṣa, The powerful lord, that by the sole means of This manual with its procedures All these [mantras] will be accomplished.[1977]

gang yang mi yi 'jig rten dang / / gang gzhan sngags kyi lha mo dang / / 'jig rten 'das pa'i sngags kun dang / / 'jig rten rdzu 'phrul che dang bcas/ / 'di nyid tshul gyi cho ga yis/ / cho ga'i rgyal pos 'grub pa nyid/ / sngags rnams kun dang cho ga kun/ / 'di yi dbang du 'gyur bar bstan/ / cho ga'i rgyal po bla med 'di/ / gang du 'jam dpal gyis rab bzhed/ /

“It is a foregone conclusion that Whatever other deity mantras[1978] there are‍— All the supramundane And mundane ones of great power‍— “They too can become accomplished By the ritual methods in this king of manuals. Mañjuśrī controls all the mantras In all the rites that have been taught‍— He is thus acclaimed In this supreme king of manuals.[1979]

gang yang bzo ni rnam par shes/ / 'jig rten pa yi 'jig rten 'dod/ / rgyu mtshan shes dang la nye bzang / / skar ma'i dpyad kyi rtags dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan shes dang spyod pa dang / / sgra skad dge dang mi dge dang / / 'byung po kun gyi skad shes dang / / spyod dang sems kyi spyod pa dang / / zur gyis shes pa dag kyang bshad/ / de bzhin gter lta nor sgyur byed/ / rtsis dang brda sprod bstan bcos dang / / gos kyi rim pa'i cho ga dang / / nang rig gso ba rig pa dang / / de nyid thams cad phan dang bde/ / gtan tshigs lugs kyi bstan bcos dang / / gzhan yang sgra yi bstan bcos bstan/ / sdeb sbyor rig byed dri za'i glu/ / spos sbyor dag kyang bstan pa yin/ / bdag gis byang chub sems kyis ni/ / sems can don phyir bshad pa yin/ / bdag ni byang chub sems sngon gyur/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtshor sngar gnas tshe/ / sems can rnams la phan pa'i phyir/ / bdag gis su ni bshad pa yin/ / 'khor ba'i dgon pa'i tshang tshing du/ / bdag ni yun ring dus su gnas/ / ji ltar gdul bya'i sems can la/ / de ltar bdag gis de bzhin byas/ / ji lta ji ltar sems can rnams/ / phan pa'i las ni len pa dag / phan don las kyis dge ba'i gzhi/ / de lta de ltar 'di dag byas/ / sna tshogs las kyis bsgyur ba yi/ / sems can 'gro ba'i skye gnas dag / 'di dag bya ba sna tshogs byas/ / sna tshogs skye gnas rab tu bstan/ /

“Whatever[1980] practical skills and branches of knowledge Are recognized in the world, Such as the omens taught in the art of prognostication And interpreted based on the knowledge of astrology; Whatever types of behavior are taught in the art of prognostication, Or auspicious and inauspicious sounds; “Whatever voices there are of whatever creatures That betoken their thoughts and behavior; Whatever elements, sense bases, substances, . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[1981]; “Whatever so-called portents or signs, Techniques (kriyā) of mining minerals, Algebra, grammar, sciences, Armaments, and ritual procedures; “Whatever knowledge of one’s inner being, medicine, And the welfare and happiness of all beings; Whatever art of logical argument (hetunīti) and other skills; Whatever established science of linguistics; “And whatever prosody, music, and the art of making perfumes there are‍— Whatever of these have been enumerated, I, the bodhisattva, have taught them In order to benefit sentient beings. “In former times, I, the bodhisattva, Knowing that they benefit beings, Taught them to the inhabitants Of the ocean of saṃsāra. “Living for a long time In the dense forests of saṃsāra, I act in the way that Brings beings to maturity. “I work for the benefit of beings, Creating for them stores of merit In every way that good karma Can be accumulated. “Established in various activities, Beings obtain [corresponding] types of birth. I perform various activities For those limited by birth who have various needs.[1982]

las rnams sna tshogs ldan pa yis/ / sna tshogs don gyi bstan bcos bstan/ / rnam pa sna tshogs gzugs ldan pas/ / 'di la de bzhin byas pa yin/ / sna tshogs 'gro ba'i skye gnas su/ / bdag gis de bzhin cha byad byas/ / phan pa'i bsam pas sems can la/ / sna tshogs gzugs ni bdag gis sprul/ / dbang phyug brgya byin tshangs pa sogs/ / khyab 'jug nor sbyin bden bral dang / / sna tshogs gza' yi gzugs sogs kyang / / de tshe sngon ni nga yis sprul/ / thugs rje chen po'i dbang gyur thugs/ / sems can bsam pa'i spyod yul can/ / de dag la ni rim gyis su/ / zhi ba'i gnas la bzhag pa yin/ / 'khor bar phan tshun 'gro ba na/ / yun ring dus su thogs pa ni/ / sems can rnams kyi don bsgrub phyir/ / sngags kyi tshul gyis bstan pa yin/ /

“Beings engage in various activities, Serving the different aims described in the śāstras. I fulfill these [aims] for them, Assuming various excellent forms. “I thus assume different guises, Using different bodies, be they my own or not.[1983] Motivated by [the wish] to benefit beings, I created different forms. “I created, in the past, [the forms of] Maheśvara, Śakra, Brahmā, and others; Viṣṇu, Dhanada, and Nairṛta; And also the different forms of the grahas. “With their minds full of great compassion, They are objects of refuge[1984] for beings. Gradually, I establish these beings In a state of peace. “I wander throughout saṃsāra, Observing beings over long periods of time. Being of the nature of the mantra, I bring the fulfillment of their needs.[1985]

yun ring 'khor ba'i skye bar ngas/ / sangs rgyas rigs la brten nas ni/ / ye shes sngags dang cho ga ni/ / mthar gyis bstan par byas pa yin/ / byed pa dang ni bdag po'ang rung / / nga la gang yang yod min te/ / nges pa'i rigs la brten nas ni/ / nga ni sangs rgyas byang chub mchog / bde ba nad med yang dag zhi/ / dri med mya ngan med zhi ba/ / ngas thob mya ngan 'das zhi ba/ / skye ba'i 'ching las nga rab grol/ / yang na 'khor lo rab bskor zhing / / yang dag mtha' la brten nas ni/ / sngags kyi tshig ni rgya chen dang / / cho ga 'di ni nga yis bstan/ / las dang cho ga rgya che ba/ / zlos pas don med mi bya'o/ /

“While wandering from birth to birth, I propagate, relying in the lineage of the Buddha, Mantric rituals[1986] that represent The gradual knowledge of the mantras. “For me, there is neither a creator, Nor an owner. Always relying on the lineage, I have realized the ultimate awakening. “I am at ease, un-aging,[1987] peaceful, Free from worry, pure, and benevolent. I have reached the peace of nirvāṇa And liberation from the fetters of birth. “Presently, the wheel that holds fast to the ultimate reality Is made to roll on, As I teach this manual That explains mantras at length. The reciter must not misuse This manual of rites in any of its details.

'jig rten ji snyed sngags rnams dang / / cho ga dag kyang rab bstan pa/ / de kun mchod cing ri mor bya/ / de dag la ni brnyas pa spang / / cho ga rgya chen de dag kyang / / des na sngags pas brnyas mi bya/ / rgyu mtshan shes dang rig pa dang / / skar ma'i dpyad shes skad shes pa/ / 'di dag don med mi bya ste/ / bkra shis don du bstan pa yin/ / mthong ba'i chos kyi don du yang / / grub pa'i rdzas sogs sman dang ni/ / zang zing bcas par mig sman 'grub/ / de las bkra shis 'grub pa yin/ / rab bsngags rgyal ba'i tshigs bcad dang / / bde legs tshigs bcad kyis brgyan pa/ / rab bsngags zhag ni bzang po dag / yar ngo dag gis legs mtshan pa/ / gza' mchog dkar ba dag ldan la/ / sngags sgrub pa ni brtsam par bya/ / de la sogs pa'i dge dang ldan/ / mi dge dag kyang spang bya ba/ / nga nyid kyis ni sngon bstan te/ / de bas zlos pas gzung bar bya/ / 'jig rten ji snyed gang su dag / skar ma'i dpyad la mkhas pa dang / / gzhan gyi rgyud la mkhas pa dang / / lugs kyi bstan bcos gtan tshigs bcas/ / rig pa'i bstan bcos legs 'brel ba/ / sems can rnams la phan byed gang / / de kun nga yis sngon gsungs te/ / sngags zlos pas ni gzung bar bya/ /

“Whatever worldly mantras there are, Their rituals have been taught accordingly. All these [mantras] should be worshiped and honored, Without any contempt whatsoever. Consequently, the practitioner of mantra Must also not disregard their [respective] rituals in any detail. “As for applying the knowledge of signs That has been taught as the science of astrology, One should not interpret these [signs] incorrectly. They have been taught for good purposes, “So that mundane pursuits, such as The preparation of power substances and other medicines, Or the healing [remedies] for the eyes,[1988] can succeed‍— They are thus described as beneficial. “The sayings of the victorious ones, adorned with the stanzas of benediction, Recommend the auspicious [settings]. One should choose a day during a bright fortnight Recommended as the best and indicated by auspicious signs. “With such auspicious and excellent planetary positions, One should commence the mantra practice. One should thus choose the auspicious [signs] And avoid the inauspicious. “I myself taught these things in the past; The mantra reciters should therefore accept them [as true]. Whatever benefits there are in this world That can be derived from the knowledge of astrology, “Or other such benefits[1989]‍— Those derived from polity and logic Or those well conceived in the treatises of Nyāya For the benefit of beings‍— “I have taught all of this And the mantra reciters should accept it [as true].

lam 'di grub pa'i rgyu yin par/ / de nyid gzigs pas bstan pa yin/ / grub pa'i mtha' ni mtha' dag kun/ / gang yin thar pa'i rgyur gsungs pa/ / sngags kyi lam gyi grub pa'i rgyur/ / nga nyid kyis ni byas pa yin/ / sngags kyi rig pa mtha' dag ni/ / zlos pas don med mi bya'o/ / 'jig rten pa yi sngags kun dang / / dam par yang ni rab bstan dang / / de bzhin 'jig rten 'das bzang po/ / thams cad kun la rab sbyar bya/ / sems ni log par mi bya ste/ / yid kyis nam yang sun mi dbyung / / sngags rnams kun la mchod byed pa/ / dam tshig shes pas rab tu bstan/ / sangs rgyas dgongs shing phan pa yin/ / de bzhin ston pa'i bstan pa la/ / rab zhugs rgyal ba'i sras rnams kyang / / zhugs par rab tu shes pa yi/ / thub zla'i dkyil 'khor dag la ni/ / 'di ni dam tshig shes par gsungs/ /

This path is the cause of accomplishment; It has been shown by those who know reality. “The entire [Buddhist] canon, as taught by me, Is wholly for bringing liberation. Because of this, one should follow the path of mantras, As they are the source of accomplishment. “The reciter must never, to any extent, Employ the mantras the wrong way, Be they any of the worldly mantras Or those proclaimed as supreme. “When employing, in any [rites], The supramundane mantras or the divine mantras [of magic], One must not harbor wrong thoughts And must never defile one’s mind. “One should worship all the mantra [deities] Approved for those who know the right time And taught in the instructions of the Teacher That are founded on the sameness of all buddhas.[1990] “These deities are the recourse of the victors’ sons; They are summoned and caused to enter Into the maṇḍala of the moon-like sages. They are here taught for those who know the right time.[1991]

rtag tu sngags rnams don yod de/ / yang dag bsams pa thob pa yin/ / gzhan dbang ngas ni ma byas te/ / brnyas pa dag kyang spyad ma yin/ / sngags rnams 'phags pa ma yin pa'ang / / de dag don med byas min brjod/ / 'jig rten ji srid sngags rnams sam/ / yang na gzugs su byung ba'ang rung / / kun nas nyon mongs mthong lam mtha'/ / de dag 'bras bu yod par bstan/ / khros dang zhe sdang ldan pa yis/ / don med par ni mi bya'o/ / mi 'dod gus pa med pa yi/ / las ni mi bya 'bras bu med/ /

“They are always effectual, and if one wishes them to enter, One can summon them with mantras.[1992] One should neither bow to submit to the mantras [deities] Of other systems, nor treat them with contempt, As it is said that the mantras that are debased Are not unproductive. “Whatever worldly mantras there are, Reciting them brings inferior results.[1993] Although they produce results for reciters, They will lead, as far as can be seen, to afflictions. “When one feels indignant and angry, One should not harbor wrong thoughts. Nor should one indulge in pleasures, As this brings adverse karmic results.[1994]

de dang 'brel ba'i sems la ni/ / nam yang de la sbyin mi bya/ / rtag tu mnyam par bzhag nas ni/ / sngags tshig ldan par bzlas byas shing / / cho ga ji bzhin gzung byas na/ / 'bras bu mtha' dag thob par 'gyur/ / yid ni g.yo med byas nas kyang / / sngags gcig de ni bzla bar bya/ / sngags ni don kun sgrub pa ste/ / rtse gcig sems kyis 'grub par 'gyur/ / rmongs pa'i bdag nyid g.yeng ba'i sems/ / de la grub pa 'grub mi 'gyur/ / gang la yid ni dag pa dang / / bstan pa la ni rab dad pa/ / 'bras bu mtha' dag 'grub pa ste/ / 'gro ba dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ / dkon mchog gsum la dad pa ni/ / 'dod pa'i grub par nye bar bstan/ /

One must not allow one’s mind To develop such inclinations. “One should stick with just one mantra And recite it continuously with a focused mind. One will consequently obtain the full result As specified in the ritual instructions. “Without allowing the mind to wander, One should recite the same mantra. Mantras accomplished through single-mindedness Will accomplish every purpose. “One who is distracted in mind and inwardly confused Will not see success. One should instead win the full array of results And a high rebirth. “One whose mind is always pure, Who trusts in the teachings[1995] And has faith in the Three Jewels, Will obtain the accomplishment as specified.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ las dang bya ba dang cho ga dang rgyu mtshan shes pa'i le'u rab 'byam las/ nyi shu rtsa bdun pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter that explains the knowledge of signs pertaining to the ritual activity procedures,[1996] thirty-third[1997] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
phyag rgya bskul ba'i cho ga 'jam dpal gyis yongs su zhus shing bstan pa'i le'u
Chapter 34
de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/
At that time the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and spoke to the divine youth Mañjuśrī as follows:

'jam dpal khyod kyi phyag rgya dang sngags rab 'byam mchog tu shin tu gsang ba nyon cig / ma dad pa'i sems can dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa la mngon par dad pa med pa dang / dam tshig med pa dang / gnang ba med pa dang / dkon mchog gsum gyi gdung rgyun gcod par byed pa dang / mi dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis yongs su zin pa dang / bsod nams mi 'dod pa dang / skye bo sdang ba dang / 'grogs shing 'dres pa dang / sdig pa'i grogs pos yongs su zin pa dang / sangs rgyas dang chos las thag ring du gyur pa dang / cho ga 'di la 'bras bu med par gyur pa dang / slob dpon gyi man ngag med pa dang / gzhon nu khyod kyi gsang ba'i dkyil 'khor la dbang ma bskur ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs la dam tshig ma mthong ba dang / skye bo mngon par mi 'dod pa dang / snod du ma gyur pa'i sems can rnams la bstan par mi bya'o/ /

“Listen, Mañjuśrī, to your most esoteric and secret teaching on your mudrās and mantras. No followers of your mantra path should ever disclose this teaching to people who have no trust and no faith in the doctrine of the Tathāgata; to people who do not have the authorizing samaya or do not maintain the continuity of the lineage of the Three Jewels; to people who are in bad company; to people who do not desire religious merit; to people who interact and mix with evil companions or are surrounded by bad friends; to people who distance themselves from the Buddha’s teaching; to people who have not been instructed by their master and so this manual would bring no results for them; to people, divine youth, who have not been initiated into your supreme and most secret maṇḍala; or to people who do not observe their samaya or who have no connection to the family of the Tathāgata.

sangs rgyas chos la ma dad dang / / byang chub lam ni ring gyur la/ / de la phyag rgya mi sbyin zhing / / rgyud nyid kyang ni bstan mi bya/ / bag med rmongs par gyur pa'am/ / yang na gal te chags pas byin/ / zlos pa phyin ci log byed la/ / de la sngags ni mi 'grub bo/ / phyag rgya nye bar mi 'gyur zhing / / sngags nyid kyang ni gzhan du 'gyur/ / myur du grub pa mi 'thob cing / / de yi lus kyang nyams par 'gyur/ / zhi zhing dad pa'i sems ldan dang / / der ni dam tshig mthong ba dang / / rgyud dang sngags la rab zhugs la/ / phyag rgya rgyud ni bstan par bya/ / dkon mchog gsum la mchod byed dang / / rgyal ba'i bstan la rab dad dang / / cho ga'i sbyor ba mthong ba dag / de dag la ni phyag rgya bstan/ / byang chub sems kyi cho ga shes/ / byang chub sems kyis rnam par brgyan/ / rtag tu byang chub lam la gnas/ / de dag la ni phyag rgya bstan/ / sngags dang rgyud la rab brtson zhing / / phan tshun brgyud pas dam tshig mthong / / byang chub chen por dam bcas pa/ / de la phyag rgya rab tu bstan/ /

“One without faith in the Buddha’s teachings Is far from realization. One should not teach mudrās Nor explain the tantra to such a person. “If someone stupefied by ignorance Should disclose them through carelessness, greed, and the like, The methods[1998] and mantras of such an errant reciter Will not be accomplished. “One should practice the mudrās And the mantras in seclusion, Otherwise accomplishment will not come soon, And one’s body will decline. “One can explain the art (tantra) of mudrās [Only] to those who are gentle, have faith, Are true to their samaya, And are advanced in the tantra and mantra. “One can explain it to those who Worship the Three Jewels, Have faith in the doctrine of the victorious ones, And know how to apply the procedure. “One can explain it to those Who are adorned with bodhicitta And, familiar with the methods of its generation, Always pursue the path to awakening. “One can explain the mudrās to those who engage In the practice of the mantras and tantras, Who observe their samaya in regard to the relative and the absolute And are committed to the great realization.
rgyal ba'i sras po dag dang ni/ / de bzhin nyan thos rang rgyal dang / / mthong ba'i chos kyi 'bras thob gang / / de la phyag rgya rab tu bstan/ /
“One can explain the mudrās to those who have faith In the sons of the victorious ones,[1999] In the śrāvakas and the solitary pratyekabuddhas, And who understand the results of Dharma practice.

chos rnams la ni rnam rtog med/ / dad cing ser sna bral ba dang / / ston pa'i bka' la rigs par shes/ / de la phyag rgya rab tu bstan/ / rtsa brgyad brgya yi tshad du ni/ / 'di dag phyag rgya phyag rgyas btab/ / lhag dang nyung ba ma yin par/ / mngon sum sangs rgyas kyis rab bshad/ / 'jam dpal gang gi cho ga la/ / sngags kyang de dang mnyam pa yin/ / brgyad bcas brgya zhes gsungs pa dang / / sngags rnams de dang mnyam par bstan/ / phyag rgya'ang brgya ni rtsa brgyad du/ / thub pa mchog gis sngon gsungs so/ / 'di tsam tshad du cho ga la/ / phyag rgya sngags ni yang dag 'byung / / sangs rgyas kun gyi mdzod nyid ni/ / sngags kyi mdzod du nye bar bstan/ / phyag rgya sngags ni mnyam ldan na/ / yang dag ldan pas las myur byed/ /

“One can explain the mudrās to those Who see phenomena without conceptual contrivance, Who have faith, are free from avarice, And know how to apply the Teacher’s instructions. “These mudrā seals are themselves sealed. Their exact number is one hundred and eight‍— No fewer and no more than that Have been proclaimed by the buddhas. “[The number of] mantras In Mañjuśrī’s manual is the same. One hundred and eight mantras Have been taught, As have one hundred and eight mudrās By the eminent sages in the past. “This number is the standard For the mudrās and mantras found in this manual. It is a treasury of all the buddhas Referred to as a mantra treasury. Mudrās used in combination with mantras Accomplish activities swiftly.

'khor lo med pa'i shing rta ni/ / rigs par 'gro bar mi 'byung ste/ / de bzhin sngags rnams ma lus pa/ / phyag rgya med par las mi byed/ / sngags dang phyag rgya mnyam ldan zhing / / yang dag ldan pas myur las byed/ / lha dang lha min bcas pa yi/ / 'jig rten gsum kun 'gugs byed na/ / las gzhan dag gis legs sbyar ba'i/ / mi yi 'jig rten smos ci dgos/ / mthong chos 'bras bu 'di dag gi/ / phyag rgya sngags la snang ba yis/ / gnyi ga ldan zhing dag pa dang / / cho ga ldan pa'i don bstan na/ / rgyal ba mchog dang sras rnams dang / / 'byung po rnams ni 'gugs par byed/ / sngags dang phyag rgya dka' thub nyid/ / rnam gsum las ni legs gnas dang / / ci 'dod phun sum tshogs pa kun/ / de bzhin zlos pas thob par 'gyur/ / sngags rnams phyag rgyas phyag rgya btab/ / sngags kyis kyang ni de rgya btab/ / sngags ni phyag rgya med pas min/ / sngags kyang phyag rgya spangs pas min/ / phyag rgya sngags ni mnyam ldan na/ / yang dag ldan pas las kun byed/ / 'di dag phan tshun 'bras bu ste/ / phan tshun 'bras bu 'byung ba yin/ / sgrub pas rigs ldan sbyar byas na/ / bsgrub bya min pa'i las rnams med/ /

“Just as a chariot would never roll on Without wheels, So also no mantra Will accomplish its activity without a mudrā. Mantras used in combination with mudrās Accomplish activities swiftly. “They can summon everyone within The entire triple universe with its gods and asuras, Let alone accomplish other activities In the cultivated[2000] world of humans. “When mudrās and mantras Are used together and are pure, The results will be seen in real life. They will manifest based on the applied procedure. “They can summon spirits, As well as the eminent victors along and their sons. There are three accessories that make rites effective: Mantras, mudrās, and austere meditation. “The reciter can obtain Any accomplishments as desired If the mantras are sealed with the mudrās, And the mudrās with the mantras. “If no mantra is without a mudrā And no mudrā without a mantra, The mudrās thus employed along with the mantras Will accomplish every activity. “Mutually they produce results, Which arise in mutual dependence. If the practitioner applies them in tandem, There is no activity that could not be accomplished.

phyag rgya ldan pa'i zlos pa pos/ / sngags rnams ma lus 'grub par 'gyur/ / cho ga mthong bas rab brtson zhing / / sngags dang phyag rgya kun byas na/ / gang du 'gugs 'gyur mi 'grub pa/ / de gnas de ni yod ma yin/ / srid rtse mnar med bar dang ni/ / 'jig rten khams kyi 'gro ba gzhan/ / gang du mi 'bebs mi 'gugs dang / / bsgrub bya ma yin gang yang med/ / sems can skye gnas las skyes dang / / byang chub sems dpa' mi snang ba'ang / / cho gas bskul nas mi 'gugs pa/ / de ni gang yang yod ma yin/ / srung ba'i cho ga'i rgyud dag gam/ / las 'grub bzlog par bya ba la/ / sa bcu la ni gnas pa yi/ / byang chub sems dpas kyang mi nus/ / sngags dang phyag rgya la gnas la/ / 'byung po kun gyis mi tshugs so/ /

“All mantras will succeed if used along with mudrās By those endowed with a physical form.[2001] The mantra should be employed according to procedure And sealed with a mudrā.[2002] “Even if one were to cross all the worlds From the pinnacle of existence down to Avīci Hell, There is no such place from where a being Could not be successfully summoned, “Nor a place where a being could not be controlled Even though they had not been summoned. Nor is there any being Able to resist [this ritual]. “Even bodhisattvas of great power can be summoned And induced to speak if the procedure is followed. They are unable to invalidate the protection procedure Or thwart the successful outcome of a rite, Even if they are established On the tenth level. “Beings who rely on mantras and mudrās Are unassailable by any spirits.[2003]

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[2004] When employed as part of the procedure Mudrās become a source of protection.[2005] “They accompany all the mantras And can be seen [used] with each of them. So, too, each mudrā is accompanied by a mantra‍— They belong one with the other.

dka' thub bzlas pa cho ga'i lam/ / sbyin sreg las la rab sbyar na/ / 'di las skye zhing de las grub/ / phyag rgya sngags la snang ba yin/ / zlos pa rtag tu 'bad brtson zhing / / rtag tu de dag la gnas na/ / sngags rnams grub par 'gyur ba ste/ / don yod 'gyur bar thub pa'i bka'/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi gsung dag ni/ / de dag gis ni gzhan du byed/ / sngags dang rgyud ni rigs pa la/ / gang zhig rtag tu mi 'jug pa'o/ /

“If the procedures involving form[2006] and recitation Are employed in the rites of homa, They will be a source of accomplishment; The mudrās are assigned to the mantras. “For someone who is constantly engaged in And always relies on the recitation of mantras, All the mantras will be effective. The words of the sages are not spoken in vain‍— “Those who distort The teachings of all the buddhas Will never be able to apply[2007] The art of mantras correctly.

sngags dang phyag rgya mtha' dag ni/ / gang zhig cho ga ldan byed pa'o/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nu 'di dag ni/ / yang dang yang du bstan pa yin/ / sngags kyi rig pa mtha' dag ni/ / phyag rgyas sngags ni phan pa 'byung / / de srid las la cho ga'i rgyal/ / 'dis ni 'bras bu rgya chen 'byung / / 'jig rten gsang mchog phan pa dang / / sngags dang phyag rgyas dam bcas pa/ / de nas rigs ldan 'jam dpal te/ / khyab par byed pa byis pa'i gzugs/ / cung zad 'dzum pa'i bzhin gyur gnas/ / gzhon nu sna tshogs yang dag 'byung / / byang chub sems dpa' brtson 'grus che/ / sa bcu la ni gnas pa yis/ / sangs rgyas nyi ma'i gnyen gyur pa/ / thub pa mchog la rab tu zhus/ / bcom ldan sngags kyi rgyud dag ni/ / gang yin 'di ni 'jig rten bstan/ / sngon gyi sangs rgyas dag gis kyang / / de yang bdag la gsungs pa yin/ /

Those who apply the teachings [correctly] Follow the procedure complete with the mantra and the mudrā.[2008] “I say this, Mañjuśrī, divine youth, Again and again, that A mudrā, when complemented by a mantra, Is a source of benefit. “I applaud the result derived from this king of manuals, Which is to ferry [beings] out of [saṃsāra]. The art of mudrās constitutes The most secret boon for the world.”[2009] Then, smiling softly, The divine youth who is the origin of everything, Clever, glorious, and forbearing, With the form of a young boy, The bodhisattva of great courage Established on the tenth level, said, “Please explain, O supreme of sages, The buddha Friend of the Sun,[2010] [Why it is] that you, O Blessed One, For the sake of mantras, teach in this world “That which has already been taught to me By the fully realized buddhas in the past.

de ltar shAkya seng ge yis/ / ci yi phyir na rab tu gsungs/ / bdag ni de ltar the tshom 'tshal/ / thub pa mchog gis bdag la gsungs/ / blo ldan ka la ping ka'i skad/ / tshangs pa yi ni gsung dbyangs kyis/ / sa bcu la ni rab gnas pa'i/ / byang chub sems dpa' la gsungs pa/ / sngon ni bskal pa mang po ru/ / nga ni 'khor bar 'khor ba na/ / thub dbang me tog kun skyes las/ / cho ga'i rgyal po'ang nga yis thob/ /

Why is the Lion of the Śākyas Teaching it [again] now? This uncertainty is born [in me], So please explain [this], O supreme sage!” The learned one with the sweet voice of a cuckoo That resembles the powerful voice of Brahmā Replied to the bodhisattva [Mañjuśrī], Who was established on the tenth level, “Formerly, while wandering In saṃsāra over many eons, I obtained this king of manuals From the sage called Saṃkusuma.[2011]

de dang der ni sems can la/ / phan pa mang po byas pa yin/ / thugs rje'i dbang du song nas ni/ / de tshe bdag gi smon lam byas/ / sangs rgyas mchog tu de tshe bdag / dus kyi mthar ni yang dag byung / / chos kyi 'khor lo bskor nas ni/ / bstan pa'i don ni byas pa yin/ / phyi ma yi ni dus dag tu/ / de tshe nga ni mya ngan 'da'/ / de na cho ga'i rgyal dbang po/ / khyod kyi drung du nga yis bstan/ / nga yang 'jig rten mya ngan 'das/ / 'dzam bu'i gling ni rab stongs shing / / de bzhin ston pa'i chos kyi mdzod/ / rtsod dus thag ring gyur pa na/ / sems can rnams la bstan pa'i don/ / cho ga'i rgyal po gcig byed 'gyur/ / cho ga'i rgyal po rgya chen la/ / de bzhin 'di ni yang dag 'jug / sems can rnams ni don la brtson/ / de yi tshe na 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de dus 'jigs su rung ba yi/ / de tshe sems can chos ldan min/ / rtag tu lus la mi gnas shing / / rgyal po rnams ni ma rungs yid/ /

“[Wandering] from place to place, I brought about much help for beings. Swayed by the power of compassion, I formed an aspiration then That I would become, during the debased eon, The supreme buddha. “Having fulfilled the goal of teaching And having set the Dharma wheel rolling, In the final period Before I would pass into nirvāṇa on earth, I would teach this king of manuals In your presence. “When I have departed into nirvāṇa And the world that is called Jambu[2012] is empty, When the Dharma basket of the Teacher Is difficult to find, during the lowest eon, This king of manuals would fulfill The purpose of instructing beings. “This king of manuals, with its extensive contents, Is [now] entrusted to you in particular,[2013] So that it will be used, at that time,[2014] For the benefit of beings. “At that terrible time, People will be without Dharma. Never following any rules,[2015] The kings will be full of ill will.

mi dang mi ma yin rnams ni/ / kun kyang bstan la rnam par sdang / / ngas bshad chos kyi mdzod rnams ni/ / nga yi thams cad 'jig par 'gyur/ / de dag gdul ba'i don gyi phyir/ / sngags kyi mdzod ni nye bar bstan/ / bskal pa bsam mi khyab par sngon/ / gzhon nu khyod kyi smon lam 'di/ / sangs rgyas ji snyed gang su dag / 'jig rten gnyen gyur mya ngan 'das/ / de dag bstan pa'i don du ni/ / dus dang dus su bya'o zhes/ / bdag ni byis pa gzhon nu'i gzugs/ / dus kun tu ni rnam par spyod/ / sngags kyi gzugs kyis sems can la/ / de dang der ni rnam par 'dul/ / gzhon nu khyod kyi smon lam 'di/ / sngon chad du ni byas pa yin/ / nga ni byis pa'i gzugs thob gyur/ / des na khyod la bshad par bya/ /

“Both humans and nonhuman beings Will all be hostile to the teaching. They will destroy the entire Dharma basket That I have taught. “The mantra basket was taught In order to guide them. It was for you, O divine youth, that I made this aspiration Throughout inconceivable past eons:[2016] “ ‘Whatever buddhas, friends of the world, have existed, Who are now in the state of nirvāṇa, I will strive to spread their doctrine Eon after eon. “ ‘I will travel everywhere In the form of a young boy And guide beings In the form of the mantra, time after time.’ “This aspiration, O divine youth, I made in the past for you. This has now come to pass, O youth! This is my instruction to you:[2017]

skye bo skyabs ni med pa dang / / sangs rgyas zhing ni stongs pa na/ / sngags kyi gzugs kyis sems can la/ / byis pa'i tshul gyis yang dag shod/ / sems can mang po 'dul byed cing / / phun sum tshogs pa sbyin byed pa/ / dus kyi tha ma de la ni/ / sems can kun la mchog sbyin byed/ / 'jig rten nga ni mya ngan 'das/ / sa yi steng ni stongs gyur na/ / khyod nyid byis pa'i gzugs kyis ni/ / sangs rgyas mdzad pa byed par 'gyur/ / de tshe dgon chen rab dga' ba/ / kha ba can nang yod pa yi/ / chu bo gser dang ldan 'gram du/ / nga ni mya ngan 'da' bar 'gyur/ /

“When the buddhafield is empty And people are without refuge, You should instruct them, as a young boy, In the form of the mantra. “You will guide many beings, Granting them every good fortune. At that time, during the debased eon, You will grant boons to all beings. “When I have departed from this world into nirvāṇa, And the land has become empty, You will carry on the Buddha’s work In the form of a young boy. “At that time, I will enter nirvāṇa In the delightful wilderness Of the foothills of the Himalayas, On the bank of the Hiraṇyavatī.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ phyag rgya bskul ba'i cho ga 'jam dpal gyis yongs su zhus shing bstan pa'i le'u rab 'byam las/ nyi shu rtsa brgyad pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter with the instructions on the procedures enhanced by the stimulus of mudrās, given in response to Mañjuśrī’s inquiry, thirty-fourth[2018] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.

Chapter 35

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i phyag rgya'i mdzod yang dag par bskul ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ / snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i mdzod spu nas 'od zer du ma bye ba khri phrag brgya stong grangs med pa'i 'khor dang bcas pa byung ste/ / 'od zer gyi dra ba du ma des sangs rgyas kyi zhing du ma gsal bar byas nas/ sangs rgyas thams cad la yang dag par bskul nas/ phyir yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i mdzod spur zhugs par gyur to/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la yang dag par bskul ma thag tu nam mkha'i ngo bo nyid kyi ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs te/ gnas gtsang ma'i steng gi nam mkha'i dkyil du bzhugs par gyur to/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas sangs rgyas thams cad la mchod nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal phyag rgya'i le'u'i cho ga'i mdzod sangs rgyas thams cad kyi byin gyis brlabs pa bshad kyis nyon cig /

At that time the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and entered the samādhi called that which animates the great receptacle of mudrās of the tathāgatas. As soon as he entered this samādhi, a great light issued from the tuft of hair between his eyebrows. This mass of light, surrounded by innumerable billions of light rays, illuminated many buddhafields, arousing all the buddhas [dwelling there], and entered back into Lord Śākyamuni’s tuft of hair. As soon as they were roused, all the blessed buddhas entered the samādhi of the nature of the sky and positioned themselves in the sky above the Pure Abode. Having greeted all of them reverentially, the blessed Śākyamuni spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, as follows: “Listen, Mañjuśrī, about the procedures pertaining to the receptacle of mudrās, blessed by all the buddhas to come.”

de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas sangs rgyas thams cad kyi zhabs la btud de phyag 'tshal nas/ bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi mdzod kyi phyag rgya mchog tu shin tu gsang ba gang yin pa de dus la bab par mkhyen na/ bcom ldan 'das de ni legs te bshad du gsol/ skye bo mang po la phan pa dang skye bo mang po la bde ba dang 'jig rten la snying brtse ba dang skye bo'i tshogs mang po'i don dang phan pa dang bde ba'i phyir dang lha dang mi rnams dang sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde ba dang bde ba'i rnam par smin par 'gyur ba'i slad du'o/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas gsol ba btab nas/ phyag rgya thams cad la gzigs shing sangs rgyas thams cad la mkhyen par byas nas/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad rab tu dga' bar byed pa/ 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad yang dag par tshim par byed pa/ 'phags pa'i sngags rnams la yid brtson par byed pa la yang dag par gzengs stod pa/ ma rungs pa thams cad zlog par byed pa/ 'jigs pa thams cad dbugs 'byin par byed pa/ 'khor bar gnas pa dag la bde ba dang shis pa dang mya ngan las 'das pa la rab tu 'jog par byed pa/ sems can sdug bsngal ba thams cad la bde ba'i don gyi phyir phyag rgya'i le'u'i cho ga ngas bshad kyis

Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, prostrated to the feet of the Blessed One,[2019] bowed to all the buddhas, and spoke to blessed Tathāgata Śākyamuni as follows: “Very good, O Blessed One! Please teach, if you think that the time is right, the most secret chapter on the receptacle of the mudrās of all the tathāgatas. This will be for the benefit and happiness of many people. Teach it out of kindness for the world, for the welfare and happiness of great numbers of people. This will create happiness and the ripening [of the causes of] happiness for gods, men, and all beings.” Being thus supplicated by Blessed Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, the blessed Śākyamuni began to teach, gazing at all the buddhas, directing his attention to all the beings,[2020] gladdening all the bodhisattvas, perfectly calming all the pratyekabuddhas and noble śrāvakas, animating all those whose minds were occupied with the meaning of their respective mantras,[2021] keeping all the evil beings at bay, restoring confidence in all the frightened ones, and establishing in the ease of the auspicious nirvāṇa all those that were in difficult predicaments. For the happiness of all suffering beings, he taught the procedures from the chapter on the mudrās as follows:
'jam dpal gzhon nu nyon cig /
“Listen, Mañjuśrī, divine youth, As I teach the chapter on mudrās.

dang po gtsug phud lnga pa ni/ / de ni phyag rgya chen por 'dod/ / gnyis pa gtsug phud gsum pa yin/ / ral pa gcig pa gsum pa ste/ / bzhi pa ut+pa lar gsungs pa/ / rkang gnyis dam pa rdzogs sangs rgyas/ /

First comes the five-crested Known as a ‘great mudrā.’[2022] “One should know the three-crested as the second, And the single-crested as the third. The perfect buddhas, best of two-legged beings, Call the fourth one the utpala.[2023]

lnga pa bkra shis ldan du brjod/ / drug pa rgyal mtshan zhes su brjod/ / bdun pa gang ba zhes bstan te/ / sngags shes dag la legs mdzes shing / / brgyad pa srog shing zhes brjod pa/ / sngags shes dag la legs mdzes yin/ / dgu pa gdugs zhes bstan pa ste/ / bcu pa mdung du brjod pa yin/ / de bzhin bcu gcig sangs rgyas kyis/ / kha sbyar zhes ni yang dag bstan/ / bcu gnyis pa ni phub ces gsungs/ / bcu gsum pa ni da pus yin/ / bcu bzhi pa ni ral grir bshad/ / de bzhin dril bu bcwa lnga pa/ / bcu drug pa ni zhags par bstan/ / bcu bdun pa ni lcags kyur shes/ / bcwa brgyad pa ni bzang po'i gdan/ / bcu dgu pa ni gdan du brjod/ / nyi shur bstan pa rma bya'i gdan/ / nyi shu gcig pa paT+Ti saM/ / rtags gcig nyi shu gnyis pa ste/ / rtags gnyis nyi shu gsum pa yin/ / de bzhin phreng ba nyi shu bzhi/ / nyi shu lnga pa gzhu yin te/ /

“The swastika is regarded as the fifth, And the banner as the sixth. Those adorned by the knowledge of mantras Call the seventh one the complete. “The conquering lords of the world[2024] Called the eighth the stick, The ninth, the parasol, And the tenth, the javelin. “The eleventh is called By the perfect buddhas the hollow space,[2025] The twelfth, the shield, And the thirteenth, the mace. “The fourteenth is called the sword, And the fifteenth, the bell. The sixteenth is known as the noose, And the seventeenth as the goad. “The auspicious seat is the eighteenth, And the nineteenth, the seat. The peacock seat is said to be the twentieth, And the three-pointed lance, the twenty-first. “The one-pointed lance is the twenty-second, And the two-pointed lance, the twenty-third. The twenty-fourth mudrā is the rosary, And the twenty-fifth, the bow.
nyi shu drug par gsungs pa ni/ / lcags mda' dag tu rnam par brtags/ / nyi shu bdun par gsungs pa ni/ / rtags kun dag tu rab tu bstan/ /
“The twenty-sixth is designated as The iron arrow, And the twenty-seventh Is called the even-pointed lance.[2026]

nyi shu brgyad pa gsal shing ste/ / nyi shu dgu pa tho ba yin/ / sum cu pa ni mda' bo che/ / sum cu gcig pa mche bar bstan/ / sum cu gnyis pa de bzhin kha/ / sum cu gsum pa ras kyi gos/ / sum cu bzhi pa bum pa ste/ / sum cu lnga pa 'khar gsil yin/ / sum cu drug pa bya ma bum/ / sum cu bdun pa gtun shing ste/ / sum cu brgyad pa skyil krung yin/ / sum cu dgu pa pa Ta ha/ / bzhi bcu par ni rab bstan pa/ / chos kyi dung zhes nye bar bstan/ / bzhi bcu dag ni gcig pa yang / / lcags thag ces ni yongs su bsgrags/ / gnyis par 'dod pa mang por gsungs/ / gsum pa yid la re ba rdzogs/ / bzhi pa skyed byed snang ba ste/ / shes rab pha rol phyin par 'dod/ /

“The twenty-eighth is the spear (śūla), And the twenty-ninth, the hammer. The thirtieth is the hatchet,[2027] And the thirty-first, the fangs. “The thirty-second is the mouth, And the thirty-third, the cloth. The thirty-fourth is the jar, And the thirty-fifth, the mendicant’s staff. “The pitcher is said to be the thirty-sixth, And the club, the thirty-seventh. The thirty-eighth is the cross-legged posture, And the thirty-ninth, the kettledrum. “What they name as the fortieth Is the Dharma conch. The chain is proclaimed To be the forty-first. “The forty-second is called the highly esteemed, And the forty-third, the fulfilled wish. The forty-fourth is regarded as The mother Prajñāpāramitā.

lnga pa ma mo zhes bshad pa/ / rkang gnyis rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyis/ / drug pa rta babs zhes byar gsungs/ / bdun pa rta babs bzang po yin/ / brgyad pa sgra skad dag tu bstan/ / dgu pa rgyal ba'i sgra yang yin/ / lnga bcu pa ni rnga bo che/ / lnga bcu gcig pa chos kyi rnga/ / lnga bcu gnyis pa ba lang bshad/ / gsum pa lag pa mchog yin te/ / lnga bcu bzhi par shes bya ba/ / phyag rgya de ni 'khrul med yin/ / lnga bcu lnga pa mjug rings yin/ / lnga bcu drug pa mda' yin te/ / bdun pa dag ni dgra star bstan/ / brgyad pa 'jig rten gyis mchod yin/ / lnga bcu rtsa dgur shes bya ba/ / mdor na mtshon ni rtse gcig yin/ / drug cu par ni 'gyur ba yang / / mdor na gshol du shes par bya/ / drug cu gcig pa pad+ma ste/ / drug cu gnyis pa rdo rjer bshad/ /

“The perfect buddhas, best of two-legged beings, Call the forty-fifth the bowl.[2028] The forty-sixth is called the archway, And the forty-seventh, the fine archway. “The forty-eighth is known as the voice, And the forty-ninth, the sound of recitation.[2029] The fiftieth is the drum, And the next after that, the Dharma drum. “The fifty-second is the elephant, And the fifty-third, the supreme hand. The fifty-fourth mudrā should be known as The movement in the direction of that.[2030] “The fifty-fifth is called the comet, The fifty-sixth, the bow and arrow,[2031] The fifty-seventh, the axe, And the fifty-eighth, the worshiped by the world. “The fifty-ninth should be known, briefly, As the short javelin, And the sixtieth is designated, briefly, As the plow. “The sixty-first is the padma,[2032] And the sixty-second, the vajra.

chos kyi 'khor lo skor byed pa/ / 'jig rten drug cu gsum par gsungs/ / drug cu bzhi par shes bya ba/ / mdor na pad+ma dkar po yin/ / drug cu lnga par shes bya ba/ / phyag rgya mchog sbyin dam pa yin/ / de nas drug cu drug pa ni/ / theg pa'i phyag rgyar sangs rgyas gsungs/ / drug cu bdun par 'jig rten du/ / mkhas pas mdung du bstan pa yin/ / drug cu brgyad par bya ba ni/ / rdo rje dbyug pa'i phyag rgyar gsungs/ / drug cu rtsa dgur 'gyur ba ni/ / dgra 'joms byed par rab tu bstan/ / bdun cu par ni shes bya ba/ / mdor na klu yi phyag rgya yin/ / bdun cu gcig par gsungs pa ni/ / gzhal med phyag rgya mchog bzang yin/ / bdun cu gnyis pa mdor bsdu na/ / shing rta zhes ni de la brjod/ / mdor na bdun cu gsum pa ni/ / 'jig rten mgon gyi gdan du gsungs/ /

The sixty-third is said, in this world, To be the revolving Dharma wheel. “The sixty-fourth should be known, Briefly, as the water lily (puṇḍarīka). The sixty-fifth one should know As the supreme boon-granting mudrā. “The sixty-sixth is called By the buddhas the rope.[2033] The knowledgeable call The sixty-seventh the spear (kunta).[2034] “The sixty-eighth is designated As the vajra staff, And the sixty-ninth is known as The killer of hundreds.[2035] “The next mudrā, the seventieth, One should know, briefly, as the boat.[2036] The seventy-first, the excellent, auspicious mudrā, Is called the palace. “The seventy-second, briefly, Is called the chariot. The lords of the world call The seventy-third the resting place.

de bzhin bdun cu bzhi dang ni/ / bdun cu lnga ru bstan pa dag / tshes brgyad zla ba pi bang dag / phyag rgya gnyis su bstan pa yin/ / bdun cu rtsa drug 'jig rten du/ / phyag rgya pad+ma 'dra ba yin/ / bdun cu bdun pa'i phyag rgya mchog / ut+pa la ni 'byung ba'i gnas/ / bdun cu brgyadapa'i phyag rgya ni/ / phyag 'tshal ba zhes bstan pa yin/ / bdun cu rtsa dgu mchod yon rgya/ / dgra bcom phyag rgya brgyad cu pa/ / mar me brgyad cu gcig par shes/ / thal sbyar brgyad cu gnyis par 'dod/ / gsum pa phreng ba zhes bya ba'o/ / bzhi pa gdan zhes gsungs pa yin/ / lnga pa gnas kyi phyag rgyar bstan/ / drug pa rab gnas gsungs pa ste/ / bdun pa dbang gi phyag rgyar brjod/ / brgyad cu brgyad pa mchog tu 'dod/ / dgu dang dgu bcu'i grangs dag ni/ / phyag rgya gnyis ni dge ba mchog / kha sbyar zung gi phyag rgya ste/ / grangs ni dgu bcu 'byung ba ste/ / dgu bcu rtsa gcig ces gsungs pa/ / me tog gi ni phyag rgyar bstan/ / gnyis pa gtor ma'i phyag rgya ste/ / gsum pa rtag tu spos kyi yin/ / bzhi pa dri yi phyag rgya ste/ / lnga pa mar mer shes par bya/ /

“The two mudrās, The seventy-fourth and the seventy-fifth, Are called, respectively, The lute and the half-moon.[2037] “The seventy-sixth, in this world, Is the mudrā abode of lotuses. The superior seventy-seventh Is the mudrā birthplace of water lilies. The seventy-eighth mudrā Is called the salutation.[2038] “The seventy-ninth is the drinking water And the eightieth is the foe destroyer. The eighty-first is known as the lamp And the eighty-second is designated as the joined palms. “The eighty-third is called the garland And the eighty-fourth the seat.[2039] The eighty-fifth is taught as the place, And the eighty-sixth is the consecration. The eighty-seventh is called the initiation, And the eighty-eighth is designated as the supreme. “The[2040] mudrās that are counted as the eighty-ninth And the ninetieth are both supremely auspicious; They are the hollow space and the couple, Which brings the count to ninety. “The ninety-first mudrā Is called the flower, The ninety-second, the bracelet,[2041] The ninety-third is always the incense, The ninety-fourth, the perfume, And the ninety-fifth, the lamp.

drug pa sbyor bar shes par bya/ / bdun pa skyil krung phyed kyi gnas/ / brgyad pa dag ni bong ba ste/ / dgu pa dag ni gshegs su gsol/ / de bzhin brgya rdzogs phyag rgya ni/ / thams cad pa yi las shes bya/ / brgya las rtsa gcig gsungs pa ni/ / phyag rgya chen po zhes bya ste/ / gtsug tor 'jig rten mgon po ni/ / rtag tu bla ma 'khor los sgyur/ / phyag rgya de ni dang por gsungs/ / gnyis pa gdugs dkar las byung yin/ / gsum pa rtsa ba'i phyag rgya ste/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs su snang ba yin/ / bzhi pa chos kyi mdzod kyi gnas/ / chos kyi phyag rgyar shes par bya/ / lnga pa dge 'dun zhes bya ste/ / de ni phyag rgya chen po'ang yin/ / drug pa 'byung po zhi byed pa/ / rang rgyal lag pa'i phyag rgya nyid/ /

“The ninety-sixth should be known as the formal practice, And the ninety-seventh as the sitting posture.[2042] The ninety-eighth is the summoning,[2043] And the ninety-ninth is the dismissing. “The mudrā that completes the count of one hundred Is the suitable for all rites. As for the mudrās beyond these one hundred, They are known as ‘great’ mudrās. “Among the uṣṇīṣa lords of the world, The most senior is always Cakravartin. His mudrā is said to be the 101st. The 102nd belongs to Sitātapatra. “The 103rd is regarded as The root mudrā of Mañjughoṣa. The 104th mudrā, which constitutes the treasury of the Dharma, Has been designated as the Dharma mudrā. “The 105th is called the saṅgha; This one, too, is a ‘great’ mudrā. The 106th, the pacifier of beings, Brings on [the state of] a pratyekabuddha or an arhat.

bdun pa byang chub sems dpa' ni/ / sa bcu dag la zhugs pa yi/ / phyag rgya pad+ma'i phreng ba ste/ / phyag rgya chen por de shes bya/ / 'jig rten pa ni thams cad kyi/ / phyag rgya sngags rnams mchog sbyin byed/ / mthu chen gtso bo chen po ste/ / gtso bo 'jig rten gsum gyis mchod/ / brgyad pa yang dag rab sbyar ba/ / phyag rgya srid gsum skye gnas yin/ / phyag rgya rnams kyi grangs bstan pa/ / rgyud 'di las ni rab 'byung ba/ / brgya gcig de bzhin rtsa brgyad du/ / phyag rgya'i grangs su brtags pa yin/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis 'di tshad du/ / sa steng sngon ni bstan pa yin/ / ston dang bstan pa 'jig pa na/ / lus can rnams ni rab spyod 'gyur/ /

“The 107th is the mudrā of the bodhisattvas Who have entered the tenth level; The lotus wreath by name, It is known as a ‘great’ mudrā. “Among all the worldly mudrās and mantras, The boon-granting has the greatest power; It is the most exalted and excellent And worshiped throughout the triple universe. “Designated as the 108th, This mudrā is the birthplace of the triple universe. Among the mudrās enumerated in this tantra, This one is the most powerful.[2044] “The count assigned to the mudrās Is thus one hundred and eight. This number was formerly taught in song[2045] By the perfect buddhas on the earth. When the teachings of the Teacher have disappeared, These one hundred and eight mudrās will be circulated among the living.

dang po re zhig lag pa gnyis/ / thal mo sbyar te rtse mo sprad/ / sor mo phan tshun nang du gshib/ / sor mo phan tshun sbyar nas ni/ / de nas yang dag sbyar nas kyang / / lag gnyis yang dag ldan pa la/ / gtsug pud lngas ni legs mtshan bya/ / sor mo rnams kyi rtse mo dag / de nas de dag rnam bzlog pa/ / phyag rgya gtsug pud lngar shes bya/ / gtsug pud lnga pa nyid dag ni/ / phyag rgya chen po zhes su bsgrags/ / byang chub sems dpa'i dbu la yod/ / 'di ni phyag rgya mthu bo che/ / rab sbyar las kun byed pa yin/ / 'jam dpal gyi ni sngags dag gam/ / snying po nyid ni rab tu sbyar/ / skra can ma yi sngags dag gam/ / rtsa ba'i sngags kyis rtag tu bya/ / cho ga mthong bas sbyar ba'am/ / sngags rnams kun gyis byas na ni/ / las rnams kun ni don yod par/ / thub pa'i bkas ni bstan pa yin/ /

“Starting again at the beginning,[2046] With the [fingers of] both hands joined at the tips, One should cross over the opposite fingers And keep them interlaced. The two hands [thus] joined Have the shape of five crests. “When the tips of the fingers are thus In reverse positions, That mudrā should be known as the five-crested Or the five locks of hair. “It is known as a ‘great’ mudrā, And also as the head of a bodhisattva. It possesses great power And can be employed in all rites. “One can optionally employ it Together with the heart mantra of Mañjuśrī, And also with the mantra of Keśinī Or the root mantra [of Mañjuśrī]. “Or, following the procedure, One can employ it with any other mantra. One will thus accomplish every rite; The Sage did not teach this in vain.[2047]

de bzhin lag pa rnam bkod nas/ / de yi lag pa kha sbyar bya/ / de bzhin rtse mo gsum bya ste/ / sor mo rnams ni rab sbyar nas/ / lag gnyis mthe bo spyod pa dang / / rab tu phyung ste drang por bya/ / gung mo dang ni srin lag dag / phyin ci log tu 'brel pa bya/ / 'di ni gtsug pud gsum zhes bya/ / ral pa gsum pa zhes bya'ang yin/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni blo ldan gyi/ / phyag rgya 'di ni phyag rgya che/ / gang dag cho ga mthong ba yi/ / las rnams kun ni byed pa yin/ / 'jam dpal gsang sngags gang yin pa/ / de dag kun la sbyar bar bya/ / zlos pa yid la gang 'dod pa/ / don de myur du grub par byed/ / lag pa de bzhin rnam bkod nas/ / de bzhin gtsug pud gcig par bya/ / sor mo gung mo yang dag sbyar/ / nges par gtsug pud gcig par 'gyur/ / rgya 'di phyag rgya chen po ste/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyis gsungs/ / gzhon nu'i sngags ni rab bkod dang / / gang yang 'jig rten kun gyi yang / / de dang sbyar na 'grub 'gyur te/ / myur ba nyid du 'grub par 'gyur/ /

“Similarly, one should join the hands together With a hollow space between them. Out of this, one should form [the shape of] three crests, With the fingers interlaced. “When the thumbs of both hands Cling together forming the shape of a needle,[2048] And the middle and ring fingers Are in a reverse position resembling a plait,[2049] “This is known as the three-crested, Or, alternatively, as the three locks of hair; This mudrā is a ‘great’ mudrā Of the sagacious Mañjughoṣa. “One can use it in all the rites Whereof the procedure is known. One can combine it With any mantra of Mañjuśrī. Such reciters will thus swiftly accomplish Their desired aims in this lifetime. “To form the single-crested mudrā, One should join the hands as before, With the middle fingers touching along their sides; This is definitely the single-crested. This mudrā is a ‘great’ mudrā Taught by the fully realized buddhas. “The mantras associated with Mañjuśrī, As well as the others associated with the world, Will be mastered when combined with this mudrā, And swiftly accomplish all activities.

de bzhin 'di yis bsgrub bya ni/ / sngags mchog rgyal bas bshad pa yin/ / cho ga mthong ba'i las kyis ni/ / 'di don myur du bsgrub par bya/ / de bzhin lag pa yang dag sbyar/ / sor mo'i rtse mo dgug cing dgod/ / mdzub mo gnyis ni rtse sprad dgug / sor mo gzhan ni rang bzhag la/ / mthe mo gnyis ni rab gshib nas/ / gung mo gnyis ni rab brkyang bya/ / srin lag gnyis ni rtse sprad bkug / ut+pa la ru bstan pa yin/ / 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / rtsa ba'i sngags ni brjod cing bya/ / gtsug pud lnga par bstan pa yi/ / las rnams gang yin de dag nyid/ / de kun ut+pa la yis ni/ / myur du sgrub par byed pa yin/ /

“Likewise, the supreme mantras taught by the victorious ones Will be accomplished when used in combination with it. Performing the rite according to procedure, One will swiftly accomplish one’s aims. “With the hands joined together as before, The fingertips ‘piled up,’[2050] And the two index fingers bent in, One should form a shape resembling the añjali.[2051] “When the two thumbs are then crossed over,[2052] The middle fingers outstretched, And the ring fingers folded in,[2053] This mudrā is called the utpala.[2054] “This mudrā is indicated for use With the root mantra of the bodhisattva [Mañjuśrī]. Every rite that is sanctioned for the five-crested, Can also be accomplished with this mudrā. “Any rite performed with the utpala[2055] Will bring swift success.

'di ni mchog sbyin phyag rgya ste/ / myur du longs spyod sgrub byed pa'o/ / rtsa ba'i sngags dang ldan byas na/ / myur du nor ni byed par 'gyur/ / lag gnyis de bzhin sbyar byas nas/ / lag pa gnyis po rab bkan la/ / kho ra yug tu sor mo yis/ / de nyid kha ni yang dag sbyar/ / bkra shis ldan pa'i rnam par 'byung / / mdzes pa'i rnam par dgod par bya/ / gung mo'i sor mo'i dbus su ni/ / mthe'u chung gnyis ni yang dag sbyar/ / mthe bo gnyi ga rnam sbyar ba/ / phyag rgya bkra shis ldan du brjod/ / don kun byed pa'i phyag rgya 'di/ / zhi ba'i las la rab tu sbyar/ / snying po'am yi ge drug ldan pas/ / las rnams kun ni byed par 'gyur/ / de bzhin lag gnyis sbyar nas ni/ / sor mo phan tshun rab sbyar ba/ / 'gro ba'i khyad par mkhyen pa yis/ / gang ba bzang zhes gsungs pa yin/ / rtse mo'i phyogs kyi sor mo rnams/ / kun nas yongs su 'gyed byas pa/ / gang ba bzang zhes sangs rgyas kyis/ / zlos pa rnams la gsungs pa yin/ / de 'di sdug bsngal dag dang ni/ / dbul ba'i sdug bsngal rab zhi byed/ / rtsa ba'i sngags kyis bskul byas na/ / myur du nor gyis phyug par byed/ / 'jig rten mkhyen cing legs spyod pas/ / phyag rgya gzhan yang gsungs pa ni/ / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / g.yon pa phab cing de la brten/ /

This mudrā grants the boons And swiftly brings enjoyments. When combined with the root mantra, It will swiftly accomplish one’s aims.[2056] “Similarly, one should join the hands, Stretching them upward And forming a hollow space in between With the fingers surrounding it. One should then form the auspicious symbol That has the shape of a swastika: “One should keep the little fingers On the level with the middle [joints] of the middle fingers, And the thumbs crossed over[2057]‍— This mudrā is called the swastika. “This mudrā can accomplish every purpose, And should be employed in the rites of pacifying. When combined with the six heart syllables,[2058] This mudrā will fulfill every activity. “When the hands are placed as before, With the opposite fingers interlaced, This mudrā is referred to by the experts In the knowledge of destinies as the complete. “When the palms are joined to form an open flower bud With the fingers kept apart in a circle, This mudrā has been specified by the perfect buddhas To the reciters as the complete.[2059] “It pacifies every calamity of those Suffering from poverty or other afflictions. It swiftly brings prosperity When activated by the root mantra. “Those with excellent conduct and knowledge of the world Also taught another mudrā: One should hold both hands as before, With the left index finger touching [the right hand].[2060]

lag pa g.yas pas bya ba ni/ / de yi sor mo dgug cing gzhag / mdzub mo gung mo nyid dag ni/ / bsgreng ba rgyal mtshan zhes brjod de/ / rgyal mtshan phyag rgya zhes grags pa/ / bsgreng bas dgra ni zlog par byed/ / phyag rgya 'di yi bya ba ni/ / rim gyis gtor ma sbyin sreg sogs/ / phyag rgya 'di yis bya ba ni/ / rtsa ba'i sngags kyis rab bskul na/ / 'di ni las kun byed pa yin/ / lag pa de bzhin rnam sbyar ba/ / thal mo sbyar ba'i phyag rgya ste/ / bgegs rnams ma lus rnam 'jig cing / / sngags shes mnyam par brjod pa ni/ / rim gyis las rnams byed par 'gyur/ / cho ga mthong ba'i ldan pas ni/ / myur du don ni sgrub par byed/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyi snying po ni/ / snying gi gnas las yang dag byung / / 'jig rten ma lus bsam pa yi/ / las rnams yang dag ldan pas byed/ / lag pa de bzhin sbyar byas nas/ / g.yon pa'i steng du g.yas pa bzhag /

“Putting the right hand into position, One should bend its fingers[2061] And extend the index and the middle fingers. This is referred to as the banner. “Called the banner, this mudrā, when raised, Can hold back enemies.[2062] This mudrā should be used to perform The rites of bali, homa, and so forth. If activated by the root mantra, It will accomplish every activity. “One should join the hands as before, With the fingers enclosing an empty space. This is the mudrā hollow space;[2063] It pacifies all the vighnas.[2064] “Used with the understanding of the mantra, It will, in due course, accomplish the intended activity. The mantras swiftly bring success If used according to procedure. “When combined with the mantras of Mañjughoṣa That originate from his very essence, [The hollow space] will cause the intended activity To fully manifest in the world. “One should put the hands together as before With the right hand above the left.
