g.yas kyi mdzub mo blangs nas ni/ / g.yon pa'i mdzub mo bsgreng byas pa/ / 'di ni srog shing phyag rgya yin/ / dgra rnams kun ni zlog byed cing / / mi bzad shin tu 'jigs rung ba'i/ / bgegs rnams thams cad zhi bar byed/ / sngags zlos pa yis bstan pa ni/ / ma rungs thams cad gsad don phyir/ / rtsa ba'i sngags dang yang dag ldan/ / myur du las ni byed par 'gyur/ / de bzhin lag pa sbyar byas la/ / srog shing 'dra bar btsugs byas nas/ / de steng lag g.yas brkyang byas pa/ / phyag rgya gdugs zhes bya bar brjod/ / phyag rgya 'di yis bya ba ni/ / bdag gi spyi bor bsrung bar bya/ / sngags rnams kun gyis byed pa ste/ / las ni srung bar byed pa yin/ / dgra rnams kyi ni gdong 'gebs shing / / mi 'dod pa dag rengs par byed/ /

Holding the right index finger, One should raise the left index finger. This mudrā, called the stick, Is capable of warding off enemies.[2065] “It pacifies all the terrible And very frightening vighnas. It has been recommended to the reciters[2066] As the means of destroying all evil beings. When used in combination with the root mantra, It will swiftly accomplish one’s aims. “One should position the hands as before, Forming the shape of a raised stick And stretching out the right hand‍— This mudrā is called the parasol. With it one can perform the protection for the body, If one places it on the head. “It may be used with any mantra In a rite designated as protective. One can cover or paralyze, as desired, The mouths of one’s enemies.[2067]

mi ma yin dang ma rungs pa/ / ci ltar 'dod par byed pa yin/ / gdugs kyi phyag rgya de mthong bas/ / bgegs rnams kun ni rnam par 'jig / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / lag pa dag ni mdzes sbyar nas/ / mthe bo mdzub mo rtse sprad ldan/ / gung mo gnyis ni rab brkyang zhing / / srin lag gnyis ni rtse sprad bkug / gung mo'i tshigs gnyis sbyar bar bya/ / de nyid mdung gi phyag rgyar bstan/ / ma rungs thams cad zlog par byed/ / srin po gdon rnams 'jig byed nas/ / 'jig rten mgon gyis gsungs pa yin/ / khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed/ / khros pas rab tu bstan pa yin/ / mi bzad sdig pa'i las byed pa'i/ / 'jig rten la ni rab myur byed/ / srog la gnod par byed pa'i las/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis spangs pa yi/ / las 'di dag ni mi bya ste/ / 'jig rten dam pas bkag pa yin/ / yang na kun 'gro'i sngags sbyar ba'i/ / mdung gi phyag rgya dam pa yin/ / gang dag 'jig rten sngags rnams dang / / de bzhin rgyal bas rab bshad pa/ / de dag gi ni sngags rnams sbyar/ / mdung gi phyag rgya legs mnyam bzhag /

“One may do to evil beings, Including humans,[2068] whatever one wishes to. All the vighnas will perish Through merely seeing the parasol mudrā. “Positioning the hands as before, One should form the auspicious symbol. The tips of the thumbs should touch, And the middle fingers should be extended.[2069] “The tip of the folded ring finger [Should touch] the middle joint of the middle finger. This [mudrā], designated as the javelin, Wards off all evil beings. “According to the lords of the world It destroys the rākṣasas and the grahas. It is displayed by Yamāntaka, The furious Lord of Wrath. “This mudrā could swiftly bring The rise of terrible evils in this world. Any activities, though, that destroy life Are shunned by every buddha. One should never perform activities Forbidden by the most eminent of men. “One can use the supreme javelin With any mantras of general application. In combination with this mudrā One can use any worldly mantras that have been Taught by the victorious ones, Focusing as much as one is able to.[2070]

sngags kyi mchog ni mi bzad mthong / / bden bral thams cad 'jig par 'gyur/ / sha za skar ma yi dgas dang / / srul po dang ni ma mo dang / / byis pa'i gdon dang mi sdug gzugs/ / byis pa rnams la gnod byed pa/ / gang dag gdug pa'i las ldan pa/ / ma rungs thams cad 'joms par byed/ / de bzhin lag ni sbyar byas nas/ / thal mo'i rnam par byas pa dag / de nyid rnam par bzlog bya ste/ / sor mo phan tshun 'byar ba ni/ /

“When they see this excellent mudrā, All the nairṛtas will perish, And so will the piśācas, the tārakas, The pūtanas along with the mātṛs, “And the child-stealing virūpākṣas[2071] Who oppress children‍— All these miscreants will perish, Along with other evildoers. “Positioning the hands as before To form the shape of a javelin, One should form an ‘inverted enclosure’ By interlacing one’s fingers.[2072]

rdzogs sangs rgyas pa zhe sdang bral/ / de nyid kha sbyar zhes ni gsungs/ / yi ge gcig pa'i sngags dang ni/ / phyag rgya 'di yi las kyis bya/ / 'di nyid phyag rgyas phyogs kun bcing / / de ni phyogs bcing zhes bya'o/ / phyag rgya 'di ni bsrung ba che/ / kha sbyar byas nas 'dug pa yin/ / gzhan yang gang dag gnod byed pa'i/ / ma rungs thams cad 'jig par byed/ / lus dang sems can 'khor dang ni/ / spyod yul dag kyang 'dzin par byed/ / gang du zlos pa rtag gnas pa/ / ma lus tshogs ni srung bar byed/ / de la sdig pa ci yang med/ / phan pa med pa'ang 'byung mi 'gyur/ / bde dang lo legs nad med na/ / pha rol dmag tshogs 'jigs pa gang / / de nas lag gnyis yang sbyar nas/ / bzlog par yang ni bya ba yin/ / g.yas pa 'og tu byas nas ni/ / g.yon pa'ang steng du bkan par bya/ / lag gnyis phan tshun bsnol ba 'di/ / rgyal ba mchog gis mchog sbyin gsungs/ /

“This mudrā is called by the perfect buddhas, Who are free from hatred, the hollow space; One should use it in the performance of activities. When this mudrā is used with the mantra One Syllable To seal off all the directions, This is called the ‘binding of the directions.’ “This mudrā affords great protection While it remains enclosing the hollow space‍— All the miscreants perish, And so do any others who bring harm. “It protects the entire body, As well as one’s retinue within the area. It always protects the entire environment Where the reciter resides. “Such a reciter will not experience downfalls And nothing untoward will happen to him, Only comfort, abundant provisions, and good health. Would he have to fear even a hostile army? “Pressing the hands together, One should put them in the reverse position,[2073] With the right hand below And the left one above, turned upward. When the hands are thus placed in relation to each other, The supreme victors call this mudrā the shield.[2074]

sdig pa yang dag 'byung byed pa'i/ / ma rungs dgra rnams zlog par byed/ / yi ge gcig gnyis gsum dag gi/ / yi ge ldan pa brjod pa dang / / sngags ni 'dod pa dang ldan pas/ / 'di ni myur du las rnams byed/ / dgra las byung ba'i sdig dag la/ / don gyi las rnams sna tshogs byed/ / rtsa ba'i sngags dang ldan pa yis/ / sbrul gyi dug ni sel bar byed/ / yang na gzhan gyis sbyar ba yi/ / lus can skyon ni sel bar byed/ / sangs rgyas rkang gnyis mchog dag gis/ / 'di ni phyag rgya mchog tu gsungs/ / lag pa de bzhin sbyar byas nas/ / sor mo rnams ni sbyar ba las/ / de tshe da pus 'dra bya ba/ / rtsa bar yang ni bcing ba ste/ / mthe bo gnyis kyi dbus su ni/ / mthe'u chung dag gis legs par dkri/ / sor mo drug gis bya ba ni/ / rtse mo sbyar te legs mdzes bya/ / 'di ni da pus phyag rgyar gsungs/ / lha min thams cad 'joms par byed/ / lha ma yin dang gdug sems ldan/ / mthong bas sems ni zhi 'gyur zhing / / phyag rgya brjod na 'jig par 'gyur/ / da pus phyag rgya legs mchod pa/ /

“This mudrā stops the malice Of wicked enemies from arising. When used in combination with the syllables of a mantra‍— One, two, or three[2075]‍—it possesses magical power. “When used in combination with one-syllable[2076] mantras, This mudrā will swiftly accomplish one’s aims. It will turn the evil activities of one’s enemies Into different kinds of advantages. “If combined with the root mantra, It neutralizes the poison of snakes And removes from living beings Other accidental mishaps. This excellent mudrā has been taught By the perfect buddhas, supreme among two-legged beings. “One should join the hands as before, So that they touch along the fingers And form the shape of a mace That is covered at the base‍— It should be well covered with the small fingers Placed between the two thumbs. “Using six fingers, one should then form A nicely pointed shape.[2077] This mudrā is called the mace; It destroys all the dānavas. “When they see the mace mudrā, The daityas and other malevolent beings become gentle. When this highly honored mudrā is raised upward, They perish.[2078]

rtsa ba'i sngags ni rab sbyar na/ / myur du don rnams byed cing zhi/ / de bzhin ral gri bstan pa yang / / srin lag mdzub mo bkug pas so/ / de bzhin lag gnyis byas nas ni/ / rab brkyang dang po dgug par bya/ / sor mo dag gis 'khor yug tu/ / kham phor mnyam pa'i dbyibs su bya/ / dril bur sangs rgyas kyis mkhyen cing / / lus can rnams la yang dag bstan/ / lag gnyis de bzhin sbyar nas ni/ / gnyi ga kha sbyar rab bcings nas/ / phan tshun bsre ba byas nas ni/ / de bzhin gung mo'i sor mo gnyis/ / dkyil 'khor 'dra bar byas pa yis/ / zhags pa 'dra bar 'byung ba ni/ / de nas mdzub mo gnyis po dag / dbu ma'i tshigs su bcing bya ba/ / 'di ni zhags pa zhes bya ste/ / rgya 'di sangs rgyas kyis sprul pa'o/ / sems can rnams ni gdul don du/ / mi bzad 'ching ba byed par gsungs/ /

“When used in combination with the root mantra, This auspicious mudrā will swiftly accomplish one’s purpose. When the tips[2079] of the ring fingers are folded in, The same mudrā is designated as the sword. “Placing the hands exactly as before And stretching them while folding in the fingertips, One should form the shape of a round vessel With the fingers placed all around. The buddhas know this mudrā as the bell, And they taught it as such to beings. “One should join the hands together as before, Forming the hollow space mudrā.[2080] Then, one should interlace the opposite fingers While forming, with the middle fingers, The shape of a circle, That is, the shape of a noose. “Then, when the index fingers Are crossed at the middle joint,[2081] This is called the noose‍— This mudrā is the magical creation of the buddhas Intended to guide beings And release them from their terrible bondage.

gang yang ma rungs gdug pa'i gza'/ / gang yang gnod sbyin srin po rnams/ / 'di ni cung zad rab bskul bas/ / 'dir ni ma mor bcas pa 'ching / / chings shig chings shig ces brjod pas/ / brgya byin bcas pa'ang 'dir 'ching na/ / sha za sha ni za ba dang / / mi yi 'jig rten smos ci dgos/ / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / de ni gnyi ga mnyam byas nas/ / de bzhin lag pa g.yas pa ni/ / g.yon pa'i steng du yongs su gzhag / gung mo dang ni mdzub mo dag / de nyid lcags kyu 'dra bar bya/ / tshigs ni bar ma la brten nas/ / mdzub mo nyid ni lcags kyur bya/ / rtsa ba'i sngags la 'di rab sbyar/ / lcags kyur 'di ni rab tu bya/ / yid la gang zhig zlos par 'dod/ / myur du las ni rab tu byed/ / myur du lha dbang tshangs pa sogs/ / brgya byin bcas pa'ang 'gugs par byed/ / phyag rgya gtso mchog rab sbyar ba/ / lcags kyu 'gugs pa dge ba yin/ / lag gnyis de bzhin rab sbyar nas/ / bzlog pa'i rnam pas nang bcings la/ / g.yon pa'i lag pa'i sor mo ni/ / gung mo srin lag dgug par bya/ / g.yas pa'i lag pa'i sor mo ni/ / gung mo srin lag rnam par dgug / mdzub mo mthe'u chung dag kyang ni/ / gnyi ga sdigs mdzub bya ba ni/ /

“If there are evil grahas, Or any cruel rākṣasas,[2082] This mudrā, even if activated only slightly, Will bind them, along with the mātṛs. “If one utters, ‘Bind, bind!’ and so forth, This mudrā will bind even Śakra, Let alone beings in the human world That feed on carrion and pieces of flesh. “One should position the hands as before, Aligning them together. The right hand should be Placed above the left. “Keeping this position, the shape of a hook should be formed With the middle and index fingers‍— That is, the index finger should form a hook While clinging to the joint of the middle finger. “Used in combination with the root mantra, This activated goad mudrā Will swiftly accomplish the activities Intended by the reciters. “One will swiftly summon the lords of gods‍— The Brahmās, the Śakras, and so forth. This excellent mudrā, when employed, Becomes an excellent goad for drawing beings. “Using both hands as before, one should join them In a reverse position, forming a round shape. One should bend the middle and ring fingers Of the left hand, “And make a threatening gesture With both the index and small fingers of the right hand. It is instructed that the middle and ring fingers Of the right hand should be bent.[2083]

de nas rnam bzlog bzhag pa la/ / mthe bo gnyis ni dgug cing sbyar/ / de nyid bzang po'i gdan gsungs pa/ / phyag rgya mchog ni dge ba yin/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi gdan yin te/ / khro ldan sems can zlog pa yin/ / rgyal ba mchog gi rigs las byung / / sngags rnams kun la rab tu sbyar/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' kun/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'joms byed cing / / lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten dag / thams cad g.yo ba med byed pa'o/ / bzang po'i stan ni de nyid la/ / gung mo la ni yang dag brten/ / steng du rnam par dgod pa ni/ / gung mo srin lag rab brkyang ba'o/ / de nyid gdan du gsungs pa ni/ / thub pa dgra rgyal seng ges so/ / de bzhin lag gnyis sbyar nas ni/ / sor mo rnams ni bcing bar bya/ / de nas yal ga 'dra bar ni/ / 'og tu mthe'u chung rtse mor sbyar/ /

“The hands, being in reverse position, Should press against each other with their thumbs. This, the auspicious seat, Is said to be an excellent and auspicious mudrā. “It is the seat of all the buddhas; It can ward off angry beings.[2084] It may be used in combination with any mantra That belongs to a family of the chief victors. “[This seat,] fixed by all the buddhas And the bodhisattvas of great power,[2085] Stabilizes everything‍—all the worlds, Including those inhabited by gods. “One should form the same auspicious seat. It should, however, rest[2086] on the middle fingers‍— These fingers[2087] should be extended And the hands raised up. This mudrā has been designated by the lion-like sages, Who have defeated their enemies, as the seat. “One should join the hands together By interlacing the fingers. Then, with the little fingers, one should form below A pointed shape like a braid.[2088]

gung mo yang dag dgug bya zhing / / pad+ma'i 'dab ltar yangs pa bya/ / mthe bo gnyis ka sbyar bzhag nas/ / rtag tu bsgreng ste bzhag pa yin/ / zhe sdang bral ba'i sangs rgyas kyis/ / 'di ni rma bya'i gdan du gsungs/ / 'di ni blo ldan 'jam pa'i dbyangs/ / byang chub sems dpa' 'di yi ni/ / byis pa rtag tu rtse byed pa'i/ / gdan du thub pa mchog gis gsungs/ / mthu chen phyag rgya chen po 'di/ / rang byung rnams kyis sngon bshad pa'o/ / 'jam dbyangs sngags kyis rab bskul na/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las rnams byed/ / sha za sha ni za ba rnams/ / gdug pa rnams ni 'jig par byed/ / nyi shu de bzhin tshang bar ni/ / de dag phyag rgyar 'dod pa ste/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas pa rkang gnyis mchog / 'jig rten gtso bos gsungs pa yin/ / de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / phyag rgya rnams kyi cho ga rnams/ / lag pa dge zhing dag pa dang / / dri med chu yis bkrus pa dang / / tsan+dan dkar dang ga pur dang / / gur gum chu dang ldan pa yi/ / dri yi khyad par mang po yis/ / byugs shing me la bskams pa yi/ /

“The middle fingers should be bent,[2089] Forming the oblong shape of a lotus leaf. One should join the thumbs together, Always positioning them upright.[2090] The perfect buddhas who are free from hatred Call this mudrā the peacock seat. “According to the eminent sages, This is the seat of the sagacious Bodhisattva Mañjughoṣa, Ever for his childlike enjoyment. “Formerly taught by the self-arisen [buddhas], This mudrā has great power. When activated with the mantra of Mañjughoṣa, It can accomplish a variety of activities, Such as destroying evil beings‍— Kravyādas and piśitāśas. “This completes the first twenty[2091] mudrās; More [mudrās] beyond these[2092] Were taught by the world leaders‍— The perfect buddhas, supreme among two-legged beings. “Next I will teach the procedures Specific to the mudrās. One’s hands should be pure and clean, Washed with unsullied water. “They should be sprinkled with water Suffused with white sandalwood, camphor, saffron, And many types of perfume, And then dried in the breeze.[2093]

lag pa ma nyams gtsang ba dang / / ma smad shu ba med pa yis/ / dang por phyag bya rkang gnyis mchog / de yi phyag rgya bcing bar bya/ / sa la me tog kun skyes dang / / 'od dpag med dang rin chen tog / dpag med tshe shes mi g.yo dbang / / 'jig rten mgon po nyin byed dang / / bde byed 'jig rten mgon po dang / / spyan bzang chos kyi tog dang ni/ / 'od kyi phreng ba zhes grags pa/ / gtso bo mchog ni dam pa dag / 'di dag ga pur sangs rgyas ni/ / rkang gnyis mchog la phyag byas nas/ /

“With the hands, which are clean, unimpaired, Perfect, and free of blisters[2094]‍—only with such hands‍— One should form a mudrā for saluting, and so forth, The most eminent of two-legged beings, such as “Śālendrarāja, Saṃkusumitarāja, Amitābha, Ratnaketu, Amitāyurjñānaviniścayarāja, The lord of the world Divaṃkara, “Kṣema, and the lords of the world Sunetra, Dharmaketu, and Prabhāmālin‍— These are the names of the seniormost [tathāgatas] Who transcend this [world]. “One should salute any buddha from among the above Who are superior among two-legged beings.

gtsang ba'i gnas su gtsang byas nas/ / zlos pa'i dus su phyag rgya bcing / / slob dpon la ni yang dag dris/ / the tshom don las rnam par grol/ / de 'dra'i spyod pa de ldan na/ / ci ltar bde bar phyag rgya bcing / / rnam sbyangs rnam par dben pa dang / / gnas kyang mngon par bsngags byas pa/ / khros min zas lhag bcas pa min/ / gzhan dag gis ni sems g.yeng min/ / sol ba thal ba'i nang dag tu/ / nam yang phyag rgya bshad mi bya/ / gzhan gyi bud med la chags dang / / gzhan nor chags la'ang bshad mi bya/ / langs dang nyal ba dag la ni/ / phyag rgya bde 'byung bshad mi bya/ / lhor bltas 'dug la'ang ma yin te/ / nub tu bltas te 'dug par min/ / steng dang 'og gi phyogs dag tu'ang / / phyag rgya bcing bar mi bya'o/ / byang dang shar du bltas pa dang / / phyogs mtshams dag ni de dag tu/ / dkyil 'khor bdag po'i sngags dran nas/ / sngags shes pas ni phyag rgya bcing / /

Purified, in a clean place, One should form a mudrā during recitation. “Once having examined[2095] the master, One should relinquish one’s doubts about him. Adhering to the right conduct, One should form a mudrā at ease. “One should clean a [suitable] place, set it up as separate, And incant it with the mantra. One must not get angry, leave rubbish behind, Or be an object of the others’ rebukes.[2096] “One should never form a mudrā Near smoldering embers or ashes. Nor should one hanker after the wives Or the possessions of others. “For a mudrā to bring happiness, one should form it Neither standing up nor lying down. One should not be facing south Or west. “Nor should one form a mudrā Facing upward or downward, But only facing north or east, Or the intermediate directions in between. “An adept of mantras should form a mudrā Knowing that the mantra [deity] is the lord of the maṇḍala.[2097]

phyag rgya ma lus bcing ba la/ / cho ga mchog 'di 'dod pa yin/ / de yi 'og tu brjod bya ba/ / phyag rgya nyi shu gcig pa yin/ / lag gnyis mnyam par byas nas ni/ / sor mo rnams ni sbyar bar bya/ / de nas sor mo gung mo ni/ / rtse mo sbyar bar bya ba yin/ / mdzub mo dang ni mthe'u chung gi/ / rtse mo tshigs ni bar mar gzhag /

When forming any mudrās, This procedure is regarded as supreme. “Next, I will teach the mudrās Enumerated after the twentieth. One should join the hands, evenly aligned, And bring the fingers together, Pointing them toward the tips Of the middle fingers.[2098] “The tips of the index and small fingers Should be placed on the joint of the index finger.[2099]

phyag rgya shes pas rtag bya ba/ / mthe bong gnyis ni bkug rten cing / / rtse mo gsum sbyar yang dag ldan/ / paT+Ti saM du mkhas pas shes/ / phyag rgya 'di ni mchog yin te/ / myur du gzhan gyi sngags rnams gcod/ / de nas gzhan gyi phyag rgya gcod/ / ma rungs sems can la sbyar bya/ / gza' dang ma mo srul po yi/ / 'byung po kun ni skrag par byed/ / las rnam sna tshogs byed pa ste/ / zhi ba'ang myur du 'gugs par byed/ / drag po khyab 'jug tshangs pa dag / gang dag rang gis smras pa'i sngags/ / cho ga mthong ba'i las kyis ni/ / sngags shes pas ni de dag gcod/ / bdag nyid chen po paT+Ti sa'i/ / phyag rgya dang ni ldan pa dang / / rgyal ba'i zhal nas byung ba yi/ / sngags nyid dang yang ldan gnas na/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las byed de/ / de bzhin gcod dang dral ba'i las/ / sems can gzhan gyis byas pa'i skyon/ / ma lus mtha' dag 'jig par byed/ /

The mantra[2100] adept should always do [this] With the thumbs folded and drawn in. When the hands thus form the shape of three spikes, The learned ones know this mudrā as the three-pointed lance. “This excellent mudrā will quickly Break the mantras Or the mudrās of one’s adversaries. It can be used only against wicked beings. “It will frighten all the spirits‍— The grahas, the mātṛs, and the pūtanas‍— And will accomplish a variety of activities. It can swiftly summon Śiva. “The mantra adept can break The mantras recited by Rudra, Viṣṇu, or even Brahmā himself, If he performs the rite according to procedure. “If one keeps using this mudrā‍— The mighty three-pointed lance‍— Along with a mantra that originated From the mouths of the victorious ones, “One will accomplish a variety of activities. By performing the rites of crushing and destroying, One will completely destroy Any negativity created by hostile beings.

lag gnyis de bzhin sbyar nas ni/ / gung mo srin lag bsgreng bya ste/ / lag gnyis yang dag ldan pa ni/ / mtshan dang 'dra bar yang dag 'byung / / sor mo bzhi ni yang dag ldan/ / mtshan gyi phyag rgya zhes 'dod do/ / lha yi bu ni dbang phyug che/ / rang gi rgyas ni phyag rgya btab/ / thub pas sngon ni bkug pa la/ / rgyud 'di las ni gsungs pa yin/ / cho ga mchog 'dir dam tshig dang / / bdag nyid sngags ni ma lus dag / de bzhin phyag rgya rgya cher bcas/ / bkug nas rab tu bstan pa yin/ / phyag rgya yi ni rab mchog 'di/ / 'jig rten dag la rab tu bstan/ / phyag rgya dag ni gang ji snyed/ / drag pos sa steng rab bstan pa/ / de dag gi ni bdag po mchog / phyag rgya 'di ni rtags gcig yin/ /

“One should clasp the hands together, Raising up the middle and ring fingers. The two hands should be joined, Forming the shape of a liṅga. This mudrā, known as the liṅga,[2101] Is formed using four fingers. “The god Maheśvara himself Taught this mudrā and his personal mantra In a tantra that was formerly Adopted by the Sage. “He also taught at length his other Personal mantras[2102] and mudrās, Which were, at that time, Adopted in this supreme manual, But this excellent mudrā Was proclaimed the best among worldly mudrās. “However many mudrās there are That were taught by Rudra on earth, This mudrā, the single liṅga,[2103] Is their lord, best of them [all].

'jam pa'i dbyangs ni blo ldan pa/ / byang chub sems dpa'i mthu yis ni/ / dkyil 'khor 'dir ni bsdus pa ste/ / sbyin sreg las ni rab sgrub pa'o/ / gang dag ji snyed gdug pa pa/ / sa yi steng na rgyu ba yi/ / gdon dang sha rjen sha za dang / / ma mo dang ni lus srul po/ / drag pos bgegs ni byas pa dag / de dag bzlog pa'i don ched du/ / mtshan mo gtor ma'i las dag la/ / phyag rgya mchog 'di gsungs pa yin/ /

“Brought into the maṇḍala Through the bodhisattva power Of the sagacious Mañjughoṣa, [This lord of mudrās[2104]] accomplishes the rites of homa. “Whatever evil beings Roam the earth‍— Grahas, kravyādas, piśitāśas, Mātṛs, kaṭapūtanas‍— “This mudrā is for restraining them. Further, this excellent mudrā is recommended For the rites of bali performed at nighttime And intended to ward off the obstacles created by Rudra.[2105]

sangs rgyas byin rlabs rdzu 'phrul gyis/ / las rnams ma lus byed par 'gyur/ / de bzhin de ni rnam gnyis byas/ / rtags ni gnyis su yang dag bstan/ / de bzhin sor mo phreng bar byas/ / phreng ba zhes ni yongs su bsgrags/ / de nyid phreng ba yang dag bsdus/ / kha sbyar 'dra bar yang dag 'byung / / mdzub mo gnyis kyi rtse sprad pa/ / gzhu dang 'dra bar bya ba yin/ / mthe bo gnyis ni chang par gnon/ / de ni gzhu yi phyag rgyar mtshon/ / de bzhin sor mo byas nas ni/ / g.yas pa'i mdzub mo nges par brkyang / / g.yon pa'i mdzub mo'ang brkyang byas te/ / mthe bo'i tshigs ni chang pas gnan/ /

This mudrā will accomplish every activity By the power of the Buddha’s blessing. “Having done this exactly the same way, but with two points,[2106] The mudrā is called the two-pointed lance. Formed in the same way, but with the fingers Arranged rosary-wise, the mudrā is called the rosary. “If the [shape of] the rosary Is contracted to enclose a hollow space, With the index fingers touching And forming the shape of a bow, And the thumbs squeezed in a fist, That mudrā is designated as the bow. “One should position the fingers the same way, Extend the right index finger, And also extend the left index finger. The thumb joints should be squeezed in a fist.[2107]
lcags mda'i phyag rgya zhes bstan te/ / mtshan ma mnyam par yang brjod do/ / de bzhin lag gnyis byas nas ni/ / sor mo rnams ni phan tshun bcing / /
This mudrā is called the iron arrow. The next mudrā is the even-pointed lance. “[Here,] both hands should be extended With the opposite fingers clenched together.
The thumb of the right hand Should be raised to resemble the penis. Those proficient in this instruction Know this mudrā as the even-pointed lance.[2108]
mdzub gnyis bslang bar yang dag sbyar/ / mdung dang 'dra bar byas pa yang / / ma rungs thams cad rjes skrag pa/ / 'di ni mdung zhes rab tu gsungs/ /
“One should position the hands in the same way, With the opposite fingers contracted. Then, joining the two index fingers, One should form the shape of a spear. This mudrā is called the spear;
de bzhin lag gnyis byas nas ni/ / gnyi ga'ang khu tshur bcing bya zhing / / mthe bo gnyis ni bsgreng byas pa/ / tho ba'i phyag rgyar bstan pa yin/ /
It disciplines the wicked beings. “Positioning the hands as before, One should make both of them into a fist, While keeping the thumbs upright. This mudrā is called the hammer.
kha sbyar tho ba de nyid las/ / cung zad rab tu bskyod pa ni/ / mda' chen mchog tu gsungs pa ste/ / phyag rgya dgra ni 'jig byed pa'o/ /
“If one shifts this hammer[2109] slightly Into the space between the hands, This excellent mudrā is called the hatchet; It destroys one’s enemies.[2110]

de nas ut+pal bcings byas te/ / de bzhin mthe'u chung sor mo gnyis/ / mthe bo'i 'og gi nang dag tu/ / dgod cing mdzub mo bstan par bya/ / 'di ni mche ba zhes gsungs te/ / rnam par bye ba zhal zhes brjod/ / sor mo dag ni kun nas kyang / / de dag mnyam par byas nas su/ / g.yas pa'i lag pa'i dkyil dag tu/ / g.yon pa'i lag bzhag ba dan brjod/ /

“One should form the shape of a lotus With one’s ring fingers[2111] And position it between the thumbs below, So that it is not invisible.[2112] This [mudrā] is called the fangs; When [the lotus] is exposed, it is called the mouth. “When the fingers of each hand Are evenly placed around[2113] And the right hand is placed on the thigh, [That mudrā] is called the cloth.[2114]

lag pa dag ni gnyi ga yang / / kha sbyar dag ni mdzes par gzhag / sor dang sor mo dag kyang ni/ / phan tshun rtse mo dag sbyar bya/ / de nas srin lag rtse gnyis dgug / bum pa'i phyag rgyar yang dag bstan/ / de nyid khu tshur sbyar nas ni/ / mdzub mo gnyis ni sngon du bsgreng / / rtse mo dgug pa'i rnam par bya/ / 'khar gsil 'dra bar 'gyur ba yin/ / phyag rgya 'di ni yang dag bstan/ / 'khar gsil sgra ni sel bar byed/ / 'khar gsil de nyid cung zad tsam/ / legs par rab tu btud pa ni/ / mthe bo gnyis la rnam par sbyar/ / de 'dir bya ma bum du brjod/ / mdzub mo dang ni srin lag gnyis/ / bsgreng bar yang ni bya ba ste/ / de dag gi ni rtse bzhi sprad/ / gtun shing 'dra bar yang dag 'gyur/ / sngags shes yang dag ldan pa yis/ / gtun shing gi ni phyag rgyar bshad/ / lag gnyis de bzhin sbyar nas ni/ / gung mo srin lag 'og dang ni/ / steng du de dag rnam par dgod/ / g.yas pas g.yon pa bcing bar bya/ /

“One should gracefully join the hands together, Leaving a hollow space in between. The fingertips should be Mutually touching, And the ring fingers raised and folded; This mudrā is called the jar. “One should join the hands forming a fist as before And raise the index fingers, Forming the shape Of a twisted mendicant’s staff. This mudrā is called the mendicant’s staff; It is the destroyer of foes. “If this mendicant’s staff is slightly tilted In a graceful manner, And the two thumbs are touching, The mudrā is called the pitcher. “One should raise The index and ring fingers And form, with these four fingers, The shape of a club. Those who know about mantras Call this mudrā the club. “One should position the hands as before, With the middle and ring fingers [placed] below. Above them, one should always place . . . ,[2115] With the right hand covering the one below.[2116]

sor mo mdzub mo mthe'u chung dag / phan tshun du ni yang dag sbyar/ / khor yug skyil krung 'dra ba yi/ / phyag rgyar de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs/ / 'di ni skyil krung phyag rgya zhes/ / 'jig rten kun tu grags pa yin/ / phyag rgya 'di dang ldan pa dang / / de bzhin sngags dang rab ldan pa/ / rgyal ba kun gyis gsungs pa dang / / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs las byung / / 'di dag gi ni sngags ldan 'di/ / zhi ba'i las kun byed pa yin/ / gtun shing la sogs mdung gi bar/ / gang yang phyag rgya de bzhin gsungs/ / thams cad khro bo'i rgyal po ni/ / gshin rje gshed 'di'i bstan pa yin/ / mtshon cha drag po 'di dag ni/ / thams cad gdul phyir sprul ba yin/ /

“One should join the small and index fingers And wrap the thumbs around them,[2117] Forming the shape of a cross-legged posture. The tathāgatas call this mudrā The cross-legged posture, By which name it is known all over the world. “Again, one should use this mudrā In combination with a mantra. It can be combined with the mantras Taught by any victorious one From the Vajra or Lotus families. This mudrā accomplishes all the peaceful activities. “But the mudrās taught here, such as the club and so forth, Including the mudrās of the ‘spear’ type, All belong to the instructions Of the krodharāja Yamāntaka. “These [mudrās] are fierce weapons Created to guide sentient beings.

byang chub sems dpa'i mthu yis ni/ / de tshe bsgrub bya sgrub pa yin/ / gdul bya gdug pa thams cad la/ / bum pa la sogs phyag rgya gsungs/ / lag gnyis de bzhin bkod nas ni/ / pa Ta ha yi rnga 'dra bya/ / sor mo rnams ni mnyam par sbyar/ / thams cad kyis kyang rim par bsnol/ / mthe bong yang ni rim par bya/ / de nas lag pa'i nang du gzhug / gung mo mdzub mo gnyis po ni/ / gyen du bsgreng ba dag tu bya/ / 'di ni pa Ta ha zhes bas bstan/ / phyag rgya ma rungs zlog byed pa'o/ / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / sor mo rnams ni legs par sbyar/ / gdub kor 'dra bar mdzes pa yi/ / mdzub mo gnyis ni rnam bkug la/ / mthe bo gnyis ni 'og mthar bya/ / mthe bo gnyis kyang smad par bya/ /

Through the bodhisattva’s power They can accomplish magical feats; The mudrās such as the jar Were taught for all the miscreants who need guidance. “One should join the hands as before, Forming the shape of a kettledrum. One should then fasten the hands together By interlacing all the fingers like a plait. “One should also entwine the thumbs, Placing [each] in [the opposite] hand. One should stick the index finger in the center And raise its tip.[2118] This mudrā is designated as the kettledrum; It wards off evil beings. “One should join the hands as before, Forming a neat añjali gesture. Both index fingers should be drawn in, Forming a fine shape of a coil. “The thumbs, bent down, Should be moved downward.

gung mo sbyar la rab gzhug gzhag / dung ni mdzes par 'gyur ba yin/ / 'di ni chos kyi dung zhes pa'i/ / lag pa'i phyag rgyar rab tu bstan/ / thub mchog gsungs pa'i sngags ldan na/ / las ni thams cad byed pa yin/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las byed pa/ / rtsa ba'i sngags dang rab sbyar na/ / mche ba'i dug can thams cad dang / / sbrul gyi dug rnams thams cad sel/ / rig pa'i rgyal po rdzu 'phrul che/ / phyag rgya dung ni 'bud bzhin bzlas/ /

When both are inside the central space,[2119] This [resembles] an auspicious conch. This excellent mudrā Is designated as the Dharma conch. “It may be used in combination with the mantras Taught by the eminent sages, and is suitable for all activities. When employed together with the root mantra, It will accomplish a variety of activities‍— It will completely destroy the tooth venom of snakes And any beings with fangs and poison. “One should make this conch complete By incanting it with the vidyārāja mantras of great power.[2120]

dug gis brgyal ba'i skye bo ni/ / myur du dug ni med par 'gyur/ / phyag rgya mchog ni rdzu 'phrul che/ / bzhi bcu dag ni yang dag bstan/ / de nas gzhan yang phyag rgya yi/ / mtshan zhing yang dag bshad bya ba/ / lag gnyis de bzhin rnam bkod pa/ / sor mo'i rtse mo legs par sbyar/ / g.yon min lag pa'i nang du ni/ / 'bad pas lag g.yon gzhug par bya/ / thams cad 'og tu byas pa yi/ / lu gu rgyud du bstan pa yin/ /

The person fallen unconscious because of the poison Will soon become detoxified. “This supreme mudrā of great power Is counted as the fortieth.[2121] Moving on, I will teach further about The mudrās and their characteristics. “One should join the hands as before, Interlocking the fingertips. Further, one should snap the fingers with care And position the right hand below. When all this is done; This mudrā is called the chain.[2122]

'di ni phyag rgya rab mchog ste/ / gdug pa ma lus 'ching bar byed/ / thub pa mchog gis gsungs pa yi/ / sngags 'di dag dang ldan byas na/ / gza' dang ma mo sdig ldan rnams/ / 'byung po ma lus 'ching bar 'gyur/ / lag gnyis de bzhin kun bsdus nas/ / bkrol zhing rim par yang dag bsgreng / / gung mo'i tshigs su mthe bo ni/ / 'di nyid cho gas gzhag par bya/ / mthe bo gnyis kyi rtse mo yang / / gung mo'i bar tshigs yang dag sbyar/ /

“This excellent, supreme mudrā Will bind all those who harbor ill will. When used in combination With the mantras taught by the supreme sages, It will bind all the spirits, Such as the grahas, the mātṛs, and the kaśmalas. “One should close the hands, open them, And raise them one after the other.[2123] Starting with this procedure, one should ‘fasten’ the hands, With the opposite thumbs and middle fingers Clinging at the middle joint, And both hands moved forward.[2124]

me la mngon phyogs bstan byas nas/ / me yi sngags dang legs par sbyar/ / me yi las la thams cad du/ / me la spyan ni drang bya ste/ / me yi phyag rgya rab sbyar na/ / myur du me ni spyan drang 'gyur/ / phyag rgya sngags kyis gshegs su gsol/ / mdzub mo'i rtse mo nyid la ni/ / mthe bo'i rtse mo rab sbyar bas/ / me yi lha ni gshegs gsol ba'i/ / phyag rgya 'di ni kun gyis bzhed/ / me yi las ni rab sgrub pa'o/ / zlos pa sngags ni gang 'dod pa'i/ / lha rnams dag ni spyan drang 'gyur/ / phyag rgya kun gyi bzhed pa 'di/ / sangs rgyas byin brlab gsungs pa yin/ / sngags mchog dang ni ldan pa yis/ / las rnams rnam pa sna tshogs byed/ / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / sor mo tshang bar sbyar nas ni/ / sor mo'i rtse mo'i mthong dbye zhing / / lhod cing zlum par yang dag bya/ / de nas pad+ma yongs rdzogs pa/ / kha ni bye bar ma gyur bya/ / 'di ni re ba rdzogs byed pa'i/ / phyag rgya don kun sgrub byed ces/ /

“With this mudrā, facing the fire And employing the mantra of fire, One will summon Agni during a homa rite, Or any rite that involves fire in whatever way. “[The god of] fire will be promptly summoned When this mudrā is employed. One should dismiss him with the same mantra, While bringing together the tips of the index fingers. “When one is dismissing the fire deity, The thumbs must be joined together. This mudrā, the highly esteemed, Accomplishes the rites involving fire. “It will summon the deities As required by the reciters Who highly esteem this mudrā, Praising it as endowed with the buddhas’ blessing. When combined with the supreme mantras, This mudrā will accomplish a variety of activities. “With the hands joined together And the fingers touching, One should form, with an añjali gesture, A complete bud that is loose and round in shape. “When it is completely full Like a bud born of a lotus plant, One should know this as the fulfilled wish[2125]‍— The mudrā that accomplishes all aims.

phyag rgya 'di ni rab mchog ste/ / sngon gyi de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs/ / sems can rnams la phan 'dod nas/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis sbyar ba yin/ / sems can yid la 'dod pa dag / yid la re ba'i phan 'dod gang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po sngags ldan pas/ / myur du de dag sgrub par byed/ / phyag rgya 'di ni rab mchog ste/ / yid la re ba rdzogs zhes brjod/ / 'di ni phyag rgya rab mchog ste/ / las kun rab tu sgrub byed pa'o/ / myur du sngags rnams sgrub byed cing / / rgya che nyid kyi rdzas dang bcas/ / thub pa'i zla ba de yis ni/ / zla ba'i 'od la rab tu bstan/ / zla bas pad+ma'i rigs dag la/ / des ni phyag rgya 'di la sbyar/ /

“This excellent, supreme mudrā, Formerly taught in song by the tathāgatas, Is employed in [the rites of] Mañjughoṣa To fulfill beings’ good wishes. “Whatever wish a being may have in mind That aims for something beneficial Will soon be fulfilled [by this mudrā], If it is combined with powerful mantras. This excellent, supreme mudrā Is named the fulfilled wish.[2126] “This excellent, supreme mudrā Accomplishes all activities. It magically empowers (sādhayate) A wide range of mantras and substances. “This mudrā was spread [in the world] Like moonlight by the moon-like Sage. It has been auspiciously linked up by him To the moon-like mantras in the Lotus family.
sngags mkhan ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las rnams byed/ /
This mudrā will accomplish a variety of activities, [Such as] producing the white ambrosia.[2127]

“One should join one’s well-washed hands At the fingers, in such a way That the six fingers[2128] that are in contact Form the shape of a book. The folded small finger and a thumb Should form a raised circle.[2129] “This excellent mudrā is said To pertain to Prajñāpāramitā. As her, this mudrā is the mother of all the buddhas Employed for the sake of liberation. She will accomplish every activity‍— Pacifying and nourishing in particular. “One should join the hands With the right one above the left And position them at the navel, In one’s lap. When the hands thus cling to each other, This mudrā is called the bowl. “The mudrās the bowl and the mother [Prajñāpāramitā][2130] Are best employed with the mantras of the victorious ones. They will accomplish a variety of activities, Whatever may be desired by the mantra adepts.

lag gnyis de bzhin bsdu byas nas/ / mdzub mo gnyis ni bsgreng bar bya/ / gung mo'i sor mo'i rtse mo gnyis/ / cung zad smad pa rta babs yin/ / de nyid yang dag bsgreng byas na/ / rta babs bzang por gsungs pa yin/ / de nyid phan tshun sbyar byas pa/ / sangs rgyas ru dung sgra ru bstan/ / mthe bo'i gtso bo bsgreng byas pa/ / mkhas pas rgyal ba'i sgra ru shes/ /

“When both hands are upraised,[2131] With the index finger raised And the tip of the middle finger slightly bent, This is the archway. “If both[2132] [fingers] are raised, That mudrā is called the fine archway. When they[2133] are mutually interlaced, This is the [forty-]eighth mudrā, the voice. When the thumbs are raised, The wise ones know this as the supreme sound of recitation.[2134]

lag gnyis de bzhin yang dag sbyar/ / mdzub mo'i rtse mo yang dag dgug / sor mo thams cad sbyar byas la/ / cung zad yangs par 'byung ba ni/ / de ni sangs rgyas rnga chen mkhyen/ / chos kyi rnga ni bsgreng byas pa'o/ / de nas lag gcig thal mo ni/ / g.yas pa g.yon pa'i steng du bsgreng / / 'og tu rab tu sbyar ba ni/ / glang po'i rnam par yang dag sbyar/ / g.yas pa'i gung mo'i sor mo ni/ / glang po'i sna 'drar rab tu bya/ /

“One should raise the hands as before, Folding the fingertips in And expanding the fingers As splayed hair.[2135] The wise ones[2136] know this mudrā as the drum, And when [the fingers] are raised, As the Dharma drum. “With the right palm pointing up And laying on top of the left One should create below The nice form of an elephant. “With the right middle finger One should form the shape of an [elephant’s] trunk;

'khor ba'i pha rol phyin pa yis/ / phyag rgya de ni glang por bstan/ / phyag rgya 'di ni phyag rgya che/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis rab tu bstan/ / las rnams mtha' dag byed pa ste/ / 'jig rten kun gyis mchod pa yin/ / lag g.yas brkyang zhing rab bsgreng ba/ / de ni mi 'jigs sbyin par brtags/ / lag pa g.yon pa brkyang byas pa'i/ / mkhrig ma'i tshigs la rab bzhag pa'o/ / gung mo mdzub mo sbyar byas la/ / mthe bo gnyis ni bar du gzhug / gung mo gnyis ni bsgreng bar bya/ / 'khrul pa med pa'i rgya de yin/ /

Those who have transcended saṃsāra Designate this mudrā as the elephant. “This mudrā is proclaimed By the perfect buddhas as a ‘great’ mudrā. It accomplishes all activities, each and every one completely, And is worshiped throughout the world. “Raising up the right hand,[2137] One should display the mudrā of fearlessness And grasp it, at the wrist, With an upraised left hand. “The middle and index fingers should touch each other, With the thumb stuck in between. When it is joined with the middle joint,[2138] This mudrā is called the supreme hand.[2139]

“This excellent, supreme mudrā Was taught by the buddhas from the earliest times. Having formed this mudrā, The reciter grants fearlessness to all beings. When combined with the mantras approved by the sages, This mudrā will swiftly accomplish one’s aims.[2140] “When the hands are joined together, Gracefully enclosing an empty space in between, And the middle fingers are raised, That mudrā is the moving in the direction of that.

de nyid sor mo rnam sbyar zhing / / mthe bo steng du gnas byas te/ / tshigs kyi 'og tu rab bzhag pa/ / mjug rings kyi ni rgya zhes bas bstan/ / de nyid mdzub rtse rab bsgreng ba/ / mda' yi phyag rgyar bstan pa yin/ / mdzub rtse gnyis ni yang dag ldan/ / phan tshun rtse mo rnam sprad cing / / de gnyis tshigs su mtheb gnyis sbyar/ / mthe'u chung gnyis ni yang dag brkyang / / de nyid dgra star bstan pa ste/ / phyag rgya don kun sgrub byed pa'o/ / thams cad yang dag bsdu ba yang / / phyag rgya kun gyis mchod pa yin/ / de bzhin du ni rab bsgreng ba/ / mdzub gnyis rtse mo sbyar byas pa/ / de ni mtshon cha rtse gcig rgya/ / de bzhin 'khor lo mda' chen gshol/ /

“If one entwines the same fingers, With the thumbs placed above, And places the joints against the palms of the hands,[2141] That mudrā is called the comet. The same mudrā, but with the fingertips[2142] raised, Is called the bow and arrow.[2143] “One should join together the index fingers, Entwining their fingertips. The thumbs should be contracted at their joints[2144] And the small fingers outstretched. This mudrā is designated as the axe; It accomplishes all activities. “If one then folds in all [the fingers], That mudrā is the worshiped by the world. If one raises this [mudrā] up, Forming a ‘needle point’ with the tip of the index finger, The mudrā becomes the short javelin; If [this mudrā] assumes a circular form, it becomes the plow.[2145]

mdzub mo 'khor lo bzhin bya dang / / phyag rgya dam pa gshol yang bya/ / phyag rgya drug cu 'di dag ni/ / cho ga dang bcas gsungs pa'ang yin/ / 'di dag ma lus mtshon cha'i rgya/ / sngags dang yang dag ldan par gsungs/ / dman pa kun gyis byas pa'i skyon/ / gza' dang grul bum ma mo dang / / srin mo kun gyi gtso bo rnams/ / byis pa'i sems can 'jigs byed pa/ / phyag rgya'i mtshon cha las byung bas/ / de dag thams cad des 'jig 'gyur/ / phyag rgya drug cu 'di dag gi/ / mtshan nyid nye bar bstan pa yin/ / de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / phyag rgya'i cho ga yang dag 'byung / / lag gnyis de bzhin rnam bkod pa/ / pad+ma 'dra bar yang dag bsgreng / / sor mo thams cad kyis bsgrubs pa/ / phyag rgya pad+ma zhes bya'o/ /

“The plow is a supreme mudrā Formed by bending the index fingers; It completes the first sixty mudrās Repeated here along with instructions.[2146] “All these mudrās are weapons Used along with and activated[2147] by mantras. They remove the problems created by vighnas And destroy grahas, kuṣmāṇḍas, mātṛs, “All the chief rākṣasas, And all those who terrorize children.[2148] These mudrās, serving as weapons, Destroy all of them. “I have now taught the characteristics Of the [first] sixty mudrās. Now I will give the instructions For the [next] mudrās. “Putting the hands together as before, One should raise them, forming the shape of a lotus With all the fingers outstretched;[2149] This mudrā is known as the padma.[2150]

phyag rgya 'di ni mchog ces bya/ / pad+ma'i rigs la yang dag sbyar/ / pad+ma'i rigs ni ji snyed pa/ / sngags dang ldan pas dge bar 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas byin rlabs las byung ba/ / myur du las rnams byed par brjod/ / ji snyed pad+ma'i rigs gsungs pa/ / sngags rnams ma lus sgrub par byed/ / pad+ma rnams kyi phyag rgya 'di/ / phyag rgya'i pad+ma zhes su brjod/ / lag gnyis yang dag sbyar nas ni/ / mdzub mo gnyis ni yang dag bsgreng / / gung mo'i sor mo sbyar byas nas/ / rdo rje rtse gsum yang dag 'byung / / gung mo'i sor mo'i tshigs dbus su/ / mthe bo gnyis kyi rtse mo sbyar/ / de nyid rdo rje zhes gsungs te/ / phyag rgya dam pa tha ma yin/ / ji snyed rdo rje'i rigs kyi sngags/ / de dag phyag rgya 'di sgrub 'gyur/ / cho ga ldan par rab zhugs na/ / myur ba nyid du 'grub par 'gyur/ / sgrub pa las dang yang dag ldan/ / bsgrub bya rtag tu sgrub pa na/ / grub mchog tha ma bar ma ni/ / de la rtag tu 'grub par 'gyur/ / 'jig rten sngags rnams ma lus pa'ang / / the tshom med par 'grub par 'gyur/ /

“This excellent mudrā is said To belong to the Lotus family. Used in combination with any mantras of the same family, It will produce auspicious results. “Being a source of the buddhas’ blessing, It is said to accomplish activities swiftly. It will make effective any mantra That belongs to the Lotus family. Among the mudrās, this mudrā, the padma,[2151] Is taught for the middling [rites].[2152] “One should join the two hands together, Stretching out the index fingers And joining the middle fingers, Thus forming the vinyasta[2153] shape. “When, in the same [mudrā], the thumbs are placed Against the joints of the middle fingers,[2154] That mudrā is called the vajra; It is the supreme mudrā for minor [rites].[2155] “Whatever mantras belong to the Vajra family, They will be rendered efficacious if sealed [with this mudrā]. If used according to procedure, They are known to bring success swiftly. “By employing them, the practitioner will always accomplish Whatever activity he has set out to perform; He will always obtain accomplishment, Whether a supreme, medium, or minor one. All the worldly mantras Will be successful without any doubt.

lag gnyis yang dag sbyar byas nas/ / gung mo gnyis ni yang dag bsgreng / / srin lag mthe bo dag kyang dgug / mthe'u chung gnyis ni sbyar byas la/ / mdzub gnyis rtse mo sprad nas ni/ / mdzub mo'i dbus tshigs gnyis dgug bya/ / gung mo gnyis kyi rtse mo sbyar/ / 'khor lo 'dra bar yang dag 'byung / / 'di ni chos kyi 'khor lo ste/ / 'dir ni phyag rgya'i rgyal por bstan/ / de tshe chos rgyal gyis gsungs te/ / chos kyi 'khor lo rab tu bskor/ / thub pa'i zla ba bdun pa yis/ / de tshe zhi ba'i 'khor lor gsungs/ / phyag rgya'i rgyal po rab sbyar nas/ / dus gsum rgyun mi chad bzlas na/ /

“One should join the hands together, Stretching out the middle fingers. The ring fingers and the thumbs should be folded in And the small fingers should form a ‘needle.’ “The two index fingers should be touching lengthwise, Their tips folded in at the middle joint. The middle fingers, aligned to form a ‘needle,’ Should form the shape of a circle. “This mudrā, the Dharma wheel, Is here taught as the king of mudrās. It was taught by the Dharma kings For the Dharma wheel to turn. “The seventh moon-like sage[2156] designated it, At that time, as the ‘wheel’ for pacifying. Mantra recitation combined with this king of mudrās Destroys the three types of impurity.[2157]

'jig rten pa yi sngags kun dang / / khyab 'jug dbang ldan gyis bshad pa/ / zlos pa phyag rgyar yang dag ldan/ / mthong ba tsam gyis de dag gcod/ / 'di ni phyag rgya rab mchog ste/ / chos kyi dbyings las rnam par byung / / sems can rnams ni ci 'dod pa/ / thams cad las ni byed par 'gyur/ / chos kyi rgyal pos zhi don du/ / phyag rgya 'di ni yang dag bstan/ / cho ga'i rgyal ba'i mchog 'di ni/ / las rnams ma lus rab tu sgrub/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis bstan pa la/ / chos kyi 'khor lo'i phyag rgya 'di'o/ / ma zhi ba yi phyag rgya kun/ / zhi ba'i las la rab tu sbyar/ / sngags pas rtag tu mgo bor ni/ / 'khor lo'i phyag rgya brtag par bya/ / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / kha sbyar 'dra bar bya ba yin/ / sor mo lhod cing yangs par bya/ / lag gnyis sor mo'i rtse dgug pa/ /

“All the worldly mantras Taught by Viṣṇu or Śiva Can be annihilated by reciters Who employ this mudrā, through merely seeing it.[2159] “This excellent, supreme mudrā Originates from the sphere of phenomena; It accomplishes all activities As desired by sentient beings. “It has been taught by the king of Dharma To [accomplish the activity] of pacifying. It will also accomplish all the rites taught In this excellent, supreme manual of rites. This mudrā is called the Dharma wheel, And belongs to the teachings of Mañjughoṣa. “Among all the mudrās,[2160] this one should be employed As the one best suited for the rites of pacifying. The mantra practitioners always view this mudrā As an auspicious wheel.[2161] “One should join the hands as before, Leaving an empty space in between. Then, loosening up[2162] the fingers that form the sheath, One should cup the hands gracefully.[2163]

'di ni pad+ma dkar po yi/ / phyag rgya sems can don sgrub shes/ / de las lag pa gcig btang nas/ / khu tshur phye zhing sor mo bsrings/ / lag pa brkyang ba lta bu ni/ / mchog sbyin gyi ni phyag rgyar brjod/ / lag gnyis kyang ni de bzhin byas/ / kun nas sor mo rnams kyis ni/ / phreng ba bzhin du gshib byas pa/ / rgyal ba'i phyag rgyar 'di brjod do/ / de bzhin lag gnyis sbyar nas ni/ / gung mo mdzub mo gnyis dag ni/ / khab kyi rnam par bya ba yin/ / de las gzhan pa'i sor mo ni/ / cung zad dgug par bya ba yin/ / de nas mdzub mo gnyis dag ni/ / gnas pa'i rnam par legs dgod bya/ / de yang yang dag sbyar byas te/ / srin lag gi ni tshigs su brten/ / 'jig rten mang po'i 'dren pas ni/ / rus sbal phyag rgyar 'di bstan to/ / de bzhin lag gnyis rnam par dgod/ / sor mo dag ni kun nas kyang / / gnyi ga khu tshur mnyam byas nas/ / mdzub mo gnyis ni sbyar bya ba/ / mkhas pas phyag rgya de nyid ni/ / rdo rje dbyug par yang dag brjod/ /

This mudrā is known as the water lily; It accomplishes all aims. “One should put the [right] hand down, Opening the fist and extending the fingers. When the hand is thus fully outstretched, This mudrā is called the boon-granting. “Using both hands again, One should position the fingers To form the pattern of a plait on all sides; This mudrā is called the rope.[2164] “Extending again the same hand‍— The superior right hand‍— One should form the shape of a ‘needle’ With the middle and index fingers.[2165] “The fingertips of the other[2166] fingers Should be slightly bent. One should prop up the index finger, Positioning it appropriately. “The two fingers that touch alongside Should lean against the joint of the ring finger.[2167] The guides of the world Most often refer to this mudrā as the spear.[2168] “One should join the hands as before, With each index finger forming a ‘needle.’[2169] Each hand should form an identical fist With the fingers arranged the same way. The wise call this mudrā The vajra staff.

lag gnyis de bzhin yang dag par/ / kha sbyar 'dra bar byas nas ni/ / phan tshun sbyar ba la brten nas/ / sor mo'i thal mor rnam par dgod/ / mthe bong gnyis ni nang gzhug pa/ / dgra 'jig phyag rgyar brjod pa yin/ / de nas lag gnyis mnyam byas te/ / de nas thal mor byas nas ni/ / kun nas gzhol bar rab tu bya/ / gru yi bzhon par rab tu 'byung / / 'jig rten gsum gyi skyob pa yis/ / gru yi phyag rgyar 'di rab bstan/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho chen po las/ / 'byung po rnams ni yang dag sgrol/ / sor mo de nyid bsgreng nas ni/ / de tshe lag gnyis sna tshogs bya/ / phyag rgya gzhal med khang zhes bya/ / sems can steng du rjes su 'dzud/ / de bzhin lag gnyis yang dag bsdus/ / shing rta zhes ni de la brjod/ / theg gsum 'gro ba'i gtso bo ste/ / skyob pa rnams kyis shing rtar gsung / /

“One should join the hands as before, Enclosing an empty space in between. The fingers, arranged as in the añjali gesture, Should tightly press against each other. When the two thumbs are tucked in, This mudrā is called the killer of hundreds.[2170] “If one then positions both hands In such a way that there is a complete concavity, And forms the añjali gesture Resembling a sailing vessel, “The benefactors of the threefold universe Call this mudrā the boat;[2171] It delivers beings from The great ocean of saṃsāra. “If one subsequently releases the añjali[2172] And forms the citrahasta[2173] gesture, Those who cause beings to move upward Call this mudrā the palace. “When the hands thus positioned are contracted, This is called the chariot; [This mudrā] is the supreme threefold vehicle Called by the world protectors the chariot.[2174]

zlos pa sngags ni 'dod pa la/ / 'byung po kun ni 'dren par byed/ / theg pa mchog la brten nas ni/ / sangs rgyas go 'phang 'thob par byed/ / de nyid lag gnyis rab bsgred nas/ / gnyi ga yang ni kha sbyar bya/ / lag mthil gnyis ni mnyam byas brkyang / / lan kan 'dra bar yang dag 'byung / /

“It brings all beings onto The mantra path of the reciters; Having resorted to this supreme vehicle, They travel the path to buddhahood. “One should shake the hands loose, Repeating this [a few times], And then form the citratala[2175] gesture In the shape of a bench.[2176]

'di ni phyag rgya rab mchog ste/ / 'jig rten mgon gyis legs mchod pa'o/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi gnas rnams su/ / thub pa'i zla bas yang dag gsungs/ / gang du 'das pa'i sangs rgyas dang / / ma 'ongs da ltar bzhugs pa dang / / mya ngan 'das pa'i dbyings la bzhugs/ / gang du gnas mal la bzhugs pa/ / phyag rgya gnas mal zhes bya bar/ / 'jig rten 'dren pas de 'dir mkhyen/ / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / sor mo rnams ni yang dag sbyar/ / kha sbyar du ni rnam par dgod/ / g.yas pa'i mdzub mo gcig gis ni/ / g.yon pa'i rtse mor gtug bya ba/ /

“This excellent, supreme mudrā Is venerated by the lords of the world. The sons of the victorious ones[2177] Call it the resting place of all the buddhas.[2178] “The fully realized buddhas of the past Attained peace by relying on this mudrā.[2179] They have been delivered into the sphere of nirvāṇa Wherein they found their resting place. This mudrā is therefore called By the guides of the world the resting place. “One should place the hands as before, With the fingers touching at the same level And forming a sheath around an empty space. The index finger of the right hand Should be bent at the tip.[2180]

de ni zla ba phyed du brjod/ / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / g.yas pa'i sor mos khu tshur bya/ / lag pa g.yon la yod pa yi/ / sor mo kun ni mnyam bsgreng ste/ / sor mo'i rtse mos khu tshur bcing / / g.yas dang g.yon pa ldan pa yi/ / sor mo rnams ni sbyar byas nas/ / mthe'u chung gnyis ni brkyang byas pa/ / pi bang phyag rgyar nye bar bstan/ / lag gnyis de bzhin byas nas ni/ / sor mo cung zad kha bye yang / / mthe bo gnyis kyi bar du ni/ / mdzub mo gnyis ni brten par bya/ / 'di ni pad mtsho'i phyag rgya ste/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis 'gro la gsungs/ /

This mudrā is called the crescent moon.[2181] “Using both hands again, One should enclose the right thumb in a fist. The fist should be formed With all the fingers of the left hand Evenly aligned and bent at the tip, Thus embracing the right thumb.[2182] “The fingers of the right hand, joined together, Should enclose an empty space, And the small finger should be extended; This mudrā is called the lute.[2183] “Using both hands again, One should splay the fingers in space. Each index finger should be touching The middle of the thumb. The perfect buddhas disseminated this mudrā To the world as the abode of lotuses.[2184]

rtag tu mthe bo gnyis brkyang ba/ / ut+pa la yi phyag rgya zhes/ / rkang gnyis dam pa sangs rgyas kyis/ / 'jig rten du ni gsungs pa yin/ / de nyid thal mo sbyar byas pa/ / 'gro ba phyag 'tshal 'dra ba ste/ / bla ma phyag 'tshal rgya 'di zhes/ / 'jig rten kun tu rnam par grags/ / rgya de nyid ni bsngam byas na/ / lag gnyis zung du yang dag 'byung / / rgya 'di lag pa gnyis gzung zhes/ / 'jig rten gsum du rnam par grags/ / cung zad mthe bo rtsar bzhag ste/ / mtheb rtsar phan tshun legs gnon pa/ / de ni kha sbyar rgya ru 'gyur/ / mya ngan 'khrug pa rnam par 'jig / gang dag mtshon cha las byung rnams/ / phyag rgya 'di dag gsungs pa yin/ / me tog gdan dang bzhon pa dang / / gzhan yang gdon ni 'jigs byed pa/ / thams cad las kun byed ldan pa/ / skyob pa'i sngags kun thams cad yin/ /

“When the thumbs are subsequently raised up, The mudrā becomes the birthplace of water lilies;[2185] It was taught in the world By the perfect buddhas, supreme among two-legged beings. “One should make the añjali gesture In salutation to the teacher of the world. This mudrā is known all over the world As the salutation. “The same mudrā, when the two hands Are propped up to form a pair, Is known throughout the three worlds As the couple.[2186] “When the hands are slightly lowered, With the thumbs tightly squeezed,[2187] That mudrā is the hollow space; It destroys sorrow and weariness. “All these mudrās that are described here‍— Those that constitute weapons, Those that have the names of flowers, Or furniture for resting, or instruments, and so forth‍— All of them collectively can accomplish anything, If combined with the mantras as has been taught.[2188]

tshes grangs dang ni rgyu skar dang / / smyung ba dag kyang mi bya ste/ / phyag rgya sngags su rab ldan na/ / las rnams myur du grub par byed/ / zlos pa dka' thub ldan pa dang / / sngags zlos pa la mkhas pa dang / / phyag rgya sngags su rab ldan na/ / bsgrub bya min pa'ang cung zad med/ / lag pa gnyis po bya ba ni/ / phan tshun thal mo yang dag sbyar/ / mthe'u chung srin lag mthe bo yi/ / tshigs ni bar ma sbyar bar bya/ /

“There is no need to observe the right lunar days, Planetary configurations, or fasts; If the mudrās and the mantras are used in combination, They will swiftly accomplish any activity. “For an experienced reciter who has developed the energy (tapas), It is enough merely to recite the mantra. When the mudrā and mantra are combined, though, There is nothing that cannot be accomplished. “Using both hands again, One should join them in the añjali gesture And extend sideways the small and the ring fingers and the thumb; This mudrā is called the incense.[2189]

gung mo sbyar ba'i tshigs gsum par/ / mdzub mo bkug ste sbyar bar bya/ / rigs gsum gyi ni spyi la yang / / mchod yon gyi ni phyag rgyar bstan/ / sor mo zung ni gsum po dag / de bzhin phan tshun yang dag sbyar/ / mdzub mo'i rtse gnyis yang dag sprad/ / mthe bo gnyis kyi 'gram du bskum/ / thal mo 'dra bar yang dag ldan/ / me tog phyag rgyar bstan pa yin/ / lag pa'i thal mo bkan byas nas/ / mthe'u chung sbyar byas rgyab tu ni/ / srin lag yang dag sbyar bar bar bya/ / de yi rgyab tu gung mo sbyar/ / mdzub mo gnyis ni sbyar bar bya/ / sa la thal sbyar bya ba yin/ / mthe bo gnyis ni 'gram bzhag pa/ / chos kyi phyag rgyar bstan pa yin/ / thal mo gzhan gyi sbyor ba yis/ / mdzub gnyis cung zad bkug pa ni/ / gtor ma spyi yi phyag rgya ru/ / 'jig rten skyob pas de gsungs so/ /

“One should join the bent index finger With the three joints of the middle finger. The three pairs of the opposite fingers Should be interlaced.[2190] “The tips of the index fingers should touch, Inclined toward the thumbs. The añjali shape thus formed Is designated as the flower mudrā. “The palms of the hands should face upward, With the small fingers interlaced. The ring fingers should be intertwined behind [the palms], And the middle fingers should be joined behind them. “The two index fingers should also be interlaced, Touching the ground with the palm. When the two thumbs are placed close together, This is taught to be the Dharma mudrā. “Using as the basis the añjali gesture, One should slightly bend the index fingers. This mudrā is the common bali mudrā[2191] Passed down by the protectors of the world.

ji ltar cho ga bzhin du ni/ / nang du me tog gzhug byas na/ / gtor ma kun gyi las la ni/ / gsang sngags kun la byin par 'gyur/ / g.yas pa mi 'jigs sbyin pa'i lag / g.yon pa'ang de bzhin bya ba yin/ / mkhrig mar sbyor ba'i bya ba yis/ / g.yas g.yon dag ni bsnol bar bya/ /

“Inside [this mudrā] one should place flowers Of various kinds, as available,[2192] And offer them while reciting mantras In all bali rites. “One should display with the right hand The mudrā of granting fearlessness; With the left, one should grasp The right hand around the wrist.[2193]

'di ni sngags rnams ma lus pa'i/ / dri yi phyag rgyar brjod pa yin/ / lag g.yas khu tshur bcings nas ni/ / mthe bo dang ni gung mo gnyis/ / de nas rab tu sbyar bar bya/ / mar me'i phyag rgyar brjod pa yin/ / srin lag dang ni mthe bo nyid/ / bgrang phreng dag tu yang dag gnas/ / rtag tu mthe'u chung rnam par brkyang / / de 'og gung mo'ang brkyang bar bya/ / mdzub mo bskums te bzhag pa la/ / bgrang phreng gi ni phyag rgyar brjod/ / de nas thal sbyar nang du ni/ / sngags rig pas ni phreng ba gzhug / ci 'dod sngags ni bzla byas na/ / myur du grub pa'i mchog rab ster/ /

This mudrā is called the perfume; It may be used with any mantra. “One should make the right [and left] hands into fists. Always [joining] the thumbs and the middle fingers, One should form [with the thumb] the shape of a needle; This mudrā is called the lamp.[2194] “The ring finger and the thumb should be positioned As if for turning rosary beads. The small finger should always be extended With the middle finger lying on top of it, And the index finger should be folded in; This mudrā is called the bead.[2195] “The mantra adept should place A rosary of beads between the palms joined in añjali And recite the mantra according to their wish‍— This will swiftly effect the fulfillment of wishes.[2196]

cho ga 'di ni rtag mthong na/ / sngags rnams kun ni spyod par byed/ / me la lag pa g.yas pa ni/ / mi 'jigs sbyin pa'i phyag rgyar bya/ / me la mngon du bltas bzhag nas/ / mdzub mo rtag tu dgug par bya/ / mthe bo lag pa'i dbus su ni/ / bkug nas yang dag rab tu dgod/ / me ni yongs su spyan drang ba'i/ / phyag rgyar 'di ni bstan pa yin/ /

Always employed according to procedure, This mudrā is effective [in combination] with any mantra. “[In the rites involving] fire, one should display, With the right hand in front, the mudrā of fearlessness. Positioning it to face the fire, One should always fold in the index finger. “The thumb should be placed against the hand, Curled in the center [of the palm]. This mudrā has been designated For summoning Jātavedas.[2197]

mdzub mo yi ni rtse mo dang / / mthe bo gcig tu sbyar bya ba/ / me dang las rnams kun la ni/ / gshegs su gsol bar rab tu snang / / sngags rnams kun la mkhas pa yis/ / sbyin sreg las la bya ba yin/ / rgya 'di dag dang ldan pa yis/ / sngags ni me la legs par sbyar/ / phyag 'tshal thal mo byas pa las/ / sor mo kun nas nang du gzhug / de nyid rnam par bzlog byas nas/ / mthe bo gnyis kyang gshib par bya/ / mdzub mo phyi rol yang dag bkug / gung mo dag la yang dag brten/ / phyag rgya 'di ni mchog tu gsungs/ / mchod pa'i las la sbyar bar bya/ / sngags rnams kun la phyag 'tshal dang / / sngags kyi mgon po rgyal sras sbyar/ / sngags rnams kun la sbyang ba dang / / gdan dag la yang rab tu sbyar/ / me tog med par gyur na yang / / phyag rgya bcings la mchod par bya/ /

“When the tips of the index fingers are bent And the thumbs joined together as one,[2198] This is the dismissing mudrā; It is recommended for the all the rites involving fire. “The wise practitioner should perform The rite of homa for every mantra [deity]. The mantra, appropriate for the rites involving fire, Should be used in combination with these [two] mudrās. “One should form the gesture of salutation, añjali, With all the fingers folded in. One should do this in reverse,[2199] With the thumbs crossed over. “The folded index fingers, projecting outwardly, Should rest on the middle fingers. This mudrā, described as the most excellent, Can be employed in all acts of making offerings. “One should salute every mantra[-deity] And the mantra-lord of the sons of the victorious ones, And offer, to every such deity, A fine seat. “If flowers are unavailable, One should form and use[2200] this mudrā.

cho ga 'di yis mchod na ni/ / sngags rnams don kun sgrub par byed/ / mchod yon phyag rgya byas pas ni/ / mchod pa bzang po byas par 'gyur/ / gnyis pa sems kyi mchod pa ste/ / me tog ci 'dra yod pas so/ / rdzogs sangs rkang gnyis dam pa yis/ / mchod pa'i cho ga 'di gsungs so/ / me tog med par gyur na yang / / mchod pa rnam pa gnyis su brjod/ / sngags rnams rab tu 'grub bya'i phyir/ / las rnams kun la sbyar bar bya/ / sngags kun byed pa'i phyag rgya ni/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis gsungs pa'ang yin/ / gnas dang mal dang bzhon pa dang / / khrus dang btung dang bza' ba dang / / mar me spos dang sngags khrus dang / / dkyil 'khor dag ni byed pa la/ / sngags rnams kun gyi dam tshig dang / / sngags pa rnams kyis byin rlabs byed/ / 'jig rten mgon gyis gsungs pa yi/ / phyag rgya 'di ni las kun byed/ / phyag rgya rnams kyi nges byung ba/ / yongs rdzogs brgyar ni gsungs pa yin/ /

The mantra[-deities], worshiped according to procedure, Will fulfill all aims. “When this mudrā is employed, The aim of worship is accomplished better.[2201] As for the second, the mental offering, One can offer any type of flowers. “This worship procedure was taught By the fully realized buddhas, supreme among two-legged beings. The worship may be of two kinds, [Either with or] without the flowers. “To make all the mantras fully effective in all rites, One should employ this mudrā‍— The suitable for all rites[2202]‍— Taught by the fully realized buddhas. “[It can be used] when sitting, Lying down,[2203] bathing, drinking, eating, Decorating, lighting lamps, reciting mantras, Or creating a maṇḍala at a specific location.[2204] “It activates the bond with all the mantra[-deities], Thus conferring blessings on the mantra practitioner. This mudrā, the suitable for all rites, Was taught by the lords of the world. “The first one hundred mudrās have now been taught, Following the required order.[2205]

de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / phyag rgya dag ni brgyad po ste/ / lag gnyis de bzhin sbyar nas ni/ / gnyi ga kun nas mnyam byas la/ / de dag nyid las mdzub mo dang / / gung mo gnyis ni sbyar bar bya/ / mthe bo gnyis kyi sen mo ni/ / gsum pa'i tshigs char sbyar bar bar bya/ / cung zad nang du bkug nas ni/ / rab tu sbyar ba dag tu bya/ /

Now I will teach the eight mudrās That come next. “One should use both hands, Starting from the same position. The index fingers should be placed exactly as before, Joined with the ‘needle’ of the middle fingers.[2206] “The two fingers should touch At the third knuckle below the nail [of the middle finger]. One should thus display the shape of a needle, While forming a sheath [with one’s hands].[2207]

bdag nyid chen po 'khor lo can/ / sngags kyi bdag po'i phyag rgya yin/ / 'di nyid las ni mdzub mo dgug / gung mo dag ni mnyam par sbyar/ / srin lag gnyis kyi sen mo ni/ / sbyar ba'i rnam par dgod par bya/ / 'di ni gtsug tor phyag rgyar ni/ / rgyal ba'i dbang pos gsungs pa yin/ / lag gnyis de bzhin bkod nas ni/ / gung mo'i sor mo bcings byas pa/ / mthe'u chung sor dang yang dag ldan/ / gdugs dkar po las rgya 'di byung / / gung mo mnyam par byas nas ni/ / sor mo gnyis ni yang dag sbyar/ / gdub kor zlum po 'dra ba ni/ / phyag rgya chen por de la brjod/ / de nyid las ni mdzub mo yi/ / tshigs ni skam kha lta bur bya/ / de nas gung mo sbyar te dgod/ / lag pa'i 'og gi char sbyar nas/ /

This is the mudrā of the mantra-lord, The great Cakravartin.[2208] “If the same index fingers are brought into contact With the middle finger sidelong, And the ring fingers touch At the tips of the fingernails,[2209] That mudrā is the uṣṇīṣa; It was taught by the victorious lords. “One should place the hands as before, With the middle fingers entwined[2210] And the small fingers joined together; This mudrā is called the arising of Sitātapatra. “One should align the tips of the middle fingers So that their fingernails touch.[2211] When the shape of a bracelet is formed, The mudrā is said to be the great mudrā.[2212] “One should place the tips of the index fingers . . . with the three . . .[2213] The middle fingers should form a ‘needle,’ With the hands firmly joined below.[2214]
de las gsum pa'i tshigs dag tu/ / mthe bo'i sor mos gnon par bya/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni blo ldan gyi/ / 'di ni phyag rgya mchog tu gsungs/ /
“The thumbs should reach [to the middle fingers], With their nails[2215] squeezed [under the third joint thereof]. This mudrā is taught as the most excellent mudrā Of the sagacious Mañjughoṣa.[2216]

“One should place the hands as before, Forming the añjali gesture. The tips of the middle fingers Should remain bent.[2217] The thumbs should touch the joints Of the middle and three other fingers.[2218] “One should then form a ‘needle’ with the small fingers, Straightening them and raising them up. This excellent supreme mudrā Constitutes the treasury of the Dharma.[2219]

lag gnyis de bzhin bkod nas ni/ / cho ga mthong la yang dag gnas/ / sor mo de nyid kun gyis ni/ / kun nas gang ba'i mdzod ltar gnas/ / lag pa gnyis ni rnam bskyed nas/ / lag sor brgyad ni rab tu brkyang / /

“One should position the hands as before Following the same basic instructions, And then arrange all the fingers To form the complete [shape of] a basket. “Both hands should be splayed, With the eight fingers forming an enclosure.[2220]

skyes bu brgyad po de nyid shes/ / zung bzhi dag tu gyur pa ni/ / rdzogs sangs rkang gnyis dam pa yis/ / de nyid dge 'dun zhes kyang gsungs/ / de nyid 'phags pa'i dge 'dun rgyar/ / srid pa'i gnas 'dir gsungs pa yin/ / phyag rgya 'di ni rab mchog ste/ / phyag rgya ma lus rab tu sgrub/ /

These eight, divided into four pairs, Represent the eight personages who know reality. The perfect buddhas, supreme among two-legged beings, Call this mudrā the saṅgha. “This mudrā is known In the realm of existence as the saṅgha. It is supreme and excellent, As it accomplishes the aims of all activities.[2221]

lag gnyis de bzhin kha sbyar te/ / thal mo sbyar ba'i rnam par gnas/ / mdzub mo gcig ni rab brkyang ba/ / lag pa g.yas pa yang dag brkyang / / de 'di 'byung po zhi byed par/ / de nyid gzigs pa rnams kyis bstan/ / phyag rgya 'di ni mchog ces bya/ / las rnams kun gyi don sgrub byed/ / lag gnyis de bzhin sbyar nas ni/ / sor rtse rim bzhin mtshan pa yi/ / bsdus nas kha sbyar dag tu bya/ / mthe bo gnyis ni bsgreng nas bskum/ / de 'di pad+ma'i phreng ba zhes/ / dang po'i sangs rgyas dag gis gsungs/ / lag pa dag ni de gnyis kyis/ / sor mo kun nas bkan la brkyang / / sor mo gsum gnyis bsgreng nas ni/ / me tog kha bye'i rnam par bya/ /

“One should cup the hands, Joining them together in an añjali gesture, And then extend the index finger Of the right hand. “This mudrā, the pacifier of beings, Was taught by the teachers who see reality; It is described as excellent, As it fulfills the aims of all activities. “One should place the hands as before, Their fingertips ‘piled up’ in a line. The hands should form a lump, hollow within, With the thumbs raised up and bent. This mudrā, the lotus wreath, Was taught by the buddhas from the earliest times. “The palms of the hands should face upward, With the fingers splayed around. The hands should form the shape of a fully open bud, With the thumbs and three other fingers fully extended.[2222]

gnyis pa'i tshigs la bzhag pa ni/ / mthe bo dang ni mdzub mo gnyis/ / de 'dir srid pa gsum gnas kyi/ / phyag rgyar rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis gsungs/ / phyag rgya 'di ni phyag rgya che/ / las kun byed kyi phyag rgya brgyad/ / mthu mnyam brtson 'grus chen por ni/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis yang dag gsungs/ / muSh+Ti gtams phrag bye ba ni/ / stong phrag brgyad cu yang dag 'byung / / thub mchog grangs med 'das pa yis/ / phyag rgya 'di dag rab tu gsungs/ / phyag rgya cho ga yang dag 'byung / / rtsa brgyad brgya ni rab tu gsungs/ / 'di dag kun gyi sngags kun dang / / las rnams dag kyang grub pa yin/ /

“The thumbs and the index fingers Should touch at the second joint. The fully realized buddhas call this excellent mudrā The abode of the Thirty[-Three].[2223] “These [last] eight mudrās, designated as ‘Great’ mudrās, are suitable for peaceful rites.[2224] Taught by the fully realized buddhas, They are of equal splendor and great efficacy. “The spontaneously arisen Eminent sages of the past, Who are beyond counting, Taught sixty quadrillions and eighty mudrās. The practical instructions Were given for 108 mudrās. “With all of them available, One can accomplish all the mantra-rites;
One will accomplish the rites Of all the mantra [deities].[2225]

sangs rgyas rdzu 'phrul che kun gyi/ / phyag rgya 'di ni bzhed cing gsungs/ / cho ga 'di dag sbyar ba yis/ / don rnams myur du sgrub par byed/ / shAkya seng ge mi yi mchog / thub pa mchog gis de gsungs nas/ / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs la de bzhin gsungs/ / 'jam dpal gyi ni cho ga 'di/ / phyag rgya dag ni yang dag byung / / sa steng bstan pa bsrung don du/ / phyag rgya 'di ni rab tu gtad/ / dus mtha' nye bar 'od 'gyur zhing / / dus mthar mya ngan 'das pa na/ /

“These one hundred [and eight] mudrās were taught By all the buddhas of great power.[2226] If employed according to procedure, They will swiftly accomplish all aims.” Having thus spoken, the most eminent of sages, The Lion of the Śākyas, supreme among men, Then specifically addressed Mañjughoṣa, The bodhisattva of great power: “This collection of the different sets of mudrās Found in your manual Was handed down by yourself, Mañjuśrī, To protect [the Buddha’s] instructions on earth At the time when the final period has arrived And I have departed into nirvāṇa.

nga yi bstan pa bsrung don du/ / nga yis 'di dag thams cad bshad/ / sngags rnams dag ni rgya cher bcas/ / phyag rgya rnams kyi mtshan nyid bshad/ / 'jig rten kun la gsang ba dang / / shin tu gsang ba'ang brjod pa yin/ / mdo 'dir cho ga lhag pa ste/ / yon tan rgya chen gsal bar byas/ / sngags rnams du ma'i tshig dang ni/ / yon tan brjod pa yang dag 'byung / / phyag rgya rnam pa mang por ldan/ / rigs pa'i rgyud ni rab tu bstan/ / mthu dang yon tan grub mtha' dang / / zlos pa'i rgyu ni yang dag 'byung / / 'gro ba'i skye gnas sems can gyi/ / dge ba'i 'bras bu 'byung ba'ang gsungs/ / gzhon nu khyod kyi sngags rnams kyi/ / grub pa'i gtan tshigs rab tu sbyar/ / de skad gsungs nas 'jam dpal ni/ / gzhon nu nam mkhar gnas pa yis/ / 'jig rten mgon po 'od byed pa/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas la mgos phyag 'tshal/ / dbugs ring phyung nas snying rjes brlan/ / mchi ma de nas phyis nas kyang / / sangs rgyas zhabs drung gnas nas kyang / / de la myur du zhus pa ni/ /

“I have now taught all of it In order to protect my doctrine‍— I taught the defining characteristics Of the mudrās and the mantras at length. This esoteric and secret lore Has now been taught for all of the world. “It has been taught in this sūtra‍—the lord of manuals That is replete with excellent qualities That arise in multiple ways Based on the letters of the mantras. “Many applications of mantra and tantra Have been explained in it. [This sūtra] constitutes for the reciters the cause Of a definitive accomplishment of glorious qualities. “It is said that auspicious results will arise For beings, whatever destinies they follow, If they apply themselves to the cause Of accomplishing your mantras, O divine youth!” Thus addressed, the divine youth Mañjuśrī, Resting in space, Bowed his head to the perfect Buddha, The sun-like lord of the world. He sighed deeply, tender with compassion, And then began to weep piteously. He moved close to the Buddha And asked about the supreme boon:[2227]

bcom ldan 'jig rten 'das pa na/ / sngags kyi mdzod 'di sa steng du/ / bdag nyid chen po'i sems can la/ / de tshe ji ltar 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de skad gsungs nas sangs rgyas kyis/ / de tshe 'jam pa'i dbyangs la gsungs/ / gzhon nu khyod kyis yongs zhus pa/ / bu khyod 'jam dpal rab tu nyon/ / nga ni 'jig rten mya ngan 'das/ / sa steng stongs par gyur pa dang / / chos kyi mdzod kyang 'jig pa dang / / nyan thos rnams kyang 'das pa na/ / rkang gnyis dam pa ston pa yi/ / gzugs brnyan mchod rten dag kyang bya/ / spos dang dri dang byug pa yis/ / mchod dang bsnyen bkur bya ba dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs gos mchog dang / / gzhan yang nor bu'i gdub kor rgyan/ / rnam pa sna tshogs bza' dang bca'/ / yang dag sbyar ba dbul bar bya/ / rnam pa sna tshogs phun sum tshogs/ / ci 'dod kha zas byas pa la/ / de bzhin sngags ni bzlas byas dbul/ / sems can dge ba'i skyes gnas 'gyur/ / dam pa'i 'gro ba'i skye gnas su/ / grong mchog dag tu skye bar 'gyur/ / mthar ni byang chub gzhol 'gyur zhing / / phyi nas zhi bar de dag 'gro/ / de skad gsungs nas 'jam dpal ni/ / sangs rgyas kyis ni gsungs la dga'/ / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / blo ldan de nas cang mi smra/ / chos kyi 'khor lo skor byed pa'i/ / sangs rgyas 'dus par sangs rgyas kyi/ / gtsang ba'i gnas kyi steng gnas nas/ / 'di dag sangs rgyas snga mas gsungs/ / de tshe chos kyi 'khor lo bskor/ / yun ring dus su 'das pa yin/ /

“When the mantra basket [of teachings] Has disappeared in the world and on earth, How will beings be able to ensure An auspicious course of rebirth?”[2228] Being thus asked, the perfect buddha Spoke to Mañjughoṣa as follows: “Listen, dear Mañjuśrī, divine youth, If you are asking. When I have passed from this world into final nirvāṇa And the earth is devoid of a buddha, When the basket of the Dharma has disappeared And [all] the śrāvakas have long ago entered nirvāṇa, “At that time, [beings] should make An image of the Teacher,[2229] best of two-legged beings,[2230] And offer to it, respectfully, Incense, fragrances, scented oils, “Different types of high-quality clothes, And other things, such as jeweled earrings, adornments, And sacrificial food consisting of Different types of solid and liquid articles That come in different forms, According to the maker’s choice. “The destiny of beings who repeat the mantra While doing these things will be auspicious. They will reach exalted abodes And the highest birth. They will eventually attain awakening And obtain the subsequent peace.” Buoyed up by the perfect Buddha, Mañjuśrī rejoiced at his words. The sagacious bodhisattva of great power Remained very joyful afterward.[2231] All that was taught in former times Was now set to continue above the realm of the Pure Abode. The Buddha, turner of the wheel of Dharma, Turned, in the presence of the buddhas, The wheel of the mantra [path], Letting it roll for a long time.[2232]

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ phyag rgya'i cho ga'i le'u rab 'byam las/ nyi shu rtsa dgu pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter on mudrā procedures, thirty-fifth[2233] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
phyag rgya'i cho ga'i le'u
Chapter 36
