de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal mchog tu rab tu gsang ba khyod kyi phyag rgya dang ldan pa'i phyag rgya'i mtshan nyid 'khor dang bcas pa yod de/ las thams cad la nye bar sbyar ba phun sum tshogs pa thams cad sbyin par byed pa/ 'bras bu dang bcas pa/ sngags thams cad kyi rjes su 'gro ba/ las thams cad sgrub pa/ mdor na 'jam dpal nyon cig / dang por re zhig thal mo rab tu brkyang la mdzub mo dang mthe'u chung gnyis rtse sprad de tshigs bar ma btud nas so so so sor rjes su bcug pa yin te/ de la 'di ni 'jam dpal khyod kyi rtsa ba'i phyag rgya zhes bya ba las thams cad byed par 'gyur ba'o/ / lag pa gnyis de bzhin du byas la srin lag gnyis sbyar la de bzhin du gung mo dang mdzub mo yang bya zhing mthe'u chung gnyis kyi ri mo gong ma la mthe bo'i rtse mo bzhag pa ste/ 'jam dpal 'di ni khyod kyi gdong gi phyag rgya zhes bya ba ste gnyis pa'o/ / phan tshun du sor mo bsnol ba khu tshur du byas la gung mo'i sor mo gnyis rnam par bkrol la rtse mo sbyar te/ de'i 'gram gnyis su mdzub mo gnyis dkri zhing mthar gzhag par bya'o/ / de la 'di ni 'jam dpal khyod kyi mche ba'i phyag rgya zhes bya ba gzhan yin no/ / mche ba'i phyag rgya'i 'gram du mthe bo gnyis bzhag pa'i phyag rgya 'di ni mngon sum du 'jam dpal gzhon nu khyod nyid yin no/ / gnas de dang lag pa'i kha sbyar der nye bar bzhugs shing dam tshig gis byin gyis rlob par byed do/ /

At that time the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “There is, Mañjuśrī, a most secret mudrā presentation that includes your root[2234] mudrā and its assorted mudrās. [These mudrās] may be employed in all rites. In short, they bring every kind of good fortune and produce results; they supplement every mantra and accomplish the aim of every activity. “To start, one should extend the hands in the añjali gesture, with the index and the ring fingers folded in at the middle joint and the fingers not touching.[2235] This, Mañjuśrī, is described as your root mudrā; it is suitable for all rites. “If one joins the hands the same way, but with the ring, index, and middle fingers touching closely and the small fingers positioned along an upward line toward the tips of the thumbs,[2236] this, Mañjuśrī, is another mudrā of yours, called the mouth. “If one makes a fist in such a way that the facing fingers touch,[2237] extends the middle fingers to form the shape of a needle, and places the two index fingers in such a way that they surround this [needle] on either side, this, Mañjuśrī, is your mudrā called the fangs. “If one [subsequently] positions the thumbs on either side,[2238] that mudrā is you, Mañjuśrī, in person. You remain contained in that place, in the cavity between the hands, as the blessing of the samaya.

lag pa'i sor mo phan tshun khu tshur du byas la mdzub mo gnyis bkrol te/ mthe bo gnyis gung mo'i nang du chung bar byas pa 'di ni 'jam dpal khyod kyi gtsug pud kyi phyag rgya zhes bya ba ste/ gzhan yin no/ / thal mo'i tshigs rnams brkyang ba byas la srin lag dang / mdzub mo gnyis kyi rtse mo gung mo'i nang du rtse sprad de bzhag pa 'di ni 'jam dpal mngon sum khyod nyid kyi rtsa ba'i sngags su bstan pa yin no/ / 'di nyid kyi phyag rgya la mdzub mo gnyis brkyang bar byas pa ste/ de la 'di ni 'jam dpal khyod kyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ro/ / mthe'u chung dang srin lag gnyis bsnol ba byas nas lag pa kha sbyar gyi nang du bzhag la gung mo'i phyi rol tu mdzub mo'i rtse mo yongs su bkug la/ mthe bo gnyis kyi rtse mo yang dag par bcar ba'o/ / gzhan 'di yang 'jam dpal khyod kyi zhal gyi phyag rgya yin no/ /

“If one stretches out the index fingers of the mutually touching fists and positions both thumbs in the space in between,[2239] this, Mañjuśrī, is another one of your mudrās, [called] the crest. “If one extends the hands in the añjali gesture and places the index finger, crossed at the joints with the ring finger, between the tips of the middle fingers,[2240] this, Mañjuśrī, is another root mudrā that is said to be yourself in person.[2241] “If one forms the same mudrā as before, but with the index fingers extended, this, Mañjuśrī, is your eye[2242] mudrā. “If the small and ring fingers are entwined and positioned in the cavity between the hands, the middle fingers are placed on the outside with their tips folded in above the index fingers,[2243] and the tips of the thumbs press against each other, this, Mañjuśrī, is yet another mouth mudrā of yours.

las thams cad pa yang yin te 'di nyid kyi rim gyis sor mo re re bkrol ba mthe bo dang bcas pa byas na ma rungs pa'i gdon thams cad rab tu 'byer bar 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du rna ba dang mgrin pa dang lag ngar dang snying dang lag pa dang lkog ma dang rked pa dang lte ba dang brla dang byin pa dang rkang pa dang mig dang kha dang lce rnams te/ de ltar sor mo bcu rnams mthar gyis brkyang na/ rim bzhin du phyag rgya'i mtshan nyid du 'gyur te/ mthar gyis kyang las byed do/ / zhal gyi phyag rgyas ni kha 'ching bar byed do/ / mche ba'i phyag rgyas ni gdon ma rungs pa las grol lo/ / lce'i phyag rgyas ni tshig ngan pa zlog par byed do/ / snying gi phyag rgyas ni mi'i bdag po'i khro ba sel bar byed pa'am/ sems can gzhan lha dang lha ma yin dang mi dang mi ma yin pa dang 'gro ba rnam pa sna tshogs la brten pa'i khros pa rnams kyi khro ba 'jig par 'gyur te/ de bzhin du mthar gyis thams cad du las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ /

“Proceeding in the same way, one should loosen up the fingers one by one‍—all of them, including the thumbs‍—and then extend them one by one, with the right thumb raised up. This, Mañjuśrī, is your uṣṇīṣa mudrā. “When the right . . . is curled[2244] and the left extended, that [same mudrā] becomes the forehead mudrā; seeing it,[2245] all the wicked grahas will flee. “In the same way [one should form the mudrās of] the ears, neck, arms, heart, hands, throat, hips, navel, thighs, calves, feet, eyes, mouth, and tongue. By extending the ten fingers one after the other, one will display the mudrā signs in their respective order. They accomplish their respective activities: “A mouth mudrā will shut [the opponent’s] mouth. The fangs mudrā will effect release from the wicked grahas.[2246] The tongue mudrā will suppress evil talk. The heart mudrā will appease the king’s anger, or the anger of any other displeased being‍— a god or asura, or any other human or nonhuman being born in whatever form. In this way, one can successively accomplish all activities in all respects.

de ltar rim pa 'dis phyag rgya grangs med par 'gyur te/ / las grangs med pa dag kyang byed par 'gyur ro/ / 'jam dpal khyod kyis rnam pa thams cad du phyag rgya thams cad kho na las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / dpa' bo chen po de bzhin gshegs pa grangs las 'das pa dag gis phyag rgya 'di dag bcings so/ / phyag rgya chen po dpa' bo chen po sa chen po la gnas pas kyang bcings so/ / gang du gtams pa phrag bye ba sum cu rtsa gsum mam brgyad cu'am dgu bcu rtsa lnga'am khri phrag drug cu'i grangs la sogs pa 'jig rten las 'das pa'i yang 'das pas phyag rgya bcings so/ /

“Following this pattern, there are innumerable mudrās. Accordingly, Mañjuśrī, you can accomplish every activity whatsoever. All activities arise because of all these mudrās. These great mudrās are used by tathāgatas impossible to count, great heroes and protectors, and also by the great heroes who have reached all the higher levels that transcend the world‍—ever and ever beyond it‍—where myriads [of them abide].[2247] They are the thirty-six . . . eighty . . . nine . . . five . . . who are sixty billion in number.[2248]

'jig rten bya ba gang gzhan ni/ / kun kyang phyag rgya rnams su 'dus/ / 'di dag gang yang rung ba yi/ / phyag rgyas don kun sgrub byed pa'o/ / dkyil 'khor bsgrub pa'i dus dag tu/ / lag pa gnyis kyis bcing bar bya/ / sngon du bsnyen pa la brtson pas/ / sbyin sreg bzlas pa dag la'ang bya/ / 'dug pa'am 'greng ba dag gis kyang / / zlos pas ci 'dod bar du bzla/ / srung ba chen po'i cho gas kyang / / myur du grub pa thob par 'gyur/ / dus kun phyag rgya kun gyis ni/ / las rnams kun ni bya ba yin/ /

“All the rites involve mudrās, Including all the worldly rites. If performed using these and other mudrās, These rites can accomplish the aim of any practice. “The mudrās are formed with both hands At the time of practice within the maṇḍala, Whether one is doing the preliminary practice, The homa [rite], or during recitation. “A vow holder may recite while sitting, Standing, or however they wish. One should perform all the activities Always relying on the full repertoire of the mudrās And employing the ritual procedure Of the great protection for oneself and others.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ phyag rgya'i cho ga'i le'u rab 'byam gnyis pa las/ sum cu pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed second chapter on mudrā procedures, thirty-sixth[2249] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
sngags dang phyag rgya dang nges par sdom pa dang las dang cho ga'i le'u
Chapter 37

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal khyod kyi rtsa ba'i cho ga la phyag rgya mchog tu shin tu gsang ba gzhan yang yod de/ phyag rgya dang rgyud thams cad kyi cho ga sngags thams cad kyi mngon par 'dod pa/ sngags thams cad dang lhan cig yang dag par sbyar na/ las thams cad rab tu sgrub par byed pa/ yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi lam rnam par sbyor bar byed pa/ sems can thams cad kyi lam du gyur pa yin no/ /

At that time the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, as follows: “There is, Mañjuśrī, in your root manual, another most secret mudrā. Its ritual procedure [represents] the entire mudrā system. It is recommended for all the mantras and can be employed with any of them. It accomplishes all rites and purifies the path to perfect awakening.[2250]

srid pa'i las thams cad rnam par 'jig par byed pa/ sems can thams cad kyi nye bar 'tsho ba tshe dang nad med pa dang dbang phyug dang bsam pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa/ sems can thams cad yongs su dga' bar byed pa/ sems can thams cad kyi yid la mngon par 'dod pa 'bras bu dang bcas par byed pa/ las thams cad byed pa/ sngags thams cad rab tu sgrub par byed pa/ phyag rgya dang sngags thams cad dang ldan pa yin te/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa khyod de nyon cig /

It destroys all the paths that lead to saṃsāric existence. It sustains all beings and grants long life, freedom from disease, and powerful sense faculties. It fulfills all wishes and gives rise to all the factors of awakening. It gives joy to all beings and produces the results they all wish and hope for. It fulfills all activities and makes all mantras efficacious. It comprises all the other mudrās and mantras. Listen, Mañjuśrī, divine youth!

dang po re zhig gtsug tor gyi mtshan nyid du gyur pa ni/ lag pa gnyis mnyam por bkan cing brkyang bar bya'o/ / mthe bo dang srin lag gnyis lag pa'i dkyil du sen mos bzung zhing mthe bo'i rtse mo sbyar bar bya'o/ / mthe'u chung gnyis kyi rtse mo gtug cing sbyar bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du gung mo gnyis kyi sen mo dang rtse mo gnyis sbyar bar bya zhing mdzub mo dang mdzub mo yang sbyar bar bya'o/ / kun tu snang ba'i gtsug tor gyi mtshan nyid chen po zhes bya ba'i phyag rgya yin te/ 'dir sngags ni/

“One starts with the [hand] sign of uṣṇīṣa. Both hands should be extended and evenly aligned, forming the shape of a flame. The ring fingers should be between the hands, their nails placed one against the other and covered by the tips of the thumbs. The small fingers should form a ‘needle’ with their tips joined, and the middle fingers should be centered, aligned, and touching at the nails. The index fingers should form a ‘needle.’[2251] This is the great[2252] mudrā called the great representation of the uṣṇīṣa surrounded by light. The corresponding mantra is
aM mu ha~M/
āḥ maḥ haṁ.

mdzub mo de nyid yang dag par bkug ste/ sen mo dang sen mo'i rtse mo'i dkyil 'khor ltar sbyar bas ni/ lta ba ngan pa'i zug rngu'i phyin ci log sel ba zhes bya ba chos kyi 'khor lo chen po'i phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags su 'gyur ba ni/

“If, subsequently, one brings the index fingers together[2253] so that one fingernail touches the other and the fingertips form the shape of a circle, this is the great Dharma-wheel mudrā called incinerating[2254] the perversions‍—the thorns of the wrong views. The corresponding mantra is:
“Oṁ,[2255] make [them] tremble and fall! Crush [them], O wheel! You are the possessor of the vajra, hūṁ![2256]

“If, subsequently, one . . . the index fingers . . . ,[2257] this is the great mudrā called the seat of the enemies of the four māras‍—the vajra heroine who devours the great afflictions [experienced] on the earth with its animate and inanimate entities.[2258] The corresponding mantra is:
oM badzrA sha ni hU~M phaT/
“Oṁ Vajrānanī![2259] Hūṁ phaṭ![2260]

'di ni skyil krung gi phyag rgya ste/ sngags dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad byed pa/ ji ltar ston ka'i sprin bzhin du bgegs thams cad 'jigs par byed pa/ gang yang bdud bzhis byams pa dang gang yang lha dang lha ma yin gyi bgegs rnams ni skyil krung gi phyag rgya dam pa mthong ba tsam gyis 'jigs par 'gyur ro/ /

“These mudrās and mantras[2261] Can be universally employed in all rites. They will destroy all the vighnas Like autumn clouds. “Any obstacles created by the four māras And those created by gods or asuras [2262] Will all perish as soon as This supreme mudrā is displayed.[2263]

“Further, the third [of these] mudrās may be formed by displaying The same gesture, but with the index fingers loosened up. If the [remaining] fingertips are neatly folded in, Such a fist is known as the tathāgatī.[2264] “This great mudrā is known throughout the three worlds under the name of the garland of light rays of the great lord. The corresponding mantra is: “Oṁ Vijayā! Haḥ![2265]

'og ma gnyis kyang rtse mo mnyam par gshibs na khu tshur gyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ro/ / sngags kyang 'di dag gang yang rung ba dang phyag rgya lag pa gnyis kyis bcings te sgrub pa'i dus sam sngon du bsnyen pa'i dus su 'dug pa'am langs te/ lan cig gam ji srid 'dod kyi bar du bzlas par bya'o/ / de ltar byas na bgegs dang log 'dren thams cad kyis glags rnyed par mi 'gyur zhing grub pa yang mngon du 'gyur ro/ /

“There is also the fist mudrā of the tathāgata, [where] the two hands are evenly aligned below.[2266] During formal or preliminary practice, one should recite the mantra just once while forming any of these mudrās with both hands, and then recite as long as one likes, either sitting or standing.[2267] Consequently, no vighnas or vināyakas will be able to cause harm, and the accomplishment will be imminent.
mdzub mo gnyis kyi rtse mo dang gung mo gnyis kyi rtse mo dag yongs su sbyar ba ni gtsug tor 'phags pa zhes bya ba'i phyag rgya yin te/ 'dir sngags ni/
“If one brings the same index fingers together in such a way that their tips touch above the middle fingers, this is the mudrā of Udgatoṣṇīṣa.[2268] The corresponding mantra is
oM dz+wA la dz+wA la dIp+tod ga toSh+NI Sha dU ra dU ra hU~M haM/
Oṁ, burn, blaze up! O blazing Udgatoṣṇīṣa! Make [them] tremble, do! Hūṁ![2269][2270]

srin lag de nyid bkug pa dang gung mo sbyar ba de gnyis kyi sor mo'i rtse mo'i sen mo gshibs la/ rna cha gdub kor zlum po ltar bya ba ni gtsug tor gdugs dkar po'i phyag rgya yin te/ 'dir yang sngags su 'gyur ba ni/

“If one brings the same index fingers into contact with the ‘needle’ formed by the middle fingers and joins them at the tips of the fingernails so that they form the shape of a straightened anklet, this is the mudrā of the uṣṇīṣa [king] Sitātapatra. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M ma ma ma ma hU~M ni/
“Oṁ, ma ma ma ma, hūṁ niḥ![2271]
mdzub mo de nyid phan tshun mnyam par sbyar la gung mo gnyis sbyar ba ni gzi brjid phung po'i phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/
“If, subsequently, the same index fingers are evenly raised so that they cling to the ‘needle’ formed by the middle fingers, this is the mudrā of Tejorāśi. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M ta thA ga toSh+NI ShA ba lo ki te/ mUr+t+ti te dzo rA shi hU~M dz+wA la dz+wA la/ d+ha ka d+ha ka/ da ra bi da ra/ ts+tshin+da ts+tshin+da/ hU~M hU~M phaT phaT swA hA/
“Oṁ Tejorāśi! You are the uṣṇīṣa of the tathāgatas, invisible on their head! Blaze, blaze! You are one and unique! Rip and tear! Chop and split! Hūṁ hūṁ, sphaṭ sphaṭ, svāhā![2272][2273]
mdzub mo de nyid yang dag par sbyar ba dkyil 'khor lta bur bya ba ni rgyal ba'i gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags su 'gyur ba ni/
“If the tips of the same index fingers are joined, forming the shape of the circle, while the middle fingers form the ‘needle,’ this is the mudrā of Jayoṣṇīṣa. The corresponding mantra is:
oM dza ya dza yo Sh+NI Sha dz+wA la dz+wA la ban+d+ha ban+d+ha da ma da ma/ hU~M hU~M hU~M ho ha na hU~M/
“Oṁ Jayoṣṇīṣa! Blaze, blaze! Bind, bind! Tame, tame! Ṅraṁ ṅraṁ ṅraṁ, haḥ! Strike! Hūṁ![2274]
rgyal ba'i gtsug tor gyi sngags so/ /
This is the mantra of Jayoṣṇīṣa.[2275]
mdzub mo de gnyis kyi rtse mo btud pa byas pa gung mo sbyar ba la/ mdzub mo'i sen mo gung mo'i tshigs gsum pa'i char sbyar ba ni 'khor los sgyur ba'i phyag rgya'o/ /

“If the tips of the same index fingers are brought in contact with the ‘needle’ of the middle fingers above the nail[2276] and cling to them at the third phalanx, this is the mudrā of [the uṣṇīṣa king] Cakravartin. The corresponding mantra is:

o~M na mo a pra ti ha ta ta thA ga toSh+NI ShA ya/ a na ba lo ki te mUr+d+ha na tsakra brti hU~M dz+wA la dz+wA la/ d+ha ka d+ha ka/ d+hu na d+hu na/ bi d+hu na trA sa ya mA ra yo ta sA d+ha ya/ ha na ha na/ AM AM A/ ka ka/ dro khi Ni dro khi Ni/ kuN+Da li ni/ a pa rA dzi tA tra pa ri Ni hU~M phaT/

“Oṁ, homage to Cakravartin, the invincible uṣṇīṣa of the tathāgatas, invisible at the top of their head, hūṁ! Blaze, blaze! Burn, burn! Make [them] tremble, make! Drive [them] away! Frighten [them]! Kill [them]! Uproot [them]! Strike, strike! Aṁ aṁ aḥ aḥ kaḥ kaḥ! O Proṅkhinī,[2277] Proṅkhinī! The unconquerable bearer of arms, adorned with earrings! Hūṁ phaṭ![2278]
'khor los sgyur ba'i sngags so/ /
“[This is the mantra of] Cakravartin.[2279]

mdzub mo de nyid kyi rtse mo mdud pa byas la/ gung mo sbyar ba byas pa la mdzub mo sen mo'i 'og gi gsum pa'i cha la sbyar ba ni sngags kyi bdag po 'khor los sgyur ba'i phyag rgya'o/ / mdzub mo de nyid kyi rtse mo yang dag par bkug pa gung mor sbyar ba'i 'og tu yang dag par bcar ba ni sngags kyi bdag po'i phyag rgya'o/ /

“If the tips of the same index fingers are brought into contact with the ‘needle’ of the middle fingers under the fingernail and cling to them along the third phalanx, this is the mudrā of Cakravartin, the lord of mantras. If the index fingers are brought into contact with the ‘needle,’ touching it under the fingernail, this is the mudrā of the lord of mantras.[2280]

mdzub mo de nyid kyi rtse mo yang dag par bkug la gung mo sbyar ba'i sen mo dang tshigs nang du yang dag par sbyar ba ni 'khor los sgyur ba chen po'i phyag rgya'o/ / mdzub mo de nyid kyi rtse mo gnyis yang dag par bkug la gung mo sbyar zhing 'og tu yang dag par sbyar te/ gdub kor ltar byas pa ni 'khor los sgyur ba chen po'i phyag rgya'o/ / mdzub mo de nyid kyi rtse mo yang dag par bkug la gung mo'i tshigs gsum pa'i nang du yang dag par sbyar ba ni sngags kyi bdag po 'khor los sgyur ba chen po'i phyag rgya ste/

“If the tips of the same index fingers are brought together [2281] and remain in contact in the space between the fingernail phalanges of the needle-shaped middle fingers, this is the mudrā of Mahācakravartin. If the tips of the same index fingers are brought together and mutually touch below the third phalanx of the needle-shaped middle fingers, forming thus the shape of a circle, this is [another] mudrā of Mahācakravartin. If the tips of the same index fingers are brought together and mutually touch in the space between the third phalanges of the needle-shaped middle fingers, this is [another] mudrā of Mahācakravartin, the lord of mantras.[2282]

mdzub mo de nyid kyi rtse mo gnyis sbyar la kun nas zlum por bya zhing gung mo gnyis sbyar te/ gung mo'i tshigs gsum pa'i 'og tu sbyar ba ni gzhan gyis mi thub pa gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba'i snying po'i phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir snying po ni/

“If the tips of the same index fingers are made into the shape of an anklet with each tip touching the third joint [of the opposite finger(?)] and are positioned below the middle joint of the needle-shaped middle fingers,[2283] this is the heart mudrā of the cakravartin Aparājitoṣṇīṣa.[2284] The corresponding mantra is:
oM a pa rA dzi tA d+hi ka/
“Oṁ Aparājita,[2285] dhik![2286]

gtsug tor gyi rtsa ba'i phyag rgya de nyid la gzhan gang yang rung ba dang lhan cig pa'i spyod pas bkod na las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / de las mthe bo'i rtse mo bteg la srin lag gi rtse mo gtugs nas yang dang yang bteg pa ni bod pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“Using the root and other mudrās of the uṣṇīṣa kings as an auxiliary practice one will accomplish all activities. “If one extends the tips of the thumbs up to the [base of] the ring fingers and raises [the hands], this is the mudrā of summoning. The corresponding mantra is:

na mo b+ha ga ba te a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ e h+ye h+yi b+ha ga bAn d+harma rA dza pra tIts+tshe da ar+g+haM/ gan+d+haM/ puSh+pa~M d+hU pa~M ba liM dI pa~M mAM tsA b+hi rak+Sha/ a pra ti ha ta/ ba la pa rA kra mA ya swA hA/

“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Come, come, O blessed Dharma lord! Take this welcome offering of water, fragrances, flowers, incense, refreshments, and lamps, and protect me! Svāhā to you, one of invincible strength and power![2287]

me tog dkar pos spyan drang bar bya'o/ / rang gi gzugs kyi mchod yon dang zhabs bsil ba dbul bar bya'o/ / gdan dang bzhugs su gsol ba yang bya'o/ / de la 'di nyid kyi phyag rgya dang sngags kyis phyogs dang phyogs mtshams dang steng 'og bcing bar bya'o/ / de nyid kyi srin lag dang mthe bo'i rtse mos gtugs shing smad pa byas la/ tshigs bar ma la mthe bos gtugs shing yang dang yang bteg par byas nas/ mchod yon phul na rang gis lha gshegs su gsol bar 'gyur ro/ / phyag rgya g.yon phyogs su bskor na phyogs bcings pa las grol bar 'gyur ro/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“When one has performed the summoning, using flowers that are naturally white, water for the feet, water for rinsing the mouth, and a seat to sit on, one should bind the cardinal directions, the intermediate directions, and the ones above and below, using the same.[2288] “One should touch, as before, the ring fingers with the tips of the thumbs and then bend[2289] the ring fingers at the middle joint. When they have touched [the thumbs?], one should stretch them upward. One should rotate [this mudrā] from the right to the left with the offering of dismissal for one’s deity. The mudrās for binding the directions should [also] be displayed.[2290] The corresponding mantra for dismissing is:
na mo a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ gats+tsha gats+tsha b+ha ga bAn d+harma rA dza pra tIts+tshe daM ar+g+haM/ gan+d+haM puSh+paM/ d+hU paM mAM tsA b+hi rak+Sha/ a pra ti ha ta ba la pa rA kra mA ya/

“Homage to the invincible uṣṇīṣa! Go, go, O blessed Dharma lord! Take from me this dismissal offering of water, fragrances, flowers, and incense, and protect me! Svāhā[2291] to you, invincibly strong and powerful![2292]

phyag rgya dang sngags gshegs su gsol ba ni mchod yon gyis so/ / mdzub mo de nyid gung mo'i tshigs gsum pa'i 'og tu bzhag ste/ gung mo yang dag par sbyar la mthe bo gnyis dang mthe'u chung gnyis phan tshun mnan cing khu tshur du bya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/ /

“These were the mudrā and the mantra of dismissing with the respective offerings. “The same index fingers should touch below at the third joint of the needle-shaped middle fingers. The opposite thumbs, together with the small fingers, should form a tight fist. The middle fingers should form a ‘needle.’[2293] The corresponding mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba te a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ o~M drA ban+d+ha hU~M phaT/
“Oṁ blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Oṁ oṁ, hrauṁ! Bind, hūṁ phaṭ![2294]

“This mudrā and mantra of the invincible uṣṇīṣa Tejorāśi can be employed in all the rites of binding, and so forth. It will accomplish all of them. “If the tips of the same index fingers are folded in and lightly touch at the third joint of the needle-shaped middle fingers,[2295] this is the mudrā of Vikaraṇoṣṇīṣa. The corresponding mantra is:
a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ bi ki ri Ni/ bi ki ri Ni/ d+hu na d+hu na d+hu/
“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! O Vikaraṇa, shake [them], shake! Hūṁ![2296]

rnam par 'jig par byed pa/ bcom ldan 'das rig pa'i rgyal po'i gtsug tor gyi sngags bgegs dang log 'dren thams cad kyis zin pa dag dang dbang bskur ba dang bdag bsrung ba dang phyogs bcing ba dang dkyil 'khor bcing ba la sogs te las thams cad la rab tu sbyar ro/ / mdzub mo de gnyis kyi rtse mo gnyis bkug cing yang dang yang brkyang ba ni me lha spyan drang ba'o/ / de nas sbyin sreg gi las bya ste/ 'di nyid kyis slar gshegs su gsol ba ni bzlog pa'o/ / mdzub mo gnyis kyang 'bar ba'i phreng bar bsam mo/ / gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya 'di ni las thams cad la thogs pa med pa'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“The great vidyārāja Vikaraṇoṣṇīṣa can be employed in all the rites belonging to the uṣṇīṣa system of the blessed vidyārāja, such as destroying all the vighnas and vināyakas, conferring empowerments, self-protection, binding the directions, binding the maṇḍala, and so forth. “If the same index fingers are extended outward with the tips folded in and are moved in a pulling motion,[2297] [this is the mudrā] for summoning [the god of] fire for the purpose of homa. The same mudrā [is used also] for dismissing, if the index fingers are stretched forth. This is the mudrā of Jvālāmālinoṣṇīṣa. It is invincible in every rite. The corresponding mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba te/ a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ e h+ye hi te dzo mA li ni ag+na ye swA hA/
“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Come, come! Svāhā to Agni, one who is garlanded with flames![2298]

mdzub mo de nyid kyi rtse mo gnyis cung zad bkug par bya zhing gung mo sbyar la gung mo'i tshigs gsum pa'i nang du sbyar bar bya'o/ / gtsug tor gyi stobs shin tu drag po'i phyag rgya yin no/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“If the same index fingers are folded[2299] at the tips and are joined together in the space between the needle-shaped middle fingers at the third joint, this is the mudrā of Balotkaṭoṣṇīṣa. The corresponding mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba ti/ a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ i maM gan+d+haM/ d+hU paM/ puSh+paM ba liM dI paM tsa pra tIts+tsha ha ra sarba bud+d+ha a d+hiSh+Thi te/ d+harma rA dza a pra ti ha tA ya swA hA/
“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Accept these fragrances, flowers, incense, refreshments, and lamps! Take [them], take. Svāhā to you, invincible Dharma king![2300]
dri la sogs pa'i sngags so/ /
“This is the mantra for offering fragrances, and so forth.

srin lag gnyis bzlog ste/ tshigs gsum pa la mthe bo gnyis yang dag par sbyar zhing mdzub mo gnyis kyang sbyar ba ni gzi brjid gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya ste/ log 'dren thams cad kyis 'joms par mi nus so/ / phyag rgya 'di ni srung ba dang bzlas pa'i dus dang / sgrub pa'i dus dang dkyil 'khor dang las thams cad la yang bya ba yin no/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“If the ring fingers are in reverse position, the thumbs joined at the third joint, and the index fingers form the shape of a needle, this is the mudrā of Vajratejoṣṇīṣa. Unassailable by any vināyakas, it should be used to restrain them and, also, for making the time and the place salutary.[2301] One can thus use this mudrā and its mantra[2302] to afford protection at the time of recitation, formal practice, or the maṇḍala [ritual]. They can be used in all activities. The mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba te/ a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ sarba bi g+h+naM bi d+hA na sa na ka rA ya kro d+hA ya swA hA/
“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa who destroys all the vighnas! Destroy [them]! Svāhā![2303]

srin lag gnyis kyi rtsa bar mthe bong gnyis gtugs te/ de bzhin du gdub kor ltar bya zhing mdzub mo gnyis kyi nang stong pa'i rnam par bya'o/ / 'di ni thams cad du thogs pa med cing gzhan gyis mi thub pa'i gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya yin no/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“If the ring fingers [each] form a circle [touching] the base of the thumb, and the index fingers form the shape of a needle,[2304] this is the mudrā of Aparājitoṣṇīṣa, invincible in every way. The corresponding mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba te/ a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ sarba tra a pa rA dzi tA ya/ sha ma ya sha ma ya/ shAn+te dAn+te d+harma rA dza ba shi te/ ma hA bid+yE sarbAr+tha sA ng+hA ni swA hA/
“Homage to the blessed, Aparājitoṣṇīṣa that can never be defeated! O great vidyā! You are the samaya, peaceful and restrained, taught by the Dharma king! You fulfill all aims, svāhā![2305]

mar gyi sbyin sreg la sogs pas zhi ba dang rgyas pa la sogs pa'i las bya'o/ / srin lag gnyis kyis gdub kor ltar bya zhing mdzub mo'i rtse mo gnyis bkug pa ni thogs pa med pa'i bde byed kyi gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“One should perform, [using this mudrā and mantra], the rites of pacifying and nourishing, while offering homas of ghee, and so forth. “If the same ring fingers are folded into a circular shape, and the folded tips of the index fingers press against each other, this is the mudrā of Śaṅkaroṣṇīṣa. The corresponding mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba te/ a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ o~M shang ka re swA hA/
“Homage to the blessed invincible uṣṇīṣa! Oṁ, svāhā to Śaṅkara!
las thams cad srung bar byed do/ /
“[This mantra and mudrā] afford protection in every rite.

mthe bo gnyis kyi rtse mos srin lag gnyis kyi gsum pa'i tshigs la mnan la/ de bzhin du mdzub mo gnyis kyi rtse mo yang rdo rje'i rtse mo dang 'dra bar bya'o/ / 'di ni dam tshig thogs pa med pa'i spyi gtsug gi phyag rgya ste/ dam tshig thams cad kyi thun mong ngo / / 'dir sngags ni/

“If the tips of the thumbs are placed upon the third joint of the ring fingers, and the index fingers form the shape of a needle, this is the mudrā of Samayoṣṇīṣa, invincible as a vajra and applicable to every type of samaya.[2306] The corresponding mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba te/ a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ o~M shang ka re sa ma yaM swA hA/
“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Oṁ, the samaya for prosperity! Svāhā![2307]

mthe bo gnyis kyi rtse mos srin lag gnyis kyi bar ma'i tshigs la bcar la mdzub mo gnyis kyi rtse mo dgug par bya zhing gung mo gnyis kyi rtse mo dang tshigs bar ma sbyar ba ni dam tshig thogs pa med pa gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya yin te/ lha dang lha ma yin la sbyar na dam tshig la 'jog par byed do/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“If the tips of the thumbs are placed upon the middle joint of the ring fingers, and the index fingers, with their tips folded in, cling to the middle joint of the needle-shaped middle fingers, this is the mudrā of the invincible Mahāsamayoṣṇīṣa. When employed against the gods and the asuras, this [mudrā] establishes them in the samaya. The corresponding mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba te/ a pra ti ha toSh+NI ShA ya/ o~M shang ka re ma hA sa ma yaM swA hA/
“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Oṁ, the great samaya for prosperity! Svāhā![2308]

'dis dkyil 'khor bcing ba byas nas bzlas na 'khor los sgyur ba yang dam tshig la gnas par 'gyur zhing 'khor los sgyur ba gzhan yang zil gyis gnon par 'gyur ro/ / gnas de nyid du bzlas pa byas na rig pa'i mthu stobs kyis 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi sngags rnams kyis phan tshun gnod pa byed par nus pa ma yin no/ / bzlas pa ni gnas gcig tu rnam pa thams cad du bya'o/ / de la sogs pa gtsug tor gyi rgyal po grangs med pa yod de/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi rigs la rgya cher bya'o/ /

“Having bound the maṇḍala with this mudrā, one may recite, ‘Abide in the samaya, abide!’ addressing even the emperor; one may subdue other emperors, too. While mantras are being recited at that very place, whether worldly or supramundane, none will interfere with another or neutralize its power. [This is true] for all the reciters in a particular place. Starting with those just mentioned, there are innumerable uṣṇīṣa kings‍—one should practice the entire Tathāgata family at length.

'jam dpal cho ga'i rgyal po 'di la ni sngags tshad med pa yod de/ phyag rgya yang rnam pa sna tshogs nyid de ngas 'di mdor bsdus nas bshad pa yin no/ / ngas gal te rgya cher bshad na ni mi dang mi ma yin pa thams cad kyis bskal pa stong gi tshad du yang 'dzin pa'am 'chang bar nus pa ma yin no/ / 'jam dpal de lta bas na mdor bsdus nas bshad par bya yis/ mdor na yid la nye bar gzung bar gyis shig /

“Further, Mañjuśrī, there are, in this king of manuals, mantras that are infinitely profound and mudrās of many different kinds. I will now teach them in brief. If I were to explain them in detail, no human or nonhuman being, not even in a thousand eons, would be able to grasp or remember them. I will therefore, Mañjuśrī, teach them in brief. Keep all of this in your memory.
dang po thub pa'i phyag rgya mchog / 'dir ni rab tu gsungs pa yin/ /
“The heart mudrās of the Sage Are the most excellent taught in this manual.[2309]

lha yi lha ni de nas kyang / / 'khor los sgyur ba'i phyag rgya dang / / byang chub sems dpa' blo ldan ni/ / spyan ras gzigs ni zla ba dang / / de nas phyag na rdo rje'i rgya/ / gnod sbyin dbang po'i bstan pa yin/ / de nas gzhan yang phyag rgya ni/ / dpag med chen po'i gzi brjid ldan/ / pho nya pho nya mo tshogs kun/ / bran pho bran mo de bzhin gzhan/ / de bzhin gnod sbyin gnod sbyin mo/ / klu dang klu mo de bzhin gzhan/ / mngag gzhug mngag gzhug mo dag dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po sha za mo/ / de bzhin gzhan yang srin mo dang / / lha dang lha min bu mo dang / / grub dang rig pa 'dzin rnams dang / / mi rnams ma lus pa dag dang / / skye bo thams cad dag gi ni/ / so so so sor phyag rgya bstan/ /

After them, there are the mudrās Of the cakravartin deities who surpass all gods. “The mudrās of the moon-like Avalokiteśvara, Of the sagacious bodhisattva [Mañjuśrī], And of Vajrapāṇi, the king of yakṣas, Are said to be next. “After them come other mudrās Of great power and energy, Namely all those of the hosts of dūtas and dūtīs, Followed by those of the ceṭas and ceṭīs, “The celestial yakṣas and yakṣiṇīs, The nāgas and nāginīs, The kiṃkaras and kiṃkarīs, And the piśācas and piśācīs;[2310] “Of the powerful[2311] rākṣasīs And other celestial[2312] ladies; And of the wives of the daityas,[2313] Of all the siddhas and vidyādharas, “And of all the human and nonhuman[2314] beings Born in the threefold universe[2315]‍— In short, the mudrās of all beings That are designated to them individually.

sngags kyang rnam pa sna tshogs dang / / las dang ting 'dzin sna tshogs dang / / glang po nor bu'i rigs dag dang / / de dag so so'i phyag rgya dang / / dgra bcom dang ni rang rgyal dang / / legs 'byung phyag rgya de nyid dang / / sa bcu la ni rab gnas pa'i/ / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi/ / phyag rgya snying po sngags dag ni/ / gcig pa nyid du yongs su bsgrags/ / lha dang gnod sbyin rigs dang ni/ / drang srong dri zas mchod pa dang / / phyag rgya dri zas bstan pa dang / / bdun pa'i rigs kyis gsungs pa dang / / de bzhin brgyad pa'i phyag rgya ni/ / gnod sbyin rigs su yongs su bstan/ / phyag rgya thams cad yang dag bstan/ / gzhan yang bder gshegs bka' dag gis/ / rgyud rnams dag ni so so dang / / 'jig rten pa yi yang 'dir gzung / / phyag rgya ldan pa'i sngags dag ni/ / las rnams la ni gsal bar 'gyur/ / phyag rgya 'ching la sogs mkhas na/ / log 'dren dag gis gnod mi 'gyur/ /

“Mantras, too, are of many types, Accomplishing a variety of activities.[2316] Whether in the Royal[2317] or Jewel families, These mantras each have a corresponding mudrā. “The mudrās of the arhats or the pratyekabuddhas Both bring splendid results. As for all the bodhisattvas, Established on the ten levels, “Their heart mudrās and mantras Are taught individually. The mudrās in the family of the divine yakṣa,[2318] A family worshiped by the ṛṣis and the gandharvas; “The mudrās taught as belonging to the seventh family And relating to the gandharvas; And likewise the mudrās in the eighth family, Are [all] said to be for their [respective] families.[2319] “All the mudrās thus enumerated, And the others named after the sugatas, Are individually paired with mantras, Both worldly and those related to the sugatas.[2320] “A mantra employed together with a mudrā Is exceptionally powerful in the performance of rites. The vināyakas will stay away[2321] from those who Skillfully employ mudrās and so forth.

de nas phyag rgya chen po la sogs pa'i mtshan nyid bshad par bya ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi snying po'i phyag rgya'i mtshan nyid du 'gyur ba ni/ / lag pa gnyis kyi sor mo phan tshun bsdams la mthe bo gnyis bstan par bya'o/ / 'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi thugs kyi phyag rgya'o/ / 'di nyid la mthe bo g.yas pa gcig bstan pa ni pad+ma 'dzin pa'i phyag rgyar 'gyur ro/ / lag pa g.yas g.yon snga ma bzhin du khu tshur bcangs te/ gung mo'i sor mo gnyis rab tu phyung zhing brkyang bar byas la gcig tu byas shing rdo rje'i rtse mo 'dra ba 'di ni rdo rje 'dzin gyi phyag rgya'o/ /

“Now the descriptions of these and other such great mudrās will be given. First come the descriptions of the heart mudrās of the blessed buddhas. “One should hold the fingers of both hands together, with the thumbs exposed to view. This is the heart mudrā of the tathāgatas. The same mudrā, but with only the right thumb showing, is the mudrā of Padmadhara. If one first makes the left and right hands into fists, and then relaxes and extends both the middle fingers to form the single form of a vajra, this is the mudrā of Vajradhara.

de las gcig bkug pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' spos kyi glang po'i phyag rgya'o/ / yang de nyid brkyang nas gung mo gnyis gdub kor ltar byas pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' glang po'i spos kyi phyag rgya'o/ / lag pa gnyis po thams cad bsdus te/ khu tshur du byas pa 'di ni rin po che'i rigs kyi phyag rgya'o/ / nor bu la spyod pa thams cad dang dzam b+ha la chu dbang la sogs pa'i sngags dang phyag rgya 'di nyid sbyar bar bya'o/ /

“If one inclines the pointed tip [of the vajra] down, this is the mudrā of the bodhisattva Gandhahastin. If one subsequently raises [the hands] up and forms the shape of a circle, this is the mudrā of Gajagandha.[2322] If one then folds in one phalanx of each [middle finger], this is the mudrā of the Jewel family.[2323] It may be employed, in combination with the mantras of Jalendra and so forth, [to invoke] Jambhala and all the spirits of the Jewel family.

mdzub mo gnyis kyi tshigs gnyis bkug nas sen mo gnyis phan tshun du sprad pa 'di ni gnod sbyin gyi rigs lngas rtsen la sogs pa'i gnod sbyin rdzu 'phrul chen po'i phyag rgya'o/ / lag pa gnyis snga ma bzhin du khu tshur bcing ba byas la mthe bo'i sen mo gnyis phan tshun sprad cing steng du bzhag la gung mo gnyi ga'i rtse mo rdo rje'i rtse mo dang 'dra bar byas pa 'di ni lha thams cad de lha'i rigs 'og min la sogs pa'i phyag rgya yin no/ /

“If the index fingers are each folded at two joints and touch each other at the fingernails, this is the mudrā of the five very powerful yakṣas and so forth, which belongs to the Yakṣa family. If [the index fingers] are joined at the fingernails and held above the fingernails of the thumbs, with the hands positioned as before and the middle fingers raised up to form the shape of a needle, this is the mudrā of all the gods who inhabit the celestial realms of Akaniṣṭha and so forth; it belongs to the Celestial family.[2324]
lag pa gnyis de bzhin du bsdams la khu tshur bcangs nas mthe bo gnyis bstan pa 'di ni rang sangs rgyas rnams dang 'phags pa nyan thos kyi phyag rgya'o/ /
“If one brings the hands together and makes them into fists with the thumbs exposed to view, this is the mudrā of the pratyekabuddhas and noble śrāvakas.
khu tshur bcang bar byas pa 'di dag ni 'phags pa'i gang zag brgyad kyi phyag rgya'o/ / rgyal ba'i sras thams cad kyi phyag rgya ni gcig tu brjod par bya ste/
“The eight mudrās just mentioned Belong to the eight families. Now I will teach a single mudrā That can be used for all the sons of the victors.[2325]

thal mo brkyang ba sbyar nas cung zad rtse mo bskum par byas pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpar grags pa'i phyag rgyar bstan pa yin no/ / nor bu rin po che dang / 'khar gsil dang / snam sbyar dang / lhung bzed dang / chos gos dang / mche ba dang / mi 'jigs pa'i lag pa ste/ bdun po de dag ni thub pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / spyan dang byams pa dang 'od kyi dra ba dang chos ston pa dang mdzod spu'i nor bu dang gnas pa dang phyag rgya bdun po 'di dag kyang rgyal ba'i sku nyid las skyes pa'o/ /

“If [the hands] are extended in the añjali gesture And then slightly contracted,[2326] This is the mudrā, it is taught, Of all the great bodhisattvas. “The seven mudrās of the Sage are those Of the wish-fulfilling gem, the mendicant’s staff, The monk’s shirt, the bowl, the robe, The fangs, and the fearlessness. “The vision, the loving kindness, the aura of light, the webbed [fingers], The [forty] teeth, the ūrṇā, and the abiding in bliss May also be regarded as mudrās Arising from the Victor’s own body.[2327]

bdun gnyis kyi tshogs gnyis pa 'di dag dang phyag rgya lnga ngas bshad pa dang thub pa'i snying po dang ldan pa nyi shu ni dang po'i rang byung gis kyang bstan pa yin te 'khor los sgyur ba nyi shu'i 'khor gyi phyag rgya yang bstan to/ / phyag rgya dang sngags byung ba 'di grangs kyi mthar yang byas pa yin no/ /

“The above two heptads of mudrās, Together with the five mudrās handed down by me And the heart mudrā of the Sage, Constitute twenty mudrās taught by the primordial, self-arisen ones. “These mudrās, formerly taught By the primordial victors, Are also referred to as the ‘retinue’ Of the twenty cakravartins. The enumeration may continue on and on, With each mudrā having a corresponding mantra.

thal mo sbyar ba byas nas gdub kor ltar byas pa ni nor bu rin po che'i phyag rgya'o/ / skyil mo krung gi g.yas g.yon brla'i nya'i phyogs su khu tshur rgyal mtshan du 'dzin pa ni 'khar gsil gyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ro/ / lag pa thal mo sbyar la phan tshun du mngon par phyogs pa ni snam sbyar gyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ro/ / lag pa thal mo sbyar ba las bzed pa ltar byas pa ni lhung bzed kyi phyag rgya'o/ / chos gos ni lag pa g.yon pas so/ /

“If one raises [the hands] and cups them, this is the mudrā of the wish-fulfilling gem. If one makes [one’s hands] into fists and holds them, while sitting in a cross-legged position, at the left and right shoulders, this is the mudrā of the mendicant’s staff. If the hands face each other with a space in between, this is the mudrā of the monk’s shirt.[2328]

thugs kyi phyag rgya bzhin du g.yon pa'i mthe bo bteg pa ni mche ba'i phyag rgya'o/ / lag pa g.yas pas mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa dang g.yon pas chos gos la 'dzin pa ni mi 'jigs pa'i lag pa'o/ / thal mo sbyar ba las gung mo gnyis rdo rje'i rtse mo ltar byas la/ de'i rgyab tu mdzub mo gnyis cung zad bkug cing bzhag la/ mthe bo gnyis nang du bcug pa 'di ni sangs rgyas spyan gyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ro/ / 'di nyid kyi gung mo'i tshigs bkug la mdzub mo gnyis gcig tu byas pa 'di ni sangs rgyas byams pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / thal mo sbyar ba yangs par byas la mdzub mo dang srin lag gnyis bkug la rdo rje rtse gsum du byas pa 'di ni mA ma kI'i phyag rgyar 'gyur ro/ /

“If the hollowed [hands are held] down below, this is the mudrā of the bowl.[2329] The mudrā of the robe is formed with the left hand. The mudrā of the fangs is formed out of the heart mudrā by raising the thumb of the left hand. In the mudrā of fearlessness, the [right] hand displays the gesture of granting fearlessness, while the left is supporting the robe.[2330] “If there is a hollow space between the middle fingers, the index fingers are folded outside and the thumbs placed inside, this is the mudrā of the Buddha’s eye.[2331] The same mudrā, but with the middle fingers folded at the joints and the index fingers at the side of them,[2332] is [the mudrā] of the Buddha’s loving kindness.[2333] If one forms the añjali gesture with the fingers splayed, and then forms a triple ‘needle’ by hiding away the index and ring fingers, this is the mudrā of Māmakī.[2334]

thal mo sbyar ba byas nas mdzub mo gnyis gung mo gnyis kyi tshigs gsum pa la bkug nas bzhag la mthe bo gnyis so sor bskyed nas thal mo'i rnam par bya ba 'di ni longs spyod ldan pa zhes bya ba'i phyag rgya yin no/ / lag pa gnyis thal mo sbyar nas mdzub mo gnyis dang gung mo gnyis sbyar ba ni rnam par rgyal ba'i phyag rgya'o/ / g.yas pa'i sor mo gsum rdo rje'i rtse mo ltar byas la rked pa'i phyogs su brten pa 'di ni gnas pa'i phyag rgya'o/ /

“If one forms the añjali gesture, bends the index and middle fingers outward at the third joint, and joins the thumbs but keeps them apart from other fingers, this is the mudrā of Bhogavatī.[2335] The mudrā of Vijayā is formed with the index and middle finger of the left hand.[2336] With the three fingers of the right hand, one should display a vajra at the waist.[2337]

de ltar bdag nyid kyi mgo bor rig pa'i rgyal po'i phyag rgya dang phyag rgya chen po brgyad bcings la las thams cad bya zhing dam tshig gzung ba'am dkyil 'khor bya ba dag la'ang me tog gtor bar bya'o/ / yang na sngar bstan pa'i cho ga ji lta ba bzhin du byas na ci 'dod pa'i las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / sngags dang phyag rgya dang rig pa brjod pas ni dam tshig thams cad du 'gyur ro/ / legs par phyag rgya bcing na ni phyag rgya'i mthu 'byung bar 'gyur gyi/ gang phyag rgya bab col du byas pa dang gnas ma yin par bcas pa des ni 'di'i dam tshig nyams par 'gyur ro/ /

“Similarly, one can accomplish all activities by forming, above one’s head, the mudrā of the vidyārāja,[2338] which has the nature of the eight great mudrās.[2339] If one casts flowers onto the maṇḍala at the right time following the procedure as previously described, one will accomplish any activity according to one’s wish.[2340] Samayas are expressed by vidyās or mantras; when properly sealed with a mudrā, they become as powerful as the mudrā.[2341] Should one display a mudrā carelessly or at the wrong time and place, one would break one’s samaya.[2342]

gang rdo rje'i phyag rgya de nyid ni mdud rtse'i phyag rgya yin mod kyi/ rtse gsum dang rdo rje ni khyad par yod de/ gang gyen du bstan pa de ni rdo rje 'dzin gyi phyag rgyar 'gyur la/ 'og tu bltas pa ni dbang phyug chen po'i phyag rgya yin no/ / bar du bzhag pa ni sbyin gnas su 'os pa'i slob dpon dang bla ma la ni phyag rgya dbus su gzung bar bya'o/ / mi thams cad la ni sor mo gcig gdeg par bya'o/ / mi ma yin pa thams cad dang rkang gnyis dang rkang bzhi dang rkang mang dang srid pa gsum la gnas pa'i sems can rnams kyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni sor mo gnyis bsgreng ba'o/ / gnod sbyin dang gnod sbyin mo thams cad kyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni gsum bsgreng ba'o/ / rig pa 'dzin pa dang rig pa 'dzin ma thams cad kyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni sor mo bzhi bsgreng ba'o/ / lha dang lha ma yin thams cad kyi bu mo'i phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni lag pa'i mthil mnyam por bzhag pa'o/ /

“As with the vajra, so with the trident[2343]‍—there is no difference between them[2344]‍—if it is raised, the [mudrā] is associated with Vajradhara; if lowered, with Maheśvara. If it is formed in the center, it is associated with the venerable masters and teachers as well as all humankind.[2345] If a single finger is raised up, this is the mudrā of all human beings and other two-legged, four-legged, multilegged, and legless creatures in the threefold universe. If two fingers are raised, this is the mudrā of all the yakṣas and yakṣiṇīs. If three are raised, this is the mudrā of all the vidyādharas and vidyādharīs. If four fingers are raised, evenly leveled with the palm, this is the mudrā of the male and female lower gods[2346] and asuras.[2347]

thal mo sbyar ba legs par byas te bzhag pa ni gzugs na spyod pa'i lha thams cad kyi phyag rgya'o/ / thal mo de nyid legs par byas pa las khu tshur bcing ba byas pa ni 'dod pa'i khams kyi dbang phyug la sogs pa 'dod pa'i khams na gnas pa thams cad kyi yin no/ / dmyal ba dang dud 'gro dang yi dgas dang gshin rje'i 'jig rten gyi sems can thams cad kyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni de nyid las sor mo gcig yang dag par bsgreng ba'o/ /

“If the hands display a gracefully formed añjali gesture, this is the mudrā of all the gods inhabiting the realm of form. The same gesture is also the mudrā of the gods inhabiting the formless realm.[2348] “If the hands, positioned as before, are made into hollow fists, this is the mudrā of all worldly beings, starting from the lords of the realm of desire and all the beings dwelling there, including men, animals, pretas, and yāmas.[2349]

sha za dang sha za mo la sogs pa thams cad kyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni sor mo gnyis bsgreng ba'o/ / srin po dang srin mo rnams kyi ni gsum bsgreng ba'o/ / sha rjen za ba thams cad dang gdon dang ma mo dang grul bum la sogs pa dang / sha za rnams dang mkha' 'gro ma thams cad dang sdig pa'i sems dang ldan pa thams cad la ni sor mo bzhi bsgreng ba'o/ / sdig pa thams cad kyi phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni sor mo thams cad bsdus pa'o/ / lag sor bsdus pa'i phyag rgya ni dgug pa'o/ / lag sor brkyang ba ni slar gtang ba'i phyag rgya'o/ /

“If one extends a single finger[2350] while forming the above mudrā, this is the mudrā of the piśācas and piśācīs. If one extends two[2351] fingers, this is the mudrā of the rākṣasas and rākṣasīs. If one extends three[2352] fingers, this is the mudrā of all the kravyādas and other carrion-eating spirits, the grahas, the mātṛs, the kuṣmāṇḍas and so forth, the piśitāśas, all the ḍākinīs,[2353] the vyantaras, the kaśmalas, and others. If one forms four fingers into hooks, this is the mudrā of all the kaśmalas. “One performs summoning with the mudrās of summoning, and dismissing with the mudrās of dismissing.[2354]

las thams cad ni rang gi sems kyis bya'o/ / ci 'dod pa'i phyag rgya 'di dag la rang rang gi sngags sbyar bar bya'o/ / gzhan gyi phyag rgyar gzhan gyi las ni mi bya'o/ / gang gi sngags gang la yod pa de dang de'i phyag rgyar sbyar bar bya'o/ /

If one employs one’s own mind, one will accomplish all activities. Using only these mudrās according to need, one can combine them only with the mantras assigned to them. One must not use other [mudrās], or perform activities other than [those assigned to these mudrās]. One can only employ a mantra with whatever mudrās they are designated to.
phyag rgya 'di dag ni rin thang mnyam pa med pa yin te/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis byin gyis brlabs pa sems can thams cad kyis phyag rgya mthong bas khro bar byed mi nus so/ /
“These mudrās, blessed by all the buddhas, Must not be used in a transgressive way. Through merely beholding the mudrā, No being will be capable of feeling anger.[2355]

phyag rgya las 'da' bar byed pa ni rnam par nyams pa thob par 'gyur ro/ / phyag rgya nyams pa las ni dam tshig nyams pa dang rig pa thams cad las rnam par 'das par 'gyur ro/ / mthar yang ngu 'bod kyi 'gro ba thob par 'gyur ro/ / dmyal ba chen po mnar med par yang shin tu brtan par skye ba thob par 'gyur ba ni phyag rgya la bgegs byed pas so/ / gang yang phyag rgya dang dam tshig la gnas pa de dag ni yun ring po mi nyung bar bde bar 'gyur te/ lha'i gnas chen po'i 'gro bar skye bar 'gyur ro/ / mthar yang nges par byang chub la gzhol bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Those who use the mudrās transgressively will perish. By violating a mudrā one breaks one’s samaya and transgresses against all the vidyās. The violator will certainly fall into the Raurava or Avīci hell. Creators of obstacles will fall deep down into one of the great hells. Those, on the other hand, who keep their samayas regarding the mudrās will experience long-lasting great happiness, will be reborn in the gods’ realms, and will certainly progress toward the final goal of awakening.

mdor na dang po'i sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul chen po dag gis phyag rgya rnam pa mang po rnams rab tu gsungs so/ / sems can thams cad kyis kyang 'di'i mtha' rtogs par ram gzung bar ram grangs rtsi bar byed par mi nus so/ / mdor na rgyal ba'i rigs kyi rig pa'i rgyal po 'khor los sgyur ba'i yi ge gcig pa de'i phyag rgyar 'gyur ba ni lag pa g.yas g.yon snga ma bzhin du khu tshur du byas la/ gung mo gnyis phyir phyung la brkyang ste gcig tu rtse sprad la/ gnyi ga'i yang rtse mo'i tshigs bkug la mdzub mo gnyis kyi tshigs gnyis bkug cing sen mo gnyis phan tshun rtse sprad de/ mthe bo gnyis kyi sen mo'i steng du bzhag pa 'di ni 'khor los sgyur ba'i phyag rgya ste/ las thams cad byed pa phyag rgya thams cad kyi rab mchog 'jig rten gyi skyob pa rnams kyis gsungs pa/ 'khor los sgyur ba'i yi ge gcig pa dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / 'dis bsgrubs na de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi rigs dang 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi sngags grub par 'gyur ro/ / 'dis bzlas pa byas na sngags thams cad bzlas par 'gyur ro/ /

“In short, many different types of mudrās have been taught by the primordial buddhas and the bodhisattvas of great power. It is impossible for any being to fathom, enumerate, or learn them. “Briefly, there is in the family of the Victorious One a single-syllable mantra, the vidyārāja, the cakravartin.[2356] Its corresponding mudrā, used for protection,[2357] is formed as follows: First one should make the left and right hands into fists, except for the middle fingers, which should be extended forth together, each bent at the first joint.[2358] As for the index fingers, each should be bent at both joints and touch the other at the fingernail. [Their tips] should be above the fingernails of the thumbs. This mudrā of the cakravartin [One Syllable] is suitable for all activities. It was declared by the protectors of the world to be the best of all mudrās. “When this mudrā is employed with the previously described cakravartin One Syllable, it can accomplish all activities. When [One Syllable] is accomplished, the entire Tathāgata family is accomplished, and all the worldly and supramundane mantras are accomplished. When One Syllable is recited, all the mantras are recited.

sgrub pa pos nges par sngon du cho ga'i rgyal po 'dir gsungs pa'i sngags kyi mchog brgyad stong bzlas pa bya'o/ / de ltar byas na rig pa 'di thams cad mngon du 'gyur zhing myur du grub pa rab tu ster bar 'gyur ro/ / myur du mchog kyang ster bar 'gyur ro/ / nges par byang chub la gzhol bar 'gyur ro/ /

“As for the other eminent mantra [deities] invoked in this king of manuals, the practitioner should always recite [their] mantras one thousand and eight times to start with.[2359] In this way, all these vidyā deities will be experienced directly and will soon grant accomplishments and boons. One will steadily progress toward awakening.

pad+ma 'dzin pa'i phyag rgya dang spyan ras gzigs kyi snying po yi ge gcig pa dang ldan par byas na las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / yang na gos dkar mo'i rig pa phyag rgya dang ldan par byas na'ang de bzhin du las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / rdo rje 'chang gi phyag rgya dang de nyid kyi snying po yi ge gcig pa dang ldan par byas na yang de bzhin du las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / yang na mA ma kI'i rig pa chen mo dang ldan par byas na'ang las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ /

“One will accomplish all activities by combining the one-syllable heart mantra of Avalokiteśvara with the mudrā of Padmadhara, or by combining the vidyā of Pāṇḍaravāsinī with her mudrā‍—so also, by combining the mudrā of Vajradhara with his one-syllable heart mantra, or by combining the mudrā of Māmakī with her great vidyā.

de bzhin du glang po'i rigs kyi yi ge gcig pa byang chub sems dpa' glang po'i spos kyi snying po dang de bzhin du de nyid kyi phyag rgya dang rin po che'i rigs dang gnod sbyin gyi rigs dang lha dang 'phags pa dang 'di dag la yang 'dir snying po yi ge gcig pa nyid la phyag rgya dang sngags thams cad dang ldan par byas na las thams cad bya ba yin no/ / ji ltar rigs par rig pa dang sngags kyi stobs bskyed pa mtha' dag bya'o/ /

“Similarly, in the Royal[2360] family, [one will accomplish all activities by combining] the one-syllable heart mantra of the bodhisattva Gajagandha[2361] with his mudrā. Also, regarding the Jewel, the Yakṣa, the Celestial, and the Noble families,[2362] one will accomplish all activities by combining the one-syllable heart mantras of these families with their respective mudrās. In this way, one will always be able to accomplish all activities using any of these mudrās and mantras. The power of the vidyā mantras will be directed according to how they are employed. Activities will not be accomplished any other way.[2363]

“Similarly, the right hand raised in a svasti gesture[2364] [should be combined with the mantra] of Brahmā Sahāmpati; the single liṅga mudrā, [with the mantra] of Maheśvara; the discus mudrā, [with the mantra] of Viṣṇu; the añjali gesture with the fingers splayed, [with the mantra] of Garutman;[2365]

de bzhin du drang srong rnams la ni dmod pa 'debs pa'i lag pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / de bzhin du dri za dang lha dang lha ma yin dang bcas pa rnams la ni lag pa g.yon pa'i mthe bo nang du bcug pa byas pa'o/ / grub pa bstan pa'i khu tshur du gnas pa'i rgya ni gzhon nu ma bzhi'i phyag rgya dang de nyid kyi sngags kyis so/ /

a hand raised in a cursing gesture, [with the mantra] of the ṛṣis. The same applies to the mudrā of the gandharvas, the lower gods, and the asuras, which is formed by placing the tip of the left thumb inside a fist. The mudrā of the four virgins, again, can be combined only with the corresponding mantra.[2366]

de bzhin du smin drug gi bu la ni mdung gi phyag rgyas so/ / de bzhin du gshin rje dang chu lha dang lus ngan dang gnod sbyin dang srin po dang sha za dang lto 'phye chen po la sogs pa sems can srid pa gsum la yang dag par gnas pa thams cad dang 'gro ba thams cad du gtogs pa dang khams thams cad na gnas pa dang sems can thams cad kyi gdon dang ma mo dang sha rjen za ba dang sdig pa can gyi sems can thams cad dang thams cad kyi phyag rgya dang sngags kyang thams cad du gsungs pa yin no/ / rim gyis sbyar zhing mthar gyis thams cad kyi thams cad du 'gyur gyi gzhan du ni ma yin no/ /

“Similarly, the spear mudrā [should be combined with the mantra] of Kārttikeya. The same applies to the mudrās of Yama, Varuṇa, Kubera, and the yakṣas, rākṣasas, piśācas, and mahoragas‍—all the beings inhabiting the threefold universe, following the course of whatever destiny, and reborn in whatever realm‍—the grahas, mātṛs, kravyādas, kaśmalas, and so forth. All these beings have mudrās and mantras designated to them, which must be employed observing the right correspondence. Everything must follow the right order, not otherwise.

dang por re zhig sgrub pa pos cho ga'i rgyal po 'di la de bzhin gshegs pa las byung ba'i phyag rgya chen po dang phyag rgya de'i yan lag tu gyur pa las byung ba dang 'phags pa kun tu bzang po dang mthu chen thob dang dri ma med par grags pa dang 'jam dpal khyod kyi ut+pa la'i phyag rgya dang byang chub sems dpa' 'di dag gi phyag rgya shar du mngon par bltas te gnas pa dang nyi ma la mngon du bltas te gnas nas/ tho rangs langs la gtsang zhing gtsang ba'i gnas la gnas nas sgrub pa pos nges par 'di dag gi phyag rgya gang yang rung ba bcings la rang gi spyi bo'i steng du gzhag par bya'o/ / 'di dag gang yang rung ba'i sngags brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas pa byas na nad thams cad las rnam par grol bar 'gyur ro/ / tshe ring ba dang bgegs thams cad kyis zil gyis gnon par mi 'gyur ro/ / sems can thams cad kyis mi tshugs par 'gyur ro/ / myur du grub pa ster bar 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas thams cad kyis byin gyis brlab par 'gyur ro/ / nges par byang chub la gzhol bar 'gyur ro/ / byang chub kyi snying po'i bar du 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa 'di'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen du 'gyur ro/ / snying po dang phyag rgyar 'gyur ba de yang gang zhe na/

“First of all, the practitioner should rely on the auspicious mudrās and their corresponding mantras,[2367] as taught in this king of manuals, that represent the way of the tathāgatas.[2368] Also, Mañjuśrī, there are the mudrās of the noble bodhisattvas Samantabhadra, Mahāsthānaprāpta,[2369] and Vimalagati,[2370] as well as your utpala[2371] mudrā. These mudrās, of both the tathāgatas and the bodhisattvas, should always be displayed by the practitioner facing the east. Having gotten up early, he should stand facing the sun in a clean place and, himself clean, should display any one of these mudrās, raising it upward, above his head. “Any of the corresponding mantras should be recited one hundred and eight times. He will be free from all disease, will live long, and will not be overcome by the vighnas. He will become unassailable by any living being. He will meet, face to face, all the mantra [deities][2372] who will promptly grant him accomplishment. He will receive blessings from all the buddhas and will steadily progress toward awakening. The divine youth Mañjuśrī will himself become his spiritual friend until the attainment of full realization. What, then, are these mudrās and mantras?[2373]

dang por re zhig dpa' bo chen po'i phyag rgya bca' bar bya ste/ lag pa gnyis sbyar bar byas la sor mo rnams nang du bsdus te/ mthe bo gnyis bteg la tshigs gsum pa'i cha bkug pa 'di ni dpa' bo chen po'i phyag rgya de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis gsungs so/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“First, I will teach the mudrā of the great hero. One should join the cupped hands folding the fingers in and raising up the thumbs bent where they meet the wrist. This is the mudrā of the great hero, taught by all the tathāgatas. The corresponding mantra is:
a bI ra hU~M baM/
“Āḥ hero! Hūṁ khaṁ![2374]

sngags 'di dang yang dag par ldan na phyag rgya 'di ni las thams cad byed pa yin no/ / lag pa gnyis de bzhin du yang dag par sbyar ba byas la phyir yang rnam par phye zhing / kun nas sor mo rnams pad+ma kha bye ba ltar byas pa 'di ni kha bye ba zhes bya ba'i phyag rgya mchog yin te/ dang po'i sangs rgyas kyis rab tu bstan to/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“If combined with this mantra, the mudrā of the great hero will accomplish all activities. “Having joined the cupped hands as before, one should open them with the fingers expanded all around into the shape of a blooming lotus.[2375] This excellent mudrā, introduced by the primordial buddhas, is called blooming. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M ga ga na sam+b+ha be dIp+ta dIp+ta dz+wA la ya dz+wA la ya/ bud+d+ha a d+hiSh+Thi te bi kA sA ya sarba b+hu tA nA~M/ hU~M hU~M bi kA si ni phaT phaT swA hA/
“Oṁ, you who originate from the sky! Be bright, be! Spread light, spread! You are blessed by the buddhas! Illuminate all the buddhas! Hūṁ hūṁ, Vikāsinī! Phaṭ phaṭ, svāhā![2376]

'di ni pad+ma kha bye ba'i sngags te/ phyag rgya 'di dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad par 'gyur ro/ / gdon zhugs pa la sogs pa yang rab tu shes pa yin no/ / smra bar byed par 'gyur ro/ / gdon gyis zin pa rnams dang sha za sdig pa dang ldan pas zin pa dang dug gis brgyal ba rnams la ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar de thams cad byed do/ / 'di ni mdor na rig pa me tog kha bye ba'i phyag rgya dang ldan par byas na don thams cad sgrub par byed do/ / ma grub pa nyid kyang myur du 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“This mantra,[2377] when employed in combination with its namesake mudrā, is suitable for all activities. It points out those who are possessed by grahas. It causes those possessed, whether it is by grahas, kravyādas, or kaśmalas, or those knocked out by poison, to speak. Following the manner of its employment, it will fulfill all the required activities accordingly.[2378] In short, this vidyā, when employed along with the blooming mudrā, will fulfill all aims; it will swiftly bring the desired result even if it is not fully mastered.

lag pa gnyis sbyar ba byas la sor mo rnams nang du mnyam par byas te bcug pa ni snying po'i phyag rgya ste/ snying pos lan bdun mngon par bsngags la bkrol bar bya ste/ de bzhin du thams cad du yang bya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“If one joins the cupped hands together with the fingers evenly folded, this is the heart mudrā [of the tathāgatas]. This heart [mudrā] should be incanted seven times with the [corresponding] heart mantra, and then ‘released.’[2379] The corresponding mantra is:
o~M go da ro bI ra swA hA/
“Oṁ, brave Godari, svāhā![2380]

de bzhin gshegs pa'i snying po'o/ / lag pa de nyid khu tshur du bya ste sor mo rnams brkyang la sor mo'i rtse mo phan tshun sprad cing nang du stong pa ni gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“This is the heart mantra of the tathāgatas. “If one joins the cupped hands as before, with the fingers set apart so that there is free space between the fingertips, this is the uṣṇīṣa mudrā.[2381] The corresponding mantra is:
o~M o~M ban+d+ha swA hA/
“Oṁ droṁ! Bind! Svāhā![2382]
'di ni las thams cad byed pa ste/ lag pa g.yas pa'i mthe bo bteg la khu tshur bcangs pa ni 'khar gsil gyi phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/
“This mantra is suitable for all activities. “If one makes the right hand into a fist with the thumb free, this is the mudrā of the mendicant’s staff. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M d+hu na dzi ta ra NI nA~M hU~M/
“Oṁ, shake [them]! You are invincible in battle, hūṁ![2383]
'khar gsil gyi sngags ni las thams cad pa'o/ / 'di nyid kyi phyag rgya dang ldan pas lag pa g.yon pa chos gos la 'dzin par byas pa ni chos gos kyi phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/
“This mantra of the mendicant’s staff is suitable for all activities. “If the same mudrā is formed with the left hand touching the robe, this is the mudrā of the robe. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M rak+Sha rak+Sha sarba bud+d+ha a d+hiSh+Thi ta da ma tsI ba ra swA hA/
“Oṁ, protect [me], protect! O my robe, blessed by all the buddhas, svāhā![2384]

de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos gos kyi sngags so/ / 'di nyid kyi phyag rgya dang ldan par byas na las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / gos la mngon par bsngags nas gos bgos na bsrung ba chen po byas par 'gyur ro/ / gdon thams cad dang ma mo dang sha za dang sha rlon za ba dang sdig pa can rnams dang bgegs thams cad kyang mthong ba tsam gyis rab tu 'byer ro/ / mthe bo g.yas g.yon dang mthe'u chung gnyis phan tshun sprad pa byas la lag pa'i kha sbyar thur du bstan pa ni lhung bzed kyi phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“With this mudrā of the robe of the Tathāgata one can accomplish all activities. If one wears a robe incanted with the corresponding mantra, one will enjoy good fortune[2385] and powerful protection. All the grahas, mātṛs, piśitāśas, kravyādas, kaśmalas, and vighnas will flee upon merely seeing [such a robe]. “If the thumb of the left hand and the small finger of the right mutually touch,[2386] and the hands are lowered down with a hollow space between them, this is the mudrā of the bowl. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M lo ka bA la a d+hiSh+Thi taM ba ra d+hA rA ya/ ma hA nu b+ha ba nu d+ha bA trA swA hA/
“Oṁ, O buddha bowl of great power, you are blessed by the protectors of the world! Hold, hold, and cause [the contents] to be held! Svāhā![2387]

phyag rgya 'di dang sngags 'di yang dag par ldan par byas na las thams cad byed do/ / kha zas za ba'i dus su dran par byas na sbyar ba'i dug thams cad nus pa med par 'gyur ro/ / lag pa gnyis khu tshur bcang la mdzub mo gnyis dang gung mo bkug pa 'di ni yid bzhin gyi nor bu'i phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“This mantra, when combined with the mudrā, is suitable for all activities. If one recollects [this mantra] at the time of eating, one will not be affected by any poison that one might swallow. “If one makes the hands into fists, with the index fingers bent at the middle joint,[2388] this is the mudrā of the wish-fulfilling gem. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M te dzo dz+wA la sarba ar+tha sA d+ha ka sid d+h+ya tsin tA ma Ni rat+na hU~M/
“Oṁ splendor, blaze! You who fulfill all aims. Bring success, bring! O wish-fulfilling gem, huṁ![2389]

nor bu rin po che'i sngags so/ / phyag rgya 'di nyid dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad byed cing dge ba yin no/ / rgyan gyi khyad par thams cad la 'di nyid kyis mngon par bsngags te rgyan du byas na bdag nyid la bsrung ba chen po byas par 'gyur ro/ / mchog tu skal ba bzang po dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / go cha la mngon par bsngags te rang nyid kyis bgo bar byas nas g.yul du 'jug na/ 'di ni lus la mtshon gyis mi phog cing mi tshugs par 'gyur ro/ / dgra thams cad kyi rang gi dpung 'byed par byed cing pha rol gyi sde yang rab tu gnon par byed de/ de la sogs pa tshad med pa'i las ma grub pa nyid kyang grub par byed do/ / rin po che pad+ma rA ga dang margad ta la sogs pa gang yang rung ba'i rin po che'i khyad par blangs la/ brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags pa byas nas rgyal mtshan gyi rtse mo'am rang gi mgo bo'am glang po che'i mchog mar bcing ba byas nas g.yul gyi thog mar zhugs na nges par pha rol gyi dpung dang 'thab pa med pa kho nar mthong bas 'jigs par 'gyur ba'am rmugs pa chen po nyid du 'gyur ba'am bdag po dpung dang bcas pa de dag rab tu 'byer bar 'gyur ro/ / sor mo rnams phan tshun bsdus nas khu tshur du byas la sor mo gung mo'i gnas kyi gsum pa'i tshigs kyi cha la mdzub mo'i rtse mo bkug pa 'di ni chos kyi 'khor lo'i phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“This mantra of the wish-fulfilling gem, when combined with its namesake mudrā, will accomplish all activities splendidly.[2390] “By incanting with this mantra all one’s ornaments and decorations and putting them on, one ensures a powerful protection for one’s body, and one attains supreme good fortune. If one enters a battle, having donned the ornaments and incanted the armor, no weapon will be able to strike one’s body and one will be unassailable by one’s enemies. One will protect one’s own army and defeat the enemy army. One will accomplish these and innumerable other feats, even if one has not mastered them previously. “If one takes a ruby, an emerald, or other type of precious stone, incants it one hundred and eight times and places it at the tip of a banner, on one’s head, or on an elephant’s back, one will not be taken prisoner[2391] when one enters the front lines of a battle. Seeing [the incanted gem], the enemy army will certainly be crushed without any fight or will fall into a heavy stupor. The defeated troops will flee, and so will their leader. “If one forms the hands into mutually touching[2392] fists with the index fingers[2393] bent at the middle joint, on the level with the third joint on the middle fingers,[2394] this is the mudrā of the Dharma wheel. The corresponding mantra, the mantra of the Dharma wheel, is:
o~M ts+tshin+d+ha ts+tshin+d+ha ha na da ha/ tsakra dIp+ta hU~M/
“Oṁ blazing circle! Chop up, break, strike, burn, burn! Huṁ![2395]

chos kyi 'khor lo'i sngags so/ / rkang pa g.yon pa bteg la rkang pa g.yas pas la bzhag ste/ g.yon pa'i rkang pa'i bol gyis g.yas pa brkyang ba'i brla la bzhag la/ lag pa g.yas pas brdeg pa'i tshul du nga rgyal gyis brtan par byas pa 'di ni gzhan gyis mi thub pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“If one is firmly set[2396] with the left foot outstretched, the right knee touching the ground, the left [hand] extended backward, and the right poised to deliver a blow,[2397] this is the mudrā of Aparājitā. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M hu lu hu lu tsaN+Da li ma tang gi swA hA/
“Oṁ, hulu hulu! O caṇḍālī, O mātaṅgī![2398] Svāhā![2399]

gzhan gyis mi thub pa'i sngags so/ / chos kyi 'khor lo dang gzhan gyis mi thub pa'i sngags 'di dag nyid dang yang dag par ldan pas las thams cad par 'gyur ro/ / mdor na sdug bsngal thams cad nges par gcod par byed do/ / ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / lag pa g.yon pa brla'i steng du dkur brten la/ lag pa g.yas pas chos ston pa'i phyag rgya ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i mdung gi phyag rgya yin no/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“The mantra of Aparājitā and the mantra the Dharma wheel are suitable for all activities if used in combination with their corresponding mudrās. In short, they will remove all suffering. Whatever activities they are employed for, they will accomplish all of them. “One should place the left[2400] hand in the lap[2401] and display with the right [the gesture] of teaching the Dharma. This is the spear mudrā of the tathāgatas. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M bi dza ye ma hA sha ka ti d+hu ra d+ha ri hU~M phaT/ bi dza yi ni phaT/ mang ga lA ya phaT/
“Oṁ Vijayā of great power, difficult to resist! Hūṁ phaṭ! O Victorious One, phaṭ! O auspicious one, phaṭ![2402]

de bzhin gshegs pa'i mdung gi sngags so/ / 'di nyid kyi phyag rgya dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad par 'gyur ro/ / bgegs thams cad dang ma rungs pa thams cad dang dgra thams cad dang lha dang bcas pa yang rengs par byed do/ / 'di'i yon tan ni mtha' yas te ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / lag pa'i sor mo rnams phan tshun de bzhin du byas la/ lag pa gnyis bkan te mdzub mo gnyis kyi rtse mo sbyar la de nyid bzlogs la thur du bstan te dpral bar bzhag pa 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang po'i sangs rgyas kyi mdzod spu'i phyag rgyar gsungs so/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“[This mantra of] the spear of the tathāgatas, when employed with its [namesake] mudrā, can accomplish all activities. It can paralyze all the vighnas, evil beings, and enemies, as well as all the gods. Its qualities are infinite. Whatever activities it is employed for, it will accomplish all of them. “One should interlace the fingers of the hands with the palms facing upward and the index fingers touching at the tips to form the shape of a needle.[2403] This mudrā, turned around so that the palms face downward, should be displayed at the forehead. This is the ūrṇā mudrā of the blessed buddhas, taught by the primordial buddhas. The corresponding mantra is,
na maHsarba ta thA ga te b+h+yaH/ ad+ha te b+h+yaH/ saMmyak+saM bud+d+he b+h+yaH/
‘Homage to all the worthy tathāgatas, the fully realized buddhas.’ [The portion to be recited is]:
he he ban+d+ha ban+d+ha tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha d+hA ra ya d+hA ra ya/ ni run+d+ha ni run+d+ha/ Ur+Na ma Ni swA hA/
“He he! Bind, bind! Remain, remain! Support, support! Suppress, suppress! O jewel of the ūrṇā, svāhā![2404]

de bzhin gshegs pa'i mdzod spu'i sngags 'di nyid kyi phyag rgya dang / yang dag par ldan na las thams cad par 'gyur ro/ / gi wang gi lde gus dpral ba la thig ler byas la sngags bzlas na dgra'i nang du zhugs kyang mi tshugs par 'gyur ro/ / ma rungs pa thams cad kyis kyang mi 'tshe bar 'gyur ro/ / g.yul gyi nang du zhugs na yang mthong ba tsam gyis gzhan gyi sde 'jig par byed do/ / ma mthong yang las tshad med pa byed par 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das tshad med pas kyang gsungs so/ / rgyun mi chad par phan tshun thal mo sbyar ba byas la mdzub mo gnyis phan tshun rtse sprad la/ tshigs bar ma bkug cing mthe bo gnyis kyang bkug pa 'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyan gyi phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“This mantra of the ūrṇā of the tathāgatas, when employed along with its [namesake] mudrā, can accomplish all activities. “If one steps into the midst of one’s enemies wearing a bindi on one’s forehead made with bovine bezoar [incanted with the ūrṇā mantra] and reciting [the same], one will be unassailable by any wicked beings and will not be harmed by them. Or, if one enters the middle of a battlefield, one will cause, merely by one’s gaze, the destruction of the enemy army. If one does not fail to display [the bindi], one can accomplish feats without limit. This [ūrṇā] has been taught by innumerable blessed buddhas. “One should form the añjali gesture with the hands joined together without any gaps. The two index fingers should be bent at the middle joint.[2405] The thumbs should also be bent.[2406] This is the mudrā of the eye of the tathāgatas. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M ru ru s+phu ru dz+wA la tiSh+Tha sid+d+ha lo tsa ni sarbAr+tha sA d+ha ni swA hA/
“Oṁ, ru ru! Flash, blaze, and stay on! O Siddhalocanā who accomplishes all purposes, svāhā![2407]

'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyan gyi sngags so/ / 'di nyid kyi phyag rgya dang yang dag par ldan pas las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / mig gnyis la mngon par bsngags te dgra'i nang du zhugs na/ dgra rnams mthong ba tsam gyis byams pa'i sems dang phan pa'i bsam pa dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / bshes gnyen nyid du'ang ldog par 'gyur te grogs nyid du'ang sgrub par byed do/ / yang na g.yul gyi thog mar mig gnyis la mngon par bsngags nas pha rol gyi dpung la bltas na/ zhi ba'i sems dang ldan par 'gyur zhing mtshon brdeg par rab tu nus pa ma yin no/ / 'thab pa med pa nyid du'ang ldog par 'gyur te/ grogs nyid du'ang rab tu sgrub par byed do/ / lag pa gnyis kyi sor mo de bzhin du glegs bam lta bur phan tshun gyi rtse mo sbyar la/ thad kar bzhag pa 'di ni shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / 'dir sngags ni/

“This mantra of the eye of the tathāgatas, when employed along with its namesake mudrā, can accomplish all activities. “If one enters among one’s enemies, having incanted one’s eyes [with the eye mantra of the tathāgatas], they will lose their anger[2408] upon merely being looked at. Filled with loving kindness, they will harbor good wishes and will become friends. Or, if one gazes at one’s enemies when in the vanguard of the battle after incanting one’s eyes, they will become kindly disposed. Unable to raise their weapons in assault, they will turn back without any fight and subsequently turn into allies. “If the hands are positioned horizontally and form the shape of a book with the opposite fingertips touching,[2409] this is the mudrā of Prajñāpāramitā. The corresponding mantra is:
na mo b+ha ga ba te tsu ru dar+sha ne o~M thA/
“Homage to you, blessed goddess beautiful to look at! Oṁ tha![2410]

'di ni bcom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i sngags so/ / 'di nyid kyi phyag rgya dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / sngags 'di bzlas nas snying la byugs shing myangs na dran pa dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / dgra ma rungs pa'i nang du bzlas pa byas na de dag gi sems 'phrog par 'gyur ro/ / yang na g.yul gyi nang du rkang gnyis dang / rkang bzhi la sogs pa phyir rgol ba thams cad rnam par rmongs par byed pa'am sems rnam par g.yengs par byed par 'gyur ro/ / mdor na bcom ldan 'das ma 'di ni ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / mdor na yon tan mtha' yas pa dang 'di'i las mtha' yas par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi phyag rgya dang sngags ni mtha' yas par 'gyur te/ ji ltar de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi 'khor 'dus pa'i le'ur gsungs pa de bzhin du sngags dang phyag rgya thams cad la yang rab tu sbyar bar bya'o/ / yang na gzhan dag tu sngags dang phyag rgya'i cho ga grangs med par 'gyur ba de dag kyang cho ga'i rgyal po 'dir nges par sbyar bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du pad+ma'i rigs la pad+ma'i phyag rgya dang ldan pa'i sngags su 'gyur te/

“This [mantra of] Blessed Prajñāpāramitā, when employed along with its namesake mudrā, can accomplish all activities. “If one touches one’s heart while reciting [the mantra just described], one will increase one’s powers of recollection. If, while reciting, one enters into the midst of wicked enemies, one will deprive them of the ability to think. In the heat of a battle, one will be able to stupefy one’s adversaries, whether they are two-legged or four-legged, or make them lose their minds. In short, whatever activities the blessed goddess is employed for, she will accomplish all of them. The qualities of this [mantra] are infinite, and so are its ritual applications. “The mudrās and mantras of the tathāgatas are infinite. One should employ [primarily] all the mudrās and mantras of the [deities] listed in the ‘Assembly’ chapter[2411] as the retinue deities of the tathāgatas, as the rites of other [deities] are innumerable.
