These mudrās and mantras should be employed according to the ritual of this king of manuals. “Thus, the mantra of the Lotus family should be used together with the padma[2412] mudrā. This mantra is:
o~M dzi dzi dzi nAM ga taM ya te di ne swA hA/
“Oṁ jiḥ jiḥ! Svāhā to the dispeller of fear, one with the body of a victorious one![2413]

sngags 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi pad+ma'i phyag rgya dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad par 'gyur ro/ / 'di bzlas na pad+ma'i rigs thams cad bzlas pa yin no/ / 'di grub na pad+ma'i rigs thams cad grub par 'gyur ro/ / de nas gos dkar mo'i rig pa chen po gang yin pa de'i sngags ni/

“This is the mantra of the bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara. When employed together with the padma mudrā, it will accomplish all activities. When it is recited, all the mantras of the Lotus family are being recited. When it is accomplished, all the mantras of the Lotus family are accomplished. “The mantra to be used with [the mudrā] of the great vidyā Pāṇḍaravāsinī is:
o~M a ka Te bi ka Te ni ka Te/ ka Ta~M ka Te swA hA/
“Oṁ kaṭe vikaṭe nikaṭe kaṭaṅkaṭe kaṭavikaṭakaṭaṅkaṭe svāhā![2414]

rang gi phyag rgya'am pad+ma'i phyag rgya sbyar na las thams cad par 'gyur ro/ / dur khrod thams cad du song nas bsrung ba yang bya'o/ / de bzhin du sgrol ma dang khro gnyer can dang skul byed ma dang rta mgrin la'ang sbyar bar bya'o/ / rig pa 'dus pa'i le'ur gang gsungs pa'i pad+ma'i rigs grangs med pa thams cad kyang 'dir sbyar bar bya'o/ / phyag rgya dang sngags kyi cho ga rgya cher pad+ma dag kyang sbyar bar bya'o/ /

“[This mantra], when combined with the mudrā of Pāṇḍaravāsinī or the padma[2415] mudrā, can accomplish all activities. It also affords protection to those visiting any of the charnel grounds. “Similarly, Tārā, Bhṛkuṭī, Candrā, any deities said to be from the retinue of the lord of vidyās Hayagrīva, as well as the entire Lotus family in its infinity, may be invoked by the means of the mantras and mudrās along with their extensive rituals.[2416]
de bzhin du rdo rje'i rigs kyi rdo rje'i phyag rgya dang bcas pa yin no/ /
“The same applies to the Vajra family where the mantra is used together with the double vajra mudrā.[2417]
'dir yang sngags ni/
This mantra is:[2418]

“Hūṁ! “When this mantra of Vajrapāṇi is accomplished, all the mantras of the Vajra family are accomplished. When this mantra is recited, all of them are recited. When employed along with previously described double vajra mudrā, this mantra will accomplish all the activities the practitioner desires, even those forbidden by the most eminent of victors, if they are required to guide sentient beings. This mantra of the great yakṣa is extremely fierce. “Similarly, [the mudrā] of Māmakī, the great vidyā who is the mainstay of the [Vajra] family, can accomplish all activities. The corresponding mantra is:
o~M ku laM ba ri ban+d+ha ban+d+ha hU~M phaT/
“Oṁ maintainer of the family! Bind, bind! Huṁ phaṭ![2419]

'di ni mA ma kI zhes bya ba'i rig pa chen mo las thams cad byed par sangs rgyas thams cad kyis bstan to/ / sngar rab tu sbyar ba'i phyag rgya dang rig pa chen mo mA ma kI dang yang dag par ldan na sgrub pa po 'dod pa bzhin du las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / gleng gzhi'i le'u sngar bstan pa'i phyag na rdo rje'i 'khor rdo rje'i rigs ma lus pa thams cad kyi phyag rgya dang sngags dang ldan pa yang 'dir rab tu sbyar bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du glang po'i rigs la glang po'i spos kyi byang chub sems dpa'i sngags su 'gyur ba ni/

“This great vidyā called Māmakī, taught by all the buddhas, is suitable for all activities. When employed together with the mudrā of Māmakī formed in advance, it can accomplish any activity according to the practitioner’s wish. One can also employ the mudrās of the retinue [deities] of Vajrapāṇi as listed in the introductory chapter,[2420] as well as the entire vajra holder’s family[2421] without exception, in combination with their respective mantras. “Similarly, in the Elephant[2422] family, there is, the mantra of the bodhisattva Gajagandha:
o~M ga dza a hwa ye hU~M khe tsa ra swA hA/
“Oṁ, you with an elephant’s name, hūṁ! You who walk in the sky, svāhā![2423]
sngar bstan pa'i phyag rgya dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad par 'gyur te/ snga ma de bzhin du thams cad glang po'i rigs la grub par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du kun tu bzang po'i sngags ni/

“When [this mantra] is employed along with the previously described mudrā, it will accomplish all activities. Just as before, when this mantra is accomplished, the whole family is accomplished. “So also [is the case with] the mantras of Samantabhadra, Mahāsthānaprāpta,[2424] and Vimalagati, which are, [respectively:]
o~M sa ma ya sa ma dzin su ra ta mA bi laM ba hU~M phaT/
“Oṁ, son of the victors! The same and not the same! Do not delay! Hūṁ phaṭ!;[2425]
mthu chen thob kyi sngags ni/
o~M tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha ma hA s+thA ma ga ta bo d+hi/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra hU~M phaT phaT swA hA/
“Remain, remain in the exalted place! Having attained awakening, remember your samaya! Hūṁ, phaṭ phaṭ, svāhā!;[2426]
dri ma med par grags pa'i sngags ni/
“and
o~M bi ma le bi ma le bi ma la murte/ o~M d+ha ka d+ha ka sa ma ya ma nu sma ra swA hA/
“Oṁ, stainless, stainless! With stainless form! Burn, burn! Remember your samaya, svāhā![2427]

nam mkha' mdzod kyi sngags ni/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi phyag rgya dang yang dag par ldan na las thams cad par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du ngan song kun spong dang rtag tu ngu dang sa'i snying po dang rin chen lag pa dang byams pa la sogs pa sa bcu rab tu thob pa rnams dang byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyang grangs med cing phyag rgya dang sngags kyang grangs med par 'gyur te/ de dag kyang cho ga'i rgyal po 'di la rab tu sbyar ba bya bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The mantra of Gaganagañja can accomplish all activities if employed with the mudrā of any bodhisattva.[2428] This applies also to all the innumerable great bodhisattvas who have attained the tenth bodhisattva level, starting with Apāyajaha, Sadāprarudita, Kṣitigarbha, Ratnapāṇi, and Maitreya. Their mudrās and mantras are, likewise, innumerable. They ought to be employed [as instructed] in this king of manuals.

'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi shin tu rgya che ba dang bcas pa'i sngags dang phyag rgya thams cad kyi cho ga rgya che ba dang dam tshig chen po dang dam tshig la rab tu zhugs pa cho ga dang cho ga'i rnam pa thams cad kyi bye brag cho ga'i rgyal po 'dir gsungs te/ sngags thams cad kyang 'di la sgrub pa byar rung ba yin no/ /

“The detailed section on all the mantras and mudrās covers a vast range of the worldly ones and the different levels of the supramundane. All the rites and their variants taught in this [manual] entail a samaya of the great assembly and require accomplishing all the relevant mantras.[2429]

de bzhin du rin po che'i rigs dang gnod sbyin gyi rigs dang lha'i rigs dag la yang sngags dang rgyud dang phyag rgya thams cad rab tu sbyar ba 'dir bstan pa yin no/ / rigs gcig kho nar 'gyur zhing gzhan du ma yin pa ni 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs te de yang 'jam dpal gzhon nu de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs su blta bar bya ste/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas dang / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad dang / zag pa dang bcas pa dang / zag pa med pa'i phyag rgya dang / cho ga dang cho ga'i rnam pa rnams ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs kyi nang du gtogs so zhes gzung bar gyis shig / 'jam dpal rig pa dang rgyud thams cad dang sngags kyi gsang ba gang de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam tshig la ma chud pa de ni gang yang med do/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nu de rab tu rtogs pa nyid du zung shig / gang gi phyir de bzhin gshegs pa mchog tu gsungs te de bas na de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs kyang mchog nyid du brjod do/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nu de ltar na cho ga'i rgyal po 'di yang rigs kyi mchog rin po cher dang po dang po'i sangs rgyas kyis rab tu bstan pa dang ston pa dang rab tu gzhag pa dang rnam par 'grel par mdzad pa ni/ bcom ldan 'das me tog kun tu skyes pa'i rgyal po dang / bcom ldan 'das sA la'i dbang po'i rgyal po dang / bcom ldan 'das me tog kun nas skyes pa'i dri mchog rgyal po dang / bcom ldan 'das rin chen tog dang / bcom ldan 'das 'od dpag tu med pa dang / bcom ldan 'das bsod nams kyi 'od dang me tog dam pa dang / yang dag pa'i me tog dang / me tog bzang po dang / tshe dang ye shes dpag tu med pa rnam par nges pa'i rgyal po'i dbang po dang / gser thub dang / 'od srung dang / 'khor ba 'jig dang / gtsug tor can dang thams cad skyob dang / da ltar shAkya thub pa ngas kyang rab tu bstan te/

“These mudrās and mantras should thus be employed according to their family association, whether the Jewel, the Yakṣa, the Celestial, or the Noble family. However, all these mantras and mudrās in all the tantras in the three times constitute but one family, which is none other than the Tathāgata family. And you too, Mañjuśrī, divine youth, may be regarded as belonging to the Tathāgata family. “You should remember, Mañjuśrī, that all the buddhas, bodhisattvas, noble śrāvakas, and pratyekabuddhas; all the worldly and supramundane mantra [deities],[2430] whether subject to karmic influences or not; and all the different mudrās‍—all of them belong to the families[2431] of the tathāgatas. There is no such mudrā,[2432] Mañjuśrī, or esoteric mantra system, that would not belong to a tathāgata family or have no samaya bond with a tathāgata. Know, divine youth, that they are connected. “Just as the Tathāgata is said to be at the forefront, so is the Tathāgata family said to be at the forefront. Therefore, Mañjuśrī, this king of manuals is the jewel of the most eminent of families. It was taught, elucidated, established, and propagated by the past buddhas since time immemorial. “This king of manuals was taught by Blessed Saṃkusumita Rāja, Blessed Śālarājendra, Blessed Saṃkusumitagandhottama Rāja, Blessed Ratnaketu, Blessed Amitābha, Blessed Puṇyābha, [Blessed] Kusumottama, [Blessed] Saṃkusuma, [Blessed] Supuṣpa, [Blessed] Amitāyurjñānaviniścayarājendra, [Blessed] Kanakamuni, [Blessed] Kāśyapa, [Blessed] Krakucchanda, [Blessed] Śikhin, [Blessed] Viśvabhū, Blessed Konākamuni,[2433] and also by me, Śākyamuni. It was taught before and will be taught again.

de bzhin du de ltar sangs rgyas gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de 'ongs pa 'di ni 'jam dpal gzhon nu cho ga'i rgyal po'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs kyi mchog rin po cher gyur pa/ phan yon che ba nges par chos kyi dbyings la brten pa/ bskal pa stong du'ang 'di'i phan yon bstan par ni mi nus so/ / yon tan chen po rgya che ba'i yon tan 'byung ba ni mthong ba'i chos dang 'jig rten pha rol du'ang yin no/ / dad pa can gang zhig gis the tshom med par 'chang ba dang klog pa dang / the tshom med par rgyud 'di la brtson pa byed cing sngags sgrub pa dang zlos pa dang phyag rgya 'ching ba dang rtag tu mngon par brtson par byed pa de la ni mthong ba'i chos kho na la yon tan gyi phan yon brgyad rab tu 'thob ste/

“In this way, O divine youth Mañjuśrī, this sovereign manual of your rites has been passed down by the succession of buddhas. It is the prime jewel of the Tathāgata family that brings great benefits. It is necessarily rooted in the sphere of phenomena. It is not possible to describe its benefits even in a thousand eons, or to fully describe its great qualities. Not even the likes of you could describe or communicate the experiences to be had in this world, or those related to the future state of awakening, its ultimate goal.[2434] “The extent of the great qualities of this manual and the ensuing results are immeasurable. They relate to both this existence and the hereafter. If any persons, full of trust and free from doubt, should memorize and propagate [this manual], apply themselves to its diverse practices, accomplish [its] mantras or [just] recite them, display [its] mudrās, applying themselves continually, such persons would exhibit the following eight qualities:[2435]
“(1) They would obtain special qualities and benefits.[2436]

'khrul pa med par 'gyur ba dang phyir rgol ba thams cad dang dgra'i 'jigs pa 'di la mi 'byung ba dang / 'di'i lus la dug mi 'byung ba dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpas kyang 'di la byin gyis brlabs par 'gyur ba dang tshe ring ba dang / bde ba la brten par 'gyur ba dang / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'ang 'di'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen du 'gyur ba dang mtshan mo'ang 'di la nyin re zhing rmi lam du mthong ba stsol ba dang sngags thams cad kyang 'di la bsrung bar 'gyur ro/ / phyag rgya'ang 'di la rmi lam du ston par 'gyur ro/ / rgyal po ma rungs pa dang sems can ma rungs pa dang mi phan pa 'dod pa rnams kyis kyang gnod pa med par 'gyur ro/ / nges par byang chub la gzhol bar 'gyur ro/ /

(2) They would be unfazed by their adversaries and have no fear therefrom. (3) Their bodies would be immune to poison and invulnerable to weapons. (4) They would be blessed by the buddhas and bodhisattvas and have long life, comforts, and intelligence. (5) The divine youth Mañjuśrī would become their spiritual friend and would appear to them in their dreams at night. (6) All the mantra [deities] would protect them and reveal to them their mudrās in their dreams. 7) No evil kings, wicked beings, or other ill-wishers would be able to harm them. (8) They would certainly be destined for awakening.[2437]

dad cing the tshom med la mngon par brtson pa'i phan yon ni brgyad po 'di dag yin te/ khyim pa'am rab tu byung ba'am bud med dam skyes pa'am sems can chen po bstan pa la phan par byed pa rnams kyi yin gyi/ sdig pa la zhugs pa gzhan gyi ni ma yin te/ de las bzlog pa de'i 'gro ba ni ngu 'bod la sogs par skye bar 'gyur ro/ / phyag rgya snga dro bcing ba byas na tshe ring bar 'gyur ro/ / zhes bya ba ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i sngags dang 'khor gyi snying po dang gtsug tor la sogs pa'i sngags dang spyan la sogs pa gzhan gyi phyag rgya de bcing bar bya'o/ / yang na 'jam dpal gzhon nu khyod kyi phyag rgya bya ste/ 'di dag ni brtson 'grus dang stobs mnyam pa yin no/ /

“These eight benefits will manifest for those with faith and no doubts, who earnestly apply themselves to the practice‍—householders or renunciants, women or men‍—if they follow the instructions. They will not manifest for others. For those engaging in evil actions the opposite will happen; they will proceed downward into the Raurava and other hells. “As has been said, displaying the mudrās in the forenoon is conducive to long life. One should respectfully display the mudrās of the uṣṇīṣa [kings], and of Locanā[2438] and the others, while reciting the heart mantras of the deities from the retinue of the Tathāgata. They are of the same efficacy and power as your mudrās and mantras, O divine youth Mañjuśrī.

gtsang zhing gtsang ba'i gnas su 'dug ste zhes bya ba ni gnas gtsang ma'i phyogs su zug rngu med pa'i gnas la ba'i lci ba sa la ma lhung bar byugs la me tog dkar po'i dri zhim po dag gis gcal bkram pa der 'dug la sngags bzla zhing phyag rgya bcing bar bya'i gzhan du ni ma yin no/ / gzhan dag tu ni phyag rgya dang lhan cig bzlas pa gcig kyang mi bya'o/ / gtsang ba zhes gang gsungs pa ni nyi ma nub pa na srog chags med pa'i chu gtsang mas khrus byas te gos sar pa bgos la/ gtsug tor gyi sngags kyis srung ba byas la/ grong gi chos rnam par spangs shing gtsang zhing gtsang sbra la dga' zhing dge ba ska rags dkar pos bcings pa de bzhin gshegs pa bsgoms la thun gcig 'das pa dang der nyal bar bya'o/ / bram ze mo'i bu mo gtsang mas bkal ba'i skud pa blangs la/ sngags 'di brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par sngags pa bya'o/ /

“As has been said, one should be clean and be in a clean place. The intermediate area[2439] should be free from thorns, smeared with cow dung that has not fallen,[2440] and strewn with sweet-smelling white flowers. Standing there, one should recite the mantra and display the mudrā‍—not anywhere else, and not [the mantras and mudrās] of other [deities], but a single mantra out of those [specified], accompanied by [its respective] mudrā. “As said before, one should be clean. When the sun has set, one should wash oneself in pure water, free of living organisms, and put on fresh clothes. One should perform the uṣṇīṣa protection,[2441] and one should avoid sexual activity, be morally upright, and joyfully guard one’s purity and virtue. “The protection effected by the uṣṇīṣa Should be followed by creating a [protected] circle[2442] Where, during sleep after the first watch of the night, One should contemplate the tathāgatas. “One should obtain a thread spun by a virgin girl, or a brahmin girl who has never experienced sexual pleasure,[2443] and incant it one hundred and eight times with the mantra:
o~M ha ra ha ra ban+d+ha ne shu kra d+hA ra NI sid d+hAr+the swA hA/
“Oṁ, seize, seize! Bind, bind! Arrester of semen and fulfiller[2444] of aims, svāhā![2445]

mA ma kI'i phyag rgya dang bzlas pa bya'o/ / de nas skud pa rked pa la lan gsum dkris nas bcing ba byas na sa bon bcing ba byas par 'gyur te/ 'dod pa'i dbang phyug gis kyang rmi lam du yid la gnod pa byed par mi nus na/ rmi lam du log 'dren rnam pa sna tshogs kyis lta smos kyang ci dgos/ de bzhin du cho ga 'di 'dod chags dang ldan pas kyang mi nus na/ 'dod chags dang bral bas lta smos kyang ci dgos/ 'dod pa'i dbang phyug dga' ldan gyi bu mo gzugs rnam pa sna tshogs 'chang ba'i 'dod chags can gyis kyang yid la gnod pa skyed par mi nus na de las gzhan pa'i mi dang mi ma yin pa'i bud med kyis kyang lta smos kyang ci dgos/ de lta bu'i cho gas nang par langs la so shing bca' zhing gdong rab tu bkrus la/ cho ga snga ma bzhin du srog chags med cing dri ma med pa'i chus khrus byas te/ shar phyogs su bltas la phyag rgya bcing zhing sngags bzlas pa byas na tshe ring bar 'gyur zhing las thams cad la nus pa dang nad chen po las grol te skye bo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / dgra rnams kyang bshes gnyen nyid du 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / mthong ba tsam gyis gdon thams cad dang sha rjen za ba dang sdig pa can la sogs pa rab tu 'byer bar 'gyur ro/ / dgra rnams rengs par 'gyur ro/ / mthong ba tsam gyis gtsang ba'am mi gtsang ba'i cho gas las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ /

“One should recite this mantra while displaying the mudrā of Māmakī and then tie the thread around one’s hips. If one wraps it around three times, the semen will be arrested.[2446] “Not even the lord of the realm of desire will be able to disturb one’s mind during sleep, so how could the dream-framing vināyakas do it? Through this method, and not without it, neither the daughters of the ṛṣis nor the daughters of the lord of the realm of desire, who assume various forms to excite passions, will be able to disturb one’s mind, even if normally one has passions and is not free from them, so how could other women, whether human or nonhuman, disturb it? “Applying this procedure, one should rise early, go to the toilet, brush one’s teeth, rinse one’s mouth, and wash oneself, as before, in clean water free of living organisms. Facing the east, one should display the mudrā and recite the mantra. “As a consequence, one will enjoy a long life and proficiency in all types of activity. One will be free from all major diseases and will be loved by everybody. One’s enemies will become one’s friends. Through merely seeing [the mudrā], all the grahas, kravyādas, kaśmalas, and so forth will flee. The enemy army will become paralyzed. Through merely displaying [the mudrā], one will accomplish any activity. One thus has a choice between the procedure that is pure, or the impure lack of it.[2447]

de bzhin du cho ga'i rgyal po 'di'i phyag rgya dang sngags kyi tshogs kyi 'khor 'di yang grangs med pa yin te/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das grangs med pas gsungs pa dang gsungs pa yin te/ shAkya thub pa ngas kyang da ltar de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyis kyang 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor gyi nang du gsungs te/ 'jam dpal gzhon nu khyod la yang bstan pa yongs su bsrung ba'i phyir dang chos kyi dbyings yun ring du yang dag par bsrung ba'i phyir 'di khyod la yongs su gtad do/ / nga yongs su mya ngan las 'das te chos kyi de nyid la brten cing yang dag pa'i mtha'i tha mar gyur te zhi bar gyur pa na/ sems can snying rje chen po dang bral ba'i sems dang ldan pa la phan pa'i phyir gsungs shing dus kyi mtha' 'jigs pa chen po'i dus la bab pa na/ dkon mchog gsum la gnod pa byed pa'i sems can rnams kyang bzlog pa'i don dang gdul ba'i don gyi phyir cho ga'i rgyal po 'di ngas gsungs la rgya cher rnam par dbye ba byas na sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir yin no/ /

“This king of manuals is filled with infinite sets of mudrās and mantras,[2448] which have been and will be taught by innumerable blessed buddhas. I too‍—Tathāgata[2449] Śākyamuni, a worthy, fully realized buddha‍—have just now taught them in the midst of this great assembly. “You also, Mañjuśrī, divine youth, will engage in the task of safeguarding these instructions and safeguarding the domain of the teachings over the long period of time when I have passed into nirvāṇa, dissolved into the ultimate reality, and attained the complete peace of the final state. “As the end of an eon is now setting in, at this terrible time I taught this with my mind overcome by great compassion, for the benefit of beings. I taught this king of manuals in order to restrain and guide those who offend against the Three Jewels‍—the evil kings and the wicked beings.[2450] I taught this king of manuals with its detailed sections for the sake of all beings.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ sngags dang phyag rgya dang nges par sdom pa dang las dang cho ga'i le'u rab 'byam las/ sum cu rtsa gcig pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter on the ritual procedures that prescribe the mantras and the mudrās, thirty-seventh[2451] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
phyag rgya dang / sngags dang / las thams cad dang nges par sdom pa'i le'u
Chapter 38

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gzhan yang thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang la gzigs nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal mdor na nyon cig phyag rgya'i mtshan nyid dang sngags rnams kyi rgya che ba dang dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga'i mdor bsdus pa dang dam tshig la rjes su 'jug cing phyag rgya'i gnas dang sngags thams cad dang rgyud de dag thams cad la gsang ba dang bcas pa'i dkyil 'khor ni/

At that time the blessed Śākyamuni again directed his gaze at the realm of the Pure Abode and spoke to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “Listen, Mañjuśrī! “Briefly, there are detailed [teachings on] the characteristics of the mudrās and the mantras, the procedures of the maṇḍalas and the association-based[2452] distribution of mudrās therein, and the secret maṇḍala of all the mantra [deities] in all the tantras.[2453]

rdzu 'phrul che kun sangs rgyas kyis/ / 'di kun sngar ni gsungs pa yin/ / sngags shes bdag nyid chen po dang / / yon tan kun kyang bstan pa yin/ / dang po'i sangs rgyas dag gis sngar/ / sems can rnams la phan pa'i phyir/ / sngags kyi 'khor lo dag dang ni/ / chos kyi 'khor lo bla med bskor/ / yang dag mtha' la brten nas ni/ / zhi ba'i 'khor lo'i rjes su song / / 'jig rten sangs rgyas rdzu 'phrul che/ / sangs rgyas de kun zhi bar gshegs/ / dang po'i de bzhin gshegs rnams kyis/ / 'di kun sngon ni bstan pa yin/ / ngas kyang phyi ma'i dus dag tu/ / 'jam pa'i blo ldan khyod la bstan/ / sangs rgyas 'od can de yi bka'/ / de tshe 'di ni thos nas kyang / / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni gzhon nu yang / / thal mo sbyar byas spyan sngar 'dug / rkang gnyis rdzogs sangs rgyas pa la/ / smra ba'i mchog gis yongs su zhus/ / 'jig rten rnams la phan pa'i phyir/ / shes rab chen po chos gsungs shig / mdor bsdus rgya ni mi che bar/ / yon tan bdag nyid che 'bras 'byung / /

“All of them were taught before By every buddha of great majesty. The exalted function of the mantras Was explained for each of the families[2454] By the former buddhas from the earliest time To bring benefit to sentient beings. “Having set in motion the mantra wheel, Which constitutes the supreme wheel of the Dharma, They dissolved into the ultimate reality, Mounted upon the wheel of peace. All these buddhas, very powerful in the world, Entered the peace [of nirvāṇa]. “All this was formerly taught By the tathāgatas since the beginning of time. I, too, will teach it [now] in this final world, Putting my trust, Mañju,[2455] in you.” The divine youth Mañjughoṣa, Hearing these words Of the buddha of great splendor, Folded his hands before him, And said to the best of speakers,[2456] The fully realized buddha, supreme among two-legged beings, “Teach the Dharma, O sagacious one, To bring benefit to the world! “Teach it in a succinct manner, without elaborating, Causing the greatness of its qualities to bear fruit.”

'jam dpal gyis ni de skad gsol/ / de nas cang mi smra bar gnas/ / de nas dpal ldan tshangs pa'i dbyangs/ / ka la ping ka'i sgra skad kyis/ / dkyil 'khor dgod pa'i phyag rgya ni/ / de dag kun ni ston pa yin/ / gnas gtsang steng du gnas pa'i dus/ / de tshe sngags dang rgyud dag ni/ / shAkya seng ge mi mchog ni/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis yang dag gsungs/ / phyag rgya'i cho ga 'byung ba dang / / phyag rgya rgyud dang ldan pa yi/ / yon tan bdag nyid rgya che ba/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nu khyod nyon cig / sems can sems can ma yin pa'ang / / dang po'i rtags mtshan bzhin du bya/ / rnam pa spyad dang spyod pa dang / / zur gyis thams cad smra ba dang / / lag gnyis rkang gnyis spyi bo dang / / lag gcig sor mo'i sbyor ba dag / sngon gyi sangs rgyas de dag gis/ / de kun phyag rgya zhes su gsungs/ /

Having said this, Mañjuśrī remained silent. The glorious great lord[2457] With a voice as sweet as a cuckoo Taught then everything that pertains To the distribution of mudrās in the maṇḍala. Staying above the realm of the Pure Abode, The Lion of the Śākyas, the best of men, The fully realized buddha, [also] taught, at that time, The [relevant] mantra system. “Listen, Mañjuśrī, divine youth, About the mudrās with their procedures, And about the mantras employed in tantric methods. Hear the full account of the greatness of their qualities! “First of all, there are signs that indicate Whether something is a living being or not; [They include] form, actions, behavior, And all the gestures and speech. “These gestures may involve both hands, both feet, The head, or the fingers of each hand. All of them were designated as mudrā By the primordial buddhas of yore.

bya bum gdugs dang de bzhin du/ / pad+ma rgyal mtshan ba dan dang / / nya dang rdo rje dung dang ni/ / de bzhin bum pa 'khor lo dang / / 'jig rten sna tshogs mtshon cha ni/ / ji srid yongs su bstan pa dang / / ut+pal 'dra ba'i phyag rgya dang / / de kun phyag rgya dkyil 'khor dgod/ / de dag go rims gnas pa dang / / cho ga ldan par bstan pa yin/ / rtag tu de dag nyid la ni/ / rang gzugs 'dra bar bri bar bya/ / dkyil 'khor phyag rgyar gsungs pa ni/ / thams cad du ni spyir gsungs pa'o/ / de dag phyag rgyar yongs bstan pa/ / gnas ni ji bzhin dag la dgod/ / dkyil 'khor dag ni kun la yang / / rang dang 'dra ba nyid du sbyar/ / 'khor los sgyur la 'khor lo dang / / gtsug tor gdugs dkar nyid la ni/ / gtso bor gdugs ni dkar po yin/ / dkyil 'khor la ni rtag tu bri/ /

“They are the pitcher, Parasol, lotus, banner, flag, Fish, vajra, conch, Jar, wheel, “[And the mudrās named after] different weapons and implements[2458]‍— As many as there are known in the world‍— Including the mudrā shaped like a blue lotus, All of them are arranged around the maṇḍala. “They are arranged in sequence, As specified in the instructions. Each of them should always be drawn With its own respective form. “When talking about the mudrās in the maṇḍala, They are each placed In their own dedicated slot, Where they are known to belong. “In all the maṇḍalas, One must use the right mudrā form; Cakravartin[2459] is thus represented by the wheel. If the uṣṇīṣa lord is Sitātapatra, “One should draw a white parasol[2460] In the most prominent place in the maṇḍala.

chos kyi 'khor lo sangs rgyas la/ / pad+ma pad+ma'i rigs dag la/ / rdo rje rdo rje'i rigs la gsungs/ / glang po glang po'i rigs zhes bya/ / nor bu'i rigs la bum pa ste/ / dkyil 'khor kun la rab tu sbyar/ / lha gzhan gyi ni rigs dag la/ / dpal be'u bkra shis ldan pa bri/ / tshangs pa che la ngang pa bri/ / brgya byin la yang rdo rje dang / / dbang phyug che la bri ba ni/ / rtse gsum khyu mchog yang dag bya/ / skem byed rtse gsum paT+Ti sa/ / mdung dang bcas pa nyid kyang yin/ / khyab 'jug 'khor lo bri ba ste/ / lha ma yin la da pus dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs brgya phrag ni/ / lha yi mtshon cha sna tshogs dang / / de dag gzhan yang bzhon pa ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs de tshe bri/ /

The Dharma wheel represents the buddhas,[2461] And the lotus, the Lotus family. “The vajra is said to represent the Vajra family; The elephant, the Elephant family; And the jar, the Jewel family. These allocations apply to every maṇḍala. “The two eminent families, the Celestial and the Noble,[2462] Should be drawn as the endless knot and swastika respectively. To represent the distinguished yakṣa family, One should draw a fruit that is a source of phalaja.[2463] “To represent Mahābrahmā, one should draw a swan; For Śakra, one should draw his thunderbolt. To represent Maheśvara, one should draw his trident,[2464] And in addition, his bull.[2465] “The trident is a three-pointed lance. For Skanda, one should draw a [one-pointed] lance; For Viṣṇu, a discus; And for the dānavas, a mace. “The deities have various weapons And assume different bodily positions. They also have different vehicles, Which should always be drawn in the center.[2466]

gzugs brnyan ji ltar gnas pa ni/ / rang gzugs 'phos pa bzhin du bri/ / dkyil 'khor dag ni thams cad du/ / gang yang rung ba 'di cig bri/ / gcig dang gnyis dang yang dag ldan/ / grangs med gsum la sogs pa bya/ / dkyil 'khor rgyal ba mchog gsungs pa/ / lan kan phreng ni de dang mnyam/ / gang gi ched du dkyil 'khor gsungs/ / de ni dbus su nges par sbyar/ / rgyal ba'i rigs ni nang du bri/ / nang gi dbus su'ang sangs rgyas te/ / de tshe nang du'ang gzugs brnyan ni/ / ston pa yi ni kun tu bri/ / gnyis par pad+ma'i rigs dgod cing / / gsum par rdo rje'i rigs kyang bri/ / mthar gyis lha dang lha ma yin/ / de bzhin de tshe thams cad ni/ / de nas sa kun la gnas pa'i/ / gnod sbyin srin po mi dang bcas/ / mthar gyis ji ltar gnas pa yi/ / mu stegs rnams kyang de nas bri/ / cho ga bzhin du thams cad kyang / / phyogs skyong de bzhin bri bar bya/ /

“Conveying their form by means of an image, One should draw, in every maṇḍala, One of these [deities], Whichever one is appropriate. “The maṇḍalas taught by the supreme victors May have one, two, three, Or an infinite number [of deities], Arranged to resemble the rows of an altar.[2467] “[The deity] indicated for a given maṇḍala Should be placed in the center; If [the maṇḍala] is the ‘womb’ of the victors’ family, One should paint, in the very center, the Buddha. “One should thus draw the image Of the Teacher right in the center. Second, one should draw [the deity] of the Lotus family, And third, [the deity of] the Vajra family. “Having drawn all of this, one should add, Following the right order, the gods and the asuras, And then, filling the entire area, The yakṣas, rākṣasas, and humans. “Next, one should draw, In the right order, the tīrthikas, And also the guardians of the quarters, All of them in their respective places.[2468]

mdor na gzugs brnyan gcig dang ni/ / gnyis dang gsum sogs grangs med pa/ / mtha' yas phyogs la gnas pa yi/ / dkyil 'khor ji srid kun tu bri/ / ma mo'i dkyil 'khor nyid dag ni/ / tshad med de tshe bri bar bya/ / gzugs brnyan gcig la sogs pa ni/ / mtha' yas sa yi steng dag tu/ / dkyil 'khor cho ga gsungs pa ni/ / rnam pa gsum du nges bstan pa/ / mchog dang bar ma de bzhin du/ / tha ma nyid du'ang bstan pa yin/ / mchog la mchog dag grub pa dang / / 'bring la 'bring du nye bar bstan/ / tha mas phran tshegs grub par ni/ / rgyal ba mchog gis sngon gsungs so/ /

“In short, one may draw a maṇḍala Starting from a single dot[2469] or two, Up to infinity, until the quarters are filled Up to their farthest limits. “The earth is said to be infinite, And so can be the surface of the maṇḍala, Starting from a single dot or two, And extending over the entire earth.[2470] “Based on the instructions, The maṇḍala procedure is said to be Of three kinds, known as The highest, the medium, and the lowest. “The highest procedure results in the highest accomplishment. If the procedure is medium, the accomplishment is said to be middling. The lowest procedure results in an inferior accomplishment, As was formerly taught by the supreme victors.

sems can yid ni rnam gsum gyis/ / rgyal ba mchog gis grub par gsungs/ / sems can chen pos chen po 'grub/ / sems can 'bring gis 'bring dang ni/ / gsum pa skye bo phra mo yi/ / las ni phra mor nye bar bstan/ / sangs rgyas nyid du sems dang la/ / phun sum tshogs pa dam pa ni/ / nges par thob par 'gyur ba ste/ / sems can dkyil 'khor mthong bas so/ / de dus sems ni bar ma yis/ / rang rgyal byang chub thob par byed/ / gus pa med pas nyan thos nyid/ / tha mas nges par thob par byed/ /

“The supreme victors also explained The threefold accomplishment based on mental capacity: Great beings attain great accomplishment, And the mediocre, the middling. The third accomplishment, that of minor beings, Is taught for the minor activities. “When one’s thoughts [are suffused with] faith, One is of the highest capacity and will definitely obtain Final buddhahood with its attendant rewards Through merely seeing the maṇḍala. “Those of the middling mental capacity will attain, At that time, the realization of a pratyekabuddha. The remaining ones, because of their lack of devotion, Are bound for the state of a śrāvaka.[2471]
bdag nyid chen po don bcas 'bras/ / zhi ba'i 'gro bar nye bar bstan/ /
“This is not unfruitful, as the proclaimed result [Of the śrāvaka path]‍—the peaceful destiny [of nirvāṇa]‍—is exalted.[2472]

dkyil 'khor mthong bas mtho ris su/ / nges par de ni 'gro bar 'gyur/ / de bzhin phyag rgya mchog kun dang / / sngags rnams kyang ni rgya cher bcas/ / rnam gsum nyid kyang rab sbyar ba/ / rnam gsum bde ba rab tu byed/ / phyag rgya dkyil 'khor gsungs pa dang / / sngags rnams bstan pa'ang phan pa'i don/ /

If one merely sees the maṇḍala, One is bound to attain birth in the divine realms. “Similarly, all the excellent mudrās And the mantras, in all their vastness, Can be employed in three different ways; In terms of bringing happiness, they are divided into three categories. The mudrās and the maṇḍalas having already been described, [Now] the benefits of mantras are being told.

“Starting from One Syllable, And as far as the count goes, However many [types of] speech Are known [to be used] in the mantras,[2473] “[Whether it is] ordinary speech, Lamentation, weeping, laughter, wailing, Or any [other kind of] speaking or talking, All of them have their place in the mantras.

de dag rnam pa gsum du 'gyur/ / sngags kyang rnam gsum mnyam par bstan/ / ji ltar dkyil 'khor bstan pa bzhin/ / phyag rgya sngags kyang de bzhin te/ / 'di dag cho gar yang dag ldan/ / 'jig rten 'dren pas nges par bstan/ / de bzhin de yang rnam gsum 'gro/ / stong phrag dag ni du ma nyid/ / rnam gsum rnam pa gsum dag kyang / / rnam pa gnyis dang grangs med pa'o/ /

“These mantras are of three kinds‍— The same three categories That have been taught for the maṇḍalas Apply also to the mudrās and the mantras. “The relevant procedures Taught by the guides of the world Are, in the same way, threefold, And further still, manifold or thousandfold. “While being of three kinds, or falling into three categories, They are also twofold,[2474] or of infinite types.

gang phyir sngags ni sems la ltos/ / sngags ni sems kyis spangs mi bya/ / sems dang sngags ni yang dag ldan/ / lhan cig tu ni bsgrub par bya/ / de bzhin gshegs kyi rigs sngags dang / / gang yang pad+ma'i rigs dag dang / / gang yang rdo rje'i rigs gsungs dang / / mi yi rigs ni nyid dag dang / / 'jig rten pa yi sngags rnams kun/ / de dag ma lus 'di las byung / / gang zhig rgyal dang rgyal sras sngags/ / sems can phyir ni gsungs pa rnams/ / gang zhig de zlos mngon brtson pa'ang / / de nas nges par sangs rgyas 'gyur/ /

The mantra is coextensive with the mind And never separate from the mind. “One who employs the mantra, Blending it with the mind, will succeed. Whatever mantras there are in the Tathāgata Or the Lotus families, “Or those chanted in the Vajra Or other families,[2475] Including all the worldly mantras, All of them arise from the [mind].[2476] “If one studiously recites any mantra From the Victor’s family that was taught For the sake of beings by the victors’ sons, One will certainly become a buddha.[2477]

gang yang sngags ni bar ma dag / gang zhig zlos pa de zlo byed/ / rang sangs rgyas su yang dag bstan/ / nges par de yi rigs kyang yin/ / sngags ni tha mar rab zhugs pa/ / nyan thos dgra bcom gyis bshad dang / / 'jig rten ma lus kun la yang / / sngags zlos pa la mngon brtson pa/ / nyan thos rdzu 'phrul chen po yis/ / nges par rigs su de gnas yin/ / mchog dang tha ma bar ma yi/ / der yang las ni rab sbyar bya/ / zhi bas sangs rgyas byang chub 'gyur/ / rgyas pa yis ni rang rgyal te/ / gzhan pa phran tshegs las kyis ni/ / nyan thos kyi ni byang chub brjod/ / de ni rnam gsum dbye ba ste/ / der yang sems ni blta bar bya/ / mang por yang ni dbye bya ste/ / grangs med par yang dbye bas so/ /

“If one reverently recites The mantras of the middle category, One will definitely acquire the family status Referred to as pratyekabuddha. “A mantra reciter studiously engaged In reciting other mantras, Such as those taught by the noble śrāvakas[2478] And the worldly mantras that are essentially virtuous, Will certainly acquire the family status Of a śrāvaka of great power. “Similarly, the rites may be divided Into the highest, the medium, and the inferior. The rites of pacifying lead to the realization of a buddha; Those of nourishing, to the realization of a rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddha. Those that involve minor mantras[2479] Are said to lead to the realization of a śrāvaka. “In this context, the mind should also Be regarded as being of three types, But can be further subdivided into many, Even infinite, types.”

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las phyag rgya dang / sngags dang / las thams cad dang nges par sdom pa'i le'u rab 'byam las sum cu rtsa gnyis pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter on all the ritual procedures involving the mudrā and the maṇḍala methods, thirty-eighth[2480] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
gshin rje gshed kyi yongs su bsngags pa dang sngags kyi bdag nyid chen po'i nges par sdom pa'i le'u
Chapter 50

de nas gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon phyag na rdo rje 'khor der 'dus par gyur te/ 'dug pa de stan las langs nas bla gos phrag pa gcig tu gzar te/ pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs nas bcom ldan 'das ga la ba de logs su thal mo sbyar te/ bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ /

[2481]At that time Blessed Vajrapāṇi, the general of the yakṣas who was in the assembly, got up from his seat, draped his upper robe over the left shoulder, placed his right knee on the ground, bowed[2482] to the Blessed One with his palms pressed together, and made the following request:

gang bcom ldan 'das kyis 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'i khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje'i gshed ces bya bas bshad pa de'i cho ga rgya che ba bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la'ang bka' ma stsal bas/ bcom ldan 'das bdag dang phyi ma'i skye bo la gzigs nas/ bcom ldan 'das yongs su mya ngan las 'das te/ bstan pa nub pa'i dus la bab ste/ 'jigs pa chen po rtsod pa'i dus tha ma la nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dag med pa na/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing du de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa yang dag par bsrung ba'i phyir dang / chos kyi khams yun ring du gnas par bya ba'i phyir dang / rgyal po ma rungs pa thams cad bzlog pa'i phyir dang / dkon mchog gsum la gnod pa byed pa dag tshar gcad pa'i phyir dang / gdul bya'i sems can la bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i thabs mkhas pa bstan pa'i phyir dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir dang / bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i sems can yongs su smin pa mngon par bsgrub pa'i phyir dang / bcom ldan 'das phyi ma'i dus dang phyi ma'i dus su bstan pa rnam par 'jig par 'gyur ba na/ gang 'di khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed kyi cho ga ji lta ba bzhin gsungs pa rab tu sbyar na de la grub par 'gyur te/ nges par rgyal po ma rungs pa bstan pa la gnod pa byed pa dang / sems can phyogs chen po dang ldan pa dang spro ba chen po dang ldan pa rnams tshar gcad pa dang rjes su gzung ba la rab tu zhugs pa dang snying rje chen po dang bral ba de dag la khro bo'i rgyal po 'di rab tu sbyar bar bya'i gzhan dag la ni ma yin no/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das cang mi gsung bar gyur te/ sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul ba'i ba'i byin gyis rlabs zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa'ang cang mi smra bar gnas par gyur to/ / thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor yang rnam pa drug tu rab tu 'gul bar gyur to/ /

“O Blessed One! You have not fully explained[2483] the ritual of the lord of wrath called Yamāntaka that was taught by Mañjuśrī, the divine youth. Nor has Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, explained it. I request you, Blessed One, to teach this ritual, out of regard for human beings during the final age, so that, at the time when you are in the state of complete nirvāṇa, when the teachings have disappeared, during the dreadful time of the worst age when the buddhafield is completely devoid of śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas, the teachings of the tathāgatas may be preserved, the domain of the Dharma may remain for a long time, all wicked kings may be subdued, those who harm the Three Jewels may be suppressed, the inconceivable bodhisattva conduct may bring the virtues of beings who require guidance to completion, and innumerable sentient beings may be brought to complete maturity. “During the final eon, Blessed One, when the final age has arrived in which the Sugata’s instructions perish, should one practice this rite of the wrathful lord Yamāntaka correctly, one will attain accomplishment. And this lord of wrath should always be used against none other than those evil kings and sentient beings who harm the teachings,[2484] such as the great yakṣas who are extremely powerful and engage in acts of oppression or assistance but lack great compassion.” The Blessed One, remaining silent, entered the samādhi called the buddha’s blessing through miraculous transformation. The divine youth Mañjuśrī, too, remained silent. The entire assembly and its surroundings began to shake in six different ways.

lha tshogs dag kyang 'jigs par gyur/ / byis pa kun kyang rab tu dngangs/ / lha rnams kun dang klu dag dang / / lha min dbang dang ma mor bcas/ / gza' rnams kun gyi gtso bo dang / / lha tshogs mi dang bcas pa dang / / ma rungs sems ldan srul po dag / rab 'gul yid ni mi brtan gyur/ /

The hosts of divine beings, all the youthful lords, Were alarmed and terrified.[2485] All the gods, the nāgas, The dānava lords, the mātṛs, The grahas, the mukhyas,[2486] and so forth‍— All of the hosts of divine beings trembled. Human beings also trembled, their minds disturbed, And so did the evil-minded pūtanas.[2487]

mi yi bdag po gdug ldan sems/ / de dag nyam thag 'jigs par gyur/ / chos kyi rgyal po'i bstan pa la/ / de tshe de dag skyabs su song / / gnod sbyin gsang ba'i bdag po ni/ / 'od chen phyag na rdo rje dang / / gzhon nur gyur pa'i sngags rgyal dang / / 'jam dpal dbyangs la'ang de 'jigs nas/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyi drung du ni/ / de tshe de dag dam tshig blangs/ / ma rungs sngags ni mi bzad pas/ / kye ma bdag cag nges bsreg cing / / de ring khro bos brgyal 'gyur zhing / / sa yi steng du 'gyel 'gyur bas/ / sems can thugs la thugs brtse bas/ / yongs su bskyab cing bsrung du gsol/ / de nas 'od chen byis pa'i gzugs/ / byang chub sems dpa' des smras pa/ / lha dang gnod sbyin srin po dang / / lha min thams cad ma 'jigs shig / mi dang mi ma yin pa dang / / 'byung po ma lus lha rnams kun/ / khyod kyi dam tshig ngas bshad bsrung / /

After that the violently predisposed human kings, Fearful and distressed, Took refuge in the instructions Of the Dharma king.[2488] Awed by the great radiance of Vajrapāṇi, The lord of guhyakas, himself a yakṣa, And by the youthful prince Mañjughoṣa, Lord of the mantra, They forged then, in Mañjughoṣa’s presence, A samaya connection[2489] by saying, “Protect us, O venerable boy[2490] Who cares for all beings! We are being burnt By the extremely fierce, cruel mantras. We stand before you on earth In a stupor caused by our anger.” Then the bodhisattva with the form of a child Of great splendor addressed them as follows: “Do not be afraid, all of you gods, Yakṣas, rākṣasas, and dānavas. “Your samaya, now explained to you by me,[2491] Cannot be violated by any deity By any human or nonhuman being, And especially not by any spirit.[2492]

rtag tu byams sems gyur nas ni/ / rtag tu rang gi sngags kyang dran/ / shAkya seng ge mi yi mchog / rkang gnyis mchog ni rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / de nyid kyis gsung sngags dang ni/ / gtsug tor spyan la sogs pa'o/ / 'jig rten gsum la 'khor lo rgyal/ / gzi brjid phung po dam pa rgyal/ / rnam rgyal gtsug tor gsang sngags dang / / phyag na pad+ma rnam gzigs dang / / kun tu gzigs pa'i mgon po dang / / khro gnyer sgrol ma grags ldan ma/ / lha mo gos dkar mo dang ni/ / dkar chen ma dang snyan ldan ma/ / rigs ma longs spyod ldan ma dang / / rta mgrin sngags kyi rgyal po dang / / de dag pad+ma'i rig sngags dang / / gtsor ni rgyal bas gsung ba dang / / yi ge gcig dang 'khor los sgyur/ / sngags rnams bdag po'i mnga' bdag dang / / 'od chen sngags kyi mgon po ni/ / 'di dag de bzhin dran par gyis/ / gshin rje gshed ces bya ba yi/ / khro bo'i gtso bo de yang dran/ /

“Being perpetually of a kind mental disposition, At all times one should recollect the mantra‍— The mantra that is the fully realized buddha, Supreme among two-legged beings, the Lion of the Śākyas and best of men. “He taught the mantras Of the uṣṇīṣas and so forth, including the Locanā;[2493] The mantras of the teachers of the three worlds‍— Cakravartin,[2494] Tejorāśi, and Jayoṣṇīṣa[2495]‍— “And also of Vijayoṣṇīṣa and the rest; Of Padmapāṇi, Lokita,[2496] Avalokiteśvara, Bhṛkuṭī, Tārā, and Yaśasvinī; “And also [the mantras of] the goddesses Sitavāsinī,[2497] Mahāśvetā, and Yaśovatī; The vidyā Bhogavatī; And Hayagrīva, the king of mantras. “These are the main mantras In the Lotus family that emerged from the victorious ones. The cakravartin One Syllable[2498] Is the mighty lord of [all these] mantras. “If one remembers the god of gods, The splendorous lord of mantras By the name of Yamāntaka,[2499] One will have no anger.[2500]

mgon po spyan ras gzigs pa yi/ / thugs ni thugs rje byung ba dang / / thugs rje chen pos thugs brlan par/ / sangs rgyas snga mas gsungs pa'ang dran/ / sgrol ma skye bo sgrol bar ni/ / spyan ras gzigs kyis gsungs pa dang / / rtag dang ting 'dzin skyes 'phags ma/ / ming gi gzugs ni bstan pa'ang yin/ /

“[The mantra of] Avalokiteśvara Gives rise to compassionate thoughts And overwhelms the mind with great compassion. [The mantra of] Tārā, revealed by the former buddhas[2501] “And spoken by Avalokiteśvara, Delivers sentient beings [from suffering]. This noble vidyā is generated during samādhi And designated as woman in name and form.[2502]

byang chub sems bzhin spyod pa ste/ / byang chub spyod byed dam pa'ang yin/ / 'jig rten khams ni stong dag tu/ / grangs med rnam pa mang por yang / / sems can rnams la phan pa'i phyir/ / de tshe lha mo rgyu bar byed/ / bud med gzugs ni bzung nas kyang / / sngags kyi tshul gyis lus can la/ / de tshe sems can 'dul byed cing / / byang chub theg par sbyor bar byed/ / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa ni/ / bsam zhing bstan par mi nus so/ / phyag na rdo rje dpa' bo ni/ / sngags rnams kun gyi bdag po'ang dran/ / bdag ma rig 'dzin lha mo ni/ / 'jig rten gsum gyis rab mchod dang / / lu gu rgyud dang 'og bag ma/ / rdo rje khu tshur snyan ldan ma/ / khro dbang thig le dkar mo dang / / dbyug sngon 'jigs par byed dang bcas/ / 'di dag khro mo pho nya'i tshogs/ / rigs ma'i spyan du rab tu bstan/ /

“Consequently, the bodhisattva conducts himself As [Tārā], the supreme ‘companion[2503] in awakening,’[2504] In thousands of world spheres, Too many to be counted. “Synchronically, the goddess [herself] sojourns widely, Bringing welfare to embodied beings In her form of a woman With the nature of the mantra. “At that time, she establishes beings who need guidance On the path to awakening, Manifesting the inconceivable Conduct of the bodhisattvas. “One should also keep in mind Vajrapāṇi, The valiant lord of mantras, And Māmakī who upholds her family‍— The goddess worshiped by the three worlds‍— “And also [the dūtīs] Śṛṅkhalā, Mekhalā, Vajramuṣṭī, and Yaśasvinī; [The krodhas] Krodhendra,[2505] Tilaka, and Śatru;[2506] [And the vidyārājas] Nīladaṇḍa and Bhairava.[2507] “These are the hosts of dūtīs, The krodhas, and those known as the overseers of vidyās.[2508]
rdo rje'i rigs la gtso bo ste/ / gang zhig dran na phan zhing srung / /
They are all the main deities of the Vajra family, And my sentinels.[2509]

byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / 'jig rten dag na spos glang dang / / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / blo ldan mthu chen thob dang ni/ / sras kyi thu bo gtso bo ni/ / kun tu bzang po dge ba ste/ / de tshe gang gis dran gyur pa/ / de la 'jigs pa yod ma yin/ / rtag tu de tshe nor bzang dang / / gnod sbyin dam pa dzam b+ha la/ / nyan thos rang rgyas ma lus pa/ / dran na 'jigs pa ga la yod/ / kun nas de dag mchod byas na/ / srung ba chen por rab tu bstan/ / de tshe 'bras bu che lha dang / / bsod nams skyes dang 'du shes med/ / gzugs med gzugs can lha dag dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / dkon mchog gsum la mchod byed dang / / rgyal ba'i bstan la rab dang ba/ /

“Also, if one remembers Gajagandha, The bodhisattva of great power in this world, Or Mahāsthānagata, the sagacious Bodhisattva of great power, “Or the greatest, the head of the sons, The beautiful Samantabhadra, At that time One will be free from fear. “Similarly, if one continually recollects Māṇibhadra, or the supreme yakṣa Jambhala, Or any śrāvaka, pratyekabuddha, or buddha,[2510] How could one be afraid? “It is stated that through recollecting[2511] Or worshiping them one obtains great protection. Great rewards will then be obtained, [Such as rebirth as] a god of Puṇyābha[2512] or Asaṃjñaka. “As for those who possess the female form,[2513] They should worship the majestic goddess free from passion, And also the Three Jewels, While trusting in the teachings of the Victorious One.[2514]
sngags dang dgra la rtag 'jigs pa/ / de dag la ni cung zad med/ / de ltar dam tshig rgyud gsungs pa/ / sngags pa kun gyis sgom min te/ /
“They will not be in any danger then From either friend or foe. The relevant samaya, it is said, Must never be violated by any mantra practitioner.[2515]
'di ni khro rgyal mchog ces pa/ / gshin rje gshed kyis brjod pa yin/ / sems can dam tshig la gnas na/ / mi ni ma lus gnod mi nus/ /
“It is taught in connection with the supreme krodha And praised [as the samaya] of Yamāntaka himself. If beings keep this samaya, No humans will be eaten.”[2516]

lha dang lha min thams cad da dag / de nas yid ni dga' gyur nas/ / rgyal ba'i sras kyis rab bskul nas/ / thams cad dam tshig bstan gnas gyur/ / gnod sbyin bdag po khro ldan pas/ / khyad du gsod tshig brjod par byed/ / 'jig rten khams ni grangs med pa/ / de tshe thams cad rab tu 'gul/ / don med khro bo'i rgyal po yis/ / ci yi phyir na 'di bstan byas/ / sems can rnams ni gdul don du/ / de tshe sngon gyi rgyal ba'i sras/ / khro bo'i rgyal po'i nus pa ni/ / sngon chad bstan pa ma yin nam/ /

After that, all the gods and Nonhuman beings[2517] were delighted. Realizing the bodhisattva mind,[2518] They were all established in the samaya. The yakṣa general[2519] was angry And expressed his contempt. Then, shaking all the innumerable World spheres, [he exclaimed,] “What is the use of this instruction? There is no need for Lord of Wrath; Up to now the sons of the victorious ones Guided sentient beings! “The power of Lord of Wrath Was dispensed with long ago!”[2520]

rdo rje can gyis de smras nas/ / rdo rje sa la dor zhing gnas/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po byis pa'i gzugs/ / blo dang ldan pa 'jam pa'i dbyangs/ / gzhon nu rab tu bzhad gyur nas/ / tshig 'di dag ni smras pa ste/ / lag na rdo rje rdzu 'phrul che/ / gnod sbyin chen po sdang ma byed/ / khro bo'i rgyal po rdzu 'phrul che/ / 'di ni nga yis rab tu bstan/ / de bzhin rjes su sbyin par bya/ / ji ltar 'dod bzhin rab tu ston/ / khyod kyis khro bo'i mthu dag ni/ / yongs su bstan par mi nus te/ /

Having said this, the vajra holder Threw his vajra scepter down and waited. Mañjughoṣa, the divine youth In the form of a male child, Powerful and intelligent, Laughed and gave this reply: “Do not be upset, O great yakṣa, Powerful Vajrapāṇi! Although the [deity] taught by me Is Lord of Wrath of great power, “It is your own mantra that I am going to reveal.[2521] You may disseminate it as you like, [But] it is not possible for you to proclaim The power of [Lord of] Wrath.[2522]
'di ni khyod nyid la gnas te/ / lus 'dir gnas shing snang ba yin/ / de nyid khyod kyis drangs pa ste/ / khyod nyid kyi ni snying la dris/ /
“If you ask why, it is because He is identical with you And is seen present here in [your own] body, Summoned there for you as your heart essence.[2523]
khro bo'i mthu ni khugs pa dag / 'dir ni bzlog par nus pa min/ / ji ltar 'dod bzhin khyod la bstan/ / gzhan du dam tshig btang ba yin/ /
“With Lord of Wrath immerged in you, It is not possible to reverse it at this stage. Once you have departed, permitted to do so, You may teach your own samaya the way you like.[2524]

khrus med rab tu nyal ba dang / / grong gi chos la rjes 'jug dang / / til mar gyis byugs srung med dang / / rtag tu gdug pa'i sems ldan dang / / sngags mchog thams cad spangs pa dang / / bstan pa la ni ma zhugs dang / / de bzhin mi ni the tshom ldan/ / dad pa med cing 'gyod par gnas/ / dam chos the tshom thob pa dang / / de spong mnyam par ma bzhag dang / / gcer bu rtag par lhag mar ldan/ / mi gtsang spyod pa'i spyod yul dang / / mi brtson sngags dang mi ldan dang / / rtag tu brtse med lhag mar ldan/ / lha yi gnas dang mchod rten dang / / lha gang 'khor sa dkyil 'khor du/ / 'khrig pa la ni mngon dga' ba/ / khro bos de dag rnam par 'jig / dam tshig nyams dang dad med dang / / sngags kyi rigs pa mi shes dang / / cung zad shes pa 'khrul pa dang / / spyod pa 'khrul pa de dag la/ / khro bos rnam par 'jig par byed/ / mi yi 'jig rten rnam kun du/ / bag yod pa ni med pa dang / / bag med shin tu 'dod chags can/ / dam tshig nyams shing skyon ldan la/ / sngags rnams legs par sbyar ba yis/ / khro bo'i rgyal pos 'joms par byed/ /

“If one is unwashed, sleepy, Engaged in the dharma of commoners,[2525] Anointed with oil and not protected, And always having bad thoughts; “If one has given up all the excellent mantras, Has no faith in the teachings,[2526] And consequently harbors doubts, Is intolerant toward those without faith,[2527] “Rejects the jewel of the sacred Dharma, Repudiates the saṅgha, and is distracted,[2528] Naked, always unclean And limited to unclean pursuits, “Not discreet,[2529] not practicing the mantra, Always impure, and devoid of compassion; If one has a penchant for having sex In the vicinity of temples and caityas “Or in the courtyard of a monastery, [Lord of] Wrath will destroy one. Those who have broken their samaya, have no faith, Do not know how to use the mantras,[2530] “Or stumble in their conduct somewhat‍— [Lord of] Wrath will bring their ruin. It is not possible to find in this human world Anyone that is not careless. “Women intoxicated with passion, Tarnished by breaking their samayas, Are killed by Lord of Wrath, Along with the negligent practitioners of mantra.[2531]

bag med rigs min 'gro ba yi/ / byis pa rnams kun thams cad dang / / rtag tu 'dod chags bral gyur pa'i/ / rang rgyal dgra bcom nyan thos kun/ / khro bo yi ni rgyal po yis/ / thams cad du ni 'ching dang gcod/ / de skad smras nas 'jam dpal ni/ / snying rje yi ni brlan sems kyis/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / rdzu 'phrul spyod pa bsam mi khyab/ / de skad smras nas de dag kun/ / cang mi smra bar gyur nas gnas/ / de nas dpal ldan rdo rje 'chang / / phyir yang rdo rje rab tu blangs/ / de tshe rdo rje blangs nas kyang / / khro rgyal mthu ni shes nas dga'/ /

“All immature beings everywhere Fall under the sway of others if they are careless. Except for the pratyekabuddhas, the arhats, and the śrāvakas Who have extinguished their passions forever, “All of them will be killed by Lord of Wrath And punished in every respect.” Being thus told by Mañjuśrī, with his mind filled with compassion, The beings [in the assembly exclaimed,] “Inconceivable are the acts of the buddhas And the bodhisattvas of great power!”[2532] Having said this, They all remained silent. The glorious Vajradhara[2533] then Took up his vajra scepter once again. Holding it, he rejoiced. Permitted [to do so], he spoke again.[2534]

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ gshin rje gshed kyi yongs su bsngags pa dang sngags kyi bdag nyid chen po'i nges par sdom pa'i le'u rab 'byam las sum cu rtsa gsum pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter describing Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka, the greatness of his mantra and the attendant rules, fiftieth[2535] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.

Chapter 51

de nas gsang ba'i bdag po lag na rdo rjes thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po la bltas te/ gnas gtsang ma'i steng na 'dug par gyur pa'i tshogs de dag la smras pa/ dang po re zhig grogs po khyed cag khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed kyi stobs dang pha rol gnon pa dpag tu med pa/ gdul dka' 'dul bar byed pa/ gshin rje'i 'tsho ba mthar byed pa/ sems can ma rungs pa tshar gcod pa de gtsor byed pa byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis smras pa/ de'i ras ris kyi cho ga yod de de nyon cig /

At that time Vajrapāṇi, the lord of guhyakas, looked at the entire great assembly and addressed all the hosts of beings seated [in the space] above the realm of the Pure Abode: “Listen, honorable friends! For a start I will teach the painting procedure of Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka‍—one of infinite power and courage, the tamer of those difficult to tame, one who terminates the life of Vaivasvata,[2536] a great bodhisattva devoted to restraining wicked beings‍—the procedure that was taught by Mañjuśrī.[2537]
tshes grangs dang ni rgyu skar dang / / smyung ba dag kyang mi bya ste/ /
“There are no restrictions regarding The lunar day, the asterism, or fasting injunctions.[2538]

dgra yi 'jigs pa byung ba na/ / ras ris 'di ni bri bar bya/ / mar ngo'i zla phyed dag gnas te/ / tshes grangs bcu bzhi'am brgyad dag la/ / bram ze dam pa mchog dag gi/ / dur khrod shi ba'i ro rnyed na/ /

One should commission this painting Whenever one is afraid of enemies. “One should obtain, on the fourteenth Or the eighth day of the dark fortnight, At night, in a charnel ground, A clothing item from a dead brahmin.[2539]

de ni mtshan mo mun par blangs/ / de yi khrag gis tshon rtsi bya/ / ras ni chu yis lan gsum bkru/ / de nas de ni bskam par bya/ / 'dri byed gdug sems khro ldan zhing / / 'jigs par byed pas bri bar bya/ / mar ngo'i zla phyed dur khrod du/ / zhag ni gsum mam bdun du bri/ /

“One should take it at night, Dye it red with blood, Wash it in water again and again,[2540] And then dry it thoroughly. “One should commission a cruel and angry painter To paint in a manner that is terrifying, In a charnel ground, during the dark fortnight, And have it completed within three nights.[2541]

tshes brgyad bcu bzhi'i nub mor ni/ / zhag chen mar me sbar ba la/ / der gnas ri mo byed pa ni/ / rtag tu g.yas kyi phyogs su blta/ / mi yi thod pas gdan byas shing / / mnyam par bzhag ste bsrung ba bya/ / dgra yi sdug bsngal gyis nyen na/ / yang na sngags pa rang gis bri/ / dang po'i mtshan mor rtsom pa na/ / dgra rnams lus la tsha ba 'byung / /

“On the night of the eighth or the fourteenth lunar day, By the light of a lamp fed by human fat, The painter should stay put right there, Always facing the south. “He should be sitting on a human skull, Have the protection ritual performed, and be focused. Alternatively, the mantra practitioner can do the painting himself, If he is tormented by the fear and suffering caused by enemies. “In the course of the first night, The enemies will be seized with great fear.[2542]

gnyis par tsha ba chen po yis/ / dgra rnams brgyal bas gnod par 'gyur/ / gsum pa'i mtshan mor srog 'dor zhing / / 'jig rten pha rol 'gro bar 'gyur/ / sngags pa rab tu ma dang na/ / de la zhi ba ga la yod/ /

On the second night, they will be, in addition, Seized by a great fever and fall into a swoon. “On the third night, they will breathe their last And proceed to the next world. How could they ever experience peace When the mantra practitioner is displeased?

dgra yi lus ni bskam 'gyur zhing / / khyim la 'jigs pa'ang 'byung bar 'gyur/ / gshin rje gshed ni 'jigs chen gyi/ / ras ris 'di ni bris tsam gyis/ / zhal drug zhabs drug phyag drug bri/ / kha dog sngo zhing gsus pa 'phyang / / khro ldan thod pa'i phreng ba 'chang / / stag gi pags pa rab tu mnabs/ / mtshon cha sna tshogs mi bzad ldan/ / lag na dbyug to 'jigs par byed/ / spyan ni dmar zhing khro dang bcas/ / spyan gsum dag gis rnam par mtshan/ /

“The enemies’ bodies will wither And their houses fall into ruin As the result of drawing a picture Of the terrifying Yamāntaka in this way: “He should be drawn with six faces and six feet,[2543] Black[2544] in color, with a ‘wolf’s belly,’[2545] Wearing a garland of skulls, angry, Wearing a tiger skin, “Terrifying with his various weapons, With a staff in his hand, inspiring fear, With eyes red with rage, And distinguished by his three eyes.

skra 'bar gyen du brdzes pa ni/ / de bzhin la lar du ba'i mdog / mig sman nag po mi bzad dang / / dbyar gyi sprin nag 'dra ba'i mdog / gshin rje'i gzugs dang 'dra ba yi/ / ma he la zhon yang dag bri/ / gdug pa'i las can 'jigs pa che/ / drag cing drag po 'joms byed pa/ / sems can 'jigs par byed pa yi/ / gshin rje'i 'tsho ba 'jigs byed brjod/ / shin tu gdug pa'i las can dang / / 'jigs shing shin tu mi bzad pa/ / lus can thams cad gsod byed pa/ / 'jigs pa'ang 'jigs shing dngangs byed pa/ / bdag gi khrag gi tshon dag gis/ / khro bo mchog 'di bri bar bya/ / zhag chen po yi zhag dang ni/ / shin tu dmar ba'i tshon bsres bri/ / mtshon rtsi'i snod du thod pa bya/ / mi yi rus pas pir shing bya/ / shi ba'i skra las byas pa yis/ / pir dang pir ni bcing ba'ang bya/ /

“His blazing hair flows upward, With smoke-colored strands here and there. He is black as collyrium, terrifying, And dark as a monsoon cloud. “One should draw him mounted on a buffalo And resembling, in form, the god of death, Vicious in his actions, extremely terrifying, And a fierce and vehement killer. “He terminates the life of Yama And is ready to kill living beings. Exceedingly cruel in his actions, He is most terrible and terrifying. “This bringer of death to all embodied beings Strikes fear and panic into fear itself.[2546] One should draw the supremely wrathful one Using paints made from one’s own blood. “The paints should be of bright and varied [colors], Mixed with human fat and cow products. They should be in containers made of skulls, Secured with [pieces of] human bone.[2547] “One should use brushes Skillfully made from the hair of a corpse.[2548]

rang ngam ri mo mkhan gyis kyang / / de nas zas mi bza' bar bri/ / gtor ma me tog mang po sogs/ / phreng ba dmar dang tsan+dan dmar/ / sha chen tshil gyi spos dang ni/ / zhag gi spos kyis mchod par bya/ / ras ris dam pa de la ni/ / dang po bar mthar mchod par bya/ / ras ris yongs su rdzogs byas na/ / ri mo mkhan la sbyin pa'ang bya/ / nor ni rab tu mang po'am/ / yang na gang gi dge ba'ang sbyin/ / las kyang 'jigs pa chen po bas/ / de yi don med mi bya'o/ /

Whether the painting is done by oneself or a painter, It must be executed while fasting. “One should [thus] make the best of paintings, Offering worship at the beginning, halfway through, and at the end [of the work], [Which should consists of] copious bali offerings of flowers and so forth, Red chaplets, and prime quality sandalwood. One should burn incense of human flesh and fat And adorn [the working place] with lamps [fed] with [human] fat. “When the painting is finished, One should pay the artist‍— Always a big amount, Or whatever he will be happy with. Since his Dharma work is fraught with great danger, It should be made worthwhile for him.[2549]

mdor na dpa' bo'i rin du ni/ / ji ltar 'dod pa de la bya/ / bzo yi las ni 'bras bcas bya/ / kha zas med pa'ang rnam par spang / / ji ltar de ni yang dag dga'/ / de lta de ltar rab tu sbyar/ / srung ba chen po'ang rab tu bya/ / gzhan du de ni 'chi 'gyur zhing / / bzo bo bza' dang bcas 'jigs pas/ / bdag gis kyang ni mngon par bsrung / / rigs pa bzlas nas bya ba ste/ / gzhan du cho gar brjod pa min/ / ras ris yongs su gsal byas pa'am/ / yid la 'dod pa byas mthong na/ / gdug pa'i dgra rnams 'joms byed pa'i/ / las ni thams cad byed par 'gyur/ / ras ris mchog blangs 'gro ba ni/ / ji ltar 'dod pa'am gar 'dod pa'o/ /

“In short, one should pay a generous amount, Whatever the craftsman may desire. As the artist’s work will produce results, One should avoid underpayment. “He should be employed on terms That he finds wholly satisfactory. A protection ritual must also be performed, Otherwise he will die. “[As] the artisan would perish with his household, He too must protect himself. He must do the work after reciting the vidyā, And the procedure should not be disclosed to others. “Once the painting is fully completed And one sees that it is as had been envisaged, One can perform all the cruel rites That destroy one’s enemies. “Taking this best of paintings, One should go to a place of one’s liking.

phyogs chen rgyal po chen po dang / / sems can de ni dregs bcas dang / / mngon pa'i nga rgyal nga rgyal che/ / gdug dang gdug pa'i las rnams dang / / dkon mchog gsum la gnod byed dang / / chad par smra dang sngags spangs dang / / sngags rnams mchod par mi byed dang / / de la dad rten smod pa dang / / gang yang zlos pa smod byed dang / / de bzhin mchod rten khyad du gsod/ / cho ga mthong ba'i las kyis ni/ / de dag la ni sbyor ba bya/ / sems can kun dang skyob pa la/ / rtag tu de bzhin chos mi ldan/ / de dag la ni las rab sbyar/ / 'phral du srog ni 'gag par byed/ / lung tang 'bras bu sngags bzlas blangs/ / rtsa ba dang ni shun pa'ang blang / / 'bras bu'i rang skyur yang dag ldan/ / mi yi rus phye legs btags dang / / yungs mar dang ni dug nyid dang / / star bu dad ni lang tang tshe/ / ske tshe dang yang khrag nyid kyang / / mi las yang dag byung ba dag / thams cad blangs nas yang dag ldan/ / ras ris dben pa'i phyogs su bzhag / sgrub po lho phyogs mngon bltas nas/ / ras ris kyang ni byang du bstan/ / me thab ji 'dod byas nas ni/ / tsha zhing skam pa'i shing dag gis/ / me thab de la mnyam bzhag nas/ / dur khrod me yi sbar bar bya/ / thams cad ldan pas bsreg byas na/ / cho gar bstan pa'i sbyin sreg yin/ /

[One can target with the ritual] kings backed by powerful vassals, Or those who are arrogant on account of their great wealth, “Proud in the extreme, Cruel and given to cruel pursuits, Or committing offenses against the Three Jewels. Also, the nihilists who reject the mantras, Those who do not worship the mantra [deities], Or those who censure the devotees who take refuge in these [deities]. “Particularly humiliated will be those Who insult mantra reciters.[2550] One can target them, Following the prescribed procedure. “The rite that instantly arrests the life force Can likewise be employed Against those who always act contrarily to the Dharma And oppress[2551] each and every living creature. “One should obtain the fruit,[2552] Leaves,[2553] bark, and root of soapberry[2554] And combine them with kāñjika,[2555] tamarind,[2556] And powdered human bone. “[One should add] white mustard oil, some poison, Vinegar, fresh ginger, and brown mustard And blend [everything] with blood Of human origin. “One should take this entire preparation, Set up the painting in a secluded place, And position oneself to face south, With the painting facing north. “One should prepare the fire pit as one likes And make it blaze using bundles of straw And dry sticks that produce acrid [smoke].[2557] Fully focused, one should offer The entire preparation into the fire pit Following the procedure prescribed for homa.[2558]

khro bo'i rgyal po'i sngags kyis ni/ / me lha dag ni spyan drang bya/ / las rnams dag ni kun la'ang 'dir/ / mdung gi phyag rgya bcing bar bya/ / me thab la ni khror bcas pas/ / rtsa brgyad stong gis sreg blugs sbyin/ / dang por bu dag 'chi ba ni/ / sems can zhugs nas de bzhin 'gyur/ / gnyis pa la ni chung ma dang / / 'khor dang gtso bor bcas pa'ang yin/ / de la gsum par 'chi ba ni/ / gang gi ched du de byas pa'o/ / gang tshe mtshan phyed bzlas pa ni/ / ras ris mdun du byed pa yang / / dgra rnams gsad par bya phyir te/ / de ni de dang mthun par 'gyur/ / de yi yul 'khor 'jig par 'gyur/ / dpung yang 'chi bar 'gyur ba ste/ / mes tshig rlung ni chen po dang / / char chen dag kyang 'byung bar 'gyur/ / thams cad bsdus pa'i tshogs dag ni/ / pha rol tshogs kyis gnod par 'gyur/ / de la gnod pa sna tshogs dang / / nad chen dag gis yang dag khyab/ /

“One should summon the [god of] fire[2559] With the mantra of Lord of Wrath. For all the rites of this ritual, One should display the spear mudrā. “One should angrily offer into the fire pit One thousand and eight oblations. At the first junction [of the night], The [target’s] son will die;[2560] “At the second junction, the [target’s] wife Along with his retinue and the senior staff; And at the third, the person Against whom the rite was performed. “If one recites at midnight, Close to the painting, With the intention to kill one’s enemies, This will happen just so. “The [target’s] kingdom will be ruined‍— A plague will arise in his army, And there will be wildfires, hurricanes, Heavy rains, and floods. “The [target’s] entire army will be Completely destroyed by another army. Various misfortunes will befall him, And he will be stricken with great illness.

rgyal po de yi lus kun kyang / / skam par 'di la the tshom med/ / de yi khyim ni thams cad kyang / / mi ma yin pas yang dag dkrugs/ / mal du brtan pa mi rnyed cing / / sa yi steng du'ang 'khor bar 'gyur/ / srin po yi dgas sha rjen zas/ / de yi khyim ni yongs su bskor/ / thams cad du ni nyam thag 'jigs/ / sdug bsngal drag pos sdug bsngal 'gyur/ / sa steng lha yi dbang phyug sogs/ / de yi srung ba byed mi nus/ / 'jig rten skyong ba tshangs sogs dang / / brgya byin sogs pa sum cu'i dbang / / sngags kun lha dang bcas pa dang / / 'jig rten kun las byung ba'ang rung / /

“The entire body of that king Will wither, there is no doubt about this, And his whole household will be haunted And troubled by nonhuman beings. “He will find no rest in bed And will pace in circles on the ground. His house will be overrun By rākṣasas, pretas, and kravyādas. “He will always be troubled and afraid And tormented by acute suffering. Maheśvara and other earthly deities Will not be able to protect him, “Nor will the world protectors‍—Brahmā and so forth; Or the thirty-three gods‍—Śakra and so forth; Or any mantras or deities In the whole world.

nga rgyal gyis 'khrugs ma rungs dgra/ / de yi 'tsho ba de mthar byed/ / mtshan phyed nyi ma gung dag la/ / gang du khros nas zlos byed pa/ / gshin rje khros pa mngon sum ltar/ / bsrung bar yang ni rung ma yin/ / mar ngo'i zla phyed ci 'dod par/ / sa steng ras ris bzhag nas ni/ / gtor ma mchod pa che bya ba/ / dur khrod dgon pa'i gnas dang ni/ / shing gcig de bzhin rtags dang ni/ / brag dang bas mtha' phug kyang rung / / gcig pu gnyis su med par yang / / rtag tu las rnams yang dag brtsams/ / dgon pa chen po dben pa dang / / lha yi khang pa stong pa dang / / khang stong dang ni chu bo dang / / rgya mtsho'i 'gram la brten pa dang / / grong khyer de dang nye ba dang / / der gnas yang na ci 'dod par/ / dpag tshad brgya yi tshad tsam nas/ / rtag tu las rnams bya ba yin/ /

“The life of a person who is evil, cruel, and haughty Will be brought to an end. If the mantra is recited[2561] At midnight or at midday, The angry Vaivasvata will appear As Yamarāja before [such a person]. “During the dark fortnight, whenever convenient, One should prop up the painting on the ground And perform a big pūjā along with bali offerings. This should be in a charnel ground, in a forest, “By a solitary tree or a śivaliṅga, On top of a mountain, or in a cave. One should always perform [this rite] Alone, without a companion, “While staying in a lonely place in a great forest, A vacant temple or shrine, At a river, Or on the shore of an ocean. “One should always do the ritual Staying in or near such places,[2562] Or anywhere one wants within the radius Of one hundred leagues [from the target].
“One should always perform these rites Following the rules and staying pure.[2563]

gtsang ba'i yul ni brgya dag dang / / tshad med yul du gnas pa'ang rung / / sngags kyi rdzu 'phrul bsam mi khyab/ / zlos pa'i grub pa bsam mi khyab/ / las ni bsam mi khyab par snang / / 'bras bu'ang bsam gyis mi khyab pa'o/ / gshin rje gshed ni bdag nyid che/ / khro bo'i rgyal po bsam mi khyab/ / las dang rdzu 'phrul yul dang ni/ / rnam par 'phrul ba che 'byung ba/ / bsam gyis mi khyab zlos pa yis/ / sa steng 'di la grub pa snang / / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / kun gyis bsrung bar yong mi nus/ / 'jig rten pa yi sngags rnams dang / / gza' dang ma mo smos ci dgos/ / dbang ldan dang ni khyab 'jug gam/ / skem byed dang ni brgya byin dang / / rgyal dang rgyal ba'i sras dag ni/ / dam tshig 'dzin par byed pa dang / / sa bcu la ni yang dag gnas/ / byang chub sems dpa' bdag nyid che/ / gang zhig dgra bcom rang rgyal dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po chags bral ba/ / dam tshig sngon byas de dag gis/ / bsrung bar yang ni mi nus so/ / mdor bsdus nas ni bshad par bya/ / 'byor pa 'dod pas mnyan par gyis/ / zlos pa sems ni ma dang na/ / gzhan gyis nus par mi 'gyur ro/ /

There are countless locations where one may stay And infinite number[2564] of pure places. “Within the inconceivable domain of mantras, The range of mantra [activity] is inconceivable.[2565] The power of mantras is inconceivable, The accomplishment of reciters is inconceivable, The activity appears to be inconceivable, And the result is also inconceivable. “Inconceivable is the activity Of Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka, the great being. Inconceivable, too, is the range of his power And his great display of miracles. Inconceivable is the accomplishment of reciters Of his mantra observed here on earth. “All the bodhisattvas, with their great powers, Would not be able to protect the target; How then would worldly mantra deities, Along with the grahas and mātṛs, protect him? “Neither Īśāna nor Viṣṇu; Nor Skanda or Purandara; Nor those who are bound by samaya, Including the victorious ones and their sons; “Nor the eminent bodhisattvas Who abide on the ten levels; Nor the pratyekabuddhas and arhats, Free from passion and possessed of great powers Would be able to protect [the target], Even though they formerly took the samaya. “I will briefly explain. Listen, those of you who desire prosperity! When the reciter is not pleased, No being can escape him;[2566]

sngags pa mchog ni mi dga' na/ / de 'dir zhi ba ga la yod/ / bdag nyid chen po gshin rje gshed/ / khro bo'i rgyal po zlos pa po/ / gang tshe yid ni dang ba dang / / gang tshe snying rje brlan gyur pa/ / de tshe de ni zhi thob pa'am/ / brtan pa'am 'tsho ba 'dzin par 'gyur/ / pirtsu marda yungs mar dang / / rang skyur dug dang ldan pa ni/ / khrag dang mi yi sha dang ni/ / lan tshwa tsha ba gsum dang ni/ / ske tshe dug gi phye ma dang / / star bu dang ni sram gyi sha/ / lang tang tse yi rtsa ba dang / / de bzhin ko sha ta ka'i dang / / e ren da rtsa nas tshig thal/ / le brgan rtsi dang gze ma dang / / po son cha yi rtsa ba dang / / de bzhin sgog skya ke'u dang / / gzhan gyi zhag dang chu dang ni/ / kun dong chang ni btung bar bcas/ /

How could such a being find peace, If the reciter of this supreme mantra is not happy? “If, on the other hand, the reciter Of the great Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka Is kindly disposed in his mind Or tender with compassion, Then such being will obtain peace and stability And will remain alive. “[One should combine] neem,[2567] White mustard, kāñjika, the five poisons,[2568] Human blood, flesh,[2569] Salt, the three pungent substances,[2570] “Brown mustard, powdered conch,[2571] Vinegar,[2572] fresh ginger,[2573] The root of devil’s trumpet,[2574] The root of ribbed gourd,[2575] “The root of the castor-oil plant, barley potash, Safflower, devil’s thorn,[2576] The root of madana,[2577] Garlic, gṛñjanaka,[2578] “Dhak tree,[2579] śākhoṭaka[2580] tree, Onion, and grain beer.[2581]

'di kun cha mnyam byas nas ni/ / ras ris nye bar sbyin sreg bya/ / sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad byas na/ / zla ba phyed kyi nang du ni/ / bu dang gnyen sdug bcas pa yi/ / dgra rnams rtsad nas 'jig 'gyur te/ / 'khor kun ma lus 'joms par byed/ / gnyis pa'i nang du sbyin sreg byas/ / de yi rtsad nas 'byin par byed/ / zlos pas me nang sbyin sreg byas/ / gsum pa'i dus su phyin pa na/ / de yi grong rdal bcas de la/ / mu ge dag ni 'byung ba dang / / char mi 'bab cing 'chi ba mang / / srin pos kun tu khyab pa dang / / mes tshig rdo yi char 'bab dang / / rdo rje dang ni thog kyang 'bab/ / ljongs dang phyogs dang yul dang ni/ / ji snyed rgyal po de la yod/ / 'tshe ba mang po rab 'byung zhing / / de bzhin gzhan gyi dmag tshogs 'byung / / de yi yul du 'tshe ba ni/ / du ma mang po dag kyang 'byung / / dpal min mang po rab ston pa/ / rnam pa sna tshogs 'byung bar 'gyur/ /

Having blended all these [ingredients], one should offer [The mixture] into the fire, near to the painting. “When one has offered one thousand and eight homas,[2582] The enemies will be destroyed, root and branch‍— One will destroy all of them Along with their sons, daughters, and retinues. “If one performs the homa at the second junction,[2583] They will be completely uprooted. If the reciter performs the homa When the third junction has arrived, “A famine will strike the target[2584] And his townsfolk. There will be droughts and many deaths, With rākṣasas pullulating everywhere. “There will be wildfires, hailstorms, Thunder, and lightning In the countries and domains Of such a king. “Many disasters will occur, Including an invasion by a foreign army. There will be many misfortunes In his country‍— They will manifest in various ways, As the goddess of fortune departs.[2585]
