lad tang rtsa bas sbyin sreg byas/ / de la rims nad 'byung bar 'gyur/ / tsha bas rtag tu sbyin sreg byas/ / tsha ba chen po skye bar 'gyur/ / shin tu skyur bas sbyin sreg byas/ / grang ba'i rims ni yang dag 'byung / / ma rungs rgyal po stobs kyis dregs/ / de yi lus la de dag 'gyur/ / phyogs che nor dang ldan pa dang / / gdug cing dpung chen yang dag ga gnas/ / de yi 'tsho ba tha ma ni/ / nub gnyis yang na bdun gyis so/ / gang zhig gang la dad lha'am/ / skyes pa'i skar ma ming yang rung / / ras ris mdun du gzugs bya ba/ / dur khrod sol bas bris pa la/ / mgo la rdog pas mnan nas ni/ / khro bas bzlas pa brtsam par bya/ / glo bur rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i/ / mi yi bdag po zug gzer 'byung / / nad chen pos ni thebs 'gyur te/ / de yi mod la'ang 'chi bar 'gyur/ / yang na dgra stas gcod pa'am/ / yan lag kyang ni mi tshang 'gyur/ / sdig can mi ma yin pa yi/ / srin po gdug pas za bar 'gyur/ / bdag gi 'khor dang bcas pa dag / sha rjen za dang srul po dang / / sha za yi dgas ma mo yis/ / de yi mod la'ang gsod par byed/ / de nas dpal ldan rdo rje 'chang / / de tshe 'khor la 'di skad smras/ / sangs rgyas kun la phyag 'tshal nas/ / de nas cang mi smra bar gnas/ / 'jig rten rnams la phan 'dod phyir/ / 'di skad du ni yang smras pa/ / gnod sbyin mo ni thams cad dang / / gnod sbyin kun tshogs bos nas ni/ / de tshe gnod sbyin bdag po ste/ / byang chub sems dpa' smras pa ni/ / gnod sbyin rnams kyis ras ris smras/ / 'dod pa kun dang nye bar ldan/ / 'gugs par byed dang dbang byed kun/ / zug rngu ma lus yang dag 'byin/ /

“If one offers as homa the root of devil’s trumpet, The target will lose his mind.[2586] If one offers kaṭuka[2587] as homa, The target will definitely be caught in a great fire. If one offers a citron[2588] into the fire, A great fever with chills will arise in the [target’s] body. “Whether he is a wicked king Intoxicated by his own might, Backed by powerful and cruel vassals And his own great army,[2589] He will die after two Or seven nights. “Whichever [king is targeted], one should write The name of his personal deity or his nakṣatra And draw his form on the ground in front of the painting Using charcoal from a cremation ground. Then, one should step upon the [king’s] head with one’s foot And recite the mantra angrily. “All of a sudden the king will be seized By various acute pains. Overcome by a terrible disease, He will die that very moment. “He also may be struck with an axe And, moreover, lose his limbs. He may be eaten by nonhuman beings Such as the cruel rākṣasas, kaśmalas, “Kravyādas, pūtanas, Piśācas, pretas, or mātṛs. He may suddenly be attacked by them, And even by his own servants.” The glorious Vajradhara,[2590] Having thus spoken to the assembly, Bowed to all the buddhas And then waited in silence. For the sake of those who want to benefit the world, He furthermore pronounced The mantra[2591] of all the hosts of yakṣas And yakṣiṇīs everywhere.[2592] Continuing with his talk, The bodhisattva, the general of the yakṣas, Then taught the section on the yakṣiṇīs[2593] That contains all the [relevant] rites: The summoning of anyone, the enthrallment, And the removing of all physical afflictions.[2594]
sngags pa gang tshe 'khrig pa 'dod/ / 'dod chags ldongs pa'am rmongs pa'i blos/ / bder gshegs bkas kyang bzlog pa dang / / gnyen pos kyang ni mi nus so/ /
When a mantra practitioner is looking for sex And is blinded by passion or otherwise confused in his mind, The Sugata’s prohibitive ordinances Cannot possibly stop him.[2595]

thog ma med pa'i 'khor ba nas/ / shin tu sdug bsngal rgyu sngon byas/ / de dag sdug bsngal sdug bsngal bar/ / snying rje chen pos 'gro ba gdungs/ / tshangs spyod dbang po dul bas ni/ / bde 'gro dag ni thob par 'gyur/ / bzang po shis par bstan pa dang / / mthar ni zhi ba'ang thob par 'gyur/ / theg pa gsum la brten nas ni/ / mya ngan 'das pa legs pa 'thob/ / bzlog pa blo ngan gyis zin pa/ / 'dod chags kyis ldongs bka' thub med/ / 'khor ba mi zad tshang tshing gi/ / 'gro ba lngar ni 'khor bar 'gyur/ / de dag sdug bsngal ldan don du/ / 'dod pa'i longs spyod rjod par byed/ / khro bo 'di ni mnyes byas na/ / sdig pa kun las ldog par 'gyur/ /

Such people have already experienced intense suffering In the cycle of births without beginning. The tathāgatas taught that their [future] rebirth Will take them from suffering to greater suffering.[2596] A celibate person who has tamed his senses Will obtain a pleasant rebirth, Which is said to be good and auspicious. Eventually, he will obtain peace. Riding[2597] the three vehicles with equanimity, He will obtain nirvāṇa. Those among the ascetics who, blinded by passion, Do the opposite under the sway of bad inclinations, Will wander in the terrible abyss of saṃsāra, Following the five destinies. It is for the sake of those who suffer [like this] That the sensual enjoyments will be described.[2598] They will then have all their negativity extinguished, Will turn away from the three faults, and, Following the injunctions of the Teacher, Will be released from all fetters.[2599]

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed kyi mngon spyod dang legs par sdom pa'i le'u rab 'byam las sum cu rtsa bzhi pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed second chapter with the precepts regarding the violent rites of Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka, fifty-first[2600] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.
gnod sbyin mo sgrub pa'i cho ga
Chapter 52

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po zhi ba'i blo gros zhes bya ba 'khor de nyid du 'dus shing 'dug par gyur pa de stan las langs te/ sangs rgyas thams cad la phyag 'tshal nas/ 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor gyi dbus su 'dug ste/ bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la la lan gsum bskor ba byas nas zhabs gnyis la btud de/ gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon chen po lag na rdo rje de la bltas nas tshig 'di smras so/ / phyag na rdo rje gang khyod sems can thams cad la gnod par byed pa dang / 'dod pa dang ldan pa'i sngags dang rgyud bshad na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi nges par chos 'di ni ma yin te/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po ni gang gi phyir snying rje chen pos rab tu phye zhing / byang chub sems dpa'i spyad pa spyod cing sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir/ phan pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa la rab tu zhugs na 'khor ba'i 'ching ba las grol bar 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras gzhan yang sems can la gnod par byed pa'i chos ston pa ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis ni sems can thams cad kyi ched du gsungs pa ma yin te/ snying rje chen po dang ldan pa'i phyir sems can thams cad la phan pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa la rab tu zhugs pa yin no/ /

At that time the great being, Bodhisattva Śāntamati, who was sitting in the midst of that great gathering, got up from his seat, bowed to each of the buddhas, and stood in the middle of the assembly. Having circumambulated the blessed Śākyamuni three times clockwise, he bowed at his feet and, looking in the direction of Vajrapāṇi, the great general of the yakṣa army, said: “You are exceedingly cruel,[2601] Vajrapāṇi, in that you teach mantra methods that are harmful to all sentient beings, or serve to obtain sensual pleasures. It is not proper, O son of the victorious ones, for the bodhisattvas, the great beings, to act like this because bodhisattvas, great beings, are endowed with great compassion and practice bodhisattva conduct. Practicing benevolence for the sake of all beings, they do not cast off the fetters of existence.[2602] “Moreover, O son of the victorious ones, the venerable tathāgatas, the fully realized buddhas, having all sentient beings in mind, do not[2603] give Dharma instructions on how to harm beings.[2604] Since they possess great compassion, they adopt the attitude of benevolence toward all beings.”

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po lag na rdo rjes byang chub sems dpa' zhi ba'i blo gros la smras pa/ ji ltar khyod smras pa dang ji ltar khyod rab tu ston pa de bzhin du zhi ba'i blo gros byang chub sems dpas bslab par bya/ de bzhin du bsgrub par bya/ ji ltar sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul chen po dang ldan pa de bzhin du bdag gis kyang bstan par bgyi'o/ / don dam par ni yang dag pa'i mtha' la yang dag par brten nas chos kyi mtha' las grol ba thob par 'gyur ro/ /

The great being Bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi replied to Bodhisattva Śāntamati, “Śāntamati! A bodhisattva should indeed train to be this way and should adopt such an attitude. What you now say and teach, all the buddhas and the bodhisattvas of great power teach. I will explain it, too, speaking from the perspective of the absolute truth. “The ultimate Dharma is taught While abiding in the ultimate reality.

sems can mtha' ni bsam mi khyab/ / rnam par smin pa'ang bsam mi khyab/ / sangs rgyas chos kyang bsam mi khyab/ / byang chub spyod pa'ang bsam mi khyab/ / gdul ba'i sems can la brten nas/ / phan pa'i spyod pa bsam mi khyab/ /

The limit of beings cannot be conceived of, Nor can the methods for ripening them. “The teachings of the buddhas are inconceivable, And so is the conduct of awakening. When it comes to beings who require guidance, A bodhisattva’s mode of acting is inconceivable.
byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa rnams/ / bsam mi khyab par yongs su bstan/ / rgyud rnams kun la rgyud 'di yi/ / mthu ni bsam gyis mi khyab yin/ /
“The conduct of the bodhisattvas Is proclaimed as inconceivable. Among all of the mantras, The power of this mantra-method is inconceivable.[2605]
gshin rje gshed ni bdag nyid che/ / khro bo'i rgyal po'i sngags dag dang / / yul gsum dag kyang bsam mi khyab/ / rtogs pa'i bdag nyid bsam mi khyab/ /
“The extent of the miraculous power of the mantra[2606] Of Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka, the great being, Is inconceivable, and so is the greatness Of mastering it.

zhi ba'i blo gros byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po'i spyod pa ni bsam gyis mi khyab ste/ chos kyi dbyings kyi rgyu mthun pa las byung ba'i sgrub pa yang bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhi ba'i blo gros byang chub sems dpa' sngags zlos pa na 'di ltar sems bskyed par bya ste/ 'phags pa ma yin pa'i sems can 'dod pa la lhag par chags pas bsod nams ma yin pa shin tu rab tu mang por 'phel bas dmyal ba chen por skye zhing sems can 'di dag ni bsod nams kyi phung po shin tu mang po 'di 'phel bar mi 'gyur ro/ / sems can 'di dag byang chub rnam pa gsum gyi skal ba med par mi 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir/ zhi ba'i bla gros de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' sngags zlos pas sems nye bar gzhag par bya zhing thabs mkhas pa 'di la mngon spyod kyi las rab tu sbyar bar bya'o/ / las thams cad la yang mtshan mar 'dzin par mi bya'o/ / mi dge bar 'dzin par mi bya zhing snying rjes brlan pa'i sems kyis sems can gdul ba'i thabs la yang bslab par bya'o/ /

“Śāntamati, the conduct of the bodhisattvas, the great beings, which manifests throughout the entire domain of sentient beings, is inconceivable. Accordingly, Śāntamati, a bodhisattva who recites the mantra should think, ‘Supposing the aims of the target [were fulfilled], he would accumulate a lot of negativity and would fall into one of the great hells. But this being should not make his store of negativity even greater. May he never be separated from the three realizations.’[2607] “Only after forming this wish, Śāntamati, can a bodhisattva who recites the mantra perform a violent rite of assault, applying the skillful means. In all [such] rites, he must be aware of his motive and avoid any unwholesome motives. When undertaking to guide beings, he must strive to do this with a mind full of compassion.

kye rgyal ba'i sras gzhan yang chos dang chos ma yin pa dang / dkar po dang / nag po dang / dge ba dang / mi dge ba dang / 'gro ba'i bdag nyid chen po sems can 'dul ba'i thabs sgrub pa dang / chos kyi dbyings sgrub pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis rab tu rtogs par 'gyur te/ de nyid chos ston pas sems can smin pa'i thabs kyang rab tu sgrub par byed do/ /

“Moreover, son of the victors, because of the greatness of their comprehension of Dharma and non-Dharma, virtue and nonvirtue, and good and bad, the blessed buddhas mastered the ability to skillfully guide beings. They have attained the realization of the sphere of phenomena, and all of them without exception bring beings to maturity by the skillful means of Dharma instructions.[2608]

kye rgyal ba'i sras de bzhin du bdag cag gis bslab par bya zhing / 'di lta ste/ sems can gdul ba dang sems can smin pa dang bstan par bya ba'i phyir dang de la rgyal ba'i sras khyed cag gang 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor 'dir dam tshig chen po la zhugs pa de thams cad kyis mnyan par bya/ dad par bya de nyid dge ba dang mi dge ba tshol ba nyid du bya ste/ 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa chos ston pa la mngon par dga' bar bya'o/ /

“We should strive, son of the victors, to be the same [as them], so that we can guide, mature, and instruct beings. Therefore, venerable sons of the victors, each and all of you present in this assembly, who have taken the great samaya, should study and develop trust, seeking to establish what is skillful and what is not, so that you can take joy in teaching the Dharma of the tathāgatas.”[2609]

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po zhi ba'i blo gros kyis gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon chen po lag na rdo rje la rnam par bltas nas cang mi smra bar gyur te/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams ni bsam gyis mi khyab bo zhes yid la byas nas/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la rnam par lta bzhin du rang gi stan la 'dug par gyur to/ / de nas gsang ba pa'i bdag po phyag na rdo rjes thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor de la rnam par bltas nas khro bo'i rgyal po'i cho ga yang smras pa/ gang dag lha'i tshogs dang sems can gyi khams la brten pa'i 'byung po'i tshogs khyed cag nyon cig / dang por re zhig bsrung ba byas la khro bo'i rgyal po'i ras ris de yongs su blangs la/ gnas dben par song nas dbang phyug chen po'i rtags gcig pa'i gnas su rtags de la dug dang khrag dang ske tshe dang / rang skyur gyis gtor la shing bi tsu mar da'i me tog gis mchod cing mi'i rgyu ma rlon pa dag gis bdag nyid la mchod phyir thogs byas la/ mi'i mgo bo'i thod pa g.yas pa'i lag pa na thogs pas brdegs pa lta bur byas la/ lag pa g.yon pa'i sdigs mdzub kyis mtshon gcig po la sdigs pa bzhin du byed cing gtsor khro ba'i dbang du gyur pa dang rgyal po ma rungs pas brnyas pa chen po'i sems kyis byas pa'am/ gzhan skyon can gyi skyes bu phyogs chen po dang ldan pa dang nor chen po dang ldan pa dang rab tu gtum pa chen po dang gtso bo chen po dag gis khyad du gsod par 'gyur na/ sgo bcad pa byas la/ gcer bur byas shing skra bshig pas dbang phyug chen po'i mtshan la khro bo'i sngags ji srid dbang phyug chen po'i mtshan dkyil du gas par gyur pa de srid du bzlas pa bya'o/ /

Bodhisattva Śāntamati, the great being, looked at the yakṣa general Vajrapāṇi in silence and remained in his seat. Looking then at Lord Buddha, he thought, “The Buddha’s teachings are inconceivable.” Vajrapāṇi, the master of guhyakas, directing his gaze at the entire assembly, continued to teach the ritual of Lord of Wrath: “Listen, respectable hosts of gods and all the hordes of bhūtas who dwell in the inhabited worlds! “To start, one should perform the protection ritual, take the painting of Lord of Wrath, and go to a secluded place where there is a single śivaliṅga, the abode of Maheśvara. One should anoint this liṅga with poison, blood, brown mustard oil, and kāñjika, and worship it with the petals of neem tree [flowers]. One should put on a sacred thread made of human entrails of tubular shape,[2610] take a human skull with the right hand, and make a gesture as if delivering a blow. Filled with utmost wrath, one should threaten the liṅga with the index finger of the left hand, while focusing the mind on humiliating the haughty and wicked kings or other corrupt men with powerful acquaintances,[2611] very wealthy, very fierce, and very influential.[2612] One should then shut the door [of the temple] and stand naked with loose hair, with one’s left foot atop the Maheśvara liṅga.[2613] One should recite the mantra of Lord [of Wrath] until the liṅga splits open.

dum bu gnyis su gyur na yi ge hU~M gi sgra chen po yang thos par 'gyur te de la 'jigs par yang mi bya'o/ / de thos pa'i dbang gis rgyal po ma rungs pa'am gzhan gang la la dpung chen po dang ldan pa'i dgra de'i mod la rims chen pos zin par 'gyur ba'am/ srin po la sogs pa mi ma yin pas zin par 'gyur ro/ / de nyid du ji srid yud tsam du bzlas pa byas na de'i mod la dgra rnams kyi 'tsho ba ni tha mar 'chi bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te mtshan mo bzlas na ni gza' 'khor dang bcas pa 'jig par 'gyur ro/ / gzhan yang las su 'gyur ba ni de bzhin du dbang phyug chen po'i gnas su nyi ma phyed la song ste/ nim pa'i lo mas mchod cing sha chen po'i spos kyis bdug la ji srid dgra'i khyim du mes tshig pa'i bar du bzlas pa byas na dgra yang 'dar ba'i rims chen pos thebs par 'gyur ro/ / yang na khros pas bzlas pa ma btang zhing g.yas phyogs su rtags kyang yod na dgra de 'chi bar 'gyur zhing rigs rgyud 'jig par 'gyur ro/ / ji ste slar gso bar byed na ni rtags de chus phyir yang rab tu bkrus la shin tu bsil ba'i 'o mas khrus byas na slar yang sos par 'gyur ro/ /

“The liṅga will be in two separate parts and the great syllable hūṁ will be heard. One must not be afraid at that time. On the very same day,[2614] the wicked kings, or other enemies with powerful acquaintances, will suddenly be seized with fever, or seized by nonhuman beings, such as rākṣasas and so forth. If, at that time, one keeps reciting the mantra[2615] for a while, the enemy’s life will suddenly be terminated. If one recites at night, the enemy’s entire family[2616] will perish. “There is also another rite. One should go at midday, as before, to a temple of Maheśvara and worship the liṅga with neem leaves, burn the incense of human flesh, and recite the mantra until the house of the enemy is set on fire, or the enemy starts shivering from a great fever. If one does not stop reciting and remains, really angry, near to Dakṣiṇamūrti,[2617] the enemy will die and his family line will be terminated. To bring [the enemy] back to life, one should repeatedly wash the liṅga in water and rinse it with the cool milk of a cow. [The enemy] will become well again.

las gzhan yang yod de dbang phyug chen po'i mtshan g.yas phyogs su bzhag la po son cha'i shing dang tsher ma can gyi shing gis me rab tu sbar la/ shing pA ka~M ta ka'i yam shing la dug dang khrag dang ske tshe la mngon par btags la stong rtsa brgyad kyi sbyin sreg byas na/ dgra thams cad nad chen pos thebs par 'gyur te/ las thams cad kyis kyang nus pa med par 'gyur ro/ / zhag gnyis pa la ni rims nad chen po dang zug gzer chen pos thebs pa'am nad rnam pa sna tshogs sam mi ma yin pas zin cing mthar 'chi bar 'gyur ro/ / zhag gsum pa la grangs gsum gyis byas na ni 'tsho ba thams cad kyi thams cad du 'dor bar 'gyur ro/ / slar gso bar byed na ni 'o ma'i sbyin sreg byas na zhi bar 'gyur ba ni yul mi thams cad dang dgra thams cad kyang sos par 'gyur ro/ /

“There is also another rite. One should light a fire opposite the southern face of the Maheśvara liṅga, using sticks of the thorn apple,[2618] and offer into it one thousand and eight oblations of sticks of vaikaṅkata[2619] smeared with poison, blood, and brown mustard [oil]. All the enemies will succumb to a serious illness and will be unable to perform any actions. On the second day, they will be seized with a great fever, a sharp pain, and various diseases. They may also become seized by nonhuman beings who will eventually bring about their death. On the third day, [if the rite is performed] at the three junctions, all of them will, without exception, lose their lives. To bring them back to life, one should offer oblations of milk. This will pacify the suffering. All the people in the area and all the enemies will become well again.

de bzhin du lha thams cad dam lha mo thams cad dam 'byung po thams cad gang zhig gang gi lha la dad pa de rkang pas mnan pa'i las bya ba'am/ / yang na de'i rgyu skar ram sngags sam ming dag la rkang pas mnan la las bya ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i rig pa ni ma gtogs te/ thams cad kyis kyang zhabs kyi mthe bo g.yon pa bzung ste las bya'i/ mnan par yang mi bya ba gom par yang mi bya'o/ / gang yang 'jig rten pa thams cad kyi sngags ni mnan nas las bya'o/ /

“Similarly, one can perform this rite for any target by stepping upon the deity or spirit that the target is a devotee of. This deity should be represented by its mantra or nakṣatra,[2620] upon which one should step with one’s left foot and perform the rite. The exceptions are the vidyās who are tathāgatas, over whom one should never step or stand astride but perform the rite, for all of them, holding them between one’s big toes. It is only the worldly mantra deities that one can step upon.

khro bo'i rgyal po'i bzlas pa ma grub pa nyid kyang bzlas pa tsam kho nas las rnams byed par 'gyur/ sngags thams cad rnam par 'jig par 'gyur/ dgra thams cad 'joms par 'gyur/ sngags thams cad nus pa med par 'gyur ro/ / mdor na 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags kyi cho gas kyang ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar thams cad sgrub par 'gyur/ bzlas pa tsam gyis re ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro/ / khro bo'i rgyal po'i sngags 'di bzlas pa tsam kho nas grub pa nyid de grub pa dam pa'ang rjes su rab tu sbyin no/ / yid la 'dod pas dgra rnams 'joms par byed do/ / mdung rtse chen po'i phyag rgya dang ldan par byas na las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ /

“Even if the mantra of Lord of Wrath has not been fully mastered, it can still accomplish the [intended] activities by merely being recited. With it, one can obliterate all [other] mantras, slay all one’s enemies, and destroy all the magical diagrams and devices.[2621] In short, whatever this mantra is employed to do, it will accomplish all of it regardless of whether it is a mundane or supramundane mantra ritual. The mantra will accomplish it all.[2622] Through merely reciting it, all hopes will be fulfilled. Accomplished through recitation, Lord of Wrath will subsequently grant the supreme accomplishment. The practitioner will destroy his enemies by merely wishing to do so. If employed in combination with the great spear mudrā, the mantra will accomplish all activities.

las gzhan du'ang 'gyur ba ni nyi ma phyed la dur khrod du song ste/ sreg pa'i sar mtshan gcig smyung ba byas te/ mar ngo'i bcu bzhi la dur khrod kyi shing gis me rab tu sbar la/ dug dang khrag gis btags pa'i ske tshes sbyin sreg byas na/ de las ha ha zhes pa'i sgra sgrogs shing / yi dgas thams cad 'ong bar 'gyur na 'jigs par mi bya zhing dgra la gnod par gyis shig ces byas na/ de bzhin du bya'o zhes smras nas mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / de nas yud tsam gyis dpag tshad stong du yang song nas/ dgra rnams 'joms par byed cing rigs rgyud kyang rlag par byed do/ / de la sogs pa'i las mang po byed par 'gyur ro/ / gzhan yang las su 'gyur ba ni dben pa'i phyogs gtsang mar gos gtsang ma bgos te/ / khang stong du rab tu zhugs nas mi'i rus pa'i sreg blugs kyis stong rtsa brgyad sbyin sreg byas te/ de nas thal ba de lag pa gnyi gas blangs la/ gos gtsang ma'i dum bu la so sor bcings te thum po gnyis su byas la/ kham por kha sbyar gnyis kyi nang du so sor bzhag la/ bdag nyid srung ba chen po byas nas rdzas de blangs la/ khyim du slar zhugs nas mtshan mo dur khrod chen por song nas/ mar ngo'i bcu bzhi'am tshes brgyad la mi sreg pa'i sar bzhag cing lho phyogs su bltas nas kham por kha sbyar gnyis blangs la langs shing gcer bur byas te skra bshig pa dang khro ba dang bcas pas 'jigs pa med par bya ste/ rig pa stong phrag bcu bzlas pa byas na thal ba de grub par 'gyur ro/ / mi gang su dag rdzas de slong bar gyur na sbyin par mi bya'o/ / gal te tshan khar slong bar byed na ni khro bo'i rgyal po dran nas yi ge hU~M rab tu sbyar ba byas na de'i mod la 'byer bar 'gyur ro/ / bgegs thams cad rnam par 'joms pa yang cho ga 'di nyid do/ / lag pa g.yon pa dang g.yas pas blangs pa'i thal bas ni rtags mtshan bya zhing bag yod pas bsrung ba yang bya la/ tho rangs nyi ma 'char ba'i dus su slar 'ong bar bya ba na khrus byas shing gtsang zhing gtsang ba'i gos bgos te rang gi khyim du 'jug par bya ste/ rang gi gnas sam ji ltar 'dod par 'gro bar bya'o/ / de nas lag pa g.yas pa gang gis blangs pa'i thal ba des mi dang rkang gnyis dang rkang bzhi dang srog chags 'byung po thams cad dang / lha dang bcas pa'i klu dang gnod sbyin rnams kyi spyi bor gtor na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / gang lag pa g.yon pas blangs pa'i thal ba des ni mi'i bud med thams cad kyi spyi bor gtor na dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

“There is also another rite. One should go at midday to a charnel ground, fast for one night‍—the fourteenth of the dark fortnight‍—at a cremation spot, light a fire there using charnel ground wood, and offer into the fire oblations of brown mustard smeared with poison and blood. Subsequently, all the pretas will arrive, making the sound hā hā. One must not be afraid, but say, ‘Please kill my enemies!’ They will reply, ‘So be it!’ and disappear. Then, traveling one thousand leagues in a mere instant, they will kill the enemies and ruin their families. They will carry out these and similar acts. “There is also another rite. In a secluded and clean area, wearing clean clothes, one should enter an abandoned house and offer one thousand and eight oblations of cotton[2623] seeds.[2624] One should then scoop the [sacrificial] ashes with both hands, wrap them in clean cloth in two separate bundles, and seal them in a double clay bowl. Ritually protected, one should then take the [sealed] contents out of the house[2625] and go at night‍—either the fourteenth or the eighth of the dark fortnight‍—to a big charnel ground. Standing at a cremation spot with one’s face toward the south, naked and with loose hair, one should hold the sealed vessel and recite the mantra, angry and fearless, ten thousand times. The ashes will thus become empowered. “Should any nonhuman being then request a power substance, one should not give it, but apply force, recollecting Lord of Wrath and employing his syllable hūṁ. [The spirit] will die that very instant.[2626] This method is in particular for all the vighnas. One should make an ash mark with the ashes held in the left or the right hand.[2627] “Having performed the protection [rite] with care, one should return [to the abandoned house] before dawn. At sunrise, one should wash oneself and, when clean, put on clean clothes and go to one’s own house or a place of one’s choice. “Then, if one takes the ashes with one’s right hand and throws them at the head of any male being, whether two-legged or four-legged‍—a man, a god, a nāga, or a yakṣa‍—he will become enthralled. If one takes the ashes with one’s left hand and throws them at the head of any female being, whether human or nonhuman,[2628] she will become enthralled.

lag pa g.yas pas blangs pa'i thal ba gang yin pa des mi rnams kyi lte ba'i phyogs sam/ pho mtshan gyi phyogs su gtor na grong pa'i chos bsten pa la nus pa med par 'gyur ro/ / gang zhig bud med la mngon par chags pa de'i gsang ba'i gnas su thal ba'i phye mas gtor na skyes bu gzhan brten pa la nus pa med par 'gyur ro/ / skyes bu gzhan brten pa na rma med par yang 'gyur ro/ / ji srid rang gi skyes pa nyid thob na ni phyir yang de'i rma'i sgo de rab tu 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / 'dod pas log par g.yem pa bsten pa la yang nus pa med par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du skyes pa la yang skyes pa'i dbang po la lag pa g.yas pas thal ba'i phye mas gtor na/ de yang gzhan gyi bud med la 'gro ba'i nus pa med par 'gyur te/ yongs su rnying pa bzhin du de'i de nyid 'byung zhing gnas par 'gyur ro/ / ji srid du rang gi chung ma de nyid dang yang phrad na phyir yang rnying pa med par 'gyur ro/ / skyes pa'am bud med gang la thal ba gtor bar gyur pa de med par 'gyur ba'am med par mi 'gyur ba'o/ / yang na ni ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du byed do/ / gal te nan gyis byed na ni gsang ba'i phyogs su srin bu rnams rab tu 'byung bar 'gyur zhing / de dag gis zos pa na 'tsho ba yang 'gag par 'gyur la/ zla ba gcig gi nang du rul par 'gyur te/ dri mi zhim zhing ro myags pa 'dra bar 'gyur ro/ / gcin sri ba'i nad la sogs pas skyes bu zin par 'gyur la/ skrangs nad chen po yang 'byung bar 'gyur te/ gang de dag gi nad kyis dus byed par 'gyur ro/ / yang na gzhan gyi bud med la bsten par 'dod na yang nus pa med par 'gyur ro/ / ji lta ji ltar mngon par 'dod pa de dag thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / gal te gtor bcom gyis thal ba dang phrad par ma gyur na/

“If one takes the ashes with one’s right hand and strikes with them a man around the navel, he will become a eunuch. Or, if one sprinkles the ashes onto his private parts, he will not be able to have sex. “If one sprinkles some ash onto the private part of the woman that one is fond of, she will not be able to have sex with another man. She will be free from lesions, but whenever she returns to the other man again, the lesions will clearly manifest.[2629] She will thus be unable to indulge in her inappropriate passion. “Likewise, if one sprinkles the ash onto a man’s penis with one’s right hand, he will be not be able to have sex when frequenting the wives of others. His penis will be as if completely withered.[2630] The erection, however, will return when he submits to the will of whoever administered the ashes.[2631] Whoever administers the ashes, whether it is a woman to a man or the other way around, the recipient will come under his or her power. According to their wish, the recipient will either remain or not remain under their control. “If the ashes are administered to men who rape their partner, their private parts will become infested with worms, eaten by which they will lose their lives. Within one month their bodies will fester, smelling foul and looking like corpses. They will contract male diseases, such as the ‘great discharge’[2632] and so forth. They will develop cancer, and when they do, the torment of it will kill them. Or, if this is the wish of the person who administers the ashes, they will just be unable to enjoy anything.[2633] One can make all this happen with a mere touch, if one wants to.[2634]

mthong ba'am ma mthong ba la yang mthun pa'i rlung dang sbyar te thal ba gtor te/ de la thal ba cung zad kyang babs par 'gyur ba'am gtor bar byed pas yid kyis bsams te thal ba gtor na/ gang brtsams par 'gyur ba de dag thams cad kyi las rnams byed par 'gyur ro/ / bdag nyid dam gzhan gyi lag pas gtor na ji ltar 'dod pa de thams cad kyi las byed par 'gyur gyi gzhan du ni ma yin no/ / ji ste gnas mal la sogs pa dang stan dang gos la sogs pa rnam pa sna tshogs sam bzhon pa dang theg pa dang lham dang gdugs la sogs pa yo byad thams cad dang lhag ma ni bza' ba dang / btung ba dang / bca' ba la sogs pa dang lus thams cad la dgos pa'i cha byad thams cad dang / me tog dang so rtsi dang 'bras bu dang spos la sogs pa 'di dag thams cad la thal ba'i phye mas gtor na dgra de dag gi lus la shig dang ma ku ta'i srin bu rnams kyis kun nas khyab par 'gyur te/ shing ji lta ba bzhin du za bar 'gyur ro/ / rmi lam ngan pa yang mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / zhag bdun gyis kyang 'chi bar 'gyur te/ sman pa thams cad dang lha thams cad kyis kyang bzlog par mi nus so/ / sngags thams cad kyis kyang bsrung bar mi nus te/ gang gis thal ba gtor bar byed pa ni ma gtogs so/ /

“If one cannot physically touch the target, one should stand within the range of sight, [and if this is not possible], outside the range of sight, and cast the ashes with the wind, so that some of it settles on the target. The dispenser should thus cast the ashes making a wish. Whatever acts he thinks of, he will realize all of them, whether by his own or somebody else’s hand. All of them will come to pass according to his wish, and not otherwise.[2635] “One can also sprinkle the ashes onto beds, seats, and so on; spreads, covers, and so on; different types of adornments, different clothes, riding animals, vehicles, shoes, parasols, and so on; any types of tools; all the things necessary for the body; cooked and uncooked food and drink; crockery and cutlery;[2636] or flowers, betel, fruit, perfume, incense, and so on. If one besprinkles any of these, the body of the enemy will become infested with and bitten by lice, fleas, and worms all over.[2637] He will be smitten by suffering of different kinds and will die within seven nights.[2638] Neither physicians nor gods will be able to stop it. No mantras will be able to protect him and nobody will be able to help, except for the one who administered the ashes.

ji ste slar gso ba byed na ni shing mngar dang ut+pa la sngon po dang tsan+dan dkar po gcig tu byas la chu grang mo la btags te/ de nas spyi bo nas bzung ste rkang pa'i mthil gyi bar du de'i lus la byugs shing 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i sngags bzlas na sos par 'gyur ro/ / gzhan yang bud med rnams la las su bya ba ni/ mthun pa'i rlung gi phyogs gang du 'dod pa der song nas bud med mkha' 'gro ma ma rungs pa nga rgyal can thams cad la yang sbyor ba bya ste gzhan la ni ma yin no/ / mthun pa'i rlung yod pa de nyid la gnas nas/ bcom ldan 'das yid la bsams te thal ba gtor na mo mtshan dang nu ma thams cad mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / skyes pa la'ang kha spu dang ba spu med pa dang mo mtshan dang nu ma yang rab tu 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / de lta bur rnam pa mang po du ma'i las kyang byed pa'am/ gzhan byed du gzhug par 'gyur ro/ / yang na gang dga' ba skye ba de byed du gzhug par 'gyur ro/ / bud med dam skyes pa gang la sems dga' ba skye ba de la thal ba de byin na ji ltar 'dod pa'i las byed du gzhug par 'gyur ro/ / sbyor ba'ang bslab par bya'o/ / de ltar nad chen po dag gis kyang 'debs su gzhug par bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das yid la bsams nas/ thal ba'i lag pas spyi bor reg na klad pa zug gzer skye bar 'gyur ro/ / kha la reg par byas na kha'i nad 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du mthar gyis snying gi bar du rig par byas na snying gi nad dam/ lto ba'i nad 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du rkang pa gnyis dang rje ngar gnyis la reg par byas na'ang khrag las byung ba'i nad khrag khrug pa la sogs pa'i nad kyis 'debs par byed par 'gyur ro/ /

“The following is the remedial procedure. One should blend together licorice root, blue lotus, and white sandalwood. One should mash these ingredients together with cool water and smear [the paste on the target’s body], starting from the head and ending with the soles of the feet, while reciting the mantra of Noble Mañjuśrī. The target will become well again. “There is also another rite.[2639] One should employ it only against all the wicked witches, swollen with pride, and no other women. Having gone upwind from the woman intended as the target, one should cast the ashes toward her with the wind. If one does the corresponding visualization,[2640] her vagina and breasts will completely disappear. If the same is done to a man, he will lose his male organ and his facial and bodily hair and develop breasts.[2641] In this way, one may perform, or have someone else perform, many different and unusual[2642] acts. One may engage for this purpose someone whom one likes, either a woman or a man. “Alternatively, one may pass on the ashes to and engage in the desired [task] an accomplice that one does not like.[2643] If one duly instructs him in the procedure, the target will be seized, accordingly, by a serious illness or other disorder. Touching[2644] the head in combination with the appropriate visualization[2645] causes [the target] to develop a severe headache. Touching the mouth will cause an inflammation of the mouth. Following in this order, the target may develop an acute chest pain or stomachache. Similarly, touching the legs and the feet will result in [the legs and feet of the target] developing blood-related diseases, when the blood goes bad.

mdor na 'chi bar byed pa dang dbang du byed par yang 'gyur te/ ji lta ji ltar rab tu sbyar ba de lta de ltar de thams cad byed par 'gyur zhing / gsad pa dang dgug pa dang dbang du byed par yang 'gyur ro/ / shin tu thag ring po na gnas kyang las thams cad byed do/ / mkhar shin tu bgrod dka' ba dang nye ba mthun pa'i rlung yod par gnas par byas la/ lag pa gnyis kas thal ba de nyid blangs la yang dag par gtor na/ rab dang sgo khang dang yang thog kyang rab tu ltung bar 'gyur te/ mkhar srung ba yang ltung bar 'gyur zhing mes tshig pa chen po yang 'byung bar 'gyur/ dpung rnams kyang 'jig par 'gyur/ rnam par 'tshe ba chen pos kyang nye bar 'tsho bar 'gyur/ thams cad bor nas rab tu 'byer bar yang 'gyur/ yang na skyabs su mngon par 'gro bar 'gyur/ de ltar gzhan gyi dpung la yang mthun pa'i rlung yod pa'i phyogs su thal ba gtor na/ dpung dang sde chen po yang 'jig par 'gyur zhing / tshig pa chen po'am/ nad kyis 'debs par 'gyur ba'am/ glang po dang / rta dang / shing rta dang / rkang thang la sogs pa'i sde dpon yang 'jig par 'gyur ba'am skyabs su mngon par 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / de ltar rnam pa du ma'i ci 'dod pa rnams kyi dgra rnams 'jig par bya ba'i phyir las byed par 'gyur ro/ / bdag nyid dang rang gi dpung ngam grogs po dag la yang srung ba chen po'i don du 'gyur ro/ / ji ste slar gso ba byed na ni thams cad du 'o ma'i zas kyis 'tsho zhing / thams cad la ras ris kyi mdun du 'o ma'i sreg blugs stong gis sbyin sreg byas na sos par 'gyur zhing mi snang bar yang 'gyur ro/ /

“In short, one can cause death, loss of vitality, or inflammation with suppuration. One can also summon or enthrall the target.[2646] Whatever [the ashes] are employed for, all of that will be accomplished. One can bring harm upon, summon, or enthrall the target, even if one is far away. “One should go next to a wall that is difficult to breach and, standing upwind, cast the ashes held in both hands. The wall, the main gateway, and the watchtower will crumble. The residence that will subsequently come into view will go up in flames, and the defending army will be routed.[2647] Plagued by great calamities, the target will either flee, leaving everything behind, or will give himself up as prisoner. “Similarly, if one throws the ashes with the wind at the enemy forces, even a powerful army will be defeated. It will be seized with a great febrility or fever and its elephants, horses, chariots, banners, and so forth, including the general, will be destroyed or taken prisoner. “One can thus perform many different rites as necessary, whether they are to destroy the enemy or afford protection for oneself, one’s own army, and one’s allies. To completely undo the harm ever inflicted on any target,[2648] one should offer one thousand oblations of milk in front of the painting. They will again become strong and well.

ji ste gnod sbyin mo bsgrub par 'dod na/ gar byed 'dud ma rje btsun ma/ / nam gru mar yang rnam par grag / mdzes ma mun pa snang byed ma/ / 'og pag ma dang 'og pag bzang / / brgyad po 'di dag gnod sbyin mo/ / 'dod pa thams cad rab sgrub pa'o/ /
“If one wants to perform magic on a yakṣiṇī‍— Naṭī, Naṭṭā, and Bhaṭṭā; One known as Revatī; And Tamasundarī, Ālokā, Mekhalā, and Sumekhalā‍— These eight yakṣiṇīs Can grant every desire.[2649]
gar byed ma'i sngags ni/
“The mantra of Naṭikā[2650] is:
oM na Ti ma hA na Ti A gats+tsha A gats+tsha/ di bya rU pa NI swA hA/
“Oṁ Naṭī, great Naṭī! Come, come in your divine form! Svāhā!’[2651]

'di'i cho ga ni spang leb bam ras la mngon par bris la sha'am 'o ma'i zas za zhing rig pa stong rtsa brgyad bzlas pa bya zhing / a mra'i shing gi rtsa bar gnas shing rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa sngo sangs su gnas pa bri bar bya'o/ / ro smad gos gcig pa skra bshig pa mig gnyi ga dmar ba cung zad bzhin 'dzum pa lag pa g.yas pas sgrub pa po la sdigs mdzub byed pa/ lag pa g.yon pas shing gi yal ga 'dzin pa yan lag thams cad mdzes pa/ dar la rnam pa sna tshogs kyi gos bgos pa/ khro bo'i rgyal po de nyid kyi ras ris kyi mdun du bdag byang du mngon par bltas te 'dug la shing pa la shas me rab tu sbar la gu gul gyi ril bu dag la zho dang / sbrang rtsi dang / mar dag gis btags la dus gsum du zhag bdun gyi bar du sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad byas la/ de nas zhag bdun pa la gtor ma rgya chen po byas la mar gyi mar me yang rab tu sbar la/ ji srid nam phyed pa de'i bar du bzlas pa byas te 'dug na/ de'i 'og tu gnod sbyin mo de rang nyid snang ba chen por byas te/ rang gi gzugs kyis 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / 'ongs nas kyang smra bar bya ba ni ngas ci zhig bya zhes so/ / de nas sgrub pa pos brjod par bya ba ni/ khyod nga'i chung mar gyis shig ces bya'o/ / de ltar bgyi'o zhes byas nas mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / de nas bzung nas chung mar gyur te rang gi gnas su khyer nas 'dod pa thams cad ster bar byed cing bcud kyis len yang rab tu ster bar byed de/ gang 'thungs pas lha'i gzugs su 'gyur zhing / gnod sbyin chen po dang rab tu 'gran par 'gyur ro/ / gal te ma 'ongs na ni lan gnyis pa la khro bo'i sngags dang lhan cig bzlas pa byas na nges par 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te ma 'ongs na ni khro bo 'chol ba'i rgyal pos 'chi bar 'gyur ro/ / 'dud ma'i sngags ni 'di yin te/

“One should draw this vidyā on a slab or a tablet and recite her mantra one thousand and eight times while living on a diet of meat or milk. She should be drawn adorned with all the ornaments, of pure dark complexion, next to a tree.[2652] She wears a single garment,[2653] has loose hair and red eyes, and is smiling a little. She displays the threatening mudrā toward the practitioner with her right hand and holds on to a branch of the tree with the left. All her limbs are adorned, and she is wearing a brightly colored, silken sash. “One should position oneself before the painting of the same Lord of Wrath, alert in mind and facing north, and light a fire of dhak sticks. One should offer into it, at the three junctions of the day for seven days, one thousand and eight bdellium pills smeared with curds, honey, and ghee. One the seventh day, one should make an extensive bali offering, lighting butter lamps and reciting the mantra until midnight. The yakṣiṇī will then arrive in person in her own form, effulgent with great light. “When she arrives, she will say, ‘What can I do for you?’ The practitioner should reply, ‘Be my wife.’ She will then say, ‘So be it!’ and will disappear. From then on, she will be the practitioner’s wife. She will grant his every wish and take him to her abode. He will obtain there an elixir of long life, and upon drinking it he will obtain a divine form, equal to the great yakṣa.[2654] If she does not arrive, the second time one should include in the recitation [the mantra of] Lord of Wrath, and she will certainly come. If not, she will wither and die.[2655] “The mantra of Naṭṭā is:
oM na T+Te shu klA mA ba ra mA l+ya d+hA ri Ne mai thu na pri ye swA hA/
“Oṁ Naṭṭā! Wearing white garments and garlands, and fond of sex! Svāhā![2656]
'di'i cho ga yang 'di nyid do/ / rje btsun ma'i sngags ni 'di yin te/
“Her ritual procedure is the same as the previous. “The mantra of Bhaṭṭā is:
o~M b+had tre b+had tre a ba lo ki ni kiny+tsi rA ya si/ e h+ya hi A gats+tsha A gats+tsha ma ma kA r+yaM ku ru swA hA/
“Oṁ Bhaṭṭā, Bhaṭṭā! Splendorous one, why do you tarry? Come, come! Arrive, arrive! Do my bidding! Svāhā![2657]

de nyid kyis ni ras ris med kyang 'grub par 'gyur te/ ri'i rtse mor dkyil 'khor byas la gu gul gyi du bas bdugs te/ gcig pu mi smra bar gnas shing gtsang sbra byas te sgo bcad la rig pa stong rtsa brgyad bzlas pa byas na/ zla ba gcig gi mtshan mo nges par 'ong bar 'gyur zhing 'ongs nas kyang 'dod pa spyod par byas na/ chung mar 'gyur zhing 'dod pa thams cad ster bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te de khyim du zhugs na ni lo stong phrag lnga'i bar du 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te ma zhugs na ni 'dzam bu'i gling du lo lnga brgya 'tsho bar 'gyur zhing rnam par spyod par 'gyur ro/ / de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed cing lung thams cad la yang dag par 'grub par byed do/ / de dang lhan cig gang du 'dod pa der 'gro zhing bcud kyis len rab tu sbyin par byed la/ sdug pa'i chung ma bzhin du phan pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa yang rab tu byed do/ / nam gru ma'i sngags ni/

“Her rite can be accomplished even without the painting. One should draw a maṇḍala in a prominent spot[2658] and recite her mantra one thousand and eight times while burning an incense of bdellium. If one does this without engaging in talk, alone, pure, and behind closed doors, she will certainly arrive within one month, at nighttime. “When she arrives, the practitioner should make love to her, and she will become his wife who grants every wish. If he enters her house, he will live five thousand years. If not, he will stay in Jambūdvīpa and live five hundred years, playing with her. She will carry out his every command. She will go with him, wherever he wishes. She will procure for him the elixir of longevity, and, just as a beloved wife does, will act with the best of intentions. “The mantra of Revatī is,
na maH sarba yak+Shi NAM/ oM rak+te rak+tA ba b+hA si rak+ta rak+ta le ba ni swA hA/
‘Homage to all the yakṣiṇīs!’ [The mantra to recite is]: “Oṁ, red one with a red glow and wearing red unguents! Svāhā![2659]

gnod sbyin mchog ni nam gru ma/ / sbyor ba la dga' rjod par byed/ / cung zad dmar ba'i gos gyon zhing / / sngo zhing 'khyil ba'i skra yang yod/ / yan lag kun mdzes gnod sbyin mo/ / 'dod pa spyod la rtag tu dga'/ / 'dod dang longs spyod rtag tu sbyin/ / mchog sbyin par ni rtag tu ston/ /

“Revatī is a distinguished yakṣiṇī, Playful and fond of sex. She wears a soft-red garment And has blue, curly hair. “This yakṣa lady is adorned on every limb And always delights in the pleasures of sex. She always grants wishes and gives pleasure. One should depict her displaying a boon-granting gesture.

snga ma bzhin du ras la mngon par bris la 'di'i khyad par ni 'di yin te/ dar la dmar po gyon zhing dar la dmar pos stod g.yogs byas shing / kha dog dmar bar yang snang ba yin no/ / 'og pag ma'i sngags ni/

“Her painting should be done as before, except that Revatī is wearing garments of red silk, including an upper garment of the same material. Her complexion has a reddish glow. “The mantra of Mekhalā is:
oM me kha le ma hA yak+Shi NI ma ma kAr+ya~M sam+bA da ya swA hA/
“Oṁ Mekhalā! Great yakṣiṇī! Please do my bidding! Svāha![2660]
'og pag ma bzang mo'i sngags ni/
“The mantra of Sumekhalā is:
oM me kha le su me kha le ma hA ya k+Shi NAM sarba ar+tha/ sA d+ha ni hU~M/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra Ne swA hA/
“Oṁ Mekhalā, Sumekhalā! Great yakṣiṇī who fulfills every purpose, hūṁ! Remember your samaya! Svāha![2661]
snang ba ma'i sngags ni/
“The mantra of Ālokinī is:
a~M A lo ki ni lo ka ba te swA hA/
“Oṁ Lokinī! Lokavatī![2662] Svāhā![2663]
'di dag ni cho ga yang de nyid do/ / mun pa mdzes ma'i sngags ni/
“The ritual procedure of the [last three] yakṣiṇīs is the same as before. “The mantra of Tamasundarī is:
oM shrI Nu gu h+ya ke shrI Nu gu h+ya ke e h+ya hi gu h+yai hi guh+ya ke swA hA/
“Oṁ ghuṇu![2664] Ghuṇu, ghuṇu, O secret one! Come, come, O guhyakī! Svāhā![2665]

'di'i cho ga la ni ras ris kyi cho ga ni 'di la med do/ / dang por re zhig gtsang zhing gos gtsang ma bgos te/ zla ba nya ba la gnas dben par 'dug nas sgo bcad de snang ba med par mun pa'i gnas su rig pa stong phrag bcu bzlas na sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / de nas sgrub pa pos brtsam par bya ba ni zla ba nya nas brtsams nas zla ba nya gnyis pa'i bar 'dir las su bya ba ni/ mtshan mo nyal ba'i dus su mal du 'dug nas mi snang zhing dben pa'i sa phyogs su gcig pu sgo bcad la/ dong ka dang bA na ka'i me tog legs par kha 'bus pa yungs mar dang bsres pas/ lag pa dang rkang pa la byugs la/ lag pa g.yas pa la brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags pa bya ste/ mi smra ba'i dka' thub kyis bzlas pa bya'o/ / de bzhin du nyin re zhing ma chad par zla ba nya'i bar du byas na de nas mtshan phyed tsam na nges par 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ /

“As for her practice, no painting of her is prescribed. One should start during a full moon, wearing clean clothes and being clean oneself, in a secluded place . . . .[2666] One should firmly shut the door and recite her vidyā ten thousand times in complete and utter darkness. This constitutes the preliminary practice. “Afterward, one should begin the formal practice. One should start during a full moon and perform the rite until the next full moon, doing it alone at night in an isolated and hidden place, when it is time to sleep and one is in bed with the door closed, in complete and utter darkness. One should blend closed lotus buds and vānapuṣpa[2667] with white mustard oil and rub it onto one’s hands and feet. One should incant the right arm[2668] one hundred and eight times and go to sleep in silence.[2669] If one does this every day until the next full moon, then Tamasundarī will arrive for certain at midnight.

'ongs nas kyang mi smra bar bya zhing / cang mi smra bar gyur pas 'dod pa bsten par bya'o/ / gang gi tshe zla ba drug na smra ba de'i tshe smra bar bya ste/ de nas bzung nas chung mar 'grub par 'gyur te/ 'dod pa thams cad ster ba dang 'di la lha'i reg pa bzang po yang sbyin par byed do/ / nyin par ma mthong ba kho nar yang las thams cad sgrub par byed do/ / ro dang bcud kyis len rnams kyang rab tu ster bar byed do/ / rgyab tu zhon na ni ri rab tu yang khyer bar byed do/ / mtshan mo 'dzam bu'i gling kun tu yang 'khor bar byed do/ / dpag tshad brgya na yod pa'i dgra de dag kyang 'joms par byed do/ / ji skad bstan pa de thams cad sgrub par byed do/ / gzhan gyi bud med la 'gro ba ni ma gtogs so/ / gzhan gyi bud med la 'gro bar byed pa'i cho ga ni 'di dag thams cad la yang sbyar te/ de nyid dang lhan cig yang dag par bsten par bya'o/ / gal te gzhan gyi bud med la 'gro bar 'gyur na ni 'chi ba skyed par yang 'gyur ro/ /

“When she arrives, one should not engage her in conversation but make love to her in silence. If, within six months, she starts conversing, one should join in. From then on she will be an accomplished object of the practice, becoming one’s wife who grants every desire and whose soft touch gives divine pleasure. She will perform all tasks even when she is out of sight and will also procure the essential elixir of longevity. “Taking the practitioner upon her back, she will carry him even to the top of Mount Sumeru. At night, she will take him all the way around Jambūdvīpa. She will crush one’s enemies, even at a distance of one hundred leagues. Whatever she is ordered to do will turn out well, except for sexual advances on other women. This rule applies to all the yakṣiṇīs. One must not approach other women but cohabit only with them. If one goes to other women, they will cause death or insanity.[2670]

'di ni mun nag mdzes ma zhes bya ba gnod sbyin ma stong phrag du mas yongs su bskor bas sgrub pa pos 'grub par 'gyur na nyin re zhing gnod sbyin mo'i bran mo re re gtong bar byed do/ / blon po'i 'khor du ma dang ldan pa dang gnod sbyin mo thams cad na yang rdzu 'phrul che ba dang mun pas bskor ba 'di dag thams cad kyang cho ga tha dad pa ma yin mod kyi 'on kyang gzhan de dag ni mthong bar 'gyur ro/ /

“This yakṣiṇī,[2671] [also] called Andhārasundarī,[2672] is surrounded by many hundreds[2673] of thousands of yakṣiṇīs. When accomplished as an object of practice by any practitioner, she dispatches, every single day, one yakṣiṇī-servant for each of them. She has a retinue of many ministers, all of them yakṣiṇīs, among whom she is distinguished by her great miraculous power and her cover of darkness. As the ritual procedure is the same for all of them,[2674] could one see any of them? It is not possible to see her.

mun nag chen po na gnas pa zhes bya ba'i gnod sbyin mo rdzu 'phrul che ba dang phug gnas ma dang mi'i dpa' mo dang gzhon nu ma 'jig rten rnam par grags pa dang / mna' ma gnod sbyin mo dang yid du 'ong ma dang bdun pa lha mdzes ma dang 'di dag ni gnod sbyin mo bdun dag ste/ sems can rnams rjes su 'dzin par byed pa'o/ /

“Among the yakṣiṇīs, famous throughout the world, There is also Andhāravāsinī, Endowed with great miraculous power, Guhāvāsinī, Naravīrā, Yakṣakumārī,[2675] “Vadhūyakṣiṇī, Manojñā, And the seventh, Surasundarī. These seven yakṣiṇīs perform Acts of kindness for sentient beings.
sa rnams ma lus dag tu ni/ / 'jig rten 'dir ni yongs su rgyu/ / cung zad kyi ni dus dag tu'ang / / lha'i gnas su yang 'gro bar byed/ /
“They wander around this world And the entire earth. Within a brief moment, They can ascend to the world of the gods.[2676]

lha dang lha min g.yul dag tu'ang / / rdzu 'phrul chen pos 'thab par byed/ / chos ldan snying ni brtse ba dang / / sems can 'dod cing mnyes gshin bzang / / sems can phan pa'i 'dod don du/ / sa steng dag tu yongs su rgyu/ / de la bsgrub dka' cung zad med/ / dge ba'i las rnams ma lus byed/ / sems can longs spyod don du ni/ / byang chub sems dpas bshad pa yin/ /

“Being endowed with great miraculous powers, They take part in battles between the gods and the daityas. They are virtuous, compassionate, and lovingly tender Toward beings for whom they are objects of desire. “They wander upon the earth, Intent upon helping sentient beings. Nothing is difficult for them to accomplish, And they do a splendid job with every task. The Bodhisattva taught [their rites] To bring enjoyment to beings.
phug gnas ma'i sngags ni/
“The mantra of Guhāvāsinī is:
oM gu hi li gu ha pa ti gu ha bA si ni A na ya b+ha ga ba ti ma mA ti ka~M sa ma ya ma nu sma ra swA hA/
“Oṁ Guhilā, Guhāmati,[2677] Guhāvāsinī! Please come, O blessed one, close to me! Remember your samaya! Svāhā![2678]

seng ldeng gis me rab tu sbar la/ pri yang ku'i me tog la mar gyis btags te/ zla ba gcig gi bar du dus gsum du sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad byas na sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / de nas de'i 'og tu sgrub pa brtsam par bya ste/ dang por re zhig byang bu'am ras sam rtsig pa la tshon ma 'dres pa snod sar pa dag gi nang du bcug pa'i pir dag gis ri'i rgyal po ri rab zur bzhi dang rtse mo bzhi dang ldan pa/ ri bdun gyi phreng bas yongs su bskor ba/ ri de dag gi mtha' mar ri bo dag la brten pa'i phug kun tu bri bar bya'o/ / der gnas pa lha'i gzugs dang ldan pa rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gcig pu gnod sbyin ma phug gnas ma zhes bya ba ro smad dar la gon pa/ stod g.yogs dar la gyon pa/ gser gyi mdog can rnam pa sna tshogs gzugs mdzes pa bri bar bya ste/ de lta bu'i ras ris bri bar bya'o/ / gtsang ba'i gnas su gtsang bas 'o ma'i zas kyis 'tsho zhing / rig pa stong phrag bcu bzlas par bya ste/ ci nus pa'i mchod pa chen po byas na bzlas pa'i tha mar lha'i gzugs dang ldan pa'i gnod sbyin mo snang ba chen po dang ldan par byas nas rang nyid 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ /

“One should light a fire with sticks of cutch wood and offer into it, at the three junctions of the day for one month, one thousand and eight oblations of beautyberry flowers smeared with ghee. This constitutes the preliminary practice. “Afterward, one should begin the formal practice. Using uncontaminated paints, a new brush, and a new paint container, one should first draw the king of mountains, Mount Sumeru, either on a tablet, or a piece of cloth, or a wall. It has four slopes and four lofty peaks and is surrounded by a range of seven mountains. At the outer edge of these mountains, one should draw a cave that is situated in a mountainside. “In there, one should draw a single, divinely beautiful yakṣiṇī called Guhāvāsinī,[2679] adorned with all the ornaments and wearing lower and upper garments of fine silk. She has a golden complexion and a strikingly beautiful form. One should draw the painting like that and recite the vidyā [of Guhāvāsinī] ten thousand times, staying in a clean place, oneself clean and living off a diet of milk. One should offer a large pūjā, or one according to one’s means. Then, at the end of recitation, the yakṣiṇī will arrive in person, in her divinely beautiful form, effulgent with great light.

'ongs pa na sna ma'i me tog dang tsan+dan dkar po bsregs nas mchod yon dbul bar bya'o/ / de nas des bu ci zhig bya/ zhes smra bar byed do/ / des smra bar bya ba ni bdag gi mar mdzod cig ces so/ / de bzhin du bya'o zhes byas nas mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / de la sems 'gyod par ni mi bya ste/ de la 'dod pa dang ldan pa yang don du gnyer bar yang mi bya'o/ / de la 'phags ma rdzu 'phrul che ba don du gnyer na 'grub par 'gyur te/ de phan cad de la ma dang 'dra bar bya ba thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ /

“When she has arrived, one should give her a welcome offering of water mixed with white sandalwood and jasmine flowers. She will say, ‘Child, what can I do for you?’ One should say, ‘Please be my mother.’ She will reply, ‘So be it!’ and will disappear. One must not hurt her feelings and not request anything that is tainted with sensuality. She is noble and very dignified, so if one requests sensual pleasures one will not succeed.[2680] From then on, she will perform all the duties like a mother.

'khor brgyad brgya dang bcas pa la zas dang gos rab tu ster bar 'gyur ro/ / gnas yang ba las kyang skyob par byed do/ / dgon pa chen po dang ri'i steng du gnas na yang las thams cad yang dag par sgrub par byed do/ / bza' ba ci 'dod pa yang rab tu sbyin no/ / ro dang bcud kyis len la sogs pa thams cad kyang rab tu sbyin zhing ci 'dod pa yang rjes su sgrub par byed do/ / khang pa dang khang pa rtseg ma yang mngon par sprul par byed do/ / gser stong phrag kyang nyin re zhing rab tu sbyin par byed do/ / de nyid kyi nyin par thams cad zad par byas te/ gal te mi byed na rnam par chad par 'gyur te/ thams cad kyi thams cad du med par 'gyur ro/ / gzhan yang 'di'i las ni ras ris 'di nyid kyi mdun du seng ldeng gi me rab tu sbar la/ 'bar ba dang du ba dang bral ba'i mdag ma la lag pa g.yas pa'i mthil du ldong ros kyis gzugs brnyan du bris te/ skyes pa'am bud med kyi ming lag pa g.yon pa'i mthil du bris la me mdag gi phung po de la bdugs shing sngags bzlas pa byas na dpag tshad brgya na gnas kyang 'ong bar 'gyur te/ gang smras pa de thams cad byed du gzhug par 'gyur ro/ / tho rangs ni de nyid du khyer bar 'gyur ro/ / las 'di nyid ni mtshan mo bya ba yin gyi nyin par ni ma yin no/ / mi dpa' mo'i sngags ni/

“She will also provide food and clothes to one hundred and eight people from one’s retinue. She will protect one in difficult situations. She will carry out all her duties, even if one were staying in a deep forest or on the top of a mountain. She will provide one’s favorite food and all other things, such as the essential elixir of life and so forth. Complying with one’s wishes, whatever they are, she will magically create a monk’s hut, a family house, or another shelter. Every single day she will give one thousand pieces of gold, which must all be spent that very day. If one does not spend it all, it will be cut back. If one keeps it all, none will remain.[2681] “There is also another rite of Guhāvāsinī. One should light a fire in front of the same painting with sticks of cutch wood [and bring it to the stage where] the embers emit no flames or smoke. Using red arsenic, one should draw on the palm of one’s right hand the image and the name of a man or, if it is a woman, on the palm of one’s left hand, and heat it over the same heap of embers while reciting the mantra. Guhāvāsinī will summon them even from the distance of one hundred leagues and will compel them to do everything that was asked. This rite should be performed at night, not during the day. “The mantra of Naravīrā is:
oM na ra bI re swA hA/
“Oṁ Naravīrā! Svāhā![2682]

de bzhin du 'di'i ras ris kyang bri bar bya ste/ phug gi gnas ni ma gtogs te/ shing mya ngan med la brten pa bri bar byas la 'di'i khyad par ni 'di'o/ / las gzhan thams cad ni phug gnas ma de bzhin du bya'o/ / 'di la ni sring mo zhes kyang brjod par bya'o/ / 'di la las gzhan yang yod de/ zla ba gzas zin pa la btsag yug snam gro ba la btums te khar bcug nas ji srid du zla ba gzas btang gi bar du bzlas na/ de nas btsag yug snam gyi bud med dam skyes pa gang gi ming bris pa de dpag tshad brgya na gnas kyang de nas 'ong bar byed do/ / tho rangs ni de nyid du khyer bar byed do/ / sring mo bzhin du bya ba rnams kyang byed do/ / phongs pa'i dus su yang srung ba chen po byed do/ / bzlas pa tsam gyis bud med thams cad dbang du byed par 'gyur ro/ / mi'i dbang mo'i cho ga ni 'di'o/ / gnod sbyin gzhon nu ma'i sngags ni/

“Her painting should be executed exactly the same as [the painting of Guhāvāsinī], except for the cave dwelling. Instead, Naravīrā should be drawn next to an aśoka tree. The entire ritual is just like that of Guhāvāsinī, except that Naravīrā should be addressed, ‘Please be my sister!’ “There is also another rite of Naravīrā. During a lunar eclipse, one should wrap some red ocher in a piece of birch bark, put it in one’s mouth, and recite the mantra until the moon comes out of eclipse.[2683] Then, whichever woman’s[2684] name one writes with this ocher, Naravīrā will summon her even from a distance of one hundred leagues, and in the morning she will take her back to her original place. She will do everything just as a sister would. In the event of disasters, she will offer great protection. One can enthrall any woman by merely reciting the mantra. This is the rite of Naravīrā. “The mantra of Yakṣakumārī is:
oM yak+Sha ku mA ri ke swAhA/
“Oṁ Yakṣakumārī![2685] Svāhā![2686]

'di'i cho ga ni gro ba la gi wang gis bri bar bya ste/ gzhon nu ma mgo'i skra phyed bcings pa rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ gos gcig pa lag pa g.yas pa na ma du lung ga'i 'bras bu 'dzin pa lag pa g.yon pas shing mya ngan med la 'dzin pa/ de lta bu'i gro ba'i 'dab ma mgo'i gnas kyi steng du gzhag par byas nas/ dgon pa'i phyogs su gcig pu nyal bar byas te/ tsan+dan dkar po'i lde gus dkyil 'khor byas la dus gsum du sna ma'i me tog gis gcal bkram par byas la gu gul gyi bdug pas bdugs nas/ rig pa stong rtsa brgyad zla ba gcig gi bar du bzlas te/ de nas zla ba nya ba la sna ma'i me tog gis mchod pa chen po byas la/ mar gyi mar me dang lha bshos kyang phul nas ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug nas/ ji srid du rnam thos sras kyi bu mo rang gi gzugs nyid kyis gzhon nu ma lnga brgyas yongs su bskor ba 'ong zhing phyogs de thams cad snang bar byas nas/ rang gi gzugs kyi nam mkha' la 'dug par 'gyur zhing / de yang 'di skad du bdag gis ci zhig bya zhes smras pa dang / de nas sgrub pa pos smra bar bya ba ni/ mchog gsum las gang yang rung ba gcig don du gnyer bar bya ba ni/ ma nyid dang sring mo nyid dang chung ma nyid do/ / gal te mar gyur na ni sems la 'gyod par mi bya ste/ 'gyod na ni rnam par 'jig pa 'byung bar 'gyur bas ma bzhin du bsgrub par bya'o/ / ma des kyang bsams pa tsam gyis 'khor lnga brgya dang bcas pa'i zas dang / gos dang rgyan gyi khyad par thams cad kyang yang dag par sgrub par byed do/ / nyin re zhing yang ti na ra stong ster bar 'gyur zhing gal te 'dzam bu'i gling thams cad du rnam par rgyu na yang thams cad yang dag par sgrub par byed do/ / gang gi tshe sring mor gyur na yang de'i tshe dpag tshad brgya las kyang bud med 'gugs par byed cing de nyid du yang khyer bar byed de/ sring mo'i las thams cad kyang yang dag par sgrub par byed do/ / ci ste chung mar gyur na ni rang gi khyim du khyer zhing lo stong du 'tsho bar yang byed do/ / gang gi tshe 'chi bar gyur pa de'i tshe yang rigs bzang por skye bar 'gyur te/ ngag thams cad kyang chung ma bzhin du yang dag par sgrub par byed do/ / chung ma gnod sbyin ma'i sngags ni/ /

“Her practice is as follows. She should be drawn on a piece of birch bark, using bovine bezoar, as a young girl with slightly curly hair, adorned with all the ornaments, and wearing a single piece of clothing.[2687] In her right hand she is holding a fruit filled with seeds, and with the other she is holding onto a branch of an aśoka tree. “One should place this piece of birch bark above the place where one’s head is going to be and sleep alone in a hidden place. One should draw a maṇḍala with white sandalwood paste and, at the three junctions of the day, bestrew it with jasmine flowers, burn an incense of bdellium, and recite the vidyā one thousand and eight times. One should do this for a period of one month. “Then, during the full moon, one should prepare a large pūjā with jasmine flowers and offer butter lamps and food articles. At nighttime, sitting on a bundle of kuśa grass, one should recite the mantra until Kumārī,[2688] the daughter of Vaiśravaṇa, arrives in her usual form along with a retinue of five hundred. Drawing one’s attention to the entire region [of the sky], she will remain naturally suspended in midair. She will ask, ‘What can I do for you?’ The practitioner should then request from her one of the three boons‍—that she either be his mother, sister, or wife. “If she becomes one’s mother, one must not hurt her feelings. If one does, ruin will follow. One must treat her like a mother,[2689] and she, the mother, will fully provide an assortment of foodstuffs, clothes, and adornments for oneself and a retinue of five hundred, if these things are merely wished for. Every day, she will give one thousand dinars. She will provide everything for as long as one is living here in Jambūdvīpa. “If she becomes one’s sister, she will summon a woman [for the practitioner], even from a distance of one hundred leagues, and then take her back[2690] to her original place. She will perform all the duties like a sister. If she becomes a wife, she will take the practitioner to her own house, where one will live for one thousand celestial years. After one dies, one will be reborn in a wealthy family. Like a wife, she will carry out every order. “The mantra of Vadhūyakṣiṇī is:
o~M niH/
“Oṁ niḥ.

chung ma gnod sbyin mo 'di'i cho ga ni tsan+dan dkar po'i lde gus lag pa g.yas pa dang g.yon pa gur gum gyi lde gus nye bar byugs la/ lan stong du mngon par bsngags pa byas nas/ mtshan mo gcig pu mi smra ba'i dka' thub dang dben pa'i sa phyogs su sgo bcad la/ ba ru ra'i 'bras bu lnga'am brgyad til mar gyi nang du bcug la btsos te/ til mar de las ba ru ra'i 'bras bu blangs nas de la yongs su bzlas te/ gser dang / dngul dang / zangs ma dang / sa las byas pa'i snod sar pa la bcug nas/ nyal ba'i rkang pa'i mthar bzhag la/ gnod sbyin 'di nyid kyi sngags yi ge gcig pa stong gis mngon par bsngags pa byas nas/ gnas dben zhing mun pa'i phyogs su me tog gis gcal bkram pa la nyal bar byas na/ mi ma yin pa 'ongs nas rkang pa gnyis la lha'i bde ba'i reg pa 'jam pa'i lag pa'i mthil gyis bsku zhing byug par byed de/ gang gis reg pa tsam gyi lha'i bde ba'i reg pas gnyid 'byung bar 'gyur te/ gang gi nyi ma shar na yang mtshan mo'i mthar dka' ba'i gnyid sad par 'gyur te/ rab tu sad na yang de nyid sems par 'gyur te/ de dang lhan cig 'dod pa spyad par yang mi bya smra bar yang ma byas na zla ba drug gis 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“She is a wife-yakṣiṇī, and her rite is as follows. One should anoint one’s right arm with white sandalwood and the left one with saffron, and incant them with the mantra one thousand times. At nighttime, in a hidden place, alone and silent, one should firmly shut the door, throw into sesame oil five or eight beleric myrobalan fruits, and cook them. “Discarding the myrobalan fruits, one should take the oil and put it in a new vessel made of gold, silver, copper, or clay, and place it on the bed where the feet are. One should incant the oil one thousand times with the one-syllable yakṣiṇī mantra and go to sleep in the same bed, placed in a dark, secluded place and strewn with flowers. “When the nonhuman lady arrives, she will anoint one’s feet [with the incanted oil]. Upon being touched with the palm of her lotus-like hand whose touch gives divine pleasure, one will experience, through this pleasurable touch, a divinely blissful sleep. When the sun rises at the end of the night, one will wake up with unease, and even when awake, one will keep thinking about her. However, one should not make love to her or engage her in conversation. Within six months, she will be accomplished as an object of practice.

de nas de lha'i gzugs dang ldan pa'i bag ma sar pa 'dra ba/ g.yog 'khor gyis yongs su bskor ba/ lag na mar me thogs pa/ 'jig rten rnams 'od bzang po dag gis gsal bar byas pa/ mal stan yongs su 'dzin pa/ rgyan sna tshogs 'bar ba dang ldan pa 'ongs nas kyang tshig rjod par byed la/ 'dod pa la longs spyod pa'i yo byad yongs su 'dzin pa 'ongs nas kyang / sgrub pa po la mgul pa nas 'khyud par byed de/ de nas bzung nas chung ma sdug pa bzhin du rjes su mthun par byed do/ / 'ongs na yang 'dod pa la brten par bya'o/ / mtshan mo yongs su spyad nas tho rangs mi snang bar 'gyur te/ gser srang stong ri ba'i mu tig gi phreng ba mal du nyin re zhing yongs su bor nas 'gro bar yang byed do/ / lhag ma ma lus par thams cad nyin re zhing zad par byas te/ gal te cung zad 'jog par byed na yang yod par mi 'gyur ro/ / su la yang brjod par mi bya ste/ gal te rjod par byed na phyir yang 'ong bar mi 'gyur ro/ / yang na 'chi ba'i mtha'i bar du phung khrol byed par 'gyur ro/ / 'di dag ni mchog tu gsang zhing mchog tu sba bar bya ba ste/ sems can gnyis pa la brjod pa ni bzod pa ma yin te/

“After the six months have passed, she will arrive in her beautiful form, excited like a newly wedded wife, surrounded by a retinue of servants, with a lamp in her hand and splendid with her own radiance.[2691] She will snuggle in the bed or a seat, her colorful adornments blazing forth, and will start a conversation. She will approach holding the implements of sexual enjoyment and will embrace the practitioner around the neck. “From then on, she will follow him like a beloved wife. When she arrives, one should make love to her. She will keep one’s company through the night and disappear in the morning, leaving behind on the bed a pearl necklace worth one thousand pieces of gold. Every day, she will leave it behind and then depart. One must spend absolutely all of it. If one keeps any of it, no more will come. One must not tell anyone. If one does, one will get no more, or else one will incur some adversity that will end in one’s death. This is because these yakṣiṇīs are exceedingly secretive[2692] and discreet, and they will not tolerate another person being told about them.

tha na ma dang pha dang / gnyen bshes dang bdag po la yang smra bar mi bya'o/ / dud 'gro'i skyes gnas su song ba'i phyugs kyi srog chags la yang brjod par mi bya ste/ 'di ni mchog tu gsang ba yin te gsang ba pa thams cad dang gnod sbyin mo thams cad kyi'ang mchog 'di nyid do/ / gal te gzhan la brjod na ni grub pa yang mi 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / bud med gzhan dang rang gi chung ma la yang 'gro ba rtag tu spang bar bya'o/ / yid du 'ong ma'i sngags ni/

“One must not tell even one’s mother, father, friend, supervisor, or relative, not even a pet or another animal, as this is most secret. This rule[2693] applies to all the guhyakas and all the yakṣiṇīs. Even if they have been accomplished as an object of practice, they will cease to be so if one divulges the secret. Also, one must never approach other women for sex, not even one’s wife. “The mantra of Manojñā is:
oM ma no ha re mdot+sa ba ka ri pi tsi tra ru bi Ne mai thu na pri ye swA hA/
“Oṁ, you captivate the mind! You intoxicate and drive one insane! You are stunningly beautiful and fond of sex. Svāhā![2694]

de'i cho ga ni skyed mos tshal shing mya ngan med kyi rtsar shin tu dben par khang pa byed du bcug la shin tu rab tu dben par bya zhing / ra ba shin tu mtho ba la gser gyi sgo 'phar bya zhing gtsang mar byas la/ bzlas pa 'bum phrag gcig byas nas de nas las brtsam par bya ste/ zhag chen po blangs la dur khrod kyi skras snying po bya zhing sgo bcad la mar me sbar bar bya'o/ / ras kha tshar dang bcas shing skra dang bral bar ba tu gsar pa sgo'i phyi rol tu bzhag na/ mtshan mo de gcer bur 'ongs nas gos de bgos nas nang du 'jug cing / mi'i bud med kyi gzugs su byas shing de nas sgrub pa po de dang lhan cig ji srid mar me 'bar gyi bar du dga' bar byed do/ / mar me zad nas ni mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / de la gos gcig bcings te gos yongs su bzhag nas mal stan nas 'gro bar byed do/ / yang na sgrub pa pos lag pa'i sor gdub bzhag pa las sor gdub gnyis pa yang bzhag nas 'gro bar byed do/ / yang na gdu bu dang rked pa'i 'og pag dang rkang pa gnyis kyi rkang gdub dang mgo'i nor bu dang de bzhin du gzhan dang / gzhan lha'i rgyan gcig cig gang de khyer ba de dang de rjes su ster bar byed do/ / 'gro ba dang 'ong ba yang don med par mi byed do/ / de bzhin du nyin re zhing yang ma lus par thams cad zad par bya'o/ / de bzhin du zla ba drug na smra bar byed na/ de'i tshe smra bar byas na chung mar 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu gnas na bcud kyis len yang rab tu sbyin zhing / gang 'thungs pas dus rings por 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / yid kyis bsgoms nas seng ldeng gi phur bus sa brkos na lha'i gzhal med khang 'byung bar 'gyur la phyung na ni mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / 'di'i sngags gnyis pa yod pa ni/

“Her practice is as follows. One should build a secluded hut within a garden enclosure, below an aśoka tree. It should be well hidden and have a high wall with a paneled, bolted door. Maintaining purity, one should recite the mantra one hundred thousand times. “Afterward, one should perform the ritual. One should procure human fat, make a wick out of a textile from a charnel ground, firmly shut the door, and light a lamp. One should place a cloth that is hemmed, is brand new, and does not have any loose fibers on the outside of the door. At night, when Manojñā arrives naked, she will dress in this cloth and enter the hut, assuming the form of a female human. The practitioner will then enjoy sex with her for as long as the lamp is burning. “When the lamp burns out, Manojñā will disappear. She will leave the bed, leaving behind the cloth [that she wore] with a piece of gold tied in it. At that time one should grasp her by the hand. She will walk away, letting the rings slip off her fingers one by one. If one grasps [her] by the neck, she will relinquish her pearl necklace; if by the arm, she will let her arm bracelet slip off; if by the hips, her girdle; if by the feet, her anklets; and if by the head, her diadem. In this way, wherever one grasps her, from that place she will give a divine ornament, one after another.[2695] “Her departures and her arrivals are thus not without gain. As before, one must spend it all each day, so that there is nothing left. When six months have passed in this way, she will start talking. One should then join the conversation and she will become one’s wife. Ever present, she will procure the elixir of longevity, drinking which one will live long. If one drives a stake of cutch wood into the ground while performing the relevant visualization, a divine palace will appear. When the stake is pulled out, it will disappear. “The second mantra of Manojñā is:
oM ma hA nag+ni nag+ni dze swA hA/
“Oṁ, O great naked one! You were born naked! Svāhā![2696]

de nyid kyis mar me rab tu sbar la/ sngags 'dis lan brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags pa byas na nges par 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / phur bus mngon par bsngags pa byas nas brko bar bya'o/ / phur bu phyung zhing mar me zad na mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / phur bu dang mi'i zhag gi mar dang ba'i rwa'am ma he nag po'i rwa dang dur khrod kyi ras kyi snying po 'chang na/ yul gzhan du gang ci 'dod pa de yang ster bar byed do/ / yang na rang nyid bya ste sngags kyang gzhan la mi sbyin no/ / ci ste byin na ni rig pa chad par 'gyur ro/ / gang la byin pa de'i phun sum tshogs par 'gyur te/ gang 'dod pa de yang gnas dben par byed na 'di'i grub pa don med par mi 'gyur ro/ / yang na gzhan dang rtse bar ni byed de/ 'on kyang de dang lhan cig smra bar ni mi byed do/ / bud med gzhan dang phrad par mngon par 'dod pa'am yid la sems na yang de'i tshe zlos pa de'i gan du 'ong bar mi 'gyur te/ bud med gzhan dang ma phrad pa de'i dbang du 'gyur ba yin no/ / lha mdzes ma'i sngags ni/

“One should light a lamp made of exactly the same components as before and incant the lamp one hundred and eight times, thus compelling [Manojñā] to act. She will certainly arrive. Alternatively, one can incant a stake and drive it into the ground. When the stake is then pulled out, or when the lamp has burnt out, she will disappear. One may also take [the accessories]‍—the stake; the human fat in a horn of a cow, a gaur, or a buffalo; and the wick made of a charnel-ground rag‍—somewhere else, where one can do the rite oneself or give [the accessories] to a person of one’s choice. However, one must not pass on the mantra. If one does, one will nullify its magical power. “Whoever one gives [this paraphernalia] to, everything will turn out for them exactly the same way. Whatever the desired outcome, whatever the hidden location where the rite is performed, the accomplishment will not be in vain. Moreover, one can have other men experience the joy of sex, but should not discuss it with them. Because of the power of the practitioner, the compliant [Manojñā] will approach a new partner to her liking, who is longing to see other women.[2697] “The mantra of Surasundarī is:
oM su ra sun+da ri swA hA/
“Oṁ Surasundarī! Svāhā![2698]

'di'i cho ga ni seng ldeng gi shing gis me rab du sbar la/ mar gyi sreg blugs kyis zla ba gcig la dus gsum du sbyin sreg stong rtsa brgyad bya zhing / de nas yar ngo'i zla ba nya la bsang byed kyi khres la 'dug ste/ gtsang zhing gtsang ba'i sa phyogs dben par ji srid nam phyed pa de srid du sngags bzlas pa byas na nges par 'ong bar 'gyur zhing de nas ma dang sring mo dang chung ma sngar ji lta ba de thams cad byed par 'gyur te/ thams cad kyang rgya cher brjod par bya'o/ /

“Her practice is as follows. One should light a fire with sticks of cutch wood and offer into it one thousand and eight oblations of ghee at the three junctions of the day, for a period of one month. Then, during the full moon, one should sit on a bundle of kuśa grass in a clean, secluded place, and, oneself pure, recite the mantra until midnight, and she will certainly come. Then, one should carry out everything exactly as before, choosing her as one’s mother, sister, or wife, and saying everything just as before.

bdun po 'di dag gnod sbyin ma/ / phyag na rdo rje'i bka' yis kyang / / lha dang lha min khams gsum du/ / sa rnams kun tu yongs su rgyu/ / mi yul dag na sbyor bar dga'/ / snying rjer ldan zhing rnam par rgyu/ / kha cig phag ma byis pa dang / / gnod sbyin ma gzhan blun pa'o/ / gzhan dag phan byed 'tshe ba yang / / de bzhin mtshan mo yongs su rgyu/ / byis pa'i 'tsho ba 'phrog pa'i phyir/ / bskam zhing sha ni za byed gzhan/ / gang phyir 'dzam gling 'ongs pa ni/ / de bzhin khrag la chags byed pa'o/ / rtag tu srog la gnod byed pa'i/ / khrag la dga' ba'i gnod sbyin mo/ / srung byed 'chi dang bcas gyur pa'i/ / khyim ni kun tu yongs su rgyu/ / de dag tshar bcad bsgrub don du/ / dam tshig 'di ni rab tu bstan/ / ji ltar 'dod chags 'ching ba la/ / byis pa rnams ni bsdus pa'i don/ / sems can rnams la phan pa'i phyir/ / de ltar 'di kun gsungs pa yin/ /

“By Vajrapāṇi’s command, These seven yakṣiṇīs Roam the entire earth, As well as the triple universe with its gods and demigods. “Fond of sex with mortals, They associate with[2699] those who have compassion.[2700] Some yakṣiṇīs[2701] are noble, While others are naive and foolish. “Yet others wander at night, Assuming the form of a lion. Fond of eating flesh, They are eager to take the life of children.[2702] “They come to Jambūdvīpa Attracted by the scent of blood. Such yakṣiṇīs, ever fond of blood, Take the life force away. “They visit all the unprotected[2703] houses In which children have died. This samaya has been taught For the purpose of restraining these yakṣiṇīs.[2704] “All this has been taught To benefit beings By attracting, impassioning, and binding Such foolish yakṣiṇīs.[2705]

'dod chags kyis ldongs sems rmongs pa'i/ / gang tshe sngags pa 'khrig don gnyer/ / sngags kyis bkug byas longs spyad pa/ / gnod sbyin mo'am srin mo'am/ / klu mo'am yang na dri za 'am/ / mi 'am ci 'am lha min ma/ / lha min lha bas mchog gyur pa'i/ / sa 'og gnas ni nyams dga' bar/ / gang du bud med grangs med pa/ / sngags shes der ni rab tu 'jug / sngags shes sngags ni zlos pa dag / der song bskal par gnas par 'gyur/ / byams pa zhes bya'i rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / sangs rgyas chen po 'byung 'gyur te/ / de tshe de ni dam chos thos/ / thos nas rab tu grol bar 'gyur/ /
