“If the mantra practitioner is motivated by sex, Blinded by passion, and deluded in mind, He may, having summoned her by the means of mantras, Carnally enjoy a yakṣiṇī, a rākṣasī, A nāginī, a gandharvī, A daitya lady, or a kinnarī. “A mantra adept may likewise enter Pleasant subterranean palaces And the finest cities of the asuras, With infinite numbers of women. Once there, such a mantra reciter and adept Will live[2706] for one eon. “When Maitreya, a fully realized buddha, Becomes [the next] Buddha, He will teach the sacred Dharma, upon the hearing of which The mantra adept will become liberated.[2707]

lha dang lha min bu mo dang / / rig 'dzin bu mo dam pa dag / sngags kyis bkug nas spyod byed cing / / de tshe lha yi bde bas dga'/ / sngags pa 'dzam bu'i gling gnas pas/ / de nyid du ni rtag 'dren pa/ / gang tshe gtsang gnas gsang ba dang / / gtsang sbra spyod la rtag dga' ba'o/ / grub pa dam pa rmongs rnams la/ / nam yang sems la 'byung mi 'gyur/ / bshang gci mi gtsang gnas dang ni/ / rtag tu dri nga rul ba dang / / nad kyis sdug bsngal mya ngan dang / / tha mar 'chi zhing sdug bsngal snod/ / bral ba'i rnam par yang dag ldan/ / mi yi bud med reg mi bya/ /

“Having summoned with mantras A celestial girl, an asurī, Or the finest vidyādhara lady, He will enjoy with her the divine bliss of sex. “A mantra follower who lives in Jambūdvīpa Can always summon her there. Then, in a clean and hidden place, He always delights in pure conduct. “The highest accomplishment Will never arise for fools. One should never touch a human female,[2708] Who, full of piss and shit, is always a seat of impurity, “Foul-smelling and putrid. She is a receptacle of suffering, destined to die, And afflicted by disease and grief. Sex with her will end in separation.[2709]

mi rtag sdug bsngal stong pa dang / / stong pa gsog dang ther zug med/ / byis pa rnams ni rjes brid dang / / kun tu rtogs las byung ba la/ / thog ma med las 'dod kun 'byung / / sngags pas 'dod pa bsten mi bya/ / de dag chags bral zhes gsungs te/ / rnam grol de dag grub pa nyid/ / gang zhig 'dod la chags bral ba/ / 'di yi sngags ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / bshang gci khrag gis brlan pa dang / / rul bas kun tu khyab pa dang / / rga dang 'chi dang mya ngan bcas/ / mi yi lus la reg mi bya/ / rmongs pa'am chags pa'i sems kyis ni/ / der ni 'khrig pa brten mi bya/ / de dag rtag tu mi gtsang brten/ / sngags kyi grub pa rnyed mi 'gyur/ / sngags shes sngags kyi gzugs can dang / / shes ldan dbang po thul ba dang / / dpa' bo gtsang ba'i spyod la dga'/ / rtag tu de yi sngags kyang 'grub/ / pad+ma mtho ma rab dga' ma/ / mi pham ma dang rtag rgyal dang / / sngo bsangs ldan pa'i gnod sbyin mo/ / rdzu 'phrul che 'di gnod sbyin mo/ /

“She is impermanent, a source of suffering, Empty, vacant, void, and will not last. She is the deceiver of the naive And a source of false concepts. “The mantra practitioner should not indulge, out of desire, In any passions that have been arising since beginningless time. Emancipation attained in their midst Is referred to as their cessation.[2710] “One’s mantras will succeed If they are not motivated by desire. One should worship those that possess ambrosia And are unstained by feces, urine, and blood.[2711] “One should not touch the body of a woman That is subject to old age, death, and great anguish. One should not have sex with her, As she is blinded by delusion and concupiscent at heart. The mantra practitioner will not attain accomplishment If he approaches them sexually, remaining ever impure. “On the other hand, a mantra reciter and adept[2712] Who has insight, has conquered his senses, And delights in pure conduct Can always master any mantra.[2713] “Other yakṣiṇīs with great magical power Are, invariably, Padmoccā, Pramodā, Ajitā, and Jayā,[2714] As well as the yakṣiṇī Śyāmāvatī.
pad+ma mtho ma'i sngags ni/
“The mantra of Padmoccā is:
oM pad+ma uts+tshe swA hA/
“Oṁ Padmoccā! Svāhā![2715]

'di'i cho ga ni gang gA'i ngogs sam rgya mtsho'i ngogs sam skyed mos tshal gyi me tog gi ldum ra'i nang du lo ma'i spyil po byas te rab tu gtsang zhing bdag nyid kyang gtsang bar byas la/ rdo'am sa'i sgo glegs byas la de nyid du mtshan mo sgo bcad nas 'dod pa'i yo byad kyi longs spyod rnams bsogs te/ de nyid du bdag nyid dang nye bar gnod sbyin mo'i mal yang bsham par bya ste/ rig pa stong phrag bcu bzlas pa byas la/ de bzhin du zla ba gcig byas na nges par 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / 'ongs nas kyang 'dod pa la longs spyad par byas na/ mu tig gi phreng ba bzang po mal du yongs su bor nas tho rangs 'gro bar 'gyur te/ ji srid zla ba drug gi bar du nyin re zhing rtag tu gnas par 'gyur ro/ / gal te mu tig gi phreng ba de len na ni de tsam kho nar yod par 'gyur la/ phreng ba rin po che chen pos nye bar mdzes par byas pa de ni ti na ra 'bum ri ba yin no/ / zla ba drug 'das nas ni rtag tu gnas par 'gyur ro/ / chung ma 'dod pa thams cad ster bar byed pa ji ltar rjes su mthun pa 'dod pa de ltar rjes su mthun par byas te/ nye bar gnas par byed do/ / sgrub pa pos 'dod pa bzhin du ji ltar 'dod pa bdag nyid kyis mngon par sprul bar byed do/ / gnod sbyin mo thams cad kyi cho ga yang 'di yin no/ / ji ltar bstan pa 'di dang gzhan du yang sbyar bar bya'o/ / rgyal ba ma'i sngags ni/

“Her practice is as follows. One should build a hut on the banks of the Gaṅgā, in the ocean shore, or in a flower garden. The hut and oneself should be clean. Using clay, one should make a form shaped like a stone slab[2716] and firmly shut the door. One should collect all the requisites for making love and prepare a bed for the yakṣiṇī next to one’s own. One should then recite her vidyā ten thousand times. “If one continues in this manner, she will certainly arrive within one month. When she does, one should make love to her and she will become one’s wife.[2717] She will leave in the morning, leaving behind a celestial pearl necklace. And so it will be every day, until, within six months, she will remain permanently. One must not hold on to that pearl necklace. If one does, this will be the only thing one will ever get.[2718] This necklace, adorned with jewels and gems, is worth one hundred thousand dinars. “After six months have passed, Padmoccā will remain permanently as a wife who fulfills all desires. Whatever form one wants her to assume, she will attend upon one in that form. She will magically transform herself into the form that is pleasing to the practitioner, according to his wish. This procedure applies to all the yakṣiṇīs. The instructions given for the yakṣiṇīs here apply also to other yakṣiṇīs. “The mantra of Jayā is:
oM dza ye su dza ye dza ya ma ti sarba kAr+yA Ni me ku ru swA hA/
“Oṁ Jayā, auspicious Jayā, one who is victorious! Perform all the tasks for me! Svāhā![2719]

gser mdog lus ni sna tshogs lus/ / sngo zhing 'khyil pa'i skra dang ldan/ / lha mo yan lag kun mdzes ma/ / zhi ba'i 'od ldan skal ldan dge/ / snyan smra sgeg ldan gtso mo ste/ / mu tig 'od ldan mthong na mdzes/ / rab bsngags gzugs ldan smin ma ma mdzes/ / 'jig rten kun gyis legs par mchod/ / cung zad dmar ba'i gos gyon pa/ / de ni rgyal mar mngon par ston/ /

“Her fine body has a golden glow, And her curly hair is blue. This goddess is beautiful in every limb, Gentle, gracious, and charming. “She is an intoxicating speaker of pleasant words And a superior woman with a beautiful form, pleasant to look at.[2720] Bright with her excellent features like the evening star,[2721] She is worshiped by the whole world. Wearing, in addition, a soft-red garment‍— This is how Jayā is described.

'di'i cho ga ni dang po 'bum phrag gcig bzlas pa byas na sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / de nas dgon pa chen por rab tu zhugs nas/ 'bras bu'i zas za zhing ji srid du rang nyid kyi gzugs kyis 'ong ba de'i bar du bzlas pa bya'o/ / 'ongs nas kyang smra ba ni ci zhig bya zhes so/ / gal te mar gyur na ni ma bzhin du re ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed cing / rgyal thabs ster bar byed la nor gyi bdag po chen po yang byed la tshe ring ba nyid du yang gnas par 'gyur ro/ / ci ste sring mor 'gyur na ni dpag tshad stong du gnas kyang ji ltar 'dod pa'i bud med 'gugs par byed de nyin re zhing yang ti na ra 'bum sbyin par byed de de yang zad par bya'o/ / ci ste chung mar gyur na ni rang gi gnas su khyer te/ lha'i gzhal med khang du 'dzegs nas/ de dang lhan cig dga' bar byed cing / dus ring por lo stong phrag sum cu'i bar du ji ltar 'dod par rnam par spyod de/ gnod sbyin chen po dang 'dra bar 'gyur ro/ / rab tu dga' ma'i sngags ni/ /

“Her practice is as follows. First, one should recite her mantra one hundred thousand times; this constitutes the preliminary service. Then, one should go to a large forest and, living on fruits, recite her mantra until Jayā arrives in person. When she does, she will ask, ‘What can I do for you?’ If she becomes one’s mother, she will, like a mother, fulfill one’s every wish. She will grant a kingdom, make one the owner of great wealth, and ensure that one lives a long life. “If she becomes one’s sister, she will summon a woman as desired even from a distance of one thousand leagues. Every single day she will give one hundred thousand dinars. One must spend all of this. If she becomes one’s wife, she will take one to her own abode. Living in a celestial palace, one will engage in a delightful play with her for a long time. For thirty thousand years, one will do whatever one likes, equal to the great yakṣa.[2722] “The mantra of Pramodā is:
oM hr-i Sh+TI ma hA nag+ni hUM phaT swA hA/
“Oṁ ṣṭhrīḥ hrīḥ! O great nude! Hūṁ, phaṭ, svāhā![2723]

'di'i cho ga ni mtshan phyed kyi bar du bzlas pa grangs med pa byas te/ phyir yang gnyid log par ma byas na zla ba gcig gi nang du nges par 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ / chung mar 'gyur na ni 'dod pa thams cad sbyin par byed de/ nyin re zhing ti na ra nyi shu rtsa lnga rab tu sbyin par byed do/ / rang gi mdzod nyid kyang ston par byed do/ / dus ring por yang 'tsho bar byed do/ / de bzhin du gnod sbyin mo brgya stong phrag du ma yang yod do/ / de bzhin du sha za mo dang sha za mo rdzu 'phrul che ba dang / klu'i bu mo dang / lha ma yin gyi bu mo dang / lha'i bud med dang / lha ma yin gyi bud med dang / de bzhin du rig pa 'dzin pa thams cad kyi bud med dang mi dang mi ma yin pa thams cad kyi sngags grangs med pa dag kyang yod do/ / de bzhin du gnod sbyin rnams dang / lha rnams dang / klu rnams dang / drang srong rnams dang / dri za rnams dang / lha ma yin rnams dang / yi dgas rnams dang / srin po rnams dang / tshangs pa chen po dang / dbang phyug chen po dang / khyab 'jug dang / ma mo rnams dang / dbang mo dang / rgan byad ma dang / phag mo la sogs pa'i sngags rnams kyang yod de/ so so so sor thams cad dam tshig gis 'dir bkug nas khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed kyis zos pa dang dam tshig la bzhag cing / 'jam pa'i dbyangs la nye bar gtad nas rjes su 'brang bar 'gyur te/ go rims bzhin du gnas shing bsnyen bkur yang byed do/ /

“Her practice is as follows. One should recite her mantra at midnight without counting. If one does not go back to sleep, Pramodā will certainly arrive within one month. She will become a wife who fulfills every desire. Every single day she will provide twenty-five dinars and offer sexual delights personally. In addition, she will ensure long life for the practitioner. “There are uncountable hundreds of thousands of yakṣiṇīs. So, too, there are innumerable piśācīs of great power,[2724] nāga girls, asura girls, apsarases, girls of the lower celestial (sura) orders, and daitya girls. The same is true for the vidyādharīs and all the human and nonhuman females. All of them without exception have their respective mantras, which are likewise innumerable. In the same way there are mantras of the male yakṣas, gods, nāgas, ṛṣis, gandharvas, asuras, pretas, and rākṣasas; of Mahābrahmā, Maheśvara, and Viṣṇu; and also of the mātṛs, headed by Indrāṇī, Cāmuṇḍā, and Vārāhī. All these beings have been individually summoned here on this occasion. They have been brought here by Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka, seized[2725] by him, established in the samaya, and thus made subordinate to Mañjughoṣa. They stand here in the right order as his retinue and attendants.

thams cad kyi yang mdor bsdu na 'khrul 'khor gyi gzugs sam de nyid kyi gzugs brnyan byas nas khro bo'i rgyal po gshin rje gshed kyi rig pa ci srid gzugs brnyan rab tu 'gul ba'am rab tu g.yo ba'am rdul 'byung ba'i bar du bzlas pa byas na rang nyid kyi gzugs kyis 'ong bar 'gyur te/ gang smras pa de thams cad yang dag par sgrub par byed do/ / de bzhin du gang gzhan yang gzhon nu ma bzhi gnod sbyin ma chen po'i ming po tum bu ru zhes bya ba yang dag par rten pa/ gru'i theg pa la yang dag par zhon pa/ 'jig rten thams cad kyis rab tu mchod pa/ sems can rnams rjes su 'dzin par byed pa de dag kyang cho ga 'di bzhin du bya'o/ /

“[The rite] for each of them, in short, is as follows. One should recite the Lord of Wrath[2726] Yamāntaka‍—either in a place where there is an image or having made such an image oneself[2727]‍—until the image shakes and then moves or starts perspiring. Then [the being portrayed in the image] will arrive in its own form and will do everything it is asked to. “In the same way, one can [practice] also the ‘four virgins.’ These great yakṣiṇīs, who have Tumburu as their brother, live, in their celestial forms,[2728] upon the ocean aboard a boat. They practice kindness to beings and are worshiped by the whole world. The same procedure[2729] may be used also for them, namely,

dper na ras sam rtsig pa'am spang leb la mtsho'i dkyil du bri bar bya ste/ gru'i theg pa la zhon pa phu bo ming po'i rjes su 'gro ba bu mo bzhi po nyid kyang rgya mtsho'i nang du zhugs shing mnyam par 'dug pa'o/ /

“They should be either drawn or etched On a piece of cloth, a slab of stone, or a plank, Riding in a boat, Where they attend to their elder brother.[2730] “These four girls travel together Within the confines of the ocean.

de dag mi snang gnas bzhag nas/ / khro bo'i bzlas pa yang dag brtsam/ / de tshe g.yo 'gul rdul 'byung bar/ / de dag kun ni skye 'gyur bar/ / de tshe grub pa yin shes nas/ / sngags kyi bzlas pa yongs su btang / / mtshan mo'i tha mar rang tshul nyid/ / dge dang mi dge ston par 'gyur/ / skad cig gis ni zlos pa yis/ / don rnams thams cad sgrub par 'gyur/ /

One should set up their image in a hidden place And begin the practice by reciting the [Lord of] Wrath. “They[2731] will start moving, shaking, Or sweating all over. Knowing by this that they are accomplished,[2732] The mantra reciter should stop reciting. “Appearing, at the end of the night, in their usual form, They will tell the practitioner what is good and what is bad for him. They will accomplish The reciter’s every aim.[2733]

khro bos bkug cing rgyas byas nas/ / smras pa thams cad byed par 'gyur/ / rtag tu nyi ma sogs kyi gza'/ / de bzhin drang srong srin po dang / / nam mkha' lding dang sha zas kyang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po de dag mchod/ / dbang phyug che sogs 'byung pos kyang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po de dag mchod/ / de dag gis bshad cho ga dang / / sngags rgyud rgya che bcas pa yi/ / thams cad de dag khro rgyal gyi/ / 'bad pa med par dbang du 'gyur/ / gang dag sngags ni ci yod pa/ / khro bo 'chol ba rnyog 'byung ba/ / de kun khro bo'i rgyal po yi/ / de dag bsgo ba mnyan par bstan/ /

“Summoned and stunned[2734] by [Lord of] Wrath, They will do everything as commanded. Soma and other prominent planets, The ṛṣis, the rākṣasas, “The piśācas, and the garuḍas Worship these four powerful sisters. Also Maheśvara and other gods like him Worship these majestic ladies. “They[2735] also taught their extensive rituals And their own mantra systems. All of them may be employed, Along with their extensive rites. All these [mantra deities] remain in the thrall Of Lord of Wrath, without any effort on his part. “However many mantras there are That originate from impure spirits and dry up [the life of beings],[2736] All of them were taught And prescribed by Lord of Wrath.[2737]

gang yang 'phags pa'i sngags dag ni/ / thams cad kun 'gro'i khyad par can/ / mchog dang rab mchog drag po dang / / gang yang de bzhin rgyal bas gsungs/ / de bzhin pad+ma 'dzin sngags dang / / bdag nyid kyis kyang rab bshad dang / / gang yang gzhan gyi sngags mchog ni/ / rigs lnga dag gis gsungs pa dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'jig rten pa'i/ / rgyal ba'i sras kyis gsungs pa dag / khro bo'i rgyal po rdzu 'phrul ches/ / thams cad de dag yang dag 'gugs/ / sngags dang rgyud ni thams cad kun/ / bstan pa 'di la nges par 'brel/ / gang zhig gang dag cho gar bstan/ / de nyid 'dir ni nges par sbyar/ / gshin rje gshed ni khro rgyal gyi/ / las kun byed pa'i mchog yin no/ /

“The noble and distinguished mantras, on the other hand, That are universally applicable, The foremost mantras, exalted and excellent,[2738] Were taught by the eminent victors And also by myself In the capacity of the mantra holder.[2739] “Whatever other prominent mantras there are That are associated with [any of] the five families‍— Those taught by the sons of the victors And also the powerful worldly mantras‍— “The powerful Lord of Wrath Has collected all of them And included them in this teaching[2740] Along with the mantra methods for all of them. “Whatever procedure was designated for whatever mantra, He prescribed for that mantra precisely that procedure. As for the [mantra of] Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka, however, It is supremely suited for every activity.

sgrol ma khro gnyer can nyid dang / / de bzhin gos dkar mo dang ni/ / de bzhin dkar chen rigs ma dang / / rdo rje'i rigs 'byung mA ma kI/ gtsug tor 'byung ba thams cad dang / / lha mo spyan ni nyid dag dang / / de bzhin gshegs kun rig pa dang / / mthu chen thob dang kun bzang dang / / pad+ma 'dzin pa'i mnga' bdag dang / / bdag kyang 'jig rten gnod sbyin bdag / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / rgyal sras rmad du byung ba dang / / dpung bzang 'jig rten rnam par grags/ / rdo rje'i sde dang sde bzang dang / / blo ldan chos kyis 'phags pa dang / / bdag gis kyang ni bshad pa'i sngags/ / zlos pas brnyas par mi bya'o/ /

“The mantras[2741] of Tārā, Bhṛkuṭī, and Pāṇḍaravāsinī; Those of the vidyā Mahāśvetā And of Māmakī of the Vajra family; “The mantras of every female uṣṇīṣa emanation[2742]‍— In particular of the goddess Locanā‍— And of every [other] vidyā from the Tathāgata family; The mantras of the sagacious Mañjughoṣa,[2743] “Mahāsthāmaprāpta, Samantabhadra, And the lord Padmapāṇi;[2744] The mantras that I have taught Of the lord of the yakṣas,[2745] a very powerful bodhisattva, “And of the [other] victors’ sons That are known throughout the whole world; The mantras of my sagacious sons Vajrasena and Suṣena[2746]‍— “All these mantras, which I have taught, Must not be disparaged.

sngon du rtag tu mchod bya zhing / / legs gsungs de dag bgom mi bya/ / khro bo'i rgyal po legs mchod cing / / der ni zlos pas sbyar mi bya/ / dus rnams kun tu sngags dag la/ / de dag rig pa bcad mi bya/ / ji bzhin las ni kun la yang / / 'jig rten sngags kyi lha dag ni/ / dka' zlog bde byed tshangs sogs dang / / lha chen la yang legs par mchod/ / ji ltar rgyud la sngags rnams ni/ / de bzhin nyid du'ang kun la bya/ / thams cad sngags ni kun la yang / / thams cad nyid du'ang yang dag bstan/ / sngags kun rab tu 'jug pa yang / / khro bo las ni yang dag 'byung / /

All of them[2747] must be worshiped, and, it is taught, Never transgressed against. “The reciter must not employ The venerable Lord of Wrath against them[2748] And must never break his vidyā[2749] connection With these mantra deities. “One may practice all the worldly Mantra deities, according to the rite, Such as Umā, Śaṅkara, Brahmā, Or the venerable Hari, Using the mantras as found in the respective tantras And performing the rites, for each of them, accordingly. “One may do every rite Of every mantra deity in every way With the knowledge, however, that the action Of every [such] mantra derives from [Lord of] Wrath.

sngags 'di khro bo chen po ni/ / gshin rje gshed ces bya ming gis/ / bdag nyid chen po gshin rje yang / / myur du bkug nas 'joms par byed/ / nyi ma'i bu ni gshin rje dang / / brgya byin bdag nyid chen po yang / / bkug nas dbang med mi bzad pa/ / gdul dka' 'dul byed mnga' bdag yin/ / sngags 'di sngags ni chen po ste/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis bshad pa yin/ / ma rungs las rnams thams cad byed/ / sngags kun rab tu sgrub par byed/ /

“The mantra Lord of Wrath, Known by the name of Yamāntaka, Can swiftly summon and strike Even the great being Yama. “Also, the great beings such as Śakra, or Vaivasvata who brings death, Can be summoned and enthralled. This terrible lord is the tamer of the hard to tame. “This mantra is the great mantra taught By the sweet-spoken Mañjughoṣa. It is suitable for all rites, is fierce, And makes all other mantras effective.”

de skad smras nas dpal ldan ni/ / lag na rdo rje rdzu 'phrul ches/ / shAkya seng ge mi yi mchog / dpa' chen sangs rgyas la btud nas/ / sngags 'khor rten pa'i rdo rje can/ / rdzu 'phrul can gyis sngags rnams gsungs/ / 'byung po kun tshogs dge ba ni/ / sems can kun gyis mnyan pa yin/ / sngags rnams kun tshogs lta byed pa/ / sngags kyi mchog ni bdag gis bshad/ /

Having said this, venerable Vajrapāṇi, One of great miraculous power, Bowed to the Buddha, the Lion of the Śākyas, The great hero supreme among men. Then the vajra holder who dwells in the circle of mantra beings Taught the mantra of great magical power. “Listen, all of you sentient beings, And all of you virtuous hosts of spirits, And all of you overseers of the hosts of mantras![2750] I will teach this supreme mantra
blo dang ldan pa 'jam pa'i dbyangs/ / byang chub sems dpas bshad pa yin/ / mi bzad gdul dka' 'dul byed pa/ / ma rungs thams cad zlog par byed/ /
“That was taught by the sagacious Bodhisattva Mañjughoṣa, A terrible mantra that tames those difficult to tame And restrains all the wicked ones.[2751]
“It was taught by the bodhisattva [Mañjughoṣa] In order to guide sentient beings. Now I will pronounce this terrible [mantra] In the midst of this assembly.

namaHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a b+hA ba swa b+hA ba mung+ga tA nAM/ namaHpra t+ye ka bud d+hA nAM Ar+ya shra ba kA nAM/ na mo bo d+hi sa twA nAM/ da sha b+hU mi pra tiSh+Thi te shwa rA nAM/ bo d+hi sa twA nAM/ ma hA sa twA nAM/ tad+ya thA/

“Homage to all the buddhas who arise out of the absence of the independent existence of entities! Homage to the pratyekabuddhas and the noble śrāvakas! Homage to the bodhisattvas, the lords established on the ten levels, the great beings! This is the mantra proper:

oM kha kha khA hi khA hi/ duSh+Ta sa twa da ma ka a si mu sa la par+shu pA sha hasta/ tsa tur+b+hu dza/ tsa turmu kha/ Sha Ta tsa ra Na/ gats+tsha gats+tsha/ sarba big+h+na big+h+nAn+te ka / bi krI tA nan/ sarba b+hU ta b+ha yaM kar/ aT+TAT+Ta hA sa ni nA di ne/ bya g+h+ra tsarma ni bA sa na/ ku ru ku ru/ sarba d+harmA na/ ts+tshin+da ts+tshin+da/ sarba man+t+rAn/ b+hin+d+ha b+hin+d+ha/ pa ra mu drAn/ A kar+Sha ya/ A kar+Sha ya/ sarba b+hU tAn/ nirma tha nirma tha/ sarba duSh+Ta na/ pra be sha ya pra be sha ya/ maN+Da la ma d+h+ye/ bai ba swa ta dzI bi tAn+ta ka ra/ ku ru ku ru ma ma sarba kAr+yam/ da ha da ha/ pa tsa pa tsa/ mA bi lam+ba/ mA bi lam+ba/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ hUM hUM phaT/ s+pho Ta ya s+pho Ta ya/ sarba A sha pa ri pU ra ka/ he b+ha ga bAn kiny+tsi rA ya si ma ma sarbAmar+thaM sA d+ha ya swA hA/

“Oṁ, kha kha! Devour, devour! O tamer of evil beings, with a sword, a club, a noose, and an axe in your hands! One with four arms, four faces, and six feet, go, go! O great destroyer of obstacles with a contorted face, inspiring fear in all nonhuman beings! You who roar with wild laughter and wear a tiger skin, perform, perform all tasks! Cut, cut all the mantras [of non-believers]! Break, break the mudrās of non-believers! Draw here, draw all nonhuman beings! Grind, grind all the wicked ones! Cause them to enter into the center of the maṇḍala! O terminator of the life of Vaivasvata, perform, perform tasks for me! Burn, burn! Cook, cook! Do not delay, do not delay! Remember your samaya pledge! Hūṁ hūṁ! Phaṭ phaṭ! Split, split! Fulfiller of all wishes! O blessed one, why do you tarry? Please accomplish all my aims! Svāhā![2752] [S578]

“Friends, and you, all the hosts of gods! This [mantra] called Yamāntaka, Great Lord of Wrath, will summon, crush, dry up, cook, and tame even the king Yama. It will likewise summon all the mantra deities and all the gods, not to mention human beings afflicted with suffering. It will summon even the bodhisattvas established on the ten levels, let alone [the deities of] worldly mantras. “The power and strength of the Lord of Wrath is thus immeasurable. He can perform all the activities of all the mantras, whatever are taught in all the mantra systems. Once he is mastered by reciting, he will accomplish whatever he is employed to do.” This completes [the section on] the lord of wrath named Yamāntaka.

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ gnod sbyin mo sgrub pa'i cho ga rab 'byam las le'u sum cu rtsa lnga pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the fifty-second[2753] chapter, which is the detailed third chapter with the ritual prescriptions pertaining to Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka, from “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings. This also concludes [the section on] the ritual of Lord of Wrath Yamāntaka. Homage to the Buddha!
Chapter 53

Blessed Śākyamuni, having now emerged from his samādhi,[2754] continued to teach the Dharma to the assembly that resembled a great ocean. There, sitting in front of all the [assembled] beings and hosts of spirits, were uncountable thousands of bodhisattvas, headed by Vajrapāṇi; uncountable thousands of arhats, headed by Śāriputra; innumerable gods devoted to the four great kings, headed by Vaiśravaṇa; innumerable gods from the realm of the Thirty-Three, headed by Śakra; as well as innumerable gods from the realms of Suyāma, Tuṣita, Nirmāṇarati, Paranirmita, Vaśavartin, Brahmakāyika, Brahmapurohita, Mahābrahmā, Parīttābha, Apramāṇa, Ābhāsvara, and so forth, until Puṇyaprasava, Bṛhatphala, Avṛha, Atapas, and Akaniṣṭha. The Blessed One addressed them as follows: “Listen, venerable hosts of gods, and all of you bodhisattvas and noble śrāvakas! “All conditioned things are impermanent, Being characterized by arising and ceasing. Having arisen, they [temporarily] cease. Their definitive cessation is bliss. “They all originate from ignorance And arise based on causes. The aggregates are then said to arise From the same cause that constitutes the root of suffering. “Knowledge is their arrester;
de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ /
sdug bsngal spang zhing bde bya ba/ / sdug bsngal spang zhes bstan pa ni/ / mdor bsdus na ni bzlog pa yin/ /

de nyid theg pa rnam gsum du/ / nga yi 'di ni bstan pa yin/ / mi rtag sdug bsngal bdag med dang / / 'dus byas thams cad skad cig nyid/ / gsob dang rtag tu kun stong par/ / 'khor ba'i 'ching ba nges par bstan/ / de las chags bral rnam gsum 'gro/ / sems can dge la brten pa yin/ / byang chub sems dang sangs rgyas dang / / rang rgyal byang chub la brten dang / / 'dod chags bral ba rdzu 'phrul che/ / de bzhin gzhan dag dgra bcom nyid/ / nyan thos byang chub la brten nas/ / rnam gsum zhi ba thob par byed/ /

“That is the very reason that I taught a threefold vehicle. Everything conditioned changes from moment to moment; It is all impermanent, suffused with suffering, and lacking self-essence. “The entire prison of existence is taught As being empty at all times. Beings who belong to the Buddha family and have developed An aversion to this prison are divided into three groups: “(1) The bodhisattvas who later become buddhas, (2) Those who attain awakening on their own,[2757] And further there are (3) the arhats, Devoid of passion and very powerful. “The arhats attain the awakening of the śrāvakas And obtain the three types of peace.

chos 'di dag ni mdor bsdu na/ / dge dang mi dge bstan pa yin/ / rtag tu mi dge spang bya ste/ / dus rnams kun tu dge ba spyad/ / 'byung po kun la mi 'tshe bar/ / ngas ni chos kyang rab tu bstan/ / 'gro ba lnga po'i lam nyid du/ / chos 'di nyid ni 'gyur ba yin/ / gang zhig zag med chos rnams ni/ / yang dag mtha' la yang dag brten/ / dang po'i sangs rgyas snga ma yis/ / 'di nyid lam du gsungs pa yin/ / zhi ba mya ngan 'das 'gro bar/ / ngas kyang thams cad bstan pa yin/ / chos kyi mtha' la brten nas ni/ / yang dag mtha' ni thob pa yin/ / chos rnams kun gyi mtha' med pa/ / yang dag mtha' zhes brjod pa yin/ /

In short, I gave this teaching To show what is virtuous and what is not. “One should always shun nonvirtue And practice virtue at all times. The Dharma that is taught Is to never harm any sentient being. “Regarding the dharmas of the five destinies, Only one constitutes the path‍— It is the dharma that is free from karmic influences And is rooted in ultimate reality. “It is the same path that was taught By the primordial buddhas of the past. I also taught it in full, Propelling beings toward the peace of nirvāṇa. “Relying on this ultimate dharma, One will attain the ultimate reality‍— The ultimate reality that is described As the absence of limits common to all the dharmas.
chos 'di dag ni mdor bsdus nas/ / nyon cig lha ni thams cad dang / / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / dgra bcom nyan thos dag kyang nyon/ /
“This dharma, in short, Has been explained as twofold. Listen, all you gods, And you bodhisattvas with great powers! “Arhats, śrāvakas, listen to me!

nga ni sa steng mya ngan 'da'/ / kha ba can gyi nang dag tu/ / sA la'i nags ni yang dag 'byung / / gser dang ldan pa'i chu bo dang / / gyad rnams kyi ni nye 'khor du/ / sA la zung gi nags nang du/ / nga ni mya ngan 'da' bar 'gyur/ / grong khyer ming ni sdig pa can/ / cod pan bcings pa'i mchod rten dang / / chu bo'i 'gram ni rtag nyams dga'/ / der ni sa steng mya ngan 'da'/ / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / / rdzu 'phrul che ldan nyan thos dang / / lha dang klu dang gnod sbyin dang / / 'jig rten skyong ba rdzu 'phrul che/ / brgya byin tshangs bcas 'dab bzang dang / / gzhan yang 'og min la sogs lha/ / der ni thams cad 'dus par ni/ / rab tu 'byung bar 'gyur ba yin/ /

When I attain nirvāṇa on earth, It will be[2758] in the middle of the Sāla Grove At the foothills of the Himalayas, “On the banks of the Hiraṇyavatī That flows through the country of the Mallas. There, in the middle of the Yamakasāla Grove, I will attain nirvāṇa. “In the city named Pāvā, Near the Makuṭabandhana shrine, On the pleasant bank of the river, I will attain nirvāṇa on earth. “All the bodhisattvas, The śrāvakas with great magical powers, The gods, nāgas, and yakṣas, The powerful guardians of the world, “The Śakras, Brahmās, and Suyāmas, As well as the gods of Akaniṣṭha, and so forth‍— All of them will gather At that place.

der ni gyad kyi nye 'khor dang / / gang gA'i byang phyogs 'gram dag ni/ / chu bo chen po de las gzhan/ / kha ba can ri'i lho phyogs char/ / sA la'i nags zhes bya ba 'byung / / de tshe nub phyogs bltas pa'i mal/ / de yi gnas su 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de tshe chu bo rab dga' ba/ / bzang po gser ldan 'gram dag tu/ / lha rnams kun gyi tshogs la sogs/ / 'dus pa dag ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ / mi dang rgyal po'i mchog rnams dang / / mi dang mi ma yin pa 'byung / / de tshe mi dang 'byung po kun/ / de tshe byis pa 'phags pa dang / / dga' ston chen po dga' chen ltar/ / gnas de la ni yang dag 'dus/ / rang lus zang zing bcas par ni/ / bzang po chen po'i bkod pa'ang byas/ / chos kyi mtha' ni yongs spangs nas/ / yang dag mthar ni yang dag zhugs/ /

“There, in the Yamakasāla Grove,[2759] In the country of the Mallas, Between the northern bank of the Gaṅgā And the western bank of the Mahī, “On the south side of the Himalayas, In the Sāla Grove‍— In that place there will also be My final resting place.[2760] “At that time, on the pleasant bank of the river, On its sloping bank described as golden,[2761] All the hosts of gods And other beings will gather. “All the most eminent human kings, And beings of human and nonhuman origin Such as all the spirits and mortal beings, Both the naive and the mature, “Will gather at that place For that public event of great magnitude. This divine celebration[2762] Will be on the account of my physical remains. “Stepping then into the immaterial, I will attain the peace of nirvāṇa.[2763] Leaving behind phenomenal reality, I will enter the ultimate reality.

de tshe sngon gyi skye ba ni/ / ser skya'i grong khyer gzhi dag tu/ / shAkya'i rigs kyi gtso bo ni/ / nga ni 'khor ba'i btson rar skyes/ / bdag gi sdug bsngal bdag nyid kyis/ / khyim las nges 'byung yongs su spangs/ / de tshe mu stegs mang po bsten/ / bdud rtsi dag kyang thob ma gyur/ / dka' ba dag kyang bdag gis spyad/ / lus kyi gdung ba'ang yun ring ba/ / lo drug tu ni bsten pa yis/ / lus kyang zhig cing rnam par skams/ / shes dang shes bya gsal ba ni/ / ngas ni cung zad thob pa med/ /

“My final birth occurred[2764] In the city of Kapilavastu Within the illustrious family of the Śākyas, Where I was born into the prison of existence. “Then, leaving behind its inherent suffering, I went forth from my home. I visited many holy places But still did not find the elixir of immortality. “I practiced severe austerities, Mortifying my body.[2765] Having fasted for six years, I was on the verge of dying from exhaustion, “But I did not find anything That would reveal [true] knowledge to me.[2766]

de nas nga ni langs nas kyang / / 'bras chen dkar ba'i zas kyang zos/ / lha rnams kyis mchod lam dag ni/ / der ni sa steng nga yis bgrod/ / chu bo nai rany+dza na'i 'gram/ / shing gi rgyal po legs mdzes pa/ / me tog rnam pa du mas khyab/ / de 'gram sa ni nyams dga' ba/ / nags chen 'bras bu ldan pa dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs shing dag 'byung / / chu bo chen pos yongs bskor ba'i/ / shing gi rtsar ni nga yis phyin/ / sa yi cha ni mthong tsam gyis/ / bdag gi sems ni brtan pa thob/ / de lta'i shing ni bdag gis mthong / / yal ga lo ma nyer mdzes pa'i/ / shing chen grib ma chen po ni/ / rtsa ba mi mngon nyer spyad 'os/ / shing rtsa a shwat+thar 'dug nas/ / sems ni shin tu dang bar gyur/ / bsam gtan dang ni ting 'dzin dang / / der ni brtan pa'ang mngon par 'thob/ / mtshan mo'i mthar ni skye mthar byed/ / der ni snang ba med pa'ang 'thob/ /

I got up, therefore, and partook of some food‍— A delicious milk porridge. “Following the road indicated to me by the gods, I traveled across the land, To the bank of the Nairañjanā River, Beautified by kingly trees, “Where the salty ground Was strewn with various flowers, And fine forest fruits abounded, Produced by various trees. “Walking along the great river, I came, in the end, to the foot of a tree. As soon as I saw that this place was right for me, A firm resolve was born in me. “Seeing also that this large tree Was adorned with leafy branches That afforded plenty of shade And had root spurs that provided shelter,[2767] “I attained aśvattha-hood during the aśvattha, Sitting at the foot of that [aśvattha] tree.[2768] There, I attained stability, Concentration, and samādhi. At the end of the night I attained that which Is not subject to destruction and ends [the cycle of] rebirth.[2769]

bdud kyi bgegs ni rnam mang po/ / rnam pa du ma rab tu sbyar/ / sde rnams bcom nas slar ldog cing / / rang gi gnas su'ang de dag song / / sngags dang rgyud ni 'di don du/ / rnam pa mang po'ang gsungs pa yin/ / rnam pa du ma'i sbyor ba dang / / bsam gtan shes pa'ang bstan pa yin/ / der ni theg pa gsum yang spyad/ / gzhan dag sems can rten la 'dzud/ / nyes pa rnam pa gsum nyid kyi/ / gnyen po dag kyang rab tu bstan/ /

“Māra cleverly deployed many vighnas With many different forms, But after his armies were defeated, He turned back and returned to his abode. “It is because of him[2770] That many mantra systems have been taught, Along with many ritual methods, Meditative concentrations, and knowledges. “The path, moreover, is threefold, To serve each of the three types of beings.[2771] The antidotes to the faults, Likewise, are taught as threefold.

de nas langs nas yang song nas/ / grong khyer lteng rgyas chu bzang gis/ / khrus byas der gnas drang srong rnams/ / slob mar bcas pa'ang rab tu phyung / / sems can rnam mang don byas nas/ / de nas nga ni yang dag 'das/ / ka shi'i grong ni nyams dga' bar/ / mthar gyis su ni yang dag zhugs/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po sngar sangs rgyas/ / de yi gnas su'ang bzhugs pa yin/ / ka shi skye bo'i yul dag tu/ / der ni rang bdag nyid gnas 'gyur/ /

“Then, I got up and went To Urubilvā, with its auspicious waters. Having bathed in the waters there, I visited the local sage and his disciples. “After performing many acts for the sake of beings, I[2772] set out once again And in due course Entered the beautiful city of Kāśī. “Having gone to the place Where the former buddhas with great powers had gone, I remained there myself Among the local Kāśī folk.

zhi ba mya ngan 'das byed pa'i/ / dam chos chos kyi 'khor lo bskor/ / 'jig rten lha dang lha min bcas/ / 'gro ba lnga la yang dag brten/ / 'byung po kun la bde ba'i phyir/ / der ni chos kyang rab tu bstan/ / der ni snga ma'i sangs rgyas kyis/ / chos kyi 'khor lo rab tu bskor/ / chos kyi 'khor lo bla na med/ / de ni nga yis rab tu bstan/ /

“Having turned the wheel of the sacred Dharma That brings the peace of nirvāṇa, I taught the Dharma there To bring about the happiness of all beings Whose existence depends on the five vital airs,[2773] Including gods and demigods. “The Dharma wheel was turned there Before by the primordial buddhas. I too taught The unsurpassed Dharma wheel there.

srid las grol zhing ba de don dang / / sems can nyes pa bzlog pa'i phyir/ / bde zhing zhi bar gzhol ba'o/ / tshangs pa'i 'khor lo rab tu bskor/ / srid pa'i lam ni gzhig don dang / / bden bzhi'i ting 'dzin las byung ba'i/ / 'phags lam yan lag brgyad pa ni/ / tshangs pa'i gnas bzhis rnam par brgyan/ / rten cing 'brel bar 'byung dang bcas/ / rnam pa bcu gnyis byas pa yin/ / ma rig 'gag par yang dag ldan/ / rig pa bskyed pa'i rim las byung / / yang dag mtha' yi legs mthar skyes/ / de nyid mthar ni bstan pa yin/ / lugs su 'byung dang bzlog pa dag / tha mar bdag nyid rtogs chen skyes/ / sems can mang po thar don du/ / zhi ba'i 'khor lo yang dag ldan/ / nyams dga' ka shi'i grong spangs nas/ / de tshe bdag ni mnyan yod song / /

“To bring the happiness of release from saṃsāra And to stop the faults[2774] of sentient beings, I turned the great wheel[2775] That brings the happiness of the final peace; “The wheel that is intended to destroy the path of becoming And arises out of the samādhi of the four truths; The wheel comprised of the eightfold path And adorned with the four abodes of Brahmā;[2776] “The wheel from whose felly arises knowledge, Thus blocking ignorance Along with the twelvefold cycle Of interdependent origination; “The wheel that spreads the absolute truth Born, at its extreme edge, out of the ultimate reality; The wheel whose greatness arises from its felly With its forward and backward movements;[2777] “The auspicious wheel that spreads instructions And brings liberation to many beings. Having thus turned the wheel,[2778] I left the pleasant city of Kāśī and proceeded to Śrāvastī.

de tshe mu stegs gdul bya'i phyir/ / cho 'phrul chen po'ang byas pa yin/ / mi yul dag tu rdzu 'phrul ni/ / de tshe yang dag bstan par byas/ / mu stegs mang po'i gnas dag tu'ang / / de tshe'ang rab tu dga' bar byas/ / yul ming me thab ces bya bar/ / lha las babs pa bzang po byas/ / sum cu rtsa gsum dag tu yang / / chos nyid la ni brgya byin sbyar/ / de nas 'og min lha sogs dang / / tshangs sogs brgya byin bcas pa dang / / rnam thos gnod sbyin dbang dang bcas/ / rgyal chen bzhi yi ris dag dang / / rtag tu myos dang gzhong thogs dang / / pi wang gsum pa phreng thogs dang / / lha dang gnod sbyin tshogs rnams kun/ / sa bla lha dang bar snang gnas/ / 'phags pa gnod sbyin tshogs bdag dang / / lha dang lha min thams cad kyang / / chos kyi 'bras bu ldan par byas/ / mya ngan 'das gsum rjes 'gro byas/ / sems can bsam gyis mi khyab pa'ang / / de tshe legs pa nyid la btsud/ / de dag rtsis kyi grangs med pa/ / 'khor ba'i mtha' bzhin de mtha' med/ / stong chen po yi 'jig rten gyi/ / khams dang 'dra bar bsam mi khyab/ /

“There, I humbled the tīrthikas With displays of miracles.[2779] Similarly, I displayed a miraculous feat In the district of Sāṅkāśya.[2780] “Having delighted the people who live In the many places of pilgrimage, I made an auspicious descent from the realm of gods Among the people of Agnibhāṇḍa.[2781] “In the realm of the Thirty-Three I introduced Śakra to the nature of phenomena, And in Akaniṣṭha, and so forth, I did the same With Brahmā and the others, including the Destroyer of Cities;[2782] “The lords of yakṣas, including Vaiśravaṇa; The hordes belonging to the four great kings; The sadāmatta and karoṭapāṇi gods; The vīṇātṛtīyaka and mālādhārin gods; “All the gods and hosts of yakṣas Who dwell on earth, in heaven, or in the space in between; The noble leaders of yakṣa hosts; And all the lower gods and asuras. “I introduced them to the fruit of the Dharma And caused them to seek out the threefold nirvāṇa. I established inconceivable numbers of beings In a better state. “The number of these beings is incalculable, As saṃsāra is infinite and has no end. Within great thousandfold universes dwell inconceivable numbers Of beings composed of the primary elements.[2783]

rtag tu sems can mang po ni/ / bden pa'i don la yang dag sbyar/ / de tshe der ni nga 'ongs nas/ / gnas gtsang steng du gnas nas kyang / / theg pa gsum la rjes 'jug pa'i/ / dam chos sngags ni rab tu bskor/ / sems can gdul bya la brten nas/ / nga yis cho ga'i rgyal po 'di/ / 'jig rten mang la rab bstan nas/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs la'ang gtad pa yin/ / nga ni 'jig rten mya ngan 'das/ / sa steng stongs par gyur pa na/ / de nas 'jam dpal sems can la/ / sangs rgyas mdzad pa byed par 'gyur/ / thub dbang yongs su mya ngan 'das/ / dam pa'i chos ni bsrung ba'i phyir/ / de tshe rtag tu srung bar ni/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni 'gyur ba yin/ / sngags ni rab tu dbye don du/ / cho ga rgya chen bstan pa yin/ / de tshe dus kyi tha ma la/ / ma rungs mi bzad chen po yi/ / mi bdag gdug pa chen po ni/ / phan tshun gsod pa dag la dga'/ / sdig pa'i las can spyod pa ngan/ / de tshe longs spyod chung ba dang / / de tshe dus kyi tha ma la/ / 'byung bar 'gyur bar the tshom ma med/ /

“Having thus introduced many beings To the true meaning, I have now arrived and remain here, Above the realm of the Pure Abode. “I turned the wheel of the sacred mantra teachings That accord with the three vehicles And established beings in discipline. Further, I taught this king of manuals Throughout the entire world And am now giving it to Mañjughoṣa. “When I have passed from this world into the final nirvāṇa And the earth is devoid of my presence, Mañjuśrī will continue the work of the Buddha For the sake of the beings there. “In order to preserve the sacred Dharma When the victorious lords[2784] are in the state of nirvāṇa, Mañjughoṣa will always Guard it continually. “This extensive manual has been taught In order to promulgate the mantra path. During the terrible and dreadful time At the end of the eon “The human kings will be very violent And delight in killing one another. They will commit evil acts and follow wrong conduct. During the debased eon Enjoyments will be few, Of this there is no doubt.

sA la zhes bya'i nags su ni/ / de dag mchod don rtsom par byed/ / chu bo gser ldan 'gram dang ni/ / cod pan 'ching ba'i mchod rten du/ / zhi ba'i dbyings la brten pa'i phyir/ / nga ni mya ngan 'das mal 'cha'/ / lus ni sreg pa'i shing la bzhag / rdzogs longs spyod pa longs spyod spangs/ / de'i sngon mdzad pa nyid dang ni/ / nga yi rmad byung spyod mthong nas/ / nga yi gdul bya'i spyod yul dang / / sangs rgyas gdul bya'i mdzad pa dang / / spyod pa dge ba sna tshogs de/ / mi yi bdag po kun dran nas/ / thams cad mchod pa byed par 'gyur/ / lha dang lha min mir bcas pa/ / de nas sa bdag kun 'dus nas/ / de tshe nga yi drung du ni/ / dga' ston chen po mchod pa kun/ / byed par 'gyur bar the tshom ma med/ /

“The kings of men will come To worship in the Sāla Grove, In the Makuṭabandhana temple, And on the banks of the Hiraṇyavatī river. “When I have passed, on my bed, into final nirvāṇa And have entered the sphere of peace, My body, in a state of bliss but devoid of sensation,[2785] Will be placed upon the funeral pyre. “Looking upon my former deeds, The miracles I have performed, And the guiding activity of the Buddha That leads to the propriety of conduct, “And reflecting upon these auspicious and illustrious acts, All the kings, along with the gods, The asuras, and ordinary humans Will offer worship to me. “All the earthly rulers, having come together, Will offer worship amidst great celebrations At that time, near to my body, There is no doubt about that.

sku ni shing la rab bteg nas/ / zang zing yon tan 'byung ba'i gnas/ / dge ba dang ni mi dge dang / / bsod nams bsod nams ma yin spangs/ / yang dag mtha' don stong nyid mtha'/ / phung po lnga ni 'byung ba che/ / sems can mang pos de rjes mthong / / bsod nams che ba'i don du sbyar/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / nyan thos chen po bdag nyid che/ / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyang / / sa bcu la ni yang dag gnas/ / yang dag mtha' ni rtogs nas kyang / / chos kyi mtha' la yang dag gnas/ / sems can kun la snying brtse bar/ / kun gyis yongs su bskor nas gnas/ / lha yi tshogs ni thams cad dang / / 'phags dang so so'i skye bo dang / / 'di kun bsod nams chen po'i gnas/ / mchod rten la ni 'dus par 'gyur/ /

“My physical body, a source of qualities, Will be placed on the funeral pyre, Its faults terminated and only the merit left. It will be free from all nonvirtue And its five empty aggregates Will now arise as the corresponding [five] realities. “Upon seeing it, Many beings will acquire great merit. The great śrāvakas, great beings devoid of passions And possessed of great powers, And all the bodhisattvas Who abide on the ten levels “Will all gather around, Filled with compassion for all beings. All the hosts of gods, As well as the noble and ordinary people,[2786] “Will all congregate around That single place of great merit.

mi rtag sdug bsngal don gnas nas/ / dang ba'i sems ni rab tu thob/ / mchod rten mtha' yi nyen kor du/ / 'byung po'i tshogs kyang 'dug pa yin/ / mchod pa chen po byas nas ni/ / smre sngags 'don cing ngu bar byed/ / dbugs 'byin snying rjes brlan nas nas ni/ / mchi ma'i thigs pa'ang rab tu 'dzag / smre sngags 'di ltar kun 'don pa/ / mi rtag sdug bsngal stong pa yi/ / sangs rgyas chos ni sngar ston mdzad/ / da ltar sa steng 'di la ni/ / de 'dir thub mchog dam pa ni/ / drang srong mchog gyur bdun pa dang / / sems can kun mchog shAkya'i rgyal/ / de mthong ba yi tha ma yin/ /

They will attain the faith that rests upon The understanding of impermanence and suffering. “All the hosts of spirits Will be near the [funerary] caitya, Making large offerings, Wailing and crying. “They will shed profuse tears And sob, overwhelmed by compassion. They will lament over impermanence, Suffering, and emptiness as follows: “ ‘The Buddha taught the Dharma Here on earth, in the present time. And now, this best of sages, The eminent seventh bull of a sage, Born among the Śākyas, the foremost of all beings, Is seen by us for the last time.

sdug bsngal mi rtag ston pa yi/ / bcom ldan de 'di gzims pa yi/ / mthong ba yi ni tha ma 'am/ / stong nyid don dam ston byed dang / / thog ma nas zhi don ston pa/ / lha yi tshogs dag ci yi phyir/ / kye ma mnga' bdag sad mi byed/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po lha yi bu/ / thams cad 'dir ni lhags par 'gyur/ / dpa' bo chen po chos don gnyer/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po nyan thos dang / / sems can kun ni sdug bsngal ba'i/ / mi dang lha dang lha ma yin/ / chos kyi 'khor lo rjes bskor ba'i/ / de yi dus ni 'di dag yin/ / bcom ldan khyod ni myur du bzhengs/ / sangs rgyas dus kyi rjes 'gro ba/ / rgya mtsho chen po'i dus bzhin du/ / thub pas de 'drar mi 'da' mdzod/ /

“ ‘The Blessed One, who taught us Impermanence and suffering, is lying here. He taught emptiness, the absolute truth,[2787] And he explained the meaning of primordial peace. Why, O gods, do you not wake up Our lord and master? “ ‘Gathered here are all the Buddha’s sons[2788] Of great miraculous powers And the powerful śrāvakas, Rich in religious merit and courage. “ ‘All the beings‍—men, gods, and asuras‍— Are thoroughly distressed. This is an occasion to continue Turning the wheel of Dharma, “ ‘So rise up swiftly, O Blessed One! May the Buddha’s sojourn [on earth] continue For as long as the great ocean [of saṃsāra] lasts! Do not neglect those sinking in it, O sage![2789]
yun ring dus nas brten mdzad pa'i/ / sems can mang po'i don mdzad stsol/ / zhi ba mya ngan 'das lam mam/ / bsam gtan rnam thar bstan du gsol/ /
“ ‘Do not disregard so many beings By staying for a long time in a samādhi-like state. Abandon meditative absorption And teach the path to peaceful nirvāṇa.’[2790]

de ltar rnam pa du ma yi/ / smra ba mang po'i tshig brjod nas/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po'i lha yi tshogs/ / de nas thams cad cang mi smra/ / mtshungs med smre sngags byas nas ni/ / bdud dang bcas pas rab tu 'dug / yun ring ngu zhing smre byas nas/ / 'gul nas mchi bcas sgra 'dzer bcas/ / mya ngan yid mi bde dang bcas/ / tshangs sogs lha dang lha min bcas/ / mi dang mi yi bdag po kun/ / sa steng de la gnas par 'gyur/ / gzhan yang shAkya'i rigs skyes pa/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / bdag nyid chen po sangs rgyas ni/ / lha yi lha yi gnyen gyur pa/ /

“Lamenting, they will utter Many words of this kind. “Then all these powerful gods, And all their hosts, will fall silent. Having wailed so much, They will now wait, bowing respectfully.[2791] “Then the gods and the asuras, Brahmā and so forth, Will cry for a long time, uttering shrill cries With stammering voices And throats choked by grief. “All the human-born kings,[2792] Sitting on the ground, [will say,] ‘The liberated one born into the Śākya clan, Free from passion and very powerful, Is none other than the great Buddha, The knowing one, the god of gods.’[2793]

dge slong ma 'gags pa zhes bya/ / de gcung mi yi nang na dge/ / shin tu phra la mkhas shing gsal/ / chags bral lugs la mkhas pa dang / / dgra bcom gtso bo rgyal po ni/ / du ma'i 'khor gyis yongs su bskor/ / mya ngan gyis bskyed dbugs phyung nas/ / shin tu yun ring tshig kyang smras/ / snying rje yid mi bdes drangs pas/ / rgyal po dang bcas gyad rnams la/ / grogs po re zhig shing la ni/ / me ni 'jug par ma byed cig / ji srid bcom ldan sras po ni/ / mchog gyur chos nyid las byung ba/ /

“A young monk by the name Aniruddha, Human-born and virtuous, Distinguished by his subtlety and ability, Excelling in recitation and conduct,[2794] Surrounded by a retinue Of eminent arhats and kings, “Will then say to the Malla kings and subjects Sighing in anguish, Their minds moist with compassion, The following sweet words: “ ‘My friends, do not Set this pyre here aflame Until the Blessed One’s foremost son, The fount of the Dharma, has arrived.

de ni nyan thos rdzu 'phrul che/ / 'od srung chen po zhes bya ba/ / thub pa chen po blo yi mchog / bram ze'i rigs skyes zang zing med/ / ma ga d+hA yi mi nang skyes/ / ri bo der ni mnyam par bzhag / grong khyer rgyal po'i khab mchog tu/ / pi ba la yi khyim du gnas/ / de ni myur du 'dir 'ong bar/ / byed kyi gzhan du ma yin no/ / lha ni gang zhig der dang ba/ / sku la me 'bar nges bzlog pas/ / de bar sku la me gtong ba/ / ngal ba don med ma byed cig / ji srid rdzu 'phrul che ba'i mchog / nyan thos thub pa thugs dgyes des/ / 'jig rten gsum mchod sangs rgyas dang / / ston pa 'jig rten gyis mchod la/ / zhabs la spyi bos phyag 'tshal nas/ / bla ma g.yas su bskor byas pa/ / de tshe sku 'di sbar don du/ / der ni kun gyis rab byos shig / gang tshe sngar ni sbar gyur na/ / kun tu 'bar ba'ang don med 'gyur/ / thams cad don med ma byed cig / 'dir ni ngal ba kho na 'byung / /

“ ‘His name is Mahākāśyapa, And he is a śrāvaka of great miraculous power. He possesses the intelligence of a great sage, And was born a brahmin, free from worldliness. “ ‘He was born among the Magadhans And spends his time in meditative equipoise there, On a hill, under a pipal tree that affords shelter, Near the fine city of Rājagṛha. “ ‘He will swiftly arrive here; He would not do otherwise. The deity that he worships Would surely put out the kindling flame, “ ‘So do not light the pyre just yet, As this would be a vain labor. [Wait] until that powerful śrāvaka, The foremost son of the Sage, “ ‘Circumambulates [the remains of] the guru, The Buddha worshiped in the threefold universe. After Mahākāśyapa has bowed his head to the feet Of the Teacher who is revered throughout the world, “ ‘Then you can all proceed with The lighting of the pyre. Only then will the fire In the caitya ignite. So do not, all of you, perform this vain labor That is nothing but [pointless] toil.’

blo dang ldan pa ma 'gags pas/ / kun la de skad smras nas ni/ / mi dang mi yi bdag po dang / / gyad rnams kun kyang 'dug par gyur/ / mi yi rigs su nga skyes shing / / mi rnams kyis kyang rab tu skyed/ / longs spyod rnam mang gzhan dang ni/ / bzo dang sgyu rtsal dge ba'ang bskyed/ / sa steng shing gi rtsa dag tu/ / mi yi gzugs kyis byang chub thob/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi mdzad pa ni/ / mi rnams la ni chos kyang bstan/ / de nyid phyir na mi rnams kyis/ / sku sbyang don phyir me yang sbar/ / nga ming 'byung po kun gyi ni/ / mchog nyid du ni gyur pa yin/ / mi yi 'jig rten zhi ba dang / / nga ni mya ngan 'das par brtags/ /

“Being thus told By the sagacious Aniruddha, All the Malla men and their kings Will remain seated. “Because I was born among humans, And was nurtured by them, With the attendant pleasures of many kinds And other benefits, such as those arising from the arts and crafts; “Because I attained awakening among humans, On earth, at the foot of the [Bodhi] tree; And because I taught, among humans, The Dharma that benefits all sentient beings, “It is fit for human beings alone To light the funeral pyre. Since I attained preeminence among all beings As a human being, My peaceful final nirvāṇa Is destined to take place in the human world.

gang dag sangs rgyas thams cad ni/ / 'das dang ma 'ongs da ltar gyi/ / thams cad mi yi 'jig rten du/ / mi yi lus su yang dag 'byung / / skye dang byang chub de bzhin du/ / dam chos 'khor lo dge ba spyod/ / zhi ba yang dag kun gshegs par/ / de bzhin rang rgyal dgra bcom pa/ / mi yi lus la brten nas ni/ / bla med zhi bar gshegs pa yin/ /

“Whatever buddhas came in the past, Will come in the future, or are active at present, All of them are born in a human body In this human world. “All of them are born, attain awakening, Turn the auspicious Dharma wheel, And enter the peace [of final] nirvāṇa. Because the pratyekabuddhas and the noble śrāvakas Also take a human birth and attain unsurpassable peace, This attainment is regarded as threefold.[2795]

bskal pa bsam gyis mi khyab par/ / de dag la ni ngas phan byas/ / nga ni phyi mar zhi ba dang / / bsil bar gyur cing 'gog par gyur/ / sa steng stongs par gyur pa na/ / der ni sku gdung rab bzhag pa/ / mi rnams la ni phan don du/ / mchod pa rjes su gzung 'dod pas/ / 'jig rten lha dang lha min bcas/ / mi dang gnod sbyin mkha' lding bdag / srin po yi dgas grul bum dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po'i sha za rnams/ / 'byung po dag ni thams cad dang / / gzar bcas ma mo rnams dang ni/ / de bzhin 'jig rten thams cad ni/ / grangs med bsam gyis mi khyab khams/ / srog chags thams cad nyid dag ni/ / mchod pa'i don phyir sku gdung dag / sa steng stongs par gyur pa na/ / de yi tshe na yang dag bzhag / kha cig sa steng mi dag dang / / lha yi rgyal po de bzhin gzhan/ / lha min dbang po rdzu 'phrul che/ / sa 'og gnas pa gzhan dag dang / / de bzhin klu rgyal lha min dag / sku gdung so so so sor ni/ / yon tan ldan pa rdzu 'phrul ches/ / phyogs nas thams cad bdag gir byas/ / rang gi gnas su khyer nas ni/ / de tshe mchod pa byed 'gyur zhing / /

“I have assisted [human beings] For inconceivable eons. When I pass into the state of final peace, Cool and not subject to arising,[2796] I will leave behind my relics there, On the earth devoid of my presence, “For the benefit of the human beings On whom I wish to bestow the benefits of worship. The relics will likewise be for the lower gods and asuras, For the ṛṣis,[2797] yakṣas, and garuḍas, “For the rākṣasas, pretas, and kuṣmāṇḍas, For the powerful piśācas, For all the spirits including The grahas and the mātṛs, “And likewise for all the innumerable worlds With their inconceivable world spheres That support all [types of] life. The relics will be left behind on the earth, Destitute at that time of my presence, For the purpose of worship. “Any mortals who arrive for these substances, Any celestial kings or other beings, Such as the inhabitants of the subterranean paradises, The powerful lords of the dānavas, The nāga kings, and the daityas, Will each separately take my relics. “Bereft of their valued object[2798] But endowed with good qualities, These powerful beings will take [the relics] To their own abodes and worship them.[2799]

rdzu 'phrul chen po sangs rgyas su/ / thams cad the tshom med par 'gyur/ / mchog dang tha ma bar gnas pa'i/ / sems ni dad pa rnam gsum gyis/ / 'jig rten rnam gsum 'gyur ba ni/ / sangs rgyas bse ru dgra bcom thob/ / theg pa rnam gsum 'jig rten gsum/ / rnam gsum yang dag bstan pa yin/ / theg chen la 'jug lam gyis ni/ / de la brten nas nges par 'byung / /

“All of them will become, without a doubt, Buddhas with great miraculous powers. Depending on their clarity of mind, They will fall into three categories‍—the highest, the lower, and the middle.[2800] “They will thus become, in this threefold universe, Either buddhas, or rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddhas, or arhats. Accordingly, there will arise in the world Three vehicles of three different types:[2801] “There will be (1) those who become liberated Based on the practices of the path described as Great Vehicle.

rang rgyal byang chub la brten pa/ / de bzhin 'jig rten 'gyur ba yin/ / de las gzhan pa nyan thos kyang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / de bzhin 'jig rten 'gyur ba yin/ / rnam gsum rigs kyis rnam par brgyan/ / sa bdag longs spyod chen po dang / / bde chen don du 'khor los sgyur/ / lha dang mi yi phun sum tshogs/ / yun ring de tshe rjes myong nas/ / mthar ni 'chi ba la brten nas/ / de dag zhi ba rnam gsum 'gro/ / dang por sngar ni sangs rgyas dang / / da ltar ma 'ongs pa dag kyang / / thams cad la ni 'di nyid de/ / 'di ni yang dag ji bzhin bstan/ / mya ngan 'das pa'i sa de la/ / lha rnams thams cad 'dug nas ni/ / yid byung sems ni skyo nas kyang / / skad 'dzer bcas pas smra ba ni/ / de tshe thams cad 'di skad smra/ / kye ma'o kyi hud mi rtag pa/ / 'jig rten sangs rgyas rdzu 'phrul che/ / de 'dir yongs su mya ngan 'das/ /

There will also be, at that time in the world, (2) Those who attain awakening and become liberated[2802] by themselves. “And there will also be (3) the śrāvakas, Freed from passions and endowed with miraculous powers. Thus, there will be at that time in the world Beings adorned with this threefold family affiliation. “Kings who enjoy great comforts Yet exercise their imperial might with great gentleness, Will enjoy, as human beings, Divine fortunes for a long time, And when they eventually die, They will attain one of the three kinds of peace. “The previous buddhas since the beginning, And those of the present and future too, All followed the same course As the one displayed here. “All the deities sitting there At the place of my nirvāṇa Will become disturbed and upset, And their voices will falter. “They will all say at that time, ‘Alas, this is impermanence! The buddhas with great miraculous powers Pass from this world into final nirvāṇa.’

lha yi rgyal po rdzu 'phrul che/ / de dag kun gyis de smras nas/ / snying ni mya ngan bcas gyur nas/ / de nas cang mi smra bar gnas/ / ma ga d+hA yi skye bo mchog / ku sha'i mchog gi grong gnas pa/ / de dang nye ba'i ri bo ni/ / phag rgod ces bya'i ming du grags/ / dge slong bsam gtan der byed pa/ / pi pa li yi phug zhugs pa/ /

“All the powerful divine kings, Having said this, Will experience anguish in their hearts[2803] And will remain silent. “Among the noble people of Magadha Who dwell in the city of Kuśāgrapura, Not far from there, On the mountain called Vārāha, There meditates a monk, Sheltered by [the root spurs of] a pipal tree.[2804]

'di ni nyan thos nga yi bu/ / thugs skyes chos las byung ba gang / / de ni 'od srung chen po yin/ / de tshe phug mchog la 'dug nas/ / de nas bsod snyoms la spyad de/ / 'dug nas rang nyid sems par byed/ / dus ring bdag gis sangs rgyas la/ / bdag gis kyang ni de phyag byas/ / rang byung gyur pa mi yi mchog / bdag gis da ltar de blta bya/ /

“He is a śrāvaka and my foremost heart son, The fount of the Dharma. His name is Mahākāśyapa and he will be sitting, At that time, in his fine shelter. “Having eaten his supply of alms, He will sit and reflect as follows: ‘I have spent a lot of time Paying homage to the Buddha, the great sage. Now I would like to visit That supreme, spontaneously arisen person.

shAkya'i rigs skyes thub pa mchog / bcom ldan de ni ga la bzhugs/ / bram ze'i rgyal po 'od srung che/ / der ni yang dag dgongs par gyur/ / thub pa'i thub pa kho na ni/ / sems kyis de ltar bsam par gyur/ / lha yi mig gis 'jig rten la/ / 'jig rten ma lus lta bar byed/ / 'og min de bzhin 'jig rten mtha'/ / srid rtse'i 'jig rten khams kyi bar/ / 'jig rten ma lus thams cad dang / / stong chen sred pa las byung ba/ /

“ ‘Where is the Blessed One staying, This most virtuous sage of the Śākyas?’ Mahākāśyapa, the king of brahmins, will thus focus his mind On the Blessed One while remaining at his place. “He will perceive the sage of sages With his mind alone. He will also see, with the divine eye, The world [where he lives] and all the [other] worlds: “Akaniṣṭha and other such worlds With their luminous world spheres, And all the worlds that are named after all their beings And are part of great thousandfold worlds within still greater units.[2805]

nyan thos spyod yul ji tsam par/ / lha yi mig gis blta byas na/ / mya ngan 'das gzims zhi ba dang / / bsil bar gyur cing nad med pa/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po lha tshogs kyis/ / kun nas yongs su bskor ba dang / / mi dang mi yi bdag po dang / / lha min gnod sbyin srin po dang / / 'byung po'i tshogs ni thams cad dang / / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / grags chen nyan thos chen po yang / / shes rab gtsor ni gyur pa dang / / 'dod chags bcas dang 'dod chags bral/ / lha dang bcas pa'i mi rnams kyis/ / dpa' bo shing la bteg pa ni/ / sangs rgyas nyi ma'i rigs las byung / / de bzhin lha yi lhar gyur gtso/ / thub pa dam pa'i mnga' bdag ni/ / sa bdag gling la gnas rnams kyis/ / kun nas yongs su bskor gyur nas/ / mi yi dbang mchog gyad dag gis/ / lag na rtswa sgron yang dag thogs/ / de dag me sbar mi nus par/ / lha rnams kyis ni bzlog 'gyur zhes/ / dge slong ma 'gags pa yang ni/ / brtul zhugs can gyis de skad smras/ / 'chi mas brnangs shing smre sngags 'don/ / sa rnams sgra ni chen pos gang / / ha ha zhes bya'i sgra nyid dang / / rnga bo che yi sgra yang thos/ /

“Looking with his divine eye As far as the śrāvakas can, He will see the Teacher passed into nirvāṇa, Peaceful, emancipated, and immaterial, “Surrounded on all sides By hosts of very powerful gods As well as human kings,[2806] Asuras, yakṣas, rākṣasas, And all the hosts of spirits, And also by the bodhisattvas with great powers, “Śrāvakas of great renown Who excel in wisdom, And noble celestials and humans Both with and without passion. “He will see the valiant one upon the funeral pyre‍— The Buddha, a relative of the sun,[2807] The god of gods, The supreme and most virtuous lord of sages, “Surrounded on all sides By the earthly kings, Including the mighty Mallas, Holding in their hands lamps, fragrances, and grass torches. “As explained by the monk Aniruddha, Who keeps his observances, The kings, held back by the gods, Will be unable to light the pyre. “The earth goddess will wail loudly, Her voice choked by tears. There will be terrible exclamations of ‘alas, alas!’ And the sound of thunder will resound.[2808]

lha dang drang srong tshogs kyis khyab/ / lha yi bu mo'i tshogs kyis bstod/ / grub pa rig 'dzin klu dang ni/ / mi 'am ci klu rgya che ba/ / snyan pa'i sgra ni sgrogs par byed/ / bya yi skad ni dge ba dang / / yid 'ong sna tshogs rol mo dang / / lha dang mi yis rjed pa dang / / lha yi bu mo'i tshogs kyis gang / / grub pa rig 'dzin dag dang ldan/ / de tshe sA la'i nags dag tu/ / rnal 'byor dag gis kun tu khyab/ / thub mchog gzims mal dam pa ni/ / kun nas yongs su bskor bar mthong / / rdzu 'phrul chen po mya ngan bral/ / de nas dbugs 'byin mya ngan bcas/ / de tshe bram ze 'od srung ni/ / mchi ma'i thigs pa'ang rab tu 'don/ / nga yi nyan thos mchog gyur pa/ / de tshe sa yi steng du 'gyel/ / tshig kyang myur du brjod pa ni/ / kye ma'o dka' ba rab tu byung / / gang du sangs rgyas zhes bya ba/ / zag med mya ngan 'das gyur tam/ / mi rtag sdug bsngal stong pa zhes/ / de nyid kyis ni 'dir gsungs pa/ / skye ba gzhan gyi rjes 'gro ba/ / bdag gis ston pa'i sku mi mthong / /

“The grove will be divinely filled with hosts of ṛṣis And apsarases singing praises; It will resound with songs of siddhas and vidyādharīs, And with the singing of kinnaras. “There will be the sweet cooing And beautiful warbling of birds And lovely sounds of various instruments Played by celestials and humans. “The Sāla Grove will be Filled with the songs of apsarases, Graced with the presence of siddhas and vidyādharas, And full of yogins all over. “The fine bed of the bull among sages Will [thus] be surrounded on all sides,[2809] And above it, Kāśyapa will sigh with grief, Even though he is normally free from sorrow. “Shedding tears, The monk[2810] Kāśyapa, Foremost among my śrāvaka-disciples, Will then collapse on the ground “And promptly cry out, ‘Alas! A difficult time has begun Where the Buddha, free from karmic traits, Has now passed into final nirvāṇa. “ ‘He himself taught, in this world, About impermanence, suffering, and emptiness. I see nothing permanent; Everything must undergo successive rebirth.’[2811]

de nas langs nas myur du ni/ / ma ga d+hA yi rgyal por song / / sdug bsngal nyam thag ma skyes dgra/ / pha yi mya ngan gyis non pa'i/ / de tshe de yi phug 'ongs nas/ / mi yi bdag po de la smras/ / rkang gnyis dam pa rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / rgyal po chen po mya ngan 'das/ / bzhon pa myur du sbyor mdzod dang / / nga ni ston pa'i drung 'gro ba/ / sA lar gzims mal bzhugs pa ni/ / nad med sems dang rnam par bral/ / bstan pa thams cad las 'das shing / / sku yi dam pa longs spyod rdzogs/ / ma rungs de tshig thos nas ni/ / rgyal po de yang sdug bsngal zhing / / nyam thag smre bar gyur pa yi/ / de tshe tshig ni rgyal po 'don/ / ston pa dang ni pha dag dang / / gnyi ga las kyang bdag nyams gyur/ / gnyen rnams kun gyis spangs pa ste/ / de tshe skye bo yid ches med/ / dmyal ba mi bzad ltung 'gyur na/ / bdag ni su yi skyabs la brten/ / nyan thos ston pa'i mchog gyur pa/ / dpa' bo chen po skyabs mdzod cig /

“Kāśyapa will then quickly get up And go to the king of the Magadhans, Ajātaśatru, who will be in a state of anguish, Overwhelmed by grief for his father.[2812] “Having arrived in his house,[2813] Kāśyapa will say to the king, ‘O great king! The perfect Buddha, Supreme among two-legged beings, has passed into nirvāṇa. “ ‘Quickly prepare a carriage, And let’s go to the Teacher’s side! He is lying on a bed on the ground, His mind free from feverish agitation, Beyond any enmity or fear, Abiding in the supreme body of bliss.’ “Hearing the painful news, The king will become even more distressed. Expressing his inner lament, He will say the following words: “ ‘I have lost both My Teacher and my father. I have been abandoned by all my relatives, And the people, likewise, do not trust me. When I fall into the terrible hell, In whom will I find my refuge? “ ‘Protect me, O great hero, Foremost śrāvaka of the Teacher!

nyan thos chen po gzi brjid che/ / bdag gi 'tsho ba 'di na med/ / ma ga d+hA yi mi yi bdag / de nas de skad smras pa dang / / nyan thos mchog gi rkang gnyis la/ / de yi mod la spyi bos gtugs/ / der ni sems med brgyal gyur pa/ / de yi tshe na gzhon nu ni/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'jam pa'i dbyangs/ / dbugs 'byin pa ni byed par 'gyur/ / sems can rjes su gzung 'dod pas/ / 'jig rten kun tu rgyu bar gyis/ /

Mahākāśyapa of great splendor![2814] There is no life for me in this world.’ “Having spoken this, the king, The chief ruler of the Magadhans, Will suddenly collapse on the ground At the feet of the distinguished śrāvaka. He will lie on the ground, stripped of his will, Motionless and unconscious.[2815] “At that time, you, Mañjughoṣa, Divine youth of great magical power, Will visit places around the world With the wish to benefit beings.[2816]

gang tshe sA la'i nags su ni/ / nga lus shing gi steng bzhag pa/ / byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs bskor nas/ / de tshe khyod ni 'dug par 'gyur/ / gang phyir nga lus mchod pa'i phyir/ / sa steng 'dir ni khyod kyis byas/ / 'jig rten kun tu bltas nas ni/ / su zhig sdug bsngal gang las drang / / gzhon nu zab pa'i blo ldan pa/ / de ltar sa la 'gyel bar gyur/ / 'jam dpal gyis ni de yi tshe/ / sa bdag de ni sdug bsngal ba/ / der gnas pa la khyod kyis ni/ / khyod nyid kyis ni de 'dul 'gyur/ / byang chub sems dpas rtogs 'gyur gyis/ / lha dang drang srong rnams dang ni/ / nyan thos rang rgyal gzhan dag dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen pos mi nus so/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis mi bdag ni/ / rmi lam gnas pa bzhin du mthong / / khyod kyi rdzu 'phrul byin rlabs kyis/ / rgyal po mya ngan gyis brgyal des/ / de tshe de ni rmi lam du/ / mngon sum byis pa lta bur mthong / / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'jam pa'i dbyangs/ / gzhon nu bdag nyid sna tshogs pa/ / de bzhin chos ni rnam par 'phrul/ / byang chub sems dpa' byis pa'i gzugs/ / sna tshogs rdzu 'phrul bsam mi khyab/ / 'jam dpal gyis bstan sems dang byas/ /

“When my body is placed on the pyre At its location in the grove, You[2817] will also sit there, Surrounded by a host of bodhisattvas. “Having prepared my body To be worshiped there, on the earth, You will look at the beings around and reflect, ‘Which of them are suffering? Whom can I save?’[2818] “When I lie there on the ground, there will be you, Divine youth with the profound understanding of the truth. You, Mañjuśrī, will be able to enthrall The greatly suffering King Ajātaśatru.[2819] “Even though [Mahākāśyapa] will be there, It is you alone who will be able to guide the king, Because what is possible for the bodhisattvas Is not possible even for the magically endowed beings, Such as deities, ṛṣis, and so forth Or the pratyekabuddhas and noble śrāvakas. “The king, lying there, Will see you, Mañjughoṣa, as if in a dream. Given by you a special power, The king, fallen into a swoon from his grief, “Will see in a dream The clear form of a young boy‍—[2820] The all-pervading, divine youth, Mañjughoṣa of great power. “Through you grace, Mañjuśrī, he will see you, A bodhisattva with the form of a child Who is the magical manifestation of the Dharma, With manifold, inconceivable power.[2821]

rgyal po mnar med 'gro ba las/ / myur du de las ldang bar 'gyur/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las dang ni/ / ngan song mtho ris bzang po dang / / 'gro ba bdag nyid che yon tan/ / nyan thos thams cad rnam spangs pa/ / de nas rgya cher byas pa ni/ / mdo sde 'gyod pa sel ba ste/ / rgyal po ma skyes dgra yi ni/ / shin tu rgya cher gsal ba'o/ / rgya che don gyis brgyan pa yi/ / mdor bsdus nas ni 'di gsungs so/ / dang po bar ma tha ma yi/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi gsung dag ni/ / sems can kun la phan pa'i phyir/ / cho ga rgya cher gsungs pa yin/ / de nas 'jam dpal dus kun tu/ / gzhon nu khyod ni de yi tshe/ / sdig pa'i las la rjes 'jug pa'i/ / sa bdag rnams ni 'dul bar 'gyur/ / khyod ni rdzu 'phrul bsam mi khyab/ / gdul bya dag kyang bsam mi khyab/ / 'byung po'i tshogs rnams ma lus pa/ / khyod ni 'dul byed nyid du 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas dpa' bos de gsungs nas/ / 'od chen ldan pa 'jam dbyangs la/ / gnas gtsang steng bzhugs de tshe gzigs/ /

“The king will fall into the Avīci hell But then will rapidly rise up Through the different states of being, His lower rebirths having been auspiciously purified, And will also experience the merits of higher births That are shunned by all the śrāvakas. “When he has thus completely purified His string[2822] of crimes, King Ajātaśatru will enjoy Immense pleasures. “This teaching, presented here only briefly, Is nevertheless adorned with a wide range of distinctive meanings. It represents the speech of all the buddhas In the beginning, in the middle, and at the end.[2823] This extensive manual has thus been taught In order to benefit all beings. “You, divine youth, will, at that time, With your all-reaching words of Mañjuśrī, Guide the kings Who perpetrate evil acts. “The range of your miraculous powers is inconceivable, And the number of those you will guide is inconceivable too. You will become the guide For all the classes of beings.” So spoke the great hero to Mañjughoṣa, The great light of the buddhas, Who, at that time, was staying Above the realm of the Pure Abode.[2824]

rkang gnyis dam pa rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / smra ba'i mchog gis de la gsungs/ / bskal pa mang po 'das pa na/ / khyod ni rdzogs sangs rgyas par 'gyur/ / grangs kyis mnyam med bsam mi khyab/ / mi yis grangs dang mnyam med par/ / 'jam pa'i rgyal mtshan zhes bya ba/ / sangs rgyas 'jig rten 'byung bar 'gyur/ / rtag tu yang ni mthar gyis kyang / / sangs rgyas mdzad pa de tshe byed/ / sems can mang po rnam bkrol nas/ / mya ngan 'das pa nyid du 'gyur/ / gzhon nu'i gzugs can rdzu 'phrul che/ / gzhon nu la ni de gsungs nas/ / brtse bas brlan pa'i sems kyis ni/ / yun ring dbugs phyung rnam par skyo/ / yun ring rdzogs sangs rgyas bltas nas/ / mchi ma'i thigs pa'ang rnam 'dzag cing / / thal mo sbyar dang bcas nas ni/ / de nas kyang ni 'dug par gyur/ / de nas de ni sa gnas pa/ / mi yi dam pa ma skyes dgras/ / rmad byung 'od srung chen po ni/ / bram ze la ni mgos btud nas/ / dran pa rnyed cing sems sad nas/ / rkang gnyis skyil krung bcas nas 'dug / de nas yun ring dbugs phyung la/ / don ni rgya cher nges bstan byas/ / dbang phyug chen po ma skyes dgra/ / rgyal po'i bu ni 'dug par gyur/ / de nas 'od srung ches smras pa/ / nga ni spur sbyong gnas su 'gro/ / mi rnams la ni phan phyir dang / / mchod rten gzugs gnas mchod don du'o/ /

The best of speakers, the perfect buddha, Supreme among two-legged beings, addressed [Mañjughoṣa again]: “After taking, over many eons, Innumerable human births, Too many to be counted or conceived of, You will be the perfect buddha, Mañjudhvaja by name, In the human world. “Then, having performed the acts of a buddha In the correct order as always occurs, And having liberated many beings, You will enter final nirvāṇa.” Thus addressed, the divine youth of great power, With the form of a young boy, Let out a long sigh, Awestruck and overcome with compassion. Shedding tears, He looked at the Buddha for a long time. Then, with his hands folded in salutation, He sat down again. [The Buddha continued to speak:] “On the earth down below, The emperor Ajātaśatru Will bow his head to the brahmin, The wonderful Mahākāśyapa. “Now awake and back to his senses, He will bow down to [Mahākāśyapa’s] feet[2825] And, letting out a long sigh, Will announce his aim in full. “Taking his seat, the son of the late king,[2826] The great lord, Ajātaśatru by name, Will then say to Mahākāśyapa, ‘Let us go to the place of cremation, Where people worthy of help Worship the one interred under the caitya dome.’[2827]

nyan thos mchog ni gnas de ru/ / rdzu 'phrul nyid kyis nye bar lhags/ / de dang 'brel bar sems skye ba/ / bdag gi rdzu 'phrul rigs pa min/ / mchod rten chen po mthong bar ni/ / rkang gnyis bdag ni 'gro bar 'tshal/ /

“The eminent śrāvaka, endowed with many powers, Will however remain in the same place And explain his intentions [to Ajātaśatru]: ‘It is not proper for me to use my magical power; I would like to proceed To that great funerary gathering on foot.’

de nas lam gyi bar 'dug nas/ / 'khor ba'i stegs ni rab tu bstan/ / ji tsam de nas 'ongs gyur pa/ / dge 'dun kun dga' rar gnas pa'i/ / dge slong rgan zhugs gsar bu ni/ / sdig pa nyid kyis rnam rmongs pas/ / mthong nas rgan zhugs rnams 'khrugs te/ / gang phyir de dang nye bar 'ongs/ / grags pa che zhing skal ba che/ / sems can dag pa rims nad med/ / bram ze de yi drung lhags nas/ / de tshe rkang gnyis phyag byas nas/ / de la smras pa skal ba che/ / legs 'ongs khyod ni ci phyir byon/ /

“He will then set out to see the Teacher In his final journey.[2828] On the way, the vow holder [Mahākāśyapa] Will stop at the monastery that is midway,[2829] “So that he can look up The monastery’s occupants, Particularly, a newly ordained elderly monk[2830] Who is sinful and deluded.[2831] “Seeing the approaching figure, The elderly monk will come forward To meet this most illustrious brahmin, Who fasted for a long time, pure and free from illness. “Having approached, He will bow to his feet And say to the illustrious guest, ‘Welcome! What brings you here?[2832]

myur du khyod ni gang du 'gro/ / yid byung ci phyir rab tu 'dug / de smras khro ldan byis pa la/ / tshe ldan khyod kyis ma thos sam/ / rkang gnyis dam pa rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / 'jig rten kun gyi ston pa ni/ / sangs rgyas bdag gi pha zhes smra/ / mar me 'bar bzhin mya ngan 'das/ / dpa' bo chen po nub par gyur/ / sa yi steng ni stongs par gyur/ / de bzhin 'jig rten ma lus stongs/ / bdag gi phyogs rnams kun stongs gyur/ / byis de phyin ci log sems kyis/ / der ni rgan zhugs rab dga' nas/ / rab rgod tshig tu smras pa ni/ / rab tu ring de 'das gyur tam/ / phyag ring lus ni che ba dang / / mgo ni gdugs kyi rnam pa 'dra/ / bdag cag rnams kyi gtso bo mchog / bslab dang bslab min rjes su ston/ /

“ ‘Or where are you going? Are you leaving soon, or are you going to stay?’ He will say that to the sage [Mahākāśyapa], Who will reply to the fool, ‘Long-lived one! Have you not heard? “ ‘The Teacher of the whole world, The perfect Buddha, supreme among two-legged beings, My father, a buddha of great wisdom,[2833] Is extinguished like the flame of a lamp. “ ‘The great hero has departed, And the earth has become empty. All the worlds are likewise empty, And empty too are the regions for me.’ “Thereupon, the elderly monk With the twisted mind of a fool will rejoice. Laughing in ridicule, he will say, ‘Is that old geezer dead? “ ‘The one with long arms And the head lofty as a parasol? Our chief guide Steeped in his ‘learned’ ignorance?[2834]

da ltar de ni mya ngan 'das/ / ci 'dod bzhin du bdag cag spyod/ / rgan zhugs kyis ni de smras nas/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po rab 'khrugs nas/ / gdong la khro gnyer byas nas ni/ / yi ge hU~M ni rab tu sbyar/ / sdom brtson bag chags bslang nas ni/ / bram ze de mod rab 'khrugs nas/ / rkang pa'i mthe bos de ma thag / sa yi steng du rab bsnun pas/ / sa rnams dang ni ri rab kyang / / rab tu 'gul bar gyur pa dang / / rgya mtsho rnams dang shing rnams dang / / ri rab kun kyang 'khrugs par gyur/ / klu rgyal dang ni lha rnams dang / / ri sul phug kyang rnam par 'gyel/ / zla ba dang ni nyi ma dang / / sa steng de tshe snang ba nyams/ / rlung yang rgyu ba med par gnas/ / skar mda' dag kyang sa la ltung / /

“ ‘Now that he is gone, I will promptly do whatever I want.’ Powerful Mahākāśyapa, his hair standing on end, Being thus addressed by the old monk, “Will knit his brows in angry contortion And employ the syllable hūṁ.
