The brahmin, habituated to asceticism, Will be furious at that moment. “He will strike the ground, At that moment, with his toe, And the entire earth[2835] will sway With a loud thunder coming from the mountains. “All the oceans will become agitated, All the trees, mountains, Valleys, and caves will quake, And all the nāgas and deities dwelling there will tremble. “The light of the moon and the sun Will disappear on earth at that time. The winds will die down, And meteors will fall.[2836]
de nas de ni sngags zhes brjod/ / nyan thos rnams kyi rigs las byung / / yi ge hU~M de yi ge gcig / las rnams ma lus byed cing dge/ /
“He, One Syllable with the sound hūṁ, When pronounced like this by the śrāvakas, Is the manifestation of the family And auspiciously accomplishes all activities.[2837]

sngags kyi rgyal po bzlas tsam gyis/ / 'di ni bzlas pa tsam gyis byed/ / 'gro dang gnas pa'i dug dang ni/ / de bzhin dgra kun rengs par byed/ / sems can gdug pa thams cad la/ / bzlas pa tsam gyis rengs par byed/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las byed cing / / khyad par du yang gzhan nyid byed/ / rgan zhugs tshig kyal rab smras pa/ / der ni mi smrar mthur bltas 'dug / de yi rdzu 'phrul la dad nas/ / de yi mod la rnam par btul/ / de tshe nyan thos mchog gi ni/ / gdung sbyong shing gi drung du khyer/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / dge slong de ni rkang gis song / / der song des ni thub pa'i sku/ / shing la yod par rab tu mthong / / lha yi tshogs ni du mas kyang / / mchod pa chen po byed pa dang / / gau ta ma ni thub pa yi/ / sku ni shing gi steng bzhag mthong / /

“Even when he is not fully mastered, This king of mantras, just by being recited, Arrests all weapons and poisons, Whether they be of animate or inanimate origin. “Through merely being recited, He[2838] paralyzes all evil beings And accomplishes other specific activities Of many different types. “The garrulous old monk Will fall silent and remain so thenceforth, Humbled by [the display of] magical power And chastised, at that moment, by Mahākāśyapa. “He will then be led by this eminent śrāvaka To where the funeral pyre is. The monk Mahākāśyapa, free from desire, Exceedingly powerful, will travel there on foot. “Having arrived, he will see The Sage’s body laid upon the funeral pyre, And many groups of gods Worshiping it with large offerings. “He will see the funeral pyre, With the body of the sage Gautama mounted upon it,
Provided with the best accoutrements And adorned with all the [required] articles.[2839]

'od srung chen po rmad byung ba/ / skal ba chen po de mthong nas/ / rdzu 'phrul chen pos dge slong rnams/ / thams cad smre sngags 'don par byed/ / lha dang 'byung po'i tshogs kun ni/ / ha ha'i rnam pa rab 'don cing / / de ltar mya ngan skyes pa yi/ / nyam thag sgra ni shin tu che/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po lha dang klu/ / de nas kun gyis rab bsu nas/ / rkang gnyis mchog la phyag byos zhes/ / skal ba che la'ang rab tu smras/ / lha tshogs mi dang bcas pa dang / / 'byung po kun gyi tshogs dag dang / / mi bdag drang srong gnod sbyin dag / khyod la sdod cing gzhol ba yin/ / shing la me gtong 'bad gyur kyang / / sku sbyong shing ni sbar mi nus/ / de nas de ni skyon bral ba/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po skal ba ches/ / gdung sbyong shing gi smad cha la/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po des phyag byas/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rjes dran nas/ / bskor ba dag kyang mang du byas/ / de tshe lcags kyi sgrom dral nas/ / zhabs gnyis dag kyang rnam brkyang la/ / yang dang yang du zhabs byugs nas/ / zhabs gnyis spyi bos phyag byas nas/ / thub mchog mchog gi zhabs gnyis la/ / lan mang dag tu rnam par bltas/ / des ni zhabs gnyis yang zhugs te/ / lcags kyi sgrom la yang dag gnas/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / de ni de nas langs 'dug pa/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / dgra bcom rnams kyis yongs su bskor/ /

“When they see the wonderful, Illustrious Mahākāśyapa, All the monks, Free from faults and very dignified,[2840] “And all the hosts of gods and spirits, Will exclaim, ‘Alas, alas!’ They will wail with loud cries, Outpourings of their sorrow. “All the powerful gods and nāgas Will come forward And say to the illustrious one, ‘Pay respects to the supreme among two-legged beings! “ ‘All the hosts of gods and all the people Have been waiting for you; The hosts of spirits, The ṛṣis, the yakṣas, and the human kings All tried to light the funeral pyre But were unable to.’ “The illustrious one, free from faults And endowed with great powers, Will circumambulate [the pyre] many times clockwise. Recollecting the Tathāgata, He will pay his respects At the edge of the pyre with great dignity. “He will break open the iron casket So that the two feet emerge. Bowing his head at the feet [of the Blessed One], He will touch them again and again. “Having thus repeatedly looked At the fine feet of the eminent sage, He will again lay them to rest In the iron casket. “The powerful one who is free from desire Will then rise up and take his seat Among the powerful arhats, Who are also free from desire.

ma ga d+hA gtso rgyal po yang / / sku sbyong shing gi thad 'ongs pa/ / glang po shing rta bzhon rta dang / / mthar gyis de nas theg pa yis/ / de nas dpung chen sa yi bdag / kun kyang stobs dang bzhon par bcas/ / de tshe thub pa shAka thub la/ / de ni phyag 'tshal don du lhags/ / sa steng zhi ba'i gzims mal du/ / bas mtha' dgon par mya ngan 'das/ / chu bo gser ldan 'gram dang ni/ / cod pan bcings pa'i mchod rten du/ / zhi ba'i dbyings la yang dag zhugs/ / yang dag mtha' la yongs su brten/ / ma ga d+hA yi rgyal po der/ / dpung chen ldan pas yang dag lhags/ / rnam pa sna tshogs spyod pa yis/ / de yang nga la stod par byed/ / phan yon che zhing stobs dang ldan/ / ngo mtshar sa yi rgyan gyur pa/ / thub pa'i sku sbyangs las byung ba'i/ / der ni sku gdung mchod rten byas/ /

“The Magadhan king[2841] Will approach the funeral pyre At the head of a procession of chariots Drawn by elephants and horses. “Then other kings, commanders of great forces, Will arrive there, all of them with their armies, To pay respects To the sage Śākyamuni, “Who passed into nirvāṇa lying on the ground, In a peaceful spot at the edge of the forest,[2842] On the bank of the Hiraṇyavatī, in Makuṭabandhana, And is now inside the caitya, Absorbed into the sphere[2843] of peace And abiding in ultimate reality. “The Magadhan king, Accompanied by his great army, Will see celestial displays Of many kinds, “Rich in blessing, powerful, Miraculous, adorning the earth, Arising from the form of the caitya Where the Sage will be lying upon the pyre.[2844]

dge slong kun dga' bo zhes bya/ / slob pa nga yi bsnyen bkur ba/ / mi yi dam pa mnyes gshin pa/ / nga la rtag tu yongs su dad/ / yid ni zhum zhing mya ngan gdungs/ / de yi tshe na 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de nas 'od srung thad song nas/ / rkang pa gnyis la rab btud nas/ / sdug bsngal nyam thag 'dar ba yis/ / 'di skad sgra ni 'dzer bas smras/ / deng 'dir nga yi ston pa 'das/ / da ltar bdag ni mgon med gyur/ / nga yi rten dang gnas dang skyabs/ / khyod nyid du ni rab tu bstan/ / thub pa'i zla ba de nyid kyis/ / nye gnas khyod kyi ra lung yang bstan/ / nyon mongs kun ni rnam spangs pa/ / khyod kyi nye gnas dgra bcom pa/ / thun gyi phyi ma mtshan mtha' la/ / rgyal ba des ni bstan pa yin/ / nga nyid mya ngan 'das pa na/ / rtag tu khyod ni yod par 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas mdzad pa'i don du ni/ / phan par 'dod pas khyod byed 'gyur/ / sdug bsngal can bdag spangs nas kyang / / thub pa chen po zhi bar gshegs/ / blo ldan ma 'gags pa zhes pas/ / sdom chen de ni dbugs 'byin byed/ / khyod ni mya ngan du ma byed/ / mya ngan dag kyang ma byed cig / gnas ni gang du'ang 'gro ma byed/ / 'di nyid du ni gnas par gyis/ /

“The monk called Ānanda, Who attends upon me as my good student, The most eminent person, Always dear to me and a cause of delight,[2845] Will become disheartened at that time And, tormented by anguish, “Will approach Mahākāśyapa And fall down at his feet. Distressed, he will speak In a stammering and faltering voice: “ ‘My teacher has passed into nirvāṇa today; Now I am without a protector. He indicated that you alone Will be my refuge and protection. “ ‘The moon-like sage prophesied That I, continuing at your side, Will remove all my afflictions And attain arhatship. “ ‘The Victorious One revealed During the last watch of the night That I am selected to be always with you Until I have passed into final nirvāṇa. “ ‘Desiring what is beneficial, he appointed you To carry out the work of the Buddha. The great Sage has passed into the final peace, Leaving me behind in distress.’ “The sagacious Aniruddha Will comfort the pious monk: ‘Do not cry in distress! Do not fall into despair! “ ‘Do not go to any other place, But stay here.

'jig rten mig ni 'das gyur nas/ / 'di nyid ston par 'gyur ba yin/ / 'dir ni ston pas lung bstan nas/ / sangs rgyas mdzad pa byed par 'gyur/ / nga yang bcom ldan lhan cig tu/ / 'od srung rjes su 'gro bar bya/ / ston pa gnyis po dag gi yang / / sa yi steng na gzugs brnyan yin/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po'i nyan thos ni/ / 'od srung chen po gtso bo ni/ / 'tsho zhing yongs su gzhes pas na/ / khyod ni mya ngan ma byed cig / rdzu 'phrul chen po snying rjes non/ / rnal 'byor chen po 'dod chags bral/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po thub pa'i sras/ / thams cad de bzhin smre bar byed/ / gyad dang rgyal po dag gis ni/ / pur sbyong shing la me btang bas/ / 'khor yug kun nas me 'bar nas/ / pur sbyong shing de thal bar gyur/ /

Mahākāśyapa himself will be our teacher When the “eye of the world” is extinguished. “ ‘It was prophesied here by the Sage That he will carry on the Buddha’s work, And we will follow him, Along with you. “ ‘As for his magical powers, Great distinction, energy, and great splendor,[2846] Mahākāśyapa is the second Teacher, as it were, His exact replica here on earth. “ ‘For as long as Mahākāśyapa, This eminent śrāvaka of great power, Remains and holds fast, Do not fall into despair.’ “Talking thus, all the sons of the Sage, Endowed with magical powers, Free from desire, and very studious, Will sit down.[2847] “The pyre will be lit By the Malla kings. It will blaze on all sides And then change into ashes.

de mthong lha yi tshogs dag dang / / gdengs can brang 'gro rnams kyis ni/ / pur sbyong shing gnas zhi ba'i phyir/ / tsan+dan chu yi rgyun dag gi/ / char chen rab tu gtong zhing gnas/ / de nas de yi mod la yang / / sa steng du yang de bzhin du/ / me tog tshogs kyi char yang btang / / rgyal ba'i ring bsrel mchod pa'i phyir/ / de yi mod la kun der lhags/ / thams cad phan tshun 'thab pa'i phyir/ / de yi mod la bya ba rtsom/ / tshangs sogs brgya byin 'thab bral dang / / lha tshogs kun kyang de bzhin no/ / nyan thos chen po 'dod chags bral/ / rdzu 'phrul chen pos zlog par byas/ / sku gdung rgyal ba'i ring bsrel ni/ / 'od srung chen pos rnam bgos pa/ / mchod pa'i don du thams cad la/ / cung zad cung zad nges par byin/ / theg pa gsum las mi ldog dang / / zhi ba mthar phyin bya phyir ro/ /

“Seeing this, the hosts of gods And the serpent-hooded mahoragas, In order to cool down the pyre ground, Will release a heavy shower “Of sandalwood water, Followed by, the next instant, A great rain of flowers Released upon the earth. “Instantly, all who came To worship the relics of the Victorious One Will all start fighting With each other. “The Brahmās, the Śakras, the Yāmas, And all the hosts of gods Will be held back by the śrāvakas With great magical powers. “Mahākāśyapa will distribute the relics Born from the body of the Victorious One. He will give only a small portion to everyone, So that they may be worshiped, Since they bring the final peace, The ultimate goal of the three vehicles.

rnal 'byor de tshe 'od srung che/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / rgan zhugs kyis ni smras pa'i tshig / de ni yongs su sems par byed/ / 'dir ni gsung rab ma lus pa/ / yan lag bcu gnyis bde 'byung gnas/ / mdo dang 'dul ba mngon pa'i chos/ / nam mkha'i dud bzhin ma gyur tam/ / dpa' bo chen po nub gyur nas/ / bstan pa 'jig par 'gyur bas na/ / sangs rgyas gsung ba'i bka' 'di ni/ / ma lus bdag gis bsdu bar bya/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / ma lus lhan cig bgro bar bya/ / ma ga d+hA yi grong mchog tu/ / grong khyer bzang po rgyal po'i khab/ / ku sha'i grong khyer nyams dga' dang / / ri ni rdo 'jog mtho ba dang / / yul bzang yangs pa can dang ni/ / mchod rten gnas ni legs mdzes pa/ / de bzhin rnam pa du ma'i gnas/ / bstan pa bsdu ba'i ched dag tu/ / 'dus nas smra ba kun smra ba/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po byed par 'gyur/ /

“Then Mahākāśyapa, a yogi Free from desire and very powerful, Will reflect upon the memorable words Spoken by the unruly old monk, and say: “ ‘The entirety of the great doctrine that brings happiness, With its twelve branches that comprise The Sūtra, the Vinaya, and the Abhidharma, Might vanish like smoke in the sky. When the great hero has departed, The destruction of the doctrine will follow. “ ‘All the teachings spoken by the Buddha Should be collected together. Let us all go together, Free from desire and dignified, To the capital city of the Magadhans, The fine city referred to as ‘royal’;[2848] “ ‘To beautiful Kuśāgrapura, With its nice, high mountains; And to Vaiśālī, a nice place Where there is a beautiful caitya.’ “All the lamenting[2849] Mallas, Together with the dignified [śrāvakas], Will do many such [peregrinations] then For the sake of the teachings.[2850]

nga yang 'dir ni nub pa dang / / de tshe dus kyi tha ma la/ / phan tshun gsod par dga' ba yi/ / sa bdag rnams ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ / las kyi mtha' mang dge slong rnams/ / sems can rnams ni chags pas rmongs/ / de bzhin dge bsnyen dge bsnyen ma/ / dus kyi mtha' la ma zhir 'gyur/ /

“At the end of the eon, When I have passed away, The kings will delight In killing one another. “Monks will engage in many types of business, And beings will be rendered senseless by greed. At the end of the eon, the male and female Lay practitioners will have no faith.[2851]
phan tshun skyon ni 'tshol byed cing / / phan tshun gsod la mngon par zhen/ / rma ldan skyon ni ma rungs ltar/ / skyon la rtag tu rtog par byed/ /
Dedicated to mutual slaughter, They will search each other out.[2852] “Armed with ‘piercing’ weapons, They will ever inflict wounds and bring harm.[2853]

thub pa de dus nub pa na/ / dge slong rnams ni ma bsdams 'gyur/ / de tshe sa steng bstan pa ni/ / bsrung ba'i don du bzhag gyur pa/ / chags bral zag med 'jig rten du/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po rnam pa brgyad/ / de tshe dgra bcom thu bo yang / / sgra gcan 'dzin sogs rab tu bsgrags/ /

Monks will lack self-control At the end of the eon, when the Sage is gone. “At that time, there will be on earth Eight arhats with great magical powers, Free from desire and karmic traits.[2854] They will be tasked with protecting my doctrine. “These distinguished arhats Will be those known as Rāhula and so forth.

de tshe dus kyi tha ma la/ / de dag kyang ni snang ba med/ / sngags pa grub pa'i dus su ni/ / de dag mthong ba don yod 'gyur/ / rdzu 'phrul ldan zhing rdzu 'phrul che/ / ngas kyang thams cad bzhag pa yin/ / grags pa chen po chad pa'i las/ / de dag la ni ngas bstan pa/ / de dag bka' las 'das pa 'am/ / cung zad bslab las rnam 'das na'o/ /

It will not be possible to see them At that time during the debased eon. “However, the practitioners of mantra, when accomplished, Will be able to see them without fail. All of them, appointed here by me, Will use the mantras of magic and possess great powers. “I have invested them, the glorious ones, With the authority to administer justice. Any student who disobeys their orders Will be guilty of transgression.

ji srid dam chos yang dag mtha'/ / zang zing med par gnas par gyis/ / nga yi gsung gi bsod nams 'di/ / ji srid bstan pa stobs dang ldan/ / des na bdag nyid zhir 'gyur zhing / / zag med mya ngan 'da' bar 'gyur/ / de tshe thub pa'i bstan pa ni/ / yongs su nub par 'gyur ba na/ / dge slong rnams dang dge tshul rnams/ / dge slong ma rnams ser snar bcas/ / rtag tu ngan spyod g.yo sgyu can/ / de tshe yongs su ma dag pa'o/ /

“If you hold on to the sacred Dharma‍— To the ultimate reality beyond the physical‍— And proclaim on earth This meritorious message of mine, “Then you will obtain the peace of no-self And enter the final nirvāṇa without karmic traits. When the Sage and his teaching have disappeared, The following will come to pass: “The monks and nuns who live on alms Will all become very greedy. Ever acting as detestable beggars, They will proliferate during the debased eon.

nga yi bstan la mi gnas shing / / khyim dang chung ma tshol bar byed/ / de yi tshe na dge bsnyen rnams/ / gzhan gyi bud med la rtag dang / / lhag ma rnam pa bzhi po nyid/ / de tshe rtags dang ming tsam yod/ / 'khon 'dzin thams cad goms byed cing / / gcig la gcig ni rnam 'tshe byed/ / phal cher mu stegs kyis non cing / / lha rnams kun kyang gnod par 'gyur/ / de tshe bram ze'i rigs la ni/ / skye bo rnams ni dga' bar 'gyur/ / de bzhin log spyod rmongs pa dang / / mi rnams srog chags 'tshe bar dga'/ / nga ni yongs su mya ngan 'das/ / rtsod dus 'di la lung bstan yin/ /

“The practice of keeping houses and wives Will become integrated into my doctrine. Lay practitioners, at that time, Will always have sex with the wives of others. “The fourfold assembly will remain In name only, merely to keep appearances. They will all bring harm upon one another, Delighting in enmity. “The entire earth will be taken over By the tīrthikas and [saṃsāric] gods; People, at that time, Will adore the brahmin caste. “Deluded and following wrong conduct, They will delight in harming living beings. This has been prophesied for this lowest eon, When I enter into final nirvāṇa.
mi ni rnam mang gzhan dag kyang / / rtag tu gzhan gyi bud med dga'/ / mi dge kun la dga' ba dang / / dge ba'i don ni rnam spangs pa/ /
“Many men and women will Continuously indulge in adultery. They will all delight in nonvirtue And shun virtuous values.

nga ni sa steng zhir gshegs nas/ / sems can mang po 'byung bar 'gyur/ / nga yi sku ni mchod pa'i phyir/ / gzi brjid chen po lha tshogs dang / / bdag nyid chen po mi rnams dang / / de bzhin gnod sbyin 'byung po'i tshogs/ / lha min dang ni dri za dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po mi 'am ci/ / de nas mkha' lding klu dang ni/ / de bzhin srin po drang srong rnams/ / rnal 'byor pa dang grub pa dang / / gzi brjid chen po gza' rnams dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs skye gnas dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs sems can rnams/ / srid pa'i 'ching bas bcings pa dang / / blo ldan 'ching ba bcad pa dang / / sku gdung nad bral 'di la ni/ / de tshe mchod pa byed par 'gyur/ / chu bo gser ldan 'gram dang ni/ / sA la zung gi tshal dang ni/ / cod pan bcings pa'i mchod rten dang / / gyad rnams kyi ni nyen 'khor du/ / nga ni der yang mya ngan 'da'/ / 'jig med zhi bar yongs su 'gro/ /

“After I enter the final peace on earth, Many beings will be present, Worshiping my body, Such as the hosts of gods of great vitality and splendor, “Men of distinction, Hosts of yakṣas and spirits, Asuras, gandharvas, Kinnaras endowed with great powers, “Garuḍas, nāgas,[2855] Rākṣasas, ṛṣis, Siddhas, yogins, Planets with great vitality,[2856] “Beings of various types That take birth based on their different destinies And are caught in the chain of saṃsāric rebirths, And also the wise ones who have broken this chain. “They will make offerings to my body,[2857] From which the pangs of fever have departed, On the bank of the Hiraṇyavatī, In the Yamakasāla Grove, “In the Makuṭabandhana shrine, In the country of the Mallas. When I pass into final nirvāṇa there, I will attain the peace that is free from fear.

nga yi sku gdung de blangs nas/ / de bzhin gzhan gyis 'phrog par byed/ / lha dang lha ma yin rnams dang / / de tshe 'byung po'i tshogs kun gyis/ / so sor cha ni rnam phye nas/ / rnam par gzhag pa byas par gyur/ / mi yi rgyal po dpung chen ldan/ / ma ga d+hA yi ma skyes dgra/ / rdzu 'phrul che ldan nyan thos ni/ / kun la'ang gsol ba rab 'debs pa/ / bsod nams bdag gis ma byas pas/ / bdag gi pha yang shi bar gyur/ / bdag ni sdug bsngal ltung gyur pas/ / bdag nyid chen pos drang du gsol/ / de nas blo ldan nyan thos mchog / sangs rgyas thugs las skyes pa'i sras/ / 'od srung chen po zhes grags pa/ / skye dgu rnams la phan byed pas/ / ma skyes dgra ni ngo tsha ldan/ / sems zhum gyur te mthong nas ni/ / rdzu 'phrul nyid la rab gnas nas/ / de yi dus su yang dag dgongs/ / rgyal ba'i ring bsrel sku gdung ni/ / cha gcig khyod kyis blang bar gyis/ / rgyal po gzhan ni stobs ldan gyis/ / gzhan dag rab tu khyer bar gyur/ /

“My relics will be exhumed, With some being stolen By gods, asuras, And all types of spirits. They will be divided into separate portions And then distributed. “At that time, the Magadhan king Ajātaśatru, Together with his great army, Will make a request to all the śrāvakas Endowed with great magical powers: “ ‘Please, great beings, Uplift me also, Crestfallen and suffering, Even though I am a patricide without merit.’ “The most eminent, wise śrāvaka, The dear son of the Buddha Called Mahākāśyapa, Who brings benefit to beings, “Seeing this intelligent man called Ajātaśatru And noticing his distress, Will give him then his due attention And bless[2858] him with his magical power. “He will pick up a portion of relics[2859] Produced from the body of the Victorious One. The remaining relics will be taken by the others, Including very powerful snake-like beings.[2860]

phan tshun bab col 'khrugs nas ni/ / gcig la gcig ni 'khon byas nas/ / de tshe nam mkhar sku gdung khyer/ / rang gi gnas su'ang bzhag par 'gyur/ / de tshe thub pa'i nyan thos mchog / dge slong 'od srung chen po de/ / kye ma'o kyi hud sems pa ni/ / sa steng 'dir ni rab stongs pa/ / sangs rgyas dang ni rang rgyal dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po'i nyan thos kyis/ / sems can 'jigs par snang ba ste/ / srid pa'i btson rar spyod pa yin/ / rnam pa sna tshogs sdug bsngal drag / yun ring rjes su myong bar 'gyur/ / 'jig rten mgon po skyob pa yi/ / ring bsrel yang dag mchod byas nas/ / de dag lha yi 'jig rten du/ / yun mi thung bar bde ba myong / /

“Each trying to be quicker than the other, They will push and shove in great agitation. They will then carry the relics through space To their own abodes and install them there.[2861] “The monk Mahākāśyapa, The most eminent śrāvaka, Will, at that time, reflect on the Sage:[2862] “ ‘Ah, woe to humankind! He is absent from this earthly round With its buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, And śrāvakas with great miraculous powers. “ ‘The light has gone out for beings[2863] Who wander in the prison of saṃsāra. They will now experience various types Of acute suffering for a long time. “ ‘If, however, they worship the relics Of the savior, the lord of the world, They will experience the pleasures Of the god realms in abundance.

rgyal srid de nas longs spyod dang / / rnyed par dka' ba'i sngags rnams ni/ / 'gro ba sna tshogs spyod pa yis/ / rnam pa sna tshogs thob par 'gyur/ / phun tshogs 'dod pa 'jig rten mchog / rnam thar gsum gyis rnam par brgyan/ / sku gdung rnams ni mchod byas na/ / grub pa mchog ni thob par 'gyur/ / 'jig rten rnams grags bram ze zhes/ / thub pa mchog ni nyan thos gtso/ / 'od srung zhes ni bya ba yis/ / 'di ltar de ni bsams nas ni/ / de tshe sa las ma phye bar/ / de yi sku gdung blangs nas ni/ / ma ga d+hA bdag ma skyes dgras/ / 'bad nas cung zad yongs su byin/ / de bzhin rgyal po kun la yang / / 'od chen po ni ma mthong yang / / nyan thos bdag nyid chen po des/ / kun la'ang thams cad rab tu byin/ / kun la'ang mi rtag 'du shes kyis/ / de na yang ni gnas par gyur/ / snying rjes brlan pa'i sems kyis ni/ / sems can rnams la mya ngan byed/ /

“ ‘They will obtain kingdoms, prosperity, And mantric accomplishments, so difficult to attain. They will attain the various things That reflect the lifestyles of favorable rebirths, “ ‘Including the desired boon of reaching the peak of existence That is adorned with the threefold liberation. By worshiping the relics They will attain the supreme accomplishment.’ “Reflecting like this, The world-renowned brahmin, The śrāvaka and the distinguished sage By the name Kāśyapa, “Will pick up some relics And distribute them, at that time, on earth.[2864] With special care, he will give a relic-pill To the king of the Magadhans called Ajātaśatru, “And also to all the eight kings. This śrāvaka, a great being Of great splendor, Will give everything completely to all of them. “With his mind overcome with compassion, He will grieve for sentient beings Who, lacking the understanding of impermanence, Continue to undergo the cycle of rebirth:[2865]

shAkya'i skyes mchog bstan pa ni/ / 'jig rten dam chos nub pa na/ / bskal pa rnam pa mang por ni/ / yun ring sems can dud par 'gyur/ / 'di dag dud bzhin mi 'gyur bar/ / 'di dag gsung ni bsdu bar bya/ / dpa' bo de las langs nas ni/ / sems kyi stobs ni nyams pa med/ / rgyal po ma skyes dgrar gyur pa'i/ / mi yi dbang pos mgron du bos/ / ston pa'i bstan pa bya ba'i phyir/ / rgyal po'i khab kyi grong khyer 'dir/ / 'bad pas sku gdung myur du ni/ / gser gyi snod kyi nang du bcug / de dag sngon du yang dag btang / / de tshe rgyal po'i khab myur 'gro/ / 'od ma'i tshal du phyin nas ni/ / sku gdung dag ni yang dag bzhag /

“ ‘Beings will weep for a long time, Lasting many eons. When the sacred Dharma of the Teacher, the Lion of the Śākyas, Has disappeared in the world, These teachings should be chanted, During the terrible time of destruction.’[2866] “Then the valiant Mahākāśyapa will rise and, With his mind imbued with power,[2867] Will address Ajātaśatru, The king of men: “ ‘To honor the Teacher’s instructions, Let us go to the city of Rājagṛha.’ Having carefully placed the relics In one hundred jars, “They will then travel eastward, Hastily proceeding toward Rājagṛha. After they arrive in the Bamboo Grove, They will deposit there the relics of the Victorious One.

'jig rten mgon po skyob pa yi/ / mchod rten rmad byung chen po byas/ / mchod rten de ni mchod byed pa/ / rnam pa sna tshogs rgyan dang ni/ / phreng ba gos dang gdugs dang ni/ / dar la rol mo byug pa dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs du ma dang / / mar me me tog phreng ba yis/ / phyag 'tshal rjes song sems kyis ni/ / rgyal po rab tu mchod pa byed/ / mchod rten de la mgos btud nas/ / de yi tshe na smon lam btab/ / 'jig rten mchog la mchod pa yis/ / bdag gi dge ba mang po gang / / de bzhin gshegs la mchod pa 'dis/ / bsam gyis mi khyab mchog thob shog /

“After building a marvelous stūpa Of the savior, the lord of the world, The great king will offer to this stūpa Adornments of many kinds: “Garlands, fabrics, parasols, Scented powders, perfume, incense, Silks, music, riches,[2868] banners, Various bells, garlands,[2869] unguents, And lamps, chaplets, and wreaths, Of many different kinds. “Having made these offerings, The great king, his mind steeped in reverence, Will bow with his head to the stūpa And at that time make the following aspiration: “ ‘May I, by the abundant merit gained Through worshiping the most eminent being in the world, Attain the inconceivable [state whereby I will] Worship many tathāgatas.’[2870]

de nas rgyal po langs nas ni/ / 'od srung che la rab tu smras/ / mig ni mchi mas kun khyab nas/ / mig gi mchi ma phyis nas ni/ / snying ni brtse bas rab brlan nas/ / de tshe pha ni yang dag dran/ / shes rab chen po 'phags pa khyod/ / khyod ni bdag gi dbang 'gyur mdzod/ / bdag gi sdig pa gang byas pa/ / nges par mnar med rab tu gzhol/ /

“The king will then rise And speak to Mahākāśyapa, Wiping teardrops off his face. With his eyes dimmed by tears And his heart brimming with compassion, He will recall his father: “ ‘My noble friend of great wisdom, Please be my confessor![2871] The evil that I have committed Will cause me to fall into the Avīci hell.

ston pa'i bka' yi lam gnas pa/ / de 'dra'i chos kyi rgyal po yi/ / pha yi srog la gnod bcas pa'i/ / mya ngan bsal bar mi nus pas/ / 'phags pa dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis/ / bdag la chos don bstan par rigs/ / de skad smras nas bdag nyid che/ / rgyal ba'i nyan thos mchog gyur pa/ / blo ldan 'od srung zhes bya bas/ / 'di dag tshig ni rab tu smras/ / rgyal po chen po ma 'jigs shig / khyod kyi dge ba mang du byas/ / skye ba brgya phrag du mar yang / / khyod la goms pa rab tu yod/ / sangs rgyas 'byung ba med pa na/ / rang rgyal gcig ni yang dag byung / / grong khyer bA rA Na sI ru/ / de tshe tshong dpon bu zhig byung / / mi shes byis pa g.yo ba yis/ / de tshe shing rta zhon nas byung / /

“ ‘Having killed my father,[2872] A Dharma king established On the path taught by the Teacher, I am unable to distract myself. My good and noble friend, Be so kind as to teach me the meaning of the Dharma!’ “Thus addressed, the great being, The foremost śrāvaka of the Victorious One, The sagacious one called Mahākāśyapa Will say the following: “ ‘Do not fear, great king! You have accumulated a lot of merit. In your former births You have practiced virtue hundreds of times. “ ‘Once, when there was no Buddha in the world, There lived a pratyekabuddha. At that time, in the city of Vārāṇasī, A son was born to a prominent merchant. In his ignorance and childish frivolity, He went out onto the road.[2873]

bcom ldan de nyid de ru ni/ / rang rgyal yongs su byung ba ni/ / 'jig rten rjes su gzung 'dod pas/ / der ni slong mo'i don du rgyu/ / byis pa des ni de mthong nas/ / sems ni yang dag dang gyur nas/ / rkang gnyis la gtugs dris pa ni/ / dge slong khyod ni ci zhig byed/ / bse ru lta bur skye ba med/ / bcom ldan de ni mi smrar 'dug / de tshe byis pa de yi ni/ / gos la bzung nas yang dag gnas/ / 'deng ngo 'deng ngo khyim bzang 'dir/ / rgyal mtshan gyis ni rab mtshan pa'o/ / 'di ni bdag gi khyim yin te/ / zhabs bkrus nas ni bshos gsol te/ / ji ltar dus bzhin myur gsol nas/ / ci 'dod par ni rtse bar bgyi'o/ /

“ ‘He came upon The blessed pratyekabuddha, Who, out of desire to benefit the world, Was doing his alms rounds. “ ‘Upon seeing the pratyekabuddha The boy’s mind was filled with faith.[2874] He fell at his feet and asked, “What are you about to do, monk?” “ ‘The blessed, rhinoceros-like lord[2875] Remained silent And stood there As the boy held him by the robe, [saying,] “ ‘ “Come! Come to that fine house Adorned with a banner! This is our dwelling. You will wash your feet and have some food.[2876] We shall promptly eat as much as we like, And then play to our hearts’ content.”

de nas nyes dang bral ba de/ / nyes gsum mthar byed 'joms pa po/ / gzhan dag rjes gzung de dag gtsor/ / mthar gyis kyang ni rab 'gro zhing / / song nas sgo yi rtsa ba la/ / 'od chen der ni 'dug par gyur/ / de nas byis pa nang zhugs nas/ / ma la yang ni 'di skad smras/ / ma ni bdag la 'bras chan stsol/ / bza' ba rnam mang dag kyang stsol/ / yun ring sa rdul la rtse ba'i/ / bdag gi grogs po 'dir 'ongs gyur/ / yun ring bdag ni dgar 'gyur ba/ / sgor ni 'ongs nas 'dug pa yin/ / de tshe de ni rab rings par/ / de yi mod la sgor yang byung / / rdzu 'phrul chen po zhi ba'i gzugs/ / bdag nyid chen po de yang mthong / / de tshe de ni myur 'ongs nas/ / snod ni bzang po blangs nas kyang / / lag pa legs par rab bkrus nas/ / me tog spos sogs sngon 'gro bas/ / 'bras chan gtsang ma blangs nas ni/ / du ma'i ro yis rnam brgyan pa'i/ / rnam pa sna tshogs bza' ba dang / / dngul gyi snod du rab tu bcug / de tshe myur du phyir byung ste/ / de yi lhung bzed la blugs nas/ / khyor bcas chos la dad pa yis/ / de yi rkang pa gnyis la gtugs/ /

“ ‘The monk, free from faults, His three stains[2877] definitively destroyed, And committed to the kind treatment of others, Followed the boy. Having arrived at the door, The glorious monk waited. “ ‘The boy entered And called out, “Mother! Please give some food for me, And also alms of various kinds. “ ‘ “My friend has arrived here at long last, Who will play with me in the sand. At last, you will be pleased with him; He stands waiting at the door.” “ ‘Hastily, she came out the door, And immediately saw The distinguished person, Peaceful, and of great majesty. “ ‘She then quickly went in, Took a fine vessel, Cleaned it with her hands, And prepared some flowers and incense.[2878] “ ‘She took some pure rice pudding Flavored with many spices, And also different other foodstuffs, And arranged them on a silver plate. “ ‘She then promptly returned [to the door] And placed [the articles] in the monk’s bowl. Then she, fond of the Dharma like her son, Fell down at the monk’s feet.[2879]

de yis bsod snyoms blangs nas ni/ / nam mkha' la ni mngon par song / / de nas de ni rab 'bar zhing / / mar me'i phreng ba bzhin du snang / / bse ru ltar spyod gang yin pa/ / de dag ngag gis chos ston min/ / rdzu 'phrul 'od kyis sems can la/ / bdag nyid chen po ston par byed/ / de yang lhag par snying rje can/ / sems can 'gro ba ser snar ldan/ / pha rol don du sems can la/ / de nas rdzu 'phrul ston par byed/ / de yi rnam smin las kyis ni/ / ma dang lhan cig byis pa yang / / stong phrag lnga yi skye bar ni/ / lha nyid kyang ni byas par gyur/ / lha rnams kyi ni lha rgyal der/ / ma de nyid ni yang dag gyur/ /

“ ‘The monk accepted the alms And flew up into the sky, Where he could be seen As a row of lights. “ ‘The rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddhas Do not teach the Dharma verbally. These great beings present it to others Through their magical powers. “ ‘They are exceedingly compassionate Toward beings and free from selfishness. They reveal their supernatural power To beings with respect to future lives. “ ‘By the ripening of this karma, The boy along with the mother Attained the state of a celestial being For five hundred births. “ ‘He became a king of gods, And she his mother.

'khor los sgyur nyid mi rnams kyi/ / mi yi bdag por de tshe gyur/ / yun ring bde ba rjes myong nas/ / gzugs can snying po'i bur 'di gyur/ / gang gi bcom ldan de smras dang / / gos kyi tha ma la bzung dang / / tshig ngan smra ba smras pa ni/ / dge slong smra bas smras pa dang / / sa rdul bdag dang rtse ba zhes/ / de tshe sngon ni khyod ces smras/ gi las ni de yis ni/ / mi 'dod pa dang tsha ba yi/ / drag cing rab tsha'i sdug bsngal ba/ / yun ring mang po rjes myong ba/ / mi 'dod sdug bsngal bzod dka' ba/ / mi bzad dmyal bar ltung bar 'gyur/ / las kyi zhags pas bcings nas ni/ / sems can ngan 'gror 'gro bar 'gyur/ / rgod pas las ni byed pa yis/ / du bas rjes su myong bar 'gyur/ / de bzhin byis pa'i rang bzhin gyis/ / nyan thos rgyal ba skyob pa la/ / tshig ni ma rungs rgya che ba/ / de yi las ni 'di 'dra 'o/ /

Then he became a human-born king, Ruling over an empire of men. “ ‘Having enjoyed pleasures for a long time, He was born, in this world, as the son of Bimbisāra, The same one who had grabbed the blessed [monk] By the robe and pulled him. “ ‘You, however, spoke improper words When addressing a monk, Saying, at that time, “Be my playmate in the sand.”[2880] “ ‘Based on the past karma of those words, Undesirable and rude, You experienced, for a long time, An intense and acute suffering, Falling, against your wishes, into the terrible hell Where the pain is difficult to bear. “ ‘Ensnared thus in the trammels of karma, Beings follow painful destinies. One creates karma laughing, But experiences it crying. “ ‘Because of your former childish attitude Toward a savior, a pratyekabuddha,[2881] You spoke improper words, Thus creating the corresponding karma.

dmyal ba las ni thar nas kyang / / mi nyid du ni 'dir yang 'ongs/ / rnam smin skyes pa mi yi bdag / dmyal ba yang ni dran par gyur/ / de yi khro ba bdo ba yis/ / khyod kyis pha yi srog kyang bcad/ / rang rgyal dag gi spyod pa yang / / sngon gyi bag chags kyis dran pas/ / sangs rgyas mngon sum mthong nas ni/ / skye dgu dag kyang de bzhin byas/ / de nyid rgyu ni dran byas pas/ / 'dir ni rgyal thabs nyid kyang byas/ / de ltar 'od ma'i tshal du ni/ / phan tshun de dag sa steng smra/ / nga yi slob ma mchog 'di dang / / gnyis pa mi yi bdag po yis/ / mchod rten lan brgyar phyag 'tshal nas/ / de tshe rang gi khyim du song / / de nas slob ma'i mchog gyur pa/ / pi pal phug na gnas pa de/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / thub pa ma lus 'dus nas ni/ / gsung rab yan lag bcu gnyis dang / / 'dul ba ma lus sdud par byed/ / gang zhig chos ni ngas bstan dang / / de bzhin sngon gyi rgyal ba mchog / de nas slob ma'i mchog des kyang / / rnam pa gsum du yang dag bstan/ / 'dul ba dang ni mngon pa dang / / mdo sde'i dbye bas gzhung du byas/ /

“ ‘Having left the hell realm, You became human and arrived here, But your consciousness, O king, Was still in a hell born of karmic ripening. “ ‘Because of this and your violent anger, You were predisposed to kill your father. Similarly, because of a pre-existing karmic trait Created by serving a pratyekabuddha, You met the Buddha in person And you worshiped him. “ ‘By the same cause of [serving a pratyekabuddha], You have obtained a kingdom in this [world].’ Thus will the two of them converse In the Bamboo Grove on earth. “The first one, my foremost disciple, And the second one, the king, Will bow to the stūpa hundreds of times And then go each to his own home. “My foremost disciple, Who shelters under the pipal tree, Will call a meeting[2882] of the sages, All of them free from desire and very dignified. “The entire doctrine with its twelve branches, Along with the Vinaya, will be recited[2883] there‍— The Dharma that I have taught, And that which was formerly taught by other victors. “The doctrine will be presented By the foremost disciple as threefold, With its scriptures divided into Sūtra, Vinaya, and Abhidharma.

sems can 'ching ba gsum las bkrol/ / nyes pa gsum yang skem par byed/ / dpa' bo sdug bsngal gsum las 'grol/ / rtag tu theg pa gsum la dgod/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis bstan pa'i don/ / blo yi mchog ni byed par 'gyur/ / rgyal chen ma skyes dgra zhes pa'i/ / ma ga d+hA pa mi yi bdag / ang ga ma ga d+hA dang ni/ / bA rA Na sI de las gzhan/ / byang du yangs pa can dang ni/ / rgyal chen stobs po che bar ni/ / the tshom med par 'gyur ba yin/ / bstan pa'i don ni byed par 'gyur/ / gzhon nu khyod ni 'dul byed cing / / zhi ba dam pa ston par 'gyur/ /

“The wise[2884] [Mahākāśyapa] will release beings From the three fetters, dry up their three faults, Free them from the three sufferings, And establish them in the three vehicles. “The sagacious one will thus Further the cause of the buddhas’ teachings. As for the king of the Magadhans, The great monarch Ajātaśatru, “He will extend his rule over the entirety of Magadha and Aṅga, After that over Vārāṇasī, And then over Vaiśālī to the north. He will become a very powerful king “Who will advance the cause of the teachings, Of this there is no doubt. He is prophesied to attain the ultimate peace, After being instructed by you, divine youth.[2885]

de yi bu yang rgyal po ni/ / yi ge u zhes bya bar bsgrags/ / de tshe 'byung bar 'gyur ba ni/ / myur du bstan pa'i don la brtson/ / des ni ston pa'i gsung rab 'dir/ / rgya cher 'dri bar byed 'jug 'gyur/ / mchod pa chen po'ang byas nas ni/ / phyogs rnams kun tu rgyas par byed/ / phyir yang ngan song 'di mi 'gro/ / lhar skye bar ni de 'gyur ro/ / lo ni nyi shu sum cur ni/ / pha dang lhan cig 'grogs par 'gyur/ /

“His son, the king known By the initial U,[2886] Will also become, before long, Actively engaged in promoting the teachings. “He will have these teachings Committed to writing in their entirety. After worshiping [the volumes] with many offerings, He will distribute them throughout the quarters. “Later he will not suffer a low rebirth, But will be reborn among gods, After[2887] twenty or thirty years Spent among the pitṛs.

grong khyer stobs ldan mtshan phyed du/ / rigs las skyes pa'i nad kyis ni/ / mngon par zil gyis non par 'gyur/ / nyin zhag sum cu rtsa drug tu/ / nad chen dag gis nyam thag 'gyur/ / nad rnams kun gyis btab nas de/ / rnam pa sna tshogs brgyal nas ni/ / rgyal po de myur shi 'phos nas/ / lha rnams su ni skye bar 'gyur/ / de ni mthar gyis 'bad nas ni/ / nges par byang chub thob par 'gyur/ / 'di dang gzhan yang mang po ni/ / 'das pa dang ni ma 'ongs par/ / rang rgyal skyob pa dag la ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs byas pa yis/ / de bzhin lha dang mi rnams kyis/ / 'dod dang khyad par phun tshogs 'thob/ / de dag mthar gyis 'gro 'gyur ba/ / zhi ba nad med go 'phang 'thob/ /

“His earthly existence Will end at midnight,[2888] When he will succumb to a disease That runs in his family. “For twenty-six days He will suffer the pain of this terrible disease. Affected by all manner of illnesses, He will be incapacitated in different ways. “He will thus pass away And swiftly be reborn among the gods. With effort and care, in due course, He will certainly attain realization. “These and many other kings, Those in the past and the future, Having done various services For the pratyekabuddhas and the victorious[2889] saviors, “Obtain the wished-for extraordinary fortunes, Whether divine or human, And, in due course, attain peace‍— The blessed state free from decay.
rgyal po mchog dang dman pa dang / / mi yi bdag po bar ma rnams/ / rgyal po na hu sha la sogs/ / dang po'i dus su bstan pa dag /
“Kings can be of three categories, Higher, middling, or inferior. The kings said [to have ruled] in the first eon Are those of the Nahuṣa[2890] and Pārthiva[2891] lines.

“Budha, Śukra, and Udaya were kings Who were definitely mantra adepts. There were also Śāntanu, Citra, and Sucitra And the kings of the Paṇḍu dynasty.[2892] “The dynasties of Vārati and Yātu Died out because of a ṛṣi’s curse. There were also, in former times, Kārtika, Kārtavīrya, Daśaratha, and Dāśarathi. “There was Arjuna, accomplished in mantras, And Aśvatthāman, a peerless minister, Who was the only son of the twice-born[2893] Droṇa And an accomplished master of mantras.[2894] “Using mantra-empowered weapons, He became the ruler of an earthly realm Extending over the entire three islands Of Jambūdvīpa. “Kings[2895] and other rulers . . . Making the gods . . . the mantras . . .[2896]

des kyang de bzhin gshegs mchod dang / / rjes yi rang bas mtho ris song / / nges par de dag sangs rgyas gyur/ / kha cig nyan thos theg pa la/ / nges par kha cig nyan thos nyid/ / de kun thar la mngon par gzhol/ / dus kyi rnam gzhag rjes mthun par/ / tshe yang rnam par brtag pa yin/ / dam pa tshe yang ring ba ste/ / de bzhin bar ma bar ma yin/ / shin tu dka' ba'i dus mtha' la/ / dus kyi tha ma rtsod dus la/ / rgyal po rtsod pa la dga' bas/ / gzhan ni tha mar bstan pa yin/ /

And rejoicing in the worship of the tathāgatas, Proceed to the higher realms. “Some are destined to become buddhas, While others pursue the pratyekabuddha path.[2897] Some are destined to become śrāvakas. All of them are on course toward liberation. “As for their lifespans, They are divided into [three] categories. The superior ones have long lifespans, The middling have middling ones, “But in the final eon, The wretched and debased age of strife, The kings will have short lifespans[2898] And be fond of discord.[2899]

phan tshun kho na du 'dzin chags pas/ / gcig la gcig ni rnam 'tshe byed/ / dman pa'i skye ba thob pa dang / / mtshon gyi reg pas 'chi bar 'gyur/ / mtshon gyis 'tsho bas yang dag dag dga'/ / de bzhin gzhan gyi bud med chags/ / rgyal po 'jig rten smod par ni/ / the tsom med par 'gyur ba yin/ / g.yon can las ngan can dang ni/ / de bzhin 'phags min ser sna can/ / de yi tshe na 'byung bar 'gyur/ / cha gnyis ldan dang rtsod dus bar/ / mdor bsdus nas ni bshad par bya/ / gzhon nu de ni rtogs par gyis/ / dus gang 'byung bar 'gyur ba na/ / sa steng rgyal po 'byung ba yi/ / de dag gzugs dang mtshan ma dang / / kha dog kyang ni rtogs par gyis/ / ko sa'i rgyal po gsal rgyal dang / / gzugs can snying po de bzhin gzhan/ / rgyal rigs gtso bo 'char ba dang / / dmag brgya pa ni yang dag 'byung / /

“They will be given to mutual enmity And inflicting harm on one another. They will be of inferior birth And will provoke armed conflicts.[2900] “At that time, they will be eager to use weapons And will take pleasure in [seducing] others’ wives. There is no doubt that such kings will come, Reviled by the world. “They will be wicked, vulgar, and selfish, And will engage in evil acts. This will come to pass Between the dvāparayuga and kaliyuga. “I will now briefly recount The earthly kings Of the present[2901] age. Listen, divine youth! “Learn about the features and marks Associated with their caste. Prasenajit is the king of Kośala; Bimbisāra is another king. “Udayana, the son of Śatānīka, Is a distinguished kṣatriya.

lag bzang gzhu bzang zhes bya dang / / de bzhin dbang chen tsa ma sha/ / de bzhin lits+tsha bIr skyes pa'i/ / shAkya'i rigs skyes seng ge dang / / cher ldan gsal dang rab gsal dang / / sde chen du yang bstan pa'o/ / de bzhin 'phags rgyal gtum po dang / / ser skya'i grong gi rgyal po ni/ / zas gtsang zhes ni bya ba dang / / dpa' bo zhes bya stobs chen dag / 'di dag rgyal po'i rigs su gsungs/ / sa srung ston pa mchod byed pa'o/ / shAkya seng ge mi yi mchog / sangs rgyas mngon du lta bar 'gyur/ / de yang de nas chos thos nas/ / yun ring phun sum tshogs pa 'thob/ / nges par byang chub 'dod nas kyang / / shi nas zhi ba 'thob par 'gyur/ /

There are also Subāhu, Sudhana, Mahendra, and Candrasama. “Siṃha of the Licchavi clan Was born in Vaiśālī.[2902] In Ujjain, there are Udayana, Vidyota, Pradyota, and Mahāsena. “In Ujjain there is Caṇḍa. In the city of Kapilavastu There is the king Śuddhodana And the powerful Vairāṭa.[2903] “These kings are said to be kṣatriyas And worshipers of the Teacher. They have seen the Buddha, the supreme person, directly, In his [present existence] as the Lion of the Śākyas. “Having heard the Dharma, They will obtain lasting good fortune, And if they desire liberation, They will definitely attain the peace of nirvāṇa.[2904]

sa bdag sa yi dkyil 'khor du/ / 'di dag 'jig rten rnam par grags/ / rigs ni rgyal rigs dag tu bstan/ / 'du shes ming gis mtshon pa yin/ / sa steng nga yis bstan pa'i tshig / de dag mchod pa byed par 'gyur/ / gzhon nu byis pa'i gzugs can gyis/ / khyod kyis 'jig rten lung bstan pa/ / ma skyes zhes bya'i rgyal po de/ / nges par byang chub gzhol bar 'gyur/ / nga ni sa steng mya ngan 'das/ / lo brgya dag ni 'das pa na/ / snang ba med cing nyes par bcas/ / mi shes mun pas rab tu bsgribs/ / de tshe sa ni stongs pa ste/ / rgyal ba rnams kyis spangs pa yin/ / de tshe mi bzad chen po yi/ / grong khyer me tog can du ni/ / mya ngan med ces bya ba yi/ / rgyal po sa ni skyong byed pa/ / khro bcas las ni drag po byed/ / de tshe de ni snying rje med/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'dod chags bral/ / nad med ser sna bral ba dang / / dge slong tshul khrims ldan pa yi/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen thad du lhags/ /

“The kings just listed, known to the world, Belong to the earthly realm. Regarding their caste, they are said to be kṣatriyas, And as for their identification, they are known by their name. “One of them will worship your teachings, Which I have given on earth. He was predicted by you, Divine youth beautiful as a child, As the one called Ajātaśatru, Who will dedicate himself to the goal of awakening. “One hundred years after My parinirvāṇa on earth, When there is no light or joy And the darkness of ignorance descends, When the earth is empty Without the Victorious One, “At that terrible time, In the city called Kusumapura, There will be a king who rules that land, Known by the name Aśoka. He will be severe in his actions, Tempestuous, and pitiless. “He will, however, meet a virtuous friend Who is free from desire and dignified, A monk endowed with discipline Whose mind is free from the fever [of afflictions].[2905]

sngon gyi bag chags rgyu dang ni/ / sa rdul byin pa'i byin rlabs kyis/ / rigs ni nges par 'gyur ba dang / / rgyal po nor chen ldan par 'gyur/ / chos dang chos min rnam dpyod cing / / brtse ldan snying rje ldan pa dang / / chags bral rdzu 'phrul chen po des/ / rgyu ni phye zhing bstan par byas/ / sngon ni khyod kyang rgyal po ste/ / mi shes byis pa g.yo ba yi/ / rgyal ba shAkya seng ge la/ / sa yi rdul ni snyim gang phul/ / zhing de la ni rab phul bas/ / lha yul phun sum tshogs pa thob/ / lha yi 'jig rten shi 'phos nas/ / sa yi 'jig rten 'dir 'ongs gyur/ /

“Because of the karmic predisposition from the past Formed through a gift of dust to the dignified [Sage],[2906] This king will be destined To own vast land and great wealth.[2907] He will also understand what is right and what is wrong, And he will become gentle and compassionate. “Revealing the underlying cause, The monk, free from desire and very dignified, Will say, ‘You, O king, in a former life, Acting innocently with childlike flightiness, “ ‘Presented at that time, with folded hands, Some dust to the victorious Lion of the Śākyas, Placing it in his bowl as food. Because of this, you attained a divine state, “ ‘And then, having departed from the celestial realm, You took birth here, in the world of your ancestors.[2908]

'dzam gling nags tshal phun sum tshogs/ / rgyal po yi ni rgyal thabs spyod/ / bdag nyid chen po dzam b+ha la/ / gnod sbyin gyi ni sngags kyang bsgrubs/ / bdag nyid chen po sa yi bdag / de nas gnod sbyin shing rta grub/ /

Enjoy the dominion, O king, Over Jambūdvīpa with its pleasant groves!’ “The great king will practice The mantra of the great yakṣa Jambhala. After he becomes accomplished, He will obtain a chariot drawn by spirits.[2909]

de la gnod sbyin 'dug pa ni/ / bka' dang mthun par yid kyang 'jug / klu rnams kyang ni 'dug pa ste/ / bran dang bka' bzhin byed pa'i rgyu/ / de ltar rdzu 'phrul che bdag nyid/ / de tshe stobs kyi 'khor sgyur 'byung / / ci 'dod de ni 'gro ba na/ / gang du'ang 'gog pa med par 'gyur/ / rgyal ba'i sku gdung mchog sa la/ / gang yang sngon ni rab bzhag pa/ / rgyal po'i khab kyi grong khyer gyi/ / de tshe 'od ma'i tshal du'o/ /

“He will be attended upon by the yakṣas, Who anticipate his orders. The nāgas will attend upon him too, Duly awaiting his orders. “Devoted to the Dharma, Aśoka will attain great majesty, And he will exercise the powers of a sovereign, Traveling wherever he pleases Without ever being obstructed. “He will take, at that time, from the city of Rājagṛha, From the grove called the Bamboo Grove, The finest relics of the victorious ones[2910] on earth, Which had been placed there in earlier times.

sku gdung mchog ni blangs nas kyang / / dge ba la dmigs yid can gyis/ / ji ltar sngon gyi byas pa bzhin/ / mchod rten de la mchod pa byas/ / sku gdung bum pa de blangs nas/ / de ni de bzhin rnam bgos nas/ / blo ldan des ni skad cig gis/ / de nas gnod sbyin la yang smras/ / 'dzam bu'i gling 'di ma lus pa/ / mchod rten rgyan gyis brgyan pa dang / / sa rnams sku gdung snying por ni/ / khyod kyis kyang ni rab tu bya/ /

“With his mind steeped in virtue, He will take the relics from their container And then worship the stūpa, Just as was done in the past. “He will take out the jar containing the relics and, Having divided them into one hundred parts, That wise one will immediately command The yakṣas as follows: “ ‘Gentlemen, please adorn The entirety of Jambūdvīpa with stūpas. You must make the earth Into a receptacle of relics.’[2911]

'bad pa yis ni mtshan phyed du/ / gnod sbyin gyis ni bka' yang blangs/ / mi ma yin pa'i bya ba byas/ / sa steng rdo yi srog shing bsgreng / / ka ba stong phrag du ma ni/ / de tshe yongs su btsugs par gyur/ / mchod rten rnams la mchod don du/ / lus can rnams la mtshon par gyur/ / 'jig rten mgon po skyob pa yis/ / mchod rten sna tshogs byas nas ni/ / skad cig gcig gis gnod sbyin rnams/ / rgyal po yi ni drung du lhags/ / de nas gnod sbyin rab btud nas/ / dben par tshig ni rab tu smras/ / ji skad bka' stsal ma lus byas/ / sa bdag ji ste gzigs mi mdzad/ /

“Having received their orders, The yakṣas, carefully at midnight, Using for this task nonhuman labor, Will erect stone pillars throughout the land. “They will erect, at that time, Many thousands of pillars Serving as signposts for living beings For their worship of the caityas. “Having thus constructed various stūpas Dedicated to the lord protectors of the world, The yakṣas will instantly return To the side of the king, [Aśoka]. “Bowing their heads to him, The guhyakas will say, ‘We have done everything exactly as instructed. Will you not have a look, O lord?’

de nas myur du sa bdag de/ / de tshe shing rta de la zhon/ / rnam pa sna tshogs mchod don du/ / rnam pa sna tshogs mdzes pa'i phyir/ / gser dang de bzhin dngul dag dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs mchod rten brgyan/ / de nas gnod sbyin shing rta dang / / myur du rgyal po rab tu song / / gang na rgyal ba'i mchod rten yod/ / skad cig gis ni de yul du'o/ / rnam pa sna tshogs mchod pa yis/ / rgyal po des ni de la mchod/ / de tshe rgyal ba'i mchod rten gyis/ / sa rnams ma lus mdzes par byas/ / bdag nyid chos rgyal mya ngan med/ / smon lam dag ni 'debs par brtson/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di don gyis/ / bla na med pa'i sangs rgyas shog / de bzhin des kyang rig nas ni/ / rgyal po chos ni ston par byed/ / de ni shi nas lha ru 'gro/ / nges par byang chub gzhol bar 'gyur/ /

“The king will then quickly Mount his chariot, Taking with him various things to offer And adornments of many kinds. “He will thus quickly fill The spirit-drawn[2912] chariot With gold, silver, copper, And various adornments for the stūpas. “Within a moment, the king Will worship the victorious ones With manifold articles At the locations where their reliquaries will be. “At that time, when all the land has been adorned With the relics of the victorious ones, The king, the righteous and noble Aśoka, Will make the following aspiration: ‘By the power of this merit May I become a supreme buddha.’ “Remembering this, The noble, righteous king Aśoka[2913][2914] Will become a god after he dies, Steadily progressing toward awakening.

lo ni brgyad cu rtsa bdun du/ / sa steng mchod rten mchod par 'gyur/ / lo ni brgya dang lnga bcur 'tsho/ / gnod pa med pa'i rgyal thabs byed/ / de rang las las byung ba yi/ / lus la nad ni yongs su 'byung / / nad des gnod cing sdug bsngal nas/ / shi nas mtho ris 'gro bar 'gyur/ / lha yi phun sum tshogs pa che/ / thob nas rjes su myong bar byed/ / de ni yid gzhungs rim gyis su/ / rnyed par dka' ba'i byang chub thob/ / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs dag ni/ / sngags kyang de tshe 'grub par 'gyur/ / dzam b+ha la sogs gnod sbyin yang / / 'di yi bstan pa'i rjes su 'jug / rdzu 'phrul chen po 'phrog ma sogs/ / gnod sbyin mo yang yang dag 'grub/ / 'khor los sgyur bas bskyed pa yi/ / 'khor los sgyur ba'i sngags kyang grub/ / gang dag rgyal bas bstan pa'i sngags/ / rig pa'i rgyal po rdzu 'phrul che/ / gtsug tor la sogs thams cad dang / / gang gzhan rgyal bas gsungs pa'ang yin/ /

“On earth, he will worship The supreme relics for eighty-seven years. He will live for one hundred and fifty years, During which he will rid his kingdom of troubles. “Because of the maturing of his past karma, He will develop a physical illness. Afflicted by it, he will suffer pain, But when he dies, he will go to heaven. “He will obtain and enjoy A great fortune of the gods, And in due course, being intelligent, Will attain the realization that is so hard to find. “The mantras effective at that time Will be those of the Vajra and Lotus families, Those of Jambhala and other yakṣas Who follow the same teachings, And also those of the yakṣiṇīs, Such as the powerful Hārītī and so forth. “The cakravartin[2915] mantras that emanate From Cakravartin will be effective too‍— The powerful vidyārāja mantras, Starting from the uṣṇīṣas and including All the other mantras Taught by the victors.

de yi dus ni rab bzang la/ / sgrub pa dam pa dag kyang bya/ / dam pas tha ma bsgrub mi bya/ / dam pa thob par bya phyir ro/ / di lI pa dang na hu sha/ / nga las nu dang dug chen mtsho/ / rgyal bas bshad pa'i 'khor los sgyur/ / sngags ni de dag sgrub par byed/ / bdag nyid chen po na hu sha/ / de tshe gzi brjid phung po grub/ / rgyal po chen po dug chen pa/ / gdugs dkar po yang grub pa yin/ / de bzhin rgyal po di lI pa/ / yi ge gcig pa'i sngags kyang grub/ / nga las nu ni 'jig rten dang / / de bzhin gtsug tor dam pa grub/ /

“The sādhanas to be performed at that auspicious time Are those of the supreme[2916] type. They cannot be accomplished by inferior practitioners, But only by the supreme ones who pursue the highest destiny, Such as Dilīpa,[2917] Nahuṣa, Māndhātṛ, and Sagara. “They accomplished the cakravartin mantras Taught by the victorious ones. Noble Nahuṣa accomplished The mantra of Tejorāśi.[2918] “King[2919] Sagara accomplished The mantra of Sitātapatra. King Dilīpa accomplished The One Syllable mantra.[2920] “Māndhātṛ accomplished, in this world, The mantra of Unnatoṣṇīṣa.[2921]

rgyal mchog d+hun du ma ra ni/ / de bzhin rgyal ba'i gtsug tor grub/ / de bzhin 'dam gyi rgyal po ni/ / rnam rgyal gtsug tor grub pa'o/ / de bu skye dgu'i bdag po ste/ / de yang sa steng spyan sngags grub/ / skye dgu'i bdag po skye ba ste/ / de yang mdzod spu'i sngags kyang grub/ / lte ba'i bu ni khyu mchog ste/ / de ni las grub brtul zhugs brtan/ / kha ba can gyi ri dag tu/ / de yang nor spyod gnod sbyin grub/ / khyu mchog bu ni rgyas pa ste/ / de yang de tshe sngags bzlas byed/ / de tshe sa steng de mthar gyis/ / dpa' bo chen po'ang rab tu grub/ / 'di dag gzhan yang mang po yi/ / rgyal po 'jig rten rnam grags pas/ / sngags rnams rab tu bsgrubs nas ni/ / rgyal srid byas nas lha yul 'gro/ /

The supreme king Dhundhumāra Accomplished the mantra of Jayoṣṇīṣa. “King Kandarpa is said to have accomplished The mantra of Vijayoṣṇīṣa. His son Prajāpati, too, Accomplished the Locanā mantra on earth. “Prajāpati’s son Nābhi Accomplished the mantra of Ūrṇa. Ṛṣabha, a son of Nābhi, Was successful in his endeavors and strict in his observances. “He accomplished the mantra of the yakṣa Māṇicara In the Himalayas. Bharata, a son of Ṛṣabha, Also recited the mantras at that time, And in due course accomplished The Great Hero mantra[2922] on earth. “These and many other kings, Renowned throughout the world, After accomplishing their mantras, Ruled their kingdoms and then ascended to heaven.

rig pa'i rgyal po rdzu 'phrul che/ / rgyal ba'i dbang pos gang gsungs pa/ / de kun dus ni bzang po ste/ / lo ni stong phrag brgyad cu pa/ / sngags dang rgyud kyi don mkhas pas/ / grub pa dag ni sgrub par 'gyur/ / 'di dag gzhan yang rab mang ba'i/ / sa bdag 'jig rten rnam grags pa/ / de nas stong phrag brgyad cu'i sngags/ / de bzhin yang dag bsgrubs nas ni/ / rgyal srid byas nas mtho ris 'gro/ / nges par byang chub gzhol bar 'gyur/ / de tshe bar ma'i dus dag tu/ / lha mo rdzu 'phrul chen mo dang / / lha rnams kyi ni sngags dang ni/ / pad+ma'i rigs kyi sngags dang ni/ / blon po mi yi gtso bo dang / / sa bdag sa kun bdag po'o/ /

“The powerful vidyārājas[2923] That were taught by the victorious lords Could all be accomplished During the auspicious time of the eon When the lifespan was eighty thousand years, By those who knew the value of the mantra method. “These and many other kings, Renowned throughout the world, Ruled their kingdoms For eighty thousand or one hundred thousand years[2924] And then ascended to heaven, Steadily progressing toward awakening. “Then, during the middle period,[2925] The mantras that brought success Were those belonging to the family of the lotus holder;[2926] They possessed great divine and magical powers And were employed by the prominent ministers And the kings who ruled over all the land.[2927]

bA rA Na sI grong khyer na/ / rgyal po tshangs pas byin pa yang / / 'jig rten 'jig rten dbang phyug grags/ / phyag na pad+ma rab tu grub/ / bdag nyid chen po brtson 'grus che/ / lhag par snying rje chen po de/ / sems can rnams la sngags tshul gyis/ / chos rnams ston pa byin pa yin/ / rgyal po yang ni tshangs byin gyis/ / mi yi bde ba rjes myong nas/ / de nas de ni sngags grub ste/ / lus dang bcas pas mtho ris song / / de yi bu yang blo ldan ni/ / bsod nams las ni brtul zhugs brtan/ / brtson 'grus chen po rta mgrin zhes/ / rnam par grags pa de yang grub/ / de yis sngags kyi mthu yis ni/ / de tshe brgya byin las rgyal gyur/ / de bu dkar po zhes bya ba'i/ / rgyal po thams cad gtong ba 'byung / /

“Thus, the king Brahmadatta, In the great city of Vārāṇasī, Accomplished [the mantra of] the lotus holder Known in the world as Lokeśa. “He was valiant, magnanimous, And distinguished by his great compassion. He instructed beings in the Dharma, Assuming the form of his mantra deity.[2928] “King Brahmadatta experienced happiness While a human being. Then he, the master of the mantra, Ascended to heaven in his physical body. “His son, who was intelligent, Virtuous in his actions, and strict in his observances, Accomplished for his part the mantra Of the great hero known as Hayagrīva. “With the power of this mantra He defeated Śakra during that time. His son, named Śveta, was a king Who gave away everything he had.

de yang nor ni sbyin pa'i sngags/ / dkar mo che zhes bya ba yang / / sngags ni rab tu bsgrubs pas kyang / / lo ni sum brgya dag tu 'tsho/ / de yi sngags kyi mthu yis ni/ / bde ba can tu yang dag 'gro/ / nges par byang chub 'di nges thob/ / de bzhin gzhan yang ngas lung bstan/ / de tshe bar ma'i dus dag tu/ / bar ma'i sngags ni rab tu 'grub/ / dka' ba tha ma'i dus dag tu/ / nga ni sangs rgyas nyid thob nas/ / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs dag gi/ / sngags kyang rab tu 'grub par 'gyur/ /

“His mantra deity who grants boons Was the one called Mahāśvetā. Having accomplished her mantra, Śveta lived three hundred years. “By the power of this mantra He went to the realm of Sukhāvatī. He is destined to attain awakening, Just like the others I have prophesied. “The mantras that would have been accomplished During the middle period are the middling mantras. The mantras that will be effective During the wretched and debased eon, When I have passed into the final nirvāṇa,[2929] Are the mantras of the Vajra and Lotus families.

gzhon nu khyod kyi sngags dag ni/ / gang zhig sa steng sngon bstan pa/ / sngags ni longs spyod rgyu nyid du/ / de yang rab tu grub par 'gro/ / 'jig rten rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i/ / phal pa dag gi sngags dag ni/ / mi sdug gzugs can rnyog par ldan/ / bar snang dang ni nam mkhar spyod/ / sa blar gnas pa'i gnod sbyin mo/ / de bzhin sna tshogs sha za mo/ / mi 'am ci dang mkha' lding dang / / yi dgas srin pos bshad pa rnams/ / sha za lto 'phye gnod sbyin dang / / rdzu 'phrul chen po klu rnams kyi/ / dus ngan de tshe tha ma la/ / sngags ni rab tu grub par 'gyur/ /

“The mantras that you, divine youth, Have formerly taught on earth Will also be effective and will constitute The cause of good fortune. “So too is the case with other mantras Used for different worldly purposes, Such as the mantras of kaśmalas and other deformed beings Who course in mid-regions and in the sky; “Or the mantras of the yakṣiṇīs who roam the earth And of the various piśācīs; And likewise the mantras of the garuḍas and the kinnaras And those taught to be of the rākṣasas and the pretas. “So, too, the powerful mantras of the nāginīs, Who protect against the piśācas and uragas, Will be effective During the wretched, debased eon.[2930]

gzhon nu'i gzugs kyi sngags dang ni/ / gzhon nu ma yi gzugs kun yang / / dus ni 'jigs rung de yi tshe/ / de yang grub par rab tu 'gro/ / de bzhin sngags ni rnam pa gsum/ / sgrub pa'ang rnam pa gsum yin no/ / rnam gsum nyid kyis dus kyi ni/ / rnam gsum grub pa 'dod pa yin/ / rgya che'i gtam dang ldan pa dag / mdor bsdus nas ni bshad par bya/ / gtso bo mya ngan med pa yi/ / de 'og rgyal po byung ba ni/ / mya ngan bral zhes rnam par grags/ / 'jig rten chos kyis spyod par ldan/ / lha mo gos dkar mo yi ni/ / de yi sngags 'di yongs su 'grub/ / mya ngan rnam bral gyis bsgrubs nas/ / lha yi gnas su rab tu song / / yun ring bde ba mtho ris su/ / rgyal po chen po rjes su myong / / phyir yang mi yul phyin nas ni/ / blo ldan chos kyi ngang tshul ldan/ /

“The mantras [of deities] with the forms Of kumāras or kumārīs[2931] Will also be effective At that terrible time. “The mantras are thus of three kinds, And so are the sādhanas. The accomplishment can also be of three types, Corresponding to the threefold division of time periods. I present what would be an elaborate explanation In a condensed manner. “After the first[2932] king Aśoka There will come a king Known as Viśoka, A follower of Dharma in the world. “He will accomplish the mantra Of the goddess Pāṇḍaravāsinī. With this accomplishment, Viśoka will ascend to the celestial realm. “This great king, having enjoyed happiness In the celestial abode for a long time, Will again resume his life as a human, Disciplined in the Dharma and wise.

rgyal thabs rnam pa sna tshogs ldan/ / 'od chen pos ni rjes su myong / / lo ni bdun cu rtsa drug tu/ / dpal ldan mchod rten mchod pa byed/ / de nas de ni nad btab nas/ / lus zhig nas ni lha ris 'gro/ / de yi 'og tu rgyal po ni/ / dpa' bo'i sde zhes rab tu brjod/ / chos la spyod cing rnam par grags/ / bstan pa 'di la mnyam par bzhag / lha mo mchod rten dpal chen ma/ / de yi sngags kyang rab tu bsgrubs/ / des kyang ston pa'i khang chen ni/ / de yi tshe na byas par 'gyur/ / sa rnams rgyal mtsho'i mthar thug par/ / ma lus mchod rten rnams kyis brgyan/ / de la rnam smin las kyis ni/ / lus las skyes pa'i nad kyang 'byung / / zla phyed gcig tu sdug bsngal nas/ / de nas shi 'phos lus zhig 'gyur/ /

“He, the splendorous one, will enjoy his kingship Blessed with many boons. He will worship the supreme relics For seventy-six years. Then, overcome with fever, His body will give out and he will go to heaven. “Directly after him, there will be A king known as Śūrasena, A celebrated practitioner of the Dharma Always applying himself to the teachings. “For his part, he will accomplish the mantra Of the goddess Stūpamahāśriyā. He will commission great works In the Teacher’s honor, And the entire land, as far as the ocean shore, Will be adorned with stūpas. “Then, having developed a physical illness Due to the ripening of his past karma, He will deteriorate and pass away Within one fortnight.

lo ni bdun cu dag tu yang / / mi yi nang du rgyal thabs byas/ / shi 'phos de ni mtho ris 'gro/ / nges par byang chub gzhol bar 'gyur/ / de yi 'og tu rgyal po ni/ / dga' bo zhes bya 'byung bar 'gyur/ / dpal ldan grong khyer me tog ces/ / sde chen stobs ni che bar gnas/ / sha za pi lu zhes bya ba'i/ / sngags kyang des ni bsgrubs pa yin/ / de yi sngags kyi mthu yis ni/ / longs spyod chen po yod par 'gyur/ / rgya yi gtso bo zhes bya ba/ / 'jig rten 'dir ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de nor thob pas blon por 'gyur/ / 'jig rten rgyal po nyid du'ang 'gyur/ / de yi dus su 'byung ba ni/ / bram ze tshad ma shes pa'o/ / log pa'i nga rgyal dag la zhen/ / ma ga d+hA yi grong khyer gnas/ / log pa'i nga rgyal gyis dregs rnams/ / 'byung ba nyid du the tshom ma med/ / de dag gis ni rgyal po bskor/ / de dag la ni des nor byin/ /

“Having ruled the realm For seventeen human years, When he dies he will enter the celestial realm, Steadily progressing toward awakening. “Directly after him there will be Another king, Nanda by name. He, the glorious, will reside in the Flower City[2933] With his powerful army. “For his part, he will accomplish The mantra of the piśāca named Pīlu. Through the power of this mantra He will enjoy great comforts. “He will become known in this world As the ‘chief rogue,’[2934] Who first got rich as a minister And then went on to become a king. “At that time, there will live on earth, In the capital city of Magadha, Greedy brahmin logicians Proud of their magical abilities. They will be full of vain pride and arrogance, Of this there is no doubt. “The king, surrounded by them, Will bestow upon them great wealth.[2935]

nor ni mang po de dag gis/ / dge ba'i bshes la rab mchod nas/ / de yi nor ni zad par byed/ / ma 'dres de la goms pa dang / / sbyin la zhum med rgyu yis ni/ / blo ldan de yi lha khang ni/ / nyi shu rtsa bzhi byed du bcug / grong khyer me tog ces bya bar/ / bdag nyid chen po blon po'i gtso/ / bram ze bzang po snying rjer ldan/ / de yi tshe na 'byung bar 'gyur/ / rgyal po dang ni rab mdza' ba'i/ / chos kyi bdag nyid 'byung bar 'gyur/ /

Although disciplined in and devoted to the Dharma, The king will give his wealth to them. Later, having met a virtuous friend, He will make offerings to the supreme relics.[2936] “Solely because of his habitual practice And the constancy of his generosity, This wise [king] will construct monasteries Over a period of sixty-eight years. “There will be, at that time, In the city named after flowers,[2937] A great chief minister Who is a good and compassionate brahmin. “He will become the embodiment of the Dharma For that outstanding king.

gnod sbyin ma ni dpa' mo ldan/ / sa steng de yi sngags kyang 'grub/ / des kyang sa steng dag tu ni/ / mchod rten bzang po byed du bcug / gnod sbyin ma yi mthu yis ni/ / shes rab rab tu che bar 'gyur/ / de yi bag chags las kyis ni/ / sngon gyi bag chags yong bskul nas/ / blo dang ldan pas mthar gyis ni/ / rnyed par dka' ba'i byang chub 'thob/ / mchog sred ces ni rnam grags pa'i/ / de tshe 'dod chags shas che 'byung / / bud med byas pa'i skyon gyis ni/ / bram ze'i khye 'us 'chi ba thob/ /

He will accomplish on earth The mantra of the yakṣiṇī Vīramatī. “He also will commission the finest reliquary Of the victorious ones on earth. Due to the power of the yakṣiṇī, He will become exceedingly wise. “Impelled by his earlier habits And because of his karmic traits, This wise minister will attain, in due course, The awakening that is so difficult to obtain. “At that time, some brahmin youths will die Due to their indulgence in vice. Also at that time he, known by the name of Vararuci,[2938] Will succumb to excessive sexual passion.[2939]

dpal ldan rgyal po dga' bo yang / / snga ma'i las kyi nyes pa yis/ / me tog ces bya'i grong khyer gyi/ / mi rnams 'chad pas gnod par byed/ / blon po'i tshogs kyang ma dad gyur/ / stobs chen bden par smra ba yang / / sngon gyi las kyi nyes pa yis/ / nad chen dag gis thebs 'gyur te/ / rims nad chen pos sdug bsngal gdung / / nam phyed tsam na shi bar 'gyur/ / rgyal po de yi tshe tshad ni/ / de bzhin lnga bcu rtsa drug go / de ni nyan thos byang chub tu/ / rgyal po nges par 'gyur ba yin/ / de yi grogs po gzhan gyur pa/ / bram ze'i khye'u pa Ni ni/ / nges par nyan thos byang chub tu/ / nga yis lung bstan byas pa yin/ / 'jig rten dbang phyug bdag nyid che/ / de yang de yi sngags grub pa'o/ / bram ze shes rab 'dod pas kyang / / khro bo ha la ha la bsgrubs/ / rgyal po de las gzhan pa yang / / zla ba sbas zhes bya ba 'byung / / gnod sbyin chu dbang grub pa ste/ / rgyal srid gnod pa med par byed/ / longs spyod che zhing bden par smra/ / chos kyi bdag nyid sa yi bdag / mi dge'i bshes gnyen rab brten nas/ / srog chags mang po gsod par byed/ / las kyi rnam smin de yis ni/ / 'brum bu'i nad 'byung rab tu brgyal/ / de ni mtshan phyed sad nas ni/ / rgyal srid la ni bu bzhag pa/ / snying po thig le zhes bya ba/ / blon po la sdang byis pa de/ /

“The glorious king Nanda, Because of the karma of his earlier transgressions, Will displease his ministers In the city called Pāṭaliputra.[2940] “Although his ministers will be disaffected, He will remain true to his promises and powerful. However, due to the karma of former transgressions, He will develop a severe illness. “Suffering from high fever, He will die at midnight. The life of this king Will be sixty-six[2941] years long. He will be destined to become a śrāvaka And attain awakening. “Another friend of [King Nanda] Will be a young brahmin named Pāṇini, Prophesied by me To become a śrāvaka. “He will accomplish The mantra of the noble Lokīśa. Desiring wisdom, this brahmin Will accomplish the mantra of the krodha Hālāhala. “Next in succession after [King Nanda] Will be the one known as Candragupta. He will accomplish the mantra of the yakṣa Jalendra And will rid his kingdom of troubles. “This great king will enjoy great comforts And will be true to his promises and dedicated to the Dharma. Having, however, met a nonvirtuous friend He will kill many beings. Because of the ripening of this karma, He will become debilitated by poisonous skin eruptions. “Lamenting, at midnight he will appoint As his successor on earth his son, Bindusāra by name, still a child, Along with a wicked minister.[2942]

de nas zla ba sbas pa de/ / shi 'phos sa steng dus las 'das/ / mi yi 'gro ba spangs pa yi/ / de tshe yi dgas 'jig rten song / / 'gro ba las grol sngags goms pas/ / de nas lha yi gnas su song / / dge ba'i sems kyis dmigs nas ni/ / sngags kyi rgyus ni yang dag bskyed/ / rgyal po des ni mthar gyis kyang / / nyan thos kyi ni byang chub 'gro/ /

“After Candragupta’s[2943] time on earth is over, He will pass away And go to the realm of the pretas, Following a nonhuman destiny. But then, because of his mantra practice, He will leave that realm and go to heaven. “Because of the mantra, His mind will be steeped in virtue, And the king will attain in due course The realization of a pratyekabuddha.[2944]

snying po thig le rgyal po yis/ / byis pa mi gsal blo yis ni/ / bye ma las byas srid gzhan du/ / sngon ni mchod rten dag kyang byas/ / de yi rnam smin mthu yis ni/ / ma smad lha yi gnas su song / / skye ba stong phrag lnga brgyar ni/ / lha yi nang du bde ba myong / / mtho ris 'jig rten shi 'phos nas/ / mi yi nang du rab skyes pa/ / blo ldan zla ba sbas pa yi/ / rgyal po dga' ba'i rigs su skyes/ /

“In his former life as Siṃhadatta,[2945] King Bindusāra[2946] Built a caitya as a child, With his mind still undeveloped. “Through the power of this karma, The virtuous [Siṃhadatta] went to heaven And enjoyed pleasures among the gods For five hundred thousand lives. “Having departed the celestial realm, He will be become an earthly king Born in the royal family Of the sagacious Candragupta.[2947]
byis pa nyid nas rgyal por 'gyur/ / yun mi thung bar bde ba myong / 'jigs med bstan dang yang dag rig / spyi brtsan pa dang snyan par smra/ /
“A mere child, the king Will experience great pleasures, And when grown up, he will turn bold, Resolute, and smooth spoken.[2948]

de nyid rang dbang rgyal srid ni/ / lo ni bdun cur yongs su byas/ / skra can zhes bya'i sngags dag kyang / / rgyal po de la rab tu grub/ / khyod nyid kyi ni sngags nyid kyang / / de tshe grub par byed par 'gyur/ /
He will keep the kingdom Under his control for seventy years. “This king will accomplish The mantra of Keśinī. At that time, divine youth, Your mantras will bring success.[2949]
khyod nyid kyis bshad sngags dag kyang / / de yi tshe na grub par 'gyur/ / byis pa'i tshul can sna tshogs gzugs/ / byis pa rnams la mthu dang ldan/ /
“The mantras that you taught Will be accomplished at that time. The inner essence of every being is that of the divine youth, Who exercises his power over the worlds.[2950]

sngags kyi gzugs kyis lus can la/ / the tshom med par 'byung bar 'gyur/ / sems can rnams la phan 'dod pas/ / gang zhig khyod kyis bstan pa'i sngags/ / de tshe de yi dus dag tu/ / brjod pa tsam gyis 'grub par 'gyur/ / blo ldan snying po thig le yi/ / rgyal po de yi blon po ni/ / tsa nag kya zhes rnam bsgrags pa/ / bram ze'i khye 'us khro bo 'grub/ / gshin rje gshed ces bya ba ni/ / blo ngan des ni de yang 'grub/ / des ni khro bas zil non nas/ / srog chags dag gi 'tsho ba bcad/ / de tshe rgyal po gsum gyi bar/ / shin tu mi bzad sdig pa byas/ / de ni dus ring 'tsho ba yi/ / bram ze ngan pa 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de yi sngags kyi mthu yis ni/ / lus des lha min brten par byed/ / lha min lus la zhugs nas ni/ / de ni dus ring 'tsho bar byed/ / de nas lus de zhig nas kyang / / mnar med dmyal bar yang dag 'gro/ /

“He will manifest for beings In the form of the mantra without a doubt. The mantras that you have taught[2951] Out of the desire to help beings Will be recited on earth at that time And will always bring accomplishment. “The sagacious King Bindusāra Will have a minister, Cāṇakya by name, a brahmin youth Who will accomplish the mantra of a krodha. This evil-minded man will accomplish The mantra of the krodha Yamāntaka. “Overcome by anger, He will kill living beings And will commit terrible evil Over the period of the three reigns.[2952] “This corrupt brahmin Will live for a long time and, Through the power of the mantra, Will carnally enjoy an asurī. “Taking on the body of an asura, He will live for a long time. When his body gives out, He will fall into the hell realm.[2953]

de nas dmyal ba'i sdug bsngal de/ / blo ngan des ni rjes su myong / / dmyal ba'i sdug bsngal sna tshogs pa/ / mi 'dod de tshe las las byung / / las gcig sdug bsngal des zad nas/ / khro bo'i sngags kyis rab bskul te/ / dmyal ba las ni de 'chi 'phos/ / dud 'gro dag tu nye bar skyes/ / klu yi skye gnas brten nas ni/ / 'jigs pa'i gzugs can dag tu 'gyur/ / khro ldan chen po klu yi rgyal/ / gdengs can dug gis dregs byed dang / / mi bzad las ni rab byed pas/ / ma rungs las las de 'chi 'phos/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po yi dgas kyi/ / gshin rje'i rgyal por rab tu 'gyur/ / de ltar sdug bsngal stong phrag ni/ / yang dang yang du rjes su myong / / blo ngan de ni mthar gyis su/ / bram ze'i khye'ur sa steng 'ong 'ongs/ / mi yi skye bar 'ongs nas ni/ / 'jigs pa yi ni gzugs can 'gyur/ / khro ba dang ni dbul ba nyid/ / grags pa chung ba nyid du 'gyur/ / gang yang 'jig rten rang sangs rgyas/ / 'dod med bse ru lta bur spyod/ / dman pa la ni rjes brtse ba/ / sa yi steng na rnam par rgyu/ /

“There, the evil-minded [Cāṇakya] Will experience the sufferings of hell. His bad karma will bring upon him The sufferings of different hells. “Having passed there one eon,[2954] he will be aroused From that state by the mantra of the Krodha.[2955] After passing away from hell, He will be reborn as an animal. “Born as a nāga, He will have the frightening form Of a nāga king, very wrathful, With a big hood, and proud of his venom. “He will commit terrible acts, And when he dies, with his bad karma He will be reborn in the realm of Yama.[2956] “Having become the king Yama, The powerful king of the pretas, He will endure thousands of sufferings Again and again. “In due course, he will be reborn on earth As a dull-witted brahmin youth. Having obtained a human birth, He will have a frightening form. Destitute and short-tempered, He will have few friends. “The pratyekabuddhas, who have no desires in this world And live alone like rhinoceroses, Wander the earth filled with compassion For those who are forsaken and miserable.

sems can rnams la phan 'dod phyir/ / bsod snyoms spyod la rab tu zhugs/ / de tshe gzhan sems rig pa des/ / blo ngan de ni rab tu mthong / / snying rjes yin gyis gzhan min des/ / de yi thad du byon par 'gyur/ / des ni zan dron gsol ched du/ / bse ru lta bu la ni khyer/ / des ni sngags la rab brnyas nas/ / de tshe rgyu ni yang dag bstan/ / de las gcig gi bdag nyid la/ / bsod snyoms de ni yang dag bstabs/ / kye 'di rab byung ma lus pa/ / ji ltar bde ba bzhin du gsol/ / de la rjes brtse rang sangs rgyas/ / de tshe rdzu 'phrul bstan par 'gyur/ / de yi mthu yis yid bskyod nas/ / de nas ngo mtshar rab skyes te/ / sangs rgyas bse ru lta bu la/ / spyi bos kun la rab tu btud/ / ji ltar 'dod par nyes bral rnams/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba de yi mthus/ / rang rgyal byang chub smon lam btab/ /

They take up the life of mendicancy Out of the desire to help sentient beings. “Seeing the bad [state of Cāṇakya’s] mind, And being able to read the thoughts of others, They will approach him, Solely out of compassion. “Cāṇakya, having obtained Some inferior gruel in order to eat it, Will be swayed by the power of the Krodha’s mantra And create, at that time, a good cause. “He will offer the gruel to them as alms With a singularly magnanimous mind and say, ‘Excuse me, all of you renunciants! Eat this food, as much as you like.’ Right then, out of their sympathy for him, The pratyekabuddhas will display their miraculous power. “Stricken with wonder, His mind uplifted by their power, He will prostrate himself headlong To the rhinoceros-like pratyekabuddhas. And they all, free from faults, Will fly into the sky as they please.[2957] “Cāṇakya will then, with a good intention, Make an aspiration for the realization of a pratyekabuddha:[2958]
