Having experienced poverty and humiliation, He will direct his acts of destruction at kings. “Taught by Mañjughoṣa present here, This [mantra of] Yamāntaka, the Lord of Wrath, Is the tamer of the wicked beings So difficult to tame. “It is for suppressing what is bad And promoting what is good. It can also be used to destroy physical life, But only as an act of kindness to sentient beings. “This foolish young brahmin, however, Stricken with poverty and swayed by anger and greed, Will recite the Krodha [mantra] In order to kill the king. “There will also be another brahmin, Known by the name beginning with S.[3281] He will be skilled in the art of mantras,[3282] studious, Truthful, and in control of his senses.[3283]

mnga' bdag mang pos bkur ces pa/ / de tshe sngags ni zlos par 'gyur/ / sngags ni bsgrub par gyur pa la/ / dbang 'gyur yin gyis gzhan ma yin/ / 'byung po dbang du gyur pa na/ / de tshe nor dang ldan par 'gyur/ / de 'og rnam par grags pa ni/ / bram ze chos don sems byed pa/ / de nas mthar ni dang yig sha/ / ma la'i yul du de ni 'byung / /

“A reciter of mantras, He will be known as a very powerful master. He will master the mantras for enthralling, But not for other activities. As the result of enthralling the spirits, He will become very rich. “There will be another well-known brahmin In the country of Mālava, Concerned about the affairs of the Dharma, Whose name will begin with Ś.[3284]

sa steng sngags ni zlos par grags/ / bstan pa mchog la'ang rab tu dad/ / rig pa rjes bzung ma rungs dang / / tshangs pa'i srin po srin po dang / / 'byung po shin tu ma rungs bcas/ / rnam pa sna tshogs sha za dang / / bstan dang 'gro ba sna tshogs ni/ / de dag ma lus de dbang 'gyur/ / de bzhin bram ze'i mtshan ldan pa/ / thams cad de yi dbang du 'gyur/ / de 'og rnam par grags pa ni/ / lho yi phyogs su bram ze ni/ / yi ge dang por ba bstan pa/ / ston pa'i bstan la de gtsor byed/ / mchod rten kun dga' ra ba gnas/ / ston pa'i gzugs brnyan yid 'ong gis/ / sa ni rgya mtsho gnyis mthar thug / thams cad kyi ni rgyan du byas/ / de 'og rnam par grags pa ni/ / bram ze gtso bo nor chen ldan/ / dang po'i yi ge na zhes pa/ / lho yi phyogs su yang dag bstan/ / bdag nyid chen po sngags zlos ldan/ / nges par byang chub gzhol bar 'gyur/ / dbus kyi yul du bstan pa ni/ / bram ze gang ba bzang zhes pa/ / 'dul ba dang ni tshul bzang nyid/ / gang ba bcom brlag dag tu gnas/ / dang yig b+ha ni nor gyi spyan/ / rgyal po rnams ni sngags mchod byed/ /

He will have faith in the teachings And will be an exemplary reciter of mantras on earth. “He will enthrall vetālas, grahas,[3285] The evil brahmarākṣasas and rākṣasas, And all the pūtanas, bhūtas, And the various kravyādas.[3286] “All animate and inanimate things Without exception will come under his control. All of them will be in his thrall, With benefits for this man marked as twice-born. “There will be another brahmin In the southern region. He will be widely known by the name beginning with V And will be devoted to the teachings of the Teacher. “He will adorn the entire land Between the two oceans With monasteries, ashrams, caityas, And beautiful images of the Teacher. “Another distinguished brahmin, Known by the name beginning with Bh,[3287] Wealthy and famous, Will live in the southern region. “This great being, a reciter of mantras, Will be destined to attain the final goal of awakening. In Madhyadeśa, there will be a brahmin Known by the name of Sampūrṇa. “There will also be Vinaya, Suvinaya, And Pūrṇa, the citizen of Mathurā. There will be a royal treasurer with the initial Bh, A worshiper of mantra [deities].[3288]

bram ze 'di dag bstan pa ni/ / ston pa'i bstan pa mchod byed pa'o/ / thog ma bar mthar gtso bo ste/ / rnam pa sna tshogs gnas dang rigs/ / sna tshogs phyogs kyi bram ze rnams/ / bram ze gzhan gyis mchod par byed/ / mu stegs sna tshogs rigs dang ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs spyod yul spyod/ / gnas ni kun tu gsungs pa ste/ / bram ze'i khye'u mang thos yin/ / rang byung sangs rgyas chos kyi rgyal/ / sems can kun gyi don sgrub pa/ / sems can rnams ni ma lus dang / / lha gnas kyis kyang mchod pa'o/ / rgyal po chen po bzhi po yang / / 'jig rten kun la grags pa ste/ / 'phags skyes po dang mig mi bzang / / yul 'khor srung dang gnod sbyin rgyal/ /

“These brahmins, foretold as Worshipers of the Teacher’s teachings, Will be members of different houses and lineages, Prominent at the beginning, middle, and end.[3289] “These and other brahmins will worship Among [other] brahmins in different places. They will belong to different brahmanical orders and lineages And will follow different types of practices. They are foretold as full-fledged ascetics, Ordained as novices and very learned. “The self-realized buddha, the Dharma king[3290] Who fulfills the aims of all beings, Is glorified by all the spirits And also by the three gods. “The four great kings Are celebrated in all the worlds. They are Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and the king of the yakṣas.[3291]

brgya byin de nas lha rnams kyi/ / nges pa'i tshig ni rab tu bsgrags/ / 'thab bral lha yi bu dang ni/ / 'phrul dga' gzhan 'phrul dbang byed dang / / rgyal po dga' ldan gsungs pa dang / / 'dod pa'i khams kyi dbang phyug mchog / gcig gi ming ni brgya byin sogs/ / de bzhin 'dod khams dbang phyug yin/ / de yang rtag tu gcig gnas te/ / rdzu 'phrul chen po gcig gi gzugs/ / de yang mtha' yas dag tu bstan/ / rnam pa sna tshogs gzugs 'chang lha/ / de las gong du thams cad mnyam/ / de yang thams cad rdzu 'phrul che/ / lha yi gtso bo ming gcig ste/ / 'du shes med pa'i mthar yang bstan/ / de dag gtso bo med pa ste/ / mnyam pa'i tshul du yang dag gnas/ / 'og tu mnar med mthar thug par/ / der ni rgyal po yod ma yin/ /

Śakra is glorified as The long-lived[3292] among the gods. “There are the gods of the Suyāma, Sunirmita, and Vaśavartin realms,[3293] And the king called Santuṣita Is said to be the supreme lord of the desire realm. “Śakra and the other individually named gods Are, likewise, lords of the desire realm. Endowed with powers and majesty, they share a single nature, Always being one and the same person. “The gods who possess different forms Are described as infinite. The gods above them are all equal, With equal powers and majesty. “Known to be this way, The higher gods are said to be in harmony. There is no overlord among them, As they are all of the same status. “Below, down to the Avīci hell, There is no king to be found.[3294]

The eight [major hells] are the best known, Each surrounded by sixteen smaller ones. “The kings of nonhuman beings are karmic kings. King Yama is thus the lord of the pretas. Suvarṇa, a majestic garuḍa, Is the king of the birds. “[The king] of the kinnaras is called Druma, And that of the bhūtas, Rudra. The king of the vidyādharas Is the majestic Citraketu.[3295] “Similarly,[3296] the supreme king of the asuras Is called Vemacitri; Of the ṛṣis, Vyāsa; And of the siddhas, Mahāratha. “The moon is the king of the nakṣatras, And the sun, of the planets. The king of the mātṛs Is widely known as Īśāna. “The king of the days[3297] is called Pratima, And that of the rāśis, Kanya. The king of the rivers is called Sāgara, And that of the clouds, Supuṣkara. “Airāvata is the king of the elephants, And Harivara, the king of the horses. Prahlāda is known as the king Of all the animals everywhere. “The types of beings are said to be innumerable, And so are their kings. Everywhere, in each of their respective worlds, There is a buddha‍—the supreme person. “There is no supreme ruler In Uttarakuru and so forth, Nor there is one on the western islands That extend from the east to the west.[3298] “There are kings, though, among The inhabitants of Jambūdvīpa and also in the east. The wheel-holding monarchs on the four islands Where there are kings are said to be infinite.[3299] “These [kings] have been described in brief, Condensing the very extensive narrative. There are also numerous lords of spirits And of beings born as asuras or the three types of gods.[3300] “They reside in infinite world spheres And possess infinite qualities. Those that dwell on earth are innumerable, As described in this manual. “Both the kings of mantras And the various mantras of the hordes of dūtas Are taught as subject to the restrictions of time and place, Necessary for the mantras to succeed. “These teachings were given in brief By the eminent sages, And now they have been taught again By them[3301] above the realm of the Pure Abode.” The great hero Mañjuśrī Then asked the guide of the world, “Regarding these teachings, How should I remember them?”[3302] . . . And so forth, repeating in full the deeds of all the kings.[3303] “The supreme sage taught to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, the stories of his former births, the Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra,[3304] “And also the full extent of mantras That serve the aims of the bodhisattvas. These teachings, known as the sūtra teachings, Are to explain the path whose goal is awakening.[3305] “[He also taught] in full the rites that involve mantras, The activities and lifespans of people on earth, The time of death of the kings, And the proclaimed duration of their lives. “This compendium of Dharma teachings, A basket of writings dedicated to awakening, Is described as leading to such Through the direct application of the mantra methods. You, the sagacious one, should always remember it as The fulfiller of the goals of the mantra system.” This concludes the fifty-third chapter, with the prophecy about the kings, from “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings, complete with all the chapters.[3306]
phan yon dang nyes dmigs kyi nus pa
Chapter 54

Directing his gaze again at the realm of the Pure Abode, the blessed Śākyamuni said this to Mañjuśrī, the divine youth: “Wherever, Mañjuśrī, this Dharma discourse is disseminated, you should know that I am present there myself, surrounded by the hosts of all the bodhisattvas, taking the place of honor among the congregation of śrāvakas, and attended upon by a retinue of all the gods, nāgas, yakṣas, garuḍas, gandharvas, kinnaras, mahoragas, siddhas, vidyādharas, and other nonhuman and human beings. The Tathāgata resides there for the sake of protecting, sheltering, and defending.

'jam dpal de bas na/ de ltar phyi ma'i tshe phyi ma'i dus su rigs kyi bu'am/ rigs kyi bu mo gang la las de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi chos kyi mdzod 'di glegs bam du chud par byas te/ 'dri bar 'gyur/ klog par 'gyur/ kha ton du byed par 'gyur ba'am glegs bam du byas te 'chang bar 'gyur/ / gus par byas te yid la byed par 'gyur/ / gos rnam pa sna tshogs dang / phye ma dang / gdugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan dang / dril bu dang / rol mo dang / phreng ba dang / byug pa dang / spos dang / dri dang / dri zhim po dag gis mchod par byed par 'gyur/ / ri mor byed par 'gyur/ yang dag par 'dzin par byed par 'gyur/ / yid rtse gcig pa'i sems kyis chos byed par 'gyur ba de la ni/ / phan yon bcu po 'di dag tu 'gyur te/ / bcu gang zhe na/

“One should know, Mañjuśrī, divine youth, about the ten advantages obtained in any place where this Dharma treasury of the tathāgatas is written down in the form of a book, read aloud, memorized, or respectfully and sincerely worshiped with various implements such as yak-tail whisks, streamers, parasols, banners, flags, bells, music, garlands, scented oils, incense, or pleasant fragrances. These ten advantages are obtained in any place where this Dharma treasury is revered, reflected upon, or focused upon with an undivided mind. What are these ten? [3307]

der 'di la pha rol gyi dmag tshogs kyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur/ / char 'bab pa mi mkhas pa dang gza' dang 'ching ba chen po'i 'tshe ba 'byung bar mi 'gyur/ / mi ma yin pa'i 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la mi'i 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur/ / phyir rgol ba thams cad kyi 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la nad kyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / dus ma yin par 'chi ba'i 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la dus ma yin pa'i char gyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / char ches pa'i 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la rlung chen po'i dkyil 'khor gyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / sha za thams cad kyi 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la dgra'i 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du g.yon can rkun po'i 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la 'chi ba'i 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / gshin rje'i rgyal pos khyer ba'i 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la chom rkun gyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / lha thams cad dang klu dang gnod sbyin dang dri za'i 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la gzhan gyi sngags kyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / sbyar ba'i dug thams cad kyi 'jigs pa'am/ der 'di la nad kyi 'jigs pa dang / rims dang / tshad par 'khru ba dang / ma zhu ba dang / yan lag dang / nying lag gi nad kyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur te/ phan yon bcu po 'di dag tu shes par bya'o/ / gang du de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi cho ga chen po rab 'byam chos kyi mdzod 'di glegs bam du byas te/ bzhag la 'dri ba dang / klog pa dang / mchod pa dang / 'dzin pa dang kha ton du byed na de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis shin tu bzung zhing chos kyi mdzod mngon du 'gyur ro/ /

“There will be (1) no danger in that [place] of military invasions or hunger; (2) no pestilence caused by Mahāmārī or other dangers from nonhuman beings; (3) no danger of fire or anything untoward; (4) no danger of drought or excessive rains; (5) no danger of hurricanes, tornadoes, or kravyādas; (6) no danger from Śakra or any rogues or robbers; (7) no danger of untimely death or fear caused by King Yama; (8) no danger from asuras or any gods, nāgas, yakṣas, or gandharvas; (9) no danger from mantras, venoms, or poisons; and (10) no danger of disease, fever, dysentery, indigestion, or other danger to body or limb.[3308] One should know that these ten benefits occur wherever this Dharma treasury of the tathāgatas, contained in this great extensive manual, is kept in the form of a book. Let us therefore write it down, read it aloud, worship it, memorize it, and rehearse it.[3309]

dam tshig gi spyod pa la rjes su ma zhugs pa dang dam tshig mi shes pa gzhan dag la ni rnam pa thams cad du bstan par mi bya ste/ gang gi phyir 'di ni gsang ba yin pa'i phyir te/ 'dis ni thams cad mtshon pa yin na sems can rnams kyi dran pa med par ma byed cig /

“This Dharma treasury of the tathāgatas is extremely occult, as it depends in every respect on the mantras.[3310] It must not be taught to those who have not received the samaya from the master[3311] or those who do not understand the samaya. Why is this? This is because it is secret; it is an occult teaching. It is a teaching [arising from] omniscience. No beings should ever reject or take it lightly.[3312]

'on kyang khyod kyis shes par 'gyur mchod pa byed par 'gyur yang dag par 'dzin par 'gyur zhing bsod nams chen po yang rab tu skye bar 'gyur ro/ / sems can skal ba med pa rnams la bstan par mi bya ste/ gzhan du na dbul ba dang / nad dang / mdze dang / 'tshe ba dang / 'go ba'i nad nyid byed par 'gyur ro/ / de bas na gzhan dag la yang bstan par mi bya'o/ / dam tshig dang gsang ba pa dang gsang ba'i sngags kyi spyod pa la rjes su zhugs pa'i sems can rnams dang de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa la legs par bslab pa rnams dang legs par rnam par bzhag pa'i dran pa dang ldan pa rnams dang / chos kyi don la mkhas pa rnams dang bsam gtan la rab tu zhugs pa dang chos la gnas pa dang bden par smra ba dang sems can gyi spyod pa la rab tu gnas shing snying rje'i spyod pa dang rab tu ldan pa rnams te/ sems can 'di dag la bstan par bya'i gzhan dag la ni ma yin no/ /

“If [those who received it] do not worship [this Dharma treasury] and treat it with respect, they will incur a lot of negativity. One must not disclose it to others, as they could commit negative acts, such as suppressing the secret [practices], killing sentient beings, reporting [you] to the king, shortening lives, or causing other misfortunes.[3313] It can only be disclosed to beings who have taken up the secret practice of mantras and keep their samaya secret‍—to beings who are well established and trained in the study and practice of the Tathāgata’s instructions, who have good knowledge of the meaning of the Dharma, who keep their samaya concerning the sense bases and psychophysical elements,[3314] and who live by the Dharma and are thus true to their promises, firm in their observances, have entered the path of good conduct, and are compassionate. It can be disclosed only to them and not to others.”

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa stan las langs te/ bla gos phrag pa gcig tu gzar nas/ pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs te/ / thal mo sbyar ba byas nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das chos kyi rnam grangs 'di'i ming ci zhes bya/ / 'di bdag gis ji ltar gzung bar bgyi/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi rnam par 'phrul pa byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod ces bya bar yang zung shig / ngo mtshar rmad du byung ba'i chos kyi man ngag legs par bstan pa'i le'u zhes bya bar yang zung shig / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa'i rjes su 'jug pa rgyud thams cad kyi mdzod ces bya bar yang zung shig / theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa nges par bstan pa nyams pa med pa zhes bya bar yang zung shig / byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod ces bya bar yang zung shig /

The bodhisattva Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, rose from his seat, draped his robe over one shoulder, placed his right knee on the ground, and asked the Blessed One with folded hands, “What is this Dharma discourse really,[3315] O Blessed One? What should I remember it as?” The Blessed One replied: “You should remember it as a basket of bodhisattva teachings, the thundering roar of all the buddhas and bodhisattvas. “You should remember it as a text that contains the marvelous and wondrous Dharma instructions. “You should remember it as the bodhisattvas’ instructions for taking up all the practices of the ‘mantra basket.’[3316] “You should remember it as an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra with marvelous instructions.[3317]
'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga zhes bya bar yang zung shig / chos thams cad kyi don rdzogs pa nges par bstan pa zhes bya bar yang zung shig /
“You should remember it as the root manual of Noble Mañjuśrī. “You should remember it as the instructions that fulfill all the aims of the Dharma.

'jig rten ma lus thams cad la/ / chos dang chos min rnam spyod cing / / byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul che/ / gang khyod kun tu rnam par rgyu/ / de bzhin chos kyi dam pa mchog / gsang ba gzhan ni ma mthong ngo / / sngags rgyud don dang mdo rnams dang / / 'gro ba yul ni skyon med dang / / byang chub chos la rab gzhol ba/ / dpa' bo gzhan ni ma mthong ngo / / gang 'di bla ma gsang ba dang / / drang don mdo yis yongs su brgyan/ /

“You are a very powerful bodhisattva Who travels everywhere Throughout every realm where there are Those who practice the Dharma and those who do not. “Do you not see that this profoundly secret teaching Is the best of the best among the sūtras That treat the subject of the mantra methods, As it removes the dangers related to the place of rebirth? “Do you not see, O valiant one, That this supreme teaching has awakening as its goal? That an esoteric sūtra such as this Is adorned with the meaning that needs to be inferred?[3318]

rnam pa sna tshogs mdo don dang / / sngags dang rgyud kyi rjes 'jug pa/ / cho ga rab 'byam 'di las gzhan/ / ma byung gang yang yod ma yin/ / rgyal srid chen po longs spyod che/ / lha gnas dag tu'ang phun sum tshogs/ / de bzhin lha dang mi rnams kyi/ / grags pa rgyas pa'ang thob par 'gyur/ / mi khom brgyad ni spong byed cing / / dal ba dag ni thob par byed/ / theg pa rnam gsum bdag po dang / / de nges sangs rgyas nyid thob 'gyur/ /

“The diverse meanings of the sūtras Are presented here according to the mantra system. There is no other such sūtra in existence, Apart from this extensive manual of rites. “One can obtain kingship, great comforts, The great fortunes of the gods, Prosperity, and fame, Both celestial and human. “One will be able to avoid the eight unfree states, And bring about the eight freedoms. One will become a master of the three vehicles[3319] Destined to attain buddhahood.

mdo 'di 'dzin pa'i bsod nams dang / / de bzhin du ni phan yon 'di/ / 'di yi lus la mtshon mi 'byung / / dug dang mes kyang ma yin no/ / ro langs dang ni gdon dang ni/ / de bzhin srul po ma mo dang / / srin po sha zas 'tshe byed pa'ang / / gang zhig mdo 'di 'don la min/ / 'chang ba dang ni klog pa dang / / yang dang yang du mchod byed dang / / 'jigs pa med pas mchod byed dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs mchod byed de/ / phan yon 'di ni rab bstan pa/ / 'jig rten 'dir ni thob 'gyur ba/ / nad pa rnams ni nad las grol/ / sdug bsngal can ni bde bar 'gyur/ / dbul pos nor ni rnyed 'gyur te/ / bcings pa rnams ni 'ching las grol/ / 'gro ba lnga dang ldan pa yi/ / 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal ltung ba rnams/ / bde ba zhi ba mya ngan 'das/ / mi g.yo go 'phang 'thob par 'gyur/ / rang rgyal sangs rgyas nyid dang ni/ / nyan thos mthar ni phyin par 'gyur/ / mdo sde 'di ni bklag pa yis/ / sangs rgyas sku mdog thob par 'gyur/ /

“There is merit in memorizing this sūtra And there are the following advantages: Neither poison nor fire will be able To harm any part of one’s body, “And whatever vetālas, grahas, Pūtanas, mātṛs, thieves,[3320] Rākṣasas, or piśācas there are,[3321] “They will not be able to harm Someone who recites this sūtra, Memorizes it, or worships it, again and again, With offerings of various kinds. “Fearless, one should worship it With music[3322] and anything that may be offered. One will then obtain The following advantages: “If one is unwell, one will be freed from disease. If one experiences suffering, one will become happy. If one is poor, one will obtain wealth. If one is in bondage, one will be freed. “One who has fallen into the suffering of saṃsāra With its five realms of rebirth Will attain the unwavering state Of well-being, happiness, and nirvāṇa. “One will realize the awakening of a pratyekabuddha Or attain the state of a śrāvaka. If one reads this sūtra aloud, One will attain buddhahood.[3323]

gang gA'i bye ma mnyam pa yis/ / rgyal ba mchog ni mtha' yas pa/ / mchod pas thob pa'i bsod nams dang / / mdo 'di bton pa'i bsod nams mnyam/ / 'jig rten ji snyed gang su dag / zhing ni bye ba mtha' yas pa/ / de srid phra rab rdul snyed kyi/ / sangs rgyas rnams la rtag mchod pa/ / rnam pa sna tshogs bza' btung dang / / na ba rnams kyi gso sman dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs gnas mal rnams/ / rtag tu thams cad rab sbyin dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs gos dang ni/ / phye ma dag ni kun gyis kyang / / bsod nams skye bos thob gang yin/ / 'di dag 'chang dang klog pas so/ / gang zhig rang sangs rgyas rnams dang / / 'jig rten nyan thos rdzu 'phrul che/ / byang chub sems dpa' bdag nyid che/ / sa bcu la gnas de las gzhan/ / de rnams tshad ni de mnyam la/ / de dag mchod pa'ang de bzhin te/ / gang gi lag par glegs bam chud/ / mi yis de mnyam bsod nams thob/ /

“The merit of reciting this sūtra is the same as All the merit that one would obtain through Worshiping the victorious ones, said to be As uncountable as the sand grains in the Gaṅgā. “If one were to continually worship the names Of the buddhas as numerous as the atoms In the tens of millions of inconceivable [buddha]fields, However many there are in this world; “If one were to offer to these buddhas various types Of food, drink, invigorating tonics, And various seats and beds, Giving them continually to all of them; “And if one were to offer them various garments, Scented powders, robes,[3324] ornaments, Parasols, shoes, cloth, Fragrances, garlands, unguents, “And various types of incense, With lamps all around, The merit thus obtained would be the same As the merit obtained by memorizing and reciting this teaching. “However many pratyekabuddhas there are In this world, or śrāvakas of great majesty, Or bodhisattvas, great beings Established on the tenth level, “The merit that one would obtain Through worshiping them Would be the same as the merit of someone Who holds [this sūtra] volume in their hand.

'jig rten ji snyed bstan pa yang / / 'jig rten khams na gnas pa yi/ / grangs med sems can ma lus pa/ / thams cad nad ni med byas te/ / skye bo gang zhig yang dang yang / / bkur stir byas nas de mchod pa/ / chos mchog 'di la mchod na ni/ / blo ldan de yis bsod nams 'thob/ / bskal pa bye ba mtha' yas par/ / rgyal ba mchog gis rtag par yang / / 'jig rten mgon chos mdzad mchog 'di/ / mchod par yang ni mi nus so/ / chos mchog 'di ni sa steng du/ / yid bzhin nor bu rin chen 'dra/ / 'jam pa'i cho ga 'dir gsungs pa/ / bklags pa dang ni 'chang ba yis/ / des ni 'dod 'jo'i ba 'drar 'gyur/ / longs spyod che nor phun sum tshogs/ / yid ni skyo ba med byas nas/ / sa steng 'di ni rab tu sgrub/ / sngags dang rgyud don drang ba'i don/ / don yod tshig ni rab bshad pa/ /

“However many beings are said to dwell In the world with its spheres, Who are described as being free From the fever [of the afflictions], “The merit that one would obtain Through worshiping them sincerely, again and again, Would be the same that a wise person would obtain Through worshiping this supreme teaching. “Not even the most eminent, jewel-like victors Can obtain the same merit in tens of millions of eons That one can obtain through worshiping This finest Dharma treasury of the lords of the world. “If one recites and memorizes the mantras Taught by Mañjughoṣa in this manual, This supreme teaching will become A precious wish-fulfilling jewel. “It will become a cow of plenty for the reciter, And a source of great enjoyment and wealth. If someone with an indefatigable mind Accomplishes these mantras here on earth, “They will bring results, as taught by the Sage, With the inferred meaning becoming the true meaning.[3325]

bya ba dus la brten nas ni/ / sa steng rig pa 'dzin bsgrub na/ / rin chen phun tshogs rab gang ba/ / de yi phyogs kun dag tu gsungs/ / 'bras bcas 'gro ba'i bdag nyid che/ / spyod pa bzang bar brjod pa yin/ / gang zhig cho ga mchog 'di las/ / rgyal po sngags gcig 'chang byed pa/ / rgyal srid phun sum tshogs don bcas/ / tshe ring phun sum tshogs par 'gyur/ / rnam pa sna tshogs longs spyod tshogs/ / rgyal mchog dam pas 'thob par 'gyur/ / 'gro dang gnas pa'i dug dag dang / / gzhan gyis byas pa'i rig pa dang / / ro langs sngags kyis sgrub pa dang / / mtshon gyis kyang ni gnod mi 'gyur/ / gzhan gyi gnod byed gtsor byed pas/ / sa steng 'jig rten gnod mi byed/ / chom rkun nad ni gzhan dag dang / / me yi 'jigs pa de la med/ / rgyal po skye bo dag kyang rung / / su zhig de la mchod mi byed/ /

If one performs the rites at the right time, One will become a vidyādhara on earth. “All the places, it is said, will be replete for him With precious good fortune. His illustrious course of rebirths will be fruitful, And his actions will be praised by the good. “Should a king memorize a single mantra From this excellent manual, He will obtain a royal fortune with all its benefits, And a long and prosperous life. “Such a distinguished king will obtain A life of various pleasurable pursuits. He will not be harmed by weapons or poisons, Whether from animate or inanimate sources, “Or the effects of inimical magical vidyās, Such as the mantras employed in the vetāla practices. Corrupt practitioners who engage in hostile rites Here on earth will not be able to harm him. “He will not be in any danger of fire. Malevolent grahas or other such beings Will not assail his body, regardless of Whether he is a king or an ordinary person.[3326]

gang zhig mdo sde dkon mchog 'di/ / 'chang dang klog pa'ang de bzhin no/ / rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bo nas/ / dbang bskur yul du nyer gnas tshe/ / mdo sde mgo la nges bcings nas/ / yang dang yang du phyag 'tshal na/ / de la rkun pos mi gnod cing / / mtshon gyis de la phog mi 'gyur/ / gzhon nu'i gzugs su yang dag byung / / rma bya'i gdan la legs bkod pa/ / glang po'i mtshog ma'i steng bzhag nas/ / g.yul du yang dag zhugs byas na/ / skye bo rnams sdang de dag kun/ / mthong ba tsam gyis ldog par byed/ / byis pa'i gzugs can bzang po ni/ / gzhon nu'i rgyan gyis yongs su brgyan/ / gser dang dngul dang ra gan gyis/ / rgyal mtshan yu ba bsgreng ba la/ / rgyal mtshan ba dan btags nas ni/ / legs dgad legs par mnyam par bzhag / g.yul du dgras ni legs gang ba/ / mtshon cha sna tshogs thogs byed pa/ / thams cad g.yul du 'dus pa la/ / de yi tshe na 'jug par bya/ /

“The same applies to any person who memorizes And recites this excellent sūtra of great importance. Any king who, before a battle, Places it upon his head, “So that it forms a parasol above it, And repeatedly pays homage to it, Will not be killed by lowly men With any of their various weapons.[3327] “If he sends into battle An effigy of the princely youth,[3328] Seated on a peacock seat And mounted on the back of an elephant, “The enemies, seeing the divine youth In his youthful form Adorned with ornaments, Will all become mutually hostile and retreat. “If this [effigy], made of gold or silver, Is fitted onto a banner handle, Raised up on top of banners and flags, Well positioned and well set,[3329] “And taken to a battlefield Swarming with enemies, Their various weapons raised At the commencement of fighting,

rgyal mtshan sgreng la gnas pa yi/ / gzhon nu las ni sna tshogs pa/ / rnam pa du ma'i gzugs dang ldan/ / bdag nyid chen po 'jam pa'i dbyangs/ / sa bcu'i bdag po'i bdag po ni/ / mthong ba tsam gyis 'jigs par byed/ /

rgyal rigs rgyal po chen po ni/ / 'jig rten sa srung sa gnas pa/ / dad ldan yid gnyis the tshom ni/ / rnam bral chos la mnyes gshin pa/ / bde bar gshegs la dad bskyed nas/ / snying rjes brlan pa'i yid kyis ni/ / 'dir bshad 'di dag bya ba ni/ / grub par 'dod pas rab tu bya/ / cho ga'i sbyor ba'i sngags dang ni/ / rgyud dang ldan pa sa steng du/ / chos dbyings tshogs pa'i rgyal ba yis/ / gsung rab 'di dag nges par bstan/ /

“There once was a great kṣatriya king,[3331] Who lived and reigned on earth. He had faith, was free from indecision or doubts, And was a fond patron of the Dharma. “Having generated faith in the Sugata, With a mind filled with compassion And eager to find the esoteric meaning,[3332] He undertook to perform the rituals taught here. “The victors who abide in the sphere of phenomena Taught these [rituals] as part of their doctrine. They taught them in this manual of rites that employ mantras And fit into the mantra system taught here on earth.

chos kyi dbyings dang mnyam gnas pa'i/ / rgyal mchog snga ma grangs med pas/ / sa yi steng gi mi rnams la'ang / / chos kyi mdzod ni gsungs pa yin/ / lha dang lha min sngon g.yul 'thab/ / pha rol 'jigs pa byung ba na/ / gang tshe brgya byin sngon gyur pa/ / dpung ni pham byas zhe sdang bas/ / de tshe gcig tu song nas ni/ / sa steng rnam par du bar gyur/ / rgyal mchog 'od srung de la ni/ / thub pa mchog la de tshe zhus/ /

“The innumerable victors of the past Who dwell in the sphere of phenomena Taught this Dharma treasury On earth to human beings. “In times past, while a dreadful war Was being waged between the gods and the asuras, The army of [Indra][3333] Was destroyed by its enemies.[3334] “Alone on the earth, dispirited, Without a chariot,[3335] He approached, at that time, Kāśyapa, The best of sages and the supreme Victor.

ji ltar bya zhes tshig tu ni/ / bde sogs bdag pos rnam par smras/ / mi bzad lha min gyis pham nas/ / bdag kyang 'dir ni yang dag lhags/ / de skad bcom ldan gsol nas ni/ / lha yi dbang po brgya byin gyis/ / de tshe thub mchog zhabs gnyis la/ / spyi bo'i gtsug gis rab btud nas/ / mig stong kau shi ka ni/ / de yi spyan sngar 'dug par gyur/ / de skad gsol nas thub mchog ni/ / bram zer gyur pa 'od srung gis/ / de tshe gsung du bka' stsal pa/ / ka la ping ka'i sgra skad du/ / rgyal ba mchog gis sngon gsungs pa/ / gzhon nu sna tshogs yang dag byung / /

“ ‘What can I do?’ Were the words uttered by the husband of Śacī. ‘I have been defeated by the cruel asuras And now seek refuge here with you.’ “Having said this, the god of bounty[3336] Who has performed one hundred sacrifices[3337] Bowed to the distinguished sage, Touching his feet with the top of his head, “And then the thousand-eyed Kauśika[3338] Sat down as before. The distinguished sage, brahmin Kāśyapa, Thus addressed, “Replied in a voice as sweet As the song of a cuckoo bird, ‘In the past, the supreme victors praised in songs The divine youth who is the source of everything.

bdag nyid chen po 'jam dpal ni/ / rnyed dka' sku ni 'bum gyur pa/ / yang dag mtha' la gnas nas ni/ / zab mo'i don gyi don ston byed/ / spros med rnam pa med pa dang / / gnas med pa las gzugs byas nas/ / shin tu don ldan chos kyang ston/ / lha yi dbang phyug de ni dran/ / de nas de ni de dran pas/ / byang chub sems dpa' dran tsam gyis/ / gzhon nu sna tshogs gzugs can ni/ / der ni de yi mod la lhags/ / der ni bcom ldan 'das dang ni/ / bcom ldan lha yi dbang phyug bcas/ / lhags nas byang chub sems dpa' des/ / de tshe rgyal ba mchog la btud/ / rgyal ba mchog kun phyag 'tshal nas/ / 'od chen 'od srung la yang btud/ / de tshe thub pas rjes gnang nas/ / sngags kyi tshig ni 'di smras so/ /

“ ‘He is the great being Mañjuśrī, Difficult to meet, endowed with one hundred thousand powers,[3339] And said to abide in the ultimate reality. He guides beings to the deep meaning. “ ‘You should recollect him now, O lord of gods, As one who shows the Dharma to beings, Himself being without conceptual elaboration, Mental disposition, independent existence, or location.’ “Being thus caused by Kāśyapa to be recollected, And then recollected by Indra as one who abides in reality, Precisely at that moment, The omnifarious divine youth Arrived at the place where Blessed Kāśyapa And Maghavan,[3340] the lord of gods, were.[3341] “After arriving, the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī[3342] Saluted the supreme Victor. Having bowed to all the eminent victors And to Kāśyapa of great splendor, He pronounced the following mantra After first obtaining the sage’s consent:

na maHsarba bud+d+ha bo d+hi satwe b+h+yaH/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa ne b+h+yaH/ o~M ha na ha na/ sarba b+ha yot+sA da ya trA sa ya/ mo Ta ya/ tshin+da/ b+hin+da/ dz+wa la dz+wa la/ hU~M hU~M phaT phaT swA hA/

“ ‘Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas who are perfect teachers! “ ‘Oṁ, kill, kill all those that pose danger! Destroy and annihilate them! Make them afraid! Crush, chop, and break them! Burn them, burn! Huṁ huṁ, phaṭ phaṭ, svāhā!’[3343]

byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas sngags 'di smras ma thag tu sa chen po 'di ri dang rgya mtsho'i mthar thug pa dang bcas pa rnam pa drug tu g.yos te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das thams cad kyi zhing mtha' yas pa 'jig rten gyi khams kyi phyogs kyi mthar thug pa thams cad dang bcas pa yang rab tu 'gul bar gyur to/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das thams cad kyis kyang sngags kyi tshig 'di dag byin gyis brlabs so/ / de nas lha'i dbang po brgya byin 'jigs pa dang bral nas ba spu langs te ngo mtshar rmad du byung ba thob nas/ mig gnyis phye ste/ stan las langs nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la btud nas lan gsum bskor ba byas shing / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la mngon du bltas nas sngags kyi tshig de dag bzung ste/ yid la byas nas phyir yang shing rta la zhon te/ lha ma yin gang yin pa de logs su phyin par gyur to/ / de nas lha ma yin thams cad rgya mtsho chen po'i mtha'i 'gram du gang rang gi grong khyer gang yin pa der mngon du phyogs shing song bar gyur te/ sems zhum zhing nyams la dpung gi 'jigs pas sems dkrugs shing gdong gi mdog nyams shing nga rgyal dang dregs pa la sogs pa dang bral bar gyur la/ / mtshon cha dang bral zhing ri 'bigs byed 'bar ba bzhin du lha'i dbang phyug de mthong nas byer bar gyur to/ /

“As soon as this mantra was pronounced by the great being, the divine youth Mañjuśrī, the earth with its mountains and oceans, up to its farthest reaches, shook in six different ways, and so did all the infinite buddhafields and world spheres up to their farthest limits. All the blessed buddhas empowered the words of the mantra. “Śakra, the lord of gods, his fear gone and body hair bristling, struck with amazement and wonder, his eyes wide open, rose from his seat, bowed down to the feet of the Blessed One, and circumambulated him clockwise three times. Then, turning to and looking at the divine youth Mañjuśrī, he grasped and kept in his mind the words of the mantra. He mounted his chariot and rode to where all the asuras were. Confronted by him in their subterranean paradise, in their capital city that the ocean rests upon, they all attacked. However, seeing the lord of gods blazing like fire, the asuras became smitten and dazed in their minds, and their armies were struck with fear. They now grew weak and despondent, their haughty expressions changed, and they lost their weapons. They turned back and retreated to their own abodes.[3344]

de nas lha yi dbang po brgya byin gyis sum cu rtsa gsum gyi lha rnams la smras pa/ grogs po dag ma 'jigs shig / ma 'jigs shig / sangs rgyas kyi mthus lha ma yin las bdag cag nges par rgyal bas rang gi gnas su 'gro bar bya'o/ / rang rang gi gnas ci lta ba bzhin du song nas khyod cag rtse ba dang dga' ba yongs su spyod par gyis shig / de nas lha de dag thams cad yid shin tu dga' nas phyir yang rang gi gnas su log par gyur to/ / de nas lha rnams kyi dbang po brgya byin 'di snyam du sems par gyur te/ gang bdag gis gzhon nu'i gzugs can gyi gzugs brnyan gyi rnam pa de byas la rgyal mtshan gyi rtse mo la'ang btags na/ des na gang gi lha ma yin gyi 'jigs pa mi 'byung ngo / / zhes bstan to/ / de nas lha rnams kyi dbang po brgya byin gyis chen po la 'os pa'i nor bu rin po che nang 'od dang ldan zhing gsal ba'i phreng ba blangs nas/ gzhon nu'i cha byad kyi gzugs brnyan byas te/ steng gi khang bzang du grong khyer chen po blta na sdug pa'i dbus na/ lha rnams kyi 'dun sa chos bzang kyi rtse mor rgyal mtshan bsgreng ba legs par bkod pa byas nas bzhag par gyur to/ / de nas lha ma yin de dag rab tshim byed dang / thags bzangs ris la sogs pa de dag lha rnams kyi steng du mi 'gro zhing / lha de dag kyang zil gyis gnon par mi 'gyur la/ rdzu 'phrul las rnam par 'phrul pa'am/ g.yul mngon du phyogs par 'gro bar mi nus so/ / de ltar lo bye ba khri phrag du ma mi ma yin pa'i grangs kyis bgrang bar yang lha ma yin gyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du phan yon dpag tu med pa bstan pa dang / tshe dang / nad med pa 'phel bar/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos kyang sngon du gsungs pa yin no/ / de bzhin du phan yon gyi yon tan mchog 'di dag rgya che ba dang / mtha' yas shing mu med pa sngon gsungs pa yin no/ /

“Śakra, the lord of gods, then addressed the gods in the realm of the Thirty-Three: “ ‘Do not be afraid, friends, do not be afraid! We have defeated the asuras through the power of the Buddha. Now let us go home. Come, gentlemen! Having returned to your fine houses and abodes, each of you to his own, you can play, rejoice, and move around freely.’ “And so the gods, uplifted in their minds, turned around and went to their own abodes. “Śakra, the lord of gods, thought, ‘If I make an effigy in the form of the divine youth and mount it atop a banner, there will be no danger for me from the asuras.’ The lord of gods, with his great might, procured then a precious gem called Shining with the Inner Light,[3345] fashioned from it a figure in the form of the divine youth, firmly fixed it on top of a banner, and placed it in Sudharmā, the assembly hall of the gods, at the top of the palace in the middle of his great city Sudarśana. “From then on, the asuras, headed by Prahlāda and Vemacitri, stayed in their subterranean paradise. They did not travel upward, nor did they attack the gods. They were unable to work miracles or confront anyone in battle. This will last, in human reckoning,[3346] many hundreds of thousands of billions of years. Thus, there will now be no danger from the asuras. “This celebrated [Dharma treatise] is thus a boon of infinite qualities;[3347] it promotes long life and good health, as taught by the blessed buddhas and the great beings, the bodhisattvas in the past. It is full of excellent qualities and brings infinite benefits, without beginning and without end.[3348]

gang zhig chos kyi rnam grangs 'di spangs sam/ rnam par rtog par byed na/ bsod nams ma yin pa dpag tu med pa 'phel bar 'gyur zhing / dmyal bar yang skye bar 'gyur la/ dud 'gro dang / yi dgas dang / gshin rje'i 'jig rten gyi skye ba ngan par yang 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / sman dang / sngags rnams med do/ / byang chub sems dpa' med do/ / de rnams kyi bdag nyid chen po rdzu 'phrul che ba dang / rnam par 'phrul ba yang med do/ / cho ga rgya che ba yang med do/ / 'phags pa ma yin pas bshad do/ / zhes byas nas spang ba'am/ / yang na 'gro zhing 'di nyan par mi nus so/ / zhes gnas de las gzhan du 'gro na/ de dag la bsod nams ma yin pa chen po 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Anyone who contradicts this Dharma treatise, doubts it, or thoughtlessly steps over it will accumulate boundless nonvirtue. They will fall into one of the great hells or suffer the tribulations of birth in the animal realm or the Yama realm of the pretas. Those who claim that this Dharma treatise is not the word of the Buddha and that the mantras and the remedies in it do not come from the bodhisattvas, who deny the greatness of the bodhisattvas and their power to work miracles, who throw away or abandon this Dharma treatise claiming that it was originally taught by dishonorable people, they will proceed to the lower states of existence where they will be unable to understand this Dharma treatise or even hear it. When they depart from that state, they will have accumulated a great deal of nonvirtue, so it is said.
ci ste blo chung ba gang gis chos 'di ni thub pa mchog dang / thub pa'i sras blo dang ldan pa ma yin no/ / zhes rab tu spong bar byed do/ /
“Foolish people who reject This excellent teaching Taught in song by the eminent sages And the sagacious sons of the victors[3349]

mi de dmyal bar 'gro 'gyur zhing / / de nyams nas ni dud 'gror 'gro/ / thig nag dang ni yang sos dang / / spu gri so dang me ma mur/ / ro myags chu bo rab med skye/ / de nas phyir yang spu gri sor/ / lo ma ral gri lta bu'i nags/ / yang na kyi hud zer de bzhin/ / 'jig rten grags pa so thams thams/ / sdig pa'i las kyi dmyal ba ru/ / gang gis chos ni sun byed pa/ / de ni skye ba de dag 'gro/ / 'jig rten smad par rab bstan pa/ / mi bzad mnar med pa zhes bya/ / ma dad sems kyis chos spangs pa/ / sdig pa'i las can gnas yin te/ /

“Will, because of this, go to hell, With its subdivisions lying above or horizontally,[3350] Such as Kālasūtra, Sañjīva, Kṣuradhārā, Gūthamṛttikā,[3351] “Kuṇapa, Kṣāranadī, Where they will be seized in Jvaradhārā,[3352] The terrible Asipattra forest, Avava,[3353] Hahava, “Or the hell for evildoers, Renowned in the world as Aṭaṭa. Those who bring harm upon the Dharma Will go to one of these hells. “The terrible hell called Avīci Is well known in the world As a walled-in place for reviled evildoers, Who make up its population.[3354]

gang zhig chos ni 'di 'jigs pa/ / de la skye bo de 'tshed 'gyur/ / kun gyi mthar thug mnar med pa/ / de nyams de bzhin dmyal chen skye/ / dmyal ba'i sa mtha' mtha' yas par/ / rtag tu blo med de ni 'gro/ / mdo sde de ni rgya cher bcas/ / chos kyi nor kun rab spangs nas/ / de ni 'jig rten ngan par 'gro/ / dbang med rtag par dbang du 'gro/ /

“People who destroy this teaching Will be roasted there. People who are always mindless will visit[3355] All of the hells as deep down as Avīci. “They will experience death and subsequent rebirth[3356] Throughout the infinite hell realms. Those who reject this extensive sūtra That is the sum total of the Dharma[3357] “Become reviled in the world And fall into the hells that end in Avīci, Completely deprived of their own will.[3358]

gang zhig mdo sde'i cho ga 'di/ / sngags dang rgyud kyis legs par brgyan/ / grub pa sna tshogs brgya rnams 'thob/ / yang dag mtha' ni sgrib pa med/ / chos kyi dbyings kyi sku nyid yin/ / dmigs su med pa'i ngo bo nyid/ / cho ga cho ga rgya chen bcas/ / le'u rab 'byam 'dis 'dren byed/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs ni legs dgod pa/ / phun tshogs dpal dang blo gros mchod/ / rtsa ba'i cho ga mi nyung ba/ / rgya che mang por bstan pa yin/ / rtag dang chad dang thog mtha' ni/ / gnyi ga'i mtha' don rnam par spangs/ /

“This[3359] sūtra called the ‘Manual of Rites’ Is adorned with the knowledge of mantras. Through hundreds of wonderful accomplishments, It lays bare the ultimate reality,[3360] “Which is experienced in meditation without support And constitutes the body of the sphere of phenomena. This extensive manual of rites With its detailed chapters “Was skillfully laid down by Mañjughoṣa And duly[3361] worshiped by Śrīmati. Many original rites of Mañjuśrī Are presented here in full. “This manual is free from both extreme views, Those of eternalism and of nihilism.[3362]

rim bcas rim ni nges par bstan/ / sngags kyi lus ni btus pa yin/ / me dang rlung dang nam mkha' dang / / stong pa'i de nyid legs gsungs pa/ / spangs pa rtag tu 'gro ba ni/ / 'og nas 'og tu de tshe 'gro/ / bskal pa rnam mang gsum gyi grangs/ / de tshe bsod nams yongs bsags nas/ / de tshe byang chub thob nas ni/ / bdag dang rgyal ba mchog rnams kyis/ / sngags dang rgyud kyi don gsungs pa/ / 'gro ba yul ni sdig med la'o/ / rtsa ba'i cho ga dag byed dang / / sdig pa med cing bkra shis pa'i/ / le'u rab 'byam rab gsungs pa/ / nges pa'i mdo sde bzang po yin/ /

It explains the stages in the right order And constitutes a collective body of mantras. “It clearly explains Fire, wind, and space as empty. One who rejects this manual is always reborn, Going from one low birth to another. “As the supreme Victor, I accumulated infinite merit In the course of many long eons, And attained awakening. “I subsequently taught this root manual To fulfill the aims of the mantra system. By being an auspicious means of purification that destroys negativity, This manual wards off the dangers associated with the places of rebirth. “It has been presented in detailed chapters That adorn this sūtra of definitive meaning.[3363]

sa bdag yon tan bdag nyid che/ / yul dang dus kyi sbyor ba dang / / rgyal sras mi ru skyes pa yis/ / sa steng dam pa'i chos bstan ces/ / 'jig rten gtso bo thub pa ni/ / rgyal ba bdun pas bstan pa yin/ / cho ga rgya cher gsungs pa ni/ / blo dang dpal ni mngon par 'phel/ / rtsa ba rab 'byam le'u zhes/ / sngags dang rgyud dang ldan pa de/ / gang zhig mdo mchog gtso bo 'di/ / rgyal bas mchod pa'i chos kyi mdzod/ / sa steng mis ni spong byed pa/ / de ni mnar med dmyal bar 'gro/ / bskal pa chen por de 'tshed ces/ / rnam pa du mar dbye bar bstan/ /

It includes the descriptions of the great qualities of kings Explained according to their relevant period and place. “This sacred Dharma of the victors’ sons Was taught by the seventh sage,[3364] The best among the victors Who have taken human birth on earth. “It was taught in the form of this extensive manual That produces splendor and good fortune. It is described as an extensive volume[3365] with a good foundation And is revered as part of the mantra system.[3366] “Anyone on earth who rejects This excellent, important sūtra, This Dharma treasury endowed with power by the victors, Will fall, after death, into Avīci, the worst of hells, For many great eons, as described In different works.[3367]

nam zhig gang du 'byung ba ni/ / mi yi lus su skyes na yang / / dbul zhing nad mang glen pa dang / / kla klo dag tu skye bar 'gyur/ / 'jig rten smad par 'gro ba ste/ / de ni mdze can nad par 'gyur/ / lkugs shing 'on pa yan lag nyams/ / blo nyams long ba nyid dang ni/ / rtsub cing rtag tu 'jigs pa'i gzugs/ / sa steng yi dgas lta bur snang / / gos ngan sems ni zhan pa dang / / sen mo dang ni lus kyang ngan/ / srin bu rnams kyis zos pa dang / / shu ba g.yan par yang dag ldan/ / mdo sde 'di ni rab spangs na/ / gang dang gang gis 'gro bar 'gro/ / de dang der ni skye ba na/ / blo ngan rmongs par skye bar 'gyur/ /

“During his life as a human, Whenever this happens to be, He will be poor, diseased, and dumb. He will be born as a mleccha, Will be reviled in the world, And will contract leprosy. “He will smell bad and inspire disgust. Blind and missing limbs,[3368] He will have a terribly unattractive form, Always be dirty, and look, here on earth, like a preta. “He will be poorly clothed,[3369] depressed, With ugly nails, and generally detestable. He will be eaten by parasites And will be covered by sores and blisters. “Stinking and utterly revolting, He will have no partner for conversation But will walk around absentmindedly, Becoming ever more feebleminded.[3370]

“One who rejects this Dharma treasury, This revered relic of the victorious ones, Will meet with a lot of pain And be without relatives, friends, or a protector.[3371] “As a human being, one will experience Many times grief and suffering. Wherever one goes, One will never be happy. Different [negative] results will follow If one rejects this sūtra.”[3372]

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa stan las langs te/ bla gos phrag pa gcig tu gzar nas pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs te/ mig phye zhing mi 'dzums par thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i gzhal med khang na gnas pa'i lha'i bu rnams dang / 'byung po'i tshogs du ma chos mnyan pa'i phyir 'dus par shes nas/ bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das ji tsam du chos kyi rnam grangs 'di ni ngo mtshar te/ mchog tu legs par gsungs pa lags na/ de la bcom ldan 'das ma 'ongs pa'i dus na sems can mi rigs pa'i chags pas zil gyis non pa slu bar byed pa nga rgyal can ma dad pa gya gyu can dmu rgod tshul khrims 'chal pa dag 'byung bar 'gyur te/ de dag sngags rnams kyi rtog pa'i bdag nyid chen po rgyas pa grub pa dang / dus dang / yul dang / nges par sdom pa dang / sngags dang / spyod pa dang / / sbyin sreg dang / bzlas pa nges par sdom pa dang / cho ga rab 'byam dag la ma dad par 'gyur/ yid la mi byed par 'gyur te/ sangs rgyas kyi bka' ma yin no/ / zhes byas nas spong bar 'gyur te/ de dag nyon mongs pa'i sems su gyur nas dus byed par 'gyur zhing / sdug bsngal drag cing tsha ba'i tshor ba myong zhing de dag dmyal ba chen por skye bar 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das sdug bsngal ba'i sems can de dag la ji ltar bsgrub par bya/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das ni thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa lags so/ /

The divine youth Mañjuśrī, the bodhisattva great being, now rose from his seat, draped his upper robe over his shoulder, placed his right knee on the ground, folded his hands,[3373] and, with wide open and unblinking eyes, knowing that all the gods who inhabit the Pure Abode and many orders of beings had assembled in order to hear the Dharma, said to Blessed Śākyamuni: “It is wonderful, O Blessed One, that you have presented this Dharma treatise so eloquently. In the future time, O Blessed One, it will come to pass that beings will be overcome by dangerous greed, their minds will be dominated by the five degenerations, they will lack faith, and they will be deceitful, unruly, and undisciplined.[3374] They will not believe in the greatness of the of the art of mantras, nor will they appreciate the necessity to observe the restrictions regarding the time and the place of worship. Nor will they believe in the elaborate rituals with their injunctions pertaining to the mantra conduct,[3375] homa offerings, or mantra recitation. Thinking that this is not the Buddha’s teaching, they will reject it. They will develop mental anguish and die. They will thus experience intense suffering and feel sharp and acute pain. They will end up in the great hells. When beings suffer like this, O Blessed One, how can this be remedied? The lord buddhas are very compassionate, after all.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la spyi bor byugs nas bka' stsal pa/ / 'jam dpal khyod sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir rab tu zhugs pa khyod yang legs so legs so/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa khyod de bzhin gshegs pa la don 'di yongs su zhu bar sems pa de khyod yang legs so/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa de'i phyir legs par shin tu rab tu nyon la yid la zung shig dang / sems can thams cad kyi don dang / phan pa dang / bde ba'i phyir zhugs pa dang / lha dang / mi rnams dang / 'jig rten la rab tu brtse ba'i phyir ngas khyod la bshad do/ / spyod pa thams cad la zhugs pa dang / byang chub kyi lam dang / thams cad shes pa dang / chos kyi dbyings la 'jug pa dang / 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi sku la gnas par 'dod pa rnams kyis rig pa'i rgyal po mchog tu gsang ba/ gzhon nu khyod kyi rtsa ba'i cho ga'i le'u rab 'byam 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe yang 'di dran par bya'o/ / de gang zhe na/

The blessed Śākyamuni touched Mañjuśrī, the divine youth, on the head, and said, “Good it is, good indeed, that you, Mañjuśrī, are concerned about the welfare and the interests of all beings, and it is also good that you, Mañjuśrī, ask the Tathāgata about it. Listen well, then, and duly reflect upon what I will now tell you for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of all beings and to act kindly toward the world. There is, O divine youth, in your root manual with its detailed chapters, a most secret vidyārāja that should be remembered at the time of death by men and gods who strongly desire to take the final refuge in the supreme body of the dharmadhātu,[3376] thus taking the path to awakening that subsumes all mantra practices. So what is this vidyā?

na ma s+t+rai ya d+h+wa ta thA ga te b+h+yaH/ ar had b+h+yaH/ samya k+saM bud+d+he b+h+yaH/ o~M ku mA ra rU pi Ne/ bi shwa saM b+ha ba/ A gats+tsha/ A gats+tsha/ la hu la hu/ b+h+rU~M b+h+rU~M/ dzi na dzi ka many+dzu shri ye/ su shri ye/ tA ra ya mA~M/ sarba duHkhe b+h+yaH/ phaT phaT/ sha ma ya sha ma ya/ a mr-i tod+d+ha ba/ pA paM me nA sha ya swA hA/

“Homage to all the worthy tathāgatas, the fully realized buddhas! “Oṁ, the omnifarious form[3377] of the divine youth, come, come! Quick, quick! Bhrūṃ bhrūṃ, hūṁ hūṁ![3378] O victorious Victor! Splendorous Mañjuśrī![3379] Deliver me from all suffering! Phaṭ phaṭ! Pacify, pacify! You who arise from and are the source of immortality,[3380] destroy my negativity, svāhā![3381]

'jam dpal 'di ni khyod kyi snying po dam pa yin te/ zhi ba thams cad byed pa/ sdig pa thams cad zad par byed pa/ sdug bsngal thams cad las rab tu grol bar byed pa/ tshe dang / nad med pa dang / dbang phyug dang / skal ba bzang po mchog dang / ngag gi dbang phyug skyed par byed pa/ rig pa'i rgyal po thams cad gzengs stod par byed pa/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas 'di gsungs ma thag tu sa chen po ri dang rgya mtsho dang bcas pa/ sems can dang snod nye ba'i mthar thug pa rnam pa drug tu rab tu g.yos par gyur to/ / 'gro ba thams cad de yi dgas kyi 'gro ba dang / dud 'gro dang / gshin rje'i 'jig rten dang / dmyal ba'i sems can thams cad kyi sdug bsngal rab tu sbyangs shing / bde ba rnams kyang rab tu thob par 'gyur la/

“This, Mañjuśrī, is your ultimate heart essence that makes everything peaceful, removes all negativity, and releases from all suffering. It brings long life, good health, vigor, supreme well-being, and increases the powers of speech. It also stirs up the goodness in all the vidyā kings.”[3382] As soon as the blessed Buddha Śākyamuni pronounced this mantra, this great earth with all its mountains, oceans, and animate and inanimate things, up to its farthest reaches, shook in six different ways, and the sufferings of all the beings of the different classes‍—the pretas, the animals, and all the beings in the worlds of Yama[3383] ‍—completely ceased.[3384]

'jam dpal rig pa'i rgyal po 'di yang yid la byed cing / de'i tshe dam pa'i chos spong ba'i sems kyang med par 'gyur na/ bdud sdig to can gyis kyang glags rnyed par mi 'gyur la/ bgegs dang log 'dren thams cad kyang 'byer bar 'gyur ro/ / 'di ltar yang sems bskyed par bya ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi sangs rgyas dang / chos ni bsam gyis mi khyab ste/ bsam pa'am/ gzhal ba'am/ spang bar ni bdag gis ci zhig nus te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das nyid kyis mkhyen par 'gyur ro/ /

“This king of mantras, Mañjuśrī, should be kept in mind, so that, at that time,[3385] there will be no thought of giving up the sacred Dharma, the evil māras will not have any opportunity to cause harm, and all the vighnas and vināyakas will run away. “The blessed buddhas will know my thoughts, if I should reflect, ‘What am I capable of? Will I accept or reject the inconceivable Dharma of the realization of the blessed buddhas?’ ”[3386]

'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i cho ga byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ phan yon dang nyes dmigs kyi nus pa rab 'byam bstan pa'i le'u sum cu rtsa drug pa rdzogs so// //

This concludes the detailed chapter about the consequences of praising or blaming [this Dharma manual], fifty-fourth[3387] in “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” an extensive Mahāyāna sūtra that forms a garland-like basket of bodhisattva teachings.[3388]

bcom ldan 'das kyis de skad ces bka' stsal nas/ dge slong de dag dang / byang chub sems dpa' de dag dang / thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor de dag dang / gnas gtsang ma'i steng na gnas pa'i lha'i bu'i tshogs rnams dang / sems can bye ba khri phrag brgya stong du ma dang / lha dang / klu dang / gnod sbyin dang / dri za dang / lha ma yin dang / nam mkha' lding dang / mi'am ci dang / lto 'phye chen po dang / grub pa dang / rig 'dzin dang / drang srong mchog dam pa du ma dang / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa dang / spyan ras gzigs dang / byams pa dang / mthu chen thob dang / mthu chen gnas dang / phyag na rdo rje la sogs pa byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams dang / 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med pa dang / chos kyi dbyings mtha' yas pa na bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas kyi 'khor dang bcas pa dang / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das nam mkha'i ngo bo dang 'dra bar bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po bsam gyis mi khyab pa rnams thugs rangs te/ bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa la mngon par bstod do/ /

When the Blessed One had finished teaching, the monks, the bodhisattvas, their retinues, and billions of other beings present above the Pure Abode[3389] such as gods, nāgas, yakṣas, gandharvas, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, mahoragas, siddhas, and vidyādharas; as well as many prominent ṛṣis and the great bodhisattva beings including the divine youth Mañjuśrī, Avalokiteśvara, Maitreya, Mahāsthānaprāpta,[3390] Vajrapāṇi, and so forth; the blessed buddhas with the retinues of śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas who dwell in innumerable world systems and in the infinite sphere of phenomena; and the inconceivable buddhas dwelling in the sky-like nature and the bodhisattva great beings, were all very pleased and praised the Blessed One’s teaching.[3391]
'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i rgyud rdzogs so// //
This concludes “The Root Manual of Noble Mañjuśrī,” presented as it was passed down.[3392]
'gyur byang
Colophon

dpal lha btsan po lha btsun pa byang chub 'od kyi bkas/ rgya gar gyi mkhan po dge bsnyen chen po ku mA ra ka la sha dang / sgra sgyur gyi lots+tsha ba dge slong shAkya blo gros kyis bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa'o// //

By order of the glorious ruler and renunciant king Jangchub O, this text was translated, edited, and finalized by the great Indian preceptor and spiritual teacher Kumārakalaśa and the translator Lotsawa and monk Śākya Lodrö.[3393]
